title: Ethiopian Electric Power HQ Building, Ethiopia
body:
• Build an energy-efficient and sustainable green main office building for Ethiopian Electric Power (EEP) situated in Addis Ababa's financial district
  • The building will cover a total area of 20,792 square metres and a total built-up area of 197,800 square metres
  • When completed, it will have a total floor area of 208,724 square metres and a height of 345.5 metres
  • The building will have 62 floors and the main components of the works are as follows:
    o Basements 1-3: Parking spaces, MEP Rooms
       Podium Levels:
    o Ground Floor: EEP Office Lobby, Commercial Offices Lobby, Retail Spaces, services
    o First Floor: Retail Spaces, services
    o Tower levels 1 to 55: Office spaces, sky gardens, services
    o Tower level 56: Sky Garden, Technical Floor
    o Tower level 57: Restaurant
  • This project will be carried out under an EPC contract and is expected to be completed in four years
  • Dar al-Handasah is the consultant for design and construction supervision
  • EEP is looking at various financing options to cover the cost of the construction  and once the bidding process is completed, the total cost of the construction will be announced
specifications: ["208,724 square metres floor area ","345.5 metres tall"]

title: Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points (DWT/CTP), Ghana
body:
Pecan Energies has a 50 per cent  interest in the Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points block (DWT/CTP), covering approximately 2,010 square kilometres in a prolific petroleum region approximately 115 kilometres offshore Ghana. Partners in the DWT/CTP block include: 

  • Lukoil Overseas Ghana Tano Limited, 38 per cent
  • Fueltrade Limited 2%
  • Ghana National Petroleum Corporation, 10%

Source: Pecan Energies 

 

  • Location: Deepwater Tano/Cape Three Points (DWT/CTP) block, offshore Ghana
  • Water Depth: ~2,400 meters
  • Reserves Estimate: 334 million barrels of recoverable oil
  • Plateau Production Target: 110,000 barrels of oil per day (b/d)
  • Development Status: Pre-development / Early development planning

Scope of Work

Development Concept:

  • FPSO Unit:
    • A single Floating Production, Storage, and Offloading (FPSO) vessel to handle production, processing, and offloading of crude oil.
    • Topsides will include oil processing, gas compression, water injection, and utilities systems.
  • Subsea Production System:
    • Fully subsea field development with tiebacks to the FPSO.
    • Use of dynamic risers, umbilicals, manifolds, and flowlines for well connection.

Drilling Program:

  • Total Wells: Up to 26 subsea wells.
  • 14 production wells: Horizontal advanced oil wells targeting peak productivity.
  • 12 injection wells: Alternating water and gas injection (WAG) wells for pressure maintenance and enhanced oil recovery.

Artificial Lift:

  • Use of multiphase pumps to enable artificial lift and increase oil recovery efficiency.

title: Tendrara Production Concession, Morocco
body:
Resource Potential:

Recoverable Resources of 377 Bcf gross / 75.4 Bcf net (2C Resources)1 in the TE-5 Horst gas discovery, sub-salt Triassic TAGI reservoir

Interests:

  • Mana Energy (Operator) 55%
  • Sound Energy 20%
  • ONHYM 25%

Future Developments

Potential capacity to meet gas demand in a phased manner with Phase I being the implementation of a micro LNG development scheme and Phase II being the development of a larger scale central processing facility (“CPF”) and gas export pipeline. 

Phase 1

Micro LNG Development

Deployment of field gas treatment, processing, liquefaction and storage facilities to deliver mobile LNG to buyer at site. 

Phase 2

Tendrara TE-5 Development

Gas as a transition fuel flowing to the GME pipeline

  • 20’’ inch, 120km Tendrara Gas Export Pipeline (“TGEP”):
  • Tie-in to existing GME pipeline (Station M04): FEED completed by Metragaz (EMPL operator)
  • FEED completed by Enagás Consortium for a 70 mmscf/d raw gas processing capacity Central Processing Facility (“CPF”)
  • Gas Sales Agreement (“GSA”) with ONEE (Office National de l’Electricite et de l’Eau potable) signed November 2021 for domestic power plants for gas-to-power generation (transit via GME line), minimum volume of 0.3 bcm/year
  • Six horizontal wells planned for First Gas (Phase 2)

Source: Sound Energy

title: Ima Upstream Gas Project, Nigeria
body:
• Location: Offshore Nigeria, Oil Mining Lease (OML) 112
  • Operatorship: Amni International Petroleum Development Company Limited (60%)
  • Partner: TotalEnergies E&P Nigeria Limited (40%)
  • Discovery Year: 1973
  • Production Start Year: 1996
  • Project Status: Operating

Scope of Work

Field Development: 

  • Wells: Drilling of six wells
  • Facilities: Construction of a primary gas treatment facility
  • Pipeline: Installation of a gas evacuation pipeline

Infrastructure:

  • Gas Processing Plant: Design and construction of a facility to process produced gas
  • Export Pipeline: Development of infrastructure to transport processed gas to market

Production and Reserves

Gas Production: Approximately 62.61 million cubic meters per year (as of 2015)

Oil Production: Approximately 3.45 million barrels per year (as of 2023)

Condensate Production: No condensate production reported in recent years

Investment and Development

Estimated Investment: Over $1 billion

Development Focus: Initiating gas production and expanding field infrastructure

title: Bonga North Deepwater Project, Nigeria
body:
• Location: Offshore Nigeria, within OML 118, approximately 120 km from the Niger Delta
  • Operator: Shell Nigeria Exploration and Production Company (SNEPCo)
  • Partners: ExxonMobil (20%), TotalEnergies (12.5%), Nigerian Agip Exploration (12.5%)
  • Project Status: Final Investment Decision (FID) taken in December 2024
  • Estimated Development Cost: Approximately $5 billion

Scope of Work

Field Development:

  • Wells: 16 total; comprising 8 production wells and 8 water injection wells
  • Subsea Infrastructure: Installation of risers, flowlines, subsea umbilicals, and other subsea equipment
  • Tie-back: Integration with existing Bonga Main FPSO facility

FPSO Modifications:

  • Upgrades: Modifications to accommodate additional production from Bonga North
  • Capacity: Existing FPSO has a capacity of 225,000 barrels of oil per day

Production Capacity:

  • Peak Oil Production: Up to 110,000 barrels per day
  • Estimated Recoverable Reserves: Over 300 million barrels of oil equivalent (boe)

Project Timeline:

  • First Oil: Expected by the end of the decade (2030)

Contractors:

  • Engineering, Procurement, Construction, and Installation (EPCI): Saipem, KOA Oil & Gas, AVEON Offshore
  • Subsea Production Systems: TechnipFMC

title: Bonga Southwest Aparo (BSWA) Project, Nigeria
body:
• Location: Offshore Nigeria, spanning Oil Mining Leases (OMLs) 118, 132, and 140
  • Operator: Shell Nigeria Exploration and Production Company (SNEPCo)
  • Partners: NNPC, Chevron, TotalEnergies, Eni
  • Project Status: Pre-Final Investment Decision (FID)
  • Estimated Development Cost: Approximately $10 billion

Scope of Work:

  • Floating Production Storage and Offloading (FPSO) Unit:
  • Dimensions: Length: 337 meters; Width: 65 meters; Depth: 37 meters
  • Displacement: Approximately 560,000 tonnes
  • Topsides Weight: 40,000 tonnes
  • Oil Storage Capacity: Approximately 2.45 million barrels
  • Design Life: 25 years without drydocking; 40 years fatigue life

Field Development:

  • Production Wells: Number to be determined in detailed engineering phase
  • Water Injection Wells: Number to be determined in detailed engineering phase
  • Subsea Infrastructure: Comprehensive subsea production systems including risers, flowlines, and umbilicals

Production Capacity:

  • Peak Oil Production: Approximately 150,000 barrels per day
  • Estimated Recoverable Reserves: Approximately 3.2 billion barrels of oil equivalent (boe)

Project Timeline:

  • FID Target: By 2027
  • First Oil: To be determined post-FID

title: Mbour-Fatick-Kaolack Highway, Senegal
body:
Build a 100 km highway connecting Mbour , Fatick and Kaolack in western Senegal

The road will extend the existing highway between Dakar and Mbour for another 100 km, on one of the main axes of the national road network linking Dakar to Mali
 

The works include:
- Construction of a 100 km 2x2 lane motorway with: a left side strip (BDG) of 1 metre wide, 2 wide lanes of 3.5 metres each, a strip of emergency stop 3 metres wide, a berm 1 metre wide, a rounded embankment 50 cm wide, a central reservation made up of the two BDGs and a middle strip supporting a DBA type separator with a width of 60 cm;
- Development of 4 interchanges at Thiadiaye, Fatick, Gandiaye and Kaolack;
- Construction of the northern bypass of Kaolack (7 km)
- Installation of 4 toll stations, including 3 on slip roads and 1 on the current section Kaolack, the toll system being compatible with that existing on the current motorway network;
- Construction of 3 large bridges with a total length of 289.6 m;
- Construction of 16 overpasses, 50 underpasses, 210 hydraulic structures; 
- Development of the platform and roads of a service area on either side of the main axis;
- Installation of a suitable fence along the highway on both sides;
- Landscaping;
- Lighting of the exchangers; 1 command centre and video surveillance equipment.
 

The project is connected to the Blaise Diagne International airport (AIBD)-Mbour highway, connecting the special economic zone, AIBD and the eastern regions

The project is part of a system aimed at strengthening the Dakar-Bamako corridor linking to Mali as well as the Dakar-Lagos corridor as part of the wider Praia-Dakar-Abidjan multimodal corridor

The total cost of the project is US$738.7 million, financed by Exim Bank China up to 81.45% and 18.55% by the state of Senegal

title: Pitse Project, Botswana
body:
The current appraisal phase includes the drilling of 4 new appraisal wells with geographical information being used to accurately determine their locations.  These 4 new wells have been drilled and tested with a 250-500m spacing in a square pattern around Serowe 3 well, plus further testing of Serowe 3-1 well.

Downstream Development Concepts

In recognition of the global transition to renewable energy, Botala is developing the following opportunities additional to its main focus on cbm exploration and development:

  • Serowe Energy Hub: proposal for a ~20MW solar/gas hybrid plant to feed electricity into a nearby substation, and
  • Leupane Energy Hub and Industrial Park: proposal for:
    • Leupane Energy Hub: Targeting a 700MW solar/gas hybrid plant near the Morupule power station to feed electricity into the domestic and Southern African Development Community (SADC) networks via the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP), and
    • Leupane Industrial Park: to provide space and services (adjacent to the Leupane Energy Hub) for new-age industries attracted by reliable and affordable energy, its favourable geographic location with access to the SADC markets and its ports for export to Asia and Europe, attractive investment climate, presence of a skilled work force, and access to research facilities.

Source: Botala Energy

title: Serowe CBM Project, Botswana
body:
Serowe Coal Bed Methane (CBM) Project. 

The Serowe Project near the town of Serowe in the Central District of Botswana consists of ~420,000 hectares of prospecting licenses in the Karoo-Kalahari Basin. Botala has identified an independently certified 2C Resource of 454 billion cubic feet (bcf) in the immediate vicinity of 11 wells drilled within these tenements, and a total prospective resource of more than 7 trillion cubic feet (tcf) within the total area of the Serowe project.  Botala is exploring and developing the cbm potential, aiming to locate high-graded focus areas, or “sweet spots”, and developing procedures to stimulate cbm flows in commercially attractive volumes.

Exploration has increased the independently certified resource from an initial 23.8bcf 2C (Serowe-1) to 454bcf at the end of Serowe 5.

Since listing on the ASX Botala has completed another 6 exploration wells in the project area, with Serowe 6 and Serowe 7 being completed in early 2023; and Serowe 3-5 being completed in early 2024 bringing the total to 11. Serowe 7 was successfully drilled to the target depth of 510m with logging confirming the presence of gas in 35m of coal intersects within 3 seams. Botala has made the decision to progress with flow testing Serowe 7 and is currently planning surface facilities for flow-testing on site.

Serowe 3 has been showing steady progress with the annulus pressure increasing. Botala has completed drilling 4 new pilot wells around the site of Serowe 3 with core sample testing being conducted in early 2024. A comprehensive geophysical survey over both the Serowe 3 and Serowe 7 areas has been completed as part of the well location selection. This provides Botala with a greater understanding of the presence of coal sections. The site of the Serowe 3 well is location links it to the three main coal seems within the Serowe Area.

  • Well heads and gas gathering network of subsurface pipes connected to the Central Processing Facility within the wellfield for removal of water and impurities.
  • Gas supply to the proposed 20MW gas/solar hybrid pilot in Serowe, currently under advanced planning.
  • Gas being compressed into an export pipeline to the proposed Leupane Energy Hub and Industrial Park.
  • Water disposal from evaporation ponds; a reverse osmosis plant to treat saline water is under consideration.
  • Network of infield pipelines and service tracks.

Source: Botala Energy
meta_description: Serowe Coal Bed Methane (CBM) Project.

title: Rivan, Egypt
body:
Rivan is a prominent mixed-use development in Egypt’s New Administrative Capital, in the R7 district. The project is designed to offer luxury residential, serviced apartments, and commercial spaces, aiming to set new standards for urban living in the area.

Components:

  • 1,200 residential units, including apartments, duplexes, penthouses, and standalone villas
  • 16 buildings with around 500 serviced apartments (originally planned for 700 units).
  • A 4-storey mall spanning about 4,200 sqm.
  • Rivan Tower: A separate mixed-use tower project, including hotel, administrative, and commercial units
  • Swiss-Belresidences Rivan: The third phase, managed by Swiss-Belhotel International, focuses on upscale serviced apartments and hospitality.

title: AT-PHOS Phosphoric Acid Plant, Egypt
body:
A world-class world-scale significant merchant grade phosphoric acid (MGA) production Project with an annual production capacity of 500,000 MTPY of P2O5.

The Complex Facilities will contain two phosphoric acid trains with the associated CIX purification units and one train of Sulfuric acid plant with the associated co-generation plant (Steam Turbines and Electric Generators).

The Project shall be located in the Abu Tartour phosphate mine area in the New Valley Governorate. With a sulfur-burning Sulfuric Acid Plant, the Project shall be energy self-sufficient, fulfilling a significant vertical integration element.

The Project shall be located in the Abu Tartour phosphate mine area in the New Valley Governorate. With a sulfur-burning Sulfuric Acid Plant, the Project shall be energy self-sufficient, fulfilling a significant vertical integration element.

Phosphoric Acid Technology Licensor (Prayon Technologies of Belgium) used their Prayon Di-Hydrate mark IV process to produce filter acid that will be further purified using state of the art continuous Ion-Exchange (CIX) unit. This license has been patented and registered by K-Technologies of USA under the name of MER reduction. Pilot Plant Testing succeeded in producing all kinds of phosphate and compound fertilizers, mainly DAP and MAP.

With the CIX technology, the process can provide flexibility to produce Merchant Grade Acid (MGA) matching any industrial uses. The produced merchant grade phosphoric acid is characterized by the lowest suspended solids, no post precipitations, very low heavy metals content, very low radioactivity.

The Complex Facilities will contain two phosphoric acid trains with the associated CIX purification units and one train of Sulfuric acid plant with the associated co-generation plant (Steam Turbines and Electric Generators). Offsites and utilities have been developed to integrate the overall Project, the basic engineering of which has been done by ENPPI and FLUOR.

Source: Abu Tartour for Phosphoric Acid

title: Ijora LNG and Propane Terminals, Nigeria
body:
The Ijora liquefied natural gas (LNG) and propane projects are being developed by Asiko Energy in Ijora, Lagos state, southwestern Nigeria

The projects involve building an LNG storage terminal and a fully mounded propane-rated LPG terminal connected to the Nigerian Pipelines and Storage Company (NPSC) jetties

LNG Terminal

The LNG terminal will be a fully contained in-land storage facility with a 30,000-cubic-metre capacity, 12 vertical tanks and an LNG pipeline

The shipping infrastructure includes a direct connection to the NPSC jetties through a 12-inch double-walled LNG pipeline to receive gas

The LNG terminal is designed to NFPA 59 standards

Propane Terminal

The propane project involves building a fully-mounded propane-rated terminal for the storage of LPG

The terminal will be connected directly to the NPSC jetties in Apapa through a 10-inch LPG pipeline to receive gas via ship

The terminal will consist of five 1,000MT propane tanks upon completion

 

 

In a June 2024 interview with the Majorwaves Energy Report publication, Felix Ekundayo, managing director and CEO of Asiko Energy said he expected the "LPG propane side" to be fully operational in the next few years as well as the "first phase of [the] LNG terminal"

According to Asiko Energy, the potential of the in-land propane and LNG terminal lies not only in its strategic placement away from traffic dense zones in the Ijora-Apapa axis, but also in its ability to import, store and distribute LPG, accelerate LPG supply across Nigeria and limit LPG scarcity

title: Boundiali Gold Project, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
The 1037km2 Boundiali Gold Project in Côte d’Ivoire is located within the same greenstone belt as Resolute’s large Syama (11.5Moz) gold mine and Perseus’ Sissingué (1.4 Moz) gold mine to the north and Montage Gold’s 4.5Moz Koné project located to the south. Barrick’s Tongon mine (5.0Moz) is located to the northeast.

In December 2024, Aurum delivered a JORC Mineral Resource of 1.59Moz gold (50.0Mt at 1.0g/t Au) from the BST (Nyangboue), BD Target 1 and 2, and BM Target 1 and 3 deposits at Boundiali. The MRE was based on MRE based on data from 480 drillholes and nearly 74,000m of drilling.

Gold mineralisation remains open along strike and down dip at all deposits. Drilling is ongoing on these deposits, and Aurum has identified other prospects at Boundiali which have yet to be drilled. It plans to drill 100,000m at Boundiali in 2025, with two MRE updates on track and a Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) to advance the project’s development also expected by year end. It has commenced metallurgical test work on samples from the BD deposit.

Background

The Boundiali projects area covers the underexplored southern extension of the Boundiali belt where a highly deformed synclinal greenstone horizon traverses finer grained basin sediments and to the west Tarkwaian clastic rocks lie in contact with a granitic margin.

Historic exploration at PR0893 includes 93 AC drill holes and four RC holes. Airborne geophysical surveying, geological mapping and extensive soil sampling has also been performed at PR0893, while PR0808 has had 91 RC holes drilled for 6,229m along with geochemical analysis and modelling. Detailed geochemical sampling and drilling at PR414 has revealed three strong gold anomalies and returned previous impressive high-grade results (detailed in ASX: AUE 19/03/23).

Source: Aurum Resources

Barrick’s Tongon mine (5.0Moz) is located to the northeast.

title: Abaya Geothermal Plant, Ethiopia
body:
• Develop the Abaya geothermal prospect located north of Lake Abaya and south of Duguna Fango volcano, within the Wolayita zone of the Southern Nations and Nationalities People’s Region (SNNPR), about 280 km southwest of Addis Ababa
  • There is potential to build a 300 MW geothermal power plant with potential for future expansion
  • The area is situated in the southern part of the Ethiopian Rift Valley, which is part of the East African Rift System, and is characterised by high heat flow, indicated by the presence of several hot springs, fumaroles and a geyser
  • Fluid geochemistry shows geothermometry of more than 200 degrees Celsius for some hot springs but majority of the hot springs suggest medium temperature geothermal systems. The nature and geological characteristics of the prospect suggests that the geothermal system could be a result of deep circulation through the rift floor faults

title: Chipata–Petauke–Serenje Railway, Zambia
body:
• Location: Eastern and Central Provinces, Zambia
  • Total Length: Approximately 388.8 kilometers
  • Gauge: Cape gauge (1,067 mm)
  • Estimated Cost: USD 2.3 billion
  • Project Duration: 4 years (from commencement)
  • Contractor: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), a subsidiary of China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC)
  • Financing: Initially planned through a loan from the Export-Import Bank of China; however, in March 2020, the Zambian government halted plans to borrow USD 2.03 billion due to concerns over debt sustainability 

Project Components

Railway Line Construction:

  • Route: From Chipata (Eastern Province) through Petauke to Serenje (Central Province)
  • Length: 388.8 kilometers
  • Track Type: Single-track railway
  • Design Speed:
    • Passenger Trains: Up to 120 km/h
    • Freight Trains: Up to 80 km/h

Stations and Facilities:

  • Stations: Construction of new railway stations at key locations along the route (specific stations to be determined during detailed design)
  • Maintenance Depots: Establishment of maintenance and service facilities for rolling stock and infrastructure

Integration with Existing Networks

Connection Points:

  • Chipata: Integration with the existing Chipata–Mchinji railway line, facilitating linkage to Malawi and the Nacala Corridor
  • Serenje: Connection to the existing Lusaka–Mpika–Nakonde line, part of Zambia's main railway network

Economic and Strategic Significance:

  • Regional Trade Enhancement: The railway is intended to enhance regional and international trade through the Nacala Development Corridor, providing a direct economic stimulus in Zambia, Malawi, and Mozambique
  • Shortest Route to Sea: Once completed, the railway will provide the shortest route of approximately 1,500 kilometers to the sea from Kapiri Mposhi, facilitating access to the Port of Nacala in Mozambique

title: Riara University, Kenya
body:
Riara University is constructing a new main campus at Konza Technopolis, Kenya. This new campus will be the university’s second and main campus, designed to position Riara as a leading innovation and startup university in Africa, with a focus on science, technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship.

The campus will comprise the following infrastructures:

  • Administration block
  • Lecture halls
  • Laboratories
  • Cafeteria

title: Steyn City, South Africa
body:
Steyn City is a mixed-use luxury estate located in Gauteng, South Africa, covering approximately 2,000 acres of parkland. 

Key features:

  • Clearwater Lagoon Precinct - a 300-meter-long clearwater lagoon serves as a central feature, providing a beach lifestyle experience away from the coast. The lagoon area includes swimming zones, a water park for children, volleyball courts, and a refreshment kiosk.
  • Residential and Mixed-Use Developments - 10,000 residential properties, including apartments, cluster units, and freehold stands.
  • Commercial and Community Facilities - 50,000 m² of commercial space, including eight customizable office blocks (Capital Park), AAA-grade offices, and retail centers. Education facilities such as Steyn City School (Grades 000 to matric) and plans for a new college. A retirement village and two retail centers are part of ongoing and future phases.
  • Sports and Recreation - A world-class Jack Nicklaus-designed 18-hole championship golf course. 45 km of floodlit promenades for jogging and walking, a 50 km mountain bike track, resort pools, tennis and pickleball courts, fitness centers, and an equestrian center.

title: Siloam District Hospital, South Africa
body:
Siloam District Hospital, in Vhembe, Limpopo, South Africa, is undergoing a major reconstruction and expansion. The project is being executed in two primary phases:

  • Phase 1: Included the construction of the doctors’ residence
  • Phase 2: Involves the main hospital complex, renovations, and expansion to include new wards and specialized facilities.

The redevelopment encompasses:

  • Construction of new operating theatres, psychiatric, maternity, surgical, and general wards.
  • Replacement of the old gateway clinic and nursing school.
  • Student and staff accommodation.
  • Upgrades to fencing, parking, gatehouse control, landscaping, and associated civil works.
  • Renovation of existing facilities such as the mental ward and mortuary

title: Egypt-Greece (GREGY) Power Interconnector
body:
• The project involves the construction of a 950 km-long, 500 kV bidirectional submarine cable with a capacity of 3 GW that will directly connect Egypt and mainland Greece (Attica) without intermediate landing points

  • The power to be transferred will come from 9.5 GW of renewable energy projects that will be built and operated in Egypt by Greece's Copelouzos Group 

  • The €4.2 billion (US$4.7 billion) project is being promoted by Elica Mediterranean Electrical Interconnection (Elica), which is a subsidiary of Copelouzos Group

  • About one-third of the power transmitted by the GREGY cable will be consumed in Greece, while one-third will be exported to neighbouring EU countries, with the aim of reducing natural gas consumption by 4.5 billion cubic metres a year

  • Another one-third will be used in Greece for the production of green hydrogen, of which a major portion will be exported to neighbouring EU countries

  • The scheme is set to turn Greece into a clean energy hub in the Eastern Mediterranean region and Southeastern Europe as well as enhance the security of supply in Egypt

  • The project is also in line with the Egyptian government’s policy to establish the country as a regional energy hub in the Eastern Mediterranean

  • The GREGY project has been in development since 2008 and was recently included in the EU’s list of Projects of Common/Mutual Interest (PCI/PMI). It is also an EU Global Gateway flagship infrastructure scheme

  • The scheme is seeing increased impetus following the EU’s decision to fully end its dependency on Russian energy

title: Goudrand, South Africa
body:
The whole township is known as Goudrand Ext 4 and it will be subdivided into 15 different phases to be known as Goudrand Ext 5 to 19. The proposed Goudrand Ext 4 development is an integrated development consisting of 13,000 plus potential housing opportunities.

The first phase of the development is a mixed use project comprising of 13,197 housing opportunities in a mix of 1 204 Residential 1 bonded units, 1,325 Residential 1 FLISP units, 10,668 Residential 3 units, 5 educational sites, 3 shopping centre sites, and 7 crèche sites, 8 worship sites, a hospital site, a cemetery and municipal sites.

The proposed units will comply with the current norms and standards of the Gauteng Department of Human Settlements. The FLISP houses will be freehold houses and 3-Storey walk-up sectional title units while the BNG units will be built as duplex units consisting of a living/kitchen area and bathroom on ground floor and two bedrooms upstairs and single units in 3-storey blocks.

Source: Gauteng Department of Human Settlements

title: Coega Special Economic Zone, South Africa
body:
The Coega Special Economic Zone (SEZ) covers 9,003 hectares near Gqeberha (Port Elizabeth) in the Eastern Cape. 

The SEZ is structured into 14 industry clusters, including automotive, energy, logistics, metals, agro-processing, and business process outsourcing.

Major infrastructure includes roads, utilities, serviced industrial land, and a 12-hectare laydown area for abnormal cargo, supporting heavy, medium, and light industries.

title: Maitland Metro, South Africa
body:
The precinct will feature residential apartments, recreational facilities, green parks and commercial and retail opportunities. 

The upgraded public realm and urban spaces will incorporate a landscaping and greening component, a public plaza on Camp Road, and extensive greened pedestrian walkways. A park will be developed under the M5 flyover to activate this neglected space and host a variety of recreational activities such as netball, basketball, five-a-side soccer, and outdoor chess.

In partnership with the City of Cape Town, play infrastructure, street furniture and lighting will be incorporated to make these public spaces safe and usable, together with large feature trees for shade.

Residential

The development of well-designed, well-built residential apartment blocks is the most significant aspect of the Maitland Metro urban regeneration project. Over the next five years, more than 1,200 new residential units will be added to the precinct in at least seven new mixed-use projects.

Commercial

Maitland Metro will deliver over 50,000 m² of mixed-use with over 15,000 m² of commercial space in seven new buildings.

title: Riverfields Lifestyle Precinct, South Africa
body:
• Location: Ekurhuleni, Gauteng
  • Total Area: 1,500 hectares
  • Project Type: Mixed-use precinct – residential, logistics, commercial

Project Description

The Riverfields Lifestyle Precinct is a major mixed-use development located on a 1,500-hectare site in Gauteng, South Africa. Designed as a strategic urban node, the precinct integrates residential, commercial, and logistics functions to serve the growing demands of the Johannesburg and OR Tambo International Airport corridor.

The precinct is anchored by its logistics and distribution platform, with 255,000 square metres of logistics facilities currently under construction, and an additional 450,000 square metres planned for future development. Riverfields is a key hub for regional supply chain and warehousing infrastructure.

Scope of Work

Residential Development:

  • Over 1,000 completed housing units, valued at approximately R2 billion
  • 400 additional homes under construction
  • 1,000 more units in the planning pipeline
  • Includes multiple secure residential estates within the precinct

Logistics & Industrial:

  • 255,000 m² of logistics and distribution centres under active construction
  • Future development pipeline of 450,000 m² of logistics facilities

Commercial & Mixed Use (Planned/Proposed):

  • Precinct to incorporate retail centres, schools, office space, and public amenities
  • Integrated road and utility infrastructure to support growth

title: Abu Rawash Waste-to-Energy Project, Egypt
body:
Project Description

Green Tech Egypt, in partnership with OAK Holding and the Ministry of Military Production, is undertaking a large-scale Waste-to-Energy (WTE) project valued at USD 500 million. The project is a key component of Egypt’s renewable energy strategy and aligns with Egypt Vision 2023.

Over three phases, the plant will process 1.8 million tons of municipal solid waste annually, beginning with a Phase 1 capacity of over 450,000 tons/year, generating 30 megawatts (MW) of electricity. The facility will comply with both Egyptian and European environmental standards, ensuring sustainable waste management and clean energy production.

The project also supports national goals of industrial development, job creation, and capacity building by utilizing the facilities of the National Organization for Military Production (NOMP) and involving local Egyptian companies in its execution. It will provide training opportunities for graduate students, contributing to workforce development in Egypt’s emerging waste-to-energy sector.

  • Project Partners: Green Tech Egypt, OAK Holding, Ministry of Military Production (MoMP)
  • Project Value: USD 500 million
  • Phasing: 3 Phases
  • Annual Waste Processing Capacity (Full): 1.8 million tons
  • Phase 1 Capacity: 450,000 tons/year
  • Power Generation (Phase 1): 30 MW

Scope of Work

Phase 1 Development:

  • Processing capacity: over 450,000 tons/year of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW)
  • Electricity generation: 30 MW
  • Compliance with Egyptian and EU environmental standards

Future Phases:

  • Gradual expansion to 1.8 million tons/year processing capacity
  • Incremental increase in energy output to match processing growth

Plant Infrastructure

  • Waste reception and sorting facilities
  • Waste combustion or thermal treatment systems
  • Energy recovery systems and grid connection infrastructure
  • Environmental control systems (air emissions, residue handling)

title: Indorama Fertilizer Line 3, Nigeria
body:
Indorama Eleme Fertilizer III

Known as Line 3 in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. Line 3 is designed to build upon the technologies and knowledge gained from the development and operation of Line 1 and Line 2, featuring similar technology and capacity. The creation of Line 3 will raise the present urea production capacity from 2.8 MMTPA to 4.2 MMTPA. The Line 3 plant will contain a 2,300 Metric Tons Per Day (MTPD) capacity for ammonia, a 4,000 MTPD urea facility, steam, cooling tower, water treatment, product handling, power, nitrogen, plant air and instrument air, passive and active firefighting systems, along with product storage and material handling facilities.

In addition, the expansion of production facilities will result in an estimated surplus of 400 MTPD of ammonia. To facilitate exports of fertilizer and ammonia, the project also encompasses the construction of a dedicated jetty, named Line 3 Jetty. Positioned approximately 20 kilometers from the production site, at the Onne Port Complex, this planned jetty will expand Indorama’s existing export infrastructure capacity by providing necessary storage and export capabilities for the surplus ammonia and bulk urea produced by Line 3.

The Indorama complex, the site of the Line 3 implementation, features state-of-the-art facilities such as a captive gas fired power unit, utilities, an effluent treatment plant, storage tanks, bagging, a warehouse, and other supporting facilities.

The projected construction cost of Line 3 and the Line 3 Jetty is US$1.250 billion. The proposed construction period is three years for Line 3, and two years for the jetty.

Source: International Finance Corporation. Reference: Project Number
47723

title: Niger Accelerating Electricity Access
body:
The Niger Accelerating Electricity Access Project, known as "Haské" (meaning "light" in Hausa), is a major government initiative supported by the World Bank to rapidly increase electricity access across Niger. The project aims to raise the national electricity access rate to 30% by 2026 and 80% by 2035, addressing both urban and rural electrification challenges.

Scope

Reinforcement and Expansion of Transmission and Distribution Networks:

  • Construction of a 270 km double circuit 132-kV line (or a single circuit 330-kV line) and 3-4 substations connecting Zabori (Zone Fleuve) to Malbaza (Niger Centre-Est) via Doutchi and Konni.
  • Upgrading and densifying existing distribution networks, and building new medium and low voltage networks to electrify new localities, especially rural development hubs.

Deployment of Solar Mini-Grids and Off-Grid Solutions:

  • Building new mini-grids and adding solar systems to existing mini-thermal power plants in rural areas.
  • Providing electricity to households, public facilities (health centers, schools, water boreholes), and promoting productive use for businesses.

Source: World Bank - Source ID P174034

title: Lake Kariba Floating Solar Plant, Zimbabwe
body:
The Intensive Energy Users Group (IEUG) has proposed the development of a 1,000 MW solar power station to be floated on Lake Kariba and to augment the power generated by the water-driven turbines at the dam wall of the Kariba South Hydropower Station

This proposal has been accepted by the Zambezi River Authority (ZRA), the Zimbabwe Government and the power utility that runs the turbines at the wall – the Zimbabwe Power Corporation (ZPC)

The project is being divided into four stages of 250 MW each. It will involve installing 420,000 solar panels on a floating platform in a sheltered bay some 15 km from the main power plant. This will feed energy via a control system to a major battery complex where the energy will be stored prior to delivery to the ZPC power plant.. Here, it will be blended with hydropower and fed into the national grid via transmission lines to the north and south

When all stages are complete, the solar platform will increase the overall capacity of the hydroelectric plant by a third and reduce water use to a level that is more manageable. The batteries used will help stabilise and manage the power generated and allow ZPC to control the flow of energy generated to the grid. It will do so at a cost that is well below the cost of conventional power stations. This incremental power will be sold to IEUG members as baseload power for mining and industrial production

The study to determine viability and technical details was to start in January 2025 over a period of five months at a cost of US$4.5 million, conducted by a team of consultants from China, Germany, Britain, South Africa and Zimbabwe. Once completed, the study will be employed to secure the funding required to cover the cost of the project. 

The project is being backed by the African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank), which is putting up US$3 million for the bankable study, with IEUG putting up the additional US$1.5 million

 

(Source: IEUG)

title: Raville Tower and Residences, Egypt
body:
Also known as Raville Compound project in the Fifth Settlement, Cairo, Egypt

Project Overview

Raville Compound is a large-scale, mixed-use urban development located in Fifth Settlement, Cairo. The project combines residential, commercial, hospitality, and public service functions, with a distinctive architectural landmark in the form of Raville Tower. The development aims to integrate modern living with cultural symbolism and high-quality urban infrastructure.

Notable Architectural Feature

Raville Tower: A symbolic high-rise structure inspired by ancient Egyptian architecture. Designed as a pharaonic obelisk crowned with a pyramid entrance, it serves as the centerpiece of the compound and covers a vast footprint of over 5.48 million square meters.

Key Project Components

Residential Zone

  • Standard Housing Buildings (870,074 m²)

  • Separate Villas (149,734 m²)

  • Total commercial and entertainment area: 313,631 m²

Hospitality and Hotel Zone

Landmark Feature

    • Architectural Design (Pharaonic Obelisk with Pyramid Entrance)

title: Dose by Akam Alrajhi, Egypt
body:
Dose is a major luxury resort and residential project located on Egypt’s North Coast on the Alexandria-Marsa Matrouh road, near El Dabaa.

The project covers approximately 125 acres, with 70% of the area dedicated to green spaces and water features, including artificial lakes and landscaped parks. Dose offers a wide range of property types, including apartments, chalets, villas, townhouses, and twin houses, with unit sizes starting from around 70 square meters.

Dose is designed as a fully integrated, entertainment-focused community, including:

  • Multiple swimming pools and artificial lakes
  • Sports facilities (gym, running and cycle tracks)
  • Children’s play areas
  • Spa and wellness centers
  • Cafes and restaurants

title: Bumba–Aketi–Buta–Mungbere Railway Rehabilitation, DRC
body:
The Bumba–Aketi–Buta–Mungbere (also known as Uélés-Rivers) Railway Line Rehabilitation and Modernization project is a strategic infrastructure initiative aimed at restoring and upgrading a critical rail corridor in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Originally constructed between 1924 and 1937, this historic railway line spans several hundred kilometers across the Mongala and Uélé provinces, connecting the river port city of Bumba to the eastern town of Mungbere via Aketi and Buta. The railway was once vital for transporting agricultural produce, minerals, and passengers but has been largely non-operational due to decades of neglect and conflict-related damage.

This project seeks to rehabilitate and modernize the railway infrastructure to facilitate efficient, safe, and sustainable rail transport. Key activities include comprehensive track repairs, upgrading signaling and telecommunications systems, and implementing modern operating standards. The rehabilitation will improve domestic rail connectivity, foster economic development by opening up the eastern regions rich in natural resources, and support the integration of the DRC’s transport network.

The initiative is guided by the DRC government’s Ministry of Transport and Communication Routes, which has issued an international call for expressions of interest from qualified partners. The project aims to attract experienced rail operators and investors to ensure long-term sustainability and operational excellence. Ultimately, the revitalized railway will enhance regional trade, provide reliable freight and passenger services, and contribute to socio-economic growth in a region historically underserved by transport infrastructure.

Originally constructed between 1924 and 1937

title: Kigali Informal Settlement Upgrading, Rwanda
body:
The Kigali Informal Settlement Upgrading Project (KISUP) is a large-scale initiative to transform informal settlements into safer, healthier, and more resilient neighborhoods, while preserving community ties and promoting inclusive urban development. The project targets neighborhoods such as Kagugu, Rwezamenyo, and Nyakabanda.

Key Features:

  • Roads and Utilities: Upgrades include new access roads, footpaths, stormwater drainage systems, improved water supply networks, and street lighting.
  • Social Facilities: The project will deliver new or improved schools, health posts, markets, recreational areas, green spaces, community halls, early childhood development centers, sports grounds, and libraries.
  • Housing: Residents will have the opportunity to upgrade their homes without displacement, with a focus on affordable rental housing to minimize gentrification risk

title: Nairobi - Mombasa (Usahihi) Expressway, Kenya
body:
• Build the 459 km Nairobi-Mombasa (Usahihi) expressway project connecting Kenya’s two largest cities – its capital Nairobi and Mombasa
  • The scheme involves building a four-to-six-lane dual-carriageway running between Nairobi and the Mombasa port
  • The expressway will replace the current two-lane winding road between the two cities, cutting the travel times from about 10.5 hours to about 4.5 hours
  • The expressway will feature rest stops, wildlife observation points, electric vehicle charging infrastructure powered by renewable energy and overpasses to facilitate safe wildlife migration
  • Construction is planned to take between three and four years to complete
  • The Usahihi expressway will be the inaugural segment of the Northern Corridor Transport System, which connects Kenya’s principal Port of Mombasa with the landlocked Eastern and Central African countries of Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, South Sudan and Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)
  • The project is being developed by the  Usahihi Consortium, which comprises US infrastructure investment manager Everstrong Capital, engineering, procurement and construction contractors and a South African toll road operations company

title: Kavumu Waste-to-Power Plant, Rwanda
body:
• Build a facility designed to incinerate 480 tonnes a day of municipal solid waste and generate 15 MW of electricity for Rwanda’s national grid
  • The plant will be located in Kavumu Village, Kigombe Cell, Muhoza Sector, Musanze Town in the Northern province
  • The plant will treat solid waste, liquid waste effluents and gaseous material
  • For energy recovery, the hot flue gases from the furnace will flow through the boiler, releasing thermal energy which turns water into steam. The steam produced will be used to drive the turbo alternators for electricity generation
  • The plant’s location between other power stations such as Mukungwa I and II and Rwaza-Muko will facilitate its connection to the national grid

 

 

(Sources: Waste Power Plant and New Times Rwanda)

title: Guruve-Mazowe Wind Power Plant, Zimbabwe
body:
The Guruve-Mazowe Wind Power Project comprises the installation of a grid-connected 100 MW wind power plant and the requisite transmission infrastructure

The project is located in Mashonaland Central Province, along the border of the Guruve and Mazowe Rural District Councils in northern Zimbabwe

The turbines could be in the range of 2 to 5 MW capacity

Depending on the results of the feasibility studies, hybridisation with solar power and battery storage could be contemplated

The scheme is being jointly developed by Enerfin Sociedad de Energia (Enerfin), a subsidiary of Elecnor Group, and Tatanga Energy

The intent is to sell the full electricity output generated from the Project to the Zimbabwe Electricity Transmission and Distribution Company (ZETDC) under a 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA)

Source: Tatanga Energy

title: Tatanga Gas-to-Power Plant, Zimbabwe
body:
Project Overview

The project involves the development of a gas-fired power plant in northern Zimbabwe by Mbuyu Energy, a Zimbabwean consortium led by IPP developer Tatanga Energy.

The facility will use feedstock from the Cabora Bassa natural gas field, operated by Invictus Energy and One Gas Resources. 

The facility will be implemented in phases and is part of a broader national strategy to improve energy security and industrial power supply. 

The plant will be connected to the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP) as the Mukuyu gas field is located within 100 km of three major interconnectors to the SAPP grid.

Invictus Energy has inked a gas sales MoU with Tatanga Energy for up to 1,000 MW gas to power, involving the supply of up 1.4 trillion cubic feet (tcf) over 20 years.

Key Project Details

  • Location: Near Cabora Bassa Basin, Zimbabwe
  • Feedstock Source: Natural gas from the Cabora Bassa Project
  • Phase 1 Capacity: ±150 MW
  • Phase 2 Capacity: ±350 MW
  • Total Planned Capacity: 500 MW (Phases 1 and 2), expandable to 1,000 MW
  • Project Type: Thermal (Gas-to-Power)
  • Technology: Combined-cycle gas turbines (CCGT)

title: Agge Deep Seaport, Nigeria
body:
The Agge Deep Seaport is a $3 billion infrastructure project located in Agge, Ekeremor Local Government Area of Bayelsa State, Nigeria. Designed as a strategic part of Nigeria’s blue economy agenda, the port aims to become a major maritime hub for the Niger Delta region, easing congestion at existing ports, boosting international trade, and catalyzing regional economic development.

The project is being developed under a public-private partnership (PPP) involving the Federal Government of Nigeria, the Bayelsa State Government, and private investors. Once completed, it will serve both cargo and logistics operations, enhancing Nigeria’s maritime competitiveness and contributing to national GDP growth.

Riviera Park is a real estate development project in Cocody Faya, on the east side of Abidjan, Côte d'Ivoire.

The project will feature a modern shopping center with a built area of 26,000 square meters on a 40,000 square meter site. The development will include a leisure center, a movie theater complex, a large supermarket, and restaurants.

title: Village Notre Père, Cote d'Ivoire
body:
Village Notre Père is a major mixed-use real estate development underway in Abidjan’s Plateau district. The project aims to deliver modern, sustainable infrastructure, including retail, office, and residential spaces, and is positioned as a flagship for green urban development in Côte d'Ivoire.

Other features:

  • Supermarket
  • Pedestrian shopping gallery
  • Retail stores
  • Green space
  • Hotel residence (serviced apartments)
  • Renovation of the district’s first church (built in 1905).

body:

title: Mutinondo and Luchunene Hydropower Plants, Zambia
body:
• Build the 49 MW Mutinondo and 36 MW Luchenene plants in the Mpika District, Muchinga province
  • The plants will be located about 700 km from the capital Lusaka and 50 km to the southeast of the town of Mpika
  • Each project is a run-of-river plant, with a storage weir that provides the necessary volume for daily peaking generation
  • With a design flow of 12 cubic metres/s, the main feature of the projects is the available head for generation, harnessing the elevation difference along the Muchinga Escarpment
  • A detailed topographical survey confirmed an available gross head of 514m for Mutinondo and 374m for Luchenene
  • The plants are anticipated to generate up to 591 GWh of electricity a year, injecting this into the national grid
  • The project is being developed by Mutinondo Luchenene Power Company Limited (MLPC), an Independent Power Producer domiciled in Zambia, working in partnership with Berkeley Energy
  • Following completion of the Feasibility Study, MLPC is now seeking interested Contractors, both Civil and Electrical and Mechanical (E&M), for the design, manufacture, procurement, supply, construction, installation and commissioning of the two hydropower projects
  • It is anticipated that the contract will be  executed under the FIDIC Conditions of Contract for EPC/Turnkey Projects either as a fully wrapped EPC / Turnkey contract (inclusive of all civil and E&M works under one contractual entity or joint venture), or alternatively as a split-EPC arrangement (featuring separate contracts for civil works and E&M works). MLPC reserves the right to decide the final contracting structure based on technical, commercial and risk considerations

title: Highway Development and Management Initiative (HDMI) Phase II, Nigeria
body:
The main scope of the HDMI projects for the 2nd Phase of the PPP scheme includes the expansion, realignment, rehabilitation, and maintenance of the existing road pavements and bridges; construction of interchanges and pedestrian crossings; construction and operations of tolling facilities; installation of weighbridges and operations; installation and operation of intelligent traffic systems for highway remote monitoring; physical patrol of the highway, provision of towing services, ambulance service, Trailer Parks and refuse management. Work must be done in accordance with the Nigerian and globally accepted standards & and specifications. Others include the provision of directional signages, rest areas, highway illumination, etc.

The 2nd Phase scheme covers 30 strategic road corridors packaged into the under-listed lots with an Unbundled Transit Park:

title: SADC Sub-Regional Transport and Trade Facilitation
body:
The SADC Sub-Regional Transport and Trade Facilitation initiatives involving Malawi and Mozambique are major infrastructure and trade facilitation programs aimed at improving regional connectivity, reducing trade costs, and boosting economic integration between the two countries and the broader Southern African region.

Key Features

  • Upgrading critical transport corridors, notably the Nacala and Beira Corridors, which connect Malawi to Mozambican ports and onward to international markets.
  • Road upgrades, construction of new railway sections, development of logistics hubs, and modernization of border posts (including a One-Stop Border Post between Malawi and Mozambique).

title: Electricity Sector Improvement and Access, Angola
body:
The Electricity Sector Improvement and Access project in Angola aims to improve and expand the electricity sector, boost access, operational efficiency, and sustainability.

Major Construction Activities:

  • Distribution Network Expansion: Rehabilitation and expansion of distribution networks in provincial capitals, such as Uige and Cuanza Norte, including new service connections for households, businesses, and public institutions.
  • Transmission Infrastructure: Construction of a 343-kilometer transmission line to unify the national grid and deliver hydropower from the Kwanza River basin to the south.
  • Renewable Energy Projects: Ongoing construction of large hydropower plants (e.g., Laúca, Cambambe II) and new solar parks, including two photovoltaic parks in Benguela and Bafa Farta with a combined capacity of 285 MWp.
  • Rural Electrification: Focus on innovative mini-grid and renewable energy solutions to bridge the urban-rural divide in electricity access

Source: World Bank - Project ID P166805

migration_status: boost access

title: Lesotho Botswana Water Transfer
body:
The Lesotho-Botswana Water Transfer (LBWT) Project is a transboundary infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing water security and climate resilience in Botswana, Lesotho, and South Africa. The project involves transferring water from a new multipurpose dam to be constructed on the Makhaleng River in Lesotho, through a 700 km conveyance pipeline passing through South Africa, ultimately supplying Botswana. 

Key features:

  • Dam Construction: The project will feature a 124-meter-high concrete arch dam on the Makhaleng River in Lesotho, equipped with a hydropower plant.
  • Water Conveyance System: A 700 km piped water conveyance system will be constructed, including a high-lift pump station and three booster pump stations, traversing Lesotho, South Africa, and Botswana.
  • Hydropower Generation: The dam will generate approximately 30 MW, with an additional 5 MW generated along the conveyance system.
  • Capacity: The system is designed to deliver around 310 million cubic meters (MCM) of water per year, with about 75% of the yield intended for Botswana. The remainder will serve Lesotho and South African municipalities along the route.

title: Mabesekwa Coal-to-Liquids Project, Botswana
body:
• Originally known as Project Tsosoloso
  • Build a Coal to Liquids (CTL) Plant that will produce up to 30,000 barrels a day (b/d) of clean burning liquid fuels and associated petrochemical byproducts
  • The plant will be situated approximately 60 km southwest of Francistown and will be fed by the Mabesekwa No.2 Mine
  • The project will be developed by Coal Petroleum (CoPet), which is 80% owned by Shumba Energy and 10% by Holland and Hausberger
  • The developer has adopted a new and innovative approach to delivery of the CTL project using proven modular plant technology that can be phased with 600 b/d (95,000 lpd) production units at a reduction in capital costs of at least 80% over the large-scale CTL Plants ex-China that were originally envisaged
  • The developer has signed an Letter of Intent for the acquisition of its first unit subject to completion of due diligence and negotiation of agreeable terms of purchase and delivery
  • CoPet previously partnered with Powerchina International Group Limited (“PowerChina International”) and Wison Group (“Wison”) for the execution of the Bankable Feasibility Study
  • Shumba has entered into a binding Coal Supply Agreement with CoPet to guarantee supply of all the
    feedstock that would be required for the life of the Project from the Mabesekwa coal resource

title: Completion of Ajaokuta Steel Complex, Nigeria
body:
• Rehabilitate, complete and operate the Ajaokuta steel plant, located in Ajaokuta, Kogi state, about 38 km away from Lokoja, the state capital
  • The facility was conceived and developed with the vision of erecting a metallurgical process plant and engineering complex with auxiliaries and facilities
  • Construction began in 1979 on the plant with the assistance of the USSR. By the early 1990s, the enterprise was 98% complete, including three rolling mills and a thermal power plant. However, the collapse of the USSR prevented the completion of work. Currently, only a few small workshops are operating at the plant; most of the production capacity has never been put into operation
  • The plant was designed to produce iron and liquid steel from locally occurring raw materials such as iron ore from mines in Itakpe, Kogi state; the steel plant is based on blast furnace technology
  • The plant has four rolling mills, namely the Billet Mill, Light Section Mill, Wire Rod Mill and Medium Section and Structural Mill
  • In mid-September 2024, the Nigerian government signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the original builders (original equipment manufacturers (OEM)) of the Ajaokuta Steel Plant – a Russian consortium led by Tyazhpromexport (TPE) and including Novostal M and Proforce Manufacturing Limited – for the rehabilitation, completion and operation of plant
  • The full implementation of the MoU is expected to facilitate the revival of the plant, create over 500,000 direct and indirect jobs for Nigerians and increase the size of the economy by billions of dollars, thus contributing immensely to President Tinubu’s desire to grow the Nigerian economy to over US$1 trillion by 2030
  • The revival of the steel sector will also reduce imports of steel products into Nigeria, which is estimated at over US$4 billion annually
  • On 7 April 2025, Nigeria's Minister of Steel Development Prince Shuaibu Abubakar Audu said the developers were on the verge of carrying out the technical and financial audit of the complex and other critical processes so as to bring in investors and suitors from the various options available through a privatisation process as directed by the president. "Our role is to consolidate these gains and present viable options for Mr. President’s approval," said the minister

title: Red Sands BESS, South Africa
body:
• Build the 153 MW / 612 MWh Red Sands battery energy storage system (BESS) about 100km southeast of Upington in the Northern Cape province
  • The BESS will feature Iithium iron phosphate technology
  • It will take up about 12 acres of land and will connect to the grid through the Eskom Garona Main Transmission Substation, which is to be upgraded during the project
  • The Project is part of the yet-to-be-developed Red Sands solar photovoltaic facility and is located within the Renewable Energy Development Zone 7 (Upington)
  • The scheme is expected to take 24 months to complete
  • It will operate under a 15-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with Eskom
  • The project was awarded under the first bid window of South Africa’s Battery Energy Storage Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme (BESIPPPP)
  • The project was originally developed by African Green Ventures (AGV), the South African development arm of Magnora ASA, a Norwegian company listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange; in early April 2024, UK-headquartered developer Globeleq acquired the scheme from AGV

 

The project will include grid infrastructure that will be handed over to Eskom, primarily consisting of:

  • A 132 kV Eskom Switching Substation adjacent to the Independent Power Producer Substation;
  • A proposed 400 / 132 kV Main Transmission Substation (MTS);
  • A 132 kV overhead powerline (OHL) of approximately 10,5 km from the Eskom Switching Substation to the proposed 400 / 132 kV MTS;
  • Loop in and out (LILO) of the Ferrum – Nieuwehoop 400 kV OHL;
  • Loop in of the Garona – Groblershoop 132 kV OHL (including upgrade capacity of the existing 132 kV OHL section and an additional 132 kV OHL of approximately 850 m from the proposed MTS to the existing Eskom Garona MTS);
  • Access and maintenance roads, including upgrades to existing roads to allow for larger component transport

title: Suez Canal Container Terminal (SCCT) Expansion, Egypt
body:
The expansion, known as Phase 3, aims to increase the terminal's capacity by an additional 2.1 million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs), resulting in a total installed capacity of 6.6 million TEUs. The project includes the construction of a new 955-meter quay wall and an adjacent container yard, supplementing the existing 2,400-meter berth.

Details:

  • Addition of a 955-meter berth to the existing 2,400 meters.
  • Expansion by 510,000 m², increasing the total yard area to 1.71 million m².
  • Increase from 5 million TEUs to 7 million TEUs annually.

title: East Port Said Roll-On/Roll-Off (Ro-Ro) Terminal, Egypt
body:
The East Port Said Ro-Ro Terminal, developed by the Suez Canal Automotive Terminal (SCAT) consortium, is a major infrastructure project designed to position Egypt as a key automotive logistics hub in the Eastern Mediterranean. Located within the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZONE), the terminal is the country’s first dedicated facility for handling Roll-on/Roll-off (Ro-Ro) cargo, particularly vehicles.

Key Technical Features: 

  • The terminal spans approximately 212,000 square meters, specifically engineered for efficient vehicle handling, storage, and staging. The layout supports optimal traffic flow for inbound and outbound vehicle movements.
  • The facility includes a 600-meter-long berth, built to accommodate large Ro-Ro vessels. The quay is designed with reinforced structural features to support the heavy loads associated with vehicle cargo operations.
  • The terminal is designed to handle up to 50,000 vehicles per year, with scalable infrastructure to support future capacity increases. This includes parking areas, inspection zones, and customs clearance sections.
  • Supporting Infrastructure:

- Automated Gates and Tracking Systems: For efficient and secure vehicle entry/exit.

- On-site Services: Including vehicle pre-delivery inspection (PDI), washing, minor repair, and preparation services.

- Internal Roads and Traffic Lanes: Paved and demarcated to support Ro-Ro operations and minimize vehicle handling time.

  • The terminal is built to international safety and environmental standards, featuring:

- Low-emission lighting and energy-efficient systems.

- Drainage and runoff systems compliant with maritime environmental regulations.

- Dust and noise mitigation measures.

title: East Port Said Grain Terminal, Egypt
body:
The East Port Said Grain Terminal is a pivotal infrastructure project aimed at enhancing Egypt's grain import and handling capabilities. Located at the northern entrance of the Suez Canal, the terminal is strategically positioned to serve as a major transshipment hub connecting East-West trade routes. The project is a collaboration between the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZone) and a consortium comprising Roots Commodities and Rosa Grains, with an estimated investment of EGP 2.2 billion (approximately USD 140 million).

Terminal Specifications:

  • Area: 267,000 square meters
  • Quay Length: 500 meters
  • Annual Grain Handling Capacity: Ranges from 1.5 million to 7.2 million tonnes
  • Employment Impact: Expected to generate approximately 400 direct and indirect jobs

Infrastructure and Operations:

  • Bulk Grain Handling Facilities: Equipped to manage various grain types, ensuring efficient unloading, storage, and distribution processes.
  • Logistics Integration: Seamless connectivity with the SCZone's industrial zones, facilitating value-added activities and enhancing supply chain efficiency.
  • Environmental Considerations: Implementation of sustainable practices in terminal operations to minimize ecological impact.

body:
Limpopo Central Hospital, also referred to as Limpopo Central Academic Hospital, is tertiary and teaching hospital currently under construction in Polokwane, Limpopo, South Africa. 

The facility is located on a 25-hectare site with an initial 488 beds, with plans to expand to 688 beds upon full completion

title: Oasis BESS Facilities, South Africa
body:
• Build the Oasis Mookodi battery energy storage system (BESS) with a capacity of 77 MW and 308 MWh of storage in the Vryburg area of the North West Province
  • Build the Oasis Aggeneis BESS with a capacity of 77 MW and 308 MWh of storage approximately 8 km southeast of Aggeneys within the Khâi-Ma Local Municipality in the Northern Cape Province
  • Build the Oasis Nieuwehoop BESS with 103 MW of capacity and 412 MWh of storage 25 km northeast of the town Kenhardt within the Kheis Local Municipality, Northern Cape Province
  • The projects were awarded under Bid Window 1 of the Battery Energy Storage Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme (BESIPPPP)
  • The schemes are being developed by a team of local independent power producer (IPP) Mulilo and France’s EDF Renewables, along with the local Pele Energy Group and Gibb-Crede as equity partners
  • All three facilities have 15-year power purchase agreements (PPAs) signed with state utility Eskom
  • Together, the three projects total 257 MW of capacity and 1,028 MWh of storage and all of them are located in the Northern Cape Supply Area
  • The Oasis Mookodi scheme reached financial close on 15 November 2024 and Oasis Aggeneis and Oasis Nieuwehoop on 20 November 2024
  • The facilities are expected to be commissioned within 24 months

 

Grid Connections

The Oasis Mookodi BESS will be connected to the Eskom grid by constructing an onsite 132/33 kV substation, a 132 kV collector station, and a 7 km power line that connects to Eskom’s Mookodi substation

The Oasis Aggeneis BESS will be connected to the Eskom grid by constructing an onsite 132/33 kV substation, a 132 kV switching station, and a 17 km power line that connects to Eskom’s Aggeneis main transmission substation (MTS)

The Oasis Nieuwehoop BESS will be connected to the Eskom grid by constructing an onsite 132/33 kV substation and a 132 kV switching station that will be connected to the Nieuwehoop MTS via a Loop-In-and-Loop Out (LILO) of the Rooidam-Nieuwehoop 132 kV line. Metering will be done at the switching station

title: Mogobe BESS, South Africa
body:
• Norway's Scatec is constructing the Mogobe (Ferrum) battery energy storage system (BESS) with 103 MW of capacity and 412 MWh of storage, located near the town of Kathu in South Africa’s Northern Cape province
  • Scatec was awarded a 15-year power purchase agreement (PPA) under the first bid window of South Africa’s Battery Energy Storage Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme (BESIPPPP)
  • As part of the PPA, Scatec will receive payments for making the storage capacity available for the National Transmission Company of South Africa (NTCSA), which will utilise the capacity to balance the South African grid
  • Said to be one of Africa’s first and largest standalone dispatchable BESS systems, the Mogobe scheme is located close to high power demand centres
  • Scatec will own 51% of the equity in the project, with the local Perpetua Mogobe owning 46.5% and a holding company of the Mogobe Local Community Trust 2.5%
  • Scatec will be the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) provider and provide operations and maintenance (O&M), as well as asset management services to the scheme
  • The estimated total capital expenditure (capex) for the project is Rand 3 billion (US$170 million) of which Scatec’s EPC contracts account for approximately 83%. The scheme will be financed by Rand 2.7 billion of non-recourse project debt, with the Standard Bank of South Africa as mandated lead arranger and the remaining by equity from the owners.

title: Rooidraai Solar PV Plant, South Africa
body:
• Build an 85 MW solar PV plant near Carletonville in the Dr Kenneth Kaunda District Municipality, North West Province
  • The plant will generate around 220 GWh of clean energy a year
  • The developer, AMEA Power, has signed a 25-year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with GreenCo Power Services (GreenCo), a private energy trader and member of the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP), for the offtake from the plant

    o A 33 kV switch room,
    o A gate house, ablutions, workshops, storage and warehousing areas, site offices and a
    control centre
  • Battery storage – A Battery Storage Facility with a maximum height of 8m and a maximum volume of 1,740 m3 of batteries and associated operational, safety and control infrastructure

title: Olkaria Special Economic Zone (SEZ), Kenya
body:
• Kenya's Ministry of Investments, Trade, and Industry has officially declared the Olkaria area in Naivasha an SEZ
  • Located in Nakuru County, the zone spans about 8,292 acres and hosts KenGen’s Green Energy Park
  • It will serve as a key driver for industrial investment, clean energy manufacturing, and export-oriented production, supporting industries in green manufacturing, agro-processing, electric mobility and data centres, among others
  • By providing businesses with incentives such as tax exemptions, infrastructure support, and access to affordable geothermal power, the SEZ is expected to attract local and international investors seeking cost-effective, sustainable operations
  • Located along key transport corridors including the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) and the Nairobi-Mombasa Highway, the Olkaria SEZ will provide investors with seamless access to both local and global markets
  • The first phase of investor engagement has already begun, with several multinational firms expressing interest in setting up operations within the SEZ

title: Oxbow Hydropower Dam, Lesotho
body:
The project is part of Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP) Phase 2. 

The Oxbow plant will be sited on the Malibamatso River and will include a 100-metre-high gravity dam and a 6.6km (3.6-metre diameter) headrace tunnel discharging through a high-pressure steel penstock into the surface powerhouse.

Power will be evacuated via a double-circuit 132kV transmission line linking with the Muela substation. The generation discharge will be conveyed through a 4.2km tailrace tunnel to the Muela reservoir to ensure the dammed water goes back into the LHWP for onward delivery to South Africa.

Project Overview

This major hydropower development, led by the Lesotho Highlands Development Authority, involves the construction of a high-head hydroelectric scheme near Oxbow on the Malibamatso River. It includes dam infrastructure, tunnel systems, power generation facilities, and supporting works.

Key Components

1. Dam and Reservoir

  • Location: Malibamatso River near Oxbow
  • Type: Roller Compacted Concrete (RCC) dam (anticipated)
  • Height: ~100 meters
  • Impact: Reservoir will submerge sections of the A1 national road (requiring diversions)

2. Hydraulic Structures

  • Intake Structure: Gated intake to control flow into headrace
  • Headrace Tunnel: 6.6 km long tunnel conveying water from the reservoir
  • Penstock: 3.2 km long steel-lined penstock connecting to powerhouse
  • Tailrace Channel: Returns discharged water to the river system

3. Powerhouse

  • Type: Surface powerhouse
  • Turbines: 4 Pelton turbines
  • Generators: 4 × 23.3 MVA units
  • Transformers and Equipment: Full complement for power generation and transmission

4. Transfer System to Muela

  • Diversion Weir to capture flows
  • Transfer Tunnel: 4.2 km tunnel discharging into Muela Reservoir
  • Potential Additional Powerhouse: Adjacent to Muela for energy optimization

5. Transmission Infrastructure

  • Transmission Lines: Twin 132 kV lines
  • Connection Point: New Muela Substation (~6 km direct line)

6. Ancillary Infrastructure

  • Diversion of A1 road and utilities
  • Site access roads and bridges
  • Quarry development and material processing areas
  • Construction camps and labor accommodation
  • Plant and laydown yards
meta_description: The project is part of Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP) Phase 2. The Oxbow plant will be sited on the Malibamatso River and will include a 100-metre-high gravity dam and a 6.6km (3.6-metre diameter) headrace tunnel discharging through a high-pressure steel penstock into the surface powerhouse.

title: Boutoubre Hydropower Plant, Cote d'Ivoire
body:
• Build the 150 MW Boutoubre hydropower plant upstream of the Gribo-Popoli dam on the Sassandra River in southern Cote d'Ivoire
  • The plant will produce  908 GWh a year and have a lifespan of 40 years
  • The plant is set to benefit from the regulation of the Soubré hydropower plant, thus allowing the generation of hydropower at lower cost
  • The location of the project near the CLSG transmission line also allows for sharing of hydroelectric production with Sierra Leone and Liberia
  • The Boutoubré hydropower plant is seen as one of the most profitable hydroelectric projects in Côte d'Ivoire as it accumulates high available energy (utilisation factor of 5,800 hours a year) and a cost per MW installed in the low range of hydroelectric projects (US$3,200/MW). In this context, it appears as economically justified to satisfy demand in the subregion

title: Katende Hydropower Dam, DRC
body:
The Katende Hydropower Dam is situated on the Lulua River in Kasaï-Central Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). It will have an installed capacity of 64 megawatts (MW) and aims to improve the electricity supply to the cities of Kananga, Mbuji-Mayi, Tshimbulu, and surrounding communities.

The project is being implemented in phases:

  • Phase 1: Installation of two 16 MW turbines (total 32 MW) and a transmission line to Kananga
  • Phase 2: An additional 16 MW.
  • Phase 3: The final 16 MW, bringing the total to 64 MW

title: KEZAD East Port Said Logistics Zone, Egypt
body:
• AD Ports Group and the General Authority for Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZONE) have signed a 50-year renewable usufruct agreement to develop and operate a 20 square km industrial and logistics park near the Egyptian coastal city of Port Said on the Mediterranean Sea
  • The zone will be situated at the northern entrance of the Suez Canal
  • AD Ports Group will develop, construct, finance, operate and manage the zone in phases, with a focus on Phase 1 to start with, an area covering a total of 2.8 square km 
  • An estimated total investment of US$120 million will be allocated to market and technical studies as well as to phase 1 development over the next three years
  • Construction on Phase 1 is expected to start by the end of 2025
  • The development of Phase 1 will be anchored by key potential clients and partners including Hassan Allam Holding
  • KEZAD East Port Said Industrial and Logistics Zone will seamlessly connect with East Port Said Port, a key strategic location on the Mediterranean Sea. The port features deep berths for large vessels, efficient operations and excellent connectivity to advanced road and transportation networks

The development will include:

  • Community infrastructure such as a health center, school, sports field, football pitch, and community center

The project will be constructed in four phases.

title: Clayville Megacity, South Africa
body:
Clayville Megacity is a large-scale, integrated housing development located within the City of Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality. The project is designed as an infill development along the N1 Development Corridor, enhancing connectivity to major urban centers like Johannesburg, Tshwane, and Centurion.

The development aims to deliver between 12,000 and 14,200 residential units upon completion, with the following breakdown:

  • Multi-storey BNG (Breaking New Ground/RDP) units: approximately 5,300–5,400
  • Single residential FLISP (Finance Linked Individual Subsidy Programme) units: approximately 5,300–5,400
  • Multi-storey rental units: approximately 3,500

The project includes a comprehensive range of social amenities:

  • Primary and secondary schools
  • Community parks and sports facilities
  • Business stands and shopping centers
  • Multi-purpose community centers, clinics, crèches, and places of worship

title: New Garden City New Capital, Egypt
body:

title: Ebolowa-Kribi Road, Cameroon
body:
The Ebolowa–Akom II–Kribi Road Construction Project is a major infrastructure initiative by the Government of Cameroon aimed at improving internal connectivity and boosting regional trade, particularly between the country’s southern forested zones and the Atlantic coast. Stretching approximately 179.2 kilometers, the road will connect Ebolowa—the capital of the South Region—to the deep-water port of Kribi, via Akom II.

Key Features:

  • Modern two-lane asphalt road, designed to handle heavy freight traffic
  • Bridges and culverts to support year-round accessibility in all weather conditions
  • Right-of-way clearance and environmental mitigation measures are part of the preparatory activities
  • Expected to serve as a key regional trade corridor from inland Africa to the Atlantic coast

title: Ndarugu II Dam, Kenya
body: Ndarugu II Dam is a major water supply project planned at the confluence of the Ndarugu and Githobokoini rivers in Gatundu North, Kiambu County, Kenya. The dam will be a 52-meter-high roller-compacted concrete structure. It is designed to supply approximately 50,000 cubic meters of water per day.

title: GCL Blue Hydrogen Project, Ethiopia and Djibouti
body:
• China's GCL Group intends to pipe output from its natural gas fields in Ethiopia through a pipeline to Djibouti, where a 4 million tonne-a-year ammonia factory will produce blue hydrogen to be shipped to China 
  • In November 2013, POLY-GCL Petroleum Group Holdings Ltd. signed five oil and gas production sharing agreements with the Ethiopian government, under which POLY-GCL acquired eight exploration blocks and two development blocks, an acreage of natural gas reserves equivalent to an area 1.5 times of China's Jiangsu Province
  • This marked the official launch of  GCL Group's Ethiopia-Djibouti natural gas project, consisting of Ethiopian natural gas exploration and development, the Ethiopia-Djibouti long-distance pipeline and the Djibouti processing facility
  • The upstream resource blocks of the project are located in the Ogaden Basin in East Africa, with natural gas resources of 5 trillion cubic metres, oil resources of 4 billion tonnes and proven natural gas reserves of 190.7 billion cubic metres
  • The first phase is to have a production capacity of 3.5 billion cubic metres a year, which can meet the raw material demand for an annual output of 10 million tonnes of hydrogen for 40 consecutive years
  • Natural gas is designed to be transported through the pipeline from Ethiopia to the GCL processing base in Damerjog free trade zone in the capital of Djibouti, where the gas-to-ammonia and further ammonia-to-hydrogen production will be processed
  • The blue hydrogen produced will then be shipped to China and fuel steel smelting, chemical refining, power generation and other end-use applications

 

(Sources: GCL Group and Fana Broadcasting Corporation)
specifications: ["10 million tonnes of hydrogen for 40 consecutive years"]
