title: Pemba Airport Expansion, Tanzania
body:
The Pemba Airport Expansion Project in Zanzibar, Tanzania, is a strategic infrastructure development initiative aimed at transforming Karume Airport on Pemba Island into a modern international-standard facility. The project is designed to meet the growing demand for air travel, support tourism, enhance cargo handling capabilities, and stimulate economic growth in the region.

Scope of Work:

  • Runway Extension: Lengthening the runway from 2,200 meters to 2,510 meters and widening it to 45 meters to support Code 4C aircraft.
  • Terminal Expansion: Demolishing the existing terminal and constructing a new 14,000 square meter terminal building.
  • Additional Facilities: Building a new air traffic control tower, aircraft rescue and firefighting facility, electrical and airfield lighting substations, sewage treatment plant, and utility buildings.
  • Ancillary Works: Upgrading parking areas, access roads, and landscaping to enhance overall airport infrastructure.

title: Beira-Ndola Oil Pipeline
body:
Also known as Mozambique-Zambia Oil Pipeline project, the proposed Beira–Ndola Petroleum Products Pipeline is a significant infrastructure project aimed at enhancing the transport of petroleum products between Mozambique and Zambia. The pipeline is designed to run from the port city of Beira in central Mozambique to Ndola in Zambia, with a transport capacity of 3.5 million metric tons per year.

Project Scope

  • Pipeline Route: The pipeline will extend from Beira, Mozambique, to Ndola, Zambia. The distance between Beira and Ndola is approximately 1,200 kilometers.
  • Storage Facilities: The project includes the construction of petroleum storage facilities at both the Beira and Ndola terminals. These facilities are intended to support the efficient operation of the pipeline and ensure a stable supply of petroleum products.
  • Transportation Efficiency: Once operational, the pipeline is expected to reduce heavy truck traffic on regional roads, thereby improving road safety and decreasing transportation costs. It will also enhance fuel delivery efficiency, ensuring a more reliable supply of petroleum products to Zambia.

Strategic Importance

This pipeline project is part of a broader initiative to improve energy infrastructure and regional integration within the Southern African Development Community (SADC). By facilitating the direct transport of petroleum products from the Mozambican coast to Zambia's Copperbelt region, the pipeline will play a crucial role in meeting the growing energy demands of Zambia and its neighboring countries.

title: Kiffa Water Supply Project, Mauritania
body:
Project: Drinking Water Supply Project (AEP) from the Senegal River to Kiffa

  • Location: Mauritania – from Gouraye (on Senegal River) to Kiffa, approx. 600 km southeast of Nouakchott
  • Beneficiaries: ~550,000 people across 92 localities

Project Scope

Objective: Secure drinking water access through intake, transport, treatment, and distribution over a long-distance pipeline system.

Main Components: Water production, pumping, treatment, storage tanks, gravity-fed and pressurized pipelines, and distribution networks.

Component A

Lot 1: Water Production at Source (Gouraye)

  • Water production center at Gouraye
  • SP0 & SP1 pumping and treatment stations
  • Discharge pipe 1: 7 km, ductile cast iron (DN800 mm) from SP1 to reservoir R1
  • Reservoir R1: Twin tanks (2 × 5,000 m³)
  • Local distribution network in Gouraye

Lot 2: Transport to SP2

  • Gravity main pipe 1: 38 km (DN800 mm) from R1 to SP2
  • Service pipes to elevated tanks en route
  • Distribution networks for localities along R1–SP2 corridor

Lot 3: SP2 to R2

  • Pumping Station SP2
  • Reservoir R2: Twin tanks (2 × 5,000 m³)
  • Discharge pipe 2: 56 km (DN700 mm) from SP2
  • Service pipes and local distribution en route from SP2 to R2

Lot 4: R2 to SP3

  • Gravity main pipe 2: 69 km (DN700 mm) from R2 to SP3
  • Service pipes to elevated tanks
  • Distribution networks for communities between R2 and SP3

Lot 5: SP3 to Kiffa

  • Pumping Station SP3
  • Reservoir R3: Twin tanks (2 × 2,500 m³) with a re-chlorination unit
  • Discharge pipe 3: 74 km (DN600 mm) from SP3 to R3
  • Final supply pipe: 9 km (DN600 mm) connecting R3 to Kiffa network
  • Service pipes and distribution for localities from Kankoussa to Kiffa

Key Infrastructure Highlights

  • Over 250 km of transmission pipelines (DN800–DN600)
  • 3 main pumping stations (SP1, SP2, SP3)
  • 3 large-scale storage reservoirs (R1, R2, R3)
  • Full distribution networks for 92 rural and urban communities

body:

Seazen North Coast offers around 2,000 residential units, including chalets and villas with 2, 3, and 4 bedrooms. Unit sizes range from 90 to 475 square meters.

title: Mzuzu University, Malawi
body:
Project Overview

The project entails the design and construction of a new university campus for Mzuzu University in Luwinga, aimed at expanding access to tertiary education and improving academic infrastructure in Northern Malawi.

Scope of Work

The project includes the following key components:

Academic Facilities:

  • A modern library with study areas, digital resource centres, and administrative space
  • Lecture halls with a combined capacity of 1,000 students
  • Four fully equipped science laboratories for teaching and research
  • 50 administrative and academic offices

Student and Campus Life Facilities:

  • A student centre to support extracurricular and campus community activities
  • A wellness centre with capacity to accommodate up to 1,000 people, supporting physical and mental health programs

Cultural and Recreational Infrastructure:

  • A 10,000-seat stadium for university sports, events, and public gatherings
  • A multi-purpose auditorium for university ceremonies, performances, and conferences

Student Accommodation:

Objective: Increase on-campus student housing capacity by over 4,700 beds

  • Main Hostel Block:
    • 4,500 double occupancy rooms across five stories
    • Designed for shared student living with common amenities
  • Single Occupancy Rooms:
    • 200 standard single rooms for individual students
    • 20 self-contained single occupancy rooms with private bathrooms and kitchenette
  • Villa Apartments:
    • 6 villa units providing semi-independent accommodation, suitable for senior students or visiting faculty

Entrepreneurs Training and Incubation Center (ETIC):

ETIC will include a 500 seat lecture theater, 16 laboratories dedicated to artificial machinery, data science, ICT for development, internet, hardware and networking, energy and testing center. Source: Malawi News Agency

title: Renishaw Coastal Precinct, South Africa
body:
Renishaw Coastal Precinct Development

  • Location: KwaZulu-Natal Mid-South Coast, South Africa
  • Land Area: 1,300 hectares
  • Municipal Jurisdictions: eThekwini (north), Umdoni (south)

Project Overview

The Renishaw Coastal Precinct is a large-scale, mixed-use urban development masterplanned over 1,300 hectares of prime coastal land. Strategically positioned between two municipalities, it aims to stimulate sustainable regional growth and provide a range of urban functions and services.

Masterplan Components

The precinct is organized into several key development nodes, each with distinct land uses:

  • Residential: Planned neighbourhoods offering various housing typologies and densities.
  • Mixed-Use Zones: Integrated commercial and residential developments supporting retail, office, and lifestyle offerings.
  • Commercial: Designated zones for office parks, retail centers, and business hubs.
  • Industrial: Areas allocated for light industry and logistics, strategically positioned for ease of transport access.
  • Institutional: Allocated land for civic services, public administration, and community facilities.
  • Educational: Sites for schools, training centers, and tertiary institutions.
  • Healthcare: Plots designated for hospitals, clinics, and wellness facilities.

title: Ressano Garcia Railway Upgrade, Mozambique
body:
The Mozambique Ressano Garcia Railway Upgrade is a significant infrastructure project aimed at enhancing the capacity and efficiency of the railway corridor connecting Mozambique's capital, Maputo, to the South African border at Ressano Garcia. This corridor is vital for regional trade, particularly for the export of minerals and other goods from South Africa through the Port of Maputo.

Technical Scope:

Track Doubling: The project involves doubling the railway track to increase capacity and reduce congestion.

Phase 1: Completed in September 2024, this phase doubled the track between Maputo and Secongene, enhancing freight capacity from 13 million to 24 million tonnes annually.

Phase 2: Currently underway, this phase focuses on doubling the remaining 25 km stretch from Movene to Ressano Garcia.

Rolling Stock Acquisition: To support the increased capacity, the project includes the procurement of new rolling stock:

  • 15 diesel-electric locomotives
  • 250 freight wagons
  • Over 30 passenger coaches

Technological Enhancements: The new locomotives, such as the SDD1 models from CRRC Ziyang, are equipped with intelligent real-time control systems and optimized cooling technology, tailored for the African operating environment.

title: Ponta Techobanine Railway Corridor, Botswana – Zimbabwe – Mozambique
body:
The Ponta Techobanine Railway project entails the development of a new 1,700-kilometer railway corridor connecting Botswana, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique, terminating at a proposed deep-water port in Techobanine, Mozambique. The railway is designed to support both freight and passenger services, with a primary focus on mineral and bulk commodity transport from landlocked countries to the Indian Ocean.

Technical Scope:

A) Route Alignment and Corridor Configuration

  • The corridor will extend from Botswana (likely via Francistown or Lobatse), traverse central Zimbabwe (via Bulawayo, Dabuka, and Chicualacuala), and terminate in southern Mozambique at Techobanine, approximately 70 km south of Maputo.
  • The final alignment will integrate existing railway infrastructure where viable and include construction of new segments, particularly in Mozambique’s Matutuíne district.

B) Track Infrastructure

  • Gauge: Cape Gauge (1,067 mm) to ensure interoperability with existing Southern African rail networks.
  • Track Type: Welded rail on concrete sleepers; designed for heavy-haul traffic, including coal, copper, and iron ore.
  • Axle Load: Infrastructure to support a minimum of 20–25 tonnes per axle, suitable for bulk freight.

C) Structures

  • Construction of bridges, culverts, and overpasses, with consideration for floodplain areas and wildlife corridors.

title: Petrochemicals City, Mozambique
body:
National Petrochemical City – Mavanza, Inhambane

The National Petrochemical City is poised to be a landmark project for Mozambique, contributing significantly to the country’s industrial capacity, economic growth, and regional development. The project’s focus on sustainable resource use, job creation, and infrastructure development positions it as a key driver of Mozambique's economic future.

  • Location: Mavanza, Mapinhane Administrative Post, Vilankulo District, Inhambane Province, Southern Mozambique.
  • Initial Investment: Approximately USD 2 billion.
  • Promoter: Phoenix International Group, a Hong Kong-based company.
  • Launch Date: April 2025.
  • Estimated Completion Date: 2028.

Main Components and Infrastructure

Key Industrial Lines

  • Chlor-Alkali: Production of chlorine, caustic soda, and derivatives.
  • Fertilizers: Production of ammonia, urea, and other fertilizers.
  • Petrochemicals: Production of various petrochemical products.

Energy and Industrial Infrastructure

  • Refinery: Installation of a refinery for the processing of petrochemical products, logistics, and energy.
  • Thermal Power Plants: Installed capacity of 300 megawatts (MW) to power the city.
  • Maritime Terminal: Construction of a terminal with a 4 km extension for the transport of products.
  • Treatment Stations: Units for the treatment of wastewater and industrial effluents.
  • Logistics Infrastructure: Installation of transport and storage systems for raw materials and finished products.

Social and Urban Infrastructure

  • Housing: Development of modern residential neighborhoods to accommodate workers and their families.
  • Education: Establishment of schools for technical and vocational training.
  • Healthcare: Installation of hospitals and healthcare centers for the community.
  • Commerce and Services: Development of commercial centers and service facilities for the population.

Economic and Social Impact

Annual Production: More than 1 million tons of petrochemical products, including ammonia, urea, chlorine, and fertilizers.

Employment: Creation of 4,300 direct jobs and 5,000 indirect jobs, with vocational training programs for Mozambican youth.

Contribution to GDP: Estimated contribution of USD 1.15 billion to the national Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

Regional Development: Promotion of industrialization and economic transformation in Southern Mozambique.

title: New October City, Egypt
body:
• October Gardens City (New October City) – Giza Governorate, Egypt
  • Location: West of 6th of October City, Giza Governorate
  • Total Project Area: 41,780 acres
  • Total Housing Units Planned: 194,000 units

Project Overview

October Gardens City — also known as New October City — is a major urban expansion initiative designed to accommodate growing housing demand in Greater Cairo. The city integrates public, private, and cooperative sector developments, with large-scale residential programs and supporting urban infrastructure. It is master planned with sustainability and livability at its core, featuring a 13 km long and 65 m wide green belt as a central open space spine.

Housing Development Breakdown

  • By NUCA (New Urban Communities Authority):
    Includes social housing, mid-income housing, and integrated neighborhoods
    • 121,000 housing units
  • By Housing and Development Bank:
    • 21,000 housing units
  • By the Private Sector:
    Includes gated communities and private compounds
    • 41,000 housing units

Key Residential Projects within the City

  • Social Housing Project
    • 77,000 units targeted at low-income households
  • Dar Misr Housing Project
    • 177 residential buildings designed for middle-income housing
  • Sakan Misr Housing Project
    • 10,000 units, also for middle-income beneficiaries
  • Private Compounds
    These developments offer higher-end amenities and gated community living
    • Degla Gardens
    • Palm View
    • Beta Gardens

Urban Features and Amenities

  • 13 km long green belt, 65 m wide – a continuous landscaped corridor for recreation and environmental sustainability
  • Integrated infrastructure including schools, healthcare, commercial centers, and public services
  • Accessibility to major road networks connecting with Cairo and other new urban communities

title: Expansion of Chisamba Solar PV Plant, Zambia
body:
• Expand by 100 MW the 100 MW Chisamba solar photovoltaic (PV) plant located across 120 hectares in Kafungalubala village, Chisamba district  
  • Phase 1 of the plant is being built by Kariba North Bank Extension Power Corporation (KNBEPC) and had reached 91% completion as of late March 2025
  • Phase 1 is set to be commissioned in June 2025
  • Phase 2 is set to be built by PowerChina and be commissioned in 2026
  • In mid-May 2025, the Phase 1 project secured US$71.5 million in commercial debt from Stanbic Bank
    Zambia, a member of South Africa's Standard Bank Group, with financing anchored by a 13-year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with the local GreenCo Power Services (GreenCo)
  • GreenCo will supply the energy from Phase 1 to First Quantum Minerals (FQM), Zambia’s largest mining investor, under a separate Power Supply Agreement (PSA)

title: Catete and Lauca Solar PV Plants, Angola
body:
Project Overview

Angola Ministry of Energy and Water, in collaboration with Sun Africa LLC and Omatapalo, is undertaking the construction of two utility-scale photovoltaic (PV) solar power plants in Catete (Ícolo e Bengo municipality, Luanda Province) and Laúca (Malanje Province). These projects aim to bolster Angola's renewable energy capacity and support the nation's electrification goals.

Technical Specifications

Catete Solar PV Plant:

  • Installed Capacity: 104 MWp (84 MWac)
  • Location: Catete, Ícolo e Bengo municipality, Luanda Province
  • Purpose: To reinforce electricity production, supporting local communities and industrial growth in the region

Laúca Solar PV Plant (also known as Malange Solar PV Plant):

  • Installed Capacity: 400 MWp (320 MWac)
  • Location: Adjacent to the Laúca Hydroelectric Dam, Malanje Province
  • Purpose: To generate daytime energy, conserving water resources for nighttime hydroelectric production

Combined Infrastructure:

  • Photovoltaic Panels: Approximately 840,000 units across both sites
  • Grid Connection: Both plants will be integrated into Angola's national electricity grid

Scope of Work

Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC): Comprehensive development, including design, equipment supply, construction, supervision, and commissioning of both solar PV plants

title: Hayyu Green Hydrogen Hub (HGH2), Djibouti
body:
The Green Star (Hayyu) project will be developed across 870 square kilometres on the Horn of Africa in northern Djibouti 

The first phase is planned to produce up to 5 GW of wind and solar power for the annual production of 700,000 tonnes of green hydrogen 

The scheme includes the development of up to 20 GW of renewable energy capacity

According to CWP Global, Djibouti’s port infrastructure will allow the project to export green ammonia as well as serve as a refuelling station for maritime shipping. The scheme will also contribute to the diversification of Djibouti’s energy mix, with the government targeting 100% of its power to come from renewable sources by 2035

The project will also provide potable water supplies to local communities, further develop local and regional agriculture, and open the door to emerging international markets for green hydrogen and derivatives

title: Rehabilitation and Expansion of Kainji Hydropower Plant, Nigeria
body:
• Rehabilitate the 760 MW Kainji hydropower plant, located on the Niger River in Niger state, north-central Nigeria
  • The plant was commissioned in 1968 and is operated by Nigeria's Mainstream Energy Solutions Limited (MESL)  
  • The Kainji dam creates a reservoir 136 km long, holding approximately 15 billion cubic metres of water. The main dam is 550 m long with a height of 64 m
  • The plant's powerhouse has an installed capacity of 760 MW comprising eight turbine-alternator groups that include four Kaplan-type 80 MW, two turbines also Kaplan-type rated 100MW and two propeller turbines rated at 120 MW. In the original design there was a provision to further accommodate four turbines and MESL is now embarking on a project to add more turbines, with the first phase to add two turbines with a total capacity of 220 MW;
  • The contract for the two turbines has been awarded and units 1G3 and 1G4, each generating 110MW, are expected to come online in 2026; as of early April 2025, unit 1G4 had achieved a critical milestone with the successful completion of pressure tests, while unit 1G3 was undergoing spiral case installation
  • In a late January 2025 interview with The Energy Year publication, MESL managing director Lamu Audu said the civil works to add all four extra turbines had been done, with the electromechanical work left to be completed
  • MESL engineers are also currently upgrading unit 1G11. The unit's electrical and mechanical systems will be upgraded with advanced equipment including an excitation system and general protection for the generator. This will significantly enhance operational efficiency and reliability while improving SCADA
  • The 80MW unit 1G9 was successfully rehabilitated by Powerchina and began commercial operations in April 2025. The two-year rehabilitation project involved the replacement of critical components, upgrade of electrical and mechanical systems and implementation of advanced control systems to enhance operational efficiency and reliability. With this restored unit, the Kainji plant's installed capacity increased from 520 MW to 600 MW

 

(Sources: MESL and The Energy Year)

title: Nkaya–Mchinji–Chipata Border Railway Rehabilitation, Malawi
body:
Project Overview

The project involves the rehabilitation of the railway line from Nkaya (Km 297) to the Mchinji–Chipata border (Km 696), covering a total distance of approximately 399 kilometers. 

This strategic rail corridor is part of the broader regional rail network linking Malawi to Zambia and Mozambique.

Scope of Work

  • Rehabilitation of the existing track between Nkaya and Mchinji–Chipata border
  • Infrastructure upgrades to improve track safety, reliability, and capacity
  • Potential improvements to drainage structures, culverts, and crossings along the corridor
  • Support for future integration with regional logistics and trade corridors

title: Expansion of Djen Djen Port, Algeria
body:
The Djen Djen Port Expansion Project in Jijel, Algeria, is a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at transforming the port into a major Mediterranean logistics hub. 

Technical Scope:

  • Container Terminal Expansion: Construction of a new container terminal, extending the quay by 490 meters with a depth of 17 meters, enabling accommodation of vessels carrying up to 18,000 containers. 
  • Specialized Terminals: Development of dedicated terminals for minerals, asphalt, grain, and other bulk goods, enhancing the port's versatility in handling diverse cargo types. 
  • Multimodal Connectivity:
  1. Rail Infrastructure: Integration with a railway freight station within the port complex, boasting an annual handling capacity of 12 million tons, and connections to major industrial sites like the Bellara steel complex in El Milia (45 km away) and the Ramdan Djamel station in Skikda (150 km away).
  2. Road Access: Construction of the 110 km Djen Djen-El Eulma highway (Pénétrante de Djen-Djen), linking the port directly to the East-West Highway.

title: Khoemacau Copper-Silver Expansion, Botswana
body:
Khoemacau is a long-life copper silver mine located in one of the most prospective mining regions in Africa, the Kalahari Copper Belt in Botswana.

MMG announced its decision to acquire the asset in November 2023, completing the transaction in March 2024.

In June 2021, Khoemacau completed construction of its low cost, c.60ktpa copper and c.1.6Mozpa silver metal in concentrate at full run rate. It completed ramp up of current operations to full production in Q4 2022. Khoemacau’s annual production is expected to be around 43,000 and 53,000 tonnes of copper in copper concentrate.

Ore at Khoemacau is mined from underground using the longhole stoping method and transported by truck on a 35km purpose-built bitumen haul road to the Boseto processing plant. The copper concentrate is then transported by road to port and shipped to customers globally.

Drilling of and studies on its expansion project forecast a potential increase production to over 130ktpa copper and 5Mozpa silver (average run rate at full production) to unlock the full potential of its prized position in the emerging Kalahari Copper Belt.

Source: MMG Australia

title: AMEA Power Wind Farm in Gulf of Suez, Egypt
body:
Located in Ras Ghareb, within the Red Sea Governorate, AMEA Power currently has this 500 MW wind power project under construction, through its subsidy, Amunet Wind Power Company (AWPC). AMEA Power has signed power purchase agreements with the Egyptian Electricity Transmission Company (EETC) and once commissioned, the project will be one of the largest of its kind in Africa.

Source: AMEA Power

Project Overview

Also known as Amunet Wind Power Project, is a 500 MW onshore wind farm being developed by AMEA Power in Egypt’s Red Sea region. It marks a significant step in Egypt's clean energy transition and is one of the country’s largest privately developed wind power initiatives.

  • Location: Ras Ghareb, Red Sea Governorate, Egypt

  • CO₂ Emissions Offset: ~1 million tonnes/year
  • Power Purchase Agreement: 25-year PPA signed with the Egyptian Electricity Transmission Company (EETC)

Scope of Work

  • Technology: 77 Envision Energy wind turbines, each with a capacity of 6.5 MW

title: Cap Lopez LNG, Gabon
body:
Project Overview

The project involves the development of a Floating Liquefied Natural Gas (FLNG) facility designed to process and export natural gas offshore. The facility will produce 0.7 mtpa of LNG and 25,000 tons of LPG, enabling flexible and cost-effective monetization of offshore gas reserves. The FLNG system will utilize a converted gas tanker as an FSO, offering a storage capacity of 137,000 m³, minimizing the need for onshore infrastructure.

Production Capacity:

  • LNG: 0.7 million tons per annum (mtpa)
  • LPG: 25,000 tons per annum

Storage Capacity:

  • 137,000 cubic meters, housed in a converted gas tanker repurposed as a Floating Storage and Offloading unit (FSO)

title: Mmamabula West Coal Power Project, Botswana
body:
The 2,935Mt Mmamabula West project contains some of the best quality coal in Botswana in two 4m to 6m thick seams (A-Seam and K-Seam) which lie 100m to 150m below the surface. The project is situated some 65km west of the main railway line in Botswana which provides access to local and regional coal markets.

A prefeasibility study on the extraction of the high-quality lower A-Seam was completed for the project in 2015 and determined that conventional underground mining could produce a variety of products for coal export or power generation at highly competitive prices, and that this coal could be readily trucked to a rail loading station on the main Botswana railway line. African Energy has developed coal specifications for several different coal products, including high quality export coals and coal suitable for use in South African power stations.

Source: African Energy Resources

title: Integrated Water Security and Sanitation, Senegal
body:
The Integrated Water Security and Sanitation Project in Senegal is a large-scale initiative aimed at improving access to safe water and sanitation, while also enhancing resilience to climate-related risks such as floods and droughts. 

Water Resources Management and Protection

  • Restoration of Strategic Water Resources: Includes activities such as restoring depleted or polluted sources, especially at Lac de Guiers, and improving groundwater recharge and management in areas like Diass and Littoral Nord.
  • Nature-Based Solutions (NBS): Implementation of retention systems, soil restoration, and landscaping to enhance groundwater recharge and restore aquifers.

Water Supply Infrastructure

  • Drilling and Rehabilitation: Construction/rehabilitation of multi-village systems, including drilling 20 boreholes and rehabilitating or constructing 30 multi-village drinking water supply and sanitation (DWSS) systems.
  • Water Towers and Pumping Equipment: Installation of water towers and pumps to extend networks to remote villages, providing both individual household connections and public standpipes.
  • Urban Water Network Upgrades: Renewal of 20 km of existing urban water networks, extension by 3 km, and construction of 22 km of new sewerage networks, including two pumping stations and two sewage treatment plants.
  • Individual Connections: Provision of 7,250 individual water connections to households in targeted areas.

Sanitation Infrastructure

  • Household and Public Sanitation: Construction of 17,000 household latrines and 40 public toilets, with priority given to health centers and schools in rural areas.
  • Urban Sanitation: Replacement and extension of antiquated sewerage networks in Dakar and Ziguinchor, strengthening wastewater pumping capacity, and construction of new treatment plants.
  • On-site and Off-site Systems: In difficult-access urban areas, on-site sewer disposal systems are used, while off-site and semi-offsite sanitation systems are implemented where technical conditions allow connection to wastewater treatment plants.

Circular Economy and Irrigation

  • Sanitation in a Circular Economy: Focuses on improving access to urban and rural sanitation, strengthening irrigation systems, and supporting the reuse of treated wastewater where feasible.

Source World Bank - Project ID P178673
meta_description: The Integrated Water Security and Sanitation Project in Senegal is a large-scale initiative aimed at improving access to safe water and sanitation
migration_status: while also enhancing resilience to climate-related risks such as floods and droughts. Water Resources Management and Protection

title: Urban Resilience and Solid Waste Management, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
The Urban Resilience and Solid Waste Management Project in Côte d'Ivoire is a comprehensive initiative, primarily targeting the city of Abidjan and selected secondary cities, to address flood risks and modernize solid waste management systems. 

Flood Risk Mitigation Infrastructure

  • Drainage Systems: Construction and rehabilitation of primary and secondary urban drainage networks to reduce flood risk in vulnerable neighborhoods. This includes associated roadworks and nature-based solutions to combat erosion and manage stormwater.
  • Structural and Non-Structural Measures: The project integrates both physical infrastructure (e.g., drainage channels, retention basins) and non-structural interventions such as urban planning, revegetation, and early warning systems.
  • Nature-Based Solutions: Incorporation of green infrastructure to complement traditional drainage, aiming to enhance resilience to climate change and reduce erosion.

Solid Waste Management Infrastructure

  • New Facilities: Construction of seven solid waste management infrastructures, including treatment, valorization, and disposal facilities in Abidjan and targeted secondary cities.
  • Consolidation Points and Transfer Centers: Establishment of new consolidation points and transfer centers, with necessary civil works and equipment, to improve the efficiency of waste collection and transfer.
  • Landfill Development: Development of a new landfill in Kossihouen (northwest Abidjan) with a capacity to treat 1,250,000 tons/year, operated under a public-private partnership (PPP) model.
  • Recycling and Valorization: Future integration of waste recovery, recycling, reuse, and composting activities, with proposals for valorization to be evaluated for additional investment.
  • Digital Technologies: Implementation of digital platforms for service management, early warning systems, and municipal data repositories to optimize operations and planning.

Inclusive and Sustainable Practices

  • Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs): Strong involvement of the private sector in the construction, operation, and financing of waste management infrastructure, leveraging performance-based contracts and concessions.
  • Community Engagement: Active involvement of local communities, women’s organizations, and vulnerable groups in the project’s implementation, including support for microenterprises in waste collection.
  • Environmental and Social Safeguards: Adoption of World Bank Environmental and Social Standards, including resettlement action plans, conflict management mechanisms, and stakeholder engagement throughout site selection and construction

Source: World Bank - Project ID: P168308
meta_description: The Urban Resilience and Solid Waste Management Project in Côte d'Ivoire is a comprehensive initiative
migration_status: primarily targeting the city of Abidjan and selected secondary cities
migration_action: to address flood risks and modernize solid waste management systems. Flood Risk Mitigation Infrastructure

title: Morupule B Power Plant Rehabilitation, Botswana
body:
Morupule B Power Plant Remediation and Rehabilitation Project

  • Location: Palapye, Botswana
  • Installed Capacity: 600 MW (4 × 150 MW units)
  • Commissioned: 2014
  • Client: Botswana Power Corporation (BPC)

Project Overview

The project involves the comprehensive remediation and rehabilitation of the Morupule B Power Station, a 600 MW coal-fired power plant commissioned in 2014. The facility, which consists of four generating units of 150 MW each, has faced persistent operational and structural challenges since commissioning, leading to reduced availability and reliability of generation capacity.

Scope of Work

  • Engineering assessment and fault diagnostics of critical systems across all four units
  • Replacement or repair of defective boilers, turbines, and generators
  • Upgrade of emission control and dust handling systems to align with modern environmental standards
  • Rehabilitation of cooling systems, coal handling, and ash disposal infrastructure
  • Implementation of plant automation, monitoring, and protection system upgrades

title: Nexgen Sustainable City, Egypt
body:
Planned for the eastern district of Cairo in Egypt, the 580 hectare sustainable city will provide 9,000 residential units for a population of 35,000 residents. The project will create 10,000 jobs with majority focusing on green tech industries such as food-tech, energy-tech, water-tech and waste-tech, thus creating a circular green economy for the city.

KEY FACTS

  • 580 hectares with total population of 35,000 residents
  • 9,000 residential units with variation of town houses and apartments for all levels of income.
  • Smart self-sufficient city providing food, energy, and water security.
  • Climate positive city producing more renewable energy & food than it consumes
  • Solar powered atmospheric water generators will produce clean drinking water from the air.
  • 100% walkable city with dedicated running, cycling & equestrian tracks.
  • Eco resorts, nature reserve & leisure facilities to promote ecotourism.
  • Medical hub with facilities such as an autism village & wellness center as well as clinics for medical tourism.
  • State-of-the art educational facilities including nursery, school, and an institute.
    Waste recycling facilities and biogas plant for a zero-waste city.

Source: URB

title: The Parks, South Africa
body:
The 1,700 hectare smart city is planned in the eastern region of South Africa. The development provides various mixed use hubs such as residential, medical, tourism, entertainment, retail & education. 40,000 residential units are distributed in 12 residential districts.

KEY FACTS

  • 17 KM2
  • $20 Billion USD
  • 150,000 residents
  • 40,000 residential units
  • 5km park
  • 100% renewable energy
  • 100% Food production
  • 100% water recycling
  • Smart self sufficient city
  • Car-free city
  • 25 kms dedicated running & cycling tracks
  • 7km dedicated equestrian track
  • Ecotourism, medical tourism & edutainment
  • State-of-the art education
  • Zero-waste city

Source: URB

title: Dekemhare Solar and BESS Plant, Eritrea
body:
• Design, supply and install a 30 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) plant and 15 MW/ 30 MWh battery energy storage system (BESS) in Dekemhare, southern Eritrea
  • Associated facilities include a 66 kV substation, connection to 66 kV transmission line connecting to the existing Asmara East-Dekemhare transmission line about 1 km from the project site in a loop-in-loop-out arrangement
  • The project will increase both system generation capacity and energy to 185 MW and 365 GWh/year  respectively
  • The contract includes a 1 year defect liability period

body:
The hotel is situated in Dar es Salaam’s CBD. This is a 138-room hotel featuring 94 guestrooms and 44 three-bedroom apartments. The hotel will occupy the top 14 floors of a 33-floor tower, one of the tallest buildings in the area.

The hotel will offer a diverse array of dining facilities, including a lobby café, business class lounge, all-day dining restaurant, specialty restaurant, outdoor pool, and pool restaurant. Additional amenities include retail stores, a ladies’ salon, indoor parking, a gym, steam room and sauna, kids’ playroom, and eight meeting rooms.

title: Radisson Hotel Mwanza, Tanzania
body:
This 196-room hotel is situated in Mwanza, Tanzania’s second-largest city. It will feature a lobby café and bar, all-day dining restaurant, sports bar, outdoor pool bar, executive lounge, and two specialty restaurants, Balaustine, a ‘casual-fine dining’ experience inspired by the Barbary coast and the Levant and Filini, offering a delectable dining experience of fresh, simple, and delicious Italian-style cuisine.

The meetings and events space includes a triple-height ballroom, a business center, boardrooms, and a conference room. The extensive wellness facilities will include a gym, spa, outdoor pool, and a kids’ playground.

Source: Capital Ethiopia

title: GIETAF Special Economic Zone, Gambia
body:
The Special Economic Zone (SEZ) at Yundum International Airport, Banjul, The Gambia. 

The project created several zones for different land use, including Residential, Light Industrial, Commercial Office, Showroom, and Retail. The project has undertaken the initial Phase 1 build out and is currently in an extensive marketing phase to initiate the further development and roll-out of the scheme in its entirety. The precinct seeks to create a major commercial district adjacent to the airport at Yundum.

title: Ndola–Sakania–Mufulira Road, Zambia
body:
Project Overview

Ndola–Sakania–Mufulira Road Project is a strategic infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing regional connectivity and trade between Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The project encompasses the rehabilitation and upgrading of the M4 road, which connects Ndola to Mufulira via Sakania, and includes significant improvements to border infrastructure at the Sakania border post. ​

Scope of Work

Road Construction and Upgrading:

  • Ndola to Kamalasha Junction: Upgrade to a dual carriageway (2+2 lanes) to improve traffic flow and safety.
  • Kamalasha Junction to Sakania Border Post: Reconstruction of the existing gravel road to a single-lane rigid pavement (1+1 lanes).
  • Kamalasha Junction to Mufulira: Upgrade to a dual carriageway (2+2 lanes) to accommodate increased traffic volumes. ​

Border Post Infrastructure Development:

  • Sakania Border Post:
    • Construction of government cluster offices, warehousing facilities, passenger terminals, logistics centers, banking halls, and shopping areas.
    • Development of truck parking bays, toll plazas, weighbridges, and installation of ICT systems for efficient border operations.
    • Implementation of perimeter fencing and security installations to enhance safety and control.

Integrated Transport System and Instrumentation:

  • Installation of advanced traffic management systems to monitor and control vehicle movement.
  • Deployment of surveillance and communication equipment to ensure security and efficient operations along the corridor.
  • Implementation of tolling systems and weigh-in-motion stations to manage and regulate freight transport. ​

title: Cubango/Cunene – Cuvelai Water Transfer Scheme, Nigeria
body:
Overview

The Cuvelai Basin regularly suffers from severe water shortages. In response, the Angolan Ministry of Energy and Water commissioned Dar to provide consultancy services on a large-scale venture that aimed to resolve this issue by transferring water from the Cunene and Cubango river basins to the Cuvelai catchment area, increasing the capacity of the water supply system, establishing water reservoirs, and creating an effective and viable water transfer system. 

At a glance

  • 5 dams
  • 210 boreholes
  • 350 groundwater wells

The project

The project involved developing a strategic inter-basin water transfer (diversion) scheme from the right bank of the Cubango River, to the Cuvelai River and several other streams in the Cuvelai Basin, in order to resolve long-term water stress issues, increasing water availability and developing irrigated perimeters in the basin.

The final transfer scheme comprises five dams; 210 boreholes with related pumping, storage, and distribution systems; flood protection measures; a pumping station; a 14-km-long diversion channel North of Cunene; two other diversion channels with lengths of 15 km and 25 km; control structures; and other appurtenances.

The five dams include four earthfill dams ranging in height from 20 to 28 metres, in length from 1,300 to 1,870 metres, and in capacity from 100 MCM to 220 MCM. The remaining dam is a RCC dam with a height of 46 metres, a length of 1,000 m, and a capacity of 2.28 BCM. The project also comprised the diversion tunnels and dikes and all other appurtenances in addition to access roads of various lengths and widths, leading to the sites of the dams.

The project also comprised conducting hydrogeological investigations, identifying the number of needed wells, and preparing well cross-sections for the drilling and commissioning of over 350 groundwater wells to serve the short-term water resources plan for 158 localities

Components

  • Cunene River Water Transfer System – Cafu Town to Shana Zone (Towns of Cuamato and Namacunde. The Future Phase includes Cubango Water Transfer System to Cuvelai Basin (includes the construction of Mumba Dam, diversions, tunnels, and the channelisation of the Cuvelai Rivers).
  • Dam 128 (Calucuve) and its associated channel. The Future Phase includes expanding the Integrated Water Supply System serving the municipalities of Cahama, Otchinjau, and Chitado.
  • Dam 71 (Ndue) and its associated channel.
  • Exploration of the Chiede/Ohangwena II Deep Groundwater Aquifer.
  • Cova do Leao Dam and Integrated Water Supply System for the Cahama, Otchinjau and Chitado Municipalities.

Source: Dar

title: Minim Martap Bauxite Development, Cameroon
body:
• Canyon Resources is developing the Minim Martap Bauxite Project in Cameroon, which contains over 1 billion tonnes of high-grade, low-contaminant bauxite, as a direct shipping ore (DSO) development opportunity
  • The Project is located in central Cameroon and situated near the main rail line linking the region to the Atlantic port of Douala
  • The Bank Feasibility Study (BFS), released in June 2022, outlined an operation that will produce up to 6.4Mt of high-grade bauxite per annum using an open cut mine extracting DSO bauxite, using only surface mining and no drilling and blasting
  • Minim Martap ranks among the world’s richest bauxite deposits, with an Ore Reserve of 109Mt at 51.1% Al2O3 and 2.0% SiO2 and a JORC Mineral Resource Estimate of 1,027Mt at 45.3% Al2O3
  • Results from the BFS confirmed Minim Martap as a robust long-term project, containing some of the highest-grade bauxite globally for an initial 20 years of mining
  • The 20-year mining schedule represents only 10.6% of the current Minim Martap Resource and technical studies have identified opportunities for a significant future increase in production tonnages
  • The Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS) is on track for completion in Q3 2025. The DFS is assessing the implementation of the two-stage development aimed at accelerating production through a phased ramp-up approach, which would see Minim Martap make its first shipment of bauxite in H1 2026
  • In July 2024, Canyon announced a key milestone for Minim Martap through the signing of a Mining Convention for the Project, which allows Canyon’s subsidiary, Camalco Cameroun, to mine and export Alumina and bauxite at the Project, on the grant to the Company of a mining permit
  • The results of the drilling campaign are to be assessed and released along with an updated JORC-compliant mineral resource estimate in H1 2025
  • Large-scale logistics infrastructure will enable the transportation of production, including: (i) a 50 km upgraded government road and road extension linking the mining area to the approved Inland Rail Facility, (ii) an existing 800 km railway line to the coast to be upgraded and completed (contract with CAMRAIL) and procurement of new rolling stock scheduled for Q1 2025), and (iii) a dedicated port facility to be developed in Douala port that will offer bauxite-specific unloading, stockpiling and barge-loading facilities. The terminal will be established on the banks of the Wouri River near Dibamba
  • Over the longer-term, Canyon will focus on integrating Minim Martap with processing plants producing alumina and aluminium. A BFS contract is being finalised with an alumina refinery developer for a 1m MT p.a. refinery plant to be established at mine head to produce smelter-grade alumina destined for export and local consumption; construction is expected to start within 2 years after BFS completion

title: Qena Safaga Hurghada Rail, Egypt
body:
Also known as the third line of the high-speed train network (Qena - Safaga - Hurghada). 

The track extends from the interchange station with the second line (Qena Station, which will be implemented with the second line), then extends east to Hurghada and then to the port of Safaga, with a length of about 175 km. The design speed of the project is 250 km/hour, and the operational speed of the fast electric trains is 230 km/hour (6 trains). ) Regional electric trains 160 km/h (12 trains) and electric freight tractors 120 km/h (6 trains). The project includes 3 stations, 2 high-speed train stations and 1 regional station, which is (Hurghada - Sahl Hasheesh - Safaga).

Source: National Authority for Tunnels

title: Qalyoub Railway Modernization, Egypt
body:
Project Description

The project involves the modernization of signalling and telecommunication systems, along with track rehabilitation and duplication across two key railway corridors in Egypt, enhancing capacity, safety, and service reliability.

Scope of Work

Track Works:

  • Rehabilitation and duplication of:
    • Qalyoub – Menouf – Tanta Line (approx. 94 km)
    • Qalyoub – Shebin El Qanater – El Zagazig Line (approx. 64 km)

Signalling & Telecommunications:

  • Modernization of signalling systems to enhance operational safety and efficiency.
  • Upgrade of telecommunication infrastructure along both corridors.

Interlocking Station Modernization:

  • Modernization of two interlocking stations:
    • Farz
    • Limon Bridge

title: Maguga Hydropower Plant Expansion, Eswatini
body:
Project Description

The project involves the expansion of the existing Maguga Hydropower Plant to increase its installed generation capacity by an additional 10 MW to 20 MW. This initiative aims to strengthen Eswatini’s renewable energy output and improve the national electricity supply.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a new powerhouse:
    A reinforced concrete surface powerhouse to accommodate new turbine-generator units.
  • Installation of generating equipment:
    Including turbines, generators, and associated electro-mechanical systems.
  • Associated civil infrastructure:
    Dewatering bay and necessary hydromechanical structures.
  • Electrical works:
    • Extension of the existing switchyard.
    • Installation of a new transformer for power evacuation and grid integration.

title: Regional Emergency Solar Power Intervention Project (RESPITE)
body:
• Countries Involved: Sierra Leone, Chad, Togo, Liberia
  • Project Type: Renewable Energy Generation, Grid Infrastructure, and Regional Coordination
  • Funding: Approx. US$311 million (IDA financing)
  • Lead Implementing Entity: National governments of participating countries and the West Africa Power Pool (WAPP)

Project Description

This multi-country renewable energy project aims to improve electricity generation capacity, enhance grid reliability, and foster regional energy integration across four West African countries—Sierra Leone, Chad, Togo, and Liberia. The project includes the deployment of solar photovoltaic (PV) and hydropower systems, battery energy storage solutions (BESS), transmission and distribution upgrades, and technical assistance for institutional and regional coordination.

Scope of Work

Component 1: Solar PV with Battery Storage and Grid Connections

  • Scope:
    • Installation and commissioning of approx. 116 MW of solar PV capacity integrated with battery storage systems across Sierra Leone, Chad, Togo, and Liberia.
    • Includes grid connection infrastructure and short-term (3-year) operation and maintenance (O&M) contracts.
  • Budget: US$184 million (IDA)

Component 2: Mt. Coffee Hydro Expansion and Dam Safety

  • Scope:
    • Expansion of 44 MW hydropower capacity at Mt. Coffee Hydro Power Plant in Liberia.
    • Implementation of dam safety enhancement measures.
  • Budget: US$61 million (IDA)

Component 3: Distribution and Transmission Infrastructure

  • Scope:
    • Implementation of grid reinforcement and optimization measures in Sierra Leone and Togo.
    • Upgrading of distribution networks to accommodate additional renewable generation.
  • Budget: US$15.5 million (IDA)

Component 4: Regional Coordination and Technical Assistance

  • Scope:
    • Led by the West Africa Power Pool (WAPP), this component includes institutional strengthening, capacity building for implementing agencies, and technical assistance to support greater cross-border energy trade and integration.
  • Budget: US$50.5 million (IDA)

title: Rehabilitation of Kalemie Port, DRC
body:
The rehabilitation and modernization of the Port of Kalemie in the DRC encompasses several key features aimed at transforming it into a regional trade hub. It will have the following facilities:

  • Port facilities: Rehabilitation of the dry dock, slipway, and military annex, alongside construction of new administrative buildings.
  • Cargo handling: Expansion to handle up to 2 million tonnes annually post-modernization, with container facilities including yards (4,700 TEU capacity) and refrigerated stations
  • Vessel upgrades: Introduction of vessels capable of transporting dry cargo, liquid cargo, and passengers.

title: Isaka Rusumo Rail, Tanzania
body:
Isaka–Kigali Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) is a significant infrastructure project jointly undertaken by Tanzania and Rwanda, aiming to enhance regional connectivity and trade.​

Project Overview

  • Total Length: Approximately 571 km
  • Gauge: Standard gauge (1,435 mm)
  • Electrification: 25 kV AC overhead catenary system
  • Estimated Cost: Around US$2.5 billion
  • Purpose: To facilitate efficient cargo and passenger transport between the Port of Dar es Salaam and Kigali, and further to neighboring countries like Burundi and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Route Details

  • Tanzania Section: Isaka to Rusumo
    • Length: Approximately 371 km
    • Terrain: Relatively flat
    • Estimated Cost: US$942 million
    • Status: Feasibility studies completed; funding discussions ongoing.
  • Rwanda Section: Rusumo to Kigali
    • Length: Approximately 150 km
    • Terrain: More mountainous
    • Estimated Cost: US$847 million
    • Status: Feasibility studies completed; plans to extend to Bugesera International Airport.

Project Components

  • Passenger Terminal: To be constructed in Ndera, approximately 20.5 km east of Kigali city center.
  • Cargo Terminal: Planned for Masaka, about 17 km southeast of Kigali's central business district.

Technical Specifications

  • Design Speed:
    • Passenger Trains: Up to 160 km/h
    • Freight Trains: Up to 120 km/h
  • Power Source: Electric locomotives powered by a 25 kV AC overhead catenary system.

Financing and Implementation

  • Tanzania: Responsible for funding the Isaka–Rusumo segment.
  • Rwanda: Adopting a public-private partnership model for the Rusumo–Kigali segment.
    International Support: The World Bank has expressed interest in funding the project.
meta_description: Isaka–Kigali Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) is a significant infrastructure project jointly undertaken by Tanzania and Rwanda
migration_status: aiming to enhance regional connectivity and trade.​Project Overview

title: Aghlabid Medical City, Tunisia
body:
Project Overview

  • Project Name: Cité Médicale des Aghlabides (Aghlabid Health City)
  • Location: Approximately 40 km from Kairouan, Tunisia
  • Total Area: Approximately 552 hectares (5.52 million m²)
  • Built-Up Area: Approximately 300 hectares (3 million m²)
  • Estimated Cost: Around 5 billion Tunisian dinars (approx. USD 1.6 billion)
  • Timeline: Feasibility studies to commence in early 2025; construction expected to begin between 2026 and 2027
  • Employment Impact: Projected to create between 40,000 and 50,000 direct and indirect jobs ​

Key Components

Healthcare Facilities

  • University hospital center (CHU) with 400 beds, expandable to 600
  • Multidisciplinary military clinic
  • Psychiatric center and autism care center
  • Emergency medical assistance center
  • Private clinics and specialized treatment centers
  • Two hotel units for medical tourism ​

Academic and Research Institutions

  • Military academy of medicine offering trilingual instruction (Arabic, French, English)
  • National school of biomedical engineering
  • Health sciences institute and medical simulation center
  • University residences and associated facilities ​

Industrial and Technological Zones

  • Production facilities for medical equipment and pharmaceuticals
  • Sterilization and biopharmaceutical manufacturing units
  • Renewable energy production center
  • High-performance medical waste management system ​

Residential and Public Services

  • Residential area spanning 53 hectares with villas and apartments
  • Educational institutions: kindergartens, primary, junior high, and secondary schools
  • Public amenities: banks, pharmacies, mosques, administrative service centers ​

Leisure and Cultural Facilities

  • Tourist area and commercial complex
  • Multidisciplinary sports fields
  • Cultural venues: indoor and outdoor theaters, clubs, cinemas
  • Parks and green spaces ​

Governance and Development

The Tunisian government has established a dedicated public company, the Société médicale de la ville des Aghlabides de Kairouan, to oversee the project's studies and infrastructure development. This entity will operate under the supervision of the Ministry of Equipment and Housing .​
meta_description: Project Overview
migration_status: skipped

title: Tanzania Roads to Inclusion and Socioeconomic Opportunities, Tanzania
body:
The Tanzania Roads to Inclusion and Socioeconomic Opportunities (RISE) Project is a major infrastructure initiative focused on improving rural road access, enhancing connectivity, and fostering socioeconomic development in Tanzania. 

The project aims to construct and upgrade 535 km of tarmac road, 400 km by TARURA (Tanzania Rural and Urban Roads Agency) and 175 km by TANROADS (Tanzania National Roads Agency).

title: Dakar Tambacounda Rail Upgrade, Senegal
body:
Modernization of Dakar–Tambacounda Railway Line and conversion to Standard Gauge (SGR). 

Project Description

The project involves the rehabilitation, modernization, and conversion of the existing Dakar–Tambacounda railway line in Senegal from metre gauge to standard gauge. After being shelved by the previous administration, the initiative is now being revived by the current government, with completion estimated over a 5- to 10-year period.

Scope of Work

  • Rehabilitation of the existing metre-gauge railway infrastructure as an intermediate step.
  • Conversion to standard-gauge tracks along the full length of the line.
  • Procurement and commissioning of 32 modern trainsets.
  • Construction of new modern railway stations along the route to enhance passenger experience and operational efficiency.
  • Development of a dry port in either Kidira or Tambacounda to improve logistics and cargo handling capabilities.
  • Phased implementation approach to allow for progressive milestones while securing financing and managing national debt considerations.

Estimated Investment

Approximately 1,200 billion CFA francs (around USD 2.1 billion).

title: ISF Walvis Bay Green Energy Complex, Namibia
body:
Project Description

The Walvis Bay Green Energy Complex is a large-scale, integrated energy infrastructure project spearheaded by ISF Trading Enterprises. 

The complex will comprise three major components to support Namibia’s energy transition and industrial capacity:

Modular Oil Refinery

  • Capacity: 300,000 barrels per stream day (BPSD)
  • Initially designed to process imported crude oil
  • Will transition to processing domestically produced crude by 2027–2028 as Namibia's upstream oil production scales up

Renewable Energy Power Plant

  • Capacity: 500 MW
  • Will supply green electricity to the refinery and associated infrastructure

Desalination Plant

  • Capacity: 4,000 m³/day
  • Will provide water for industrial processes within the complex

Site & Land Allocation:

The project is to be located on a 305-hectare industrial site (Portion 46), conditionally allocated by the Walvis Bay Town Council.

title: Volobe Amont Hydropower Plant, Madagascar
body:
Build a 120MW upstream hydropower project on the Ivondro River in the eastern Atsinanana region

Work on the scheme includes building:

  • A dam 25 metres high and 350 metres wide, creating a reservoir of 15 million cubic metres;
  • An underground plant with six horizontal-axis Francis turbines, each with a unit capacity of 20MW;
  • Intake, surge and pressure shafts, and headrace and tailrace tunnels, altogether approximately 6.8km long, with a gross head of about 130 metres;
  • A 1.5MW micro-power plant to turbine the ecological flow;
  • An outdoor substation and a high-voltage transmission line about 30km long connecting to the existing Toamasina substation;
  • Repair the 26km main access road and construct a 150-metre bridge across the Ivondro River.

 

The developer consortium of EDF , Axian Energy and Africa50 is set to design, finance, construct, operate and transfer the hydro plant and its infrastructure to the government under a 25-year concession agreement

The project is expected to increase the country's power production by about 20% through an annual output of 750GWh, and provide electricity to nearly 2 million people in the largest cities of the Atsinanana region, including the economic hub of Toamasina, where the country's main port is located

The scheme is also envisaged to contribute to the government’s target to have renewable power make up 75% of its energy mix by 2030

According to CGHV, hydropower production will vary depending on the time of year and the plant’s reservoir can be utilised in the dry season to concentrate part of the production on peak consumption

Under its current design, the Volobe plant will be able to produce 40% of Madagascar’s current national electricity consumption

title: Abuja Warri Railway, Nigeria
body:
The project entails the construction and extension of a standard gauge railway (SGR) line connecting Abuja in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) to Itakpe and Warri in southern Nigeria, integrating key inland and coastal logistics hubs. The key scope elements include:

  • Main Line: Extension of the existing Itakpe–Warri railway northward to Abuja, via Baro city, improving connectivity between central and southern Nigeria.
  • Branch Line: A spur line to Lokoja, the capital of Kogi State, enhancing multimodal integration and accessibility for inland states.
  • Port Connection: Completion of the railway segment between Warri Central Station and the new Warri Sea Port, enabling efficient freight movement from inland Nigeria to the coast.
  • New Port Construction: Development of a new deep-sea port in Warri, to serve as a strategic export-import terminal connected by rail to the hinterland.

​Abuja–Itakpe–Warri Railway Extension project encompasses several segments with the following approximate lengths:​

  • Warri to Itakpe: 326 kilometers ​
  • Itakpe to Abuja: Approximately 300 kilometers (planned extension)​
  • Branch line to Lokoja: Approximately 50 kilometers (planned spur)​

The total length of the railway, including the planned extensions and branch line, is approximately 676 kilometers.​

title: Lagos–Kano Railway Ibadan–Kano Section, Nigeria
body:
Lagos–Kano Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) Ibadan–Kano Section. Also known as Ibadan–Kano Standard Gauge Railway. 

Project Description (Scope of Work):

The Ibadan–Kano Standard Gauge Railway forms the northern section of the Lagos–Kano rail corridor and will extend approximately 790.6 kilometres, supporting passenger and freight transport across key economic regions in Nigeria. The project is being developed in three phases:

  • Section 1: Kaduna–Kano (203 km), with 6 passenger stations and a link to the Kano–Maradi Railway, enhancing regional connectivity with Niger Republic.
  • Section 2: Ibadan–Minna (460 km), traversing Oyo, Osun, and Kwara States.
  • Section 3: Minna–Abuja (127 km), improving connections to the nation's capital.

Once complete, this railway line will provide a seamless standard gauge connection between Lagos Port (via Ibadan) and Kano, with a link to Tin Can Island Port, significantly enhancing inland freight logistics and reducing travel time across Nigeria’s central transport corridor.

title: New Casablanca Port Shipyard, Morocco
body:
• Develop, equip, operate and maintain a new shipyard at the Port of Casablanca over a period of 30 years
  • The  shipyard will have a 244 m x 40 m dry dock, a 150 m x 28 m lifting platform with a capacity of 9,000 tonnes, a 62 m x 13 m dock equipped with a 450-tonne strap gantry crane and outfitting quays with a total
    length of 820 linear metres. The shipyard also includes 21 hectares of backfill land
  • With the new facilities, such as the three fitting-out quays, the future shipyard will have the capacity to deal with 22 units per year in a dry dock, 400 to 470 boats using the dockside crane and simultaneously 6 medium-sized boats on the lifting platform 
  • The shipyard is set to strengthen the country's ship repair capacity, satisfy demand and diversify services provided to the users of the Port of Casablanca
  • With this project, Casablanca aims to make the most of its geographic position and the high amount of traffic along its coasts. It also hopes to respond to the strong demand for boat repair in light of the saturation in supply, in particular, on the Canary Islands
  • In addition to its infrastructure, the new shipyard will guarantee efficient management, (entry and exit of boats, processing and handling times, development of a unique and visible interface) and will offer competitive services (for quality, diversity and service cost)

title: Hera-Westgate 400kV Transmission Line, South Africa
body:
The 36 km 400 kV Hera-Westgate line is to be constructed in the Gauteng province by an independent transmission provider

The project is part of phase 1 of the West Rand strengthening project

The work includes constructing 500 MVA of transformer capacity

The line will have a transfer capacity of 400MW and is set to be completed by 30 January 2029

The line is part of the pilot tender (Phase 1) of South Africa’s Independent Transmission Projects (ITP) programme through which the government is looking to collaborate with the private sector for the expansion and strengthening of the country’s transmission network as required by the Transmission Development Plan (TDP) 2024

The 180 km 400 kV Pluto-Mahikeng line running from the Gauteng province to the North West province is to be undertaken by an independent transmission provider

title: F Tower, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
General Overview

  • Height: 421 meters (including spire), making it the tallest building in Africa upon completion.
  • Floors: 76 above ground, plus 3 basement levels.
  • Gross Floor Area: Approximately 140,000 m².
  • Primary Use: Administrative offices for the Ivorian government, with additional amenities.

Structural & Engineering Highlights

  • Foundation System:
    • Comprises a 3.5-meter-thick reinforced concrete raft slab.
    • Supported by 70 barrettes (rectangular piles) measuring 2.8m x 1.5m, extending 60 to 70 meters deep. ​
  • Superstructure:
    • Constructed entirely of cast-in-place concrete.
    • Stabilized by a central core.
    • Perimeter columns align with the faceted outer shell, featuring varying inclinations. ​
  • Wind & Seismic Engineering:
    • Advanced modeling conducted to analyze dynamic responses to wind and seismic activities.
    • Sensitivity analyses performed to validate structural assumptions. ​

Architectural Features

  • Design Inspiration:
    • Symmetrical geometry inspired by African tribal masks.
    • Faceted façade with sloping glass panels and reflective white bands, reminiscent of traditional West African fabrics. ​
  • Double-Skin Façade:
    • Outer layer consists of 16,000 glass panels covering 36,000 m².
    • Functions as a brise-soleil (sunshade) to enhance energy efficiency.
    • Maintenance catwalks situated between the inner and outer skins. ​
  • Public Spaces:
    • A "lantern" at the summit offers a 30-meter-high panoramic space with 360° views of Abidjan and the Ébrié Lagoon.
    • Accessible to the public via a dedicated panoramic elevator. ​

Interior Layout & Amenities

  • Auditorium: 200-seat facility located on the first floor.
  • Ceremonial Hall: Double-height space situated on the 60th floor.
  • Vertical Transportation:
    • 21 elevators.
    • 2 freight elevators.
    • 1 panoramic elevator servicing the lantern. ​

Sustainability & Certifications

Environmental Certification: EDGE (Excellence in Design for Greater Efficiencies), focusing on energy and water efficiency. 

Project Significance

The F Tower is a landmark project aimed at centralizing government administrative functions, reducing rental expenditures, and maximizing land use efficiency in Abidjan's Plateau district. It symbolizes Côte d’Ivoire’s commitment to modern infrastructure and sustainable urban development. ​

title: Benghazi Sallum Rail, Libya
body:
This project is the Libyan section of Egypt Libya Rail link project which involves the construction of a major transnational railway line spanning approximately 1,080 kilometers, designed to link Alexandria on Egypt’s north coast to Benghazi in eastern Libya. 

This strategic corridor will enhance regional connectivity, support trade and economic integration between Egypt and Libya, and lay the groundwork for broader North African rail integration.

Route and Geography

  • Total Length (Alexandria - Benghazi): ~1,080 km
  • Egypt Section (Alexandria - Sallum): ~520 km
  • Libya Section (Sallum - Benghazi): ~560 km

Key Stations and Cities Along the Route:

  • Alexandria (Egypt)
  • Sallum (Egypt–Libya border)
  • Tobruk (Libya)
  • Al Bayda (Libya)
  • Benghazi (Libya)

Scope of Work

  • Construction of dual and/or single-track railway segments as per terrain and traffic forecasts.
  • Establishment of new rail stations, maintenance depots, and cargo terminals.
  • Installation of modern signalling and communication systems.
  • Border infrastructure and customs facilities at Sallum.

title: Benghazi Metro, Libya
body:
Benghazi Metro and Integrated Electric Bus Systems project is a transformative initiative aimed at modernizing the urban transportation infrastructure of Benghazi, Libya's second-largest city. The project encompasses the development of a 130-kilometer metro network complemented by an electric bus system, designed to enhance mobility, reduce traffic congestion, and promote sustainable urban growth.​

Key Components

  • Metro Network: Development of a 130-kilometer metro system with six updated routes, approved by the Libyan Railroads committee. ​
  • Electric Bus System: Integration of electric buses to provide last-mile connectivity and complement the metro network, ensuring comprehensive urban coverage.​
  • Renewable Energy Integration: Utilization of renewable energy sources to power the transportation systems, aiming for carbon-neutral operations. ​

Scope of Work

  • Infrastructure Development:
    • Construction of metro lines, stations, and related facilities.
    • Establishment of electric bus routes and charging stations.​
  • Technology and Equipment:
    • Procurement and installation of modern rolling stock and electric buses.
    • Implementation of advanced signaling, communication, and control systems.​

title: Ferkessedougou Dry Port, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
Ferkessedougou Dry Port and Industrial Park

Location: Ferkessedougou, northern Côte d’Ivoire (near the borders with Burkina Faso and Mali)

Purpose: To serve as an inland logistics and industrial hub connected to the port of Abidjan, facilitating trade flows with landlocked neighboring countries.

Key Project Components

  • Logistics Platform
    • Warehouses and storage facilities
    • Cold chain systems for perishable goods
  • Hydrocarbon Depot
    Storage and distribution infrastructure for petroleum products
  • Regional Abattoir and Livestock Market
    Facilities to support regional meat processing and livestock trade
  • Industrial Zone
    Designated area for agro-industrial and mining product processing industries

Scope of Construction Work

  • Site Preparation & Remediation
    Land clearance, leveling, and environmental mitigation measures
  • Transport Infrastructure
    Development of multimodal transport platforms with equipment for cargo handling and logistics
  • Oil Depot Construction
    Building and outfitting of fuel storage and distribution units

title: Port Said - Abu Qir Rail, Egypt
body:
Also known as High Speed Electric Train Line 4. 

Project Overview

The project involves the construction of an Electric Express Train network, designed to enhance high-speed rail connectivity across the northern Delta region of Egypt.

Key Details

  • Route Length: 250 kilometers
  • Start and End Points: Port Said - Abu Qir Port (Alexandria)
  • Number of Stations: 14
  • Governorates Covered:
    • Port Said
    • Dakahlia
    • Damietta
    • Kafr El-Sheikh
    • Beheira
    • Alexandria

Additional Features

An interchange station will be established in Alexandria to provide connectivity with the planned Alexandria Metro Line.

title: Cairo Bus Rapid Transit, Egypt
body:
The new Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) is one of the forms of urban development that the Egyptian government is working on to develop the road and bridge network, and to start the new era of replacing microbuses on the Ring Road. The BRT is distinguished by being one of the means of expanding the implementation of green, sustainable, environmentally friendly transportation networks that operate on electricity, in addition to being a safe and fast means of transportation for passengers on the Ring Road. 

The Ministry of Transport is developing a comprehensive plan to achieve safety and comfort for citizens and provide a clean environment to ease the burden on the Egyptian family. This comes within the framework of the political leadership's keenness to provide a decent life for citizens from the moment they leave their homes until they return, and to provide all daily services efficiently and effectively, given that the process of moving from one place to another is one of the important services.

Source: General Authority for Roads and Bridges

Cairo BRT project, set to operate along the Ring Road, represents a strategic alternative to the previously proposed Cairo Metro Line 5, which has since been cancelled. Designed to enhance public mobility and reduce reliance on informal transport, the BRT system will be implemented in two phases, ultimately covering 49 stations and operating with a fleet of 100 electric buses. 

Phase 1 will include the development and operation of 36 stations, prioritizing high-traffic areas to maximize early impact. The project aligns with national goals for sustainable and inclusive urban development, offering a reliable, efficient, and environmentally friendly transit option for millions of daily commuters.

title: Cairo Metro Line 2 Upgrade, Egypt
body:
Also known as Cairo Metro Line 2 Rehabilitation and Extension Project. 

Overview

Cairo Metro Line 2 (CML2) currently runs from Shubra El Kheima to El Monieb, covering a total length of 21.5 km and serving 20 stations, including:

  • 12 underground stations
  • 6 surface stations
  • 2 elevated stations

An 8 km northern extension from Shubra El Kheima to Qalyub City is also planned, adding 7 new stations to improve regional connectivity.

Scope of Rehabilitation Works 

The comprehensive upgrade of Line 2 aims to enhance system capacity, safety, and efficiency. Key components include:

  • Modernization of systems: Replacement and upgrade of signalling, safety, power supply, control, and electromechanical systems to support a reduced headway of 105 seconds (from the current 160 seconds).
  • Rolling stock upgrade: Modernization of 45 train sets, including installation of advanced onboard communication systems.
  • Maintenance innovation: Implementation of a Computerised Maintenance Management System (CMMS) to improve reliability, operational performance, and maintenance efficiency.

title: Oran Metro, Algeria
body:
Oran Metro will be developed in three phases, covering key areas of the city to enhance urban mobility and reduce congestion.

Phase 1

  • Route: Hai El Feth to Boulevard 5 July
  • Length: 13.3 km
  • Stations: 13
  • This initial phase forms the backbone of the metro line, connecting major residential and commercial zones.

Phase 2

  • Route: Green Theatre to Wilaya Headquarters
  • Length: 1.74 km
  • Stations: 2
  • This segment improves access to cultural and administrative centers.

Phase 3

  • Route: Boulevard 5 July to the University Pole
  • Length: 4.22 km
  • Stations: 5
  • This phase aims to serve the academic community, linking the metro to key university facilities.

title: Algiers Metro Extension El Harrach - Bab Ezzouar - Algiers Airport, Algeria
body:
The new metro line will span 9.5 km and feature 9 stations, enhancing connectivity between densely populated residential areas, key academic institutions, and major transport hubs in Algiers. The line will serve neighborhoods including Beaulieu, Oued Smar, Cité 5 Juillet, Bab Ezzouar, El Harrach Pôle Universitaire, Bab Ezzouar Business Center, and Houari Boumediene University.

Stations and Key Connections:

  • Hassan Badi Station
    Located near Hocine Badi Hospital and the National Agricultural Institute.
  • Pôle Universitaire Station
    Serves the National Agricultural Institute, the Polytechnic School of Architecture and Urban Planning, and the National Veterinary School.
  • Beaulieu Station
    Centrally located in the Beaulieu neighborhood.
  • Oued Smar Station
    Situated in the northern part of Oued Smar, near the National School of Mechanics and the Young Women’s University Residence.
  • Houari Boumediene University Station
    Positioned near the northern entrance of Houari Boumediene University.
  • Rabia Tahar Station
    Located north of the City 2045 housing area, near the tram and bus interchange.
  • Smail Yefsah Station
    Southwest of the Cité 5 Juillet area.
  • Business Center Station
    Southwest of the Bab Ezzouar Shopping Center.
  • Airport Station
    Strategically located within the airport’s outdoor parking zone, serving Terminals 1 and 2.

title: Zafarana Hybrid Power Facility, Egypt
body:
• Establish a 3.2 GW fully integrated hybrid power facility in Zafarana, located in the Suez governorate, which will combine 1.1 GW of wind power with 2.1 GW of solar power
  • The facility will be developed on plots 5-8 of the original 545 MW Zafarana wind farms, which were set up 20 years ago and are approaching the end of their operational lives
  • Studies are under way to assess technical and environmental viability, with completion anticipated by December 2025
  •  First commissioning is expected in 2028
  • 1.6 GW (550 MW wind and 1,050 MW solar) of the capacity will be reserved for Voltalia
  • Located 130 km southeast of Cairo, Zafarana is one of the windiest sites in the Mena region; it also enjoys exceptional sun irradiation typical of the Sahara climate

title: RETRADE-SA MPA Phase 1: Zambia - Tanzania Interconnector
body:
Regional Energy Transmission, Trade and Decarbonization Project in Southern Africa (RETRADE-SA) Phase 1: Zambia - Tanzania Interconnector Project includes the following key construction features:

Transmission Line Specifications

  • Tanzania section: 620 km (Iringa to Sumbawanga/Zambian border). Primary line: 400 kV double-circuit (Tanzania section)
  • Zambia section: ~600 km (Kabwe to Tanzanian border), with additional segments like the 200 km Mpika-Kasama 330kV line. Zambia’s upgrades: 330 kV lines (Kabwe-Tanzania border)
  • Double-circuit configuration for enhanced reliability and capacity.

Substations and Infrastructure

  • New substation at Tunduma (Tanzania-Zambia border) to manage cross-border power flow.
  • Grid upgrades: Strengthening Zambia’s grid to integrate renewables and improve resilience.

Source: World Bank Project ID - P507033

title: Southern Africa Trade and Connectivity, Malawi and Mozambique
body:
Scope of Work

  • Construction of new border markets in cities (Blantyre, Zomba, Mzuzu) and districts (Ntcheu/Tsangano, Dedza/Lizulu, Nsanje/Bangula, Machinga/Liwonde, Mchinji) under a Public Private Partnership (PPP) framework.
    • The markets will support a range of businesses, including farm produce vendors, secondhand clothing sellers, hardware shops, and restaurants.
  • Improved waste management systems, sanitation and hygiene facilities, and organized trading spaces to reduce congestion and street vending. 
  • New bus terminals will be constructed in the major cities of Blantyre, Zomba, and Mzuzu, also under a PPP arrangement.
  • Rehabilitation of the Liwonde to Matawale road
  • Construction of a new One Stop Border Post at Muloza
  • A new weigh bridge in Liwonde 

Source: World Bank - Project ID P164847

title: Boundary-Ferrum 400kV Transmission Line, South Africa
body:
The 265 km Boundary-Ferrum line will be located in the Northern Cape province

The contract will be undertaken by an independent transmission provider

The line is part of phase 4 of the strengthening of transmission infrastructure in the province’s capital city Kimberley

The line is to unlock 500MW of capacity and be completed by 30 September 2029

The line is part of the pilot tender (Phase 1) of South Africa’s Independent Transmission Projects (ITP) programme through which the government is looking to collaborate with the private sector for the expansion and strengthening of the country’s transmission network as required by the Transmission Development Plan (TDP) 2024
