title: Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene Program, Kenya
body:
The Kenya Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene Program (K-WASH) is a comprehensive initiative aimed at increasing sustainable access to improved water and sanitation services, eliminating open defecation, and enhancing the financial performance of water service providers, particularly in rural and vulnerable regions, including refugee-hosting counties.

Water Supply Infrastructure

  • Water Storage Tanks: Installation of 5,000-litre capacity water storage tanks in selected schools, designed to provide at least 5 litres of water per pupil per day. 
  • Rural Water Supply Expansion: Construction and expansion of rural water supply infrastructure, including:
    • Boreholes and surface water intake sources
    • Water treatment facilities
    • Transmission mains and storage tanks
    • Distribution networks and last-mile household connections

Sanitation Facilities

  • Construction of two separate, single-sex (gender-friendly) toilets in schools
  •  Sanitation facilities are designed and constructed to be accessible for people with disabilities
  • Implementation of improved and innovative solid waste management systems in schools.
  • Construction of WASH facilities in rural public Early Childhood Development Centres (ECD), primary schools, and healthcare facilities.
  •  Construction of faecal sludge management (FSM) facilities and sewerage treatment plants, especially for rural market centres and small towns.

Source: World Bank - Project ID P179012

title: Phefumula Emoyeni One Wind Power Plant, South Africa
body:
Build a 550 MW wind power plant located approximately 16 km north of Ermelo in the Msukaligwa Local Municipality and Gert Sibande District Municipality, in the Mpumalanga Province of South Africa

The project site will cover about 33,660 hectares

Wind turbines

Number of turbines: Up to 88 turbines (between 6MW and 15MW each)
Turbine hub height:  Up to 200m 
Rotor diameter: Up to 200m
Tip height: Up to 300m 
Permanent hard standing area:  Approximately 75m x 120m
Foundation: Each turbine will have a foundation of approximately up to 40m2 – excavation up to 6m deep, constructed of reinforced concrete to support the mounting ring. Once tower established, footprint of foundation is covered with soil



IPP Portions

Three IPP portions with onsite substations and battery energy storage systems (BESS):
Each IPP onsite substation and BESS will have a total footprint of up to 10ha in extent
Each 33kV/132kV onsite collector substation (IPP portion) will have a footprint of approximately 5ha
The substation will consist of a high-voltage substation yard to allow for multiple 132kV feeder bays and transformers, control building, telecommunication infrastructure, access road, etc.

Each BESS will have a footprint of approximately 5ha
• Export Capacity of up to 200MW
• Total storage capacity 800MWh
• Storage capacity of up to 6-8 hours
• The BESS will be housed in containers
• Battery types to be considered: solid State batteries as the preferred (lithium Ion) and redox flow batteries as the alternative (vanadium redox)

 

Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Building Infrastructure

O&M building infrastructure will be required to support the functioning of the wind farm and for services required by operations and maintenance staff. The O&M building infrastructure will be near the onsite substation and will include 3 O&M offices of approximately 1.5ha each adjacent to each collector substation

Each O&M building will include:
- Operations building;
- Workshop and stores area
- Refuse area for temporary storage of waste
- Conservancy tank to service the ablution facilities

 

Access Roads 

The project site can be accessed easily via the N11 national road, which runs along the eastern boundaries of the site. There are existing roads that go through the land parcels to allow for direct access to the project development area

Internal and access roads with a width of between 8m and 10m, which can be increased to approximately 12m on bends. The roads will be positioned within a 20m wide corridor to accommodate cable trenches, stormwater channels and bypass /circles of up to 20m during
construction. Length of the internal roads will be approximately 60 km

 

Associated Infrastructure

  • 33kV cabling to connect the wind turbines to the onsite collector substations, to be laid underground where practical
  • Cabling between turbines, to be laid underground where practical
  • Laydown and crane hardstand areas (approximately 75m x 120m)

title: Nagaa Hammadi - Luxor Rail Upgrade, Egypt
body:
Also known as Nagaa Hammadi–Luxor Railway Signaling and Communications Modernization Project. 

Project Overview

  • Line Length: 118 km
  • Location: Upper Egypt, connecting Nagaa Hammadi to Luxor
  • Key Infrastructure:
    • 14 main signaling towers
    • 45 level crossings

Scope of Work

  • Signaling System Upgrade: Transition from mechanical to electronic interlocking systems
  • Automatic Train Protection (ATP): Implementation of ATP systems to enhance safety
  • Centralized Traffic Control (CTC): Establishment of a CTC system for efficient train operations
  • Infrastructure Enhancements: Upgrades to control, mechanical, and power facilities​

Project Objectives

  • Increase Train Capacity: From 56 to 200 trains per day
  • Enhance Speed: Raise maximum speed from 120 km/h to 160 km/h
  • Improve Safety: Reduce accidents through modern signaling and communication systems

title: Tanta-Damietta Rail Upgrade, Egypt
body:
Project Summary

This project aims to upgrade the 119 km Tanta–Damietta railway corridor, located in Egypt’s Nile Delta region, to improve reliability, efficiency, and safety. It is supported by the Egyptian National Railways (ENR) and co-financed by the European Investment Bank (EIB).

Line Details

Tanta - El Mansoura

  • Length: 54 km
  • Configuration: Double-track, non-electrified
  • Stations: 16
  • Status: Will benefit from signalling modernization

El Mansoura - Damietta

  • Length: 65 km
  • Configuration: Single-track, non-electrified
  • Stations: 19
  • Status: Will be upgraded to double-track and get signalling upgrades.

Project Components

Component A: Modernisation of Signalling System

  • Affects entire 119 km line (Tanta to Damietta)
  • Includes installation of modern electronic interlocking and centralized traffic control.
    23 interlocking systems and 83 level crossings will be upgraded for safety and automation.

Component B: Track Doubling

  • Applies to the El Mansoura – Damietta segment (currently single-track)
  • Will significantly boost train capacity and reduce delays.

title: Infinity Renewable Energy Initiative, Sierra Leone
body:
Infinity Power Renewable Energy Project in Sierra Leone is a significant initiative aimed at bolstering the country's renewable energy capacity. In July 2024, Infinity Power - a joint venture between Egypt’s Infinity and the UAE’s Masdar - signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Sierra Leone’s Ministry of Energy to develop 1,000 megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity by 2033. ​

Project Scope

The project encompasses a diverse mix of renewable energy technologies:​

  • Solar Photovoltaic (PV): Both ground-mounted and floating solar installations.
  • Hydropower: Expansion and development of hydroelectric facilities.
  • Wind Energy: Potential deployment of wind turbines in suitable locations.
  • Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS): To ensure grid stability and energy reliability.​

The initial phase involves the development of 200 MW of renewable energy generation, focusing on expanding hydroelectric dam capacity and installing both floating and ground-mounted solar PV systems.

title: Angola Rural Solar Energy Project Sun Africa
body:
The project is part of Angola Solar Mini-Grids & Water Infrastructure Project, also known as Angola's Rural Solar Energy and Water Supply Project.

Overview

The project involves the construction of 65 solar photovoltaic mini-grids with integrated battery energy storage systems (BESS) to power water collection, treatment, and purification systems across four underserved provinces in southern Angola.

Provinces Covered:

  • Cunene
  • Namibe
  • Cuando Cubango
  • Huíla

Key Components:

  • Electrification of municipal headquarters and main communes
  • Installation of solar PV mini-grid systems
  • Deployment of battery energy storage systems (BESS)
  • Construction of substations
  • Development of potable water supply systems
  • Extension of distribution lines to rural and peri-urban communities

Financing

Supported by the Export-Import Bank of the United States (EXIM Bank)
Project is part of a broader push for renewable energy and water security in Angola.

title: Hydropower Plants Rehabilitation, Kenya
body:
​Kenya is undertaking a significant rehabilitation initiative targeting nine of its major hydropower plants. This effort is led by the Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen) and aims to enhance the reliability, efficiency, and sustainability of the country's hydroelectric infrastructure.​

Scope of Rehabilitation

The rehabilitation encompasses the following hydropower stations:​

  • Gitaru (Embu) – 225 MW
  • Kamburu (Machakos) – 94.2 MW
  • Kiambere (Embu) – 144/168 MW
  • Kindaruma (Embu) – 44/72 MW
  • Masinga (Machakos) – 44 MW
  • Sangoro (Kisumu) – 21.2 MW​
  • Sondu Miriu (Kisumu) – 60 MW
  • Tana Upper Tana (Murang’a) – 14.4/20 MW
  • Turkwel (West Pokot) – 106 MW

Collectively, these plants contribute over 810 MW to Kenya's national grid, playing a crucial role in providing base load power and ensuring grid stability. ​

Rehabilitation Objectives

The primary goals of the rehabilitation project include:​

  • Modernization of Equipment: Upgrading turbines, generators, and control systems to improve efficiency and extend operational life.
  • Infrastructure Enhancement: Reinforcing dam structures, spillways, and other civil works to ensure safety and resilience against environmental factors.
  • Capacity Optimization: Where feasible, increasing the generation capacity of the plants to meet growing electricity demand.
  • Environmental Compliance: Implementing measures to minimize ecological impact and align with sustainable energy practices.​

Strategic Significance

This rehabilitation initiative aligns with Kenya's Vision 2030, which emphasizes the development of reliable and sustainable energy sources to support economic growth. By revitalizing existing hydropower infrastructure, Kenya aims to reduce reliance on fossil fuels, lower greenhouse gas emissions, and provide affordable electricity to its citizens.​

title: Tunisia Railway Upgrade Lines 6 and 22
body:
Tunisian Railway Lines Upgrade for:

  • Line 6 Tunis – Kasserine ~270 km
  • Line 22 Sousse – Mahdia ~50 km

Scope of Work

The project targets a comprehensive upgrade of two key railway corridors in Tunisia, aimed at modernizing the country’s rail infrastructure and enhancing overall service efficiency and sustainability.

Key Components Include:

  • Track Doubling: To increase capacity and reduce travel time by allowing bidirectional traffic flow.
  • Superstructure Upgrading: Replacement and enhancement of railway tracks and supporting infrastructure for better durability and performance.
  • Electrification: Modernizing energy systems to reduce emissions and operational costs.
  • Station Rehabilitation: Renovating and modernizing existing railway stations for improved passenger services and accessibility.
  • New Signalling and Telecommunications Systems: Installing advanced safety and communication technologies.
  • Rolling Stock Procurement: Acquisition of modern trains to enhance reliability and passenger comfort.

title: Tunisia High Speed Rail
body:
Tunisia High Speed Rail Line is part of the Trans-Maghreb High Speed Rail Network, a regional project aiming at connecting the main cities of the Maghreb countries, namely: Casablanca, Algiers, Tunis and Tripoli. The Tunisian section of the high-speed rail (HSR) network covers a total length of 840 km.

Tunisia HSR project will be implemented in three phases:

Phase 1 (Ras Jedir – Gabès, 180 km): Construction of a new line between Ras Jedir on the Tunisian-Libyan border and Gabès with an electrified double track allowing a top speed of 250 km/h for passenger trains and 120 km/h for freight trains. This first phase will use, to the extent possible, the same track as for the upcoming Gabès – Médenine railway line. The project, estimated at TND 2.6 billion, is to be procured as a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) project.

Phase 2 (Gabès – Tunis – Bizerte, 480 km): Construction of a new high-speed line that connects Bizerte to Gabès via Tunis, Nabeul, Sousse and Sfax. This will be done either through the upgrade of the existing metre-gauge rail line or through a new separate standard gauge rail line. The estimated cost is TND 14 billion.

Phase 3 (Tunis – Tabarka, 180 km): Restructuring of the existing standard gauge rail line between Tunis and the Algerian borders or construction of new section if required. The estimated cost is TND 9.4 billion.

Source: TREM Africa

title: Sousse Metro, Tunisia
body:
Metro Grand Sousse Line B project covers the construction of 12.7 km rail line to connect Sousse city center with Kalaa Kébira via Kalaa Sghira (Sousse city-Kalaa Sghira-Kalaa Kébira). The Sousse city-Kalaa Sghira section will have a single track while the Kalaa Sghira-Kalaa Kébira section will have a double track. The route will have 11 stations. The line will be extended to Enfidha in the future.

Metro Grand Sousse Line C runs from Sousse center to Msaken via Kalaa Sghira. The Sousse city-Kalaa Sghira section will have a single track while the Kalaa Sghira-Msaken section will have a double track. The route is 17.8 km long and will have 11 stations.

Metro Grand Sousse Line D runs from Sousse center to Msaken via Sousse south (Sousse Center-Sousse South-Msaken). The Sousse city-Bab Jedid and Sousse south-Msaken sections will have a single track while the Bab Jedid-Sousse south section will have a double track. The route is 13.6 km long and will have 6 stations.

Source: TREM Africa

title: Khartoum Tram, Sudan
body:
Khartoum Tramway, also called TRAM Khartoum Network, is a proposed standard-gauge tramway system that will link the major parts of Khartoum (Khartoum city centre, Omdurman and Bahri) to solve traffic problems and improve mobility in the capital city of Sudan.

Construction

A feasibility study carried out by ETC Transport Consultants GmbH and Schüßler-Plan between 2007 and 2009 proposed a three-stage implementation process:

  • Inauguration: Khartoum – Blue Nile Bridge – Bahri (Line 1) and Omdurman – Salvation Bridge – Khartoum Airport (Line 2) with a total line length of 25 km.
  • Extension: Extending Line 1 and 2 and adding two more lines giving a total line length of 92 km.
  • Completion: 185 km line length after adding four more lines.

Source: TREM Africa

title: Gautrain Rapid Rail Extension, South Africa
body:
The project involves the extension of the Gauteng Rapid Rail Integrated Network (GRRIN) to connect the people of Gauteng and create a sustainable transport service for the Province.

The proposed GRINN extension will span over various areas and will be developed in several phases under a Public Private Partnership (PPP) model.

The feasibility study for the GRRIN extension identified a total of 149 km of rail and 17 stations for the final route:

  • A link between Marlboro and Soweto with new stations at Sandton, Randburg, Cosmo City, Little Falls, Roodepoort and Jabulani — Phase 1 of the extension;
  • A link between Jabulani and Mamelodi through Cosmo City, with new stations at Fourways, Sunninghill, Olievenhoutsbosch, Irene, Tshwane East, Hazeldean, and Mamelodi;
  • A link between Rhodesfield and Boksburg with new stations at East Rand Mall and Boksburg; and
  • A link between Cosmo City and Lanseria Airport with new stations at Cradle and Lanseria.

Source: TREM Africa

title: Accra SkyTrain, Ghana
body:
Accra SkyTrain is a proposed elevated mass rapid transit system in Accra, Ghana. The system uses air propulsion technology to drive lightweight, high passenger volume rail vehicles.

The project involves the construction of five routes, four of which radiate out from the proposed Kwame Nkrumah Circle, and one route that provides an intra-city commuter loop distribution service. The project will be implemented in three phases and will have a total track length of 194 km.

The SkyTrain project will be financed by the Ghana Infrastructure Investment Fund (GIIF), an independent fund set up by the government, and the Africa Investment SkyTrain Consortium. It will also have the support of the African Development Bank.

Source: TREM Africa

title: Kenya GREEN Programme Phase 2
body:
BESS

Construct a utility-scale battery energy storage system (BESS) of up to 200 MWh for load-shifting renewable energy sources (primarily geothermal) but also for grid stability by providing system reserves (both fast and backup reserves)

The charging will occur during the off-peak period (between 10pm and 5am), while the provision of backup reserves peaks during the morning and evening hours (at 4am and 6pm)

The technical assessment recently completed with World Bank support confirmed the immediate need for 400MW of 1-hour BESS capacity. The BESS study has prioritised four sites that are owned by KenGen, KETRACO, and KPLC for BESS installation [Embakasi (Nairobi), Kipevu (Coast), Muhoroni (Western) and Olkaria geothermal complex (KenGen)]

 

STATCOMS

Install system stabilisation equipment (STATCOMs) to improve the fault levels, increase voltage stability and allow for greater import of cheaper and renewable energy through the Ethiopia-Kenya transmission interconnector

One of the STATCOMs will be installed at the existing Suswa substation, located about 80 km northwest of Nairobi where the interconnector terminates, while the second will be installed at the Rabai substation in the Coast region

The STATCOMS will comprise mechanically switched shunt busbar reactors, capacitor banks and static synchronous compensators and associated substation primary equipment, secondary systems, associated civil works as recommended by technical studies carried out in 2022

Installation of the STATCOMs at Suswa and Rabai will enable safe operation of the Ethiopia-Kenya interconnector and will enable Kenya increase offtake to 400 MW by November 2025 from the current 200 MW as stipulated

The STATCOM at Rabai will also provide reactive power compensation, reducing reliance on thermal power plants for energy and voltage support in the Coast region 

 

Substation

Construct a 400 kV substation at Kimuka that will enable the export of power from Ethiopia to Tanzania through Kenya by allowing the Suswa-Isinya line to be operated at full design capacity

The scope of work includes the construction of a new 2x200MVA 400/220kV substation, a 1.5 km transmission line in and out of the substation and an intertie about 400 metres long to the existing 400 kV line and 220/66 kV substation

title: Geregu Nuclear Power Plant, Nigeria
body:
​Geregu Nuclear Power Plant is a significant initiative in Nigeria's pursuit of diversifying its energy portfolio. Planned for construction in Geregu, Kogi State, this project is a collaboration between the Nigerian government and Russia's state-owned nuclear corporation, Rosatom.​

Project Overview

Location: Geregu, Kogi State, Nigeria. 

Reactor Type: Two VVER-1200 pressurized water reactors supplied by Atomstroyexport, a subsidiary of Rosatom.

Total Capacity: 2,400 megawatts (MW). 

Estimated Cost: Approximately $20 billion. 

Development Model: Build-Own-Operate (BOO) partnership, with eventual transfer of ownership and operations to Nigeria's nuclear regulatory body.

Scope of Work

The comprehensive scope of the Geregu Nuclear Power Plant project includes:

  • Construction of the main power generation facility (powerhouse)
  • Development of substations and access roads
  • Installation of key components such as generators, turbines, and transformers
  • Laying of transmission lines to integrate the plant into the national grid ​

title: Nuclear Power Plant, Ghana
body:
​Ghana is actively advancing its nuclear energy ambitions, with plans to construct a two-unit nuclear power plant featuring a total generation capacity between 2,000 MW and 2,400 MW. This initiative is part of the country's broader strategy to diversify its energy sources and meet growing electricity demands.​

Project Overview

Capacity: The planned nuclear power plant will consist of two units, each contributing to a combined capacity ranging from 2,000 MW to 2,400 MW.​

Timeline: Ghana aims to commission its first nuclear power plant by 2034, aligning with its long-term energy planning objectives.​

Site Selection: A suitable site capable of accommodating up to five reactors has been identified, providing flexibility for future expansion. ​

title: Nuclear Power Plant, Ethiopia
body:
​Ethiopia is actively pursuing the development of nuclear energy as a strategic component of its long-term energy diversification and sustainable development goals. While the country does not yet have an operational nuclear power plant, significant progress has been made in laying the groundwork for future nuclear energy deployment.​

Current Status and Strategic Roadmap

International Collaboration: In February 2025, Ethiopia and Russia's Rosatom signed a three-year cooperation roadmap to strengthen collaboration in nuclear technology. This agreement builds upon a 2023 memorandum and includes plans to establish a Nuclear Science and Technology Center (NSTC) in Ethiopia. The NSTC aims to support applications in energy, healthcare, and agriculture, and to develop Ethiopia's nuclear infrastructure in line with International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) standards. 

Feasibility Studies and Capacity Building: Rosatom is conducting feasibility studies for the NSTC, and efforts are underway to train Ethiopian personnel in nuclear science and technology. The Ethiopian government has emphasized the importance of developing qualified specialists as a prerequisite for advancing to the construction phase of nuclear facilities. ​

IAEA Milestone Approach: Ethiopia is currently in Phase I of the IAEA's Milestone Approach for nuclear power development. This phase involves preparatory activities such as conducting pre-feasibility studies, establishing legal and regulatory frameworks, and developing human resources. The country aims to progress to Phase II, which includes site selection and technology assessment, in the near future. ​

Future Plans

Nuclear Power Plant Development: Ethiopia has set a target to commission its first nuclear power plant between 2035 and 2040. The country is considering both large-scale reactors and Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) to meet its energy needs. Specific details regarding capacity, site selection, and reactor technology are expected to emerge as feasibility studies and infrastructure development progress. ​

Institutional Framework: The Ethiopian government is establishing key institutions to support its nuclear energy ambitions, including the Ethiopian Atomic Energy Commission and the Ethiopian Nuclear and Radiation Protection Authority. These bodies will oversee the regulatory and safety aspects of nuclear energy development. ​

Challenges and Considerations

Ethiopia faces several challenges in its nuclear energy journey, including securing financing, developing a skilled workforce, establishing robust legal and regulatory frameworks, and ensuring public acceptance. Addressing these challenges will be critical to the successful implementation of its nuclear energy program.​
meta_description: ​Ethiopia is actively pursuing the development of nuclear energy as a strategic component of its long-term energy diversification and sustainable development goals. While the country does not yet have an operational nuclear power plant
migration_status: significant progress has been made in laying the groundwork for future nuclear energy deployment.​Current Status and Strategic Roadmap

title: El Negila Nuclear Power Plant, Egypt
body:
​Egypt has been exploring the development of a second nuclear power plant at the El Negila site in the Matrouh Governorate. This initiative is part of the country's broader strategy to diversify its energy sources and meet growing electricity demands.​

El Negila Nuclear Power Plant Overview

  • Location: El Negila is situated south of the coastal town of Marsa Matrouh, approximately 80 kilometers east of Port Said. ​
  • Project Status: The site has been under consideration for nuclear development for several years. In 2010, Egypt's Electricity and Energy Minister announced the selection of El Negila for the country's second nuclear power station. Subsequent studies, including those conducted by WorleyParsons in 2016, have assessed the site's suitability for hosting a nuclear facility. ​
  • Capacity and Cost: The proposed El Negila Nuclear Power Plant is expected to have a capacity of 2,800 megawatts (MW) and an estimated construction cost of $14 billion. The project envisions a 10-year construction timeline, with contract finalization anticipated around November 2026. ​
  • Strategic Importance: The development of the El Negila plant aligns with Egypt's energy diversification goals, aiming to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and incorporate more sustainable energy sources into the national grid. The site's coastal location offers advantages for reactor cooling and potential integration with desalination processes to address water scarcity. ​

While the El Negila project is still in the planning and assessment phase, it represents a significant step in Egypt's commitment to expanding its nuclear energy capabilities. Further developments will depend on detailed feasibility studies, regulatory approvals, and international partnerships.​
meta_description: ​Egypt has been exploring the development of a second nuclear power plant at the El Negila site in the Matrouh Governorate. This initiative is part of the country's broader strategy to diversify its energy sources and meet growing electricity demands.​El Negila Nuclear Power Plant Overview

title: El Dabaa Nuclear Power Plant, Egypt
body:
​El Dabaa Nuclear Power Plant, currently under construction in Egypt's Matrouh Governorate, is a landmark project marking the country's entry into nuclear energy generation. Developed by Russia's Rosatom, the plant is situated approximately 300 kilometers northwest of Cairo and will be Egypt's first nuclear power facility.​

Project Overview

Total Capacity: 4,800 megawatts (MW), comprising four VVER-1200 pressurized water reactors, each with a net capacity of 1,100 MW.​

Reactor Design: The VVER-1200 is a Generation III+ reactor, featuring advanced safety systems, including double containment structures and passive safety mechanisms. It is designed to withstand extreme external events, such as earthquakes up to magnitude 9 and the impact of a 400-ton aircraft. ​

Construction Timeline

  • Unit 1: Construction commenced in July 2022, with commissioning planned for 2026.
  • Unit 2: Construction began in November 2022.
  • Unit 3: Construction started in May 2023.
  • Unit 4: Construction initiated in January 2024. ​

Operational Timeline

The plant is expected to reach full operational capacity by 2030. ​

Project Cost and Financing

The estimated cost of the project is $30 billion, with Russia providing up to $25 billion in loans to finance the construction. ​
Enerdata

Fuel Supply and Waste Management

Rosatom will supply nuclear fuel for the plant's 60-year operational lifespan and assist in managing spent fuel through the construction of a dedicated storage facility. ​

title: Lamwo Nuclear Power Plant, Uganda
body:
Uganda's nuclear power projects are a central component of its strategy to achieve a total electricity generation capacity of 52,481 MW by 2040, with nuclear energy contributing 24,000 MW. These initiatives are designed to meet the country's future energy demands and support its broader development goals.​

Uganda’s Vision 2040 and Energy Policy 2023 Targets

  • Total Planned Electricity Generation Capacity by 2040: 52,481 megawatts (MW)
  • Planned Contribution from Nuclear Power: 24,000 MW​

This ambitious plan aims to support Uganda's industrialization, infrastructure development, and socio-economic growth. The government recognizes that existing energy sources—such as hydro, solar, biomass, and geothermal—may not suffice to meet future demand, hence the integration of nuclear energy into the national energy mix.

Nuclear Power Development Plans

  • Buyende Nuclear Power Plant:
    • Location: Buyende District, approximately 150 km north of Kampala
    • Identified as a pilot project with a planned capacity of 8,400 MW
    • Initial Capacity: 2,000 megawatts (MW), with the first 1,000 MW expected to be operational by 2031
  • Other Proposed Sites:
    • Nakasongola (7,200 MW)
    • Kiruhura (4,800 MW)
    • Lamwo (4,000 MW)​

Uranium Resource Development

To support its nuclear energy ambitions, Uganda is actively exploring and evaluating its uranium resources. The government estimates that approximately 4,000 tons of uranium will be required annually once the nuclear power plants are fully operational. Efforts are underway to amend the Atomic Energy Act of 2008 to strengthen the legal framework governing the exploration, mining, and processing of nuclear fuel resources. ​

title: Djelfa Power Plant, Algeria
body:
Project Type: Combined Cycle Thermal Power Generation Facility

Capacity: 1,260 Megawatts (MW)

Scope of Work: Construction of a Combined Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) power plant.

Installation of:

  • Four gas turbines
  • Two steam turbines
  • Four heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs)
  • Integration of gas and steam cycles to improve thermal efficiency and reduce emissions.
  • Associated infrastructure for grid connection and auxiliary systems.

title: Angololo Multipurpose Water Resources Development Project, Uganda
body:
Scope of Work

Dam Construction:

  • A 30-meter-high dam will be constructed on the Malaba River.
  • The dam will create a reservoir with a storage capacity of 43 million cubic meters of water.

Hydropower Generation:

  • The facility will include a mini-hydropower plant with an installed capacity of 1.75 megawatts (MW).

Multipurpose Functionality:

  • The project will provide water for irrigation, domestic use, and livestock, benefiting communities in both Uganda and Kenya.
  • It will also help in flood control and improve climate resilience in the region.

title: Cairo International Airport Terminal 4, Egypt
body:
​The development of Terminal 4 at Cairo International Airport is a pivotal component of Egypt's strategy to enhance its aviation infrastructure and bolster tourism. Beyond its initial capacity to handle 30 million passengers annually, with potential expansion to 40 million, several key aspects of the project have been outlined:​

Project Scope and Timeline

Construction Duration: The terminal's development is projected to span approximately four to five years. ​
Arab News

New Runway: Plans include the addition of a state-of-the-art runway equipped with advanced navigation and ground lighting systems, adhering to international standards. ​

Sustainable Infrastructure: Large-capacity parking facilities will be constructed and entirely covered with solar panels, aligning with Egypt's sustainability goals. ​

title: Nador Desalination Plant, Morocco
body:
​Nador Desalination Plant is a significant infrastructure project in Morocco, aimed at addressing water scarcity in the Oriental region. 

Project Overview

  • Location: Nador, Oriental Region, Morocco
  • Annual Capacity: 250 million cubic meters
  • Drinking Water: 140 million cubic meters
  • Irrigation: 110 million m³, serving approximately 30,000 hectares
  • Energy Source: Powered by renewable energy to minimize environmental impact

title: Kitchener Drain, Egypt
body:
Also known as Kitchener Drain Rehabilitation and Integrated Waste Management project, and Kitchener Drainage Depollution Project (KDDP). 

Location: Nile Delta, Egypt (Kafr El Sheikh, Gharbeia, and Dakhalya Governorates)

Length of Drain: 69+ km

Irrigation Area: ~193,000 hectares (460,000 feddans)

Main Issue: Severe pollution from domestic, industrial, agricultural, and solid waste sources

Scope of Work

Drain Rehabilitation Works

  • New Pumping Stations:
    • Sega'aia (km 69)
    • Samatay (km 57.5)
    • Hamoul (km 2.5)
  • Rehabilitation of Existing Stations:
    • Pumping Stations No. 3 and 4
  • Drain and Bank Improvements:
    • Embankment protection and side support works for Kitchener Drain and Drain 4
    • Road paving on both banks from km 10 to km 69
    • Removal of land encroachments
  • Bridge Rehabilitation:
    • Overhaul of existing bridges crossing Kitchener Drain
  • Drain Cleaning & Dredging:
    • Deepening Kitchener and subsidiary drains to restore hydraulic efficiency
  • Drain Diversion & Irrigation Efficiency:
    • Divert Omar Bek Drain to Zifta Bahary Drain
    • Introduce modern irrigation techniques (e.g., drip irrigation) to reduce runoff and Nile discharge

Solid Waste Management Upgrade

Existing Infrastructure:

  • Waste Treatment Facilities (WTF): 
    • Separate and process recyclable, combustible, and organic fractions
    • Waste Transfer Stations (WTS) & Dump Sites (DS): Intermediate waste handling sites
    • Landfills: No engineered landfills in the three governorates; Al Sadat landfill (in Beheira) serves Gharbeia

Planned Investments (via EBRD):

  • Procurement of Collection Equipment:
    • Waste bins, containers, and tractors for primary collection
  • Engineered Landfills (Up to 5):
    • Including potential upgrade of Al Sadat Landfill and Motobas dumpsite into engineered facilities
  • Waste Treatment Facilities (Up to 6):
    • Upgrades and new construction for enhanced sorting and processing
  • Transfer Stations (Up to 10):
    • New construction and modernization of existing sites
  • Dump Site Closures:
    • Decommissioning and environmental rehabilitation of existing informal dumps

title: Foxwood Dam, South Africa
body:
Foxwood Dam site is located immediately upstream of Adelaide (coordinates 32˚40’30”S, 26˚16’0”E) in the Koonap River catchment. The Koonap River catchment, with an area of 3 334 km², is situated in the Eastern Cape Province and lies within the Fish to Tsitsikamma Water Management Area (WMA). 

Foxwood Dam has a catchment of 1 091 km². The proposed Foxwood Dam is a composite gravity concrete – earthfill embankment dam designed for a final height corresponding to 1 MAR storage with a 50 year sedimentation allowance.

Source: South Africa Department of Water and Sanitation

title: Transport Resilience, Burundi
body:
The Burundi Transport Resilience Project is a major infrastructure initiative designed to improve efficient, safe, and climate-resilient road connectivity along the main corridor linking Burundi with Tanzania, while also strengthening institutional capacity for sustainable road asset management. The project includes the following:

  • Rehabilitation and upgrading of road sections, particularly the Bujumbura-Gitaza Road and sections of Ndadaye and Mwambutsa boulevards, with a focus on meeting technical, environmental, safety, and social specifications.
  • Rehabilitate or upgrade 25 km of the Bujumbura-Gitaza road section to climate-resilient standards by December 2026.
  • Construction and upgrading of pilot road sections (target: 4 km by December 2027) to include dedicated facilities for non-motorized transport, such as pedestrian walkways and bicycle lanes.
  • Implementation of major road safety activities, including a safety audit for the Bujumbura-Gitaza Road, and piloting a crash recording and analysis tool for improved safety monitoring.
  • Construction of social infrastructure within the project area, with a target of five social infrastructure projects by December 2027.
  • Technical assistance and preparatory work for a multinational railway project (standard gauge railway) linking Tanzania and Burundi, although physical construction of the railway is not part of the current scope.

Source: World Bank Project ID - P172988

title: Manono Mining Extension, DRC
body:
The Manono Extension Project comprises two granted exploration permits (PRs 4029 and 4030) covering 242.25 square km surrounding the Manono Project licence in southern DRC.

Within the project, there are two primary targets delineated from the photo-geological interpretation (completed in 2014) that potentially represent the strike extensions of the Manono pegmatite to the SW and to the NE:

  • SW Extension Target: A mapped pegmatite body of about 800m strike length and 200m wide, the SW target is a very highly weathered Calcic feldspar (albite)-quartz-muscovite pegmatite with parallels in mineralisation characteristics to the main Kitotolo pegmatites which may represent the southern extension to the main Kitotolo orebody
  • NE Extension Target: A well-developed lateritic cover under soil, with laterite believed to be 2-3m thick covering the strike extension of the Manono pegmatities and measuring 2 km by 1.5 km

 

Geology

The Project lays within the mid-Proterozoic Kibaran Belt - an intracratonic domain, stretching for over 1,000 km through Katanga and into southwest Uganda. The belt strikes predominantly SWNE and is truncated by the NS to NNW-SSE trending Western Rift system

The geology of the Manono area is not well documented. The Manono pegmatites are hosted by a series of quartzitic mica schists of the Lower Kibaran and are associated with volcanic and intrusive rocks of mainly doleritic composition. The schists observed in the vicinity of the Manono mine are generally steeply dipping in contrast to the sub-horizontal attitude of the pegmatite intrusions

title: Water Security and Sanitation Support, Cote d’Ivoire
body:
The Côte d’Ivoire Water Security and Sanitation Support Program aims to improve water and sanitation infrastructure across the country, particularly in rural and underserved areas. 

The program targets both the expansion of access and the resilience of water and sanitation systems. It has the following features:

  • Construction of 50,000 sustainable household latrines in rural communities to improve sanitation coverage and reduce open defecation.
  • Upgrading and construction of improved toilets in 200 schools and 100 health centers, ensuring access to safe sanitation in public institutions.
  • Water and sanitation assets are designed and constructed with climate-resilient features to withstand the impacts of climate change, such as increased flooding or drought.
  • Expansion and rehabilitation of water supply infrastructure, including boreholes, pumps, and distribution networks, to ensure reliable access to safe drinking water in targeted regions.
  • Incorporation of nature-based solutions for climate adaptation and mitigation, such as improved drainage systems and sustainable management of water resources.
  • Renewal and maintenance of existing water and sanitation assets, with contracts ensuring long-term operability and sustainability.
  • Construction of monitoring and evaluation facilities and the establishment of local management bodies to oversee the operation and maintenance of new infrastructure.
  • Construction of training centers and the provision of equipment for local authorities and community members to manage and maintain the new infrastructure.

Source: World Bank; Project ID - P177118

title: Second Urban Water Supply and Sanitation, Ethiopia
body:
The Second Ethiopia Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Project (UWSSP II) is a large-scale initiative aimed at expanding access to improved water supply and sanitation services in Addis Ababa and 22 other secondary cities. The project is structured into multiple components focusing on both infrastructure development and institutional strengthening.

Urban Water Supply Infrastructure

  • Boreholes and Wells: Construction and rehabilitation of deep boreholes and shallow wells for groundwater extraction, including drilling supervision and groundwater assessment.
  • Transmission and Distribution Networks: Installation of extensive pipe networks for water collection, transmission, and distribution. Examples include:
  • Borehole collector pipework (e.g., 22.7 km in Adama)
  • Transmission mains (e.g., 14.2 km in Adama)
  • Distribution networks (e.g., 181.3 km in Adama; 70+ km in Godey).
  • Reservoirs and Storage Tanks: Construction of reinforced concrete reservoirs and elevated storage tanks to ensure adequate water storage and pressure management. Capacities range from 250 m³ to 5,000 m³ per tank.
  • Pumping Stations: Establishment of booster pump stations, low lift pumping stations, and installation of both submersible and surface centrifugal pumps for water conveyance.
  • Water Treatment Facilities: Development of water treatment plants, including rapid sand filtration systems and chlorine dosing for safe water supply (e.g., Godey Town).

Urban Sanitation Infrastructure

  • Wastewater Treatment Plants (WWTPs): Design and construction of new WWTPs with associated sewerage networks, particularly in Addis Ababa’s Eastern catchment, using a Design-Build-Operate (DBO) approach.
  • Sewerage Networks: Expansion and rehabilitation of conventional sewer systems where feasible, especially in larger urban centers.
  • Fecal Sludge Management Facilities: Construction and improvement of fecal sludge treatment plants, with procurement of desludging equipment to enhance operational efficiency.
  • Communal and Public Latrines: Building of communal and public toilets, particularly targeting unserved and low-income urban areas (e.g., 18 public latrines in Lalibela).

Auxiliary and Support Structures

  • Electromechanical Systems: Integration of SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) systems for real-time monitoring and control of water supply facilities.
  • Auxiliary Buildings: Construction of generator houses, guard houses, chemical storage, workshops, and pipe shades to support operational needs.
  • Access Roads: Development of access roads (e.g., 12 km in Adama) to facilitate construction, operation, and maintenance of water and sanitation infrastructure.

Institutional and Operational Enhancements

  • Modernization of Utilities: Upgrading customer care, billing, financial management, and network management systems for water and sanitation utilities.
  • Capacity Building: Training of utility staff, procurement of office equipment, and exposure visits for knowledge exchange and improved project management.

Source: World Bank - Project ID - P156433
meta_description: The Second Ethiopia Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Project (UWSSP II) is a large-scale initiative aimed at expanding access to improved water supply and sanitation services in Addis Ababa and 22 other secondary cities. The project is structured into multiple components focusing on both infrastructure development and institutional strengthening.Urban Water Supply Infrastructure

title: Expansion of Port of Luanda, Angola
body:
• Undertake dredging works that will increase the depth of the Multipurpose Terminal, also known as the Noatum Ports Luanda Terminal, from 10 metres to 16 metres, enabling it to receive Super Post Panamax vessels of up to 14,000 TEUs; work is expected to be completed by March 2026
  • Carry out the total reconstruction of the terminal, including the construction of a new advanced quay and the installation of STS and RTG cranes
  • The modernisation project involves extensive upgrades, transforming the terminal into a modern general cargo, container, and roll-on/roll-off (Ro-Ro) facility
  • The terminal’s 192,000-square-metre area will be optimised for high-density container handling and equipped with cutting-edge technology and IT systems. The extensive modernisation works are expected to be completed in Q1 2027
  • Upon completion, new container handling equipment will be installed, significantly increasing container capacity from 25,000 TEUs to 350,000 TEUs and Ro-Ro volumes to over 40,000 vehicles

 

 

In addition, the Port of Luanda will carry out dredging at the Cabotage Terminal and the Passenger Terminal, increasing the depth from 1 metre to 5.5 metres, to ensure safe navigation and eliminate grounding problems

title: Ubeta Upstream Gas Project, Nigeria
body:
Located in OML58, Ubeta gas condensate field will be developed with a new 6-well cluster connected to the existing Obite facilities through an 11km buried pipeline. Production start-up is expected in 2027, with a plateau of 300 million cubic feet per day (about 70,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day including condensates). 

Gas from Ubeta will be supplied to NLNG, a liquefaction plant located in Bonny Island with an on-going capacity expansion from 22 to 30 Mtpa, in which NNPC Limited holds a 49% interest. 

Source: NNPC

title: Sinai Railway Project (Arish–Taba Logistic Corridor), Egypt
body:
The Sinai Railway Project, also known as the Arish–Taba Logistic Corridor, is a major infrastructure initiative to construct and rehabilitate approximately 500 kilometers of railway across the Sinai Peninsula. The line connects Al-Fardan (on mainland Egypt) to Taba (on the Gulf of Aqaba), passing through key locations including Bir al-Abd and Arish. It aims to boost regional logistics, economic development, and connectivity within Sinai.

Scope of Work:

  • Rehabilitation of the Al-Fardan to Bir al-Abd line (100 km) – completed
  • Construction of new lines from Bir al-Abd to Arish (80 km)
  • New railway from Arish to Taba (190–220 km inland)
  • Modern signaling, telecommunications, and utility infrastructure
  • Construction and renovation of multiple railway stations (including new station in Arish)
  • Renovation of the Al-Fardan Railway Bridge over the Suez Canal
  • Establishment of logistics parks and cargo handling facilities

title: Cairo Metro Line 6, Egypt
body:
This line starts from El Khosous area at exit 18 of the Ring Road and then continues until the East of Shubra Al Khiemah then goes along beside Ismailia Canal, and will continue until El Sawah Square, then Port Said St. to cross above Line 1 at Ghamrah Station Until El-Sayeda Zeinab Square then continues to El Fustat Park to intersect with Line 4 and continues to the New Maadi area next to the Satellite area end of this line, with a length of about 30 km, 10 km of them on viaduct and about 20 km underground. The sixth line will include 24 Stations, 4 elevated and 20 underground stations. 

Source: Egypt National Authority for Tunnels (NAT)

Project breakdown

  • Total length: ~30 km
    • 10 km elevated (viaduct)
    • 20 km underground
  • Route:
    • Starts from El Khosous (Exit 18, Ring Road)
    • Passes East Shubra Al Khiemah, alongside Ismailia Canal
    • Through El Sawah Sq., Port Said St.
    • Crosses Line 1 at Ghamrah Station
    • Reaches El-Sayeda Zeinab Sq., then El Fustat Park (intersects Line 4)
    • Ends at New Maadi (Satellite Area)
  • Stations: 24 total
    • 4 elevated
    • 20 underground

title: Nkwashi, Zambia
body:
Nkwashi is a satellite town in Zambia designed to function as a fully self-contained and modern city. It will have its own central business district, several residential districts, an education district, several green spaces, fully paved roads, centralised electricity, water and sewerage networks—along with access to high speed internet connectivity. 

Nkwashi’s residential areas will be divided into 12 distinct district areas. Each district will also consist of a maximum of three suburbs with approximately 300 properties each.

The Town will provide the following services to its citizens:

  • Road maintenance
  • Garbage Collection
  • Maintenance and upkeep of public parks, green spaces and recreational areas
  • Maintenance and cleaning of communal areas and grounds
  • Communal Security
  • Communal Fire Safety
  • Education and Health
  • Public Transport
  • Residents of the town will also be able to opt-into the following optional services:

Source: Nkwashi

  • rooftop fitness centers, private swimming pools for selected family units, a swimming pool for socializing, and high-level security services

body: Objective: To reduce the benzene content in gasoline, enhancing fuel quality and aligning with environmental standards.​

title: SIR Refinery Diesel Desulphurization Unit, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
Objective: To produce ultra-low sulfur diesel (10 ppm) in compliance with the latest ECOWAS fuel quality standards.​

Technology: SIR has contracted Honeywell UOP to provide its Distillate Unionfining process, which reduces sulfur content while maximizing distillate yields.​

timeline: Construction is scheduled to commence in May 2025, with commissioning expected by late 2025 or early 2026.​

title: SIR Refienry Expansion, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
Ivory Coast to construct a new 170,000 barrels per day (bpd) refinery to complement the existing Société Ivoirienne de Raffinage (SIR) facility in Abidjan. This initiative aims to position the country as a leading refining hub in West Africa.

Project Overview

New Refinery Capacity: The planned refinery will have a capacity of 170,000 bpd, significantly increasing the nation's refining capabilities.​

Existing Facility Upgrade: The current SIR refinery, with a capacity of 75,000 bpd, is slated for an upgrade to 100,000 bpd.​

Modular Power Unit: The project includes the installation of a modular unit designed to produce electricity from gas. This addition aims to lower operating costs and reduce reliance on the main power grid.​

title: Sky Circle, South Africa
body:
The Sky Circle project, officially launched in July 2022, involves the construction of South Africa’s first freestanding elevated traffic circle at the intersection of Govan Mbeki Road (M9) and Jan Smuts Drive (M17) in Hanover Park, Cape Town.
This iconic project is a flagship component of the MyCiTi Phase 2A public transport expansion, aiming to improve transport links between Mitchells Plain, Khayelitsha, Wynberg, and Claremont.

The Sky Circle is designed to separate MyCiTi bus traffic from general road traffic, reducing congestion and improving travel times for public transport users.

Technical Scope:

  • Construction of an elevated, freestanding traffic circle approximately 6.2 meters above ground.
  • Exclusive busway for MyCiTi buses only, ensuring uninterrupted flow.
  • Hollow circular design to allow natural light to pass through to the ground-level intersection.
  • Upgrades to the ground-level intersection, including, reconfiguration of lanes, creation of dedicated turning lanes, and installation of advanced traffic signals and signal optimization (improved sequencing).
  • New pedestrian and cycling infrastructure.
  • Street lighting upgrades to enhance nighttime visibility and safety.
  • Relocation and upgrading of utilities within the road reserve.
  • Temporary traffic management measures during construction.
  • Planned integration with a future MyCiTi closed median station in Hanover Park (to be built at a later stage).

title: EDF-ZeroWaste Green Hydrogen, Egypt
body:
The project is also known as the Green Fuel Alliance. 

Location: Ras Shukeir Port, Egypt. 

Project Overview

  • Build an integrated plant for the production of green hydrogen and its derivatives, including green ammonia, in three phases in the Ras Shukheir area
  • Once fully operational, the plant will have a total annual production of 1 million tonnes of green ammonia
  • The first phase, set to begin in 2029, will be led by a partnership between France's EDF Renewables and Egyptian-UAE company Zero Waste. This phase alone will see a direct investment of €2 billion to produce 300,000 tonnes of green ammonia a year
  • Over the course of the project, a total of 368 square km will be dedicated to solar and wind energy generation, with 1.2 million square metres allocated for the construction of the production facility
  • Supporting infrastructure will include a 7 km electricity transmission corridor, a seawater desalination unit to supply water for all production phases, and a 400-metre-long, 17-metre-deep loading berth at the Red Sea port, which the company will finance and build

Sources: State Information Services and Egypt Today

Project Scope

  • Capacity: 1 million tons of green ammonia per year
  • Plant Area: 1.2 million m²
  • Renewable Energy Facility: 420 km² of land for solar and wind power
  • Infrastructure Includes:
    • Seawater desalination unit
    • 7 km power transmission line
    • 400 m shipping dock
meta_description: The project is also known as the Green Fuel Alliance. Location: Ras Shukeir Port
migration_status: Egypt. Project Overview

title: Potassium Chloride Complex, Egypt
body:
Project Overview

The project involves the construction of an integrated potassium chloride production complex powered by renewable energy, with the goal of producing green potassium chloride for use in fertilizers and other applications.

Key Components

Production Capacity:

  • Pilot Phase: Production of 100,000 tons of potassium chloride.
  • Full Project Goal: Production of 4.1 million tons of potassium chloride annually.

Energy Supply

Powered by renewable energy sources to ensure a sustainable and low-carbon footprint.

  • Pilot Phase: Supported by 150 MW renewable energy capacity.
  • Full Project: Operated with 6.1 GW of renewable energy, one of the largest allocations for a green industrial project in the region.

title: Tamale Yendi Tatale Road, Ghana
body:
The project involves the construction and upgrading of a 168.98 km road connecting the northern corridor from Tamale to the Tatale border post near Togo. It is a key regional transport link that enhances trade, mobility, and access across several districts.

Route Overview

The road traverses:

  • Tamale (Northern Region capital)
  • Mion District
  • Yendi Municipal
  • Zabzugu District
  • Tatale/Sanguli District
  • Tatale Border Post (Ghana–Togo border)

Project Phases

Lot 1: Tatale – Yendi Section

  • Length: 61.98 km
  • Scope: Construction of a paved road, including drainage, bridges, and safety infrastructure.
  • Key Locations: Tatale/Sanguli District, Zabzugu, and Yendi.

Lot 2: Yendi – Tamale Section

  • Length: 106 km
  • Scope: Roadworks including widening, pavement, culverts, and auxiliary infrastructure.
  • Key Locations: Yendi, Mion District, Tamale.

title: NR3 Rehabilitation: Dibamba Wouri Section, Cameroon
body:
The National Road 3 Rehabilitation Project – Dibamba to Wouri Section project, also known as Rehabilitation of Douala Eastern Access Phase 2 project. 

The project entails the rehabilitation and upgrade of a 9-kilometre section of the National Road 3, located between the Dibamba River bridge (PK18+825) and the Boko-Tradex interchange (PK9+925). This vital urban corridor lies between the Dibamba River to the east and the Wouri River to the west, serving as a critical link for regional and urban mobility in the Douala metropolitan area.

Scope of Work

  • Rehabilitation of a 9 km dual carriageway with 2×2 urban expressway lanes
  • Construction of a new bridge to accommodate increased traffic flow
  • Pedestrian infrastructure, including pedestrian bridges for safe crossings
  • Public transport amenities, including the development of dedicated bus stops and taxi stands

title: 6th of October Luxor Aswan Abu Simbel Rail, Egypt
body:
Also known as the Western Nile High-Speed Railway. 

The project involves the construction of a 1,100-kilometre high-speed railway running along the western bank of the Nile River, connecting Al-Ayat (south of Cairo) to Abu Simbel near Egypt’s southern border with Sudan. This strategic corridor is part of Egypt’s nationwide plan to modernize transport infrastructure and enhance connectivity between key cities and regions.

Scope of Work

  • Railway Line: 1,100 km of double-track electrified railway
  • Design Speed: Up to 250 km/h
    • High-Speed Passenger Trains: 230 km/h (20 trains)
    • Regional Trains: 160 km/h (48 trains)
    • Freight Locomotives: 120 km/h (20 trains)
  • Stations: 36 stations in total
    • 10 high-speed train stations
    • 26 regional train stations
  • Route: From Al-Ayat to Abu Simbel, passing through major cities including Minya,
    • Assiut, Sohag, Qena, Luxor, Aswan, and Toshka
  • Intermodal Integration:
    • Connection with Ain Sokhna–Marsa Matrouh high-speed line at October Gardens
    • Connection with Qena–Safaga–Hurghada line at Qena station

Strategic Importance

  • Provides fast, reliable passenger and freight transport along the Nile corridor
  • Enhances accessibility to Upper Egypt and supports tourism, especially in historic cities like Luxor and Abu Simbel
  • Reduces road congestion and emissions, offering a sustainable alternative to long-distance travel
  • Facilitates regional integration by improving links to Sudan through Abu Simbel

Projected Usage

  • Estimated to serve approximately 3.4 million passengers annually

title: Dakhla Desalination Project, Morocco
body:
Dakhla Desalination, Irrigation, and Renewable Energy Project (Morocco)

The project entails the development of a hybrid infrastructure system in the Dakhla region to support sustainable agriculture and water supply through renewable energy.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a seawater desalination plant with a daily production capacity of 90,000 cubic meters of potable water. 
  • Development of a water distribution network for the irrigation of 5,000 hectares of agricultural land. 
  • Installation of a 40 MW wind power farm to provide clean energy for operating the desalination plant.

title: Pont de Rosso, Senegal
body:
Pont de Rosso project involves the construction of a 1,461-meter bridge over the Senegal River, linking the towns of Rosso in Senegal and Mauritania. The bridge is designed with two vehicle lanes on one side and a single lane on the opposite side, facilitating cross-border transport and improving regional integration.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of the main bridge structure (1,461 m)
  • Development of access viaducts and 8 km of access roads on both sides of the river
  • Integration of border control and customs infrastructure to streamline transit
  • Enhanced connectivity to national road networks in both countries

Purpose & Impact

  • Strengthens trade and mobility between Senegal and Mauritania
  • Replaces the existing ferry service, ensuring year-round, uninterrupted crossing
  • Forms part of the Trans-African Highway network (Dakar–Nouakchott corridor)

This large-scale industrial complex is dedicated to the extraction and production of phosphate fertilizers, and at full capacity, it will produce 10 million tonnes of phosphate fertilizers per year.

body:
Alstom Industrial Complex is situated in Borg El Arab City, Alexandria, Egypt. This project aims to localize railway manufacturing and boost exports to the Middle East and Africa. The complex spans approximately 168,000 square meters and has the following facilities:

title: Ain Sokhna Integrated Tire City, Egypt
body:
The Ain Sokhna Integrated Tire City is located in the Free zone in Ain Sokhna, Suez Canal Economic Zone.

The project includes an integrated industrial city for automobiles and their feedstock industries in the Ain Sokhna Free Zone. The project's targeted production capacity is 9.6 million tires annually.

Facilities:

  • Three tire manufacturing plants.
  • Factories for tire production equipment, steel wire, and white carbon.
  • A research and development center for rubber and tire technology.
  • Service centers for tire-related industries.

title: Rolling Plus Tire Factory, Egypt
body:
The Rolling Plus Tire Factory is located within the Suez Canal Economic Zone and spans an area of 400,000 square meters. 

The project will be implemented in three successive phases, with a production capacity of up to 7 million tires annually, including passenger, light, and heavy vehicle tires. 

Phased Construction:

  • Phase 1: Factory construction and passenger car tire production lines; 2.5 million tires/year;
  • Phase 2: Light commercial vehicle tire production; 3.5 million tires/year;
  • Phase 3: Heavy commercial vehicle tire production; total capacity reaches 7 million tires/year

title: Luhoi Geothermal Power Plant, Tanzania
body:
• Build a 5 MW geothermal plant in the Pwani/Coast region 
  • The project had reached the verification stage of geothermal resources as of January 2024

 

Project site geothermal features:

Luhoi geothermal prospect is situated about 150 km SSW of Dar es Salaam between Kibiti Town in the North and Luhoi River (a tributary of Rufiji River) in the South

Several hot springs have been recorded with hot water outflows forming extensive warm wetlands in some places (Nyongoni hot springs) 

The main geothermal surface manifestations comprise gas bubbles, surface alteration and travertine, which are scattered within the Rufiji basin at temperatures of up to 71.5 degrees Celsius. The heat source for the geothermal system is deep circulation along the intersecting fault systems. Recent studies estimated power generation potential of 30 MWe from a reservoir of about 140 degrees Celsius (JICA, 2014)

title: Natron Geothermal Power Plant, Tanzania
body:
• Build a 60 MW geothermal plant in Arusha, northern Tanzania
  • The project was at the stage of deep scientific research as of January 2024

 

Project site geothermal features:

The Lake Natron Basin in northern Tanzania forms part of the East African Rift System

The area is one of the most tectonically, seismically and volcanically active portions of the eastern branch of the Kenya rift

Ol’Doinyo Lengai, the world’s only active carbonatite volcano, rises up from the basin floor and forms a prominent stratocone that dominates the landscape

Preliminary studies indicate that a geothermal resource exists associated with fault zones to the west and east of Lake Natron and exhibited by hot springs. It has also been suggested that a resource could be present under the Gelai volcano and shown by intense, shallow seismic activity at the volcano

title: Songwe Geothermal Power Plant, Tanzania
body:
• Build a geothermal plant with a capacity of between 5 MW and 38 MW in the Mbozi district of the southwestern Songwe region
  • The fields are located on the left bank of Songwe River, approximately 30Km west of Mbeya City
  • Tanzania Geothermal Development Company (TGDC) was in the process of drawing four wells for resource verification, as of late October 2024

 

Project site geothermal features:

The Songwe geothermal area is located within the Rukwa rift basin along the western fault scarps. Songwe is within a micro graben defined by NW trending faults. Songwe hot springs occur on the western fault that dips in the NE direction

At Songwe, travertine deposits overlie Limestone beds, Red sandstone and Karoo conglomerates. There are Cretaceous carbonatite intrusive in the southern Songwe basin. However no recent volcanic activity present in the area. Differing from Ngozi, this geothermal site should be considered as amagmatic (hydrothermal convective system along faults without magmatic heat source)

title: Kiejo-Mbaka Geothermal Power Plant, Tanzania
body:
• Build a 60 MW geothermal power plant approximately 30 km southeast of the Rungwe volcano
  • The first phase will generate 10 MW and the implementation is set to cost US$75.64 million
  • The project had reached the verification stage of geothermal resources, involving the drilling of deep research wells, as of late October 2024
  • Tanzania aims to connect geothermal energy to the national grid by 2030 to ensure reliable access to renewable electricity. This goal is in line with the Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and the national ambition to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2050

 

Project site geothermal features:

Travertine accumulates where the hot springs gush out from the hillside and riverbed

Quaternary basic volcanic rocks are widely distributed in the field, where NW-SE trending faults are well-developed. Hot springs up welling from fissures in a similar trend, with localised river, over a distance of more than 200 metres 

Mbeya Region in the Rungwe area is one of the areas seen as having the greatest potential for generating geothermal energy because one branch of the Rift Valley enters the area and another branch heads towards Malawi

title: Ngozi Geothermal Power Plant, Tanzania
body:
• Build a 70 MW geothermal plant in phases, located partly within the Poroto forest reserve in the Rungwe and Mbeya rural districts in the Mbeya region, southwest Tanzania
  • The first phase is expected to generate 30 MW and is set to cost US$144 million
  • The project had reached the verification stage of geothermal resources, which involves the drilling of verification wells, as of late October 2024
  • TGDC has already undertaken details surface studies, including geological and structural studies, geochemistry and geophysical studies, to confirm the modelled geothermal system at the Ngozi volcano to allow for development. Three deep slim holes have been sited to confirm the existence of the geothermal system
  • Tanzania aims to connect geothermal energy to the national grid by 2030 to ensure reliable access to renewable electricity. This goal is in line with the Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and the national ambition to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2050

 

Project site geothermal features: 

The project falls within the Quaternary Rungwe Volcanics Province at the southern triple junction of the East Africa Rift System, where Eastern and Western arms intersect (Nyasa rift to the south, Usangu rift to the North East and Rukwa rift to the North West) 

Ngozi is part of the Poroto Mountain ridge thought to be largely made up of basalt, phonolite and trachyte lava flow deposits erupted from numerous centres

The area is characterised by young volcanic cones and the main volcanic feature being Ngozi Caldera Lake

Mbeya Region in the Rungwe area is one of the areas seen as having the greatest potential for generating geothermal energy because one branch of the Rift Valley enters the area and another branch heads towards Malawi

title: Algiers–Tamanrasset Railway, Algeria
body:
The Algiers–Tamanrasset Railway is a monumental infrastructure project aimed at connecting Algeria's capital, Algiers, to the southern city of Tamanrasset, spanning approximately 2,406 kilometers. This railway line is part of Algeria's broader initiative to modernize its transport network, enhance regional connectivity, and stimulate economic development, particularly in the southern regions. ​

Technical Scope:

  • Route: The line will traverse 10 provinces, including Blida, Médéa, Djelfa, Laghouat, Ghardaïa, El Menia, In Salah, Tamanrasset, and extend towards the border with Niger.
  • Design Speed: The railway is designed to accommodate trains traveling at speeds up to 220 km/h, facilitating efficient passenger and freight transport.
  • Infrastructure: The project includes the construction of new tracks, stations, bridges, and tunnels, as well as the installation of modern signaling and communication systems.
  • Electrification: Plans are underway to electrify the line to promote sustainability and reduce operational costs.

title: Gara Djebilet Solar Plant, Algeria
body:
• Build a 200 MW solar plant in the Gara Djebilet desert, located in the Tindouf region
  • The plant will have a battery energy storage system (BESS)
  • Located between Tindouf and the Gara Djebilet iron ore mine, the solar plant will cover an area of over 400 hectares
  • The plant will largely cover the power needs of the Gara Djebilet mine, the primary processing facilities and the mining town of Gara Djebilet, in addition to supplying the town of Tindouf via the high-voltage network to ensure balanced power distribution in the wilaya

 

(Source: Algeria Invest)

title: Western Mining Railway, Algeria
body:
​The Western Mining Railway Project is a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing the country's mining export capabilities, particularly for iron ore from the Gara Djebilet mine.​

Project Overview

Total Length: 575 kilometers​

Route: Connects the Gara Djebilet iron ore mine in Tindouf Province to Bechar Province, traversing challenging desert terrains.​

Purpose: Facilitates the transportation of iron ore to industrial zones and ports, bolstering Algeria's mining sector and export capacity.​

Key Components

  • Railway Construction:
    The project involves building a standard-gauge heavy-haul railway line, designed to transport an estimated 40 to 50 million tons of freight annually.​
  • Sleeper Plant: 
    A new railway sleeper factory has been established in Tindouf Province, covering 91,000 square meters. This facility is tasked with producing 1.2 million concrete sleepers, incorporating Chinese-designed solutions tailored for heavy-duty operations in desert conditions.​

title: Eastern Mining Railway, Algeria
body:
The project involves the comprehensive modernization and dualization of the Eastern Mining Railway Line, covering a total length of 588 kilometers. It aims to improve transport capacity, reliability, and efficiency for mineral freight in eastern Algeria.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a new railway line (200 km):
    A new 200-kilometer section will be constructed between Jabal Al-Anq and Al-Oued to provide a more direct and efficient route from key mining areas to the national rail network.
  • Modernization and realignment of existing line (388 km):
    The existing 388-kilometer railway from Annaba to Jabal Al-Anq will be upgraded and realigned. Works include:
    • Track renewal to accommodate higher axle loads and speeds.
    • Geometric correction to improve alignment and safety.
    • Upgrading signaling, communications, and safety systems.

title: Hassi R’mel Gas Field Upgrade, Algeria
body:
The scope of the project entails the implementation of three gas boosting stations, including turbo-compressors that will compress about 188 million standard cubic meters per day of natural gas. Additionally, the project entails the upgrading of the existing gas gathering system, which includes more than 300 km of flowlines connecting the wells. 

Source: Tecnimont (MAIRE)

The project involves a major capacity enhancement of the Hassi R’mel gas field, Algeria’s largest and one of the most critical sources for domestic and export gas supply.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of Three Gas Boosting Stations. Each station will be equipped with high-performance turbo-compressors designed to compress approximately 188 million standard cubic meters of natural gas per day, improving pressure and flow for downstream transport.
  • Upgrade of Gas Gathering System - Modernisation of the existing infrastructure, including:
    • Over 300 kilometres of new flowlines
    • Interconnections with existing wells
    • Optimisation of gas collection and transmission efficiency across the field

This upgrade aims to increase throughput, maintain reservoir pressure, and improve long-term productivity of the field, ensuring sustained delivery of natural gas for both local use and international export via the TransMed and Medgaz pipelines.

title: Nambungale-Mueda Road, Mozambique
body:
• Build the 59 km Nambungale-Mueda road in Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado province, along with 5.4 km of the Mueda town bypass and 5 km of streets in Mueda
  • The Nambungale-Mueda route is part of the 170km R1251, which connects Mueda to Negomano on the border with Tanzania and complements the Unity Bridge, built over the Rovuma River and opened in 2010
  • Work on the road began in June 2024 and is expected to be completed in December 2026
  • The road’s construction will improve connectivity on the entire 1,604km link between Malawi and Mozambique, and is also the missing link on the Mtwara corridor, which links to Tanzania’s Mtwara port on the Indian Ocean

title: Ikaegeng XTL Project, Botswana
body:
Also known as Ikaegeng Coal-to-Liquid Fuels project, or Ikaegeng XTL project, is a significant coal-to-liquids (CTL) initiative in Botswana, aiming to enhance the country's energy security by converting domestic coal resources into liquid fuels. 

Project Scope

The IXTL Project is structured as a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) and encompasses the following components:​

XTL Processing Facility: A plant designed to convert coal into synthetic fuels, primarily diesel and gasoline.​

Supporting Infrastructure: This includes storage facilities, blending units, and distribution networks to facilitate the handling and transportation of the produced fuels.

Wholesale and Retail Distribution: The project plans to establish a business model for the wholesale distribution, storage, blending, and sales of XTL diesel and gasoline across Botswana.

The project is expected to meet up to 80% of Botswana's annual gasoline demand, which stands at approximately 1.2 billion litres. This would significantly reduce the country's reliance on imported petroleum products, particularly from South Africa, whose refining capacity has been declining in recent years. 

Current Progress

Feasibility Study: Completed in accordance with Botswana's PPP Policy and Implementation Framework.​

Procurement Phase: The project is currently in the procurement stage, seeking private partners for implementation. The government has authorized the issuance of a Request for Proposals to identify suitable private entities for partnership.

Technical Advisory Services: A contract was awarded to Hatch, RSA, for Phase III of the project, focusing on providing technical advisory services to Botswana Oil Limited (BOL).

Economic Impact: The construction phase is projected to create approximately 1,500 jobs, with an additional 1,420 jobs during the operational phase. The facility is also expected to generate over P1 billion in annual tax revenues for the government.

title: Reconstruction of Benga-Nkhotakota-Dwangwa (M5) Road, Malawi
body:
• Reconstruct the 102.5 km Benga-Nkhotakota-Dwangwa (M5) road in Malawi’s central region, which runs parallel to the coastline of Lake Malawi
  • The reconstruction work includes widening the road from the current 6 metres to 11 metres and working on bridges to reduce travel time and vehicle operating costs as well as improve safety
  • The work includes rehabilitating district feeder roads, with about 50km of feeder roads to be revamped in the Nkhotakota district to improve access for rural communities

 

The Benga-Nkhotakota-Dwangwa road project is part of the wider SADC Sub-Regional Transport and Trade Facilitation project, which aims to improve transport and facilitate trade in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region, specifically along the North-South corridor in Malawi, which connects the country to the Port of Dar Es Salaam in Tanzania and Port of Durban in South Africa as well as to the Copperbelt mining region

title: Dodoma Integrated and Sustainable Transport (DIST) Programme, Tanzania
body:
Implement the Dodoma Integrated and Sustainable Transport (DIST) project in Tanzania's capital city

The scheme is expected to improve urban mobility in Dodoma through the upgrade of selected corridors, resilient access routes, central business district (CBD) improvements, and enhanced walking and cycling infrastructure

Specifically, the scheme will target infrastructure development of the following roads that are part of multimodal transport:

  • The 32 km Kimbinyiko Roundabout to Chamwino Town Junction road – This is the busiest road in the city and links the CBD with major demand centres to the east, including parliament and government offices, major commercial centers and markets, the intercity bus terminal and rapidly developing residential districts. The road is part of the 260km Morogoro-Dodoma Trunk Road (T003)
  • The 10 km Bahi Roundabout-Msalato Airport Junction road (part of Dodoma-Arusha trunk road) – The second-busiest road in Dodoma, this stretch connects the CBD northward towards Arusha, providing access to the under-construction Msalato International airport
  • The 7 km Image Roundabout-Mkonze bus stand road (part of Dodoma-Iringa trunk road) – This route connects the CBD with the newly opened Dodoma standard-gauge railway (SGR) terminal and the bus station at Mkonze. The work will address the growing demand from the south and the need to better interconnect Dodoma’s transport infrastructure and enhance smooth movement of passengers to and from the SGR terminal and the rapidly developing neighbourhoods surrounding it
  • In addition, the DIST scheme will finance improvements of 4.8 km of primary CBD roads including the Mpwapwa road from the Bunge area through Chako ni Chako to the Machinga complex and the connection from the Kimbinyiko roundabout through Jamatini to Kuu Street and the airport roundabout. Work will include providing improved walking and cycling infrastructure, drainage, street lighting and improved traffic management
  • Moreover, selected access roads have been identified for improvement through a complete streets approach comprising upgrading of the road surface to a paved standard, walkways, cycleways, improved drainage and street lighting, and daladala stops
  • The project will also look to reinforce Dodoma’s prevalent use of walking for transportation and its sustainable city aspirations through the addition of about 60 km of pedestrian and cycleways to existing roads and unpaved pathways across the city

 

The project’s primary beneficiaries will be the 430,000 people provided with improved mobility and access by the project’s investments, equivalent to 56% of all residents in the city

The project will be implemented by Tanzania National Roads Agency (Tanroads), Tanzania Rural and Urban Roads Agency (Tarura), Land Transport Regulatory Authority (LATRA) and the City Council of Dodoma. It is expected to be completed by March 2030

title: Tanzania Uganda Gas Pipeline
body:
The project involves the construction of an estimated 1,440-kilometre natural gas pipeline connecting Uganda and Tanzania. The pipeline is designed to transport natural gas from Tanzania to Uganda, supporting power generation and industrial development along the corridor.

Route

The pipeline will originate in Tanzania, where natural gas reserves are located, and extend to Uganda, facilitating regional energy integration.

Purpose and Benefits

Energy Access: Provides a steady supply of natural gas to Uganda for power plants, industrial processing, and domestic use.

Regional Integration: Strengthens energy trade between Tanzania and Uganda, and enhances East Africa's cross-border infrastructure.

Economic Development: Reduces reliance on imported petroleum products and promotes development of gas-based industries in Uganda.

Sustainability: Supports transition to cleaner fuel sources compared to heavy fuel oil and diesel.
