title: Tanzania Zambia Oil Pipeline (TAZAMA Expansion)
body:
Tanzania–Zambia Oil Pipeline project involves the construction of a new 12-inch oil pipeline running from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, to Solwezi in north-western Zambia, designed to boost fuel supply to Zambia’s mining and industrial sectors. The pipeline largely follows the route of the existing Tanzania Zambia Mafuta (TAZAMA) pipeline from Dar es Salaam to the Indeni Refinery in Ndola, with a major extension from Ndola to Solwezi.

Total Length: Approximately 1,700 km

Zambia Section

Total length: ~1,110 km

Route: From the Tanzania–Zambia border to Solwezi, passing through Mpika and Ndola (Indeni Refinery)

  • Phase 1: Tanzania Border – Mpika
    • Length: 340 km
    • Estimated Cost: Up to USD 300 million
  • Phase 2: Mpika – Ndola (Indeni Refinery)
    • Length: 480 km
  • Phase 3: Ndola (Indeni Refinery) – Solwezi
    • Length: 290 km
    • This phase extends the pipeline into Zambia’s Copperbelt and mining zones.

Tanzania Section

Total length: ~700 km

Route: From Dar es Salaam to the Tanzania–Zambia border, following the corridor of the existing TAZAMA pipeline.

Purpose & Impact

Objective: To increase and stabilize the supply of petroleum products to Zambia, especially to high-demand regions like the mining areas around Solwezi.

Strategic Importance: Enhances regional fuel logistics, reduces reliance on road tankers, supports industrial and mining activities, and improves energy security for both countries.

Integration: Complements the existing TAZAMA pipeline and integrates with infrastructure at the Indeni Refinery, facilitating domestic refining and distribution.

title: Namibia Botswana Zambia Gas Pipeline
body:
The project involves the development of a 1,690-kilometre cross-border natural gas pipeline that will run from Windhoek, Namibia, through Botswana, and terminate in Lusaka, Zambia. Designed to transport at least 350 million cubic feet of natural gas per day, the pipeline will serve as a major energy infrastructure corridor in Southern Africa.

The primary objective of the project is to facilitate a reliable supply of natural gas to power plants across the region, boosting domestic energy production and supporting industrial development. The pipeline will enable gas-fired power generation in key locations along its route, contributing to energy security, regional integration, and economic growth.

This strategic infrastructure is part of a broader regional energy initiative to reduce dependence on imported fuels, lower electricity costs, and encourage cleaner energy sources compared to coal or diesel.

title: Power Sector Reform, Investment and Modernization (PRIME-1), Ethiopia
body:
The Power Sector Reform, Investment, and Modernization in Ethiopia (PRIME-1) program is a comprehensive initiative to transform Ethiopia's electricity sector.

The project comprises the following:

  • Focuses on infrastructure investments like distribution network refurbishment in 72 towns and transmission line construction.
  • Supports geothermal resource development and private participation in renewable energy generation.
  • Includes technical assistance for capacity building

Source: World Bank - Project ID P176731

title: Climate Resilience and Water Security, Angola
body:
The Climate Resilience and Water Security in Angola project, also referred to as RECLIMA, is an initiative aimed at addressing climate-related challenges and ensuring sustainable water management in Angola. 

Some of the features of the project include:

  • Sand Dams Construction: The project involves the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) and Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) for the construction of 10 sand dams. These dams are designed to enhance water storage capacity and resilience against climate variability.
  • Integrated Water Storage Systems: Investments focus on three types of water storage—watershed storage, groundwater storage, and surface water reservoirs. This combination aims to improve water security and climate resilience in southern Angola.
  • Dam Rehabilitation: Specific infrastructure rehabilitation includes restoring the Sendi dam, which is crucial for supporting farmers and livestock owners, as well as boosting economic potential in affected areas.

Source: World Bank - Project ID P177004

title: Tema-Aflao Highway, Ghana
body:
Project Scope

Tema–Aflao Highway project involves the construction and expansion of a major highway corridor linking Tema Express Roundabout to the Central University Junction, forming part of the strategic East-West transport artery in southern Ghana. The development aims to improve vehicular mobility, safety, and access along this vital route connecting Accra to the Volta Region and the Togo border.

The Tema–Aflao Highway spans approximately 540 kilometers, extending from Elubo at the Ivorian border through major cities including Sekondi-Takoradi, Cape Coast, Accra, and Tema, before reaching Aflao at the Togolese border. ​

The current construction efforts focus on a 17-kilometer segment of this highway, stretching from the Tema Express Roundabout to the Central University Junction at Miotso. ​

This 17-kilometer section is part of a broader initiative to enhance the highway's infrastructure, aiming to improve traffic flow and safety along this critical corridor.​

Key Components

  • Two one-way service roads, each with two lanes, to support local and regional traffic while relieving congestion on the main carriageway
  • Four grade-separated interchanges designed to optimize traffic flow, minimize bottlenecks, and improve access to adjacent urban and peri-urban areas
  • A pedestrian bridge at Dawhenya, ensuring safe crossing for residents and reducing the risk of accidents along the corridor
  • Full road infrastructure package, including:
    • Street lighting for night-time visibility
    • Modern drainage systems to manage stormwater
    • Installation of road signage and traffic safety features

title: Kigali Ring Road (KRR), Rwanda
body:
Kigali Ring Road project involves the construction of a 95-kilometer arterial road forming a complete loop around the capital city of Kigali. The primary objective is to decongest the urban core by facilitating smoother inter-district travel and providing an efficient bypass for long-distance and freight traffic.

Key Components

  • Construction of a 95 km ring road with appropriate surfacing (asphalt or concrete) and lane configurations tailored to traffic demand
  • Route Alignment: The road will encircle the city, passing through key peripheral zones including:
    • Ruliba
    • Mageragere
    • Gahanga
    • Masaka
    • Ndera
    • Nyacyonga
  • Intersections and Access Roads: Construction of grade-separated junctions, roundabouts, and feeder roads to ensure integration with Kigali’s existing road network. 
  • Bridges and Drainage: Development of culverts, overpasses, and bridges where needed, along with comprehensive drainage systems to ensure all-weather resilience. 
  • Pedestrian and Non-Motorized Transport (NMT) Facilities: Provision for sidewalks, cycle lanes, and safety features for non-motorized users.
meta_description: Kigali Ring Road project involves the construction of a 95-kilometer arterial road forming a complete loop around the capital city of Kigali. The primary objective is to decongest the urban core by facilitating smoother inter-district travel and providing an efficient bypass for long-distance and freight traffic.Key Components
migration_status: success

title: Sheini Iron Ore Project, Ghana
body:
The Sheini Hills Iron Project in northeastern Ghana is a large-scale greenfields iron ore project with multi-billion tonne potential. Since acquiring the asset in late 2011, Emmaland has conducted extensive exploration activities to generate resource definition and estimates with metallurgical reports and determine the resource estimate.

Through these activities, the resource estimate from the first phase of drilling was found to be 1.5 billion tonnes of proven reserve and an unproven reserve of approximately 6 billion tonnes of iron.

The project, covering approximately 400 square kilometers, is located in the Zabzugu – Tatale District in Northern Region, the Republic of Ghana.

Source: Emmaland Resources

title: Sumbawanga Kigoma OHL, Tanzania
body:
The project entails the construction and installation of a high-voltage transmission network to improve power supply and regional connectivity across western Tanzania. Key components include:

  • Transmission Line Construction (480 km)
    • Construction of a 400kV double circuit overhead transmission line spanning approximately 480 km
    • Route: Sumbawanga → Mpanda → Kigoma, passing through rural and peri-urban areas
    • Towers, conductors, insulators, and associated line hardware installations
  • Substation Infrastructure
    • Construction of a new 400/132kV substation at Mpanda
    • Extension or upgrade of substations in Sumbawanga and Kigoma, if applicable
    • Installation of control systems, protection equipment, and telecommunication infrastructure
  • Rural Electrification
    • Electrification of targeted villages in Katavi Region along the transmission route
    • Construction of medium and low voltage distribution lines
    • Installation of distribution transformers and household connections

title: The Carnelian, Nigeria
body:
The Carnelian, Lagos will be a 20-story, 94-suite tower of two and three-bedroom apartments and penthouses, set in landscaped open space on Bluewater Zone between Victoria Island’s ocean-front and Lekki Phase 1.  At 370 feet above the ground, its serene 180-degree ocean view will represent the future of lifestyle in Lagos for residential and recreational purposes and a new landmark on the city skyline.

It contains 62 or 94 luxury suites, including:

  • One-bedroom apartments (114.67 SQM).
  • Two-bedroom apartments (171.67 SQM).
  • Three-bedroom apartments with BQ (267.67 SQM).
  • Penthouses, including a four-bedroom penthouse with a rooftop infinity pool

Source: The Carnelian

title: Dar Al Hedaya Mosque, Ghana
body:
Also known as Darul Hedaya Islamic Mosque is being constructed in Ghana and will be covering an area of 7,200m².

Key features:
- A main mosque accommodating 1,500 worshipers, with a dedicated women's section.
- Four 60-meter-high minarets, inspired by the Fatimid style.
- 25 domes, alongside a multi-purpose building with event halls and an educational facility for 300 students.
- A dedicated Quran memorization school and Islamic learning center.
- Modern amenities, including elevators, escalators, and a 200-car underground garage.

Source: Arab Contractors Company

title: Special Agro-Industrial Processing Zones (SAPZ), Nigeria
body:
The Special Agro-Industrial Processing Zones (SAPZ) is a program designed by the Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security (FMAFS) in close collaboration with the Africa Development Bank, (AfDB) the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), the Islamic Development Bank (IsDB).

The first phase of the SAPZ is being implemented in seven (7) states of Cross River, Imo, Kaduna, Kano, Kwara, Ogun, Oyo and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT). Subsequently, more states would join in phases. 

The goal of SAPZ is to increase household incomes, foster job creation in rural agricultural communities, especially for youth and women, and enhance food and nutritional security in Nigeria. The development objective is to support inclusive and sustainable agro-industrial development in Nigeria.

Infrastructure Development

SAPZs involve the development of necessary infrastructure such as roads, power supply, water, and processing facilities. This helps overcome challenges associated with inadequate infrastructure in rural areas.

Source: SAPZ

title: SGR Project: Western/Southern Route, Uganda
body:
Development of the Standard Gauge Railway Western/Southern Route Project (Kampala-Bihanga-Kasese-Mpondwe/ Hima and Bihanga-Mirama Hills/ Muko). 

Source: Ministry of Works and Transport

​Uganda Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) project encompasses a comprehensive network designed to enhance regional connectivity and trade. The Western and Southwestern routes are pivotal components of this network, facilitating links between Uganda and neighboring countries such as the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda.​

Western Route: Kampala–Mpondwe (Western Line)

  • Length: Approximately 430 kilometers​
  • Route: This line originates in Kampala, traverses through Bihanga in Ibanda District, and culminates at Mpondwe, a strategic border town adjacent to the DRC.​
  • Purpose: The Western Line is designed to bolster trade and economic integration between Uganda and the DRC, providing a direct rail link to facilitate the movement of goods and passengers.​

Southwestern Route: Bihanga–Mirama Hills (Southwestern Line)

  • Length: Approximately 191 kilometers​
  • Route: Commencing from Bihanga, this line passes through Ibanda and Mbarara, terminating at Mirama Hills on the border with Rwanda.​
  • Purpose: The Southwestern Line aims to strengthen bilateral relations and trade between Uganda and Rwanda by offering an efficient rail corridor for commerce and travel.​

These routes are integral to Uganda's broader SGR initiative, which seeks to modernize the country's railway infrastructure, reduce transportation costs, and enhance regional trade. The development of these lines is part of a strategic effort to connect Uganda's rail network with those of its neighbors, thereby fostering economic growth and regional integration.​

The Western and Southwestern routes are pivotal components of this network

title: Robeiky - 10th of Ramadan - Belbeis Railway, Egypt
body:
This freight rail project involves the construction of a new railway corridor approximately 45 kilometres in length, beginning in Robaiky (north of Badr City in east Cairo) and extending through 10th of Ramadan City to the industrial area of Belbeis.

Scope of work

  • Main Line:
    • Approximately 45 km in length
    • Connects key industrial and logistics hubs from Robaiky to Belbeis
    • Designed to enhance freight movement efficiency and support industrial supply chains
  • Branch Line:
    • An additional 13 km spur
    • Provides direct rail access to the dry port in 10th of Ramadan City, improving cargo handling and intermodal connectivity

title: Dakhla Port, Morocco
body:
Also known as Dakhla Atlantic Port, the project involves the construction of a new deep-water port on the Atlantic coast of the Dakhla-Oued Eddahab region. Designed to support the region’s economic development and strategic positioning, the port will serve as a multi-purpose maritime hub with specialized terminals and industrial capacity.

Scope of Work

  • Commercial Terminal:
    • Dedicated container and general cargo facilities
    • Handling capacity: Up to 2.2 million tons per year
  • Fishing Port:
    • Equipped for industrial and artisanal fishing activities
    • Handling capacity: Up to 1 million tons of fish products annually
  • Shipbuilding and Repair Zone:
    • Industrial area dedicated to ship construction, maintenance, and repair
    • Supports maritime industry development and local job creation

title: Tripoli Third Ring Road, Libya
body:
The Third Ring Road in Tripoli is a major urban infrastructure project designed to enhance mobility, reduce congestion, and improve connectivity across the city. The project will link the Second Ring Road on the western side of Tripoli to Al Fatah Road, a key peripheral route in the northeast.

Scope of Work

  • Total Length: Approximately 24 kilometers
  • Roadway Design:
    • Dual carriageway with 3 traffic lanes per direction (6 lanes total)
    • Service roads flanking the main carriageway
    • Total roadway width: 30.60 meters
  • Structures Included:
    • 28 car bridges to facilitate uninterrupted vehicular flow
    • 14 pedestrian bridges to enhance safety and accessibility for foot traffic

title: Kondo Dam, Zimbabwe
body:
The Kondo Dam is being constructed on the Save River in Zimbabwe. It is designed to serve multiple purposes, including irrigation, water supply, and hydroelectric power generation. The dam is expected to have a storage capacity of 3.5 billion cubic meters and will support agricultural activities across 25,000 hectares of land.

The project includes a 200-megawatt hydroelectric power station. This makes it a dual-purpose dam for both water management and energy production.

title: Riverlands, South Africa
body:
The Riverlands development, formerly known as the River Club, is a mixed-use project located between the Liesbeek Parkway and the Liesbeek River in Cape Town, South Africa. This 14-hectare project is designed to integrate residential, commercial, and cultural spaces while addressing infrastructure and environmental needs.

The development includes office spaces (approximately 105,000m²), retail areas (15,000m²), and residential units (30,000m²).

It will host riverside restaurants, coffee shops, and a retail center with a premium supermarket.

title: Oued Zem Beni Mellal Rail, Morocco
body:
The project for the railway service between the cities of Oued Zem and Beni Mellal, in the centre of the country.

As part of Morocco's 2040 railway strategy, the new work includes the widening and rectification of approximately 40 kilometres between Khouribga and Oued Zem, studies for the elimination of level crossings on approximately 120 km between Sidi el Aidi and Oued Zem and the development of a new route between Oued Zem and Beni Mellal of approximately 60 km. 

Source: Ineco

Scope of work

  • Track Modernisation: Widening and realignment of approximately 40 km of rail line between Khouribga and Oued Zem to enhance speed, safety, and operational efficiency.
  • Safety Improvements: Engineering studies for the elimination of level crossings along 120 km of railway corridor between Sidi el Aidi and Oued Zem, to reduce accident risks and improve transit reliability.
  • Network Extension: Planning and development of a new 60 km railway section connecting Oued Zem to Beni Mellal, expanding access to rail services in the region and enabling integration into the national railway grid.

title: Tangier Tram, Morocco
body:
Construction of a tram network consisting of three lines, with a total estimated length between 25 to 30 kilometers.

Line 1: To link the Tangier Offshore Zone with the residential districts of Moghogha and Béni Makada, enhancing commuter access between industrial and residential areas. Line 1 connects the university hospital to the high-speed train station Al Bouraq.

Line 2: Designed to run through the city along Boulevard Moulay Ismaïl, serving as a central urban corridor and improving mobility across key urban zones. Line 2 connects the industrial zone of Mghogha to Nations Square (Tangier city center). ​

Line 3: Extending from Tangier Ibn Battuta International Airport to the Hassani Complex near the Grand Stadium. ​

title: Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit Line 5 (Nyati), Kenya
body:
The Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) Line 5, known as the Nyati Line, is a flagship public transport project aimed at easing congestion and improving mobility along Nairobi’s eastern corridor. This line is the shortest of Nairobi’s planned BRT corridors and is designed to provide a fast, reliable, and high-capacity bus service primarily along the busy Outer Ring Road.

BRT Line 5 (Nyati) will run from Balozi Estate, near the General Service Unit (GSU) headquarters at Allsops (Ruaraka), to Imara Daima, traversing the entire length of Outer Ring Road. The corridor links major residential and commercial zones in Nairobi’s east, connecting key nodes and facilitating seamless transfers to other BRT lines and public transport modes. The route includes the following primary segments:

  • Northern Terminus: Balozi Estate (near GSU headquarters, Allsops, Ruaraka, off Thika Road)
  • Main Corridor: Follows Outer Ring Road southwards, passing through densely populated neighborhoods such as Umoja, Donholm, Tena, Pipeline, Embakasi, and Fedha
  • Southern Terminus: Imara Daima, a major residential and commercial hub near Mombasa Road

Technical Scope:

  • Construction of a dual-lane BRT corridor along the entire length of Outer Ring Road (10.4–10.5 km).
  • Creation of 13 BRT stations with new and upgraded footbridges.
  • Construction of three river bridges (totaling about 1,024 meters) and two overpass bridges (about 323 meters).
  • Establishment of a 1,365-square-meter BRT depot, including parking, access roads, fencing, and electromechanical works.
  • Installation of advanced electromechanical systems, drainage, street lighting, landscaping, and other enhancements.
  • Provision of electric vehicle charging stations, vehicle tracking, and surveillance systems for the buses.
  • The line will initially operate with 30 high-capacity buses, each capable of carrying up to 160 passengers, with plans to scale up operations.

title: Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit Line 3 (Chui), Kenya
body:
Nairobi BRT Line 3, also known as the Clean Core BRT Line 3, is a major component of Nairobi’s sustainable transport plan. The project will deliver a dedicated 12–12.5 km bus corridor running from Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH), through the Central Business District (CBD), along Juja Road, and terminating at Dandora Commuter Railway Station. The route crosses densely populated urban areas and interfaces with other planned BRT lines, making it the backbone of Nairobi’s future BRT network.

The BRT Line 3 is planned to be developed in three phases:

Phase I: 12.4 kilometers, stretching from Dandora to Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH) via Juja Road.

Phase II: 20.8 kilometers, extending from KNH to Ngong.

Phase III: 52 kilometers, connecting Dandora to Tala. 

Technical Scope:

  • Dedicated BRT running lanes on existing roads
  • 19 modern bus stations with pre-paid/off-board fare collection
  • A Park & Ride facility and a bus depot at Dandora
  • Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) for ticketing, real-time passenger information, and traffic management
  • Integration with non-motorized transport (NMT) infrastructure, including pedestrian paths, cycle lanes, and secure crossings
  • Interchange stations for feeder bus services
  • Urban integration measures, including green spaces and improved streetscapes

title: Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit Line 2 (Simba), Kenya
body:
Line 2 (Simba) is a 27 km Bus Rapid Transit corridor running from Ruiru through Kasarani, Nairobi CBD, to Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH), with future extensions to Rongai and Kenol. It is part of Nairobi’s five-line BRT network under the Integrated Urban Development Master Plan, designed to alleviate congestion and provide affordable, high-capacity public transport.

The project is being executed in two phases:​

  • Phase I: Clayworks – Kenyatta University – Githurai – Kasarani – Pangani Underpass – Murang’a Road – Globe Cinema Overpass – Tom Mboya Street – Moi Avenue (approximately 20 km).
  • Phase II: Ruiru – Membley Junction – Clayworks section (approximately 3 km) and Moi Avenue – Haile Selassie Avenue – Kenyatta National Hospital (approximately 4 km).

Technical Scope:

  • Construction of 20.18 km of dedicated BRT lanes.
  • Development of 13 intermediate BRT stations, including the conversion of 10 existing footbridges along Thika Road into station facilities.
  • Construction of a BRT terminal at Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH) and bus depots at Ruiru and Kasarani.
  • Establishment of a transfer station at the Nairobi Railway Station.
  • Installation of Non-Motorized Transport (NMT) infrastructure along the corridor.
  • Implementation of automatic traffic signal systems at the Pangani Underpass.

title: Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit Line 1 (Ndovu), Kenya
body:
Nairobi BRT Line 1 (Ndovu) is a flagship component of Nairobi’s Integrated Urban Development Master Plan, designed to decongest the city by offering high-capacity, efficient public transport. The route spans approximately 50 km from Limuru through Kangemi, Nairobi CBD, Imara Daima, Athi River, to Kitengela, serving key economic hubs.

Technical Scope:

  • Dedicated Bus Lanes: Fully segregated lanes to ensure priority for BRT buses.
  • Stations: High-capacity stations with level boarding, real-time passenger information, and fare collection systems.
  • Integration: Connects with other BRT lines (e.g., Line 2–Simba) and planned rail projects (e.g., Nairobi Commuter Rail).
  • Depots: Proposed depots at Syokimau and Imara Daima for bus storage/maintenance.
  • Technology: Advanced signaling, fare collection automation, and vehicle tracking systems

title: Zaria–Kaura Namoda–Sokoto–Illela–Birnin Konni Line, Niger
body:
This rail line is part of Nigeria’s railway modernization program under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), designed to enhance regional connectivity between Nigeria and Niger. It aims to facilitate cross-border trade, reduce transport costs, and integrate economic activities across the two countries. The line connects Nigeria’s northern cities (Zaria, Kaura Namoda, Sokoto, and Illela) to Birnin Konni in Niger Republic, a critical border town.

Technical Scope: 

Route Length:

  • 520 km (Nigeria section: Zaria–Kaura Namoda–Sokoto–Illela; Niger section: Illela–Birnin Konni).

Key Components:

  • Track laying, signaling systems, and station construction.
  • Potential integration with existing Illela-Konni road networks (e.g., Sokoto-Illela-Birnin Konni road).
  • Cross-border infrastructure (e.g., customs facilities at Illela/Birnin Konni)

title: Eastern Corridor Road Development Programme (ECRDP), Ghana
body:
The Eastern Corridor Road Development Programme (ECRDP) is a major infrastructure initiative undertaken by the Government of Ghana to enhance connectivity and stimulate economic development in the eastern part of the country. The corridor spans from the southern port city of Tema through Ho, Nkwanta, Bimbilla, Yendi, and up to Kulungugu in the north-eastern border near Burkina Faso. The objective of the programme is to facilitate the efficient movement of goods and people, reduce travel time and vehicle operating costs, and improve access to social and economic services for communities along the route.

Technical Scope

Road Construction and Upgrading:

  • Upgrading of approximately 695 kilometers of road along the Eastern Corridor from gravel and poor bitumen surfaces to asphaltic concrete pavement.
  • Widening of road sections to meet standard design widths, including shoulders for enhanced safety.
  • Improvement of horizontal and vertical alignments for better driving conditions.

Bridge and Culvert Works:

  • Construction and rehabilitation of several medium- and large-span bridges to replace inadequate or failed structures.
  • Installation and rehabilitation of culverts and drainage systems to improve flood resilience and road durability.

Pavement Structure:

  • Sub-base and base layer improvement using engineered fill and crushed rock.
  • Asphaltic concrete surfacing suitable for heavy vehicular loads and tropical conditions.

Ancillary Works:

  • Installation of road furniture including guardrails, signage, and road markings.
  • Construction of pedestrian walkways and bus stops in urban and peri-urban areas.
  • Landscaping and erosion control measures.

The corridor spans from the southern port city of Tema through Ho

title: Chinsali –Nakonde Road Rehabilitation Project, Zambia
body:
The Chinsali–Nakonde Road Rehabilitation Project is a major infrastructure initiative in Zambia, targeting the upgrade of a critical segment of the Great North Road (T2), which forms part of the North-South Corridor linking Zambia to Tanzania and the broader COMESA/EAC/SADC regional trade networks. The project aims to improve road transport infrastructure and services, reduce transport costs, facilitate cross-border trade, enhance tourism, and promote regional integration and economic growth.

Technical Scope:

  • Main Road Rehabilitation:

Total length: 210 km, divided into two concurrent lots:

Lot 1: Chinsali – Isoka (100 km)

Lot 2: Isoka – Nakonde (110 km)

  • Feeder Roads:

Rehabilitation of 50 km of feeder roads to all-weather gravel standard, serving Chinsali (20 km), Isoka (15 km), and Nakonde (15 km).

  • Complementary Infrastructure:

Construction of three truck parks in Chinsali, Isoka, and Nakonde districts

Construction of two toll plazas (Chinsali and Nakonde)

Installation of a weigh-in-motion weighbridge at the T2/D1 (Mbala Road) intersection in Nakonde

title: Gara Djebilet - Béchar Railway, Algeria
body:
The Gara Djebilet–Béchar Railway is a flagship infrastructure project aimed at unlocking Algeria’s vast iron ore reserves located at the Gara Djebilet mine in the Tindouf region. The project is a strategic national priority to diversify Algeria's economy, increase mining exports, and boost regional development in the remote southwest.

The new railway will cover approximately 950 kilometers and directly link the Gara Djebilet mine to Béchar, a critical node in Algeria’s national rail network. From Béchar, ore will be transported further for domestic processing or export via ports.

Technical Scope:

Length: Approximately 950 km of heavy-haul standard-gauge railway.

Route Sections:

  • Béchar to Hammaguir (~200 km)
  • Hammaguir to Oum El Assel (~575 km)
  • Oum El Assel to Gara Djebilet (~175 km)

Track Infrastructure:

  • Heavy-haul track design suitable for iron ore transport.
  • Precast concrete railway sleepers produced locally at a new factory in Tindouf.
  • Continuously welded rails for greater stability and reduced maintenance.
  • High-capacity ballast layer for supporting high axle loads.

Stations and Logistics:

  • Construction of approximately 40 operational stations and logistical support points.

Structures:

  • Bridges over seasonal wadis (dry riverbeds).
  • Extensive culvert and drainage infrastructure to prevent flooding.

Earthworks:

  • Major excavation, embankment construction, and soil stabilization across desert terrain.

Signaling and Communications:

  • Modern electronic signaling systems.
  • Dedicated fiber optic communication lines for control and monitoring.

Maintenance Infrastructure:

  • Depots and workshops for rolling stock and track maintenance.

Energy and Utilities:

  • Substations and necessary energy infrastructure for railway operation.

Security Systems:

  • Fencing and surveillance systems along critical sections of the route.

title: Eastern Mining Rail Dualization, Algeria
body:
The Eastern Mining Rail Dualization, officially known as the Annaba–Djebel Onk Railway Upgrade, is a strategic infrastructure project in Algeria aimed at boosting the country's mineral export capacity. The 422-kilometre railway line connects the phosphate-rich inland region of Djebel Onk in Tébessa Province to the Mediterranean port city of Annaba, serving as a critical export corridor for the country’s Integrated Phosphate Project (PPI).

The upgrade is designed to increase the line's phosphate transport capacity from 2 million tonnes per year to 8 million tonnes per year, enabling the efficient movement of mineral resources to global markets. Once completed, the line is expected to handle over 10 million tonnes of phosphate annually, generating significant economic returns and reinforcing Algeria’s role in the global fertilizer supply chain.

Technical Scope:

  • Total length: 422 km (Annaba to Djebel Onk)
  • Track upgrade: Dualization (conversion from single to double track) across key sections of the line
  • Electrification: Installation of electric traction systems to support modern rolling stock and energy-efficient operations
  • Signaling & Telecommunications: Deployment of advanced signaling systems, centralized traffic control, and communication infrastructure
  • Bridges and Civil Structures: Construction and reinforcement of bridges, culverts, and protective infrastructure across the corridor
  • Earthworks: Site grading, embankment formation, and terrain stabilization across desert and mountainous zones
  • Station Infrastructure: Upgrading and expanding loading/unloading terminals and freight yards to handle increased phosphate volumes
  • New Connection: A newly constructed 23 km link between the Bled El Hadba phosphate mine and the mainline

title: Touggourt - Hassi Messaoud Railway, Algeria
body:
The Touggourt–Hassi Messaoud Railway is a 150-kilometre standard gauge line under construction in southeastern Algeria. It is designed to connect the city of Touggourt with the emerging urban and oil hub of Hassi Messaoud in Ouargla Province. The project is part of Algeria’s national strategy to expand rail infrastructure across the Sahara, aiming to improve inland logistics and facilitate both passenger and freight transport—particularly for the oil and gas sector.

While the project is being implemented as a standalone line, it is strategically integrated into Algeria’s Southeastern Railway Loop. It will eventually link with a broader corridor running from Ghardaïa to Hassi Messaoud via Ouargla, supporting regional integration, industrial development, and enhanced connectivity across the Saharan belt.

Technical Scope:

Length: 

  • 150 kilometres of new standard-gauge railway track

Track type: 

  • Single track with provision for future double-tracking

Track system: 

  • Ballasted track with continuously welded rail and pre-stressed concrete sleepers

Earthworks: 

  • Extensive sand clearance, embankment construction, and terrain stabilization across desert zones

Structures:

  • 11 railway bridges
  • Multiple culverts and hydraulic structures for flood and drainage management
  • Underground livestock crossings for pastoral movement
  • Protective civil works at oil and gas pipeline crossings

Stations:

  • Upgrade of existing station in Touggourt
  • Construction of two new stations: one in the new Hassi Messaoud city, and another at the Hassi Messaoud oil production zone

Signaling & Telecoms: 

  • Installation of modern signaling and communications systems (non-electrified line)

Access Infrastructure:

  • Construction of service roads, logistics yards, and worker facilities
  • Temporary access routes for construction equipment and materials

Speed Design:

  • Passenger trains: up to 220 km/h
  • Freight trains: up to 100 km/h
meta_description: The Touggourt–Hassi Messaoud Railway is a 150-kilometre standard gauge line under construction in southeastern Algeria. It is designed to connect the city of Touggourt with the emerging urban and oil hub of Hassi Messaoud in Ouargla Province. The project is part of Algeria’s national strategy to expand rail infrastructure across the Sahara

title: Burundi-Rwanda Integrated Development Project (BRIDEP)
body:
The Burundi-Rwanda Integrated Development Project (BRIDEP) is designed to promote regional integration within the East African Community (EAC) by improving agricultural productivity, enhancing cross-border transport links, and facilitating trade between Burundi and Rwanda. The project aligns with commitments made at the Dakar 2 Summit in January 2023 to accelerate investments in food and nutrition security, resilience, and agricultural transformation. It contributes to food sovereignty, gender equality, financial inclusion, youth empowerment, climate change resilience, and regional integration.

Technical Scope:

The construction component of BRIDEP focuses primarily on transport infrastructure to improve connectivity between Burundi and Rwanda. Key elements include:

  • Upgrading of Kazabe-Rutsiro Road (Rwanda): Upgrading a 55.3 km road section from gravel to bitumen standard to enhance cross-border transport efficiency and reduce travel time and costs. This is part of Rwanda’s contribution to improving regional connectivity.
  • Cross-Border Infrastructure: Potential development of additional road sections and related infrastructure, such as bridges or border facilities, to support trade and regional integration. While specific details on Burundi’s construction scope are limited, the project includes plans for agricultural infrastructure, such as irrigation systems or produce collection centers, which may involve civil works.
  • Social Infrastructure: Provision of social infrastructure along transport corridors, such as agricultural produce collection centers or markets, to support economic empowerment in the project areas.
  • Environmental and Social Considerations: The project incorporates Environmental and Social Impact Assessments (ESIA), Resettlement Action Plans (RAP), and gender impact assessments to ensure sustainable construction practices and community benefits.
meta_description: The Burundi-Rwanda Integrated Development Project (BRIDEP) is designed to promote regional integration within the East African Community (EAC) by improving agricultural productivity

title: Algeria Italy Interconnector (Medlink)
body:
New interconnection between Algeria and Italy

The project consists of a new interconnection between Algeria (Cheffia) and Italy_Sardinia (Cagliari Sud) through an HVDC submarine cable. The HVDC interconnection will have a capacity of 1000MW and a total length of around 350 km. The maximum depth for the installation of the undersea cable will be over than 2000m. On the Algerian side, the connection of the HVDC Converter Station to the national grid will comprise two 50 km 400 kV AC overhead lines.

  • Substation (from): Cheffia - Algeria
  • Substation (to): Cagliari Sud - Italy 
  • GTC contribution (MW): 1,000
  • Total Route length (km): 350

Source: Med-TSO

It is set to hold 130 million cubic meters of water and will have a 32-kilometer pipeline that will link the dam to the Ncema Dam pump station to supply water to the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe

title: Ziminya Dam, Zimbabwe
body: The Ziminya Dam is approximately 20 km west of Nkayi Business Centre, using the Shangani River as its catchment area. The dam will hold 98 million cubic meters of water and will be the second-largest dam in Matabeleland North after Lake Gwayi-Shangani.

title: Maputo Urban Transformation Project, Mozambique
body:
The Maputo Urban Transformation Project for Mozambique is made up of five components as follows:

 1) The first component, Informal Settlement Upgrade, aims to support the CMM to implement the Integrated Informal Settlements Upgrading Program in the most vulnerable neighborhoods of Maputo City, and has the following sub-components: 

(i) Tactical Urbanism for Coronavirus (COVID-19) Response

(ii) Integrated Infrastructure Upgrading in Informal Settlements

 (iii) Socioeconomic Inclusion Program; 

(iv) Land Regularization Performance Based Condition. 

2) The second component, Maputo City Center Rehabilitation, aims to support the (Maputo Municipal Council (CMM) to revitalize the city center by improving the stormwater drainage system in the city center to reduce flooding in the lower areas, has the following sub-components: 

(i) Drainage Rehabilitation in the City Center; 

(ii) Promoting Socioeconomic Inclusion in the City Center

(iii) Property Tax Reform Performance-Based Condition. 

3) The third component, Sustainable Urban Growth, aims to support the CMM to promote a more sustainable urban development of Maputo City, and has the following sub-components:

(i) Guided Urban Land Development in KaTembe Municipal District

(ii) Solid Waste Infrastructure Improvement

(iii) Solid Waste Management Performance-based Condition. 

4) The fourth component, Project Implementation and Institutional Support, aims to support the CMM to manage project implementation in accordance with World Bank policies. 

5) The fifth component, Contingent Emergency Response, aims to facilitate access to rapid financing through the reallocation of uncommitted project funds in the event of an eligible crisis or emergency.

Source: World Bank - Project ID P171449

title: Laayoune Phosphate Port, Morocco
body:
Project Description

The Laayoune Phosphate Port project involves the construction of a dedicated port facility to support the export of phosphate from the nearby Bou Craa mining site. Designed to improve logistics and increase export efficiency, the port will serve as a key maritime outlet for Morocco’s strategic phosphate industry.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a 3.2 km access trestle bridge linking the shore to the offshore loading infrastructure
  • Installation of a 1 km breakwater made of caissons equipped with rails and buffers for docking and loading operations
  • Deployment of a floating pontoon for flexible vessel mooring and phosphate transfer
  • Development of a seawater intake structure, featuring 1.7 km of 2,300 mm solid HDPE pipes for cooling and processing requirements, connected to an electrochlorination (EC) unit for water treatment

title: Rabat–Salé Airport Expansion, Morocco
body:
Project Description

Rabat–Salé Airport Expansion project entails the construction of a new terminal building and associated airside and landside infrastructure to significantly increase airport capacity, improve passenger experience, and align with modern international standards. The new terminal will span approximately 69,000 m² over four levels and is designed to enhance processing efficiency and service quality.

Scope of Work

Terminal Building (Total Area: ~69,000 m²)

  • Basement (16,300 m²):
    • Installation of automatic baggage handling systems
    • Technical installations and support infrastructure
  • Ground Floor (31,800 m²):
    • Public hall including model aircraft exhibition space
    • Check-in area with new counter layout
    • Security filtering inspection (PIF) zone
    • Departure hall for remote boarding gates
    • Baggage claim area
    • Passport control facilities for arriving passengers
    • Customs clearance zones with red and green circuits
  • Level 1 (2,500 m²):
    • Passenger disembarkation area served by 6 telescopic gangways
    • Moving walkways to enhance passenger flow
  • Level 2 (18,400 m²):
    • Departure hall for contact boarding gates
    • Commercial gallery with walk-through retail concept
    • Food court and various passenger service areas

Infrastructure Works

  • Airside:
    • Expansion of aircraft parking area with 6 additional aircraft stands
    • Construction of connecting taxiways and ramps
  • Landside:
    • Construction of multi-level vehicle parking facility with 1,300 vehicle capacity

title: Agadir Al Massira Airport Expansion, Morocco
body:
Project Description

Agadir Al Massira Airport Expansion project aims to increase the airport’s annual passenger handling capacity from 2 million to 7 million passengers through terminal expansion, modernization of existing infrastructure, and enlargement of airside and landside facilities. The project supports Morocco’s growing tourism sector and aligns with long-term strategic development goals for regional connectivity and international access.

Scope of Work

  • Terminal Works:
    • Construction of a 45,000 m² extension to the current passenger terminal
    • Redevelopment of the existing 25,000 m² terminal, upgrading its layout, services, and capacity
  • Airside Infrastructure:
    • Expansion of aircraft parking area by an additional 47,000 m², reaching a total of 22 aircraft stands
    • Development of a new connecting ramp to optimize aircraft circulation and parking
    • Design and sizing to meet operational demand through 2040
  • Landside Development:
    • Doubling of the airport car park capacity, increasing from 1,200 to 2,400 vehicle spaces

title: Tangier Ibn Battouta Airport Expansion, Morocco
body:
Project Description

The project involves the comprehensive expansion of Ibn Battouta Airport in Tangier to significantly increase its passenger handling capacity from 1.2 million to 4.4 million passengers per year. The development aims to modernize and scale the airport infrastructure to support growing air traffic demand and position Tangier as a regional air transport hub.

Scope of Work

  • Runway Expansion
    • Extension of the runway to 3,500 meters
    • Widening of the runway to 45 meters
  • New Passenger Terminal
    • Construction of a new terminal covering 55,000 square meters
  • Air Traffic Control
    • Installation of a new air traffic control tower
  • Parking & Access Infrastructure
    • Construction of a parking area with capacity for 1,400 vehicles
    • Development of a new access road to the airport
  • Airside Infrastructure
    • Connection of taxiways over an area of 160,000 square meters
    • Construction of aircraft parking aprons
    • Extension of the airport security fence to span 6 kilometers

title: Sania Ramel Airport Expansion, Morocco
body:
Project Description

Sania Ramel Airport Expansion project in Tétouan, a city in the Tanger-Tetouan-Al Hoceima region in Morocco, aims to triple the airport’s annual passenger handling capacity - from 100,000 to 300,000 passengers - by constructing a new passenger terminal and enhancing supporting infrastructure. 

The project is part of Morocco’s broader aviation strategy to improve regional air connectivity and support tourism and economic growth in the northern region.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a new 5,000 m² passenger terminal, designed to meet modern international standards for comfort and efficiency. 
  • Upgrade and expansion of associated airport facilities and services (e.g., baggage handling, customs, passenger processing systems).

title: Aga Khan University Hospital, Uganda
body:
The Aga Khan University Hospital Project in Kampala, Uganda, is a transformative healthcare and education initiative under the Aga Khan Development Network.

The facility will serve as a tertiary referral and teaching hospital. It is being developed in two phases:

  • Phase 1 : 150-bed hospital, outpatient specialty center, academic facilities, and student housing.
  • Phase 2 : Expansion to 600 beds

title: Mbarara Water Supply Project, Uganda
body:
The Mbarara Water Supply Project is a comprehensive initiative aimed at improving water and sanitation infrastructure in Mbarara City, Uganda, and surrounding areas.

Scope of Work
Water Treatment Facilities:

  • Rehabilitation of existing plants:
  • Kabale Road Water Treatment Plant (5,000 m³/day capacity).
  • Ruharo Water Treatment Plant upgraded from 8,000 m³/day to 12,000 m³/day.
  • Construction of a new water treatment plant at Kagera River with a capacity of 30,000 m³/day.

Water Distribution Network:

  • Expansion of transmission mains (13 km) and distribution mains (27 km).
  • Installation of SCADA systems for efficient operation.

Sanitation Infrastructure:

  • Rehabilitation of sewer networks (8–10 km) in three catchments: Katete, Kakoba, and Kizungu.
  • Construction of a faecal sludge treatment center with a capacity of 50 m³/day.
  • Upgrades to waste stabilization ponds in key catchments.

Environmental and Social Impact Mitigation:

  • Conducting Environmental and Social Impact Assessments (ESIA) and Resettlement Action Plans (RAP)

title: Chimuara-Nacala Power Transmission Line Phases 2 and 3, Mozambique
body:
• Build a 400 kV transmission line from Alto Molócuè to Namialo (272 km), a 220 kV transmission line from Namialo to Nampula (98 km) and a 220 kV transmission line from Namialo to Nacala-à-Velha (90 km)
  • Build two new substations at Namialo and Nacala-à-Velha
  • Expand the Nampula substation

 

The scheme aims to strengthen and increase the reliability of the transmission infrastructure connecting the central and northern regions of the country, linking Chimuara in the central Sofala province and Nacala in the northern Nampula province

The project is intended to improve the quality of power supply in the central and northern regions of Mozambique, especially the provinces of Zambezia and Nampula, which have the lowest electricity access rates in the country, at 25% and 18% respectively

It will also enable industrial growth in the central and northern provinces, particularly in the Nacala Special Economic Zone

body:
The project entails the construction of two hydroelectric power plants in southern Burundi, aimed at increasing the country’s electricity generation capacity and improving energy access and reliability.

Power Plants

title: Entebbe ICT Park, Uganda
body:
The Entebbe ICT Park in Uganda, is a 17-acre Information Technology / Business Process Outsourcing park situated in Lunyo, near the Kampala-Entebbe highway, covering a total area of 87,805 square meters

The park includes multiple facilities such as:

  • IT innovation and incubation center
  • Offices for the Ministry of ICT and NITA-U
  • An exhibition and events center
  • A convention center
  • Training labs
  • An integrated office complex for IT companies
  • Banks, restaurants, lounges, and shopping centers
  • Indoor and outdoor games areas, a health club, and a lush green garden
  • Utilities and parking space for approximately 162 cars

title: Menengai Geothermal Project, Kenya
body:
Development of the Menengai Geothermal Project, estimated to harbor a potential of 1,600MW, was started in 2009. Surface studies have been completed and exploration and appraisal wells done.

The project will be developed in five (5) phases with the long-term goal of developing 465MW of geothermal steam equivalent. A total of 53 wells with a potential of 169MW have been drilled by 2023. 

Phase I (105MW)

Menengai Phase I (105MW) has undertaken a steam sales business model where GDC supplies steam to the power plants for conversion to electricity. Commissioning of the power plants is ongoing.

For the first phase of 105MW at the Menengai Geothermal Project, GDC has awarded three contracts to Independent Power Producers (IPP’s) to finance, procure, construct and operate three power plants, on a Build-Own-Operate (BOO) basis. The IPPs awarded the contracts so far include:

  • QPEA GT Menengai Limited
  • Sosian Menengai Geothermal Power Limited
  • Orpower Twenty Two Limited

One of the IPP’s namely Sosian Menengai Geothermal Power Limited (SMGPL) commenced construction of their power plant in 2021, to date construction is complete, testing and commissioning is ongoing for the 35MW plant.

Phase II (60MW)

The Menengai Phase II project is located at the eastern sector of the Menengai Caldera. It is expected to generate 60MW steam equivalent. The geo-scientific studies and exploratory wells have been drilled in this sector.

Menengai Phase III, IV and V

The Menengai Phases III, IV and V are located to the greater Northern West of the Menengai Caldera. Preliminary geoscientific studies undertaken in the Menengai North West indicated a robust geothermal resource with associated surface manifestations and young volcanic activity.

title: Suswa Geothermal Prospect, Kenya
body:
The Suswa Geothermal Prospect has an estimated potential of 750MW which will be developed in phases. The first three phase will develop a total of 300MW, with each phase developing 100MW.

Detailed surface studies were completed in early 2013. National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) issued the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) License to GDC. A community engagement framework has been established.

Source: Geothermal Development Company

title: Baringo-Silali Project, Kenya
body:
The Baringo-Silali Project is a Government of Kenya and KfW sponsored geothermal development project covering three prospect areas namely Paka, Korosi and Silali.

The Government of Kenya (GoK) is funding the construction of access roads and well pads while KfW, through a Euros 80 Million loan, is funding the water supply system, drilling of 15-20 geothermal wells, as well as undertaking project related consultancies.

Surface Studies

The surface studies of this project started in 2010. The main geothermal manifestations in the area include fumaroles and altered landscapes. The Baringo-Silali Geothermal Project has an estimated geothermal potential of 3,000MW. GDC plans to develop 300MW in the first phase of the project as follows:

  • Paka – 100MW
  • Korosi- 100MW
  • Silali- 100MW

GDC has obtained an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) License from the National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA), paving way for the commencement of exploration drilling, with the development of the first 20 wells presently underway.

Current Status

GDC is currently undertaking geothermal exploration and appraisal drilling at the Paka and Korosi Prospects in the Baringo-Silali Geothermal Project. So far, eleven (11) exploration and appraisal wells in Paka field have been drilled successfully, and drilling of the twelfth (12) and thirteen (13) wells is underway. Three (3) exploration wells have been drilled successfully in Korosi prospect. Four (4) wells have been successfully tested following the completion of the heating monitoring period of the well, while the rest of the wells are heating up.

Source: Geothermal Development Company

title: Minkouma Hydropower Plant, Cameroon
body:
Design, finance, build, operate and transfer a 300 MW hybrid hydropower and solar plant located on the Sanaga River at the Minkouma village

Work includes building a 240-300 MW hydro plant along with a 50 MW solar facility (expandable to 300 MW) and a 225/90/30kV substation

The Minkouma hydro plant is designed to enhance the interconnection between Cameroon's North Interconnected Network (RIN) and South Interconnected Network (RIS). It is expected to boost the electricity coverage of the northern zone of the country as well as to improve the under-construction Cameroon-Chad power interconnection, thus paving the way for the country's complete interconnection

At the local level, Minkouma will help meet the increasing energy demand in the Haute Sanaga division

The developer Cam-Hydro and its partners are planning to use the Early Contractor Involvement (ECI) methodology, an innovative approach that allows for better steering and control of the project throughout all its phases

title: Chimuara-Nacala Transmission Line Phase 1, Mozambique
body:
• Construct 367 km of 400 kV transmission line extending from Chimuara to Alto-Molocue
  • Build a new 400/220/33 kV substation at Chimuara 
  • Upgrade the existing Alto Molocue substation to 400/220/33 kV 
  • Each substation will cover an approximate area of 60,000 square metres

The substation works have been completed. They were undertaken by Spain's Elecnor and included:

CHIMUARA
- 13 bays (6 line bays, 2 reactor bays, 2 transformer bays, 2 coupling bays and 1 STATCOM bay) and space for expansion in the future with 3 further line bays
- Two 250 MVA disassociated phase armoured power autotransformers
- Two 60 MVAr reactors and one ±100 MVAr
STATCOM
- Replacement of the protection, control and telecommunications systems of the existing substation and integration of the SCADA system with that of the new substation
ALTO MOLOCUE
- 12 bays (5 line bays, 3 reactor bays, 2 transformer bays and 2 coupling bays) and space for 3 more line bays in the future
- Two 250 MVA disassociated phase armoured power autotransformers
- Three 60 MVAr reactors and one ±100 MVAr
STATCOM
- Integration of the SCADA system of the existing substation into the new command room

 

The Chimuara-Nacala project is intended to improve the quality of power supply in the central and northern regions of Mozambique, especially the provinces of Zambezia and Nampula, which have the lowest electricity access rates in the country, at 25% and 18% respectively

It will also enable industrial growth in the central and northern provinces, particularly in the Nacala Special Economic Zone

title: Galala City, Egypt
body:
The new City of Galala is located on the highest mount plateau in the Red Sea area between Ain Sokhna and Zafarana. The plateau sits over 650 meters above sea level at its highest elevation.

The new city is one of the government’s national efforts to develop the vast and empty eastern desert to solve Cairo’s population congestion and create work and living opportunities for the youth in addition to generating investment opportunities. City of Galala is located on 17000 acres on top of the highest mount plateau in the area across the Gulf of Suez. The new city centers on a balanced approach towards development and preservation of the surrounding pristine environment.

The master plan and detailed master planning focus on developing a sustainable, dynamic, mixed use area based on a framework of land use, public land transportation, new road systems, and public spaces that integrate the existing ecological conditions.

The first phase released, out of three, covers an area of 2050 acres consisting of various activities. It includes residential areas with the most desired moderately priced units, commercial, touristic villages, cultural, medical, educational, and religious. All these entities are directly connected to the project’s public arena where you find the convention center and the city’s major mosque, positioned at the project’s highest point. Sites International is responsible for the entire internal infrastructure. It includes sewage and irrigation treatment plants, location identification for the enormous water tanks, and solar lighting preparations for use in public spaces.

Source: SITES International
meta_description: The new City of Galala is located on the highest mount plateau in the Red Sea area between Ain Sokhna and Zafarana. The plateau sits over 650 meters above sea level at its highest elevation.
migration_status: success

title: Lagos-Calabar Railway, Nigeria
body:
Lagos–Calabar Coastal Railway is a 1,400-kilometre standard gauge railway line designed to connect Nigeria’s major coastal cities and ports. The railway is planned to operate at a design speed of 120 km/h and will include 22 stations along its route. Once complete, the line will enhance freight and passenger connectivity between key urban and economic centres along the coast.

The coastal corridor will link all of Nigeria's seaports, facilitating more efficient transportation of goods and promoting regional trade and development. The project is being implemented in phases, with the first section set to connect Port Harcourt to Calabar, running through Uyo and Aba.

title: Mambilla Hydropower Project, Nigeria
body:
Build a 3,050 MW hydropower plant on the Dongo River near Baruf, in Kakara Village of Taraba State. When completed, the plant is expected to produce approximately 5.457 billion kWh of electricity a year

The objective of the Mambilla hydro project is to take advantage of the significant rainfalls that characterise the Mambilla Hills, with a yearly average above 1,900 mm, cumulated with the southern margin of the Mambilla plateau that lies 1,000m above the surrounding areas and gradients above 20 %

To make use of these natural resources of the highlands for power generation, the Mambilla project was conceived, with the headrace scheme located above the Mambilla highlands to capture, store and convey flow from the Donga River to supply a power plant complex located at the toe of the plateau

The designed backbone power scheme comprises a headrace scheme from three successive dam reservoirs linked by two transfer tunnels to convey the flow; the last reservoir will cross the Nguh River and be located at the top of the margin plateau. The turbines will be set in an underground power complex built at the toe of the Mambilla highlands escarpment, and will be fed from the Nguh reservoir by twin pressure waterways and tunnels/shafts. The generated power is to be evacuated from the power plant to the national grid through several 330 kV transmission lines

Main works

  • The facility will comprise 3 dams and an underground powerhouse 
  • The dams to be constructed include Nya (formerly known as Gembu), Sumsum and Nghu 
  • Nya and Sumsum will be 100m and 35m-tall roller compacted concrete (RCC) dams with crest lengths of 515m and 460m respectively; Nghu will be a 95m-high rockfill dam with a crest length of 650m
  • Nya and Sumsum dams will be connected through a 16 km-long, 6m-diameter tunnels, whereas Sumsum and Nghu dams will be connected by a 1.5 km-long and 10m-wide canal
  • The headrace canal for the plant will be 3.1 km-long and 15m-wide
  • Two 6 km-long tailrace tunnels for the plant will be of 8m diameter each, while the tailrace canal will be 3 km-long and 25m-wide

 

The project objectives include:

• Increasing Nigeria’s electricity generation by 30% and the country’s baseload electricity generation capacity;
• Increasing power exports to Niger, Togo, Benin and Chad

title: Owaza Refinery, Nigeria
body:
HSI Energies Limited and its subsidiary, HSI Refining and Petrochemical Company Limited (HSI R&P), are leading the establishment of a state-of-the-art 5,000 bpd modular refinery on a 12.5 hectare waterfront asset within the Abia Industrial and Innovation Park (AIIP) in Owaza, Abia State, Nigeria. This facility will meet the growing demand for refined petroleum products in the South-East geographical region of Nigeria.

Given the recurrent export challenges of crude theft and vandalization of crude evacuation infrastructure, particularly on this axis, the refinery project aligns with HSI’s strategic goal of crude production security. It will attract increasing investments in upstream assets in this region. This will increase oil and gas production, enhance refined petroleum product quality, and ultimately expand the market reach to the South-South geographical region.

The refinery will be developed in two phases.

HSI was incorporated in 2019 and is currently developing the first phase of its modular refinery located in Owaza, Abia State. In this first phase, the refinery will operate at a capacity of 5,000 bpd, obtaining feedstock from neighbouring producing fields. Featuring a crude distillation unit and ancillary equipment, the product slate will comprise diesel (gas oil), kerosene, heavy fuel oil, and naphtha.

The first phase of the refinery is at an advanced stage of project development. HSI R&P has executed feedstock and product offtake agreements and completed a project market feasibility study and front-end engineering design (FEED). The refinery is scheduled to be commissioned in the third quarter of 2026.

The second phase of the refinery will be the expansion to 10,000 bpd capacity.

HSI has partnered with VFuels LLC, a renowned international EPCIC contractor with a successful track record of building and developing modular refineries in Africa.

Source: HSI Energies

title: Eghudu Refinery, Nigeria
body:
Eghudu refinery is a proposed modern greenfield full conversion refinery and petrochemical complex in Ovia Northeast local government of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. The project will increase the refining capacity of crude oil and other refined products in Nigeria. 

The project will be located in Eghudu, Ovia North-East Local Government. Project site of 6.6 sq km (4 sq miles). 

The project will constitute the design, engineering, procurement, fabrication, construction, commissioning, operation, and maintenance of a 100,000 BPD Euro Spec 7 full conversion refinery and petrochemical complex.

Planned Production

The planned production capacity of Eghudu Refinery include the installation of a 100,000 PBD Greenfield Refinery and the construction of 2 million barrels of Crude Storage Tanks.

Refined Storage

The project plan for Eghudu Refinery also includes the construction of 2 million barrels of Refined Products Storage Tanks.

Refinery products:

  • High Grade Gasoline
  • Jet Fuel/Kerosene
  • Diesel
  • Fuel Oil
  • Unsaturate (NGLs)
  • Aromatics
  • Fuel Grade Coke
  • Sulphur

Petrochemical Plant Products:

  • Polyethylene (Plastics)
  • Ammonia (Fertilizer)
  • Poly-Urethane
  • Isopropyl Alcohol
  • Methanol
  • Ethanol

Source: Eghudu Refinery

title: Ajaokuta-Kaduna-Kano (AKK) Gas Pipeline, Nigeria
body:
Project Overview

Ajaokuta-Kaduna-Kano (AKK) gas pipeline is a 614 km-long natural gas pipeline under development in Nigeria. It aims to transport gas from the southern region (Ajaokuta) through central Nigeria to the northern region (Kaduna and Kano). 

The project forms Phase 1 of the 1,300 km Trans-Nigeria Gas Pipeline (TNGP).

Purpose and Objectives

  • Facilitate domestic gas utilization for power generation and industrial use
  • Boost economic development by improving energy access in central and northern Nigeria
  • Support Nigeria’s Gas Master Plan, designed to leverage abundant natural gas resources for national growth

Key Features

  • Pipeline Length: 614 km
  • Pipeline capacity: 2.2 billion standard cubic feet
  • Route: Ajaokuta – Abuja – Kaduna – Kano
  • Part of a larger 1,300 km TNGP

title: ESSA Fertilizer Project, Tanzania
body:
​ESSA Group, an Indonesian conglomerate, has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Tanzanian government agencies to develop a urea fertilizer plant in Mtwara, Tanzania. The project is valued at approximately $1.3 billion (3.5 trillion Tanzanian shillings) and aims to enhance local fertilizer production, thereby reducing Tanzania's reliance on imports. ​

Project Details

Production Capacity: The facility is designed to produce one million tonnes of urea fertilizer annually. ​

Timeline: Construction is scheduled to commence in 2024, with completion targeted for 2027. Production is expected to begin in 2029. ​

Natural Gas Supply: The Tanzania Petroleum Development Corporation (TPDC) will supply natural gas to the plant, utilizing the country's substantial reserves of 54.57 trillion standard cubic feet. The plant's initial requirement is projected at 70 million cubic feet per year. ​

Market Distribution: Upon becoming operational, 60% of the fertilizer produced will cater to domestic demand, while the remaining 40% is intended for export to neighboring countries. ​

title: Seaton Estate, South Africa
body:
Seaton Estate is 215 hectares in size. There are 1,480 opportunities in total made up of 595 single residential stands and 28 Planned Urban Development (PUD) opportunities comprising 885 units.

Seaton Beach is situated between the coastal cove of Sheffield (Christmas Bay) and the Umhlali river estuary, stretching across 1.1 km.

Features:

  • Country Club: Clubhouse, cricket field, cricket net, tennis courts, squash court, 5-a-side soccer pitch, half basketball court, gym, lap pool, leisure and kids pool, playgrounds and adventure zone.
  • Walking trails, bridle paths and mountain bike tracks.
  • Beach Clubhouse.
  • Whale watching lookout points.
  • Multiple picnic areas and resting spots.
  • Nature conservation areas
  • Equestrian facilities: Clubhouse, fibre track arena, lunge rings, stabling, paddocks.

Source: Collins Residential

title: Guinea Water and Sanitation Project, Guinea
body:
Guinea Water and Sanitation Project aims to address critical water and sanitation challenges in Greater Conakry. Below are the key features of the project:

Increasing and Improving Water Services in Greater Conakry

  • Construction of a new water treatment plant, Yessoulou IV, to reduce the water production deficit.
  • Development of water storage and distribution infrastructure, including:
    • Two reservoirs (500 m³ in Kouria and 7,500 m³ in Kagbelen).
    • 117.5 km of distribution networks.
    • 9,370 household connections and 24 standpipes.
  • Pilot introduction of prepaid water meters and measures to reduce non-revenue water (e.g., leak detection and pipe renewal).

Support for Institutional and Policy Reforms

  • Strengthening the national water utility (SEG) through digitalization, improved asset management, and tariff reforms.
  • Establishment of a new sanitation company with technical support for governance improvements.
  • Professionalization of fecal sludge service providers through training, licensing, and grants.
  • Construction or rehabilitation of sanitation facilities in schools to improve hygiene.

Enhancing Water Resources Management

  • Implementation of nature-based solutions in the Samou sub-basin to improve raw water quality for treatment.
  • Soil stabilization, reforestation, and erosion control measures upstream of the Baneah dam.
  • Integration of parts of the Samou sub-basin into Gangan National Park for sustainable resource management.

Capacity Strengthening and Project Implementation Support

  • Establishment of a Project Coordination Unit (PCU) under the Ministry of Energy, Water, and Hydrocarbons to oversee implementation.
  • Support for monitoring activities and guidance through a Steering Committee

Source: World Bank. Reference: Project ID P179017

title: Western Forelands Copper Exploration, DRC
body:
Ivanhoe’s DRC exploration group is targeting Kamoa-Kakula-style copper mineralisation through a regional exploration and drilling program on its Western Forelands exploration licences

The licences cover an area over 5 times larger than the adjacent Kamoa-Kakula Copper Complex

Ivanhoe Mines is exploring for new sedimentary copper discoveries, as well as expanding and further defining its high-grade Makoko, Kiala, and Kitoko copper discoveries.

 

Makoko

Makoko, first discovered in 2018, is situated approximately 20 km west of the Kakula deposit, along strike on the roughly E-W trending Monwezi regional structure controlling high-grade copper mineralisation at Kakula.

The Makoko Mineral Resource has been defined by drilling covering a total area of 15.9 square km within the much larger Makoko exploration area. The total areal extent of Indicated Resource is 1.1 square km (with 16 million tonnes of copper indicated) at a 1.0% cut-off and 14.8 square km for the Inferred Resource (with 243 million tonnes of copper indicated) at a 1.0% cut-off. The average dip of the mineralised zone in the Mineral Resource area is 14 degrees.

The Mineral Resource estimate is based on the results from approximately 50,000 metres of drilling in 148 holes. An additional 20 holes totalling more than 2,800 metres have been completed since the closure of the database for resource estimation purposes.

The Western Forelands’ 2024 drilling program was Ivanhoe’s largest to date, with over 80,000 metres of diamond drilling completed. Drilling was predominantly focused on a potential western extension along strike of the Makoko deposit, up to the licence area boundary. Drilling was also aimed at expanding the strike of the adjacent Kitoko discovery.

Drilling confirmed the continuation of mineralisation stepping further west from the Makoko area, opening up a new area called “Makoko West”, which revealed shallow, and high-grade copper mineralisation. As a result, the strike length of the Makoko mineralised district has now increased by 20%, to over 13 km. The total strike length is comparable to that of the Kakula orebody, the main source of copper ore for the Kamoa-Kakula Copper Complex’s Phase 1 and 2 concentrators. The western edge of Kakula’s orebody is approximately 10 km from the eastern edge of the Makoko deposit.

 

Kiala

Kiala, discovered in 2020, adjoins the northern boundary of the Kamoa-Kakula mining licence and is a northern extension of mineralisation from this licence along a north-trending controlling growth structure, where a sulphur-rich siltstone layer is brought progressively closer to, and eventually overlain on the aquifer. This onlapping relationship brings two key mineralising controls in contact with one another, resulting in a zone of high-grade mineralisation parallel to the growth fault.

The Kiala Mineral Resource has been defined by drilling covering an area of 0.9 square km, with 8 million tonnes of copper indicated. The average dip of the mineralised zone within the Indicated Resource is 9 degrees.

The Mineral Resource estimate is based on the results from approximately 13,000 metres of drilling in 35 holes. An additional four holes totalling more than 1,650 metres have been completed since the closure of the database for resource estimation purposes.

title: Northwestern Province Exploration Project, Zambia
body:
• Ivanhoe Mines has been granted by the government of Zambia a 7,757-square-km package of new exploration licences in the Northwestern Province of Zambia
  • Ivanhoe’s thesis behind the strategically selected licence package is to explore for an extension of the Central African Copperbelt
  • The new licence package is located between Ivanhoe’s Western Forelands Exploration Project (230 km to the northeast) and the company’s Angolan exploration licence package (130 km southwest). The Zambia licences cover an area over three times larger than the Western Forelands Exploration Project
  • Ivanhoe’s geological team will commence exploration activities for new copper mineralisation associated with Basement Domes, Katangan-age sediment-hosted copper systems and iron-oxide-copper-gold (IOCG) systems
  • The central portion of the newly approved Zambian licence package is highly prospective for copper mineralisation hosted in Paleo-Proterozoic basement inliers buried below a blanket of Kalahari sands, containing sheared amphibolite-facies schists, granitic gneiss and migmatite similar to Barrick’s Lumwana mine to the northeast, on the Mwombezhi Dome
  • Ivanhoe will appoint environmental consultants in the second quarter of 2025 to complete key environmental baseline studies and produce an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) for approval by the Zambia Environmental Management Agency (ZEMA)
  • Initial engagements with local communities will also be undertaken prior to the mobilisation of field teams for ground surveys and drilling in the second half of the year
  • A detailed review of historical and newly acquired airborne geophysical data will be carried out concurrently with the completion of the EMP
  • Ivanhoe will conduct an extensive programme of aircore and auger drilling to collect soil geochemical data and additional airborne and ground-based geophysical surveys. This work will enable Ivanhoe’s geological team to map the giant licence area in detail to better understand the extent of the Basement Domes, Katangan sediments, and felsic magmatic intrusives that underlie the licence area. Once this work has been completed target generation for future diamond drilling will commence

title: Kabaale Oil Refinery, Uganda
body:
Build a Residue Fluid Catalytic Cracker (RFCC) refinery at Kabaale in Hoima District that can produce 60,000 barrels a day

The refinery is planned to produce Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), diesel, petrol, kerosene, jet fuel and Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO)

The refinery will receive feedstock from the Kingfisher field, located in the southeast of Lake Albert, which is being developed by TotalEnergies E&P Uganda and China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) Uganda Limited, along with Uganda National Oil Company (UNOC)

Enabling infrastructure includes: 

  • A 212 km multi-product pipeline that will evacuate refined products from the refinery to a storage terminal at Namwabula, Mpigi District
  • The Mbegu Water Intake and its corresponding water pipeline
  • The storage terminal itself for the refinery products, located at Namwabula in Mpigi District

 

Uganda National Oil Company (UNOC) will have a 40% stake in the project, while UAE-based Alpha MBM Investments will own 60%

The refinery project is planned to have a debt-to-equity ratio of 60: 40 respectively, implying that 60% funding to the oil refinery will be a debt whereas 40% will be equity

The refinery will be situated within the Kabaale Industrial Park (KIP). KIP is located on 29 square km of land and its masterplan features an international airport, refinery, crude oil and products storage, transmission hub, logistics warehousing, offices, petrochemical industries and associated facilities among others

title: De Aar Solar PV Farm, South Africa
body:
• Develop a 1 GW solar photovoltaic (PV) farm in phases in De Aar
  • The farm will be connected to state utility Eskom's 400 kV transmission network
  • The project was originally conceptualised by Soventix, which in July 2022 sold the rights to Phase 1 of the cluster development (consisting of 342 MW) to SolarAfrica, which will finalise the plant to wheel power to multiple offtakers
  • The 342 MW Phase 1 is known as the SunCentral solar farm and will see the installation of more than 500,000 solar panels
     
  • Soventix is co-developing Phases 2 and 3 of the projects
  • Phase 2 is set to comprise a 300 MW facility located across approximately 400 hectares; there is to be three interconnected 100 MW plants (125 ha each), with associated infrastructure. The PV system will be connected via overhead transmission lines to the authorised Main Transmission Substation (MTS) on Sun Central Cluster 1 (Phase 1)
  • Phase 3 will feature a 400 MW plant across about 650 ha. This area includes four interconnected 100 MW solar PV plants (over 125 ha each), with associated infrastructure. The PV system will be connected via transmission lines to the authorised substation on Phase 1

title: Xin Feng Integrated Industrial Complex, Egypt
body:
• Develop the Xin Feng Integrated Industrial Complex within the Ain Sokhna Integrated Zone of the Suez Canal Economic Zone
  • The aim is to establish 9 industrial projects and two centres for comprehensive services – one for research and development, and the other for solid waste recycling
  • These projects are scheduled to be implemented in two phases within 5 years on an area of up to 3.75 million square metres, with a total investment of US$1.65 billion
  • The project is expected to generate about 8,000 direct employment opportunities

 

The first phase is planned to see the establishment of 4 factories: 

  • Automotive Components Project with an annual production of 230,000 tonnes
  • Home Appliances Metal Components Project with a yearly production of 50,000 tonnes
  • Standard Stabiliser (screws-sawmills) Project with an annual output of 100,000 tonnes
  • Hot rolled coil with an annual production of 2 million tonnes

The total area of this stage is 1 million square metres

The first three projects are expected to begin operations in the beginning of 2027

 

The second phase includes five factories in addition to two centres – the R&D Comprehensive Service Centre and the Solid Waste Maintenance and Recycling Centre

The factories are: 

  • Machine spare parts project with annual production of 200,000 tonnes 
  • Brake pads project with annual production of 150,000 tonnes
  • Steel structure project with annual production of 100,000 tonnes
  • Aluminum alloy magnesium car spare parts project  with annual production of 20,000 tonnes
  • Cold dispersed steel project with an annual production of 2 million tonnes

The phase will occupy a total area of 1.75 million square metres

The first four factories are to commence operations in January 2029 and the demo run of the cold cast steel project in March 2030

title: International Specialized Hospital, Uganda
body:
The International Specialized Hospital of Uganda (ISHU) is in Lubowa, Wakiso District, Uganda.

The hospital includes 264 beds and the complex consists of nine buildings, including the main hospital, homes for medical staff, a training school, a congress center, hotels, and commercial areas.

The site features a helipad, sports fields, parking areas, internal roads, guardhouses, gates, a boundary wall, and utility plants

The hospital is intended to offer specialized treatments, including organ transplants, cancer care, and cardiac surgeries.
