title: Sahofika Hydropower Plant, Madagascar
body:
• Build a 200 MW gross/192MW net hydropower plant on the  Onive River in Madagascar, 100 km southeast of Antananarivo
  • The project is expected to produce circa 1,570 GWh a year
  • The plant guarantees a baseload capacity of 192 MW (at 95%), including during the dry season
  • The civil works are designed to cater for an expansion to circa. 300 MW at least cost
  • The plant is being developed under a Build Own Operate Transfer (BOOT) scheme which involves the design,  financing, construction, operation and management of the hydro plant under a 35-year Concession Agreement (CA) and Power Purchase Agreement (PPA)
  • The project will generate enough energy to provide electricity to at least 2 million people and to displace up to 95% of the thermal capacity currently used to feed the Antananarivo network (RIA)

 

According to the technical studies, the development will consist of the following permanent structures:

  • Reservoir structure comprising a roller-compacted concrete dam and a dike forming a reservoir with a useful volume of 120 million cubic meters
  • Underground structures of water pipe including a low pressure gallery, a well of equilibrium and a gallery high pressure on a length of 4 km and a difference in height of 700 m
  • A plant equipped with 7 Pelton groups at 32 MW
  • A post and an evacuation line on the Antananarivo interconnected network
  • An access road

title: Gulu City Specialized Referral Hospital, Uganda
body:
The Gulu City Specialized Referral Hospital project is planned to be built on 10 acres of land within a 5 km radius of Gulu City center. The identified site is in the Bardege-Laroo Division.

The hospital will have a 324-bed capacity, providing specialized clinical services, including radiotherapy, chemotherapy, radiology, surgical services, laboratory and pathology services, outpatient care, and functional diagnostics.

Once completed, the hospital will serve not only northern Uganda but also neighboring countries such as South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Cadenza Residence, Uganda
body:
Cadenza Residence is a luxury residential development located in the Nakasero neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. It has the following key features:

  • 80 meters tall with 24 floors and 3 levels of basement parking
  • 306 condominiums, including studios, one-bedroom, and two-bedroom apartments. Two five-bedroom duplex penthouses on the top floors.
  • High-speed lifts, video intercoms, and full backup generators.
  • Heated swimming pool.
  • Fully equipped gym and steam/sauna rooms for men and women.
  • Kids' play area, games room, jogging track, and BBQ spaces.
  • Business center with workstations and meeting rooms.
  • Landscaped gardens and an aroma garden for relaxation.

title: Baleine Field, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
Baleine is the largest hydrocarbon discovery made by an energy company in Côte d'Ivoire. Thanks to this discovery, Côte d'Ivoire is also strengthening its role as a regional energy hub for neighbouring countries. Baleine’s gas production is therefore strategic since it will increase domestic and regional supply, while oil production will be instrumental in boosting exports.

In 2021, Eni discovered an extensive oil and associated gas field 70 km off the coast of Abidjan at a depth of 1,200 metres. It was the first commercial discovery in the country in the past 20 years. Baleine, a French word translated as “balena” in Italian and “whale” in English, is being developed in record time. 

Highlights

  • ~22,000 bpd equity production of oil equivalent
  • 2.5 billion barrels potential of oil in place
  • 100 billion/m³ associated gas since start-up
  • 155 k hectares for forest conservation, restoration and management projects

Source: ENI

Baleine Field Development Project is a phased offshore oil and gas production initiative utilizing a Floating Production Storage and Offloading (FPSO) unit.

Phased Development Plan

Phase 1:

  • Production via a refurbished and upgraded Baleine FPSO
  • Capacity: 15,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil
  • Gas processing: 25 million standard cubic feet per day (Mscf/d)

Phase 2:

  • Expansion to 50,000 bpd of oil
  • Gas processing increase to 70 Mscf/d

Phase 3:

  • Full-scale production reaching 150,000 bpd of oil
  • Gas processing capacity reaching 200 Mscf/d
meta_description: Baleine is the largest hydrocarbon discovery made by an energy company in Côte d'Ivoire. Thanks to this discovery
migration_status: Côte d'Ivoire is also strengthening its role as a regional energy hub for neighbouring countries. Baleine’s gas production is therefore strategic since it will increase domestic and regional supply

title: Kudu Gas Power Plant, Namibia
body:
Develop the 800 MW (nominal) Kudu combined-cycle gas turbine power station 25km north of Oranjemund in southern Namibia

The plant will be supplied by the Kudu gas field located offshore, which is being developed by Norway's BW Energy

The gas produced from the field will be transported through a 170 km pipeline to a power station that will be built and situated at Uubvlei, approximately 25 km north of Oranjemund

NamPower will be the sole purchaser of the electricity produced by the power plant. Since the expected Namibian domestic electricity demand from the power plant is approximately 400MW, the remainder of the electricity will have to be exported by means of power purchase agreements with Zambia (Copperbelt Energy Corporation) and South Africa (Eskom)

title: Ignie 2021-2046 Power Generation and Transmission, Republic of Congo
body:
• Build a 55 MW hybrid solar power plant in the Ignié Special Economic Zone (SEZ), located in Maloukou
  • The project will generate 55 MW of power from photovoltaic (PV) solar and 10 MW from biomass; the biomass plant aims to process organic waste from Brazzaville and its surrounding areas 
  • It will cover a 100-hectare site allocated for renewable energy development within the SEZ
  • The work includes building transmission lines and access roads

(Sources: Energy Capital & Power and Agence d'Information d'Afrique Centrale)

 

The project seems to be part of the wider electrification plans for Congo-Brazzaville 2021-2046, which covers the areas of Impfondo, Epena, Likouala, Cuvette, Djambala Pointe, Ollombo, Zanaga, Kibangou, Niari, Boko, Kouilou and Sangha

The scope is understood to involve a build-operate-transfer (BOT) hybrid photovoltaic and biomass project of 255 MW

title: North Core Power Interconnector Line
body:
(Also known as the Dorsale Nord Regional Power Interconnector Project)

Transmission Lines:

  • Build 875 km of 330 kV line and 24 km of 225 kV line transmission interconnection between Niger, Nigeria, Benin and Burkina Faso
  • Of this, 62 km of 330 kV lines in Nigeria, 425 km in Niger, 381 km in Burkina Faso, and 12 km in Benin
  • 24 km of 225 kV transmission lines for the ring around Ouagadougou in Burkina Faso
  • The main 330 kV transmission line from Birnin Kebbi in Nigeria to Ouagadougou in Burkina Faso through Zabori and Niamey in Niger and Malanville in Benin will be capable of handling up to 600 MW. The 330 kV line will be a double-circuit line with the two circuits equipped, except the Zabori-Malanville section, where only one circuit will be equipped, which will be sufficient for the expected traffic
  • The 225 kV line in Burkina Faso will include 9 km of double-circuit (Ouaga East-Ouaga South East) and 15 km of single-circuit lines (Ouaga South East-PA5) and will connect with the interconnection from Ghana (Bolgatanga)

 

Substations and Ancillary Works:

Work includes the construction or extension of five substations and installation of SCADA and fibre-optic cable (OPGW) along the line, with 48 fibre-optic cables

This includes the extension of two substations (Gorou Banda in Niger and Malanville in Benin) and construction
of three substations of 330 kV (Zabori in Niger, and Ouaga East and Ouaga South East in Burkina Faso). Additionally, compensation equipment will be installed in  these North Core substations and two additional existing sub-stations (Niamey 2 and Gazaoua in Niger)

The project will upgrade the capabilities of the existing SCADA systems in Burkina Faso and Benin-Togo, to allow the supervision of the existing National Load Dispatch Centres (NLDCs) in Burkina Faso, Benin, Nigeria, and the WAPP Control Centre

 

 

The interconnector will allow Niger to increase significantly the availability of lower-cost energy supply from Nigeria by releasing the transmission constraint that has hindered increasing these exports beyond amounts agreed upon in country-to-country agreements (180 MW). The line will also facilitate access to regional markets for Niger.

In the case of Benin-Togo, the North Core Interconnector would release transport constraints and allow the purchase of full amounts under the existing agreements (an additional 60 MW). It will provide access to electricity to the northern part of Benin, which is isolated from the national grid. In the longer term, it will expand the supply available to Benin and Togo as a whole, as the North Core Interconnector will be connected to the Benin-Togo national transmission network through the 161 kV Bembéréké-Malanville line. 

It will also allow Nigeria to export electricity to Burkina Faso to relieve its dependence on expensive fuel-based generation and increase supply reliability. 

In the medium to long term, the North Core Regional Interconnector will also facilitate the development and export of an estimated 235 MW VRE from solar generation now under development in Niger and Burkina Faso.

title: National Matabeleland Zambezi Water, Zimbabwe
body:
The National Matabeleland Zambezi Water Project seeks to transport water from the Zambezi River to Bulawayo and surrounding areas in Zimbabwe, solving perennial water challenges in the arid Matabeleland North province.

It consists of three phases:

  • Construction of the Gwayi-Shangani Dam (634 million cubic meters)
  • Building a pipeline from Gwayi-Shangani Dam to Bulawayo (245–252 km)
  • Extending the pipeline from Gwayi-Shangani Dam to the Zambezi River (122km)

title: Sahel Backbone Power Interconnection Line
body:
(Also known as the Sahel Dorsal High Voltage Interconnection Project and Trans-Sahel Spine)

  • Build a double-circuit, high-voltage power interconnection line linking Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad; the project is part of the overall Desert-to-Power West Africa Regional Energy Programme - Phase 1

  • Over 6,000 km of transmission line is expected to be constructed

  • The line connecting Mauritania and Mali is already under construction – the work entails building a 1,373 km line running from Kayes in Mali through Kiffa to Aioun in Mauritania (view the project here)
  • The interconnection is intended to enable the development of renewable power plants and universal access to electricity

The remaining sections of the dorsal line have yet to be studied and possible route options are as follows:

Mali-Burkina Faso-Niger transmission route: The route could run through Mauritania/Mali border - Gao (Mali) or Toumbouctou (Mali) - Ouahigouya (Burkina) - Kandadji (Niger) - Tahoua (Niger) - Agadez (Niger) -Niger/Chad border, with tee-offs to Koutiala (Mali), Ouagadougou (Burkina), and Niamey (Niger) and May Moudjia (Niger)

Chad route: The route could run from the Niger/Chad border to Ndjamena in Chad

title: Masuwe Special Economic Zone (SEZ), Zimbabwe
body:
The Masuwe Special Economic Zone in part borders the southern section of the Victoria Falls National Park, designated part of the Victoria Falls World Heritage Site (separated by the main Victoria Falls-Bulawayo transport corridor). 

The development of the SEZ include the construction of an international standard 10,000 seat cricket stadium as well as a four-star hotel with 5,000 seat conference facility, medical facilities, a golf estate and a shopping mall.

(Source: Keep Victoria Falls Wild)

title: Mossel Bay GTL Refinery Rehabilitation, South Africa
body:
Mossel Bay Refinery, also known as the PetroSA Refinery or Mossgas, is set to undergo refurbishment with a ZAR 3.7 billion ($200 million) investment from Gazprombank Africa, following approval by South Africa’s Cabinet in December 2023.

Project Scope:

  • Refurbishment of the non-operational refinery, which has been idle since 2020 due to gas supply depletion.
  • Restoration of processing capacity, previously 36,000 barrels per day (bpd) of synthetic fuels.
  • Potential modernization to ensure sustainable operations.

Background:

  • Originally commissioned in 1992 by Mossgas, the refinery was among the largest gas-to-liquid (GTL) plants globally.
  • It converted offshore natural gas into petrol, diesel, and kerosene to enhance South Africa’s energy independence.
  • Production declined in the 2010s as offshore gas reserves depleted, leading to high operational costs and eventual shutdown in 2020.

title: Transmission Infrastructure Development to 2034, South Africa
body:
South Africa's Transmission Development Plan (TDP) 2024, which was presented in late October 2024, is the country’s latest TDP. The plan covers the period 2025-34 and predicts that generation capacity will increase from 66GW in 2024 to 106.5GW in 2034. 

 

Based on the network requirements, between 2025 and 2029, about 5,044 km of power lines and 87 transformers are required to be built (these include projects in the development and execution phases). The capital expenditure for capacity expansions in this period is estimated at Rand 80.7 billion and refurbishments at Rand 17.8 billion. 

 

TDP 2024 can be viewed here.

title: South Refinery, Libya
body:
The South Refinery is an industrial facility to refine and converts its crude oil form into various oil derivatives.

The South Refinery implemented in Ubari will be next to the steam power plant, 25 km approx east of the Al-Sharara field and 6 km Approx west of the Ubari power plant. The refinery will process about 30,000 barrels per day of crude oil, producing conventional petroleum products.

Products we are going to produce:

  • Propane and Butane: LPG for domestic and industrial uses.
  • Gasoline 95: regular, unleaded, and low-sulfur gasoline. The refinery will produce recycled and conventional gasoline for local markets.
  • Kerosene/Jet fuel.
  • Diesel fuel: Low-sulfur diesel found in the trucking industry and heavy machinery.
  • Oil: tanker fuel and power generation.

Source: Zallaf Libya Oil & Gas

body:

Azikel Oil Refinery is a hydro-skimming refinery located in the Obunagha complex, Gbarain region, near Yenagoa, Bayelsa State, Nigeria.

title: Atlantic Refinery, Congo
body:
To address the growing domestic demand and reduce reliance on imports, the government has initiated the construction of a new refinery in Fouta near Pointe-Noire. Known as the Atlantic Petrochemical Refinery, this project is being developed in partnership with the Chinese firm Beijing Fortune Dingheng Investment, representing an investment of around $600 million. 

The first phase aims to achieve a production capacity of 2.5 million tons per year focusing on high-quality gasoline and diesel, as well as domestic products like liquefied petroleum gas, kerosene and fuel oil. Additionally, it will produce petrochemical feedstocks such as propylene and hydrogenated naphtha. The refinery is expected to commence operations by the end of 2025, contributing significantly to national energy security.

Source: Energy Capital Power

title: Mostakbal Misr Water Intake, Egypt
body:
The project is situated in Giza, Egypt. The scope includes the design and construction of the 7 million M3/day intake on River Nile - Rashied Branch, main pump station civil, architectural, electrical, control and mechanical works including bar screens, stop logs, main pumps, and overhead cranes.

Moreover, it consists of an electrical room, an administration building, fences, a main gate, and a security building, among others.

Furthermore, the project also involves the construction of 10 crossings beneath significant landmarks such as El Khatatba, Manshiat El Kanater road, El Riiah El Behairy Canal, El Manashy Railway, and El Riiah El Nassery Canal. These crossings will require the installation of jacking pits, receiving pits, and reinforced concrete (RC) sleeve pipes.

(Source: Hassan Allam)

title: Dakar Diamniadio Sports City, Senegal
body:
The Dakar Diamniadio Sports City is a major sports and urban development project in Senegal, located in Diamniadio, approximately 30 kilometers from Dakar. The construction features of the Dakar Diamniadio Sports City include a wide range of state-of-the-art facilities designed to meet international standards for both professional and amateur sports. Below are the key features:

Sports Facilities:

  • Tennis courts
  • Athletics track
  • Olympic-size swimming pool
  • FIFA-standard football pitch
  • Combat sports gyms
  • Multisport halls
  • Two half-pitches for 7-a-side football (Maracana)
  • Professional training center

Recreational Amenities:

  • Children's playground
  • Wellness area with spa and hammam
  • High-end fitness suite

Residential and Commercial Spaces:

  • Athlete residence building with 30 rooms
  • Four-star hotel (managed in partnership with Marriott) featuring 168 rooms, restaurants, and sports equipment shops
  • Medical and Health Facilities:
  • Medical sports center

title: Punta Europa Refinery, Equatorial Guinea
body:
The project involves the dismantling of the existing methanol plant owned by Atlantic Methanol Production Company (AMPCO) at Punta Europa Gas Complex on Bioko Island. The facility will be converted into a modular crude oil refinery, repurposing existing infrastructure to support crude oil processing operations.

The methanol plant, part of the larger Punta Europa gas processing facility, has faced challenges due to declining production from the Alba field, which supplies its feedstock. This decline has prompted the consideration of repurposing the facility.

In April 2020, Equatorial Guinea Ministry of Mines and Hydrocarbons and Marathon Oil (acquired by ConocoPhillips in November 2024) awarded a contract to VFuels to conduct the feasibility study for constructing a 5,000 barrels per day modular refinery at Punta Europa. The study was expected to be completed within 12 weeks.

title: Maroua-Moutourwa and Magada-Yagoua Roads Rehabilitation, Cameroon
body:
The project involves the rehabilitation of road sections between Maroua, Moutourwa, Magada, Guidiguis, and Yagoua in Cameroon, totaling 173 km. 

The rehabilitation works are divided into three lots:

  • Lot 1: Maroua - Moutourwa (36 km)
  • Lot 2: Magada - Guidiguis (68.30 km)
  • Lot 3: Guidiguis - Yagoua (68.70 km)

title: Rehabilitation of Ngaoundéré Garoua Road, Cameroon
body:
Ngaoundéré to Garoua Road Rehabilitation Project involves the rehabilitation of a 242-kilometer road in Cameroon. The scope of work includes:

  • Rehabilitation of the Ngaoundéré - Salah Bridge section (128.9 km)
  • Construction of three interchanges at:
    • CH 1+187
    • CH 13+348
    • CH 67+117
  • Maintenance of the Malang-Bas Crossroads section of the Falaise de Mbé
  • Construction of a weighing station in Manwi
  • Implementation of the Environmental & Social Management Plan (ESMP)
  • Reforestation activities along the road

Project Breakdown by Lots:

  • Lot 1: Ngaoundéré - Mbe Cliff Base (50 km)
  • Lot 2: Cliff Base - Keroua Bridge (39 km)
  • Lot 3: Keroua Bridge - Salah Bridge (77 km)
  • Lot 4: Salah Bridge - Ouro André Village Entrance (56 km)
  • Lot 5: Ouro André Village Entrance - Benoué Bridge (56 km)

title: N2 Highway Upgrade Ermelo KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
body:
The project involves the upgrading of the N2 highway over a 150 km stretch from Ermelo through Mkhondo to the KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) and Mpumalanga border. 

The scope of work includes:

  • Road widening and rehabilitation to improve capacity and safety
  • Upgrading of intersections and interchanges for smoother traffic flow
  • Strengthening of pavement structure to enhance durability
  • Installation of road safety features, including signage, lighting, and guardrails

title: Tizi Ouzou University Hospital, Algeria
body:
Tizi Ouzou Hospital project in Algeria is a significant healthcare infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing medical services in the region. Located in Tizi Ouzou, approximately 100 kilometers east of Algiers, the project involves the construction of a modern hospital facility equipped to provide a wide range of medical services to the local population.​

Project Overview

  • Location: Tizi Ouzou, Algeria​
  • Scope: Construction of a new hospital facility​
  • Objective: To improve healthcare services and accessibility in the Tizi Ouzou region​

Key Features

Capacity: The hospital is designed to accommodate a substantial number of patients, with various departments catering to different medical specialties.​

Facilities: State-of-the-art medical equipment, emergency services, surgical units, maternity wards, and outpatient clinics.​

Sustainability: Incorporation of eco-friendly designs and energy-efficient systems to minimize environmental impact.​

title: Saiss and Garet Water Conservation, Morocco
body:
The Saiss and Garet water conservation Project is a combination of the following:

(i) the construction of key components of the Saiss water transfer network, comprised of the main distribution pipeline as well as the primary and secondary distribution networks (the "Saiss II Project");

(ii) the rehabilitation and modernisation of the water distribution network and full conversion to drip-fed watering system in the Garet perimeter (the "Garet Project")

The Saiss II Project is part of a staged programme to preserve the Saiss aquifer and promote sustainable water management within the Saiss plain. The Saiss project consists of a hydro-agricultural water transmission and distribution system aiming to preserve the Saiss underground water, which is currently overexploited, by providing alternative surface water from the Mdez dam in Sefrou. The Saiss II project entails the following contracts:

Works:

  • Construction of the primary distribution network of the Saiss Water Conservation Project (3 lots)
  • Construction of the internal distribution network for the irrigation (4 lots)
  • Consulting services:
  • Engineering and quality supervision;
  • Laboratory supervision;
  • Governance Support.

The Garet project entails the following contracts:

Works:

  • Construction of two tanks for storage, regulation, and decantation of irrigation water;
  • Adaptation work, renovation of the Transfer Station;
  • Construction of connecting pipes and civil engineering of land and property, supply and installation of equipment, and rehabilitation of the distribution network;
  • Construction of new discharge pipes in the transfer station;
  • Renovation of the Station of Pressurization;
  • Adjustment and renovation work on the Sector Pressure Plants ;
  • Realization of the Collective Filtration;
  • Realization of remote management of the Garet perimeter.

Consulting Services:

  • Project Implementation Support, including Environmental and Social Support;
  • Technical assistance for the accompaniment of farmers + stakeholder engagement plan (agricultural council and gender);
  • Lender’s Independent Monitor (covering both Saiss and Garet);
  • Policy Dialogue on Gender;
  • Additional support to the implementation of the project;
  • Remote management study of the Garet perimeter;
  • Technical assistance for monitoring and control of modernization/reconversion works with localized irrigation;
  • Technical Assistance for Internal Equipment (ORMVAM).

Source: European Bank

title: Lagoona City, Cote d'Ivoire
body:
Lagoona City is a residential community comprising 6,300 properties with its own businesses and essential amenities for a convenient everyday life.

In addition to its location near the lagoon and facing the plateau, Lagoona City boasts a myriad of perks, all concentrated in a locked and safe space.

It has optimized space and layouts and a wide range of essential and exclusive amenities, including a cultural center, a neighborhood school, café-restaurants, two multi-sports fields, banking agencies, a shopping center, and open space for open-air activities.

Source: Addoha Afrique

title: EuroAfrica Interconnector
body:
Project Overview

The EuroAfrica Interconnector is a flagship energy infrastructure project that will establish a 2,000 MW high-voltage direct current (HVDC) submarine transmission link between Egypt and Greece, via Crete. This strategic connection will enable the bi-directional flow of clean, renewable electricity between North Africa and Europe.

Scope of Work

  • Construction of a 400-km HVDC submarine cable between northern Egypt and the island of Crete—the shortest route across the Eastern Mediterranean. This section is also known as Greece-Africa Power (GAP) Interconnector
  • Installation of HVDC converter stations in Egypt and Crete to enable efficient and stable energy transmission.
  • Integration with broader Greek and European grid networks via existing and planned interconnections:
    • Crete to Attica (Ariadni Interconnection)
    • Crete to Peloponnese (Small Interconnection)
    • Southern Aegean Interconnector (Attica–Dodecanese–Crete)

Technical & Strategic Highlights

  • Lowest cost per MW among similar regional interconnector projects, enabled by optimal routing and design efficiency.
  • Reduces energy losses and operational costs through its short cable length and advanced transmission technologies.
  • Supports integration of renewable energy, particularly solar-generated electricity from Egypt, into the European grid.
  • Reinforces grid reliability and contributes to EU energy security and market integration.

Geopolitical & Regulatory Context

  • The interconnector route runs entirely within the Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ) of Egypt and Greece, respecting international law and aligning with the revised EU Regulation (EU) 2022/869 on cross-border energy infrastructure.
  • Backed by a 2021 Memorandum of Understanding between Egypt and Greece, reinforcing bilateral cooperation on energy security.

Regional Integration

  • Forms a vital segment of the broader EuroAfrica Interconnector plan, linking Egypt–Cyprus–Crete–Greece through a 1,648 km transmission corridor.
  • Offers a reliable alternative route for electricity transmission from Africa to Europe, leveraging both gas reserves and renewable sources.

Economic & Environmental Benefits

  • Ends the energy isolation of Cyprus and Crete—last remaining isolated power systems in the EU.
  • Supports EU climate goals by facilitating greater penetration of renewables and reducing carbon emissions.
  • Enhances energy affordability and resilience for both Europe and Egypt.
    Contributes to the EU’s target of achieving 10% interconnection capacity between member states.
  • Generates socioeconomic and geopolitical value for all participating countries.

In numbers Source: EuroAfrica Interconnector

  • 3 CONVERTER STATIONS - In Egypt, Cyprus, and in Greece with multi-terminal operation
  • 3,000 METRES DEPTH - Depth of lowest point of the EuroAfrica cable along the Mediterranean basin, making it the deepest laying of a subsea cable in the world, equal to the height of 8 times the Empire State building or 9 times the Eiffel Tower
  • 2,000 MW - Enough to provide electricity to 3 million households, or the cities of Berlin and Madrid combined (or 2 million people at peak load).
  • 1,396 KM - The longest interconnector cable in the world, or the same distance between Berlin, Germany and Torquay, England.

title: Kaduna Bus Rapid Transit (BRT), Nigeria
body:
​The Kaduna Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) project is a significant initiative by the Kaduna State Government aimed at modernizing the urban transportation system within Kaduna city. The project involves the development of a 24-kilometer BRT corridor extending from Kawo Bridge to Sabon Tasha. ​

Technical Scope:

  • Dedicated lanes for BRT buses to ensure efficient and rapid transit.​
  • Approximately 30 strategically located bus stations equipped with modern shelters.​
  • Installation of street lighting and pedestrian crossing facilities to enhance safety and accessibility.​
  • Construction of a bus depot and terminals at both ends of the corridor.​
  • Implementation of an Intelligent Transport System (ITS) for improved operational efficiency.
  • Procurement of 120 articulated 18-meter buses to service the corridor. ​

title: Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit Line 4: Kifaru
body:
​The Nairobi Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) Line 4, also known as the Kifaru Line, is a planned component of Nairobi's mass transit system aimed at enhancing urban mobility and reducing congestion. The line is designed to traverse key areas of the city, providing efficient and reliable transportation for residents.​

Technical Scope:

BRT Line 4 is planned to connect the eastern and western parts of Nairobi. The technical scope includes the construction of dedicated bus lanes, modern stations with off-board fare collection systems, pedestrian bridges, and integration with other transport modes to ensure seamless connectivity. 

The design emphasizes accessibility, safety, and efficiency to cater to the high demand for public transport along this corridor.​

title: New Multipurpose Terminal at Port of Pointe Noire, Republic of Congo
body:
(Terminal is also known as the New East Mole Port)

  • Develop, manage, and operate the New East Mole multipurpose terminal at the Autonomous Port of Pointe Noire (PAPN) under a 30-year extendable concession signed by the UAE's AD Ports Group in June 2023
  • The terminal will be built in phases and will handle containers, general, break-bulk and other types of cargo
  • About US$220 million will be invested to build a 400-metre quay wall at 16-metre depth, plus a 10-hectare logistics area, during phase 1 of the project
  • In early February 2025, AD Ports Group signed a shareholders agreement with the CMA CGM group, which will have 49% ownership in the joint venture (JV) that will develop, manage and operate. The JV has confirmed that the terminal will be operated as a multi-user facility and AD Ports Group will maintain controlling majority ownership in the management and operation  of the terminal. As such the operations will still be fully consolidated
  • According to AD Ports Group, this partnership will position the Republic of Congo at the centre of maritime trade, in line with projections for annual growth of 3% to 5% in container volumes forecast for the country over the medium term
  • The New East Mole multipurpose terminal has already placed an order for three Super Post-Panamax Ship-to-Shore (STS) cranes
  • Additionally, it will receive nine hybrid rubber-tyred gantry cranes (RTGs) and other associated handling equipment. These hybrid RTGs will help reduce diesel consumption by up to 60%, equivalent to saving 1 million litres of diesel annually, and cut approximately 5,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions. China's Shanghai Zhenhua Heavy Industries Co. Ltd is the supplier

title: New Container Terminal at Port of Pointe Noire, Republic of Congo
body:
• Construct a new container terminal at the Republic of Congo’s Autonomous Port of Pointe Noire (PAPN) 
  • The terminal will have a 750-linear metre quay, with a surface area of 28 hectares and a depth of 17 metres, along with 16 electric gantries, including four ship-to-shore (STS) and 12 rubber-tyred gantry (RTG) cranes
  • The project also includes 4,000 square metres of buildings
  • A major dredging campaign is set to widen the channel to 300 metres at the bend and 250 metres for the other sections
  • The new infrastructure will increase PAPN’s overall container terminal capacity from 1 million to more than 2.3 million 20-foot equivalent containers (TEUs) handled per year and will enable Congo Terminal to accommodate larger-capacity vessels from Asia, the Indian subcontinent and Europe. It will also create 900 jobs

title: Ruzizi III Hydropower Plant
body:
The proposed 206 MW Ruzizi III is planned as a run-of-the-river hydropower project located on the Ruzizi River, which forms the border between DRC and Rwanda in the region. The Ruzizi River flows from Lake Kivu to Lake Tanganyika. The Project will be part of the Ruzizi Cascade, already equipped by the Ruzizi I and Ruzizi II projects, and will be located approximately 13 km downstream of the Ruzizi II dam. Flow available to the Ruzizi Cascade is regulated by Lake Kivu.

The project is one of the largest infrastructure projects in the Economic Community of the Great Lakes (CEPGL) region comprising Burundi, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and Rwanda. It will be a 206 MW hydroelectric power project, with an average annual energy production of about 1,200 GWh.

The project will be located at the border between DRC and Rwanda on the Ruzizi River, between Lake Kivu and Lake Tanganyika. It will be part of the Ruzizi cascade, already equipped by Ruzizi I and Ruzizi II plants.

The Project will be developed as a Public Private Partnership with Congo, Rwanda and Burundi, throughout a 25-year concession provided to the private investor to develop, build, operate and maintain the plant. The Contracting States will each have an ownership of 10% in the project company, and share off-take equally between them. They will work through EGL. The remaining 70% of the project company will be owned by the private partner.

Scope of work

The project will include the design, construction, commissioning, testing, operation and maintenance of:

  • hydroelectric power production facility with an installed capacity of 206 MW, comprising of a 45m high embankment dam with associated spillway, low level outlet, and eco-flow small-hydro, a 3.8 km long, 6.7m diameter concreate-lined headrace tunnel from the dam reservoir to the powerhouse, penstock and unit penstocks, power station comprising three Francis generating units, access roads from Bugarama (Rwanda) and Kamanyola (DRC) to the dam site, and all ancillary and related works. 
  • 7.3 km long 220 kV double-critical transmission line to evacuate the electricity from the Facility to the regional dispatch station in Kamanyola (DRC).

Source: Ruzizi III Energy

body:

title: EGENCO Salima Solar Power Plant, Malawi
body:
• Build a 50 MW solar power plant across 110 hectares of land in Nanjoka in Salima district in the central region of Malawi, 71 km away from the capital city Lilongwe
  • The project is planned to be implemented in three phases, starting with 10 MW for the first phase and then 10 MW and 30 MW for the second and third phases respectively
  • The first phase is expected to be completed in 18 months at an estimated total cost of US$13.6 million
  • The project will also have a battery energy storage system (BESS), which will be procured under a different contract
  • The project is aimed at diversifying state utility EGENCO’s energy sources and increasing the country’s power generation capacity

title: Kammwamba Coal Power Project, Malawi
body:
• Build a 300 MW coal-fired steam turbine power plant in the Kammwamba area in the town of Zalewa, Neno District, Southern Region, approximately 60 km by road, northwest of the city of Blantyre
  • The fuel will be procured from the Moatize coal mine in Mozambique
  • The scheme will be designed to allow an increase in generation capacity of up to 1,000 MW in the future
  • The project will take about three years to complete after reaching financial closure
  • The project is in line with EGENCO’s diversification objectives where the company seeks to improve its power generation mix from being 95% hydro based to 76% hydro based

title: Dekheila Dry Bulk Terminal, Egypt
body:
The project involves the construction of a dedicated clean dry bulk terminal at Dekheila Port, to be developed and operated by East Med Logistical and Industrial Terminal Egypt (ELITE), a consortium comprising: 

  • El Sewedy
  • Holding Company for Maritime and Land Transport
  • Latt Trading & Shipping
  • Mediterraneo

The scope of work includes:

  • A 1,150-meter-long quay with a depth ranging from 16 to 19 meters.
  • A rear terminal area of 300,000 square meters, adjacent to the new clean bulk cargo berth.
  • Exclusive usage rights for the west side of the berth for bulk cargo operations.
  • Loading and unloading capacity of approximately 25,000 tons per day.
  • Weighing areas and waiting zones for cargo transport vehicles.
  • Facilities for handling and storing grains and other clean bulk goods, including infrastructure for value-added processing industries.

body:

  • A 1,200-meter-long berth, forming part of the larger 1,680-meter Berth 100.
  • A depth of 18 meters, enabling accommodation of large vessels.
  • A terminal area of approximately 840,000 square meters.
  • An annual handling capacity of up to 1.5 million TEUs, supporting containerized and general cargo operations.

  • Heart Surgery

title: Trans-Desert Railway, Algeria
body:
The Trans-Desert Railway is a transformative national infrastructure initiative designed to integrate Algeria’s coastal economic hubs with its inland and southern trade corridors, linking the capital, Algiers, to the border city of Tamanrasset, near Niger. Spanning approximately 2,406 kilometers, the railway is a strategic backbone project aimed at enhancing logistics, industrial development, and cross-border trade across 10 provinces.

Conceived as a dual-track heavy rail system, the project is part of Algeria’s broader vision to position itself as a key logistics gateway between North and Sub-Saharan Africa. By unlocking mineral-rich regions, improving freight efficiency, and reducing road traffic dependence, the Trans-Desert Railway is expected to play a pivotal role in continental connectivity, especially in the context of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA).

The line will also serve as a foundation for future intermodal infrastructure, enabling integration with dry ports, mining zones, and energy corridors, while also supporting public-private partnership (PPP) frameworks for long-term operations and maintenance.

Technical Scope:

  • Route coverage: From Algiers (north) to Tamanrasset (south), traversing 10 provinces
  • Rail configuration: Dual-track line to enable high-capacity freight and passenger movement

title: Kilwa Masoko Fishing Port, Tanzania
body:
The Kilwa Masoko Fishing Port is a landmark infrastructure project in Tanzania, marking the nation's first modern, large-scale fishing harbor. Situated in the Kilwa Masoko area of the Lindi Region along the Indian Ocean coastline, the port is poised to significantly enhance Tanzania's deep-sea fishing capabilities and bolster the local fishery economy

Technical Scope of Work:

  • Berth Construction: The project includes the development of wharf berths.
  • Administration Building: An administration facility is being constructed to manage port operations efficiently.​
  • Cold Storage Facility: The port will feature a cold storage unit designed to preserve fish and maintain product quality.​
  • Processing Capacity: Upon completion, the port is expected to handle an annual fish unloading capacity of 60,000 tons. ​

title: Kalahari Copperbelt (KCB) Project, Botswana
body:
The NE-trending Proterozoic belt, 800 km long by up to 250 km wide, stretches from northern Botswana into eastern Namibia. The KCB district is similar in setting to the Central African Copperbelt sediment-hosted deposits of Zambia and DRC.

The belt contains copper-silver mineralisation, which is generally stratabound and hosted in metasedimentary rocks that have been folded, faulted and metamorphosed to greenschist facies during the Damara Orogeny.

Sediments at the base of the D’Kar Formation (on the contact with lower Ngwako Pan Formation) hosts copper sulphide minerals. The outstanding potential has been hidden under Kalahari sand cover.

Source: Aterian

title: Regional Mining Hub, Senegal
body:
Develop Senegal as a regional mining hub in West Africa; this will be carried out through three components:

  • Service Hub: Provide a platform providing services to mining companies located in Senegal and the surrounding sub-region
  • Logistics Hub: Build a logistics and distribution platform for goods, equipment, consumables and spare parts to mining companies in Senegal and the surrounding sub-region
  • Academic Hub: Develop training and certifications tailored to mining companies, and provide a skills-building platform

The project will look to develop four national projects as well as three mining areas:

  • Thiès: 360 hectares with 5 projects identified
  • Tambacounda: 300 hectares with 1 project identified
  • Kédougou: 300 hectares with 8 projects identified

The project has a total cost of CFA franc 509 billion, of which the infrastructure cost is CFA franc 379 billion, project cost is CFA franc 120 billion and the reform and governance cost is CFA franc 10 billion

 

This project aims to position Senegal as a leading mining services centre in West Africa, which is one of the 27 flagship projects of the Emerging Senegal Plan (PSE).

The roadmap includes attracting large mining and industrial groups capable of providing goods and services to encourage companies to establish their operations. More specifically, the development of parks and zones, the definition of appropriate legislation, and an information platform on all the factors that structure the mining economy are central to the process

In terms of impact, estimates suggest such a project could attract more foreign direct investment, generate nearly 19,000 jobs and contribute to exports worth above CFA franc 250 billion

 

Senegal has a rich and varied mineral potential. The subsoil is first known for its important phosphate and limestone resources of the Senegalese-Mauritanian sedimentary basin in operation. This basin in its coastal fringe is also rich in heavy mineral sands such as zircon and titanium. The ancient geological formations of Senegal Oriental (Birimien Socle) and the series representing the Mauritanian chain constitute an important potential for mineralisation that is still poorly recognised. They are known for their richness in precious metals, in particular gold, and base metals such as iron, copper and zinc. These formations also contain a wide variety of good quality ornamental stones (marbles, granites, serpentinites), building materials (basalt, sandstone, shells, flint, sand, clay) and other mineral substances such as manganese, tin and uranium. (Source: AUDIFISC)

title: Kalahari Copper Project, Namibia
body:
The project boasts a substantial land package spanning 280 kilometres along the renowned Kalahari Copper Belt, with Trigon Metals holding licences covering an impressive 963,163 hectares of exploration territory. Kalahari Copper project is bounded by Sandfire Resources to the northeast and Rio Tinto to the southwest; a strategic position in a region renowned for hosting world-class Cu-Ag deposits.

Exploration and Geology

Exploration efforts at the Kalahari Copper Project have yielded promising results, with ore-grade intercepts identified in close proximity to the project’s boundaries. Notable drill hole assays include 83 metres at 0.7% Cu and 17 g/t Ag, with significant intervals such as 8 metres at 2.5% Cu and 78 g/t Ag. Mineralization along the belt typically extends over considerable distances, presenting ample opportunities for further discoveries within the expansive licence area.

Kalahari Copper Belt

Botswana’s portion of the Kalahari Copper Belt has been gaining attention, with discoveries like Zone 5 and Motheo. Copper and Silver mineralization is primarily found at the contact between the Ngwako Pan Formation and the D’Kar Formation, showing strong structural associations.

In Namibia, the extension of the Kalahari Copper Belt is mainly covered in sand, hindering modern exploration efforts.

Despite the sand cover, previous exploration has revealed:

  • The presence of the right geological stratigraphy, including Ngwako Pan and D’Kar formations.
  • Favorable structural features such as domes, thrusts, and faults.
  • Fertility in Cu & Ag, both on the D’Kar contact and related to structures within the D’Kar formation.

The Namibian segment of the Kalahari Copper Belt remains largely unexplored yet holds significant promise, given its favourable geological stratigraphy, intricate structural characteristics, and demonstrated mineral fertility.

Source: Trigon Metals

title: Cabinda Phosphate Project, Angola
body:
Overview

The project involves mining Phosphate Rock from the Cácata Deposit and transporting it to Porto de Caio, where a granulation plant will be constructed to produce Enhanced Phosphate Rock (EPR) granules. The EPR granules will serve as the phosphorus (P) feedstock for NPK fertilizer blending plants.

Scope of Work

  • Mining: Extraction of phosphate rock from the Cácata Deposit.
  • Transport: Movement of mined material to Porto de Caio.
  • Granulation Plant: Construction and operation of a facility to produce EPR granules.
  • NPK Fertilizer Blending: Blending of EPR with imported nitrogen (N) and potassium (K) granules to suit Angolan soil and crop requirements.

Technical Details

  • Production Capacity: 150 ktpa, with potential expansion to 450 ktpa
  • Mining Target (Measured & Indicated): 6.5 Mt @ 30.2% P₂O₅
  • Mine Life: 21 years

Subantando Capacity

  • 187,500 tpa (Stage 1)
  • 400,000 tpa (Stage 2)

Source: Minbos Resources

title: Asanko Gold Mine (AGM), Ghana
body:
Located in Ghana, West Africa, the Asanko Gold Mine is Galiano’s flagship asset since 2016.

The Asanko Gold Mine is a multi-deposit complex, with four main open-pit mining areas: Abore, Miradani North, Nkran and Esaase, and multiple satellite deposits, situated on the Asankrangwa Gold Belt, and a 5.8Mtpa carbon-in-leach (CIL) processing plant. Gold production commenced in January 2016 and commercial production was declared on April 1, 2016.

In 2024, the mine produced 115,115 ounces of gold. The AGM is expected to produce between 130,000 oz to 150,000 oz of gold at AISC* between $1,750/oz to $1,950/oz. 

Exploration at the AGM is focussed on two priorities:

  • Increasing Reserves and Resources at the known deposits.
  • Delivering discovery of new deposits within the and beyond the existing AGM tenements.

Source: Galiano Gold

title: Assuéfry Project, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
The 335.88km2 Assuéfry exploration permit was granted on December 5, 2024, to Tropic Mining Group (TMG). Koulou Gold holds an option to earn up to 90% interest in the Project. Assuéfry is underlain by the same Tarkwaian-like Koun-Tanda basin and Birimian volcanic rocks, and structural setting as Assafou.

Geology

Dominantly underlain by the Tarkwaian-like Koun-Tanda basin and Birimian volcanic and intrusive rocks. The stratigraphy in the basin has a shallow dip, with the dominant structural trends defined by the NNE-SSW faulted unconformity between the basin and the Birimian volcanic rocks, as well as NNW-SSE trending structures.

Mineralization

Two significant high-grade soil anomalies:

  • 8.0 km x 1.1 km: located along a NW-SE trending Assafou parallel structure
  • 7.0 km x 3.0 km: located along a NNE-SSW trending favorable structural contact between the Tarkwaian-like Koun-Tanda basin and Birimian volcanic rocks

Source: Koulou Gold

title: Kouto Project, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
298.46 km2 Kouto project (PR 916) is located in northwestern Côte d’Ivoire on the north-northeast trending Syama greenstone belt adjacent to and along strike from Aurum Resources 1.6 Moz Au Boundiali project (December 30, 2024) and approximately 120 km northeast of Montage Gold’s 3.15 Moz Au Koné project (December 18, 2024). The Kouto Project was staked by Koulou and the permit was granted on March 2, 2023.

Mineralization

The gold-in-soil anomaly at Kouto is constrained to a highly-strained volcano-sedimentary package and spatially associated with a magnetic-high anomaly observed in the regional magnetic analytical signal map.

Exploration 

10.0 km x 5.0 km gold-in-soil anomalous corridor outlined from 69 BLEG samples and 6,200 soil samples (400m x 50m grid) has yet to be drill tested.

Source: Koulou Gold

title: Sakassou Project, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
The 396.91 km2 Sakassou project (PR 944) is located in central Côte d’Ivoire on the northeast trending Bouaflé greenstone belt approximately 30 km northwest of Perseus Mining’s Yaouré mine (Figure 3), which produces over 200koz per year and has a Proven and Probable reserve of 37.2Mt at 1.73 g/t containing 2.07Moz of gold (December 19, 2023).

Soil sampling, artisanal workings, trenching and reverse circulation drilling has identified three kilometre-scale NNE/NE trending targets (Bravo, Charlie, and Echo). 

Source: Koulou Gold

title: Bab Ezzouar Business District, Algeria
body:
The Bab Ezzouar Business District in Algiers, Algeria, is a significant mixed-use development aimed at enhancing the city's economic landscape. Strategically located approximately 10 kilometers east of Algiers' city center and near Houari Boumediene International Airport, the district spans 63 hectares and integrates residential, commercial, and leisure facilities.​

Key Features:

Hotels and Accommodations:

  • Marriott Hotels:  213 rooms ​
  • Marriott Courtyard: 497 rooms
  • Residence Inn: 147 rooms

Residential and Office Spaces:

  • Executive Apartment Towers: 348 executive apartments
  • Office Towers: Two office towers

Shopping and Leisure:

  • Bab Ezzouar Shopping Mall: 110 stores across three floors,  20 restaurants and cafés, and parking facilities for around 800 vehicles. ​

Transportation Infrastructure:

  • Connectivity: A new train line connects Bab Ezzouar to Houari Boumediene International Airport, facilitating a 5-minute commute 

Corporate Headquarters:

  • Air Algérie Headquarters

Source: Nest Properties

title: New Sidi Abdellah, Algeria
body:
Sidi Abdellah is located approximately 20 km southwest of Algiers and encompasses an area of 70 km2, of which 45% is designated for urbanization. The city is designed to accommodate up to 450,000 residents upon completion. ​
 

Key Features:

  • Housing Projects: The construction of 10,000 housing units across 109 hectares. This project is divided into four zones—A, B, C, and D—comprising 332 residential blocks with a total construction area of one million square meters. The housing types include F3 apartments (70 square meters) and F4 apartments (85 square meters), with buildings ranging from six to fifteen floors (Source: CSCEC Algerie)
  • Sidi Abdellah University Campus
  •  The Birtouta–Zéralda railway line
  • Sidi Abdellah Cyberpark dedicated to IT and communication sectors. This development includes multifunctional buildings designed to support technological innovation and business activities. ​

title: Tasiast Mine, Mauritania
body:
The Tasiast mine is an open-pit operation located in northwestern Mauritania, approximately 300 kilometres north of the capital Nouakchott, which processes ore via mill.

Kinross acquired the Tasiast gold mine in September 2010. Since then, Kinross has successfully expanded capacity at the site and ramped up throughput rates at the operation from the initial 8,000 tonnes per day. In 2018, Kinross completed the Phase One project to increase throughput to 12,000 t/d, and in 2023, Kinross completed the Tasiast 24k expansion project to further increase throughput rates to 24,000 t/d (average) on an annual basis. The capital-efficient project is expected to further increase production, lower costs, and generate significant cash flow and attractive returns. It is expected to extend mine life by four years to 2033.

  • Mining: Open pit
  • Location: Mauritania, West Africa
  • Processing: Milling, heap leach
  • Expected Life of Mine: 2033
  • 2024 Gold Equivalent Production: 622,394 oz
  • 2024 Proven and Probable Reserves: 4,705  Au koz.

Exploration

Exploration efforts in 2025 will include underground potential focused drilling from surface at West Branch, Prolongation and Piment, as well as continued exploration of the SENISA land package and on satellite deposits on the TMLSA land package.

Source: Kinross Gold
meta_description: The Tasiast mine is an open-pit operation located in northwestern Mauritania
migration_status: approximately 300 kilometres north of the capital Nouakchott

title: Tasiast South Project, Mauritania
body:
Highlights

Archaean Greenstone Belt – Kalgoorlie / Tasiast appear to be comparable and represent a significant opportunity for further exploration. 

Aura holds 125 km2 of virgin Greenstone belt that has been subject to little exploration and is 36 km south of the Kinross 20Moz Tasiast Mine. 

High-Grade Drilling Results show intercepts of Gold, Nickel, Cobalt. 

Exploration results from the first pass program were excellent, demonstrating a wide gold system with similar geology to Tasiast. 

A 1.6km high grade nickel zone has been detected with multiple cobalt hits including several up to 0.58% cobalt. 

Significant nickel and cobalt potential exists in a very large ultramafic body in Bella permit. 

Source: Aura Energy

body:

title: Ebebiyin Dry Port, Equatorial Guinea
body:
​Ebebiyin Dry Port project is a strategic initiative aimed at enhancing trade facilitation and regional integration within the Central African Economic and Monetary Community (CEMAC). Located in Ebebiyin, Equatorial Guinea, near the tri-border area with Cameroon and Gabon, the project's primary objective is to improve intra-community trade, reduce transit times and costs, and decongest existing seaports.

Technical Scope:

  • A transformer room for stable power supply.​
  • Warehouses for storage of goods.​
  • A fuel storage and pumping station.​
  • Sanitary facilities, including a latrine block.​
  • A computer system connected to the internet for efficient operations.​
  • Perimeter fencing to ensure security.​ 
  • An industrial area designated for processing agricultural and mining products in the future.

title: Mbini-Akoga Highway, Equatorial Guinea
body:
• Construct the 64 km Mbini-Akoga Highway running from Mbini, located on the mouth of the Benito River in the western Rio Muni region, to Akoga, situated in the Centro Sur region
  • The road is expected to improve connectivity and development in the area, with the government inviting mining-focused investments in the country
  • According to the African Energy Chamber, the Rio Muni region is considered to be a highly-prospective exploration frontier, with early geological surveys indicating strong commercial potential for commodities including energy transition minerals and metals 
  • Akoga, meanwhile, is home to the Grupo Abayak cement plant, a 3,000 tonne-a-day facility, which supplies local industries as well as neighbouring countries

title: Manono Lithium and Tin Mines, DRC
body:
The Manono lithium and tin mining project covers 188 square kilometres and is situated 500 km due north of Lubumbashi in the south of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC); it includes the Roche Dure and Carriere de l’Este mineral resources

The total mineral resources for the Manono project have been estimated at 842 million tonnes of 1.61% lithium oxide (Li2O), 709 ppm tin (Sn) and 37 ppm tantalum (Ta) containing 13.52 million tonnes of lithium oxide, as of January 2024; this is divided into the Roche Dure deposit with 669 million tonnes and the Carrière de l’Este deposit with 173 million tonnes

The maximum depth of the mineral resources is approximately 615m below surface, beneath which there is insufficient information with which to model the mineralisation and therefore the mineral resource can be considered open at depth

 

 

Project Geological Features:

The project lies within the mid-Proterozoic Kibaran Belt, an intra-cratonic domain stretching for over 1,000 km through Katanga and into southwest Uganda. The belt strikes predominantly SW-NE and is truncated by the N-S to NNW-SSE trending Western Rift system. The Kibaran is underlain in the east by Archaean rocks of the Tanzanian Craton and in the west and south by Lower Proterozoic metamorphic rocks.

The Kibaran belt comprises a sedimentary and volcanic sequence that has been folded, metamorphosed and intruded by at least three separate phases of granite. The latest granite phase (900 to 950MA) is assigned to the Katangan cycle and is associated with widespread vein and pegmatite mineralisation containing tin, tungsten, tantalum, niobium, lithium and beryllium. Deposits of this type occur as clusters and are widespread throughout the Kibaran terrain. In the DRC, the Katanga Tin Belt stretches over 500 km from near Kolwezi in the southwest to Kalemie in the northeast comprising numerous occurrences and deposits of which the Manono deposit is the largest known by far

 

Manono Mineralisation:

The presence of lithium mineralisation in pegmatites at Manono has been confirmed to extend along strike for more than 13km

Two large areas of pegmatite have been identified, with the northeast area, referred to as the Manono sector and the southwest area, referred to as the Kitotolo sector. Mapping within the two sectors has established that there are many pegmatites, representing separate intrusions, including six large pegmatites

The large pegmatites all contain spodumene mineralisation. The majority of the smaller pegmatites also contain spodumene and in some cases other lithium minerals. The two largest pegmatites (known as the Carriere de l’Este Pegmatite and the Roche Dure Pegmatite) are each of similar size or larger than the famous Greenbushes Pegmatite in Western Australia

title: Bibiani Underground Mine, Ghana
body:
The Project is managed and operated by Asante Gold Bibiani Limited (AGBL), a wholly owned Ghanaian subsidiary of Asante Gold Corporation.

AGBL holds one Mining Lease, as well as two Prospecting Licences, which collectively make up the AGBL tenements and span 30km strike length hosted in the Kumasi-Afema Basin sediments adjacent to the Sefwi Belt volcanic and volcaniclastic assemblage. The Mining Lease concessions cover an area of approximately 49.82 km2.

Reserves & Resources

  • Measured and Indicated Gold Resources: 2.490 Gold Koz
  • Inferred Gold Resources: 1.152 Gold Koz
  • Proven and Probable: 1.950 Gold Koz

The potential for an underground mine development with initial life of seven years at Bibiani will incorporate 831,000 ounces of gold produced. 

Source: Asante Gold

title: Black Volta Mine, Ghana
body:
Black Volta is located in a stable mining jurisdiction of Wa, Ghana, Africa. All critical infrastructure are in place with close proximity to the regional Centre.

  • Build ready project with expected development costs of c. US$198m (including mine fleet) over a 21 month construction period
  • The project will predominantly consist of open pit mining across the multiple deposits with annual throughput via a CIL processing circuit between 2.6 - 3.2 Mtpa
  • High grade resource with 91.1% overall gold recovery and strip ratio of 5.7:1
  • 13 licenses with all reserves sitting within 6 licenses.
    Remaining licenses allow for further exploration with strong prospects of mine life extension including extending existing deposits and potential for major new camps

Operational Highlights

  • Location: 50km North West of Wa, Ghana, Africa
  • Commodity: Gold
  • Mining Method: Predominantly conventional open pit mining involving drilling, blasting, loading, in addition to underground conventional open stoping with regional pillars
  • Processing: Conventional CIL processing circuit. Addition of flotation and regrind circuit to treat Julie Primary ore commencing in year 3
  • Production: 148 koz pa for the first 9 years

title: Booue Hydropower Plant, Gabon
body:
Build a 400-600 MW hydropower plant in central Gabon that will cover an area of 129,600 square kilometres, with a total annual output of 3.1 GWh

The facility is planned to benefit the country, as well as neighbouring Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and the Republic of Congo

The work includes building:

  • An intake dam with the following characteristics: maximum height (26 m), length (593 m), retention height (173 m), and equipment flow rate (2,500 cubic metres/s)
  • A headrace
  • A power plant 

 

The Booue plant is seen as essential to exploiting the Belinga and Baniaka iron ore mines

The Booue facility is part of a flagship regional project that includes the 300 MW Tsengue-Leledi hydroelectric facility. The overall scheme aims to create an interconnected electricity grid in Central Africa through the construction of hydroelectric dams on the Gabonese waterfalls. In addition to Gabon, the project will impact Congo, Cameroon, and Equatorial Guinea

title: Transport Corridors for Economic Resilience, Zambia
body:
The project includes transport and trade facilitation improvements along the main transport corridor from Zambia to Nakonde on the border to Tanzania, toward Dar es Salaam port, as well as support to economic activities along the corridor. 

Component 1: 

  • climate-resilient design and construction of the Serenje-Mpika section of the Dar es Salaam Corridor; 
  • design and implementation of physical and system improvements to the One Stop Border Post (OBSP) at Nakonde to complement Tunduma on the Tanzanian side of the border; 
  • development and implementation of the Safety, Mobility, Automated, Real-time Traffic Management (SMART) corridor concept on the Lusaka-Nakonde section of the Dar es Salaam Corridor; 
  • support for regional corridor management
  • preparatory studies for key sections along the Trans-Caprivi and Nacala Corridors (feasibility studies, detailed designs and ESIA for sections on the Nacala corridor, as well as the detailed design for sections on the Trans-Caprivi Corridor. 

Component 2

  • Corridor-oriented development will finance SME activities in the basin of the Dar es Salaam Corridor. 

Component 3

  • developing the Zambia Transport & Logistics Strategy and Roadmap
  • developing a strategy and action plan for enhancing the operational efficiency and financial sustainability of the Zambia Railways Company (ZRL)
  • supporting the domestic construction industry in Zambia
  • building institutional capacities in project-related government entities
  • project management, monitoring and evaluation

Source: World Bank

title: Upgrade of Tanzania-Zambia Railway
body:
• Upgrade the 1,860km single-track Tanzania-Zambia railway, which was built between 1970 and 1975
  • The work will include the complete rehabilitation of track infrastructure, improvement of train speeds to between 60 and 80 kilometres an hour, and the purchase of 32 locomotives and 762 wagons
  • China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) will be awarded a 30-year concession for the railway, the first three years of which would be dedicated to construction and rehabilitation, and the remaining 27 years to operational management to ensure long-term sustainability
  • CCECC will undertake periodic major overhauls, alongside continuous maintenance throughout the concession period
  • According to Zambia’s transport minister Frank Tayali, the Tazara revitalisation plan states that in order for the railway to be economically viable, it will need to move at least 1.2 million tonnes of cargo a year. This would entail two freight trains being dispatched from Dar es Salaam in Tanzania and Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia at the same time each day
  • In the near future, the railway is planned to move 4 million tonnes of cargo a year

title: Mangali Port in Mayumba, Gabon
body:
• Build a deepwater seaport in phases in Mayumba, southwestern Gabon, on the Atlantic Ocean coastline

Phase 1
- 130m quay
- Up to 10-hectare logistics area
- Will support barges and landing crafts with draft of 3m

Phase 2
- 360m quay
- Loading platform/infrastructure for Ocean Going Vessels (OGV)
- Accommodate draft of 7m
- Port services expansion to 20 hectares

Phase 3
- Vessels to 150,000 tonnes, > 16m draft
- Substantial mineral terminal
- Storage area with stacker, conveyor to feed at approximately 4,000 tonnes per hour

  • The port infrastructure will initially cater to the needs of the agriculture, mining and oil sectors already established in the region. The facility is designed to function as a hub that enhances supply chain efficiency for southern Gabon, offering a viable alternative to road transport
  • The construction of the Mangali deepwater port at Mayumba is being studied as part of the Grande Mayumba Programme, which involves consolidating and developing a forest land area of 631,100 hectares and a marine area of 260,900 hectares in the Nyanga province of southern Gabon 
  • An industrial zone is being developed concurrently behind the port spanning up to 400 hectares. This zone is intended to accommodate industrial, logistics and commercial facilities, fostering anticipated development in the Nyanga province and southern Gabon

 

The Mangali port is expected to serve the Banio potash mine and the Belinga iron ore mine

The port is set to be connected to the Belinga-Mayumba railway

title: Banio Potash Mine, Gabon
body:
• The Banio potash project covers 1,238 square km and is located approximately 450 km south of Libreville along the Atlantic coast of Gabon
  • The project is located in the West Africa Potash Basin and is estimated to have a resource base of 657 million tonnes of indicated and 1.159 billion tonnes of inferred resources
  • The mine is set to have an optimal annual production rate of 800,000 tonnes per year (TPY) of primarily granular K60 Muriate of Potash
  • The mining method deemed most appropriate for the potential of an economic project at Banio is solution mining. This includes the development of solution mining caverns at a wellfield at the North Target, with enriched brine pumped via pipeline to a processing plant facility at the town of Mayumba 50 km north of the project area. Processing will be done via evaporation and crystallisation followed by drying and compaction producing K60 (>95% KCl), as well as 99% pure NaCl, and shipped to market from the planned deepwater port at Mayumba
  • At a production rate of 800,000 TPY gMOP, the estimated Life of Mine (LOM) is 56 years

 

Initial Expenditure

  • The processing plant forms the bulk of the initial capital expenditure (capex) at US$190 million
  • The main process plant components include: Evaporators, Crystallizers, Compaction plant units, Dryers, Tanks and Clarifiers, as well as Plant Buildings and Infrastructure
  • The Initial capex for infrastructure includes the project power requirements, mobile equipment, conveyors, screens, salt storage and bagging, and a ship loader as well as MOP product storage
  • The total estimated capex for a production rate of 800,000 TPY of K60 granular MOP is approximately US$480 million

 

Sustaining Expenditure

  • The sustaining capex estimate is dominated by expenditures in the wellfield/caverns. The initial caverns are projected to have a production life of approximately 11 years and replacements will be required every 7-10 years. Every 7-10 years an additional 51 wells/cavern will be developed to maintain the 800,000 TPY production rate
  • Additional sustaining capex items include piping for the wellfield as well as fresh-water infrastructure expansions at the wellfield and road extensions have been accounted for 
  • The sustaining capex is estimated at US$180 million for the first 25 years of production

 

Operating Expenditure

  • The main OPEX items are natural gas, which will feed a combined heat and power plant for the processing plant and the wellfield, and maintenance costs for both the wellfield and the processing plant
  • Labour is also a significant cost and is comprised of 22 non-Gabonese and 388 Gabonese nationals for a total of 410 employees

 

The Banio potash mine is set to be connected to the Mangali port via the Belinga-Mayumba railway

title: Makuutu Mine, Uganda
body:
The Makuutu deposit is comprised of six licenses covering approximately 300 km2 located 120 km east of Kampala in Uganda. The defined mineralisation stretches 37 km long and is situated near high quality tier one infrastructure. Simple mining and low CAPEX processing will produce Mixed Rare Earth Carbonate (MREC) with no radionuclides (Uranium and Thorium).

The Makuutu basket contains a high proportion of magnet and heavy rare earths; including a near-perfect split of magnet rare earths Nd, Pr, Dy and Tb, required for developing the high intensity permanent magnets required for EVs and offshore wind turbines. 

A key characteristic of Makuutu is the geology. The clays of Makuutu, which is similar to the ionic clay-type deposits of southern China and Myanmar, present a low-cost mining, extraction and processing opportunity, and are the most readily accessible global source of heavy REOs. The Makuutu Project will use simple open pit mining and heap desorption processing methods.

The Makuutu IAC deposit has a mineral resource estimate of 617 million tonnes, with enormous upside potential through further exploration. The benefit of IACs is that the deposit is at surface allowing for the development of a low capital, modular project – starting with 5 million tonnes per annum and ability to scale up in time to meet increasing demand and aligned with downstream processing capacity.

Source: Ionic Rare Earths

title: Belinga-Mayumba Railway, Gabon
body:
• Establish a 1,200 km railway corridor linking the Belinga iron ore project in Gabon's northeast to a proposed port at Mayumba on the southern Atlantic Ocean coast
  • The railway will serve Makokou, Ovan, Lastourville and Tchibanga among others
  • The railway will have to be electric in order to limit the carbon footprint, lower costs and electrify all the towns along the route. Fiber optics will also be added
  • The railway is set to have two tracks along with a service track to allow for better maintenance, and open access for all mining operators, freight transporters and passenger services
  • There will also be a double-track asphalt service road, which will help open up the inhabited areas located along the railway route

 

The Belinga-Mayumba railway is expected to serve the Banio potash mine and the Belinga iron ore mine

The Belinga-Mayumba railway is set to be connected to the Mangali port in Mayumba

title: Bélinga Iron Ore Mine, Gabon
body:
Situated in the Belinga range in the northeast of Gabon, the project sits within the province of Ogooué-Ivindo. 

This area, rich in natural resources, is set to become a vital hub of economic activity and development. 

The Belinga deposit, found in 1955, has undergone extensive exploration since 2022. 

In mid-2023, the project entered its production phase, with the first cargo of iron ore being exported from Gabon in December 2023, proving the project’s viability.  

The next three years, efforts will focus on exploration and studies to optimize large-scale mining, creating economic opportunities, sustainable employment, and community benefits. 

Source: Ivindo Iron

 

The Belinga iron ore mine is set to be connected to the Mangali port via the Belinga-Mayumba railway

title: Enchi Project, Ghana
body:
The Enchi Gold Project currently hosts an Indicated Mineral Resource of 743,500 ounces of gold at 0.55 g/t and an Inferred Mineral Resource of 972,000 ounces of gold at 0.65 g/t in a district hosting several 5 million-ounce gold deposits. This 248 km2 land package covers 40 kilometers of Ghana’s prolific Bibiani Shear Zone. The property remains substantially underexplored, with several high priority geochemical and geophysical anomalies yet to be tested by drilling.

  • Locations: Southwest Ghana
  • Minerals: Gold (Au)
  • Area: 248 km2
  • Status: Indicated Mineral Resource1 of 743,500 ounces of gold at 0.55 g/t and an Inferred Mineral Resource1 of 972,000 ounces of gold at 0.65 g/t

title: Tanzania-Zambia Railway Spur
body:
• Build a spur line linking the Tanzania-Zambia railway at Nseluka in northern Zambia via Mbala to Mpulungu port on Lake Tanganyika across an approximate distance of 192 km
  • The spur line is expected to cater to the increase in volume of trade with the Great Lakes countries of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda
  • The line will be used to transport bulk cargo such as sugar, cement, coffee and minerals 
  • By developing this spur, bulk and heavy cargo will be transported by rail, which would be cheaper and efficient for Zambia to the Great Lakes region of East Africa via Lake Tanganyika

title: Marange Diamond Fields (MDF), Zimbabwe
body:
BOD has signed an MoU with Vast Resources plc, an AIM listed exploration company. In terms of the MoU, the two companies would be exchanging past exploration information and forming a special purpose vehicle (‘SPV’) to jointly develop the diamond potential of Zimbabwe. The initial focus of this understanding is on the Marange Diamond Fields (‘MDF’) of eastern Zimbabwe.

Source: Botswana Diamonds 04/2021

title: Thorny River, South Africa
body:
Extensive exploration work has been undertaken on Thorny River which culminated in both a Competent Persons Report (CPR) and Technical Economic Evaluation (TEE).  The former delineated the following exploration parameters for the kimberlite dyke and blow system in the Limpopo Province of South Africa:

  • Grade: 46 – 74 cpht (+1mm BCOS);
  • Diamond value: USD120 – 220/ct (+1mm BCOS) and
  • Volume: 1.2 – 2.1 M tons.

The TEE stated that the kimberlite exploration target at Thorny River area has a grade of between 46 and 74 cpht and diamond value of between $120-220/ct at a bottom cut off of +1mm. For the purposes of the evaluation, a lower grade of 20 cpht was also considered. 

The River medium-cost scenario mining model shows positive operational cash flow net present values for potential future open pit exploitation options at a conceptual level. Any open pit that is formed on the basis of a low revenue assumption (i.e. at revenue factors less than 80%) coupled with the maximum open pit size are indicated to be commercial.

Source: Botswana Diamonds 09/2023

title: Kilimapesa Gold Expansion, Kenya
body:
Phases of Development

  • Phase 1: Develop a 3-year mine plan to support Kilimapesa expansion financing.
  • Phase 2: Conduct a full remodeling of the Kilimapesa Hill deposit, including additional drilling.
  • Phase 3: Update the Mineral Resource Estimate (MRE) under JORC standards.
  • Phase 4: Finalize a 10-year mine plan for the Kilimapesa Hill deposit.

Phase 1 Highlights

  • Independent technical report with a 36-month mine plan for Kilimapesa Hill.
  • Forecast production of 49,155 oz of gold.

Phase 1 Mining & Processing Plan

  • Ore Mined: 2,427,279 t over 36 months.
  • Average Grade: 1.06 g/t gold.

Processing Breakdown

  • Milling/CIL Plant
    • Ore Processed: 529,756 t @ 1.8 g/t.
    • Recovery Rate: 75%.
    • Gold Recovered: 23,002 oz.
  • Heap Leach Plant
    • Ore Processed: 1,897,524 t @ 0.86 g/t.
    • Recovery Rate: 50%.
    • Gold Recovered: 26,153 oz.

Total Production (36 Months)

  • Combined Milling/CIL and Heap Leach production: 49,155 oz of gold.

title: Mozambique-Zambia (MOZA) Power Interconnector
body:
• Build about 375 km of 400 kV transmission lines running from Matambo in Mozambique's Tete province to Chipata in Zambia’s Eastern province
  • Build a lower-voltage link between Feira/Luangwa in eastern Zambia and Zumbo in northern Mozambique

  • The main component involves constructing two single-circuit 400 kV lines connecting the Matambo substation to the Chipata West 330 kV substation, which is set to be upgraded 

  • The transmission lines will run parallel to each other within a right of way (RoW) of 100 m
  • The upgrade works at the Chipata West Substation will include the associated civil and structural works for the extension of the existing 330 kV busbar to provide for the 2x 33 kV transformer bays, installation of 2x 600 MVA 400/330/33 kV transformer, 2 x 400 kV transformer bays ,2x 400 kV line bays, as well as the construction of a control building

  • About 278km of the 400 kV line will be located in Mozambique and 97km in Zambia

  • According to a World Bank December 2024 update, outstanding activities include the procurement of consulting services to finalise tender documents and the project advisory unit is working to mobilise grant funding for this task. The financial audit was completed in July 2023

 

Feasibility Studies 
Feasibility studies coordinated by SAPP using NEPAD IPPF funds (US$1.4 m) and World Bank AREP funds (US$463,300). Utilities also made financial contributions
Studies undertaken by AF Consult (AFRY) of Switzerland
Studies completed in February 2022


System Studies 
System studies conducted for different scenarios
Energy flow across interconnector investigated through an energy model developed for the entire SAPP system. 
The utilisation of the interconnector is above 50%


Project Economics
Project is economically viable
Project has NPV of US$214.5 m at a DF of 10%
Project IRR is 18%


Technical Definition 
Project infrastructure scope developed
LiDAR survey and Geotech carried out for entire line and substation locations


ESIA
ESIA studies coordinated by SAPP using NEPAD IPPF (US$561,349) and World Bank AREP funds (US$150,146)
Studies completed

title: Desert to Power Mini Grid Plants, Eritrea
body:
• Procure solar PV panels, inverters, isolators, mounting systems and electronic equipment with a total installed capacity of 12 MW to be implemented in a modular approach of 6 MW, 3 MW and 3 MW each respectively in Teseney, Barentu and Kerekebet in the Gash Barka region
  • The procurement will also include the distribution line and metering equipment for the connection of the remaining 30% underserved communities with considerable suppressed demand in Barentu and Teseney
  • The project is expected to provide improved energy access to more than 235,000 Eritreans
  • The Executing Agency for the Project will be the Ministry of Energy and Mines and the Eritrean Electric Corporation (EEC)
  • The project is part of the wider Desert to Power programme, also known as the Desert to Power G5 Sahel Facility. The objective is to create the world’s largest solar energy generation zone by harnessing the solar potential of the Sahel countries through 10 GW of solar generation capacity via public, private, on-grid and off-grid projects by 2030
