title: Du Plessis Dam PV2 Solar Plant in Northern Cape, South Africa
body:
Develop the 75 MW Du Plessis Dam Solar Photovoltaic (PV) 2 facility on the remainder of the Farm Du Plessis Dam 179 in the Northern Cape Province

The project falls under the Emthanjeni Local Municipality, which is under the greater Pixley Ka Seme District Municipality

Other Components

  • Transmission Line: 13 2kV double-circuit overhead transmission line to connect the onsite PV facility substation via a 'loop in loop out' configuration to the Eskom Chameleon - Bushbuck 132 kV transmission line (Solar Capital Line)
  • Central Substation: One 132 kV substation central to Du Plessis Dam Farm with a connection to
    the Eskom grid
  • Facility Substation: An onsite 132 kV, six-bay substation to connect the PV facility to the powerline
  • Laydown Area: This area will be used to store equipment and materials and house the construction camp
  • Offices: Temporary offices will also be constructed to manage construction activities from a central point
  • Additional Infrastructure: Access roads (main and internal) (8 km long and 8 m wide), potential water pipeline for potable water (5 km) and stormwater infrastructure

title: El-Shohdaa Hospital, Egypt
body:
The Shohdaa Hospital is a a 200-bed healthcare facility situated in Al-Monoufeya Governorate, Egypt.

This state-of-the-art hospital comprises five floors, including:

  •  a main building
  • outpatient department
  • emergency department
  • radiology center
  • central pharmacy
  • laboratories
  • operating rooms
  • among other essential facilities

With a total built up area of 27,500 square meters, the hospital will be equipped with the latest medical technology and equipment, ensuring top-quality healthcare services.

(Source: Hassan Allam Holding)

title: Ntshongweni Urban Development, South Africa
body:
Ntshongweni is a major mixed-use project in the outer western part of the eThekwini metro, approximately 30 km from Durban. It is strategically located within the Durban-Free State-Johannesburg logistics corridor and spans a total area of 2,000 hectares. 

The project has the following features:

  • The first phase includes an 85,000 m² regional shopping mall situated on 14 hectares near the N3 and M13 routes. This phase also incorporates mixed-use residential and commercial developments spanning 78 hectares.
  • Over 20,000 homes. Residential options range from high-end lifestyle units to retirement and low-cost housing.
  •  A light industrial, logistics, and business park precinct will attract investments and create jobs.
  • Half of the development area is reserved for open spaces, emphasizing outdoor activities like cycling and adventure nodes such as Shongweni Dam and Giba Gorge.

title: Westown, South Africa
body:
Westown, located in Shongweni, west of Durban, South Africa, is a significant mixed-use development project. 

The Westown Urban Core is over 100ha in extent and has secured and approved development rights of approximately 520 000m² of bulk floor area. The activation of these rights has begun with the construction of Westown Square which is supported by a number of interconnected precincts, spaces, and experiences that have been launched and will roll-out over the next 5 to 10 years. These include:

  • Farrier Business Park – Warehousing & Logistics Hub
  • Parc Ferme – Motor Focused Commercial Hub
  • Westown Mixed-Use – 22 000m2 of floor area
  • Shongweni Eco-Park by Balwin – the 1st of 3,000 units in the urban core
  • The West Private Hospital – 100 day & surgical beds
  • Westown Apartments – the 2nd phase of residential development
  • The Westown Urban Core forms part of the 2,000ha Shongweni Urban Development, a proclaimed Catalytic Projects by the eThekwini Municipality, that is also supported at provincial and national government levels.

Source: Westown

body:
Construction of a new western breakwater to protect the New-Damietta harbor and also to expand its ship capacity, the new western breakwater is about 3600ml. and consists of Core layer (rock size of 100 to 400 Km), First filtration layer (rock size of 200 to 400 Km), Protection and filter layers (rock size of 500 to 2000 Km), Armor Layer (rock size of 2500 to 3000 Km), tetrapod And precast concrete cube layer (size of 4.0 to 14.0 Ton).

The scope of work includes supply of crushed rocks “Dolomite” of 1,556,211 m3, rock size varies from 100 kg to 3000 kg each, concrete Tetrapod (4,6,10&14 Ton) size equals 35,364-unit, concrete Qty about 147,000 m3, Concrete cube (4&10 Ton) size of 15,519-unit, and concrete quantity is about 60,000 m.

title: Masdar Infinity Wind Farm in Gulf of Suez, Egypt
body:
Build a 200 MW wind power plant near the Red Sea shoreline in Ras Ghareb, Gulf of Suez region

The plant is estimated to produce 810,000MWh per year. Consequentially, it is predicted to avoid 403,672 tonnes of CO2eq emissions per year

An Egyptian-Emirati joint venture of Infinity Power and Abu Dhabi Future Energy Company (Masdar) will develop, finance, and operate the project, with commercial operations expected to commence in October 2026

The project is located on a land area of 37.5 square km and will operate for 20 years

The plant will feature  26 to 28 turbines, each with a capacity of 7.2 – 7.8 MW. The turbines will have a hub height of 110 m and a rotor diameter of 182 m for a total tip height of 201 m

 

Supporting infrastructure and utility elements for the project will include:
- Cables that will connect the turbines to an onsite substation
- Substation that converts the output from the turbines to a voltage that is appropriate for connection
with the National Grid
- Onsite building infrastructure that will include an administrative building (offices) and a warehouse for
storage of equipment and machinery
- Road network for ease of access of various project components throughout the site


Associated facilities will mainly include an Overhead Transmission Line (OHTL) that will connect from
the substation onsite to the National Grid

 

 

Ras Ghareb is seen as one of the best locations in the world for harnessing wind energy due to its high stable wind speeds averaging between 8 to 10 m/s at a height of 100m, along with the availability of large uninhabited desert areas

title: Gulf of Suez 2 Wind Farm, Egypt
body:
• Build a 654 MW wind power plant in the Gulf of El Zayt along the Gulf of Suez
  • Build a 35 km 220 kV transmission line

The key component of the project includes the wind turbines:
- There will be 104 wind turbines spread over along the eastern side of the original project site. 84 of the 104 wind turbines will each have a 6 MW capacity. The turbine model has a hub height of 97.5 m, rotor diameter of 16 5m and thus a tip height of 180 m.
- The extension to the project site includes 20 wind turbines and will each have a 7.5 MW capacity, a hub height of 110 m, rotor diameter of 182 m and a tip height of 200 m

The overall project is being built across 75.8 square km and is expected to generate 2,700-3,000 GWh to supply around 1-1.1 million people

The plant will be operated under a 25-year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with the Egyptian Electricity Transmission Company (EETC)

It will be connected to the grid over two phases, with full commercial operation planned in Q3 2025

title: Mongoumba River Port, Central African Republic
body:
​The Mongoumba River Port project aims to construct a port on the Ubangi River in the town of Mongoumba, located in the Lobaye Prefecture of the Central African Republic (CAR). This initiative is a component of the broader Pointe Noire-Brazzaville-Bangui-N'Djamena multimodal transport corridor, which seeks to enhance inter-state road and river transport systems, thereby improving regional connectivity and trade.

Technical Scope:

The project involves constructing a river port in Mongoumba, approximately 77 km from Bangui. This port will serve as a critical junction, facilitating the transfer of goods and passengers between river and road transport. The construction includes embarkation and disembarkation facilities, associated easements, and comprehensive project management, encompassing the review of technical studies and construction oversight.

title: Salkadamna Coal Complex, Niger
body:
• Develop an open-pit coal mine in the Tahoua region with a minimum annual production capacity of 3 million tonnes of coal (lignite), with current reserves estimated at 69 million tonnes
  • The project will supply a 5,200 MW coal-fired thermal power plant, the first phase of which will have a capacity of 600 MW
  • The project will include transmission lines and transformer stations, and a coal briquette factory
  • The coal-fired power station and transmission lines will be built under the first phase of the project
  • The main 330 kV transmission line will run for 400 km between Salkadamna and Niamey, with an additional line covering 200 km between Salkadamna-Tahoua-Malbaza
  • The second phase will focus on manufacturing coal mineral briquettes for domestic use, as a substitute for wood to reduce deforestation; the coal briquette plant will have a capacity of 100,000 tonnes a year

 

The project objectives are to:

  • Increase electric power capacity to meet the demands of the Nigerien population;
  • Export power to Niger’s neighbouring countries through the West African Power Pool (WAPP);
  • Increase national energy production to reduce dependence on external sources;
  • Household use of briquettes as a wood substitute.

title: Abu Qir Port Expansion, Egypt
body:
The Abu Qir Port is located on the Mediterranean coast of Egypt, near the ruins of the ancient Canopus and to the northeast of Alexandria. 

The port expansion includes the northern and southern areas of the facility as well as newly acquired land. The project is scheduled across three phases over two years. It will involve 223 million cubic meters of dredging works, along with excavation and backfill works using the latest construction methodologies and equipment. Once complete, the port will feature 9,800 lane meters of beach with 6,600 lane meters of submerged breakwaters, 11,900 lane meters of vertical breakwaters, and 2,400 lane meters of emerged breakwaters.

(Source: Hill International)

migration_status: near the ruins of the ancient Canopus and to the northeast of Alexandria.

title: Sokhna Port Expansion, Egypt
body:
The Sokhna Port Expansion in Egypt is a comprehensive initiative aimed at enhancing the port's capacity and reinforcing its strategic importance in global maritime trade. Below is an overview of the project's technical scope, involved companies, and timeline:​

Technical Scope of Work:

  • New Container Terminal: Development of a 2,600-meter-long container terminal, covering an area of 1.6 million square meters, capable of accommodating vessels up to 400 meters in length. ​
  • Berth Construction: Development of a 900-meter-long, 33-meter-wide berth designed to accommodate large container vessels, supported by deep foundation diaphragm walls extending up to 64 meters. The berth enables the terminal to handle ships up to 400 meters in length.
  • Logistics Park: Construction of the Sokhna Logistics Park, located 10 kilometers from the port, designed to support various industries, including agriculture, pharmaceuticals, retail, automotive, and textiles.

title: Kidepo International Airport, Uganda
body:
The Kidepo International Airport is a strategic aviation infrastructure project being developed in Kaabong District, northeastern Uganda, aimed at improving international access to the Kidepo Valley National Park, one of Africa’s most remote and biologically diverse protected areas. The airport is intended to boost tourism, trade, and cross-border connectivity near Uganda’s borders with South Sudan and Kenya.

Technical Scope of Work:

  • Runway Construction: The airport will feature a 3,500-meter-long, asphalt-surfaced runway, designed to accommodate wide-body, long-haul aircraft, including models such as the Boeing 777.
  • Terminal Facilities: The design includes capacity to handle up to 2 million passengers per year, with dedicated space for customs, immigration, cargo, and tourism services.
  • Taxiways and Aprons: The airport will include high-strength taxiways and aircraft parking aprons designed for Category C and D aircraft operations, ensuring safe maneuvering and turnaround of large jets.
  • Navigational and Safety Systems: Planned installations include precision approach lighting, airfield ground lighting, and air traffic control systems in compliance with ICAO safety and operational standards. 
  • Ancillary Infrastructure: Supporting infrastructure includes perimeter fencing, access roads, firefighting and rescue services, ground handling facilities, and stormwater management systems to accommodate the park’s semi-arid climate.

title: Mohammed V International Airport Expansion, Morocco
body:
The Mohammed V International Airport Expansion Project in Casablanca, Morocco, is a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing the airport's capacity and facilities in preparation for the 2030 FIFA World Cup, which Morocco will co-host with Spain and Portugal.​

Technical Scope of Work:

  • New Terminal Construction: The project involves the construction of a new H-shaped terminal designed to accommodate an additional 20 million passengers annually.
  • Integration with High-Speed Rail: The terminal will feature a direct connection to the planned high-speed rail network linking Kenitra to Marrakech, enhancing regional connectivity. ​
  • Additional Infrastructure: The expansion includes the construction of a parallel runway measuring 3,700 meters by 45 meters, a new 42-meter-high control tower, and expanded aircraft parking areas.

title: Baomahun Gold Project, Sierra Leone
body:
Baomahun Gold Project is set to become Sierra Leone’s first large scale commercial gold mine. Covering a land area of 124.27km², Baomahun has a JORC certified resource of 5.81Moz of gold across both open pit and underground mining, making it one of the largest gold development projects in Africa.

Baomahun Gold Project is situated approximately 200km east of the capital Freetown, in the Valunia and Kunike Barina Chiefdoms in the Bo and Tonkolili Districts respectively. Our host community is the village of Baomahun, which is home to a population of approximately 7,000 people. The provincial capital of Bo, home to approximately 500,000 people, is approximately 60km south of the project.

  • Mineral Resource Estimate: 4.5 Moz Au (JORC Compliant)
  • Target Production: 185,000 oz per year in the first five years
  • Resource Grade: 1.92g/t Au
  • Exploration Potential: Significant upside and exploration potential with only 1.5km of 12km strike length explored and drilled so far within Baomahun licence area

Baomahun Gold Project will include significant investment in new site infrastructure – from worker accommodation to processing facilities, power generation, roads, airstrip, and tailings and water management facilities.

  • Power Generation: 34MW Power Generation including Solar PV, Battery Energy Storage Systems & Diesel Generators
  • Site Access: 64km site access road and airstrip
  • Accommodation: 200-person camp onsite
  • Mineral Processing: 2.5mtpa CIL processing plant
  • Mine Water and Tailings Management: Mine Water Management Plan outlines best practice approach for water management onsite. Tailings Storage Facility designed to exceed modern standards.

Source: FG Gold

title: Ewoyaa Lithium Project, Ghana
body:
The project is well located to excellent infrastructure and is proven to produce a spodumene concentrate product suitable for conversion to be used in EV batteries.

In June 2023, the Company announced its Definitive Feasibility Study (“DFS”) for the Ewoyaa Project, confirming the Project’s economic viability and profitability potential for the production of 3.6Mt spodumene concentrate over a 12-year Life of Mine (“LOM”).

MINERAL RESOURCE ESTIMATE (July 2024)

  • 36.8Mt at 1.24% Li₂O, reported in accordance with the JORC Code (2012)
    81% of the Total Resource now in the higher confidence Measured and Indicated categories
  • 3.7Mt at 1.37% in the Measured category
  • 26.1Mt at 1.24% in the Indicated category
  • 7.0Mt @ 1.15% Li₂O in the Inferred category
  • Based on 168,015m of drilling completed to date
  • Significant potential to grow the Resource further

title: Rosh Pinah Expansion, Namibia
body:
The Rosh Pinah 2.0 expansion project envisages the construction of new processing facilities, including the addition of a paste fill and water treatment plant, as well as a dedicated portal and decline to extended deposits.

The project will increase mill throughput from 0.7 million tonnes to 1.3 million tonnes of ore per annum, increasing zinc equivalent production to 170 million pounds per annum, on average.

title: Lola Graphite Project, Guinea
body:
Lola Graphite Project will provide feedstock to Falcon Energy Materials Morroco Anode Plant. 

The Lola Graphite Project is located approximately 1,000 kilometers South-East of Conakry, the capital of the Republic of Guinea. The Lola Graphite Project was named after the nearby town of Lola, located approximately 3.5 kilometers to the east of the deposit.

The Lola Graphite Project deposit is present at surface over a 8.7 kilometers-strike length and has an average of 370 meters in width. The first 20 to 50 meters depth (average of 32 meters) of the deposit is weathered-laterite, free-digging, graphite flakes, which allows for easy grinding and optimal recovery of all flakes sizes. Over 50% of the graphite is large flake (+80mesh), and 26% is “jumbo” flake material (+50 mesh).

  • LOCATION: LOLA DEPOSIT 1,000 kilometers South-East of Conakry
  • LIFESPAN: 25 years
  • PRODUCTION: Graphite Concentrate
  • RESOURCES: 42Mt @ 4.2% Cg

Source: Falcon Energy Materials

title: Sadiola Mine, Mali
body:
Sadiola Mine is a world-class asset with a multi-decade mine life and a robust mineral endowment that underpins significant production growth with increasing returns. Allied is actively focusing on exploration and development of high grade oxide deposits to maximize low-cost oxide feed and boost near-term production and cash flows. 

Simultaneously, the mine is undergoing a phased expansion to increase throughput and handle increasing quantities of high grade fresh rock, with a longer-term gold production target of 300-400koz per year at an AISC below $1,200/oz.

  • Status: Production / Phased Expansion
  • Operation: Open Pit
  • Life of Mine: 19+ years

Mineral Reserves and Resources (as of December 31, 2024)

  • Proven & Probable Mineral Reserves (Koz Au): 6,997
  • Measured & Indicated Mineral Resources (Koz Au): 9,958
  • Inferred Mineral Resources (Koz Au): 496

Source: Allied Gold

title: Otjikoto Mine, Namibia
body:
Otjikoto Mine is located in the north-central part of Namibia, approximately 300 km north of the country’s capital, Windhoek.

Processed ore is sourced from the Otjikoto pit and the Wolfshag underground mine. 

On February 4, 2025, B2Gold announced positive PEA results for the Antelope deposit. Based on the positive results from the PEA, B2Gold believes that the Antelope deposit has the potential for become a small-scale, low-cost, underground gold mine that can supplement the low-grade stockpile production during the period from 2028 to 2032 and result in a meaningful production profile for Otjikoto into the next decade. 

The PEA for the Antelope deposit indicates an initial mine life of 5 years and total production of 327,000 ounces averaging approximately 65,000 ounces per year over the life-of-mine. In combination with the processing of existing low-grade stockpiles, production from the Antelope deposit has the potential to increase the Otjikoto mine production to approximately 110,000 ounces per year for 2029 through 2032. 

  • MINE TYPE: Open Pit / Underground
  • METALS MINED: Gold
  • PROCESSING THROUGHPUT: 3.4 Mtpa
  • MINERAL RESERVE GRADE: 2.07 g/t Au
  • GOLD RECOVERY: ~98.0%

Source: B2Gold Crop.

title: Karibib Project, Namibia
body:
Karibib Lithium Project is also referred to as Lepidico's Phase 1 Project. 

Mining Operations

  • Two open-pit mines redeveloped from five main pegmatites (Helikon 1 – 5).
  • Helikon 1 is located 750 m south of Helikon 2 – 5 pegmatites.

Processing & Infrastructure

  • Construction of a mineral concentrator at the site.
  • Development of associated infrastructure to support mining and processing operations.

Mineral Resource Estimate

  • Total Resource: 11.24 Mt @ 0.43% Li₂O.

Potential Expansion 

  • 2-4x scale-up for a Phase 2 project.
  • Established infrastructure and water permit in place for 2x expansion.

title: Molo Project, Madagascar
body:
The original Molo Project

The Molo mine is located some 160 km southeast of Madagascar’s administrative capital (and port city) of Toliara, in the Tulear region and about 220 km NW of Fort Dauphin and is approximately 13 km NE of the local village of Fotadrevo. The Molo project consists of an open pit mine, and modular processing plant. As well as the associated infrastructure consisting of water infrastructure, power (Thermal, Solar and BES) and accommodation camp and plant offices, laboratory, and change house.

Ground was broken in April 2022 and the plant erection commenced on 30 November 2022 and the placement of all 106 plant modules concluded on 24 December 2022. This was followed by piping and electrical hook ups. The plant commissioning is nearing completion and the RoM is 240 ktpa producing 17 ktpa of high Carbon graphite flake. One of the very challenging hurdles to overcome – among many – were the post-Covid global logistical challenges and the near complete lack of in -country logistical infrastructure. Recently the milestone number of 500 000 hours of LTI free work was surpassed.

Proposed Molo Phase II

In parallel with the execution of the phase one project, a PEA level study was conducted followed by the rapidly completed AACE Class 3 feasibility study. The phase two approach is still modular, but it will have a RoM of 2.5 mtpa looking to produce 150ktpa of high Carbon graphite flake. The processing stages are identical to the phase I plant, but the associated infrastructure required will be substantially bigger, should the financial model and economic evaluation trigger a further investment decision.

Source: Erudite

title: Kalengwa Copper-Silver Project, Zambia
body:
This exploration project is in the area surrounding the historic, high-grade Kalengwa open pit copper mine. The stratigraphic package at Kalengwa is similar to that hosting the world-class deposits in the Copperbelt. These deposits are thought to be formed from hydrothermal and ore-bearing fluids sourced from the intrusives of the Hook Granite complex. It is notable that such intrusives occur at the Kalengwa mine and are known from historic third party drilling and airborne magnetic surveying to occur at, or close to, several other prospects within the Licence.

Source: Bezant Resources

title: Hope Copper-Gold Project, Namibia
body:
Background

Bezant holds three mineral licences (i.e., a mining licence and two exploration licences) which have multiple known deposits along the Matchless Copper Belt within the Swakopmund District. This report summaries the technical work completed to date, focussing primarily on the Hope Deposit, and secondarily on the preliminary studies completed for the Gorob and Vendome deposits. The Hope and Gorob Project, of which Bezant holds a 70% interest, is a copper-gold deposit located approximately 250km southwest of Namibia’s capital, Windhoek and 120km southeast of Walvis Bay, the main port city of Namibia. 

Highlights

Bezant Resources recently (16 October 2024) received the notice of preparedness for the Hope and Gorob Project for the granting of a Mining Licence, where the Hope and multiple other deposits are located. This Report is largely specific to the near-term development of the Hope Deposit where mining and processing operations are expected to commence and does not include a detailed assessment of other deposits and targets comprising the wider Mineral Resource estimate.

The latest Hope pit optimisation results suggest a potential plant feed of 2.4Mt RoM, which has:

  • a copper grade of 1.25% and a gold grade of 0.25g/t;
  • approximately five years of LoM, assuming a production rate of 480ktpa; and
  • an operating cost estimate of USD50.80 per tonne RoM. This is indicative of a tonne of contained copper in concentrate cost of USD5,020. 

The Hope Deposit’s initial stope optimisation suggests an underground potential of 0.9Mt RoM, with:

  • a copper grade of 2.04% and a gold grade of 0.48g/t; and
  • there is an additional LoM potential of just over four years when assuming an underground mining rate of 220ktpa.

In addition to the Hope Deposit, the Gorob and Vendome deposits have a potential 1.01Mt RoM supported by the preliminary mine design and production schedule:

  • with an average RoM copper grade of 1.28%; and
  • providing just over two years of planned production (i.e., 480ktpa).
meta_description: Background
migration_status: success

title: Coola Project, Angola
body:
The Coola Exploration Project License is located in central Angola, north of Pensana’s Longonjo Rare Earth Refinery Project.

Since the award of the prospecting license in March 2020, multiple field programs have been undertaken involving stream sediment sampling, soil sampling, geological mapping, rock chip sampling, trench and pit sampling, geophysical surveying, preliminary mineralogical investigations and assaying. The outcome of this work has been the identification of two highly prospective target areas upon which future workstreams are focused, namely:

  • Coola carbonatite – which comprises a REE enriched carbonatite ring dyke, a potentially supergene REE enriched sand covered central diatreme and a high-grade fluorite in fenite occurrence.
  • Sulima West – where high grade REE mineralisation in laterite and phosphate in an apatite/maghemite have been discovered.

Coola Carbonatite

The Coola carbonatite is a roughly circular 900 metre wide body and comprises an incomplete carbonatite ring dyke surrounded by fenite, enclosing a soil covered central diatreme of roughly 600 metres diameter.

The northeastern outcropping portion of the ring dyke attains widths of 50 metres and comprises fresh pink dolomitic carbonatite containing up to 5% TREO.

Sulima West

Sulima West is a roughly 5-kilometre diameter alkaline ring complex with a corresponding high radiometric response. Ten historic trenches each of about 90 metres in length located in the western segment of the structure were identified from satellite imagery and corresponded with the highest radiometric response.

The trenches are excavated into an iron/manganese-rich laterite very similar in appearance to the rare earth element laterite developed over the Longonjo carbonatite. Initial reconnaissance sampling of the trenches returned significant values for rare earth oxides with up to 10.6% TREO encountered in the laterite. Manganese oxide values of up 15.9% MnO were also reported.

Source: Pensana

title: Twin Hills Gold Project, Namibia
body:
The Twin Hills Gold Project is located within Namibia’s prospective Damara Orogenic Belt, in proximity to and along strike of the producing, open-pit Navachab and Otjikoto gold mines.

Twin Hills is a sedimentary-hosted, structurally controlled gold deposit that fits the broad orogenic lode gold model and is amenable to conventional open-pit gold mining and carbon-in-leach metallurgical processing.

Location

The Twin Hills Gold Project is located in central Namibia approximately 150 km northwest of the capital city of Namibia, Windhoek.

The Project is comprised of 11 exclusive prospecting licenses (EPLs) granted by the government of Namibia, which are held over a combined area of 153,206 ha in and around the regional towns and settlements of Usakos, Karibib, Omaruru, and Wilhelmstal in the Erongo Region of Namibia. 

Plant Mineral Processing

The Twin Hills process plant will have a nameplate capacity of 5.0 Mtpa of ore and a nominal capacity of ~650 tonnes per hour (tph).

Gold recovery will be achieved using a 3-stage crushing, ball milling, gravity, pre-oxidation, carbon-in-leach (“CIL”), cyanide detoxification and tailings thickening and filtration process plant flowsheet. The process is based on conventional unit operations well proven in the industry and will achieve high recoveries from all major rock types that are planned to be processed.

Source: Osino Resources

title: Etango Project, Namibia
body:
Etango Uranium Project is located in the Erongo Region of Namibia, 30 kilometres south-east of Swakopmund. It possesses a uranium Mineral Resource endowment of 207 Mlbs of contained U3O8 (100ppm U308 cut-off).

In December 2022, completed the Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS) on Etango at 8Mtpa. The DFS on Etango (8Mtpa) is a study of world-class quality, with input from leading experts across each facet of mining uranium in Namibia. Critically, the DFS confirmed, to a definitive level, the robust overall viability of development and operation of the Etango (8Mtpa) Project.

Etango Mining Licence application was granted in December 2023. 

  • Initial mine life: 15+ years
  • Throughput capacity: 8 Mtpa
  • Processing yield: 87.8%
  • Total production: 52.6 Mlb U3O8

Source: Bannerman Energy

title: Matruh Sallum Rail, Egypt
body:
Construction of 220 kilometers Matrouh - Sallum railway. This project is part of Egypt-Libya Rail Link project which involves the construction of a major transnational railway line spanning approximately 1,080 kilometers, designed to link Alexandria on Egypt’s north coast to Benghazi in eastern Libya.

This strategic corridor will enhance regional connectivity, support trade and economic integration between Egypt and Libya, and lay the groundwork for broader North African rail integration.

Route and Geography

  • Total Length (Alexandria - Benghazi): ~1,080 km
  • Egypt Section (Alexandria - Sallum): ~520 km
    • Matruh Sallum ~220 km
  • Libya Section (Sallum - Benghazi): ~560 km

title: Aswan Abu Simbel Rail, Egypt
body:
This project is part of Cairo-Khartoum Corridor. 

The project involves the construction of a 1,500-kilometre railway connecting Aswan in southern Egypt to Khartoum in Sudan, passing through Toshka and Abu Simbel in Egypt, and a 66-kilometre bridge to Wadi Halfa in northern Sudan.

The Egyptian section of Egypt-Sudan Rail Link spans approximately 400 kilometres, linking Aswan, Toshka, and Abu Simbel in southern Egypt to Wadi Halfa in northern Sudan. The first phase of the project involves the construction of the 280-kilometre railway between Aswan and Toshka.

Project Overview

  • Total Railway Length: 1,500 km
  • Route: Connects Aswan (Egypt) to Khartoum (Sudan)
  • Key Locations:
    • Egypt: Aswan, Toshka, Abu Simbel
    • Sudan: Wadi Halfa, Khartoum
  • Bridge: 66 km bridge connecting the railway to Wadi Halfa in Sudan

Project Breakdown

  • Egyptian Section:
    • Length: 400 km
    • Route: Connects Aswan, Toshka, and Abu Simbel to Wadi Halfa (Sudan)
  • First Phase:
    • Railway Length: 280 km
    • Route: Aswan to Toshka

title: Sustainable and Inclusive Secondary Cities Project, Côte d'Ivoire
body:
The primary focus of the Project will be to support inclusive, green and climate-resilient urban development through investments in urban infrastructure and services (e.g., schools, health centers, recreational facilities, markets, urban roads, sanitation, drainage, and solid waste management) and support to local governments in matters related to urban planning, land administration, municipal services, infrastructure management, and local economic development. 

The Project Development Objective (PDO) will be achieved with investments channeled through the following four components: 

Component 1 - Green and Climate Resilient Urban infrastructure (US$250 million), will build or rehabilitate urban infrastructure to improve urban living conditions, promote local economic development, and foster social inclusion.

  •  renovation and construction works such as fences, classrooms, canteens, gender-segregated latrines, painting, and maintenance of public buildings
  • purchase of goods for the renovated facilities and to support local women and youth associations; 
  • tree planting, cleaning, and anti-erosion measures
  • construction and rehabilitation of health and education facilities, notably primary and secondary schools, vocational education centres, public libraries, cultural centres, childcare centres, local health centres, maternities, and dispensaries
  • greening of public spaces
  • creation and protection of green spaces such as parks, forests, and riverbanks
  • investments in the rehabilitation and construction of economic infrastructure such as public markets, cattle markets, and bus stations
  • rehabilitation or construction of about 70km of urban roads
  • the preparation of Sanitation and Drainage Master Plans
  • the construction of approximately 30 km of stormwater channels and complementary Nature Based Solutions to reduce and manage floods
  • the preparation of Communal Solid Waste Management Plans

Component 2 - Support to Local Governments (US$30 million) aims to strengthen the capacity of local governments in matters related to urban planning, land administration, and municipal services

  • update and preparation of climate and disaster informed Urban Master Plans, Detailed Urban Plans, and Local Development Plans
  • regularization of urban subdivisions, urban land tenure, and housing policies
  • establishment of Geomatics Units in selected target cities
  • hiring of municipal engineers to help plan and oversee project activities and to strengthen local governments’ capacity to program, operate, and maintain urban infrastructure
  • formulation and implementation of technical assistance and training plans to address matters such as green and climate resilient urban infrastructure, urban infrastructure operations and maintenance programming, institutional operations, local economic development, urban planning, and social and environmental safeguards
  • hiring community organizers and implementation of activities aiming at encouraging and strengthening citizen engagement
  • prepare studies and strategies to support local economic development and private sector participation,
  • establish or reinforce local economic development services;
  • promote sustainable development of local food systems

Component 3 - Project Management (US$20 million) will finance project management and coordination costs

  • staffing, training, equipment, and operating costs for the expansion of the Project Coordination Unit 
  • establishment of the project Monitoring & Evaluation (M&E) system;
  • development and implementation of all Environmental and Social Framework activities 

Source: World Bank

title: Assiut Hydrocracking Complex, Egypt
body:
The Assiut Hydrocracking Complex is designed to convert 2.5 million tonnes per year (50,000 barrels per day) of heavy fuel oil into high-quality petroleum products. 
The final output includes diesel, LPG, naphtha, kerosene, and gasoline. The complex includes the following key processing units:

  • Hydrocracking Unit (HCKU) – The primary unit for producing Diesel Euro V, naphtha (for gasoline blending), and LPG.
  • Distillate Hydrotreating Unit (DHTU) – Processes intermediate products and straight-run kerosene/gas oil from the existing refinery to produce Diesel Euro V.
  • Delayed Coker Unit (DCU) – Produces coke as a byproduct while maximizing net diesel production.
  • Hydrogen Production Unit (HPU) – Generates hydrogen required for DHTU and HCKU by processing natural gas.
  • Sulfur Recovery Unit (SRU) – Recovers sulfur from sour streams, ensuring environmental compliance.

title: Banana Deep Sea Port, DR Congo
body:
• Build a deepwater port in phases in the Kongo Central province along the Atlantic coast
  • The port will become the DRC’s single maritime gateway for containerised cargo
  • The first phase is designed to accommodate the world’s largest vessels and will see the construction of a 600-metre quay, 18-metre draught, handling capacity of 450,000 TEUs (6 million standard containers) a year and storage area of 30 hectares
  • The second phase will extend the quay wall by over 2 km
  • The port will be connected via a network of additional infrastructure, including a free zone and multimodal logistics infrastructure, to the country’s largest urban centres, namely the capital city Kinshasa and the cities of Boma and Matadi
  • The construction of the Banana port will involve several companies, including local enterprises, and is expected to enable the creation of about 85,000 jobs, along with US$1.1 billion in additional trade and US$429m in increased economic output a year

title: OCP Fertilizer Plant, Nigeria
body:

Scope of Work:

  • Ammonia Production Units: Total capacity of 1.5 million tons per year
  • Export Infrastructure: Approximately 70% of ammonia will be exported to Morocco.

title: Casablanca Dakhla Power Link, Morocco
body:
The project involves the construction of a high-voltage (HV) power line spanning approximately 450 km between Casablanca and Dakhla in Western Sahara.

Scope of work includes:

  • Design and installation of a high-voltage transmission system.
  • Construction of transmission towers along the 450 km route.
  • Substation development at key points for voltage regulation and distribution.
  • Integration with the existing power grid to enhance electricity transmission capacity.
  • Cable power capacity is 3,000 MW.

title: Transmission Expansion and Energy Storage (TEES) Programme, Namibia
body:
NamPower is embarking on the Transmission Expansion and Energy Storage (TEES) Project in Namibia. This initiative involves three main components: 

  • Construction of a 465 km 400 kV transmission line, known as the second Auas-Kokerboom transmission line
  • Establishment of a large-scale Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) facility – a 45 MW/90 MWh BESS at the Lithops Substation in the Erongo region
  • Provision of technical assistance to facilitate the implementation of renewable energy projects

title: Jamila North Coast, Egypt
body:
The project is a 130-acre residential development located 263 km from Cairo on Egypt’s North Coast. It includes various residential units, such as chalets, duplexes, hotel apartments, studios, townhouses, and villas, with unit sizes ranging from 75 to 217 square meters.

The scope of work includes:

  • Construction of low-rise residential buildings.
  • Development of supporting infrastructure, including roads, utilities, and underground parking.
  • Construction of a five-star hotel and a shopping mall.
  • Installation of water features, including lakes and a dancing fountain.
  • Construction of recreational facilities, including a clubhouse, gym, spa, and multiple swimming pools.

title: OR Tambo Airport, South Africa
body:
Midfield Cargo Terminal

Scope of Work:

  • Construction of a New Cargo Terminal: Development of the Midfield Cargo Terminal to address the increasing demand for air cargo capacity.
  • Warehousing and Cargo-Holding Facilities: The project includes the construction of modern warehousing and cargo-holding facilities to streamline cargo operations. 
  • Capacity Enhancement: Once fully developed, the Midfield Cargo Terminal is expected to accommodate up to two million tonnes of air cargo per year.

Midfield Passenger Terminal

Scope of Work:

  • Construction of a New Passenger Terminal: Plans include the development of a new Midfield Passenger Terminal to cater to the growing passenger demand.
  • Integration with Existing Infrastructure: The new terminal will be integrated with the current airport facilities to enhance passenger flow and operational efficiency.
  • Capacity and Amenities: While specific details are yet to be finalized, the terminal is expected to feature modern passenger amenities, including boarding gates, lounges, retail spaces, and other essential services.

title: Praia-Dakar-Abidjan Multimodal Corridor
body:
• Develop a 660 km maritime link between the Port of Praia in Cabo Verde and the Port of Dakar in Senegal
  • Develop a 3,164 km supranational highway running from Dakar through The Gambia, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Sierra Leone and Liberia to end in Cote d'Ivoire

The scope of work involves constructing a six-lane (2x3) dual-carriage highway, with country sections divided as follows:

  • Senegal – Part 1 (276km): Dakar-Kaolack-Karang (Gambia border) and Part 2 (114km): Gambia border-Seleti-Bignona-Ziguinchor-Mpak (Guinea Bissau border)
  • The Gambia – Part 1 (25km): Amdallai-Bara-Banjul and Part 2 (64km): Banjul-Mandinaba-Jiboro
  • Guinea Bissau – Mpack-Safim-Bissau-Nhacra-Quebo-Mampata-Guinea border (347km)
  • Guinea – Guinea Bissau border-Boke-Conakry-Forecariah-Pamelap-Sierra Leone border (483km)
  • Sierra Leone – Guinea border-Gbalamuya-Rogbere Junction- Masiaka-Bo-Bandajuma-Gendema-Liberia border (428km)
  • Liberia – Sierra Leone border-Bo-Waterside-Monrovia-Gbarnga-Ganta-Tappita-Toe-Zamu-Cote d’Ivoire border (637km)
  • Cote d’Ivoire – Liberia border-Pekan Barrage-Touleupleu-Blolequin-Guiglo-Duekoue-Daloa-Bouafle-Yamoussoukro (790km)

 

The overall Praia-Dakar-Abidjan corridor is the first part of the Trans-African Highway (TAH) coastal corridor, and is planned to converge with the planned Abidjan-Lagos corridor highway at Bingerville in Cote d’Ivoire

 

Together, the Praia-Dakar-Abidjan and Abidjan-Lagos corridors form part of TAH 7. When completed, it will link to TAH 8, which runs from Lagos to the Port of Mombasa in Kenya, passing through Yaounde in Cameroon, Bangui in the Central African Republic (CAR), Kampala in Uganda and Nairobi in Kenya. This will effectively link the three regions of West Africa (ECOWAS), Central Africa (Economic Community of Central African States; ECCAS) and East Africa (East African Community; EAC)

 

Within West Africa, the Praia-Dakar-Abidjan corridor forms part of the regional transit routes linking important sea ports, namely Dakar, Banjul, Bissau, Conakry, Freetown, Monrovia and Abidjan along the seven coastal countries. This trade route provides an important link through the North-South corridors connecting the landlocked countries of Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger to these ports

 

The Praia-Dakar maritime link scheme aims to generate increased cargo and passenger flows; stimulate trade and economic cooperation between Cabo Verde and the rest of West Africa; facilitate safe, efficient and competitive movement of persons and goods as well as regional and international trade by improving maritime equipment and infrastructure; and simplifying and harmonising the requirements and controls that govern the movement of goods and persons, with a view to reducing transport costs and transit times. A shipping line is expected to commence by the end of 2026

title: Nairobi-Nakuru-Mau Summit Highway, Kenya
body:
• Widen the Nairobi-Nakuru-Mau Summit Highway under a public-private partnership (PPP) model
  • The scheme aims to improve connectivity to Kenya’s Rift Valley, Western Kenya regions and beyond
  • The Nairobi-Nakuru-Mau Summit road forms part of the A8 highway and of the Northern Corridor that connects the Port of Mombasa via Nairobi to Malaba at the border with Uganda and onwards to Kampala
  • Work on the Rironi-Mau Summit road will involve the widening of a 175 km section of the A8 highway between Rironi and Mau Summit into a four-lane dual carriageway. There is potential for future augmentation of the road into a six-lane carriageway if traffic volumes increase
  • The scope of work involves building two additional lanes on one side, service roads for selected township areas and tracks for non-motorised traffic in built-up areas as per the design
  • The Nairobi-Nakuru-Mau Summit Highway project also includes the strengthening of 58 km of the A8 South highway between Rironi and Naivasha. The scope of work involves the improvement of pavement and rehabilitation of shoulders for the existing carriageway
  • The design includes work on three interchanges, three pedestrian overpasses, 35 underpasses for pedestrian/cattle, three vehicular underpasses, two railway overpasses and four railway underpasses along with one foot over-bridge
  • The project includes operation and maintenance (O&M) of the existing A8 road from Rironi to Mau Summit, and strengthening and O&M of the existing 57.8 km two-lane A8 South from Rironi to Naivasha
  • The project is procured as a 30-year PPP concession

title: Burutu Port Expansion, Nigeria
body:
​The Burutu Port Expansion Project in Delta State, Nigeria, is a comprehensive initiative to revitalize and modernize the historic Burutu Port to enhance its capacity and efficiency in handling various cargo types. 

The project's technical scope includes:​

  • Restoring and upgrading current port infrastructure to meet modern operational standards.
  • Constructing new deep-sea berths to accommodate larger vessels, thereby increasing cargo handling capacity. ​
  • Establishment of a 200,000-metric Tonne Oil/Gas Farm: Building storage facilities to support the storage and distribution of oil and gas products, enhancing the port's role in the energy sector. ​
  • Setting up facilities for plywood production, leveraging local timber resources to boost industrial activity.

body:

title: Tunis Sports City, Tunisia
body:
Sports Cities International (SCI) is developing a community centred on sport in Tunis, Tunisia. This 3.6 million square meter development will be home for 100,000 residents and includes a downtown core, golf course and residential district as well as the Ville du Sport where the sports facilities are located. These venues comprise of a 15,000 seat soccer stadium, 5,000 seat multi-purpose facility and an elite sports training and aquatics facility.

While on contract at SCI, Mark Koropecky was the design manager of sports facilities. His responsibilities included ensuring that the architectural design of the sports facilities executed by Pujol Architectura of Barcelona, Spain, met the rigorous design standards of SCI. In addition, he worked with the in-house Strategic Business Development Team to enhance the design of Ville du Sport so as to generate commercial activity throughout full daily and evening cycles. Revenue generating facilities were careful integrated into the master plan of Ville du Sport during the detailed design stage of the sports venues. The resulting 310,000 square meter development fuses recreation, business, leisure, entertainment and sports training facilities within the same environment.

The urban amenities which tie the development into a cohesive urban design include a signature 10,000 square metre oval public plaza, a pedestrian retail concourse and an elevated running track. Mark generated the overall urban design concept for Ville du Sport and managed the preparation of the final allotment plans by Pujol Architectura. He also managed the preparation of the urban planning, architectural and landscape architectural design by Halcrow (Yolles) International, the master planning consultant for Tunis Sports City.

Source: SURF Architecture

title: Douala-Yaoundé Rail Rehabilitation, Cameroon
body:
​The Douala–Yaoundé Rail Rehabilitation Project is a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at modernizing Cameroon's primary railway corridor, enhancing both passenger and freight transport efficiency.​

Project Scope:

  • Track Renewal: The project involves the rehabilitation of approximately 238 kilometers of track between Douala and Yaoundé. ​
  • Bridge Renovation: Bridge enhancements to ensure structural integrity and safety.​
  • Signaling System Upgrades: The modernization of railway signaling systems between Douala and Ngaoundéré.
  • Rolling Stock Procurement: The project includes the acquisition of new locomotives and passenger coaches to replace outdated equipment.

title: Freetown Waste-To-Energy Plant, Sierra Leone
body:
• Build a municipal waste-to-energy plant in Freetown under the independent power producer (IPP) model
  • The plant will process approximately 365,000 tonnes of municipal solid waste annually, converting it into 236.5 GWh of renewable electricity
  • The plant will provide reliable energy access to more than 3.3 million people
  • The project will allow for the safe diversion of approximately 30% of the waste generated in the greater Western Area of Sierra Leone. The Western Area consists of the City of Freetown, the city of Waterloo and some other rural areas, with a combined population of approximately 2.2 million people
  • The power will be supplied to the national grid under a 25-year power purchase agreement with Sierra Leone’s Electricity Distribution and Supply Authority (EDSA) 
  • The facility will provide reliable baseload power, complementing the country’s existing hydropower supply and addressing energy shortages during the dry season
  • By integrating waste management with energy generation, the project addresses two pressing issues: the country’s growing waste crisis and its limited access to electricity
  • The plant will help directly avoid over 94,000 tonnes of CO2 equivalent emissions annually

title: Dakar LNG Terminal, Senegal
body:
The project entails the development of a 140,000 cubic meter gas storage terminal, along with associated production, regasification, and distribution infrastructure to enhance energy security and supply reliability.

Key Features

Gas Storage & Processing Facilities

  • Storage Capacity: 140,000 cubic meters
  • Infrastructure:
    • LNG production facilities
    • Regasification units for converting LNG back into gaseous form
    • Distribution network to supply gas to various end users

Maritime Facilities (Dakar Terminal)

  • LNG Offloading Terminal – Enabling the reception and handling of LNG shipments
  • Seaward-Filled Platform (6 hectares) – Supporting the onshore infrastructure and connecting to the LNG jetty
  • Navigation Infrastructure:
    • Shipping channel
    • Turning basin
    • Safety maneuvering area to facilitate vessel navigation

title: Overberg Wind Farm, South Africa
body:
• Construct the 242 MW Overberg wind farm near Swellendam in the Western Cape 
  • The farm will feature 39 Goldwind 6.2 MW turbines
  • The farm has been developed in two phases, with Richards Bay Minerals (RBM), a subsidiary of Rio Tinto Group, securing the first 230 MW of the total 380 MW export capacity. This will deliver an estimated 750 GWh of clean energy annually to RBM
  • The project is secured with a 20-year private power purchase agreement (PPA)

title: Gabes Wastewater Treatment Plant, Tunisia
body:
• Construct an advanced sewage treatment plant in Gabes alongside the existing sewage treatment facility
  • The plant will have a desalination capacity of 6,000 cubic metres a day (cm/d) and operate using the membrane bioreactor (MBR) method
  • The water produced will be used for industrial purposes, in particular the Tunisian Chemical Group (GCT) plants located near the future facility
  • The contract includes a 10-year operation and maintenance period


Process:

  • The water will be taken from secondary treated water from the Gabes sewage treatment plant under the jurisdiction of the National Offices of Sanitation (ONAS)
  • The plant will adopt a desalination method using a reverse osmosis (RO) process that will ensure the quality of treated water in the advanced sewage treatment facility
  • An MBR using microfiltration (MF) membranes will be installed in the pretreatment of the RO process to remove pollutants (BOD, SS, ammonia/nitrogen, phosphorus) in secondary treated water
  • The system will also respond to fluctuations in the quality of water flowing into existing sewage treatment facilities and the treatment of sludge generated at the MBR facility

Water Intake Facilities:

  • Water intake facility – Secondary treated water from the Gabes sewage treatment plant (inflow water in case of emergency) is taken and sent to the raw water receiving tank
  • Raw water receiving tank (Receiving water tank) –  Since the volume of treated water at the Gabes sewage treatment plant fluctuates with time, a receiving water tank will be installed to adjust for the time variability of the water supply to the advanced sewage treatment facility

WWTP supply water volume: 10,000 cm/d
Supply water quality: ONAS Gabes WWTP treated water – BOD<90mg/L, SS<150mg/L, TN<39mg/L, TP<3mg/L, TDS<3,000mg/L, temperature 17-30℃, pH 7.5

WWTP treated water volume:  6,000 cm/d, distributed via water pipeline to the adjacent GCT plant
Treated water quality: Colourless, odourless, sterile, TDS 300 mg/L or less, pH 6.5-8.5 

RO concentrated water volume:  4,000 cm/d, dumped into the ocean through existing ocean dumping pipes/waterways

Number of series: MBR – 5 trains (5 trains in regular use x 2,000 ccm/d); RO – 5 lines (4 permanent lines x 1,500 cm/d)

Intermediate water tank: The intermediate tanks (MBR tank 200 cubic metres, advanced treatment tank 125 cubic metres, and concentrated drainage tank 85 cubic metres) are planned to have a capacity equivalent to the difference between the pump capacity and the inflow water volume for 2 hours (with a margin of 2.5 hours of storage), taking into account the life of the sequencer that controls pump operation. In addition, the system is basically divided into two tanks to allow for cleaning and maintenance

Sludge treatment: Sludge generated in the process of MBR sewage treatment is dewatered by a multiple plate screw press dehydrator, which is durable, odour-resistant, easy to maintain, and has a proven track record. After dewatering, the dewatered sludge is dried and reduced to about 1/5 of its original volume

Reserve: MBR operates in 5 regular trains (2,000 cm/d/train) and filters 10,000 cm/d. When one train is stopped for maintenance or cleaning, it will be operated in four trains, each train producing 2,500 cm/d
RO is operated in four regular trains (1,500 cm/d/train). The production capacity will be 6,000 cm/d. There is one spare series. One train will be stopped periodically for planned maintenance
Two important water pumps are operated at all times.  Designed with 3 units/location with 1 spare unit
One RO high-pressure pump is stored in the warehouse

title: Mumbezhi Copper Project, Zambia
body:
Mumbezhi Copper Project is situated in the world-class Central African Copperbelt region of north-western Zambia. It is located on a single Large Scale Exploration Licence (30426-HQ-LEL), covering an area of approximately 356 square kilometres. The area is prospective for large tonnage, low to medium grade copper deposits. Several major mines lie proximate to Mumbezhi and are hosted in similar geological settings.

Previous exploration drilling of Mumbezhi was conducted over a period of 10 years by Orpheus Mining Limited, with 50 holes completed across the Nyungu deposits for approximately 9,330m drilled. Historical intercepts of copper-cobalt mineralisation have been described as extensive and located near surface, which demonstrates the potential for a low-cost, large-scale open pit mine development.

Source: Prospect Resources

title: Tangier-Tétouan Railway, Morocco
body:
​The Tangier-Tétouan Railway project is a proposed initiative by Morocco's National Railway Operator (ONCF) to enhance regional connectivity in the northern part of the country. The project encompasses the development of new railway lines, focusing on two primary segments:​

A) Tangier Urban Rail Connections: This segment aims to link Tangier's city center with key infrastructure, including the football stadium and the airport, thereby improving urban mobility and accessibility. ​

B) Tangier-Tétouan Line: A new railway line is proposed to connect the cities of Tangier and Tétouan, facilitating efficient passenger movement between these urban centers.

title: Geba Hydropower Plants, Ethiopia
body:
• Build the estimated 372 MW Geba Stage 1 and 2 hydropower plants on the Geba River in the Oromia Regional State in western Ethiopia
  • Geba 1 will have a capacity of 215 MW with annual production of 935 GWh
  • Geba 2 will have a capacity of 157 MW with annual production of 853 GWh  
  • The projects are proposed to be carried out under the independent power producer (IPP) model
  • Amendments to the existing feasibility/ESIA/RAP studies are being undertaken under the AfDB-supported Mekele-Dallol and Semera-Afdera Power Transmission Supply for Industrial Development and Access Scale-up Project
  • A multi-purpose project feasibility study was completed in February 2005 by Norplan-Norconsult Association, which identified a one-reservoir, two-plant scheme as being the most economic alternative for the Geba River. The Geba reservoir would have live storage of some 1,392 hm3 operating between 2,180 m and 2,160 m
  • The installed capacities of the two plants would be 214.5 MW for Geba 1 and 157 MW for
    Geba 2. Rated heads and flows were 480 m and 50 m3/s for Geba I, and 267 m and 65 m3/s for Geba 2
  • The reservoir inflows for the Geba project were estimated from the Sor river at Metu. There are no significant inflows between the reservoir and the two plants
  • The construction of the Geba dam increases the flow of the Baro river at Gambela by 20 m3/s, which can be used for irrigation of the Gambela area
  • The potential in the downstream Geba river is in the range of 1,100 MW with the four hydropower plant projects: Geba 3 (80 MW), Geba 4 (150 MW), Geba 5 (150 MW) and Geba 6 (750 MW)

title: Halelle Werabesa Hydropower Plants, Ethiopia
body:
• Build the 422 MW Halelle Werabesa Stage 1 and 2 hydropower plants about 160 km southwest of Addis Ababa
  • The Halele Worabesa project was studied at the feasibility level (Stage I in August 2000 by Lahmayer-Electrowatt-Knight Piesold and Stage II in July 2005 by Lahmayer International)
  • The overall scheme involves two cascade projects with reservoirs at both sites
  • The Stage 1 scheme will be the first development of the cascade and the Halele dam will provide the capacity to regulate the Gilgel Gibe flows
  • The downstream Stage 2 scheme will be regulated by the huge Halele reservoir (inter-annual storage)
  • The future downstream Gilgel Gibe 3 hydropower project will also be taking advantage of the Halele Worabesa scheme regulation, but to a lesser extent
  • At Halele, an 85 m high rock fill dam (Stage 1) will provide 2,900 hm3 of live storage between operating levels 1,551 m and 1,579 m. The 96 MW powerhouse has a rated head of 89 m and a rated flow of 124 m3/s
  • The additional development includes a second dam and powerhouse at Worabesa (Stage 2) exploiting the 310 m gross head. The Worabesa reservoir would have a live storage of 106 hm3 operating between 1,450 m and 1,460 m. The proposed installed capacity at the site is 326 MW, with a rated head of 296 m and a rated flow of 128 m3/s
  • The firm production for the Halele Worabesa scheme with a total installed capacity of 422 MW will be 2,030 GWh/year or a total cost of $474M ($1,100 per kW of installed capacity); the total average production is expected to be 2,245 GWh per year
  • The project is under Mekele-Dallol and Semera-Afdera Power Transmission Supply for Industrial Development and Access Scale-up Project.

title: Mano Kongo Hydropower Project, Sierra Leone/Liberia
body:
• Build a 180 MW hydroelectric dam on the Mano River border between Liberia and Sierra Leone
  • The Mano River originates in the Guinea Highlands in Liberia and forms part of the Liberia-Sierra Leone border
  • The project is being led by IPSL Ghana
  • Construction is planned to start in 2025, with operations beginning in 2030
  • The Mano River Union (MRU) Secretariat has been instrumental in facilitating the signing of memoranda of understanding (MoUs) between the governments of Liberia and Sierra Leone, which are key stakeholders in this initiative

body:

Bloomfields is a large-scale mixed-use residential development, designed to integrate modern urban living with commercial, administrative, and recreational amenities. The project aims to create a self-sustaining community, offering:

title: Urban Water Sector Reform and Akure Water Supply and Sanitation, Nigeria
body:
The project scope consists of two major components: 

Component 1

Infrastructures on Akure city: 

  • Works  for  the  rehabilitation,  extension  and  densification  of  the  distribution  network,  including the implementation of water meters on the networks and on all connections
  • Works for the transmission systems
  • Works for the rehabilitation of production facilities

Component 2

Institutional: 

  • Project Management Support to Water Utilities;
  • Technical Assistance to Water Utilities;
  • Technical Assistance to the State Ministry in charge of water supply.

The under-listed project, specific activities are proposed for execution within the Akure water supply project:

  • Reconstruct the collapsed Dam’s Weir at Owena Ondo Road and then rehabilitate the Headworks to original Designed Capacity toservice its catchment towns.
  • Supply water to the satellite towns along the route of the transmission main of the Dam Water Supply Project not covered by assistance from the  French  Development  Bank  (AFD)  for the reticulation of water from the Multipurpose Dam Water Supply Project.
  • Provide  basic  water  services  in  the  remaining  50%  area  of  the  state  capital  that  cannot  be  covered  by AFD-funded project

Source: African Development Bank

title: Chad-Libya-Egypt Road, Egypt
body:
Build a 400 km road stretching from the Kufra region on the border with Libya to the Al-Aweinat region. The route is part of a 1,730 km road that begins in Chad and runs through Libya to end in Egypt
 


The Chad-Libya-Egypt road has two other sections:

  • A 393 km section stretching from the Kufra region in southeastern Libya and extending to the east of the Al-Sar area on the border with Chad
  • A 930 km section in Chad, running from the border with Libya to the city of Amdjarass and ending at the city of Abeche

title: Trans-Kalahari Railway (TKR)
body:
• Total Length: 1,500 km
  • Countries Involved: South Africa, Namibia, Botswana

Project Scope & Route

The Trans-Kalahari Railway (TKR) is a strategic railway corridor designed to provide a direct connection between South Africa and Walvis Bay in Namibia, with potential to serve as a coal export route for Botswana. The railway:

  • Starts at the Mmamabula coal fields in Botswana, connecting to the existing railway at Rasesa.
  • Extends westward past Molepolole and east of Letlhakeng, aligning with the Molepolole-Kang road near Maboane and continuing to Maramosu.
  • Passes through Gobabis and Omitara in eastern Namibia before aligning with the Trans-Kalahari Corridor (TKC) at Okahandja, leading to Walvis Bay.
  • Connects major cities including Walvis Bay, Windhoek, Gaborone, and Pretoria.

title: Steelpoortdrift Vanadium Project, South Africa
body:
Steelpoortdrift Project boasts a substantial vanadium deposit for generations to come with a Mineral Resource of 680 million tons at an average in-situ grade of 0.70% V2O5 (equivalent to 4.74 million tons of contained metal) and a Proved and Probable Ore Reserve of 77 million tons at an average in-situ grade of 0.72% V2O5 (equivalent to 0.55 million tons of contained metal). From Steelpoortdrift, VR8 intends to produce a vanadium rich concentrate, which will then be upgraded to Vanadium Pentoxide Flake (98% V2O5) and Vanadium Pentoxide Powder (99.5% V2O5) at the Company’s Salt Roast Leach (“SRL”) plant.

At the proposed throughput rates, the Steelpoortdrift Project has capacity to produce a significant quantity of high-quality vanadium over a lifespan of 180 years (based off the size of the JORC resource). This aligns perfectly with our commitment to shaping a sustainable and innovative future.

The concentrate received from the Steelpoortdrift Project will be processed through the state of the art Salt Roast Leach Plant to produce up to an average of 18,000t of Vanadium Pentoxide (V2O5) per annum.

Source: Vanadium Resources

title: Corridor Sands, Mozambique
body:
MRG’s Corridor Central and Corridor South portfolio at the Corridor Projects in Mozambique includes two contiguous tenements containing 13 high-priority targets.

The tenements are strategically located approximately 10km south of the Corridor Sands project, where Dingsheng Minerals has invested significantly. Additionally, Rio Tinto and Savannah Resources are planning to develop the Chilubane deposit, located 10km south of MRG’s Corridor projects.

Corridor Central (6620L) comprises 179km2 and Corridor South comprises 208km2. Both tenements cover palaeodunes known from historic drilling to host significant HMS mineralisation.

Within the Corridor Projects are the Koko Massava, Nhacutse and Poiombo deposits. MRG announced Mineral Resource estimates for all three deposits in 2021/22. 

Koko Massava has the potential to be the foundation of a multi-decade mine operation at Corridor Sands. 

Source: MRG Metals

Corridor Sands Project is a long-life mineral sands development focused on the extraction and processing of heavy minerals, primarily titano-magnetite, ilmenite, and non-magnetic minerals. The project is expected to have a mine life of 26 years with substantial annual production targets.

Production Capacity

  • Titano-magnetite: 262,000 tonnes per year
  • Ilmenite: 369,000 tonnes per year
  • Non-magnetic minerals: 48,000 tonnes per year

Project Scope & Development

  • Large-scale open-pit mining operation
  • Mineral processing facilities to separate and refine heavy mineral concentrate
  • Infrastructure development, including transport and logistics for mineral export
  • Potential expansion opportunities based on resource evaluation

title: Chongoene Development Corridor Project (CDC), Mozambique
body:
The Chongoene Development Corridor Project (CDC) is a strategic, large-scale infrastructure initiative aimed at establishing a multi-purpose deepwater seaport and mineral processing zone in Chongoene, Mozambique. The project is designed to handle 150 million tons of cargo per year, enhancing the region's connectivity and economic growth.

Phase 1 of the project includes the development of a two-berth jetty at Chongoene Port with an annual capacity of 10 million tons, alongside the construction of a 221-kilometer railway line linking Chongoene to Macarretane. This key infrastructure will facilitate the export of mineral resources, including heavy sands, and stimulate local economic activity through job creation, community development, and increased trade opportunities.

The CDC will serve as a catalyst for regional economic growth, driving the development of key industries and enhancing Mozambique's position as a critical hub for global trade.

title: Mototolo / Der Brochen Project, South Africa
body:
The development of the project leverages the existing Mototolo infrastructure, enabling mining to extend into the adjacent and down-dip Der Brochen resource, which will extend the life of mine beyond 30 years. The approval of the project supports the Company’s strategic priority of maximising value from its core portfolio of assets, investing capital into this life-extension project which is expected to be value-accretive and generate strong returns.

The Der Brochen UG2 orebody will use the same bord and pillar extraction method as Mototolo mine, and will be a fully mechanised operation, positioned in the bottom half of the primary PGM producer cost curve. The project includes development of a new shaft to replace the depleting Mototolo reserves (Lebowa and Borwa shafts), maintaining the 240,000 tonnes per month mining rate. With the completion of the concentrator debottlenecking project in Q3 2021, production from Mototolo / Der Brochen is expected to be maintained at around 250,000 PGM ounces per year.

Source: AngloAmerican Platinum 10.12.2021

title: Kabanga Nickel Project, Tanzania
body:
Kabanga Nickel Project in North-West Tanzania was acquired by Lifezone Metals in 2021.

Kabanga is expected to be a mine-to-metal operation producing battery-grade nickel, copper and cobalt for international markets. Lifezone Metals believes that the Kabanga Project comprises one of the world’s largest and highest-grade nickel sulfide deposits.

More than $400 million invested has been in the Kabanga Nickel Project to date.

Kabanga Mineral Resource estimate as of December 4, 2024 as attributable to Lifezone (69.7% of total) of 46.8 million tonnes (Measured and Indicated resources) at 2.09% nickel, 0.29% copper and 0.16% cobalt and additional 11.3 million tonnes (Inferred resources) at 2.08% nickel, 0.28% copper and 0.15% cobalt.

Source: Lifezone Metals

The total investment required in Kabanga Nickel is put at $1.3 billion, including $950 million in the mine and $350 million in the hydrometallurgical plant.

The project's refined product output is expected to be some 48,000 mt/year of nickel; 7,000-8,000 mt/year of copper and 4,000 mt/year cobalt, in cathode or rounds form, produced to LBMA 99.9% purity standards.

Source: S&P Global 2022

title: Bilboes Gold Mine, Zimbabwe
body:
Bilboes is a large, high grade gold deposit located approximately 75 kmnorth of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe. Historically, it has been subject to a limited amount of open pit mining.

The Project has NI43-101 compliant proven and probable mineral reserves of 1.96 million ounces of gold at a grade of 2.29 g/t and measured and indicated mineral resources of 2.56 million ounces of gold at a grade of 2.26 g/t and inferred mineral resources of 577,000 ounces of gold at a grade of 1.89 g/t. The Project has produced approximately 288,000 ounces of gold since 1989.

A feasibility study prepared by the vendors (DRA) indicates the potential for an open-pit gold mine producing an average of 168,000 ounces per year over a 10-year life of mine.

Source: Caledonia Mining Corporation

title: Archean-Birimian Contact (ABC) Gold Project, Côte d’Ivoire
body:
The ABC Project is in northwest Côte d’Ivoire, approximately 550km northwest of Abidjan and 460km west of Doropo project.

This is a greenfield exploration project, consisting of three permits, covering a highly prospective area of 1,143km2 along the underexplored contact zone between the Archean and Birimian cratons. This contact is demarcated by the north-south trending Sassandra Fault system, which is more than 20km wide.

Exploration to date has delineated a north-south trending gold-mineralised corridor – the Lolosso Gold Corridor – over a 30km strike length within the Kona permit.

INFERRED MINERAL RESOURCE 2.15Moz of gold

Source: AngloGold Ashanti

title: Songwe Hill Rare Earth Project, Malawi
body:
Introduction

Songwe Hill, a carbonatite-hosted rare earth deposit, is the main development target in retention licence RTL 0001/21, one of a block of eleven retention licences which Mkango refers to as the 'Phalombe Licences'. Historical exploration programmes were carried out at Songwe Hill in the late 1980s. After three phases of exploration drilling in 2011, 2012 and 2018, Mkango completed a NI43-101 compliant technical report and upgraded Mineral Resource estimate for the Songwe Hill Project in January 2019, and the Definitive Feasibility Study was completed in July 2022.

Location

Songwe Hill is located in south-eastern Malawi, between Lake Chilwa and the Mulanje Massif, approximately 70km from the former capital Zomba and approximately 90km from the commercial centre of Blantyre, which has an international airport and a railhead. Paved roads run from the urban centres to within 12km of Songwe Hill. Secondary gravel and dirt roads provide vehicle access to the exploration camp, with recently upgraded bridges capable of taking 20-tonne trucks.

Mineral Resource and Mineral Reserve Estimates

The Mineral Resource is open at depth. The combined Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource Estimate, totalling 21 Mt grading 1.41% TREO, is the basis of the mine plan in the Definitive Feasibility Study, which evaluates a bulk tonnage, open pit mining operation focused on broad zones of near surface and outcropping rare earths mineralisation.

The Measured Mineral Resource Estimate comprises 42% of the combined Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource Estimate, providing geological confidence to support the Feasibility Study.

Approximately 95% of the Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource Blocks are at a depth of less than 160 m below the surface of the hill, indicating that the majority will be accessible by open pit mining.

Source: Mkango Resources

title: Dougou Extension (DX), Congo
body:
License

Dougou Deposit is 15 km southwest of Kola and is a large, thick carnallite deposit with a Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource of 1.1 billion tonnes grading 20.6% KCl.

The deposit is ideally suited to the solution mining method (whereby ore is extracted by pumping heated water from surface to dissolve it and pumped to surface), due to abrupt geological contacts, low angle of dip, thickness, continuity, high carnallite content and low insoluble content.

Geology of Dougou

The Dougou Deposit comprises only of carnallite, hosted by four horizontal or gently dipping (<5 degrees) seams, between 7 and 12m thick, with a combined thickness of 30 to 40m. The seams are between 400 and 600m in depth and continuous across the deposit. Thickness variation is minimal and lateral grade variation within each seam is less than 10%. Of particular importance is the hanging wall seam (HWS) which appears to be unique globally in its purity of potash mineral content over such a significant thickness. At Dougou it is uniformly comprised of between 90 and 91% of the mineral carnallite and averages 10.0m thick, grading 24 to 25% KCl.

Resources and reserves

The combined Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource for the Dougou carnallite deposit is 1.07 billion tonnes grading 20.6% KCl (13.0 % K2O) as estimated February 2015 by ERCOSPLAN Ingenieurgesellschaft Geotechnik und Bergbau mbH (“ERCOSPLAN“) of Germany. The deposit is ‘open’ laterally to the North, South and East. The HWS contributes 311 Mt grading 24.7% KCl to the Measured and Indicated Mineral Resource.

Source: Kore Potash

title: Hartley Platinum Expansion, Zimbabwe
body:
Hartley Platinum Mine and Selous Metallurgical Complex (SMC) are located in the Darwendale subchamber of the Hartley Complex, part of the Great Dyke, which hosts approximately 80% of Zimbabwe’s known Platinum Group Metals (PGM) resources.

Key Project Details

  • Location: 80km west-southwest of Harare and 77km north of Ngezi mines
  • Resource Base: One of the largest PGM deposits in Zimbabwe
  • Expansion Plan: Increasing mine production capacity to 8.8 Mtpa

The project aims to enhance platinum and PGM extraction through mine expansion and processing upgrades.

title: Bengwenyama Project, South Africa
body:
Summary

The Project is an advanced stage exploration project focussed on PGM mineralisation on the Properties which are located on the Eastern Limb of the Bushveld Complex and south of the Anglo Platinum Modikwa property. Two economical reefs – the Merensky and UG2 reefs – occur on the Properties, which extend from surface to a depth of 1,100m over a distance of 10km. Both these reefs are primary economic deposits exploited by other platinum mining companies for PGMs and base metals in the region.

Location and Access

The Project comprises the full extent of the Properties. At its closest point, the Project lies approximately 5 km west of the village of Steelpoort, 20 km west-southwest of the larger town of Burgersfort, and 250 km east-northeast of Pretoria. The Project has a total areal extent of 5,279.74 ha.

Source: Southern Palladium

title: Mopani Copper Expansion, Zambia
body:
International Resources Holding (IRH) acquired the Mopani Copper Mines in early 2024 with the strategic vision to transform it into the most productive copper mine in the Copperbelt. By applying advanced and innovative new technologies and collaborating with the outstanding Zambian workforce, IRH is decarbonising the project whilst aspiring to increase copper output to 200,000 tonnes over the course of the next three years. 

This boost in output will contribute to Zambia’s goal of reaching 3 million tonnes of annual copper production by 2030, a vision that is being driven by President Hakainde Hichilema himself. His administration’s focus on creating a stable and competitive mining environment has not only attracted international investors but also positioned Zambia as a potential leader in global copper production.

Source: International Resources Holding (IRH)

title: Ngualla Project, Tanzania
body:
Ngualla Project is a world-class rare earth development located near the Ngwala Village and approximately 150km from the City of Mbeya in the Songwe Region and on the edge of the East African Rift Valley.

The project entails the construction of a mine, mill, concentrator, community projects and associated infrastructure. Construction of the project is expected to cost approximately US$320 million and create around 600 and 3,000 indirect jobs during construction and around 220 direct and 1,000 indirect jobs during operations.

Significant beneficiation and value-adding will be undertaken in Tanzania with ore with a grade of around 4.8% REO being beneficiated into a 45% REO high-grade concentrate. This high-grade rare earth concentrate will be initially be sold as a standalone product, while the study of downstream integration opportunities is undertaken in collaboration with the Government of Tanzania.

  • Location: Tanzania (~1,000km west of Dar es Salaam and ~150km
    from Mbeya)
  • Geology: Weathered carbonatite with a high-grade bastnasite-rich zone, low in acid consuming elements and radionuclides
  • Ore Reserves: 18.5Mt grading 4.80% REO for 887kt REO
  • Mineral Resources: 214.4Mt grading 2.15% REO for 4.61Mt REO
  • Resources Life of Mine: +20 years (covering only Ore Reserves)
  • Mining: Open Pit with low strip ratio of 1.77
  • ROM Throughput: 800ktpa dry ore
  • Annual Production: 37.2ktpa of concentrate (45% TREO grade)
  • Environmental Certificate: Received March 2017

Source: Peak Rare Earths
