title: Tulu Kapi Gold Project, Ethiopia
body:
Tulu Kapi Gold Project is a high-grade open-pit gold mining and processing operation located 360km west of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The project benefits from its proximity to infrastructure, including a main road (12km away) and power lines (40km away), facilitating efficient operations.

Key Project Details

  • Processing Plant Capacity: 190,000 ounces of gold per year
  • Ore Reserve Estimate: 15.4Mt at 2.1g/t gold, containing 1.1Moz
  • Probable Ore Reserve: 1.05Moz
  • Total Mineral Resources: 1.72Moz
  • Metallurgical Recovery: 93% for oxide and sulphide ore

Geology and Mineralization

Tulu Kapi is situated in a greenstone belt characterized by hills of intrusive rocks and deeply incised valleys containing metasediments and metavolcanic rocks. The gold deposit occurs within quartz-albite alteration zones, forming stacked sub-horizontal lenses in a syenite pluton, with a swarm of dolerite dykes and sills intruded into the host rock.

  • Mineralization Extent: 1,500m x 400m, open at depth (>400m)
  • Gold Associations: Hosted with silver, pyrite, sphalerite, and galena

Environmental and Climatic Conditions

  • Altitude: 1,600m - 1,765m above sea level
  • Climate: Temperate, with an average annual rainfall of 150cm

Tulu Kapi Gold Project is positioned as a low-cost, high-recovery operation, leveraging its geological potential and strategic location to become a key contributor to Ethiopia’s mining sector.

title: Chilalo Graphite Project, Tanzania
body:
New discoveries provide scope to define additional near-surface deposits to grow the mineral resource/ore reserve.

In early 2023, Evolution discovered two new high-grade mineralised zones – Chilalo East and Chilalo E2. High-grade mineralisation at Chilalo East has been defined over 1.6km out of a potential 3.5km strike length indicated by the high-conductance electromagnetic conductor.

At Chilalo E2, located to the east of Chilalo Mining Licence and parallel to the north of Chilalo East, 1.1km out of a potential 5km strike has been tested so far with mineralisation open to the east and west.

Source: Evolution Energy Minerals

title: Nachu Graphite Project, Tanzania
body:
Magnis Energy Technologies through its Tanzanian subsidiary Uranex Tanzania Limited owns a 100% interest in the Nachu graphite project located near Ruangwa, in the south-east of Tanzania. The project is approximately 220km away from the Tanzanian port of Mtwara. The Nachu Project demonstrates significant potential due to its large size, an orebody with very low variation in lithology and mineralisation and low-cost operational model.

Soure: Magnis Energy Technologies

Nachu Project is a large-scale graphite mining operation characterized by its consistent orebody composition, minimal variation in lithology and mineralization, and a low-cost operational model. The project is expected to play a significant role in the global graphite supply chain.

Key Project Details:

  • Annual Production Capacity: 240,000 tonnes of graphite concentrate
  • Graphite Purity: 98.3% total graphitic carbon (TGC)
  • Mine Life: Initial 15 years

title: Ibom Deep Seaport, Nigeria
body:
Also known as the Integrated Deep-Sea Port, the Ibom Deep Seaport (IDSP) is a major maritime infrastructure project located in Akwa Ibom State, Nigeria. Spanning 2,565 hectares, with an additional 1,565 hectares designated for future expansion, the port is designed to accommodate New Panamax Class vessels, ensuring efficient and high-capacity cargo handling.

Key Specifications:

  • Channel Depth: 18.24 meters
  • Turning Basin & Berth Depth: 16.72 meters
  • Quay Length: 7.5 kilometers
  • Container Terminal Capacity: 13 Panamax-class container vessels + 2 large feeder vessels
  • Annual Port Capacity: 2.24 million TEUs


Phase 1 Development:

  • Land Development: 505-hectare dug-out basin
  • Navigation Channel: 20 km long, 450 meters-wide
  • Breakwaters: 1,350 meters and 600 meters-long 

Phase 2 Expansion:

  • Additional Land Development: 495 hectares

title: Telal El Sokhna, Egypt
body:
Telal El Sokhna is a real estate development project located in Ain El Sokhna, Egypt. The project spans across approximately 617.76 acres, with only 20% allocated for buildings, leaving 80% for facilities and natural landscapes.  

There are approximately 4,300 residential units which comprise the following:

  • Chalets: Areas range from 96 to 136 square meters, with options for one or two terraces and a private garden in some units.
  • Standalone Villas: Total areas range from 280 to 360 square meters, featuring four or five bedrooms, maid’s quarters, dressing room, kitchenette, and spacious terraces.
  • Twin Houses: Areas range from 140 to 180 square meters, including three or four bedrooms, maid’s quarters, and terraces on each floor.

title: Skikda Refinery, Algeria
body:
Skikda Oil Refinery is a major petroleum processing facility located in Skikda, Algeria, with a refining capacity of 350,000 barrels per day (bpd). It plays a key role in Algeria’s energy sector by producing various petroleum products to meet both domestic demand and export requirements.

Skikda Refinery Fuel Oil Conversion Unit project will involve the construction and development of key refining infrastructure aimed at enhancing hydrocarbon processing capabilities. The scope includes:

Key Processing Units

Hydrocracking Block (HCU Block) – 4.5 million tons/year (90,000 bpd)

  • Fuel Oil Hydrocracking (HCU) – 2.3 million tons/year
  • Hydrocracking Unit (UOP technology)
  • Solvent Deasphalting Unit (UOP technology)
  • Vacuum Distillation Unit

Utilities & Supporting Facilities 

  • Hydrogen Production Unit
  • Sulfur Recovery Unit
  • Amine Regeneration Unit
  • Acidic Water Softening Unit
  • Water Supply & Treatment Infrastructure
  • Utility & Gas Systems

title: Distributed Access through Renewable Energy Scale-up (DARES), Nigeria
body:
• Provide some 17.5 million Nigerians and up to 237,000 micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) with new or improved access to electricity through the deployment of solar mini grids and standalone solar systems
  • The standalone solar systems will be implemented using targeted and competitively awarded performance-based and catalytic grants, and the mini grids through minimum subsidy tenders and performance-based grants
  • DARES aims to provide basic electrification for about 13.5 million unserved, rural and remote Nigerians through the deployment of standalone solar systems and electrification via mini grids for more than 2.7 million people in rural and peri-urban settings
  • The project will also improve the reliability of electricity supply for 1.3 million existing consumers in peri-urban and urban areas by connecting them to interconnected mini grids that will help replace approximately 288,000 diesel/gasoline generator sets
  • In addition, DARES will provide an estimated 237,000 MSMEs (including around 124,000 agri-businesses) with reliable and clean electricity that will help improve their income generation potential, create local jobs and improve the financial sustainability of mini grids
  • The scheme will also support the deployment of solar rooftop solutions for about 30 diesel generator set-reliant public hospitals in the state of Lagos in southwestern Nigeria under a pilot project

title: Rehabilitation and Maintenance of Kampala-Jinja Road, Uganda
body:
Civil works for the rehabilitation and maintenance of 72 km of the existing road, drainage works, preparation of the entire vertical and horizontal signage

 

The project includes scarification of the existing courses of road structure, reprocessing of sub-base with added crushed stone, construction of a base of crushed aggregate, asphalting, reconstruction of shoulders, repair of the existing holes, casting of concrete tubes (perpendicular and longitudinal culverts) as well as execution of slab culverts.

 

The project represents a continuation of the previously completed work on the repair of Spear Motors intersection at Seeta section along Kampala – Mukono Road. Due to the client’s request not to stop traffic during the execution of works, and since it is one of the busiest travel routes with heaviest traffic within the travel network in Uganda, the works under contract are only performed during the night.

 

The original completion period under contract was 12 months. Due to a change in the scope of work and drastic increase in the quantity of works, Energoprojekt Niskogradnja submitted a request for extension of the 12-month period. The works shall be carried out as per the instructions of the engineer.

title: Sky 180, Democratic Replublic of Congo (DRC)
body:
The Sky 180 project is a grand residential development with 26 floors, including four expansive parking levels, each measuring 2000 square meters. Above the parking, the residential floors offer comfortable living spaces. The project features two exclusive club floors and a rooftop terrace, providing residents with stunning views and recreational amenities.

Source: Sogebam

title: Isola Sheraton, Egypt
body:
The project area is 45 acres, with a 15% building footprint for residential buildings with types variety (townhouses – 2br apartments – 3br apartments) and 15% for a commercial mall with a length of 1,500 meters, including shops and administrative headquarters.

The project consists of residential, commercial, and administrative buildings. More than 30% of the construction work has been completed, adhering to international engineering standards and codes of major brands. The floor ceilings reach heights of up to 6 meters. The project is already considered the first real mega strip mall, serving the entire sheraton area and overlooking the guard hotel. It has the following features:

  • Luxury apartments and townhouse villas.
  • Shops, administrative offices, and medical clinics.
  • a total of 47 buildings.
  • 850 housing units.
  • 90 villas are also part of the compound.

Source: El Masria Group

title: IL Monte Galala Sokhna, Egypt
body:
IL Monte Galala Sokhna, located in Mount Galala, Egypt, is a luxurious coastal resort. it has a total of 10,000 residential units. These units include a variety of types such as chalets, villas, twin houses, townhouses, and more, catering to different tastes and needs. The project is divided into several phases, each offering unique features and designs. Here is how the units are divided:

  • Residential Units: 5,000 units
  • Serviced Units:4,000 units
  • Hotel Rooms: 1,000 units 

The units are described as follows:

Chalets:

  • Sizes range from 50 square meters to 175 square meters.
  • Options include 1-bedroom, 2-bedroom, and 3-bedroom configurations.

Twin Houses:

  • Typically range from 160 square meters to 175 square meters.
  • Designed for families seeking more space and comfort.

Duplex Units:

  • Sizes start from approximately 155 square meters.
  • Suitable for those desiring multi-level living spaces.

Villas:

  • Sizes range from 220 square meters to as large as 446 square meters.
  • Offer luxurious living with expansive areas and private gardens.

Townhouses:

  • Average around 175 square meters.
  • Provide a blend of community living with individual privacy.

title: Naivasha Special Economic Zone, Kenya
body:
The project involves the construction of an integrated mixed-use industrial park spanning 1,000 acres in Mai Mahiu, Nakuru County. Strategically located along the Nairobi – Naivasha Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) line, the SEZ is designed to enhance regional trade and logistics capabilities.

Key Features & Components

Multimodal Logistics Hub:

  • State-of-the-art transshipment facilities enabling seamless cargo transfer between
  • Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) and Meter Gauge Railway (MGR).
  • Facilitates cargo movement to East African Community (EAC) countries and Central Africa.

Industrial & Commercial Zones:

  • Industrial park for manufacturing and processing industries.
  • Free trade zone to attract investors with tax incentives.
  • Residential and commercial areas to support workforce housing and business activities.

Infrastructure & Transport Facilities:

  • Internal Container Depot (ICD) and Logistics Zone for efficient cargo handling.
  • Railway Marshalling Area to support freight operations.

title: East-West Road, Nigeria
body:
The East-West Road Project is a major infrastructure initiative aimed at improving connectivity and transportation efficiency across the Niger Delta region. The project involves the construction of a second carriageway and the rehabilitation of the existing road, covering a total road length of 657 km.

Scope of Work

  • Dual Carriageway:
    • Each carriageway spans 188 km.
  • Bridges:
    • 29 river bridges of varying lengths, ranging from 31m to 260m.
    • 2 box girder bridges measuring 700m and 850m respectively.
  • Sections of the Road:
    • The road extends from Warri, Delta State, through several key locations, and terminates at Oron to Calabar.
    • The project is divided into five sections

title: Lekki Deep Sea Port, Nigeria
body:
Overall Phase 1:

  • Deep seaport built across an initial area of 90 hectares of land and water along 3 km of waterfront, adjoining the Epe township
  • Draft depth of 16.5 metres
  • Breakwater of 1.9 metres
  • Turning basin of 600 metres
  • Quay length of 10,250 metres
  • 3 container berths
  • 1 dry bulk berth
  • 3 metres of liquid berths
  • Capacity of up to 1.2 million TEUs 
  • Pre-gate truck park spanning 2.5 hectares

Construction of the first phase was completed in October 2022 and operations began in April 2023

Phase 2 will see the port's capacity increase to 2.5 million TEUs and a draft depth of 19.5 metres

 

Container Terminal: This has a 1,200-metre-long quay, three container berths, and a storage yard with over 15,000 ground slots. The general arrangement of the container storage and handling area consists of a stacked container arrangement. The terminal is designed to support a throughput of 2.7 million TEUs annually.

Electric power comes from a dedicated power plant with a 30 MW capacity plus a 10 MW emergency capacity. Potable water is produced through captive water treatment plants and wastewater treatment plants. Stormwater drainage, sanitary wastewater drainage, and firefighting systems are also in place.

Dry Bulk Terminal: Located on the western side of the container berths, the dry bulk terminal is situated close to the turning circle. The available quay length of about 300m accommodates one berth for a Panamax-size vessel (75,000 DWT).

Products handled as cargo range from dry to hygroscopic products such as grains, raw sugar, and fertilisers. The movement of the bulk shipment to storage areas like silos and warehouses is managed by covered conveyor systems along a corridor of about 25 meters. The facility handles around 4 million metric tons of dry bulk annually. 

Liquid Bulk Terminal: Capable of servicing vessels up to the size of 45,000 DWT initially, with design flexibility for expansions that cater to an increase to a capacity of 160,000 DWT. Liquids such as finished products (petrol, diesel) are handled with storage in a tank farm located in the Lagos Free Trade Zone, close to the port site. The berth is equipped with loading arms and connected by pipelines running along the breakwater to carry cargo between the tank farm and the vessels.

 

Concession Agreement

The port is being operated under a 45-year concession agreement dated 12 December 2018 on a Build, Own, Operate and Transfer (BOOT) basis commencing from the date of Financial Closure in 2020

The Public-Private Partnership [PPP] model is based on the following sharing structure:
i. Federal Government represented by Nigerian Ports Authority (NPA) – 5%
ii. Lagos State Government where port is located – 20%
iii. Private Investor/manager – Lekki Port LFTZ Enterprise Limited (LPLEL); 75%

LPLEL is a joint venture enterprise owned by a group of investors led by the Lekki Port Investment Holdings Inc (comprising China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd. and Tolaram Group), the Lagos State Government and the Federal Government of Nigeria through NPA.

title: Rural and Small Towns Water Security, Mozambique
body:
The project aims to increase access to improved water supply and sanitation services in selected small towns and rural areas of Mozambique. It comprises of 4 components as follows:

Component 1:

Enhancement of water supply and sanitation services in small towns (8 in Nampula and 14 in Zambezia)

  • construction, rehabilitation, and expansion of small towns and rural growth centers water supply systems
  • sanitation investments in small towns
  • design and roll out performance‐based contracts (PBCs) for improved and inclusive service delivery by private operators. 

Component 2:

Enhancement of water supply and sanitation services in rural areas will support the implementation of the second phase of the National Program for Rural Water and Sanitation (PRONASAR) (2019-2030) and contribute to increasing access to improved water supply and sanitation (WSS) for the rural population of the two most populated and underserved provinces of Mozambique, Nampula, and Zambezia. 

Component 3:

Institutional and project management support will finance technical assistance (TA) for capacity development and project implementation support for central level implementing institutions (National Directorate for Water Supply and Sanitation (DNAAS) and Water and Sanitation Infrastructures Administration (AIAS)), and the extension of the regulatory role for the rural space and its strengthening in small towns. 

  • provision of support for the development of the sector; 
  • TA and project management support for DNAAS;
  • institutional and project management support for AIAS.

Component 4: 

Contingent emergency response component (CERC) will provide immediate response to an eligible crisis or emergency, as needed.

Source: World Bank

title: Lagos Free Zone, Nigeria
body:
Develop the Lagos Free Zone (LFZ) located in Ibeju-Lekki, approximately 60 km east of the city of Lagos 

The total area of the LFZ is 842 hectares divided into two parcels.  The main LFZ site of 624 hectares (Parcel A) is located north of the Lekki coastal road and the other parcel of 116 hectares (Parcel B) is a waterfront site located south of the coastal road

Development of the LFZ is being undertaken in three phases, with Phase 1 covering 300 hectares of Parcel A and Phases 2 and 3 covering the remaining area. 

A total of 70 % of the LFZ is marked for development and operation of industrial facilities, 20 % for logistics and 10 % for real estate development to support activities such as trading, manufacturing, packaging, warehousing and other ancillary services

 

Phase 1 of the LFZ development includes:

  • The Lekki deep sea port (covering 90 hectares)
  • An industrial hub with standard industrial manufacturing factories and warehouses
  • Two residential towers, an EDGE-certified commercial office tower and an industrial training centre
  • Ancillary facilities including a 24 MW piped natural gas (PNG) power plant, a gas pipeline with a capacity of 40 million standard cubic feet per day and a solid waste management or materials recovery facility
  • Road infrastructure within the LFZ
  • Zone-level support infrastructure including a customs processing centre, police station, security command centre, helipad, fire station, truck park, medical clinic, broadband network and bank branches.


Phase 2 of the LFZ is expected to be developed 2-3 years after the completion of Phase 1.  Facilities to be developed include additional industrial facilities; a heavy vehicles truck park; additional residential apartments; and a water supply network.
 

In Phase 3, the waterfront site will be developed for non-industrial use, such as residential, commercial, utilities and future mixed-use developments. Phase will also develop the recreational and tourism area in LFZ due to its location outside the bonded zone. A desalination and effluent treatment plant is also planned once the zone is fully developed

 

By 2035, the LFZ is planned to have over 150 industries fully operational, which are projected to generate over 40000 jobs, contributing 2-3% to Nigeria’s GDP

title: Nouakchott Tramway, Mauritania
body:
​The Nouakchott Tramway is a planned urban rail project in Mauritania's capital, Nouakchott, aiming to enhance urban mobility, reduce traffic congestion, and promote sustainable transportation. 

The tramway is designed to consist of two lines, each approximately 22.5 kilometers long, totaling 45 kilometers. ​

Route Details:

  • Line 1: Connects the University of Nouakchott Al Aasriya in the Tevragh Zeina department to the end of the Toujounine department, passing through the city center. ​
  • Line 2: Links Carrefour Bamako in the Riyadh department to Carrefour Hay Saken in the Dar Naïm department, also traversing the city center. ​

title: Awash-Kombolcha-Hara Gebeya (AKH) Railway, Ethiopia
body:
​The Awash–Hara Gebeya Railway, also known as the Awash–Kombolcha–Hara Gebeya Railway, is a significant infrastructure project in Ethiopia aimed at enhancing the country's transportation network by connecting its central and northern regions.

Technical Scope:

The project involves the construction of a 392-kilometer single-track electrified railway line extending from Awash in the central Rift Valley to Hara Gebeya in the north. This line is designed to facilitate both passenger and freight transport, with trains operating at speeds up to 120 km/h.

Key technical features of the project include:​

  • Bridges and Tunnels: The construction encompasses 52 bridges and 12 tunnels totaling approximately 10 kilometers in length.​
  • Stations and Facilities: The railway will feature 10 substations, 8 power control stations, 12 radio poles, and a main maintenance workshop (maintenance center). ​

title: Ifahsa Pumped Storage Hydropower Project, Morocco
body:
Ifahsa Pumped Storage Hydroelectric Power Plant is located on the east bank of the Laou Valley in the Tangier-Tetouan-Al Hoceima region, 14 km south of Chefchaouen province in Morocco.

Key project details include:

  • Installed capacity: 300 MW
  • Annual turbine production: 550 GWh
  • Annual pump consumption: 710 GWh
  • Flow rate: 44 cubic meters per second
  • Reversible units: 2 units, each 150 MW

title: Qena Pumped Storage Hydropower Project, Egypt
body:
The project involves the construction of two pumped storage hydropower plants in Armant (Luxor) and Qena, located in Upper Egypt. Each plant is designed with an estimated generation capacity of 2 GW, contributing a total of 4 GW to Egypt’s energy grid.

Pumped storage hydropower will play a crucial role in balancing energy supply and demand, enhancing grid stability, and supporting the integration of renewable energy sources. The facilities will utilize off-peak electricity to pump water to an upper reservoir and release it during peak demand periods to generate power efficiently.

title: Cairo-Khartoum Corridor, Egypt and Sudan
body:
Also known as Egypt-Sudan Rail Link, Cairo-Khartoum Corridor Project is a significant initiative aimed at enhancing transportation connectivity between Egypt and Sudan, primarily through the development of a railway network linking Cairo to Khartoum. This project is part of broader efforts to strengthen regional integration and economic cooperation between the two countries.​

Project Description and Technical Scope

  • Railway Connection: The core of the project involves extending Egypt's Cairo-Cape Town railway line to reach Khartoum, Sudan's capital. This extension aims to facilitate seamless passenger and freight movement between the two nations. ​
  • Infrastructure Development: The initiative includes the construction of a 360-kilometer railway line within Egyptian territory, connecting Cairo to Aswan. Additionally, a six-kilometer line across Lake Nasser to Wadi Halfa in Sudan is planned, enhancing cross-border connectivity. ​
  • High-Speed Rail: The project envisions the development of a high-speed rail network with a design speed of 250 km/h, connecting major cities along the Nile Valley. The network is planned to span over 2,000 kilometers, significantly reducing travel times between key urban centers. ​

Sections

  • Egypt: Aswan, Toshka and Abu Simbel to Wadi Halfa (Sudan), 400 kilometer
  • Sudan: Wadi Halfa - Khartoum, 900 kilometer

title: Trans-Maghreb Railway Corridor
body:
The Trans-Maghreb Railway Corridor is an ambitious infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing economic integration and connectivity among North African countries, specifically Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia. The project seeks to modernize and expand the existing railway networks to establish a continuous high-speed rail line connecting major cities from Casablanca (Morocco) through Algiers (Algeria) to Tunis (Tunisia). This corridor is envisioned to facilitate efficient passenger and freight transportation across the Maghreb region.​

Technical Scope

A) Modernization of Existing Lines:

  • Morocco: Upgrade of the Fès-Oujda line (approximately 354 km) to support higher speeds and increased capacity.​
  • Algeria: Rehabilitation of the Oujda-Akid Abbas cross-border section (17 km) to ensure seamless connectivity between Morocco and Algeria.​

B) Construction of New High-Speed Lines:

  • Algeria-Tunisia: Development of a new high-speed rail segment between Annaba (Algeria) and Jendouba (Tunisia), spanning approximately 110 km, designed for speeds up to 220 km/h.​
  • Tunisia: Modernization of the Jendouba-Jedaida line (approximately 150 km) to enhance operational efficiency and safety.

title: Dakar-Bamako-Niamey Corridor, Senegal, Mali, and Niger
body:
The Dakar-Bamako-Niamey Corridor Project is a major regional infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing connectivity across Senegal, Mali, and Niger. This multimodal corridor integrates road and rail networks, improving trade efficiency and economic integration across West Africa. By upgrading key transport routes, the project will significantly reduce travel times, cut transportation costs, and facilitate the seamless movement of goods and passengers between these landlocked and coastal nations.

Technical Scope

A) Railway Component:

  • Rehabilitation & modernization of the 1,228 km Dakar (Senegal) - Bamako (Mali) railway, improving track infrastructure, signaling systems, and rolling stock.
    • Senegal section 1,057 km
  • Targeted capacity expansion to accommodate increased freight and passenger volumes.

The project is part of a railway network that links:

  • Dakar - Tambacounda - Kedougou (Senegal)
  • Keniebu - Bamako - Bougouni - Sikasso (Mali)
  • Ouagadougou (Burkina Faso)

B) Highway Component:

  • Rehabilitation and upgrading of key road sections between Dakar, Bamako, and Niamey to enhance accessibility and reduce transport costs.
  • Improvements to border crossing infrastructure to streamline trade and customs processes.
  • Strengthening transport resilience to climate conditions by using durable materials and modern engineering techniques.

title: Mwanga-Same-Korogwe Water Project, Tanzania
body:
Mwanga-Same-Korogwe Water Mega-Project is a $154 million initiative aimed at providing clean and reliable water to over 300,000 residents in Tanzania’s Kilimanjaro region. The project sources water from Nyumba Ya Mungu Dam and is designed to support semi-arid lowlands in the western Pare Mountains, covering the Same, Mwanga, and Korogwe districts. It seeks to improve living conditions, reduce waterborne diseases, and support agriculture in the region.

Project Scope & Infrastructure

The project will be executed in two phases, with a total water distribution network spanning approximately 400 kilometers. Key components include:

Phase 1:

  • Water intake facilities and a pumping station
  • Drinking water treatment plant
  • Storage reservoirs and water tanks
  • 12 km of pipelines
  • Power supply infrastructure

Phase 2:

  • Water pumping station in Kisangara
  • Storage reservoir in Kiverenge
  • Gravity main and service tanks
  • Expansion of the distribution network to 28 villages and two small towns

title: Kabuyanda Dam and Irrigation Project, Uganda
body:
Kabuyanda Dam and Irrigation Project is designed to support agricultural irrigation by constructing a dam on the Mishumba River and developing an extensive irrigation scheme.

Key Project Details:

  • Dam Type: 33 m high earth-fill dam.
  • Reservoir Capacity: 8.8 million cubic meters (MCM).
  • Drainage Area: 90 km².
  • Location: 5 km northwest of Kabuyanda Town.
  • Submerged Area: 100 hectares within Rwoho Central Forest Reserve (CFR).
  • Irrigation Coverage: 3,300 hectares of farmland.

title: Zimplats Solar PV Plant, Zimbabwe
body:
Zimplats Holdings has been authorised to develop solar photovoltaic (PV) power capacity across its mining operations in phases, with a total capacity of 185 MW. The project is structured into four phases. 

Phases 1A and 2A will be located at the Selous Metallurgical Complex in Mashonaland West on an area spanning 109 hectares. The plant will have a nameplate capacity of 80 MW and will incorporate 74,000 PV panels mounted on a single automatic identification system (AIS) tracking system with control and security systems.

title: Klein de Koning, South Africa
body:
Klein de Koning is a residential development located in the Groot Phesantekraal Estate, Durbanville, Western Cape. The project offers a mix of luxury living options, including simplex studios and two-bedroom duplex apartments.

The key features are:

  • 12 simplex studio apartments (38m² each)
  • 26 two-bedroom duplex apartments (82-85m²),
  • 10 deluxe two-bedroom duplex apartments with an additional study (99m² each)
  • Amenities: Swimming pool, braai facilities, lush gardens, smart access control, CCTV, and fibre connectivity

title: Cabeolica Wind Farm Expansion, Cape Verde
body:
• Install three wind turbines with a capacity of around 4.5 MW each, representing an additional total capacity of 13.5 MW at the Santiago wind farm in Cape Verde, on the island of Santiago
  • The project will also install battery energy storage systems (BESS) in Santiago, São Vicente, Sal and Boa Vista
  • The scope of the project includes development, design, engineering, financing, licencing, insurance, provisioning, manufacturing, transportation to site, assembly, construction, activation, testing, ownership, operation, maintenance and decommissioning of wind farms and BESS installations
  • The Santiago wind farm is part of four wind farms that collectively make up the 25 MW Cabeolica wind farm, with a collective production of 100 GWh a year; the current installed capacity of the four wind farms comprises 30 wind turbines and Vestas’ 850 kW model V52, distributed over Santiago with 11 turbines (9.35 MW), São Vicente with 7 (5.95 MW), Sal with 9 (7.65 MW) and Boa Vista with 3 (2.55 MW); additional facilities include four substations and 33.5km of power cable
  • The most suitable option for the expansion was determined to be the installation of 3 Vestas V150 4.5MW (105 m hub height), which are larger turbines than those currently installed at the Santiago and Sal wind farms (Vestas V52-850kW, 55 m hub height)
  • The BESS units will be installed close to the wind farm substations to minimize cable lengths. Each BESS will require the installation of a single 20kV three-phase underground circuit to the wind farm substations

Santiago BESS and Additional Works

  • A BESS of approximately 6 MW / 6 MWh of storage capacity for spinning reserve and control, and short-term storage to be installed at the Santiago wind farm
  • The modular BESS will consist of two sets of two battery containers (4), two (2) inverters (PCS), two (2) step-up transformers, one (1) MV substation, one (1) 30 m2 warehouse, one (1) BT room and control house, two (2) temperature transformers and one (1) parking area
  •  An additional 20 kV transmission line, to be installed parallel to the existing transmission system/interconnection cable, connecting the wind farm to the Electra-owned substation (São Filipe, Monte Vaca), located outside the wind farm boundaries, approximately 2km to the NE

Sal BESS Works

  •  BESS of approximately 6 MW / 6 MWh of storage capacity for grid stability control and short-term storage to be installed at the Sal wind farm

São Vicente BESS Works

  • BESS of approximately 8 MW/8 MWh of storage capacity for grid stability control and short-term storage on São Vicente Island, located near the Electra Lazareto power plant, approximately 3.7 km from the São Vicente wind farm

Boa Vista BESS Worksa

  • BESS of approximately 6 MW/6 MWh of storage capacity for grid stability control and short-term storage on Boa Vista Island, located near the Águas e Energia de Boa Vista (AEB) Parcela Power Plant, in an industrial area approximately 8.5 km from the Boa Vista wind farm

 

Transmission Line Works

The wind turbine generators will operate at approximately 690 V, and each will have a dedicated transformer located at its base or within the turbine to “step up” the wind turbine voltage to feed the wind farm’s 20kV interconnection cable system. The preliminary electrical system configuration for the wind farm will minimise power cable length while maintaining operational flexibility, safety and security. The preliminary electrical design solution consists of terminating the 20 kV underground power cables from the new wind farm turbines at the existing Santiago Island wind farm substation, which provides access to the existing distribution system. Underground cabling between the turbines will follow the access road (site roads) as far as possible

 

  • During the last decade of operation of the current wind farm, a considerable amount of energy has been wasted due to the lack of sufficient demand load on the islands. Consequently, Cabeólica has determined that a wind farm extension and a BESS are required on Santiago Island for the Cabeólica Expansion Project, as well as the addition of BESS to the energy production mix on the Islands of Sal, Boa Vista and São Vicente
  • The Cabeólica Expansion Project aims to reduce diesel spinning reserve operations by incorporating a BESS for the benefit of Cabeólica and the Transmission System Operator (TSO) to maximise the penetration of renewable energy and increase the storage capacity of existing production for new wind turbines. The renewable energy penetration rate on the two islands of Cabo Verde will increase from around 20% (current) to around 50% (up to a maximum of 70%), allowing the targets set by the Government for the sector to be achieved by 2025
  • The expansion project will allow a significant reduction in the Cabeólica tariff and diesel savings of up to around 135 GWh per year, which will result in net savings of up to €6 million per year at a maximum of 70% SNSP (non-synchronous system penetration) at current fuel prices

title: Kyabé-Mayo Road Paving, Chad
body:
​The Kyabé-Mayo Road Paving Project is a strategic infrastructure initiative in Chad, focusing on enhancing transportation and economic connectivity in the region.​ The project entails the asphalting of a 49.5-kilometer section between Kyabé and Mayo on the Kyabé-Singako road. 

A key component includes the construction of a 55-meter bridge at kilometer point 64.5.

title: Marrakech-Agadir High-Speed Rail, Morocco
body:
Also known as Marrakech-Agadir Train à Grande Vitesse (TGV). The project is a significant extension of Morocco's high-speed rail network, aiming to connect the cities of Marrakech and Agadir. This initiative is part of a broader strategy to enhance transportation infrastructure ahead of the 2030 FIFA World Cup, which Morocco will co-host with Spain and Portugal. 

Scope of Work:

Route and Length: The proposed HSR line will span approximately 230 kilometers, linking Marrakech to Agadir. 

Stations: The line is expected to include stations in key locations, notably in Marrakech, Essaouira, and Agadir, facilitating improved connectivity for both residents and tourists. 

Infrastructure: The project encompasses the construction of dual tracks designed for high-speed trains, implementation of advanced signaling systems, and electrification to support sustainable operations.

Rolling Stock: As part of the expansion, Morocco's National Railways Office (ONCF) plans to acquire 18 high-speed trains from France's Alstom, enhancing the capacity and efficiency of the HSR network.

title: Eswatini Rail Link, Eswatini
body:
​The Eswatini Rail Link (ESRL) Project, also known as Swazilink, is a significant railway infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing regional connectivity and freight capacity between South Africa and Eswatini.​

The ESRL project involves the construction of a 150-kilometer railway line, extending from Lothair in South Africa to Sidvokodvo in Eswatini. This new line is designed to create a dedicated General Freight Business (GFB) corridor, alleviating congestion on existing coal export lines and promoting efficient transportation of general freight.

Technical Scope:​

  • Route Alignment: Approximately 100 kilometers of the new railway will traverse Eswatini, with the remaining 50 kilometers in South Africa. ​
  • Infrastructure Components: The project encompasses the construction of 28 viaducts, 28 bridges, 25 cattle creeps, 31 underpasses, and 110 culverts to accommodate the diverse terrain and ensure seamless operation. ​
  • Operational Specifications: The railway is engineered to support 2.5-kilometer-long trains comprising 200 wagons, with an axle load capacity of up to 26 tons.

title: Hinda Phosphate Project, Congo
body:
Hinda, in the Republic of Congo (RoC), is believed to be one of the world’s largest undeveloped sedimentary-hosted phosphate reserves

Shallow, it has a JORC-compliant mineral resource base totalling more than 650Mt at a grade of 10% P2O5 and a total reserve of 404.9Mt at a grade of 11% P2O5.

Opencast mining is employed, starting with a low strip ratio.

The phosphate mineralisation is hosted in a 300-800m wide corridor, within fault-bounded graben. There are two main phosphate-bearing sedimentary layers, forming contiguous layers up to 65 m thick.

The prospecting licence covers an area of some 260km2 of the country’s coastal basin. The project is permitted, with terms of reference accepted for modifications to the environmental social impact assessment.

Hinda is just 37km from the second-largest city, Pointe Noire, a port city and industrial hub, and has access to water, natural gas, a national freight route and port capacity.

Hinda’s 32% phosphate rock, like that of Elandsfontein, would be suitable to produce phosphoric acid, DAP, MAP and SSP. Blending of production from Hinda and Elandsfontein for certain markets is a prospect.

Source: Kropz

title: Nova JV Project, Namibia
body:
Background

 In 2016, Deep Yellow entered into a joint venture agreement with JOGMEC (a Japanese Government Agency) on a 4-year, $4.5M earn-in exploration and development program, for a 39.5% interest in Nova.

The joint venture included two EPLs prospective for both basement and palaeochannel-type uranium mineralisation.

In September 2020, JOGMEC completed its earn-in requirements for a 39.5% interest in the Project.

Over the duration of the joint venture, exploration was successful in identifying previously unknown mineralisation at the Namaqua palaeochannel and the Iguana and Barking Gecko basement prospects.

Following the completion and assessment of results of an RC drilling program in December 2023, the joint venture partners reassessed the Project, with regard to future exploration and limited follow-up work at the Barking Gecko prospect on EPL3669.

Source: Deep Yellow Ltd

title: Omahola Project, Namibia
body:
Omahola is located within the highly prospective “Alaskite Alley” corridor, within which major uranium deposits including Rössing, Husab, Etango and Valencia are located. These deposits contain in excess of 800 Mlb U₃0₈, with the Rössing mine alone having produced in excess of 200 Mlb U₃0₈.

Omahola occupies a 35 km x 14 km northwest-southeast trending zone within the Alaskite Alley corridor. Uranium mineralisation at Omahola occurs across three deposits including Ongolo, MS7 and Inca and amounts to a Measured, Indicated and Inferred Resource base of 125.3 Mlb U₃0₈ at 190 ppm. Uranium mineralisation is associated with sheeted leucogranites, known locally as alaskites, and hydrothermal skarn formation.

Source: Deep Yellow Ltd

title: Tumas Project, Namibia
body:
Tumas comprises of a series of palaeochannel/calcrete-type uranium deposits totalling 132.9 Mlb U308.

Uranium mineralisation in palaeochannel/calcrete-type deposits occurs as carnotite (uranium-vanadium mineral), hosted by Tertiary and Quaternary fluvial sediments occupying narrow and steep-sided palaeochannels. Host rocks vary from hard, carbonate-cemented sandstones and conglomerates (calcrete) to poorly consolidated and friable sands.

Tumas has a Resource of 121 Mlb (260 ppm U308), a Reserve of 67 Mlb (345 ppm U308) and Inferred Resources of 16.5 Mlb available to further expand the Ore Reserve base, with potential to add a further 10+ years to the current 22.25-year Life-of-Mine.

The Project has 125 km of highly prospective palaeochannels. Importantly, 40% of the 125 km Tumas palaeochannel system remains to be tested, providing the Company with significant exploration upside.

Source: Deep Yellow Ltd

title: Fekola Complex, Mali
body:
The Fekola Complex is located in southwest Mali, on the border between Mali and Senegal, approximately 500 km due west of the capital city, Bamako. The Fekola Complex is comprised on the Fekola Mine (Medinandi permit hosting the Fekola and Cardinal pits and Fekola underground) and Fekola Regional (Anaconda Area (Bantako, Menankoto and Bakolobi permits) and the Dandoko permit).

  • MINE TYPE Open Pit
  • METALS MINED Gold
  • PROCESSING THROUGHPUT 9.0 Mtpa
  • MINERAL RESERVE GRADE 1.70 g/t Au
  • GOLD RECOVERY ~94.0%

Source: B2Gold Corp

Fekola Complex consists of two main areas:

  • Fekola Mine (Medinandi permit) – Includes the Fekola and Cardinal pits and Fekola underground.
  • Fekola Regional – Encompasses the Anaconda Area (Bantako, Menankoto, and Bakolobi permits) and the Dandoko permit.

Expansion & Development Scope

  • Construction of a new tailings storage facility.
  • Procurement of new and replacement mining equipment, including rebuilds.
  • Expansion of the Fekola solar plant to enhance energy efficiency.
  • Underground mine development and infrastructure upgrades at Fekola Regional.

title: Khemisset Potash Project, Morocco
body:
The project has a large JORC Resource Estimate (2019) of 537Mt @ 9.24% K2O and significant exploration potential with an accelerated development pathway. The Feasibility Study completed by Golder Associates has confirmed the findings from the Scoping Study, which showed that Khemisset has the potential to be a world class, low capital cost, high margin potash mine, which is a very rare asset in the industry.

Source: Emmerson

title: Sandpiper Marine Phosphate Project, Namibia
body:
Namibian Marine Phosphate (NMP) owns the Sandpiper marine phosphate project, approximately 60km off the coast of Namibia, which covers a total area of approximately 7000 km2 in the regional phosphate enriched province to the south of Walvis Bay in water depths of 180–300m.

  • DFS Base Case Financial Model: 20 years
  • Saleable Rock Phosphate per annum: 3.0Mtpa

Source: Namibian Marine Phosphate

Previous exploration activities have verified to internationally approved standards the existence of a world-class economically viable marine phosphate deposit in the mining licence area ML 170.  The mining licence comprises an area of 2,233 km2 and is located offshore approximately 120km southwest of Walvis Bay. The eastern boundary of the mining licence is located approximately 40 km off the coast (directly west of Conception Bay) and water depths where the deposit is situated range from 190 m at the eastern boundary to 300 m and the western boundary of the mining licence.  The proposed project is located within the priority mining area for industrial minerals: phosphate in terms of the draft marine spatial plan.

Source: ECC Environmental

title: Dugbe Gold Project, Liberia
body:
Dugbe Gold Project is in southern Liberia within one of the last remaining genuinely under-explored parts of the Birimian geological province which is host to the majority of West African gold deposits. This part of the Birimian is has a growing gold endowment and Pasofino is a first mover with very large ground holding: 2,078 km2. The Project area is located 70 km by road from the Greenville deep-water port.

Pasofino, through its wholly-owned subsidiary ARX Resources Limited, owns 100% of the Dugbe Gold Project (prior to the issuance of the Government of Liberia's 10% carried interest).

A mineral development agreement issued by the Government of Liberia for the project secures mining rights and terms for 25 years.

Mineral Reserve

  • 200koz per year Au production from open pit 
  • 2.76Moz gold in Mineral Reserves with an average grade of 1.30 g/t Au.
  • Reserves support 2.27Moz produced over a 14-year LOM 
  • LOM metallurgical recovery of 83% from the FS test work
  • Average annual production of 200koz for the first 5 years
  • LOM strip ratio is low at 4.2:1 and lower for first 5 years
  • 5Mtpa processing plant process plant midway between the two deposits

title: Motheo Expansion, Botswana
body:
Motheo Copper Project Expansion includes the A4 and T3 deposits, both located in Botswana’s Kalahari Copper Belt. The A4 deposit is situated 8 km west of T3 and will serve as a high-grade ore feed source for the Motheo Copper Mine, supporting its long-term growth.

Key Project Details

  • Location: Botswana, Kalahari Copper Belt
  • Mine Type: Large sediment-hosted copper and silver deposit
  • Processing Capacity:
  • Current: 3.2 Mtpa
  • Potential Expansion: 5.2 Mtpa

Construction Scope

  • Mining pre-strip (initial excavation to expose ore)
  • Process plant construction
  • Site infrastructure development
  • Tailings storage facility

T3 Open-Pit & Production Hub

The T3 open-pit is the core of the Motheo Production Hub, a new copper production center in the region. Sandfire Resources holds a 26,645 km² ground position across Botswana and Namibia, strengthening its presence in this world-class copper belt.

Operational Outlook & Reserves

  • Estimated mine life: 12.5 years
  • Updated Ore Reserve: 39.9Mt @ 0.9% Cu & 12.2 g/t Ag
  • Contained Copper: 360,000t
  • Contained Silver: 15.6 Moz
  • Annual Production (First 10 Years):
  • Copper: 30,000t per year
  • Silver: 1.2 Moz per year

title: Jacomynspan (JMP) Battery Metals Project, South Africa
body:
Jacomynspan Nickel-Copper-Cobalt-PGE sulphide (JMP) project offers the potential for a Class-1 nickel-copper-cobalt-PGE-gold underground and open pit mining operation that offers an exceptional opportunity to feed South Africa’s first prospective refinery producing high-purity metal powders for use in the electronics and chemical industries.

JMP is located 65km north of Orion’s flagship Prieska Copper Zinc Mine in South Africa’s Northern Cape. The Project holds an executed Mining Right over a proven Ni-Cu-Co-PGE+Au Intrusive Complex and planning is underway for a trial mining exercise to generate sufficient scale representative bulk sample of Jacomynspan (JMP) ore in order to test innovative metallurgical refining/high purity, ultrafine metal powders production on a pilot scale. Such downstream metallurgical testing of innovative refining/processing, with the potential to improve metallurgical recoveries and revenue generation from sulphide ores of this kind, presents significant upside potential for deposits of this kind.

Resources

JMP is hosted within the Areachap Belt, an under-explored belt with high metal endowment with a confirmed presence of shallow sulphide nickel-copper-cobalt-PGE mineralisation.

Jacomynspan currently hosts a JORC Mineral Resource of 65Mt at a 0.2% Ni cut-off. Only a seventh of outcropping mineralisation has been drilled, leaving significant upside potential along this 3km high-priority target. The metals contained include 180,000t Nickel; 121,000t Copper; 12,000t Cobalt and 410,000oz PGEs+Au.

Source: Orion Minerals
meta_description: Jacomynspan Nickel-Copper-Cobalt-PGE sulphide (JMP) project offers the potential for a Class-1 nickel-copper-cobalt-PGE-gold underground and open pit mining operation that offers an exceptional opportunity to feed South Africa’s first prospective refinery producing high-purity metal powders for use in the electronics and chemical industries.
migration_status: success

title: Okiep Copper Project (OCP), South Africa
body:
The Okiep Copper Project (OCP) is located in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa, approximately 570km north of Cape Town and 450km west of Prieska Copper Zinc Project.

Resources

Total JORC Mineral Resources at the OCP currently stand at 12 million tonnes grading 1.4% Cu for 159,000 tonnes of contained Cu. This resource estimate covers an initial six deposits and is based on a detailed review of historical drilling data and subsequent geological modelling. Orion sees excellent potential to further expand this resource base through the ongoing analysis of the OCP extensive historical exploration database, as well as through the Company’s own exploration programs.

The life-of-mine for the proof-of-concept foundation phase is modelled for 12 years, during which time concurrent exploration and mine expansion scenarios will be planned and potentially implemented.

Only Mineral Resources from the Flat Mines area of the greater Okiep Copper Complex (OCC) are incorporated in the foundation-phase plan, leaving significant potential for future expansion scenarios to be considered.

Source: Orion Minerals

title: Prieska Copper Zinc Mine (PCZM), South Africa
body:
Historically mined between the 1970s and 1990s, Prieska is one of the world’s Top-30 volcanogenic massive sulphide (VMS) base metal deposits, with a recorded historical production of over 430k tonnes of copper and 1Mt of zinc from 46.8Mt of sulphide ore milled.

Location and Infrastructure

PCZM is located in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa, 270km south-west of the regional capital Kimberley. Importantly, the project has access to significant local and regional infrastructure, with key infrastructure including:

  • Sealed access roads to project site
  • 50km via bitumen road to existing rail siding
  • Four high-voltage regional lines linked to the national electricity grid
  • 175MW operational solar power plants in the area – with an additional 675MW approved and a further 300MW pending authorisation
  • 800km rail link to a major, bulk commodity and deep-water ports at Coega and Saldanha Bay
  • Bulk water pipeline supplies site from Orange River with all year pumping capacity
  • Good contractor accommodation available in the private village of Copperton, ~3km from project site
  • Low environmental sensitivity – existing disturbed/rehabilitated mine footprint

Resources

PCZM contains a globally significant VMS resource totalling 31Mt at 1.2% Cu and 3.6% Zn including Indicated Mineral Resources of 20.00Mt at 1.23% Cu and 3.43% Zn (July 2023). It has a Mineral Reserve of 14.5Mt at 1.1% Cu and 3.2% Zn. Resources remain open with both strike extensions and up-folded limb extensions identified by down-hole geophysics.

Source: Orion Minerals

title: Mponeng Mine Expansion, South Africa
body:
Mponeng is the deepest level shaft in the world, with a depth of 3 891 metres below datum and 2 062 metres below sea level. The mine, which began producing in 1986, is near the town of Carletonville, some 90km south-west of Johannesburg. 

The mine exploits the Ventersdorp Contact Reef, its primary orebody, employing mostly breast-mining methods. The economic reef horizons are mined at depths of between 3 160m and 3 740m below surface. Ore mined is processed at the Mponeng gold plant using conventional gold leaching methods carbon-in-pulp gold recovery technology.

30 JUNE 2024:

  • Gold Resource: 24.6Moz
  • Gold Reserve: 4.5Moz
  • LoM: 20 years

Source: Harmony Gold Mining Company

title: Diamba Sud Gold Project, Senegal
body:
Acquired in September 2023, the Diamba Sud Gold Project is located in the highly prospective Kenieba-Koudougou Inlier (KKI) which hosts several world class gold deposits in eastern Senegal and western Mali. Associated with north north-east trending fertile splays from the regionally significant Senegal Mali Shear Zone, the Diamba Sud Gold Project hosts three deposits with historic JORC compliant resources of 625,000 ounces of Indicated and a further 235,000 ounces of Inferred. 

 Source: Fortuna Mining Corp

title: Uis Mine Expansion, Namibia
body:
The licence covers an area of approximately 19 700 hectares hosting numerous pegmatites with mineralisation including lithium, tin, tantalum and rubidium.

Petalite is considered the dominant lithium mineral present in the pegmatites. To date, we have identified 180 pegmatites over 5% of the licence and confirmed a 138 million tonnes resource for just two of these, namely the V1/V2 pegmatites.

Andrada’s medium-term target is to define a 200 million tonnes resource from these pegmatites. The flagship Uis tin and tantalum mine is highly scalable, with plans to integrate a lithium production circuit.

Ultimately, Uis has the potential to become a global lithium supplier.

The expansion plan is to increase tin concentrate production at Uis Mine from 1,500 tpa to 2,600 tpa, in line with the Orion royalty agreement. The scope of the expansion entails improvements and additions to both the dry and wet processing sections of the plant. The dry section will be expanded through the installation of a crusher and XRT ore-sorters to constitute the pre-concentration circuit. The expected net effect of the ore-sorters is an increase of approximately 50% in the tin content feed to the wet processing plant.

Source: Andrada Mining

title: Sierra Leone Industrial Zone (SIZ), Sierra Leone
body:
The Sierra Leone Industrial Zone involves the construction of the Special Koya Industrial Zone (SIZ-Koya) on 500 hectars.

The zone is designed to host companies specializing in agro-industry, timber processing, pharmaceuticals, consumer goods manufacturing, electric vehicle manufacturing, and cement and tile manufacturing.

The construction of SIZ – Koya is divided into two phases as follows:

• Phase 1: The installation of 16 production units mainly focused on import substitution industries on 150 hectares.

• Phase 2: 37 production units will be set up over 350 hectares within the zone, mainly in the field of import substitution industries and local processing of raw materials into high value-added products. 

Source: ARISE

title: Industrial Platform Remo Free Zone (IPRFZ), Nigeria
body:
The industrial zone is situated approximately 50 kilometers from Lagos, Nigeria. It covers about 5,100 hectares, with Phase 1 covering 2,000 hectares. 

 It will host various industries, including agro-processing (soybeans, ginger, groundnuts, sesame, maize), non-agro processing (recycling, construction items, steel and metal, aluminum, ceramic, glass), light manufacturing (chemicals), and innovation sectors like renewable energy.

Industrial Platform Remo Free Zone offers state-of-the-art infrastructure with gas-powered electricity, wide lane roads, internet, security, gas and water supply, telecoms, green spaces, wastewater treatment, banks, hospital, fire station, and police station.

title: Ratanga Redevelopment, South Africa
body:
Ratanga Junction theme park, which closed in May 2018, is to be redeveloped into a vibrant new mixed-use precinct of around 120 000 square metres.

The new precinct plan for the site, which includes residential apartments, a retirement component, a hotel, restaurant and offices all set around beautiful water bodies and a large public park, has been approved by Council.

A hard edge canal wall on the northern side of the site will be created which will form the foundation for a future water-fronting mixed use development incorporating a hotel, residential apartments and showrooms and providing an attractive public realm.

Much of the current landscaping is being retained while the current water in Ratanga will be drained to allow for the sculpting of the new Ratanga footprint which will include much larger water bodies around which the new developments will be constructed.

Source: Rabie Property Developers

title: Manganese Refinery and Sulphuric Acid Plant, Namibia
body:
Manganese refinery and sulphuric acid plant east of Walvis Bay will be developed in phases, reaching full operational capacity by 2032.

The project will process 100,000 tpa of high-quality manganese ore from  Kalahari Manganese Field in South Africa.

  • Stage 1: The refinery will process 25 kt/a of manganese and produce 500 t/d of sulphuric acid, with power and water demand at 5 MVA and 30 m³/h.
  • Stage 2: Production will double to 50 kt/a of manganese and 1,000 t/d of sulphuric acid.
  • Stage 3: Output will reach 100 kt/a of manganese and 2,000 t/d of sulphuric acid, with power and water needs increasing to 25 MVA and 80 m³/h.

The facility will employ crushing, grinding, reduction, acid leaching, and purification to produce high-purity manganese sulphate monohydrate (HPMSM), a crucial material for battery manufacturing.

Additionally, the plant will generate sulphuric acid by converting elemental sulphur into sulphur dioxide (SO₂), sulphur trioxide (SO₃), and finally sulphuric acid (H₂SO₄). Any surplus sulphuric acid will be supplied to other industrial sectors in Namibia.

title: Phalaborwa Rare Earth Project, South Africa
body:
The Phalaborwa Rare Earths Project, located in South Africa, has a total JORC compliant Mineral Resource Estimate of 35.0 Mt at 0.44% TREO contained within phosphogypsum in two unconsolidated stacks derived from historic phosphate hard rock mining. Rainbow’s process will deliver separated rare earth oxides through a single hydrometallurgical plant on site, with a focus on the recovery of neodymium (“Nd”), praseodymium (“Pr”), dysprosium (“Dy”) and terbium (“Tb”). These are critical components of the high-performance permanent magnets used in electric vehicles, wind turbines, defence and exciting new markets such as robotics and advanced air mobility.

The Interim Study is based on a project life of 16 years, processing an average of 2.2 Mt of phosphogypsum per annum. With an overall recovery rate of magnet REE of ca. 65%, based on the pilot campaign undertaken in 2023 to 2024, the project is expected to produce ca. 1,900 t magnet REO production annually.

Source: Rainbow Rare Earths

title: Mahenge Graphite Project, Tanzania
body:

The Mahenge Project is spread across 324 square kilometres of exploration tenements in Tanzania’s Ulanga district, approximately 250 km north of the border with Mozambique. 250 km west of the coastal port city of Mtwara on the Indian Ocean and 300 km southwest of Tanzania’s largest city, Dar es Salaam.

Construction of Mahenge Module 1 and associated infrastructure, including the 220kV power line from Ifakara to Mahenge connecting the whole community to 220kV power.

title: Kayelekera Uranium Project, Malawi
body:
Kayelekera Uranium Project in Malawi, Africa produced ~11MIbs U3O8 equivalent over five-years between 2009-2014, before the asset was shutdown to preserve its longevity due to a sustained low uranium price.

The Project has a mining licence and its environmental permits, access to a skilled local workforce who worked at the asset previously, as well as strong support from the Government of Malawi, who own 15% of the Project.

Source: Lotus Resources

title: Fayoum Sanitation Project, Egypt
body:
Fayoum Sustainable Sanitation Infrastructure project aims to rehabilitate and expand sanitation services in Fayoum Governorate, improving infrastructure in rural villages and increasing access to sanitation. Implemented in two phases, the initiative will significantly upgrade wastewater treatment and sewer networks.

Project Scope

  • 8 new wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs)
  • Expansion of 9 existing WWTPs
  • Rehabilitation of 10 existing WWTPs
  • Construction of 139 new pumping stations
  • Development of sewer networks for unserved villages
  • Provision of on-site sanitation facilities and evacuation trucks for 400,000 people

Phase 1 (119 villages)

  • 4 new WWTPs
  • Expansion & rehabilitation of 7 existing WWTPs (out of 10 planned)
  • Decommissioning of 6 outdated WWTPs
  • Construction of 256 km pressurized rising mains & 2,334 km sewer lines
  • 100 new sewage pumping stations
  • Increases sanitation access to 75.6%, benefiting over 700,000 people

Phase 2 (41 additional villages)

  • Further expansion to increase sanitation access to 86%

title: Dekheila LNG Terminal, Egypt
body:
Project Specifications:

Marine Facilities: An 800-meter pier (400 meters on each side) with a 20+ meter draft, allowing simultaneous docking of two vessels, each with a capacity of up to 250,000 tons.

Onshore Facilities: A 390,000 m² hinterland area, including storage zones, regasification units, loading/unloading equipment, and a pipeline network for import/export operations.

Designed to meet global quality, environmental sustainability, and occupational safety standards, the project’s first phase is set for commercial operation by 2027, starting with 350,000 tons annually, ramping up to 4 million tons per year by the completion of its third phase.

Source: Petroleum Today Magazine

Marine Facilities

  • Construction of an 800-meter pier, with 400 meters on each side.
  • Pier designed to accommodate two vessels simultaneously.
  • Capability to handle vessels with a capacity of up to 250,000 tons.
  • Draft depth exceeding 20 meters for large-scale docking.

Onshore Facilities

  • Development of a 390,000 m² hinterland area.
  • Inclusion of dedicated storage zones for liquid gas.
  • Installation of regasification units for processing.
  • Deployment of advanced loading and unloading equipment.
  • Integration of a pipeline network to facilitate import and export operations.

title: Nseleni Powership, South Africa
body:
The project involves the construction of a floating Liquid Natural Gas (LNG)-fueled Combined Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) power plant, which will be moored at Richards Bay port, South Africa.

Key Features:

  • Initial Capacity: 2,800 MW (later increased to 6,500 MW, with potential expansion to 8,400 MW).
  • Modular Design: Composed of multiple individual power plants, each with a capacity of 700 MW or 1,350 MW.
  • Floating Infrastructure: Designed to enhance energy security and grid stability by utilizing LNG as a cleaner alternative to coal.

title: Gas Distribution Network, Senegal
body:
(Also known as Réseau Gazier du Sénégal – RGS)

Senegalese Gas Network (RGS) is a national gas pipeline network with a transport capacity of 2.5 bcm/year, and comprises 4 segments:

  • Northern segment which is 85 km long, linking the GTA hub to the Gandon power plant near Saint-Louis in northwestern Senegal. XOF200bn (US$318m)
  • Blue segment with a length of 99 km, connecting the Tobène power plant in Mboro (117 km north of Dakar) to Cap des Biches in the Dakar region. XOF145bn (US$230m)
  • Orange segment between Sendou and Malicounda in the south of Dakar and 45 km long. XOF130bn (US$206m)
  • Green segment from Mbroro to Louga (near Saint-Louis), interconnecting north and south segments. XOF197bn (US$313m)

The RGS aims to link the gas fields (Yaakar Teranga, Sangora and GTA) to the consumption centres, including power plants, IPP and industrial sites to reduce their production costs. The country, which started producing gas from the GTA field in December 2024, does not consume gas as of 2023. Oil, which is entirely imported as of 2023, accounts for 40% of Senegal’s final energy mix (2023).

Source: Enerdata

title: Port Nador West Med, Morocco
body:
The project involves the construction of an industrial port with terminals for containers, hydrocarbons, bulk (including coal) and Ro-Ro as well as a service quay and an industrial investment zone comprising a 1,500 ha Free Zone and an additional 2,500 ha area outside the free zone.

The first port module is composed of:

  • main dike of around 4,200 m and a counter dike of around 1,200 m
  • container terminal with a quay of 1,520 m, a depth of 18 m and a median of 76 ha, with the possibility of adding a quay of 1200 ml to -18 m for containers
  • hydrocarbon terminal with 3 oil stations 20 m deep
  • coal terminal with a quay of 360 m and a depth of 20 m
  • miscellaneous Terminal
  • ro-ro station and a service quay

In terms of annual capacities, this infrastructure will enable the processing of:

  • 3 million containers (Twenty-foot TEU equivalent) with the possibility of increasing this capacity by 2 million additional containers
  • 25 million tonnes of hydrocarbons
  • 7 million tonnes of coal
  • 3 million miscellaneous goods

Source: Nador West Med

The complex consists of :

  • a new deep-water port equipped with significant capacities for the development of an energy pool (handling, packaging, storage of hydrocarbons and derivatives), container transhipment and bulk product processing
  • an integrated platform/free trade zone, open to renowned investors, designed to accommodate the globally active companies and supported by the port

This first module includes:

  • main embankment/breakwater over a length of approx. 4,300 m (consisting of 148 caissons over approx. 3,000 m and 1,300 m of rock embankment with concrete acropods) and a secondary breakwater/dike of about 1,200 m (also rock & acropods);
  • two container terminals (concrete deck on piles) with quay lengths of 1,520 m (TC1) and 600 m (TC2); expandability by an additional 600 m), at a depth of -18 m and an adjacent container yard/platform over an area of 76 ha
  • petroleum terminal with three tanker-berths at a depth of -20 m
  • bulk terminal with a 360 m quay and a depth of -20 m 
  • diverse terminal (-11  m depth) with a ro-ro berth and a service quay

Source: Jan De Nul

title: Kunzvi Dam, Zimbabwe
body:
This is the construction of an earthfill dam located on the upper reaches of the Nyagui River, approximately 4 km upstream of the confluence of the Nyagui and Nora rivers in Goromonzi District, Mashonaland East Province, Zimbabwe. 

The dam will have a total storage capacity of 158.4 million cubic meters, with a live storage capacity of 146.9 million cubic meters and a dead storage of 1.6 million cubic meters.

(Source: Gibb)

title: Cairo Alexandria Trade Logistics Development Project, Egypt
body:
Alternative Alexandria 6 October City Cairo Railway project. 

Lot 1

Establishing a single link from the dry port on the 6th of October to Beni Salama station “on the Al-Manashi line” with a length of 68 km, in addition to renewing, raising the efficiency, track upgrade, and developing the signaling systems along a length of 67 km from the Al-Maraziq/Al-Wahat line;

Lot 2

Bashteel – Itay El Baroud Section Upgrade (117 km); dualization between Bashteel to El Itihad (provision of a new track about 90 km new track) and the single-track upgrade between El Itihad-Itay El Baroud, selective upgrade of existing track and installation of the new signaling system in both section from Bashteel to Itay El Baroud; and

Lot 3

El Itihad – Al-tafaroa – “Al-Nahda Station” Section Upgrade (96 km) - Track Upgrade and Signaling Modernization.

Source: Egyptian National Railways

Cairo Alexandria Trade Logistics Development Project will implement a railway bypass to the congested GCA. The bypass will provide freight trains between the Alexandria Sea Port and the newly constructed 6th of October Dry Port, with an alternative route to the west of Greater Cairo. The operational bypass will also allow 15 container trains per day by 2030, and as demand increases, 50 trains by 2060 to this dry port. Additional freight trains will flow between the Alexandria Port, Upper Egypt, and the Red Sea.

The project will upgrade the track and signaling on four segments –including a greenfield one– between Alexandria, the 6th of October City, and the GCA to achieve an operational railway bypass to the GCA. This railway bypass will increase capacity particularly for freight trains while decongesting the Greater Cairo Area where demand for passenger trains is high.

Source: World Bank

title: Lower Maguduza Hydropower Plant, Eswatini
body:
• Build the 13.5 MW Lower Maguduza hydropower plant on the Lusutfu River in Sidvokodvo, central Eswatini
  • Work will include building a diversion weir, a 2 km 66 kV transmission line, a footbridge across the dam and substation upgrades. There will also be works to intergrate the power plant at the Sidvokodvo substation
  • The project will unfold over a roughly 25-month contract period, followed by an additional 24-month defects notification period
  • The plant will generate 64 GWh a year for the national grid and is anticipated to augment Eswatini's power generation capacity by 20%
  • On 30 May 2023, Eswatini Electricity Company signed a 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with Middle Lusutfu Hydropower (Pty) Ltd
  • The electricity generated by the power station will be sold to EEC under the PPA at an inflation linked tariff. At the end of the PPA term, EEC will take over the plant at no cost to the company
  • The project is spearheaded by Middle Lusutfu Hydropower (Pty) Ltd – a joint venture between Old Mutual Eswatini and Public Service Pensions Fund (PSPF)

title: Temane Thermal Power Plant, Mozambique
body:
(Also known as Central Termica de Temane (CTT))

The scope involves:

  • Building, owning, operating and transferring a 450 MW combined-cycle gas turbine power plant across about 15 hectares at Temane in the Inhambane province in Mozambique; the plant will use Siemens SGT800 turbines
  • Building a 1.8 km buried gas pipeline connecting the plant to an LPG facility, with a 100m Pipeline Protection Zone (PPZ)
  • Building a 25 km 400 kV transmission line connecting the plant to the Vilanculos substation, with a 100m PPZ
  • Building a 1 km access road to connect the power plant site to the main road network
  • Drilling two groundwater boreholes within the power plant site
  • Drilling water injection wells for process effluent disposal within the plant site

The Temane plant will supply power to Electricidade de Mocambique (EDM) under a 25-year tolling agreement using natural gas supplied from the Pande-Temane fields operated by Sasol and ENH, the state-owned hydrocarbons company. The facility is set to power 1.5 million households and contribute to 14% of Mozambique's available installed capacity

CTT also anchors a new 563 km high-voltage transmission line, known as the Temane Transmission Project (TTP), and secures the first phase of the interconnection of the southern grid to the central and northern grids of Mozambique. The entire value chain (gas development, gas-fired power plant and transmission infrastructure) will see an investment of more than US$2 billion

title: Hassi Messaoud Oil Refinery, Algeria
body:
Build a new 100,000 barrel per day oil refinery in Hassi Messaoud in phases, with an overall capacity of 5 million tonnes a year 

Major process units:

  • Crude distillation
  • Hydrocracker
  • Gasoil hydro-desulphuriser
  • Naphtha hydro-processing 
  • Catalytic reformer
  • Isomerisation  
  • Solvent deasphalting 

Environmental improvement units:

  • Amine recovery
  • Sulphur recovery
  • Wastewater treatment
     

The project's scope includes the execution of a greenfield refinery, including all the process and environmental units, as well as the necessary auxiliary services. The project includes some of the most advanced processing units, with technologies that are targeted to deep conversion, clean fuel production and fulfilment of stringent environmental requirements. The oil products will conform to European environmental standards (Euro V)

The refinery project aims to meet the growing needs for diesel and other petroleum products in Algeria's southern regions as well facilitate potential exports

title: Lake Gwayi-Shangani, Zimbabwe
body:
The Lake Gwayi-Shangani project involves several key components under construction:

Dam Wall: The dam is being built to hold approximately 650 million cubic meters of water. It will be 72 meters high.

Mini-Hydro Power Station: A 10-megawatt mini-hydro power station is under construction. The station will have two generators producing 5 megawatts each, with the power to be added to the national grid.

Gwayi-Shangani-Bulawayo Pipeline: This pipeline will transport water from the dam to Bulawayo, a distance of about 251 kilometers. The pipeline includes six pump stations and will support irrigation along its route.

title: Mali Water Security Support, Mali
body:
The project will support improved access to drinking water services in Bamako (particularly the left river bank area), Mopti/Sévaré, San, Ouélessébougou, Dioila, Bafoulabé/Mahina. 

Bamako -  the works will concentrate on water transfer between Djikoroni-Para, the Missira station, and Kati-Sud, the construction of a pumping station at Missira and a 2,000 m3 water tower; as well as connecting households to the drinking water network

Secondary cities -  the project will build water supply systems to provide 24,000 cubic meters of water per day. This includes production facilities, pumping stations, three water towers with (with a capacity of 2,000 cubic meters each) a semi-underground reservoir (1,000 cubic meters), a water distribution network, household connections, and public water points in the outskirts.

(Source: World Bank)

title: Gabon-Equatorial Guinea Power Interconnection
body:
• Build a 20 kV interconnection line that will transfer surplus hydroelectricity from Equatorial Guinea to Gabon
  • The line will import 10 MW from Equatorial Guinea to supply the entire Woleu-Ntem province, specifically the towns of Oyem, Bitam, Medouneu, Mitzic and Minvoul
  • Implementation will be carried out in three phases: 
  • The first phase will involve supplying power to the line connecting the towns of Ebe-Be-Yine and Bitam; this will allow for the import of 3 MW for the municipality of Bitam and its surrounding areas
  • The second phase will energise the line connecting Oyem and Medzeng, which aims to directly connect the town of Oyem to Equatorial Guinea
  • The third phase will operationalise the line connecting Medouneu, ensuring the complete supply of Woleu-Ntem
  • The interconnection will help Gabon save approximately CFA franc 2 billion on diesel costs

title: Muntanga Uranium Project, Zambia
body:
The Muntanga Project, 100 % owned by GoviEx, is in the southeastern region of Zambia in the Siavonga and Chirundu Districts. The Project encompasses three mining licences – Muntanga (Licence no. 13880-HQ-LML), Dibbwi (Licence no. 13881-HQ-LML), and Chirundu (Licence no. 12634-HQ-LML), covering 719 km2, that are located approximately 200 km south of Lusaka, north of Lake Kariba.

Mineral Resource Estimate

The resource drill hole database for the Muntanga Project contains 2 834 drill holes totaling 191 711 m of drilling; 468 of these drill holes were drilled by GoviEx between 2021 and 2023 totaling 52 924 m of drilling. The database contains 33 280 uranium (U3O8) assays and 114 364 m of down-hole radiometric probe data converted in equivalent U3O8 (eU3O8) grade data for mineral resource estimation purposes.

Source: GoviEx Uranium Inc.

title: PMB Olympic-level Aquatics Facility, South Africa
body:
The facility is being constructed at St Charles College, Pietermaritzburg, KwaZulu-Natal. It will have a Myrtha pool, which is 52.5 meters long and equipped with a movable bulkhead. This allows the pool to be configured as a single 50-meter Olympic-standard pool or two 25-meter competition pools.

It will be built in five phases as follows:

Phase 1: initial groundwork including a car park and drainage systems

Phase 2: general construction

Phase 3:  building the pools

Phase 4 and 5: gym, restaurant/café, and an external warm-up pool

title: Addis Ababa Expressways Expansion, Ethiopia
body:
The Ethiopian Roads Administration is initiating a transformative infrastructure project involving the construction of four new expressways extending from Addis Ababa to major cities across the country. These expressways aim to enhance connectivity, stimulate economic growth, and modernize Ethiopia's transport infrastructure. The expressways will link Addis Ababa with Dessie, Jimma, Debre Markos, and Nekemte, covering an average distance of over 300 kilometers each.

Routes:

  • Addis Ababa to Dessie
  • Addis Ababa to Jimma
  • Addis Ababa to Debre Markos
  • Addis Ababa to Nekemte

Scope:

  • Terrain: The routes will pass through mountainous and high-elevation areas, requiring significant excavation and geotechnical solutions.
  • Construction Phases: The project will be executed in phases, prioritizing sections based on economic impact and engineering needs, with specific kilometers constructed at a time.
  • Road Design: Dual-lane expressways for high-speed traffic with modern safety features.
  • Excavation & Earthworks: Extensive excavation, particularly in mountainous regions, to stabilize the roadbed.
  • Paving: High-quality asphalt pavement for heavy traffic and varying weather conditions.
  • Bridges & Culverts: Construction to manage water flow and ensure road integrity.
  • Signage & Safety: Road safety barriers, reflective signs, and traffic management systems with lighting at key points for nighttime visibility.
