title: Airports 2030, Morocco
body:
The Airports 2030 project, initiated by Morocco's National Office of Airports (ONDA), is a strategic initiative aimed at expanding and modernizing the country's airport infrastructure to meet the increasing demand for air travel and enhance passenger experience. The project is aligned with Morocco's goal to co-host the 2030 FIFA World Cup with Spain and Portugal, necessitating significant enhancements to transportation infrastructure. 

Scope of the Project:

Capacity Expansion

  • Mohammed V International Airport (Casablanca): Expansion to increase capacity from 14 million to 44 million passengers by 2029. 
  • Marrakech-Menara Airport: Expansion to accommodate up to 14 million passengers. 
  • Agadir-Al Massira Airport: Expansion to handle 6.3 million passengers. 
  • Tangier Ibn Battouta Airport: Capacity enhancements to support increased traffic.
  • Fez-Saïs Airport: Upgrades to manage higher passenger volumes.

Infrastructure Enhancements

  • Terminals: Construction of new terminals and expansion of existing ones to improve passenger flow and services.
  • Runways and Taxiways: Strengthening and lengthening to accommodate larger aircraft and increase flight frequencies.
  • Air Traffic Control Towers: Modernization with advanced technology to enhance airspace management and safety.
  • Ground Handling Facilities: Upgrades to baggage handling systems, check-in counters, and logistics to expedite operations.

Digital Transformation

  • E-Gate Systems: Implementation of biometric "e-gate" portals at airports to streamline passenger processing. 
  • SMART AIRPORT System: Deployment of information systems for real-time monitoring and management of airport operations.

Access and Connectivity

  • Road Infrastructure: Construction of new access roads and enhancement of existing road networks to improve connectivity to and from airports.
  • Intermodal Transport Links: Development of integrated transport solutions, including rail and bus services, to facilitate seamless passenger movement.

title: Liwa-Rig Rig Road, Chad
body:
The Liwa-Rig Rig Road Project in Chad is a pivotal infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing regional connectivity by completing a segment of the Trans-Saharan Road (TSR) corridor. This project focuses on constructing a 55-kilometer paved road between the towns of Liwa and Rig Rig, with an additional 12 kilometers of access roads to improve connectivity to the town of Bol and the broader Trans-Saharan network.

Scope:

  • Paving 55 km between Liwa and Rig Rig
  • Laying durable asphalt suited for climate and traffic loads
  • Constructing 12 km of access roads linking Bol to TSR corridor
  • Installing culverts and drainage channels for water management
  • Building structures to ensure uninterrupted connectivity
  • Shaping roadbed for alignment and safety
  • Using compaction and stabilizing agents for durability
  • Installing road signs, lane markings, and barriers
  • Developing pull-off zones for inspections and driver comfort
  • Dust control, waste management, and impact mitigation

title: Southern Morocco–Northern Mauritania Cross-Border Road, Morocco
body:
The Southern Morocco–Northern Mauritania Cross-Border Road Project is focused on the construction of a high-quality, 93-km road linking southern Morocco (Es-Semara) to northern Mauritania. 

The road will be built to handle both local and international traffic, facilitating trade and connectivity between Morocco and Mauritania and neighboring Sahelian countries.

Project Scope:

  • Total Length: 93 km 
  • Road Type: Dual-lane, paved highway
  • Paving: High-quality asphalt concrete, with granular sub-bases and asphaltic base courses
  • Bridges: Reinforced concrete and steel bridges over watercourses and low-lying areas
  • Culverts & Drainage: Installation of culverts and drainage systems to manage water flow and prevent erosion

title: M10 Golomoti-Monkey Bay Turnoff Roadworks, Malawi
body:
• Undertake periodic maintenance of 57 km of the existing paved M10 road between Golomoti and the Monkey Bay turnoff 
  • The road serves Malawi's main fishing and tourist area on the southern shores of Lake Malawi
  • Significant erosion protection works and additional culvert openings will likely be required at the Bwanje River where the road is routinely overtopped during the rains
  • The work is planned to be carried out over 18 months

The road has areas of deteriorated base layer and surfacing and will require:

  • Short section of base rehabilitation and resurfacing
  • Extensive pothole patching on the rest of the section
  • Complete reseal of all parts not rehabilitated
  • Renewal of signs and safety features, carriageway markings, etc
  • One point on the road has flooded repeatedly and an increase of waterway area on the river crossing concerned is required

title: Dihlabeng Regional Hospital Phase 2, South Africa
body:
The Phase 2 construction of the hospital in Bethlehem, Free State comprises the following:

Bulk Earthworks

  • Earthworks to create parking areas, platforms, and entrances.
  • Demolition of redundant single-story buildings and structures, including the helipad, NHLS/SANBS building, and pedestrian link blocks.

Infrastructure Upgrades

  • Installation of ring main water supply and fire supply lines.
  • New sewer drainage and stormwater drainage systems with diversions.
  • Upgrades to Eeufees Street and the N5 entrance for improved access.

New Construction

  • Multilevel concrete structures for Blocks M & N.
  • A new two-story Block O for NHLS (National Health Laboratory Service) and SANBS (South African National Blood Service).
  • Construction of a new helistop.

Refurbishments and Extensions

  • Extensions and alterations to existing hospital Blocks A, B, C, D, and H.
  • Specific extensions to Blocks C and D.

System Installations

  • Replacement of old systems with new HVAC, electrical, fire detection/protection systems, electronic services, and medical gas supplies.

Paving and Retaining Walls

  • New layer works for paving with proper gradients.
  • Construction of retaining walls.

title: Casa Anfa City, Morocco
body:
Managed by Deposit and Management Fund (CDG), Casa Anfa City is an urban development in Hay Hassani, Casablanca spanning 350 hectares and includes a mix of offices, housing, shops, and cultural facilities. It is designed to support over 200,000 workers and residents, with a notable emphasis on sustainability, including a large 50-hectare green space.

Total constructible area of 4.5 million m2 of which 2.3 million m2 designed for housing (23 ha), 700 000 m2 for various facilities and 1.3 million m2 for retail and leisure activities. 

Key figures:

  • Total land area - 350 hectares
  • Total buildable area - 4,300,000 m²
  • Accommodations - 2,300,000 m²
  • Offices - 1,300,000 m²
  • Facilities including education, health, commercial, hotel, cultural, leisure and sports facilities - 700,000 m²
  • Green spaces including 50 hectares of large metropolitan park (Anfa Park) - 100 hectares

(Source: Casa Anfa)

title: Chileka-Likuni Corridor Road, Malawi
body:
• Upgrade 53.2 km of road on the Chileka-Likuni Corridor, located within the capital city Lilongwe in the central region
  • Work will be undertaken over an estimated duration of 30 months
  • In addition, periodic maintenance is to be undertaken on 6 km of road beginning from the end of the main corridor road at Likuni bridge and ending at Likuni roundabout
  • The contractor is also to undertake periodic maintenance and improvements to 90 km of unpaved district and community access roads
  • The works on unpaved district and community access roads will include mainly reshaping to restore the road formation and side drainage. Culverts will be replaced where necessary and spot gravelling will be carried out on slopes and areas with weak soils. No new bridges or large culverts are envisaged on the unpaved link roads

 

Specific Scope:

  • Upgrade 53.2 km of main corridor road from gravel to double bituminous surface treatment (DBST) standard
  • Build urban sections with paved shoulders/bicycle track, pedestrian walkway, and concrete-lined side drains
  • Build one new 30-metre prestressed post-tensioned bridge
  • Build 14 new reinforced concrete box culverts

In addition, the works will include:

  • Necessary improvements to road safety features (motorised and non-motorised)
  • Provision of street lighting adjacent to urban centres
  • Provision of bus bays and parking lay-bys
  • Provision of fencing to serve public schools within the vicinity of the project road
     

Periodic Maintenance Scope:

  • The periodic maintenance section begins from the end of the main corridor road at Likuni bridge and ends at Likuni roundabout
  • The first 4.9 km of the road has DBST surfacing and is in poor condition characterised by severe potholes, cracks and edge breaks. The last 1.1 km has asphalt surfacing and is in fair to good condition characterised by cracks and developing potholes
  • The intervention measures shall involve removing the existing surface for the first 4.9 km and processing the base to make subbase, bring new base material and surface with DBST. The new concrete pavement section at Chinsapo market will be retained and integrated into the periodic maintenance works
  • For the last 1.1 km, the contractor will fix the cracks and potholes, and surface with 25 mm thickness asphalt overlay, including installation of access culverts

 

(View the final scope of works here)

title: Chamtulo-Mkutumula Corridor Road, Malawi
body:
• Build 76.8 km of road on the Chantulo-Mkutumula Corridor, which runs from Mangochi district in the south to Ntcheu district in the central region
  • Work will be undertaken over an estimated duration of 32 months
  • In addition, periodic maintenance is to be undertaken on 2.2 km of road from Mkutumula to the M05
  • The contractor is also to undertake periodic maintenance and improvements to 84 km of unpaved district and community access roads
  • The works on unpaved district and community access roads will include mainly reshaping to restore the road formation and side drainage. Culverts will be replaced where necessary and spot gravelling will be carried out on slopes and areas with weak soils. No new bridges or large culverts are envisaged on the unpaved link roads

Specific Scope:

  • Upgrade of 76.8 km main corridor road from gravel to double bituminous surface treatment (DBSD) standard
  • Build urban sections with paved shoulders/bicycle track, pedestrian walkway, and concrete-lined side drains
  • Build six new reinforced concrete river bridges.
  • Build 12 new reinforced concrete box culverts

In addition, the works will include:

  • Necessary improvements to road safety features (motorised and non-motorised)
  • Provision of street lighting adjacent to urban centres
  • Provision of bus bays and parking lay-bys
  • Provision of fencing to serve public schools within the vicinity of the project road

Periodic Maintenance Scope: 

  • The periodic maintenance section begins at the end of the Chantulo-Mkutumula Corridor at Mkutumula (chainage 76+803) and ends at the junction with the M5
  • The road (2.2 km long) has existing asphalt surfacing, which shows distress parameters, i.e. rutting, cracks and edge breaks 
  • The road has no surfaced shoulders and is very narrow in some sections due to edge breaks. The general intervention is to fix the pavement distresses, widen narrow sections and provide an asphalt overlay (25 mm)
  • Drainage will be improved by cleaning and/or replacing existing culverts and reshaping side drains

 

(View the final scope of works here)

title: Nyanzaga Gold Mine, Tanzania
body:
• The Nyanzaga Gold Project is located in northwestern Tanzania, south of Lake Victoria within the Sengerema District of the Mwanza Region, approximately 60 km southwest of Mwanza 
  • The developer Perseus Mining has opted for a large scale, wholly open-pit mining operation for the first phase of development, in preference to a smaller scale, combined open-pit underground option
  • The developer Perseus Mining plans to mine the Nyanzaga (Tusker) and Kilimani deposits using a large open pit, as opposed to the smaller open pit and underground mine concept previously proposed by OreCorp in their 2022 Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS)
  • A mining study completed in 2024 proposes a mining fleet that uses 180-350 t hydraulic excavators matched with 90-150 t off-highway dump trucks. Over the life of the NGP, 52 Mt of ore and 297.8 Mt of waste will be mined at an average strip ratio of 5.7. Total material movement is forecast to peak during the period FY28 to FY32
     

Processing

The NGP process flowsheet is a conventional gold processing flowsheet that includes single-stage gyratory crushing; SAG milling with pebble recycle and ball milling in closed circuit with hydrocyclones (SAB comminution); gravity gold recovery; pre-oxidation/cyanide-in-leach (CIL) to leach and adsorb precious metals from the milled ore to activated carbon; split AARL elution, electrowinning and smelting to recover precious metals from loaded activated carbon to doré; and SO2/air detoxification of CIL tailings before pumping and deposition to the Tailings Storage Facility (TSF)

Production and Costs

  • Total gold production over an 11-year, Phase 1 mine life is currently estimated to be 2.01 Moz based on a JORC 2012 Probable Ore Reserve of 52.0 Mt @ 1.40 g/t gold for 2.3 Moz 
  • Gold production averages over 200,000 ounces of gold per annum from FY28 to FY35, with peak production of 246,000 ounces in FY28
  • Over the life of the mine, the estimated average All-In Site Cost (AISC) is US$1,211/oz
  • The capital cost for the plant and site infrastructure is estimated at US$472 million inclusive of US$49 million of contingency and pre-production capital of US$51 million, giving a total capital cost to first-gold pour of US$523 million

 

Project Infrastructure

  • The NGP is accessed from Mwanza, Tanzania's second largest city, by the sealed Mwanza – Geita Highway, crossing Smith Sound (an arm of Lake Victoria) via ferry or the recently constructed Kigongo – Busisi Bridge (John Pombe Magufuli Bridge), and then travelling on the unsealed regional road network for 35 km to Ngoma. The NGP area is approximately 9 km southeast of Ngoma, and an unsealed road is currently under construction to bypass Ngoma township and reach the NGP site
  • Power will be supplied from the Tanzania Electric Supply Company Limited (TANESCO)-operated national grid at the Bulyanhulu substation and delivered via a new 53 km 220 kV transmission line
  • Raw water for the site will be predominantly extracted from nearby Lake Victoria, with the water balance indicating a flow rate of 50-350 m3/h is required once the TSF decant return water supply becomes available (dependent on the season). Raw water supply will be supplemented by groundwater extracted from dedicated boreholes. Process water will be predominantly supplied by waterrecovered from the TSF decant.
  • The TSF will comprise a cross-valley storage facility formed by three zoned earth-fill embankments. The TSF will store life of mine tailings production of 52 Mt, with the embankments constructed in stages. The full internal basin area and upstream batter slopes of embankments will be fully lined with high-density polyethylene (HDPE) liner
  • A permanent operations village will accommodate 350 personnel, management and skilled technical staff from outside the immediate NGP area. Temporary construction accommodation will be provided by the respective construction contractors. A bus service will be provided to and from local population centres for workers from local towns and villages

 

Second Phase

A second phase of resource definition drilling is currently underway at the NGP with the aim of converting Inferred Mineral Resources into Indicated Mineral Resources, which would potentially enable the Ore Reserve to be materially expanded and the life of the NGP operation extended during the second phase of the Project, beyond the currently projected 11-year mine life

title: Western Foreland Exploration Project, DRC
body:
The Western Foreland Exploration Project in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is an initiative led by Ivanhoe Mines, focusing on uncovering new high-grade copper deposits in proximity to their flagship Kamoa-Kakula Copper Complex.

The activities include:

  • Geophysical Surveys: Utilizing advanced geophysical techniques to detect subsurface anomalies indicative of copper mineralization.
  • Geochemical Sampling: Collecting and analyzing soil and rock samples to identify geochemical signatures associated with copper deposits.
  • Drilling Programs: Conducting both diamond and reverse circulation drilling to test identified targets and assess the extent and grade of mineralization.

title: Kamoa-Kakula Copper Complex, DRC
body:
The Kamoa-Kakula Copper Complex, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), is a significant mining project developed through a joint venture between Ivanhoe Mines, Zijin Mining Group, and the Government of the DRC. With ongoing developments in mining, processing, and energy infrastructure, the project is set to solidify its status as one of the world's leading copper producers.

Ongoing Phases and Projects:

1. Direct-to-Blister Flash Smelter Commissioning

  • Installation of anode furnaces, slag mill, flotation plant, concentrate blending systems, and desulphurization facilities.

2. Phase 3 Expansion

  • Upgrading concentrator facilities to accommodate increased ore throughput.

3. Phase 1 and 2 De-bottlenecking

  • Expansion of milling, flotation, and filtration units to improve processing efficiency and output.

4. Hydroelectric Power Initiatives

Turbine #5 at Inga II:

  • Electrical infrastructure upgrades, transformer installations, and integration with existing power distribution networks.

5. Future Expansion Plans (Phase 4 and Beyond)

  • Additional concentrators, mine development, and supporting infrastructure to maintain long-term production growth.

title: Lofdal Heavy Rare Earth Project, Namibia
body: Lofdal Rare Earth Project, located 25 km northwest of Khorixas in Namibia's Kunene Region, is a strategic initiative focused on the production of rare earth elements. The project is set to produce an average of 2,000 tons of total rare earth oxide (TREO) per year, including 117 tons of dysprosium and 17.5 tons of terbium, which are critical for high-tech applications and clean energy solutions.

title: AHL Green Hydrogen Plant in Akwa Ibom, Nigeria
body:
• Build the AHL hydrogen plant in Nigeria's Akwa Ibom state
  • The plant is to be located within the Liberty Free Trade Zone at Atabrikang in the Ibeno local government area of the state
  • The plant is expected to boost Nigeria's industrial capacity and clean energy output
  • According to Idara Ekpo, chief visionary officer of AHL, the project could generate 1.2 million metric tonnes of green hydrogen-based methanol annually for export, along with medical oxygen and food-grade CO2

title: Kurmuk Project, Ethiopia
body:
The Kurmuk Project is an advanced stage development project in the Benishangul-Gumuz region of Ethiopia. The project involves a two-phase development plan requiring a total capital investment of approximately $500 million. Much of the initial phase is completed, with civil works and SMPP (structural, mechanical, plate, and piping) contractor mobilizations in progress. Main camp construction, along with engineering and procurement activities remain on track. 

Phase 2 will begin in 2025 with production expected to begin by the second quarter of 2026. The project aims to achieve an average annual gold production of approximately 290,000 ounces over the first five years and sustain an average of over 240,000 ounces annually over a 10-year mine life, at an AISC1 of $950 per ounce.

The current project design encompasses the Dish Mountain and Ashashire deposits, with numerous exploration targets across the Kurmuk Project’s expansive 1,450 km² exploration territory.

Source: Allied Gold

body:
The Engo Valley Uranium Project is an exploration stage uranium project in Namibia, that has not had any exploration since the 1970’s, and which hosts known uranium mineralization

Engo Valley Uranium Project

  • Top tier under-explored uranium project
  • Snow Lake holds an initial 68% interest in the Project
  • Ability to earn up to 85% interest upon exploration expenditures
  • Located on the Skeleton Coast in Northwest Namibia
  • 600 km north of Swakopmund
  • Last exploration was conducted in the 1970’s by Gencor
  • Multiple uranium targets identified and sampled
  • 5k of historic drilling completed by Gencor

title: Lubambe Copper Mine, Zambia
body:
The project aims to produce 90,000 tons per year of copper in concentrate in its initial phase, with plans to expand production to 160,000 tpa in subsequent phases. 

The existing Lubambe mine and associated infrastructure occupies a relatively small area of approximately 20 km2 on the western edge of the Lubambe mining license. The mining license is large, covering approximately 228 km2 of the highly prospective Konkola-Musoshi basin. The Lubambe Exploration Project Team is assessing the potential of the mining license that lies beyond the mine gate.

body:

title: Toliara Project, Madagascar
body:
Project overview

The Toliara Project being developed by Base Toliara has the makings of a wold-class mineral sands operation, producing ilmenite, zircon and rutile finished products

The large, high grade Ranobe deposit underpins the Toliara Project and has an estimated Mineral Resource of 2,580 million tonnes which is sufficient to support a 38-year mine life.

The project is located about 45km north of the town of Toliara in south west Madagascar and will involve the construct,ion of processing facilities at the mine site, a dedicated 55km haulage road, bridge across the Fihirana River and specialised port facilities. A definitive feasibility study has been completed to determine project design, execution planning and financing.

The project was granted a mining licence (PDE 37242), which was re-issued on 23 October 2017, and has a term of 40 years from 21 March 2012.

About Mineral Sands

Ilmenite and rutile are primarily used as primary inputs in the production of white pigment for paints, plastics and paper because of their brightness and very high refractive index (how effectively they reflect light). It is used widely in these products as it very stable and non-toxic. A small percentage of rutile is also used in the production of titanium metal used in various applications  including the aerospace industry and medical equipment.

Zircon has a range of uses, the most common being in the production of ceramic tiles. Zircon enables ceramic tiles to achieve brilliant whiteness and brightness in their products. Zircon is also non-toxic and is highly heat and wear resistant.

Source: Base Toliara

title: Obuasi Gold Mine, Ghana
body:
Phase 1: Set up the plant to achieve a daily processing rate of 2,000 tpd of ore, completed.

Phase 2: Work mainly involves construction of new buildings in the plant, surface infrastructure and tailings storage facilities, in parallel with underground materials handling systems and shaft refurbishment, paste-fill plant and new underground pumping and piping systems. 

Phase 2 operational readiness includes ramping up the mining operation including the start of mining in Block 8 lower, commissioning the KRS shaft, GCVS vent shaft, paste fill plant and installing the underground paste systems and commensurate recruitment and training.

Phase 3: Develop the infrastructure necessary to support the planned ramp up in production to 5,000 tpd.

Source: Anglo Gold Ashanti

title: Devil’s Gorge Hydropower Plant, Zambia and Zimbabwe
body:
• Build a 1,240 MW hydropower plant, located at the tail end of the Kariba Dam, downstream of the confluence of the Gwayi and Zambezi rivers 
  • The power generated will be shared equally by Zambia and Zimbabwe
  • The project will be situated about 60km downstream of the proposed Batoka Gorge hydropower scheme

According to a previous study, the recommended scheme includes:

  • An 181-metre-high concrete arch dam, 65 metres of which will be below the water level of the river
  • In addition, two underground power stations will be located on each side of the river, with a total capacity of 1,240 MW for the scheme
  • The reservoir is set to hold 33 billion cubic metres

title: Karowe Diamond Expansion, Botswana
body:
Karowe diamond mine, located in Botswana, is a state-of-the-art mine which was fully commissioned in Q2 2012. Karowe, which means precious stone in the local language, is a large-scale operating mine and is one of the world’s foremost producers of large, high quality, Type IIA diamonds in excess of 10.8 carats. Notable recoveries include the epic 2,488 carat Motswedi, the 1,758 carat Sewelô, the 1,109 carat Lesedi La Rona and the 813 carat Constellation.

RESOURCES AND RESERVES

The mine plan is based on:

Probable reserves from surface to a depth of 324 m below surface of 19.84 mt containing 2.6 million carats, total Mineral Reserve (including stockpiles) of 25.40 mt containing 2.96 million carats (effective date of May 25, 2018, based on 1.25mm bottom cut off size and 70% of the insitu carats at 1.00 BCOS).

A total Indicated resource from surface to a depth of 600 m below surface of 57 mt containing 7.9 million carats including stockpiles (effective date of May 25, 2018, based on 1.25mm bottom cut off size and 70% of the insitu carats at 1.00 BCOS).

Inferred resource from 600 m to 750 m below surface of 1.93 mt containing 1.17 million carats.

TYPE: Hard rock. Open pit. Mine plan to depth of 324 m. Underground operations to commence Q1 2028.

MINE LIFE: Open pit operations to 2026 with underground commencing in Q1 2028.

PRODUCTION: 2.5 - 2.8 mtpa

Source: Lucara Diamond

title: Ahafo North, Ghana
body:
Ahafo North, with approximately 3.8 million ounces of Reserves and 1.4 million ounces of Measured, Indicated and Inferred Resources and significant upside potential to extend beyond Ahafo North’s current 13-year mine life.

It expands Newmont’s existing footprint in Ghana with four open pit mines and a standalone mill located about 30 km from the Ahafo South operation.

Ahafo North is expected to add between 275,000 and 325,000 ounces of gold per year, with all-in sustaining costs of $800 to $900 per ounce for the first five full years of production.

Commercial production for the project is expected in the second half of 2025.

Total capital costs are estimated to be between $950 million and $1,050 million.

Location 290 km northwest of Accra, Ghana. 

Source: Newmont Corporation

title: Kobada Gold Project, Mali
body:
The Kobada Main Deposit is a large, shallow and well-drilled open pittable Mineral Resource. Toubani Resources is primarily focused on this deposit at present while simultaneously exploring and testing the adjacent strikes.

  • A large, continuous 4.5km long open pit hosting global Mineral Resources of 2.2Moz
  • Kobada remains open along strike in both directions and at depth
  • Oxide depth averages 65m and can extend beyond 120m in some areas of the pit, well beyond other oxide deposits in West Africa
  • Low stripping ratio with mineralisation from surface

Kobada Main Deposit is part of a much larger system being explored by Toubani, and includes Kobada East, Kobada North 1 and 2, and Kobada West. Toubani’s 2023 drill program has successfully extended strike extent from 5km to 11km at Kobada and defined new areas of gold mineralisation outside the current mineral resource estimate, with more than 40km of strike are yet to be drill tested.

Source: Toubani Resources

title: Kitoko Copper Project, DRC
body:
The Kitoko discovery confirms the presence of a significant high-grade copper mineralizing system between 1,000 meters and 1,140 metres below the surface. Kitoko fine-grained copper mineralization is hosted in near flat-lying siltstone of the lower Grand Conglomerate, like that observed at the tier-one Kamoa, Kakula, Makoko and Kiala deposits. Also, like these deposits, the Kitoko mineralization is bottom-loaded with the highest copper grades occurring at the base of the mineralized zone. 

As mineralization occurs at the Kakula orebody, the lower section of the mineralized zone features occurrences of high-grade chalcocite and bornite copper sulphide minerals, with chalcopyrite copper sulphide mineralization more prevalent towards the top. The currently defined mineralized zone is trending southwest over 1.9 kilometres of strike, with a dip extent of between 600 meters and mineralization remains open in all directions.

Source: Ivanhoe Mines

title: Meyas Sand Gold Project, Sudan
body:
The Meyas Sand Gold Project sits on the Arabian-Nubian Shield (ANS), close to Sudan’s northern border near Egypt, around 900 kilometres north of the capital Khartoum. The exploration license covers two main deposits – Galat Sufar South and Wadi Doum – and covers 1,000 square kilometres. Perseus has a 70% interest in the project, with the Government of Sudan holding a 20% stake and Meyas Nub, a local Sudanese enterprise, holding a 10% stake.

GALAT SUFAR SOUTH

The GSS deposit is located in the central portion of the Galat Sufar Andesite Domain. The GSS deposit is located just south of the contact between marine sediments to the north (a remnant of the Keraf sediments) and an andesitic volcanic sequence to the south. The andesitic sequence is heterogeneous comprising lava flows, pyroclastic deposits and primary volcanic breccias.

Of importance to deposit formation, the andesite sequence contains a discrete 80 to 200 metre wide volcaniclastic‐sedimentary horizon which contains dioritic sills / dykes. Mineralisation and alteration are concentrated in this unit, which is bordered to the north and south by increasingly unaltered andesitic flows and further volcaniclastics.

The host unit has been sequentially and intensely altered by the addition of albite, sericite, silica and lastly carbonate. Alteration grades from largely unaltered andesitic lavas and volcaniclastic host rocks to strongly altered and foliated silica – sericite schists in which the protolith cannot be identified. Pyrite is by far the most dominant sulphide with chalcopyrite, sphalerite, galena, tennantite / tetrahedrite occasionally seen in core and confirmed in petrological investigation. Gold is fine grained, typically less than 40 μm. With 95% of the gold being free gold, the remainder occurs as petzite. The gold contains ± 20% silver.

The dominant foliation at the prospect scale (S1) is pervasively developed throughout the GSS deposit area. It is sub‐vertical and strikes towards the NW (330° ‐ 340°) at moderate to high angles to the orientation of the mineralised unit.

WADI DOUM (WD)

The main, high-grade mineralization at WD outcrops at the base of a hill and is hosted by a strongly sulphidic volcaniclastic unit, which is in contact with a distinct rhyolite unit to the immediate east. The volcanoclastic unit dips at an angle of 20° to the southwest. This rhyolite is bounded to the east by a dacitic unit intruded by syn‐tectonic syenite / potassium altered diorite body which forms the summit of the main hill.

These lithologies are cut by thin (less than 0.75 cm), late, un‐mineralized felsic and mafic dykes. In contrast to the volcaniclastics, the rocks on the hill dip 75° to the east. Mineralization on the hill is associated with stringer zones within the syenite and in places smaller shears.

The high-grade mineralization is hosted within the volcanoclastic units which are confined by late felsic and mafic dykes. The mineralization is divided into a western volcaniclastic unit characterized by a dark colour caused by very fine-grained sulphides ( greater than 10 to 15%), which contains some of the best intercepts and a central unit of paler, sulphide rich felsic volcaniclastics which contain deformed sulphide veinlets and a lower grade footwall unit of largely un‐deformed felsic volcaniclastics. The dominant sulphide is pyrite (85% in Qemscan analysis) with the remainder comprising a mix of sphalerite, galena, chalcopyrite and freibergite.

Alteration is confined to sericitisation within the felsic volcanics and a wider halo of carbonate alteration. Silicification is noticeably absent or weak within the high-grade part of the deposit (hence its location at the base of the hill.

The area is dominated by a strong and pervasive, north‐south trending schistosity, which is largely followed by the late dykes. The high-grade mineralization often appears un‐affected by structure, whereas the mineralization hosted by the syenite on and around the summit of the hill does appear structurally controlled.

Source: Perseus Mining

title: Orapa Mine Cut 3, Botswana
body:
The Orapa Mine, a conventional open-pit diamond mine located 240 km west of Francistown, is undergoing a Cut 3 expansion to extend its operational lifespan and increase production capacity.

Project Scope

  • Mine Depth Expansion: Increasing the mine depth from 250 meters to 450 meters.
  • Resource Extraction: Enhancing access to deeper diamond-bearing ore.
  • Operational Efficiency: Implementing advanced mining techniques to optimize extraction and processing.

title: Kansanshi S3 Expansion, Zambia
body:
The S3 expansion entails an expansion of the mine pit and the mining fleet that services it, as well as the construction of a new processing plant, and a major expansion of the Kansanshi smelter. The result will be to extend Kansanshi’s mine life as a world class asset into the 2040s, increase copper production to more than 200,000 tonnes a year while continuing to drive economic development and jobs in Zambia.

Source: ZCCM Investments Holdings

The smelter will have a nameplate production capacity of 500,000 tonnes per annum of 99+%-pure blister copper anodes.

body:
Mogalakwena is located near the town of Mokopane within the Mogalakwena Local Municipality. Mogalakwena is one of the six local municipalities which form part of the Waterberg District, situated in the Western quadrant of the Limpopo Province in north eastern South Africa. 

Source: Anglo Platinum

Mogalakwena is the largest platinum concentrator in the world – a 600 kilo ton per month giant, was undertaken by a joint venture between DRA and TWP.

The scope of work included the engineering design, procurement, construction, management and commissioning of everything from the run of mine primary crusher to the wet process plant.

The system built and installed included:

  • A 60’ x 113’ primary crusher with a 1 MW drive, capable of crushing material from 1200mm to 475mm
  • A 600kW secondary crushing system for reducing material to -65mmA high-pressure grinding roll (HPGR_ with two 2800kW motors enabling it to produce a product size of -8mm ate a feed rate of 1270 dmtph
  • A primary mill fitted with a 17.5 MW gearless drive
  • A rougher flotation system featuring two parallel banks with a feed rate of 450 dmtph
  • A single 7.9m dia x 11.7m long 17.5 MW gearless drive secondary mill with a capacity of 900tph, producing a final grind of 80% -75µm
  • Four 35m dia thickeners for intermediate float, two 35m diameter units for concentrates and four 12 diameter units for ultra-high rate final tails
  • The concentrate handling facility itself features 144m2 filters

Mogalakwena has a mine life of more than 30 years with potential to extend further. 

Source: DRA Global

title: Simandou Project, Guinea
body:
Port

The footprint of the future river port covers and area of approximately 3.45km², on the left bank of the Morébayah. This proposed infrastructure for Phase I consists of:

  • Two general cargo berths with an unloading facility for barges, including one for handling petroleum products;
  • Four berths equipped with gantry loaders for loading iron ore onto barges;
  • A railway loop which is the terminal of the rail transport line for iron ore export and sending supplies to the mine;
  • A storage yard for general cargos including construction material during the construction phase; with a spur railway line during the operation phase to load equipment, materials and fuels onto trains to be transported to the Simandou mine;
  • An iron ore storage yard equipped with stackers and reclaimers;
  • Rotary dumpers to unload the iron ore wagons, connected to conveyor belt systems for handling the iron ore;
  • An office building and base camp;
  • An electrical station with heavy fuel generators;
  • Freshwater supply and distribution system;
  • Workshops for maintenance, repair and welding;
  • Warehouses for spare parts and consumables;
  • A wastewater treatment plant and a settling tank;
  • A waste storage area, to be followed by the construction of an incinerator;
  • An Oxygen-Acetyline factory within the port limit;
  • 4G mobile phone towers, required for communication within the port area, for boats positioning and for communication in the channel and transhipment anchorage; and
  • Two quarries for construction materials: one for granite at Senguelen equipped with a crushing station, and one for laterite at Bamboro.

The existing rural track between the N4 road at Maferinya and the port has been repaired by WCSP. An access road along the railway will be built to connect the port to the N4 road in order to provide bypass for the communities as well as for the urban area of Maferinya.

Besides the above onshore facilities, a river channel will be dredged to allow the barges and ships to navigate to the transhipment anchorage suitable for large ocean-going vessels.

Railway

The railway starts near Port Morébaya, runs eastward to Forécariah, then runs along the border between Guinea and Sierra Leone, passing Kelemou, Madina, and then the Kuru Mountains to the south of the Fouta Djallon Highland via the Kindia Tunnel (11.80 km) and passing Kassa Station. After Kassa, the railway extends northeast and crosses the highland mountains via the Mamou Tunnel (8.95 km), passes along the southern foothills of the mountains until Ouré-Kaba Station, past Tagagna and Liaya, and then the route leaves the border. It then runs parallel with the N1 Highway heading to the east and southeast, before crossing the Niger River and again running in parallel with the N1 Highway until Faranah Station. After Faranah, the railway extends east along the southern boundary of the Upper Niger National Park, crosses the Mafou River, the Niandan River and the N33 Highway, passes Nialinko Station and runs along the mountains. It then passes Diankoya Station, crosses Sonamba River to the south of Médina, runs southeast until the west of Kérouané Township where the Station is established, crosses the Milo River and finally arrives at the foothills of the Simandou Mining Area.

Mine

The Mining Project will include the following components:

  • Mine Access:  access to the open-pit mine will be via access roads going uphill to the top of the mountain, most probably on both east and west sides during construction.
  • The pioneer mining area will comprise one or two open pits, using the blasting and excavation method to exploit the iron ore blocks, with haulage by heavy duty trucks to feed into the prime crushing stations at the designed fringe of the open pits. Conveyor systems will then carry the ore downhill to reach the processing plant.
  • Mineral Processing: the crushed iron ore will be transported from the pit areas to the mineral processing plant via two or three surface conveyors. The mine plant site will be located on relatively flat ground close to the train loading facility northwest of the deposits. Mineral processing will consist of screening and secondary crushing. The final product is high-grade iron ore fines and lumps ready for rail shipment and sea shipment.
  • Mine Support Facilities: support facilities will be located adjacent to the railway terminal on the west side of the mine. These include a mining camp, mobile equipment workshop, fuel storage, power generation, concrete batch plant, administrative offices, temporary ore storage and water management infrastructure.
  • Rock waste material left over after mining will be stored in a dumping pit. The location of the dumping pit will be carefully chosen, taking into consideration environmental and safety factors. Proper preservation measures will be deployed to ensure the stability of the waste stockpiles and to avoid waste rocks to be flooded by heavy rain.
  • Other supporting facilities will include a water reservoir, to be constructed to maintain fresh water supply to the mining facilities both for living use and for environmental purposes such as dust suppression. Other miscellaneous facilities required are being assessed and designed.
  • A supporting airport 20km north of Kérouanéis being planned to improve the logistics to the mine. The airport will be constructed in three separate phases. The runway will be initially laterite in Phase 1A, then to be hardened by concrete in Phase 1B. There is a potential plan to expand to a longer airstrip during Phase 2. Phase 1B includes constructing buildings and facilities required for airport operation.

Source: Winning Consortium Simandou

title: Waterberg PGM Project, South Africa
body:
The Waterberg PGM Project is located in South Africa on the Northern Limb of the Bushveld Complex. Waterberg represents a large-scale platinum group metal resource with an attractive risk profile given its shallow nature. The project facilitates fully mechanized production with the potential to have amongst the lowest operating costs in the PGM sector.

Waterberg is a joint venture between Platinum Group (37.19%), Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd. (“Implats”) (14.86%), HJ Platinum (21.95%) which consists of Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (“JOGMEC”) and Hanwa Co., and Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) partner Mnombo Wethu Consultants (Pty) Ltd. (26%). As a result of Platinum Group’s 49.90% ownership in Mnombo, the Company has an effective interest in the Waterberg JV of 50.16%.

Platinum Group Metals Ltd. made the initial discovery of this completely new section of the Bushveld Complex in November 2011. The initial exploration was funded by JOGMEC. In October 2017, Implats purchased a 15% interest in the Waterberg Project for USD$30M and acquired a right of first refusal for concentrate offtake. Hanwa Co. retains a right to all metal marketing.

A Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) was completed in 2016. The results of a Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS) were announced on September 4, 2019. A Mining Right for the Waterberg Project was granted by the South African Department of Mineral Resources and Energy in early 2021. An update to the 2019 DFS was completed in September 2024.

Reserves and resources were updated as part of the 2024 DFS. Proven and Probable Reserves: 246.2 million tonnes at 2.96 g/t 4E or 23.41 million ounces 4E on a 100% project basis.

Source: Platinum Group Metals

Waterberg represents a large-scale platinum group metal resource with an attractive risk profile given its shallow nature. The project facilitates fully mechanized production with the potential to have amongst the lowest operating costs in the PGM sector.

title: Lumwana Copper Expansion, Zambia
body:
The project involves a two-phase expansion to double copper production and increase mining volumes through process circuit enhancements and increased throughput capacity.

Phase 1: Process Circuit Expansion

  • Doubling plant throughput from 27Mt to 52Mt by twinning the existing process circuit.
  • Annual copper production will increase from 120kt to an average of 240kt per annum.

Phase 2: Mining Volume Ramp-Up

  • Total mining volumes will increase incrementally from 150Mt to 240Mt, followed by a further increase to 290Mt per annum from 2030 onwards.
  • The expansion will support long-term production sustainability and enhance operational efficiency.

title: Karo Platinum Mine, Zimbabwe
body:
Karo Platinum Mine project is an integrated platinum mining and refining development located in the Great Dyke, Mashonaland West District, Zimbabwe, spanning 23,902.9 hectares. The project aims to establish a world-class platinum group metals (PGMs) mining and processing operation.

Key Project Components:

Mining Operations:

  • Open-pit mining in Phase 1, targeting an annual production of 150,000 ounces of PGMs in concentrate.
  • Expected to scale up to 1.4 million ounces of refined PGMs per year.
  • Estimated mine life of 20 years.

Processing & Refining Facilities:

  • Karo Refining will include:
    • Concentration, smelting, and refining of PGMs.
    • Base metal refinery for by-product recovery.
    • Precious metals refinery for final PGM production.

title: Mayumba Gas-Fired Power Plant, Gabon
body:
• Build a 21 MW gas-fired power plant in phases in the Nyanga province
  • Build a 32 km gas pipeline and associated equipment connecting the facility to Perenco's offshore oil fields 
  • The power plant will be connected to the Louetsi south electrical distribution network and produce 180 GWh a year
  • The facility will supply power across the major population centres of Mayumba, Tchibanga, Bongolo, Mouila and Lambaréné
  • It is expected to benefit 80,000 households
  • In parallel with the power plant construction, the plant is to be connected to the existing network of the city of Mayumba; this includes the construction of a 100 km 30 kV line between Mayumba and Tchibanga, and the electrification of rural areas along the Mayumba-Tchibanga axis 
  • Development of roads and various networks, as well as other related infrastructures

 

The plant can be expanded to 50 MW in a second development phase

title: Dibwangui Hydropower Plant, Gabon
body:
•  Design, finance, construct and operate a 15 MW hydroelectric plant on the Louetsi River to meet the electricity needs of the provinces of Nyanga and Ngounie
  • The plant will inject 90 GWh a year into the interconnected network
     

Overall Scope
– Closure works on the Louetsi River to create a reservoir
– Hydraulic tunnels, pipes and channels (inlet tunnels)
– A hydroelectric plant equipped with 3 Kaplan turbines, with a flow rate of 25 m3/s/turbine, nominal power of 5.1 MW/turbine and a net head of 23.7 metres
– An outdoor electrical substation
– Overhead power lines between Dibwangui and Bongolo 
– Re-electrification of the villages between Dibwangui and Makongonio
– Remodelling the Bongolo substation
– Constructing ancillary facilities necessary to the operation of the facility
– The deconstruction or rehabilitation of temporary facilities

 

Dam Specifications

  • Conventional vibrated concrete gravity dam (BCV)
  • Dam height: 19.5 metres
  • Crest length: 95.87 metres (overflow dam at 52.87 metres and closure dam at 43 metres)
  • Reservoir area: 80.7 hectares

 

Access Roads

About 2.1 km of roads will have to be built, including dam access on the right bank, factory access on the left bank, substation access, screen and loading chamber, and towards the bridges (temporary bridges and permanent bridge)

In addition, the existing road will have to be raised in the flood zone upstream of the dam with the installation of new culverts over approximately 275 metres

A temporary MABEY type bridge of 44 tonnes and a span of 57.91 metres will have to be built crossing the Louétsi River, which will be transferred above the flood spillway

 

Transmission Lines:

Build a 22 km 90 kV high-voltage overhead line, operated at 63 kV, between the Dibwangui power plant’s booster station and the existing Bongolo substation

Work on a 40 km 20 kV medium-voltage overhead line for rural electrification along the road between the Dibwangui and Bongolo substations, of which 14 km already exists and needs to be renovated; the work in under way and expected to be completed by April 2025

title: Ngoulmendjim Hydropower Plant, Gabon
body:
• Build a dam and 82 MW hydropower plant on the Komo River, 125 km from Libreville, in the Estuaire province
  • Project is to be undertaken under a build-own-operate-transfer (BOOT) agreement that includes the design, financing, construction and management of the project
     

Hydropower plant

  • The hydro plant will have an average annual production of 550 GWh and supply 38% of Libreville's electricity needs. The beneficiaries are estimated at 460,000 people 
  • The plant will have three Pelton turbines of 28.5 MW each


Dam

  • The dam will be roller compacted concrete (RCC) with rockfill sections and an upstream membrane mask
  • Dam height: 38.5 metres
  • Dam crest length: 635 metres
  • Reservoir area: 30 square km
  • Average net fall height: 219 metres
  • Average flow rate: 44 cubic metres per second

 

Transmission line

  • 65 km Ngoulmendjim / Kinguélé Aval downstream line section:
    - Type of line: Monocircuit 225 kV, 1 ASTER 366 or 570 cable
    - Power to be evacuated 150 MW
  • 30 km Kinguele Aval downstream / Ndouaniang line section:
    - Type of line: Monocircuit 225 kV, 2 ASTER 570 cables
    - Power to be evacuated 306 MW

 

Ancillary works including the construction of a 10 km access road

title: Bizerte Bridge, Tunisia
body:
Project Scope: A4 Motorway – Bizerte Permanent Link

The project involves the construction of a new permanent link between the A4 motorway and the city of Bizerte, improving connectivity and traffic flow. The scope is divided into three key packages:

Package 1 & Package 3:

  • Construction of connecting roads to the main bridge.
  • Northern side: 2.7 km, Southern side: 4.7 km.
  • Development of three interchanges to facilitate smooth traffic movement.

Package 2:

  • Extension of the main bridge by 2.1 km.
  • The bridge will be elevated 56 meters above sea level to accommodate maritime traffic.

title: Upper Umkhomazi Bulk Water Supply Scheme Phase 1, South Africa
body:
The project involves the construction and upgrading of water supply infrastructure, including dams, raw water conveyance, and potable water distribution systems. The key components include:

Dams:

  • Proposed dams at Impendle (for costing purposes) and Smithfield.
  • Construction of a high dam at Smithfield with a capacity of 251,000 m³.
  • A 33 km-long, 3.5m diameter tunnel to channel water from the river to the dam.

Raw Water Conveyance:

  • Infrastructure to transport raw water from Smithfield Dam to the proposed Balancing Dam at Baynesfield.
  • Conveyance of raw water from the Balancing Dam to the Water Treatment Plant.

Potable Water Distribution:

  • Development of potable water conveyance infrastructure from the Water Treatment Plant to the Umlaas Road/Cato Ridge Reservoir.

body:

title: Mimbula Copper Expansion, Zambia
body:
The Mimbula Copper Project is a large-scale mining licence held by Moxico Resources through its Zambian subsidiary, Mimbula Minerals Ltd. It is located in the Zambian Copperbelt on the outskirts of the town of Chingola.

The Phase 1 mining operations to produce 10,000 tonnes of copper cathode per annum using a heap leach and solvent extraction/electrowinning (SX/EW)

Phase 2 of the Mimbula Copper Project will expand the Phase 1 operations to 56,000 tonnes per annum through a 46,000 tonne per annum agitated leach and SX/EW circuit.

Phase 3 of Mimbula is the construction of a cobalt processing plant to extract cobalt from the ore and the pregnant leach solution.

title: Uganda-DRC Power Interconnector Line
body:
• Construct a 352.2 km 220 kV (400kV) transmission line connecting the Ugandan and Democratic Republic of Congo's (DRC) power grids
  • The line will run from the Nkenda substation in Kasese in Uganda's Western Region and on to Bunia and Butembo via Beni in northeastern DRC
  • The work includes building associated substations at Beni, Butembo and Bunia, and upgrading the Nkenda substation
  • The work will also cover SCADA and optic fibre
  • The project aims to interconnect Uganda and the DRC to supply the eastern DRC with hydropower from Uganda's 600MW Karuma and 183MW Isimba plants, replacing the expensive diesel generators currently in use
  • The line is set to provide electricity to rural communities in eastern DRC

title: Platreef Mine, South Africa
body:
Flatreef Underground Deposit Project involves the development of the Flatreef underground deposit, a six-kilometer-long mineralized zone containing platinum-group elements (PGE), nickel, copper, and gold. The deposit is located within the Platreef mineralized sequence, at depths ranging from 700 to 1,100 meters below the surface.

Project Phases:

Phase 1 (Completion: Q3 2024)

Annual production:

  • 113,000 ounces of palladium, rhodium, platinum, and gold (3PE+Au)
  • 5 million pounds of nickel
  • 3 million pounds of copper

Phase 2 (Completion: 2027)

Annual production increase to:

  • 591,000 ounces of 3PE+Au
  • 26 million pounds of nickel
  • 16 million pounds of copper

title: Sfax Metro, Tunisia
body:
Two tram lines (33.5 kilometer).

  • T1: A 22.8-kilometer tram line connecting the Airport Road to Cité El Ons via the city center and Martyrs Avenue. 38 stations.
  • T2: A second tram line connecting the area of Gremda to the city center and extending over 10.7 kilometers. 17 stations.

Phase I includes the completion of a part of the first light tram line T1 which extends 13.5 km long, from the region of Chihia to the airport.

Phase II includes the completion of the second light rail line T2 relating the city centre and Gremda road to the border of the high-density area, that is the 4 kilometer- away bypass.

Phase III includes the completion of the remaining part of the first light rail line T1 to the edge of Ons in the suburb of Sakiet Ezzit, taking into account the development of urban layout in the region.

Phase IV includes the finalisation of the remaining part of the second T2 light rail line and the completion of high-quality bus lines. This will be carried out in phases that will be determined later in view of the urban extension of the city.

Source: SMLS

title: Strait of Gibraltar Link, Morocco
body:
Also known as Spain-Morocco Undersea Rail Tunnel Project. 

Project alternatives

The different options analyzed were suspended bridge on fixed supports, suspended bridge on floating supports, submerged tunnel supported on the seabed, submerged floating tunnel and excavated tunnel. On the basis of a multi-criterio analysis between the different alternatives studied, it was already concluded in the mid-1990s that the two most feasible solutions were the suspended bridge on fixed supports and the excavated tunnel.

Given the topographic configuration of the area of the Straits of Gibraltar, there were 2 possible routes: to the East the Canyon Route between Punta Canales and Punta Cires with a distance between banks of only 14 km and depths greater than 800 m, and to the West, the Threshold Route between Punta Paloma and Punta Malabata, with a maritime route of 28 km and with maximum depths of around 300 m.

Bridge Solution

In relation to the bridge option, the possible solutions for each of the routes were evaluated. Thus, at the end of the second stage of studies in 1996, a primary preliminary project APP95 was obtained with the Bridge 14 solution, in reference to the route by the Canyon Route, the Bridge 28 solution, in reference to the route by the Threshold Route.

Bridge 14 would be composed of two large central spounds of 5,000 m, and two other side spounds of 1,800 m each. The maximum foundation depth would be 480 m, and the maximum pile height would be more than 1,100 m. This alternative was discarded due to the extraordinary dimensions, very far from what is executed worldwide.

Bridge 28 would be composed of three large central spases of 3,550 m, and two other side sides of 1,500 m each, which would be linked to a north approach viaduct of 7,475 m and another south viaduct of 6,275 m. The maximum foundation depth would be 315 m, and the maximum pile height would be around 800 m. The cross section would be composed of 4 road lanes, two in each direction. The possibility of incorporating two railway tracks centered on the dashboard was also analyzed.

Tunnel solution

Regarding the tunnel option, the only possible route is proposed through the shallower route, that is, by the Threshold Route, and would be designed for railway circulation. The distance between terminals would be 42 km, with 38.5 km in tunnel of which 28 km would be under the sea. The cross section of the tunnel would be provided in two parallel single-track tubes with a service / security gallery centered between them, and transverse connection galleries every 340 m. The tunnel would be designed for both conventional and high-speed train traffic, in addition to shuttles for the transport of light and heavy vehicles between the two terminals located on the respective banks. This operating model would be similar to that of the Eurotunnel.

Description of the railway tunnel base solution

The excavated tunnel base solution provides for the union of the Moroccan terminal located in Tangier and the Spanish terminal located near Punta Paloma. The composition of the main works is shown in the diagrams below and would consist of two railway tunnels with a single track and circular section of 7.90 m inner diameter, a service / security gallery of 6 m in diameter centered between the two, and transverse galleries every 340 m, with a diameter each of them of 6 m.

From the point of view of security, the execution of a Safe Parking Zone (ZAS) is planned at the lowest point of the tunnel, which would be provided with stop areas in the railway tunnels, security areas and intervention areas, as well as a smoke extraction gallery. This gallery, which would be made primarily to investigate the land to be crossed, in particular those that fill the paleochannels, would serve as an access route to the ZAS during the execution of the works, and finally would be used for the evacuation of fumes in the exploitation phase of the infrastructure.

The geological discoveries (bioclastic sands and the paleochannels filled with gaps) during the campaigns carried out during the stage from 1996-2005, gave rise, among other modifications, to a new primary preliminary project in 2007 (APP07), in which these new findings were incorporated. From this document, it is worth highlighting an adaptation of the layout in the plant, a general decrease in the tunnel level, the reconsideration of the geological model, as well as the multiparametric analysis on the geomechanical behavior of the gaps, the revision of the design of the terminals, safety, facilities and railway equipment.

Planned cross-section

  • Two single-track railway galleries of 7.9 m inner diameter.
  • A pressurized service/security gallery, 6.0 m in diameter, centered between both railway galleries and communicating with them through transverse passages at regular intervals (every 340 m).

As for the operation, the APP95 had planned a first phase of operation in monotube, that is, on a single railway track in which it would circulate in both directions, connected to a smaller diameter service gallery that would solve the problems of maintenance and safety of the work, while a second railway tunnel was built according to demand.

However, recent studies have shown that traffic demand, according to forecast models, does not recommend phased execution, and it will be more profitable to build the project in its final configuration, that is, with the two railway tubes. On the other hand, the large projects of base tunnels in Europe executed in recent years, are setting a trend with a configuration of only two railway tunnels, without service/security tunnels between them. This variant would reduce the cost and maintain an acceptable level of security.

title: Lagos Food Systems and Logistics Park, Nigeria
body:
Lagos Central Food Security System and Logistics popularly known as LHP Hub is a comprehensive system located at Ketu-Ereyun, Epe. It is designed to meet the needs of wholesalers and retailers and consumers alike. It is planned as a modern, smart central market system equipped with state-of-the-art facilities for major food processing, storage, and distribution. 

This project, a partnership between the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Systems, Lagos State through the expertise of Origin Tech Group through its construction company Rhema Projects is expected to address the growing demand for safe and wholesome food in Lagos. This project is set to play a critical role in ensuring food security, reducing post-harvest losses, and fostering economic growth in Lagos and beyond.

Total Land Area: 1,100,000 sq.m

Park Features

  • Storage Facilities
    • 22,500 m² Dry Storage Facility x 4
    • 22,500 m² Cold Storage Facility x 2
    • 9,000 m² Dry Storage Facility x 1
  • Commercial Facilities
    • 22,500 m² Dry Storage Facility x 4
    • General Administrative Facility
    • Fuel Station
    • Abattoir
  • Infrastructure
    • Power Generation Plant (900mW)
    • Waste Recycling Facility
    • Roads (4.75 km )
    • Abattoir
  • Ancillary/Services
    • 6 lane Toll Gate + Gate House
    • Modern Clinic
    • Fire Station
    • Police Station
    • Housing Facility

Project Structure

Once fully operational, the hub will include the following key features:

The Administrative Convergence Area

The Administrative Convergence Area which is planned to become the heart of the hub will house offices for various personnel and functions, ensuring seamless coordination and administration of the entire facility.

The Dealing Areas

The Dealing Areas will be a dedicated space for bulk dealers, designed to accommodate key distributors of vegetables, fresh fruits, meat, and seafood. Spacious display areas and ancillary spaces for administration, the dealing area streamlines the process of getting fresh produce to market.

Dry storage area

While the Dry storage area will be a warehouse system, the largest of its kind in Nigeria, upon completion it will have capacity to store 4,620 units of 30-tonne trucks of goods, ensuring that dry food items are preserved in optimal conditions.

Cold storage facility

A cold storage facility spanning 22,500 sqm, this facility is envisaged as a critical node of the infrastructure as it is crucial for the sorting, grading, and storing of perishable foodstuffs. It will accommodate 2,310 trucks, ensuring that fresh produce remains in prime condition until it reaches consumers.

With a capacity to process 10,000 metric tons of food per day, this shared facility will allow medium-scale operators to break bulk goods into smaller units and rebrand them as needed. This system not only support local businesses but also enhances the availability of diverse food products in the market.

The hub will have support facilities which will include a modern fire station, an emergency clinic, and an ultra-modern filling station, which will ensure the safety and well-being of all who operate within and rely on the facility.

Source: Lagos Food Systems and Logistics Park

title: Greater Mangaung Water Augmentation, South Africa
body:
The project involves the establishment of a ±180km buried water pipeline between the Gariep Dam wall and the Longridge Reservoir Complex in the Mangaung Metropolitan Municipality metropolitan area. It also entails:

  • The construction of pumping stations, a water storage facility, and Water Treatment Works
  • Renewable energy facilities to offset long-term operational costs.
  • A series of pipelines that will link the Bloemspruit Waste Treatment Works, the Sterkwater Waste Treatment Works, and the North East Waste Treatment Works to the Mockes Dam
  • The temporary storage of the water in the Mockes Dam.
  • An increase in the abstraction into the Maselspoort water treatment works. 

The proposed scheme will traverse the Xhariep District Municipality, the Kopanong Local Municipality and the Mangaung Metropolitan Municipality, all in the Free State, South Africa. 

(Source: Mangaung Gariep Water Augmentation Project)

title: Kasumbalesa Border Post, Zambia
body:
The project involves the development of a One-Stop Border Post and auxiliary infrastructure, including a multi-facility economic zone, a 2,000-capacity truck park, a fire station, 300 shops, a hotel, and a shopping mall.

title: Bougouni Lithium Project, Mali
body:
The Bougouni Lithium project is a hard-rock, open-pit lithium mine being developed in southern Mali.

  • Annual Production: 220,000 tonnes of 6% spodumene concentrate.
  • Metallurgical Recovery: 71%
  • Life of Mine (LOM): 8.5 years
  • Laboratory Recoveries: 75%
  • Total LOM Production: 1.94 million tonnes of concentrate.

title: Glen Valley Wastewater Reclamation Upgrade, Botswana
body:
The project involves the reconstruction of the existing Glen Valley Wastewater Treatment Plant, the development of a new Reclamation Plant, and the construction of a transfer pipeline.

The new wastewater treatment plant will have a capacity of up to 90 ML/d, while the reclamation plant will be developed in two stages with a maximum capacity of 50 ML/d

title: Ihumwa Dry Port, Tanzania
body:
The Ihumwa Dry Port project involves the construction of a dry port facility, including railway lines, a large marshalling yard, and facilities for handling imports and exports. 

It will also include the construction of the Dodoma City Outer Ring Road, a dual carriageway spanning approximately 112.3 kilometers, which will enhance access to the dry port. 

This road project is divided into two lots:

  • Lot 1: Nala – Veyula – Mtumba – Ihumwa Dry Port (52.3 km) 
  • Lot 2: Ihumwa Dry Port – Matumbulu – Nala (60.0 km) 

Project Value:

  • Lot 1: Estimated at approximately TZS 100.840 billion 
  • Lot 2: Estimated at approximately TZS 120.860 billion 

The project is financed through a collaboration between the African Development Bank (AfDB) and the Government of Tanzania.

title: Wessal Bouregreg, Morocco
body:
The Wessal Bouregreg Development is a large-scale, mixed-use waterfront project in Morocco, spanning 1.1 million square meters. Designed to enhance urban living and cultural infrastructure, the development is being implemented in three phases and features a blend of residential, commercial, cultural, and public spaces.

Key Components:

1. Residential & Commercial Spaces

  • 4,200 residential units
  • 5,000 sqm shopping mall
  • 105,000 sqm commercial office space

2. Cultural & Entertainment Facilities

  • 1,900-seat theatre
  • 350-seat auditorium
  • 25,000 sqm museum
  • 5 cultural centers

3. Landmark & Hospitality Developments

  • BMCE Tower (45-storey skyscraper)
  • Hilton Hotel (150 rooms)

4. Public Spaces & Infrastructure

  • Waterfront promenade
  • Public parks and plazas

title: Durban Port Upgrade and Expansion, South Africa
body:
Durban Port is undergoing a major upgrade and expansion to significantly boost its container handling capacity. The project aims to increase capacity from the current 2.9 million TEU to over 11 million TEU, positioning Durban as a key global trade hub.

The plans include expanding the container terminal, widening, and deepening the entrance channel, improving the channel depth at Maydon Wharf, expanding the automotive terminals, and upgrading the Bayhead and Langerberg Roads. Source: EThekwini Municipality

Key Project Features:

  • Capacity Expansion: Increasing container handling to 11+ million TEU
  • New Container Terminal: Construction of a modern terminal to support growing trade volumes
  • Infrastructure Upgrades: Enhancing port efficiency, logistics, and cargo processing

title: Longonjo Rare Earth Mine, Angola
body:
Develop the Longonjo rare earth open-pit mine in the Huambo district, approximately 350 km southeast of the capital Luanda in phases. The mine has a lifespan of 20+ years

The operation will extract, concentrate, calcine and chemically refine free-dig material to produce a high-value mixed rare earth carbonate (MREC) to be railed 273 km to the Atlantic Port of Lobito for export

Once in full production, the mine will produce ~5 % of the world’s output in the form of a high-value mixed rare earth carbonate, capable of being converted into permanent magnets for
electric vehicles and offshore wind turbines

The mine will comprise:

  • An open pit
  • Concentrator and recovery plants
  • Tailings storage facility (designed to meet the requirements of the Global Industry Standard on Tailings Management)
  • Process water supply
  • Bulk power supply in the form of hydropower from the 2 GW Lauca plant
  • Mine infrastructure
  • Workshops
  • Offices
  • Accommodation village
  • Recreational facilities
  • Associated infrastructure

 

Additional Information:

The mine will save over 4 million tonnes of CO2 emissions – the carbon equivalent of replacing 1.5 GW of fossil fuel electricity generation

title: Konkola Copper Expansion, Zambia
body:
The Konkola Copper Mines (KCM) Expansion Project in Zambia aims to increase annual copper production to 300,000 metric tons over the next five years.

Project Scope

  • Production Capacity Expansion: Scaling up from current output levels to 300,000 metric tons per year.
  • Mining Operations Enhancement: Increasing underground and surface mining activities.
  • Processing Infrastructure Upgrade: Improving smelting, refining, and ore processing facilities.
  • Sustainability Measures: Enhancing environmental management and operational efficiencies.

title: South Lokichar Field, Kenya
body:
The project involves the development of oil resources in South Lokichar Basin, located in Turkana County, north-western Kenya. It comprises Blocks 10BB and 13T and aims to establish Kenya’s first commercial oil production.

Key Components:

South Lokichar Basin Development

  • Oil production infrastructure for Blocks 10BB and 13T
  • Facilities for crude oil extraction, processing, and storage

Lokichar-Lamu Oil Pipeline

  • 824 km pipeline from South Lokichar Basin to Lamu Port
  • 20-inch diameter pipeline designed to transport up to 130,000 barrels per day of crude oil

Development of associated pumping stations and storage terminals
This project is a key part of Kenya’s LAPSSET (Lamu Port-South Sudan-Ethiopia Transport) Corridor, positioning the country as a regional hub for crude oil export.

title: Agogo Integrated West Hub, Angola
body:
36 new wells (21 producers and 15 Injectors), one converted FPSO with capacity for 120,000 bbl/day of oil production, 230 MMSCF/day of Gas Injection and 120,000 bbl/day of water injection. It will also entail approximately 100 km of rigid flowlines, 100 km of flexible flowlines and 100km of Umbilicals.

Agogo Integrated West Hub will produce hydrocarbons from Agogo and Ndungu Fields via both the existing Ngoma FPSO and the new Agogo FPSO that will be operational from mid 2026, reaching a peak of production of 175,000 bbl/day, thus fully exploiting the utilization and synergies with the existing infrastructures of the western area of the block 15/06.

Source: Azule Energy

title: Matola LNG Terminal and Gas Pipeline, Mozambique
body:
Beluluane Gas Company (BGC), an affiliate of the Matola Gas Company, was awarded the concession by the Mozambican Government for the importation of Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) into the Maputo harbor. The concession includes:

  • the operations of a permanently moored Floating Storage Regasification Unit (FSRU)
  • marine infrastructure 
  • a new high-pressure gas pipeline.

The gas pipeline will connect the FSRU with a new gas fired power plant, Central Térmica de Beluluane (CTB), to be constructed in Beluluane Industrial Park in Matola.

The pipeline will also connect to the existing Matola Gas Company (MGC) pipeline network in Matola which is connected to the Rompco pipeline, supplying gas to South Africa.

Source: Beluluane Gas Company BGC

title: Durban Aerotropolis, South Africa
body:
The Durban Aerotropolis is a large-scale 32,000-hectare mixed-use development near King Shaka International Airport. The project is designed as an integrated urban and economic hub, featuring distinct zones with varying land use allocations:

Urban Core

  • 400 housing units
  • 20-story buildings

Land Use Distribution:

  • 67% Residential
  • 13% Office & Banking
  • 15% Retail & Shopping
  • 2% Industrial & Warehouse
  • 3% Civic & Institutional

Urban Nodes

  • Designated areas for residential, office, and retail use
  • 10-story mixed-use developments

Land Use Distribution:

  • 60% Residential
  • 10% Office & Banking
  • 18% Retail & Shopping
  • 8% Industrial & Warehouse
  • 4% Civic & Institutional

Urban Frame

Focus on industrial, commercial, and residential development

Land Use Distribution:

  • 49% Warehouse & Industrial Facilities
  • 22% Residential
  • 12% Retail & Shopping
  • 8% Office & Banking
  • 8% Civic & Institutional
  • 1% Agriculture

Development Parks

Primarily residential with supporting commercial and industrial infrastructure

Land Use Distribution:

  • 73% Residential
  • 16% Industrial & Warehouse
  • 7% Retail & Shopping
  • 3% Office & Banking
  • 1% Civic & Institutional

Eco Developments

Designed to integrate agriculture with sustainable living

Land Use Distribution:

  • 86% Agriculture
  • 14% Residential

The Durban Aerotropolis aims to stimulate economic growth, enhance connectivity, and create a thriving business and residential community centered around King Shaka International Airport.

title: Bishoftu Airport, Ethiopia
body:
The Bishoftu Airport project is set to become Africa’s largest airport and a key component of Ethiopian Airlines' 2035 vision, with a planned capacity to accommodate 100 million passengers annually.

Located 40 miles south of Addis Ababa, the airport will cover 35 square kilometers and is designed as an airport city, featuring duty-free shopping malls, hotels, training centers, a cargo logistics hub, aviation maintenance facilities, and aircraft body manufacturing.

The project is being executed in three phases, with Phase 1 focusing on the construction of two terminals.

Key Features

  • Passenger Terminal: 1.1 million m² with full passenger facilities
  • Airline Support Facilities: 126,190 m²
  • Cargo & Airport Support Facilities: 100,000+ m²
  • Airfield & Essential Airport Infrastructure

title: Olkaria Geothermal Expansion, Kenya
body:
Project Scope:

  • The project involves drilling 42 geothermal wells, including production, monitoring, and reinjection wells. These wells will be connected to existing and future geothermal power plants. 
  • Construction of well pads and cellars for drilling activities, new roads to interconnect the well pads, and laying of water supply lines from existing storage tanks to the well pads. The drilling operations will utilize three rigs owned by KenGen, with each well drilled to depths of 1-3 kilometers to access steam and water at high temperatures (250-350°C) and pressures (600-1200 PSI).

title: Mukono-Kampala Railway Rehabilitation, Uganda
body:
The Mukono-Kampala Meter Gauge Railway Rehabilitation focused on modernizing the 26.8 km railway line to improve speed, capacity, and operational efficiency. It was part of the broader East African Railways Rehabilitation Project, valued at $301 million.

Project Details:

  • 185 kg concrete sleepers, manufactured at Imathia Construction Factory in Kawoolo, Lugazi, were used to replace traditional steel sleepers.
  • The railway was designed to support speeds of up to 120 km/h, significantly higher than the previous 20-30 km/h.
  • The upgraded infrastructure allows the line to carry 650 passengers per trip.

title: Hoima International Airport, Uganda
body:
Also known as Kabaale International Airport, and Kabalega International Airport, the project is near Lake Albert in Hoima District, Western Uganda. 

Project Overview

The airport is designed to support both cargo and passenger operations, with infrastructure tailored to accommodate large aircraft and facilitate the nearby oil refinery. The project will be executed in two phases.

Key Infrastructure & Facilities

  • Runway: 3,500m long, 75m wide (including shoulders)
  • Taxiway: 60m wide (including shoulders)
  • Aircraft Parking Apron: 125,000m², with capacity for four large aircraft
  • Cargo Terminal: 3,240m² facility
  • Fuel Storage Capacity: 240,000 liters
  • Ground Support Equipment (GSE) Area: 5,000m² paved space
  • Airport Rescue & Fire Fighting Station: Equipped for three fire & rescue vehicles

Additional Facilities

  • Parallel taxiway
  • CAT 1 airfield ground lighting
  • Navigation aids
  • Air traffic control tower
  • Passenger terminal and cargo buildings
  • Roads and parking facilities

Project Phases

  • Phase 1: The runway and cargo handling facilities, designed to support oil refinery operations. The runway is capable of handling large cargo aircraft with a carrying capacity of 100 tons.
  • Phase 2: Expand facilities for passenger operations, aiming to enhance tourism and business in the agricultural sector.

title: Kigali-Muhanga Road Expansion, Rwanda
body:
The Kigali-Muhanga Road Expansion Project in Rwanda involves upgrading a 45-kilometer stretch between Nyabugogo (Kigali) and Ruyenzi (Kamonyi District). 

Project Scope:

  • 12.2 kilometers of the road will be expanded from the existing two lanes to four lanes.
  • 11.9 kilometers of climbing lanes will be constructed specifically for heavy trucks on ascents.
  • Comprehensive drainage systems will be installed to manage water runoff and prevent flooding.
  • The project includes bicycle lanes and pedestrian sidewalks to enhance safety for non-motorized users.
  • Construction will involve the development of climbing lanes to improve the movement of heavy trucks on hilly sections.
