title: Escravos Seaport Industrial Complex (ESIC), Nigeria
body:
The development of Escravos Seaport Industrial Complex (ESIC) project commenced in 2019 and aims to develop 31,000 hectares of Delta State land into a Deep Seaport, Crude oil refinery, Gas Complex, Independent Power Plant (IPP), Airport, Nature Park, etc. It is a development that promises to massively open up Delta State and seven other States including FCT – Abuja to international investment in trade, commerce and industry. ESIC will transform Delta State economy and those of ESIC beneficiary States from a rural-driven economy with sprinklings of Urban development to a metropolis driven economy of international dimension.

ESIC project is a Non – Solicited Public – Private Partnership (PPP) driven project regulated by Infrastucture Concession Regulatory Commission (ICRC) Laws of Federal Government of Nigeria. it is model after the Lekki Deep Seaport/Free Trade Zone (FTZ) to serve the marine/economic interest of the Niger Delta, Eastern and some Northern States of the Country specifically to solve the perennial port congestion problems in Nigeria.

The uniqueness of ESIC/ESIC deep seaport/Free Trade Zone (FTZ) development is that it incorporate the development of road, rail and marine connectivity approach to the hinterland destinations in order to optimize cargo flow through to ESIC/ESIC deep seaport i.e.

  • ROAD: ESIC seaport – Warri Sapele Expressway to linking at a point near Koko junction – (45 kilometers).
  • RAIL: ESIC seaport to Warri – (45 kilometers) to join the existing Warri – Ajaokuta – Itakpe rail line. Itakpe – Abuja (New 90 kilometers rail construct) terminating at the construction/development of Abuja Dry Port in a new district to be known as Abuja Port District.
  • MARINE: ESIC seaport through marine connectivity will connect to River Niger and hence to the  Inland port of Baro in Niger State (600 kilometers). River Niger Canal from ESIC Seaport to Baro will be dredge to 10 meters depth through a partnership entered into between MMCC and Suez Canal Authority of Egypt.
  • Construction of (6) six in numbers Inland/Dry Port at: Bayelsa State (Nun River),  Imo State (Oguta lake), Delta State (Okegbele), Ebu – Inyele Edo/Delta State (Idah), Kogi State and Dry Port (FCT – Abuja).

ESIC project will inspite of the absence of its own inland port in Anambra and Niger – State, guarantee to service the marine interest of Onitsha, Baro and Lokoja Inland ports from ESIC/ESIC deep seaport.

The (8) eight ESIC project beneficiary States are: Delta, Edo, Bayelsa, Imo, Anambra, Kogi, Niger & FCT Abuja will be granted share – holding Status in the equity of ESIC project.

Source: Mercury Maritime Concession Company

title: Lesotho Highlands Water Project Phase 2
body:
This is a collaborative water resources project between Lesotho and South Africa. It will augment the water supply to the Vaal River Basin by transferring water from Lesotho to South Africa. This will increase the current supply rate of 780 million cubic meters per year incrementally to more than 1,270 million cubic meters a year.

Key Components:

Polihali Dam: A 163.5 m high concrete-faced rockfill embankment dam wall with a crest length of 915 m. It will be built downstream of the confluence of the Senqu and Khubelu rivers. A 49.5 m high saddle dam and spillway will also be constructed. The 2.3-billion cubic metre Polihali dam will have a full supply level of 2,075 m above sea level.

Polihali Transfer Tunnel: A 5 m diameter and 38.5 km long concrete-lined water transfer tunnel will convey water from the Polihali Reservoir to the Katse Dam. The works will include an intake at the new Polihali Reservoir, gate shafts, access adits, and outlet works at Katse Dam. The outlet works will terminate in a Norwegian type lake tap that will be excavated by blasting inside the Katse Dam impoundment on the eastern flank of the existing reservoir.

Ancillary Infrastructure: This includes access roads, power lines, telecommunications links, bridges, offices, workshops, and residential accommodations. Electrical infrastructure includes the construction of new substations, upgrading of existing Lesotho Electricity Company (LEC) substations, the construction of new power lines, and the diversion of some of the existing distribution network.

  • Senqu bridge - length 855 meters 
  • Khubelu bridge - length: 270 meters (9 section x 30 meters sections), width: 13.55 meters
  • Mabunyaneng bridge - length: 120 meters (4 sections x 30 meters), width: 13.55 meters

title: Vision City Phase 2, Rwanda
body:

title: Cabora Bassa Pilot Gas Plant, Zimbabwe
body:
The Cabora Bassa Pilot Gas Plant in Zimbabwe is a pivotal project aimed at harnessing the country's natural gas resources to address energy deficits and stimulate economic growth. 

Technical Scope:

  • The primary facility is a 500 MW combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) power plant, designed for high efficiency and reduced emissions. The plant's capacity may be expanded to 1,000 MW in future phases. 
  • A 12 MW power plant will be constructed to supply electricity to the Eureka Gold Mine, utilizing gas from the Mukuyu field. 
  • The project includes the development of gas extraction, processing, liquefaction, and transportation infrastructure to support both the pilot and main gas-to-power plants.

title: Mosetse-Kazungula-Livingstone Railway, Botswana and Zambia
body:
Also known as Zambia-Botswana Railway Link Project. 

The project involves the development of a railway line connecting Zambia and Botswana, enhancing regional trade and transportation. The railway will extend from Livingstone in Zambia to Kazungula Border and Mosetse in Botswana.

Key Features:

  • Total Length: Approximately 430 km of railway track
  • Main Stations: 3 mainline stations along the route
  • Additional Infrastructure: Supporting facilities for freight and passenger operations

title: Mmamabula-Lephalale Rail Link, Botswana and South Africa
body:
The project involves the construction of a cross-border railway line connecting Botswana and South Africa, aimed at enhancing coal transportation and integrating Botswana’s coal deposits with South Africa’s heavy-haul rail network.

South Africa Section

  • Length: 67 km
  • Major Infrastructure: Includes a 3-4 km bridge across the Limpopo River
  • Objective: Links Mmamabula/Dibete in Botswana to Lephalale in South Africa
  • Capacity: 15 million tons per year (MTPA)

Botswana Section

  • Length: 56 km
  • Route: Extends from Mmamabula (Botswana) to Lephalale (South Africa)
  • Capacity: 15 million tons per year (MTPA)

title: Mpatamanga Hydropower Plant, Malawi
body:
Build, own, operate and transfer a 358 MW hydropower plant situated on the Shire River in the southern Blantyre and Neno districts

The primary works involve:

  • Building a main dam and a regulating dam, along with two reservoirs and two powerhouses –
    The 55-metre-high main dam will create a 20.2-square-kilometre main reservoir with a total storage of 272.5 million cubic metres, out of which 58 million cubic metres will be used for electricity generation.
    Water from the main reservoir will drop by approximately 66 metres through two 900-metre underground tunnels to a 301 MW main powerhouse located 1km downstream of the main dam. This powerhouse will be able to produce about 1,236 GWh a year.
    The water discharged from the main powerhouse into the Shire River will then flow into a 1.5-square-kilometre regulating reservoir created by a 45-metre-high regulating dam located 6 km downstream of the powerhouse.
    Water from the regulating reservoir will then be discharged into the river through a 57 MW powerhouse located at the foot of the dam, which will be capable of generating 308 GWh a year.
     
  • Constructing two transmission lines linking to the national grid, namely a 63 km 400 kV line running from the main powerhouse to the existing Phombeya substation and an 11 km 132 kV line that will connect the regulation dam powerhouse to the existing Tedzani-Kapichira transmission line 
     
  • Upgrading the S137 road on the Blantyre side, rerouting the S137 on the Neno side and constructing a new access road between the main and regulating dams (Blantyre side). Overall, about 32 km of road will be upgraded and 10 km constructed

title: Critical and Rare Earth Element Refining Facilities Phase 1
body:
• Build three facilities utilising ReElement’s proprietary refining platform to produce high-purity lithium carbonate, rare earth oxides and other critical minerals
  • In phase 1, the first plant is planned to be built in Gauteng, South Africa, the second in Zambia or Angola to leverage the Lobito Corridor, and the third in Lagos, Nigeria, to harness the country's lithium deposits
  • The plants will be built near mines and can be constructed by repurposing existing buildings due to the modular nature of the refining technology
  • The facilities will use locally and regionally sourced raw materials as feedstock, in addition to waste products such as old batteries, magnets and cellular phones 
  • The output is expected to support growing demand in the battery and defence industries within both Africa and North America

title: Double Tree by Hilton, Ethiopia
body:
This project comprises of the DoubleTree by Hilton Adama and DoubleTree by Hilton Dire Dawa. These are upcoming internationally branded hotels set to open in Ethiopia by 2028, marking Hilton’s expansion into key cities outside Addis Ababa.

DoubleTree by Hilton Adama will feature 188 guest rooms and suites with panoramic views of the Rift Valley. Amenities will include a ballroom, six meeting rooms, a business center, a spa, a fitness center, and an outdoor pool and deck. Dining options will comprise a lobby café, a signature restaurant, a terrace, and a pool bar and grill.

DoubleTree by Hilton Dire Dawa will offer 150 guest rooms and suites. Facilities will include diverse dining venues, a spa, a fitness center, an outdoor pool, and a deck. Meeting and event spaces will feature six meeting rooms, a ballroom, and a business center.
meta_description: This project comprises of the DoubleTree by Hilton Adama and DoubleTree by Hilton Dire Dawa. These are upcoming internationally branded hotels set to open in Ethiopia by 2028

title: Konza Technopolis, Kenya
body:
In 2009, The Konza Technopolis project was initiated with the procurement of a 5,000 acre parcel of land at Malili Ranch, 60km south east of Nairobi along Mombasa-Nairobi A109 road. With this, the realization of Africa’s Silicon Savannah officially launched.

The first phase of Konza City is expected to create over 20,000 direct and indirect jobs. The city will be developed as a public private partnership, in which the Government will take a minimal role, developing the public infrastructure and regulatory guidelines.

Konza is planned as a mixed-use, high density walkable city that accommodates a diversity of programmes and districts. By avoiding superblocks and auto-orientated roadways, Konza aims to be a livable, sustainable urban environment that encourages high-value development and discourages sprawl. Planning will take cues from successful global urban centers, yet be specific to the needs of Kenya and the region.

An integrated urban ICT network will support delivery of connected urban services and allow for efficient management of those services on a large scale. Specifically, a smart city framework will integrate infrastructure services (transportation, utilities, public safety, environment); citizen services (access and participation); city services (city information, planning and development), and business services (supportive services for local commerce).

As a smart city, Konza will gather data from smart devices and sensors embedded in the urban environment, such as roadways, buildings, and other assets. Collected data will be shared via a smart communications system and be analyzed by software that delivers valuable information and digitally enhanced services to Konza’s population. For example, roadway sensors will be able to monitor pedestrian and automobile traffic, and adjust traffic light timing accordingly to optimize traffic flows.

The master plan includes a university, a residential area, science and tech area, and an office band. The intersection of these zones create vivid connections and become points of interest that seed neighbourhoods of distinct character. The stitch master plan also contains a series of neighbourhood parks, located throughout the city with varied orientations. Most parks are connected to the green boulevard, a 60 meter parkscape and public transit corridor.

Source: International Association of Science Parks and Areas of Innovation

title: Kinshasa-Ilebo Railway (KIR) Extension, DRC
body:
• Build a greenfield 870 km standard-gauge line to transport freight and passengers between the cities of Kinshasa and Ilebo in the Democratic Republic of Congo's (DRC) Kasai province
  • The planned track has a standard gauge of 1,435 mm for a maximum axle load of 23 tonnes
  • It will be electrified by 25 kV - 50 Hz catenary and will include telecommunications facilities (in particular ground-to-train radio), allowing real-time tracking of trains
  • The line will include a single track with 26 intermediate stations – one station every 32 km – all equipped with passing tracks and adequate signalling for the crossing of trains
  • The maximum speed of freight and passenger trains will be 120km an hour, allowing a journey time of 8 hours and 30 minutes for the fastest trains
  • The railway facilities are designed to run from end to end as soon as the line is put into service
  • Two freight trains (maximum tonnage of 1,600 tonnes and maximum length of 750 m) and two passenger trains (1,000 seats per train) will run per direction per day, i.e. a total of eight trains per day

Project Objectives

  • The main objective of the Kinshasa-Ilebo railway is to ensure the continuity of rail transport between the port of Matadi in western DRC and the country’s centre, east and southeast regions, and beyond to the Southern African countries of Zambia, Zimbabwe and South Africa
  • The KIR will be connected to the Matadi-Kinshasa line, Kinshasa-Brazzaville road-rail bridge and the Republic of Congo's (RoC) railway network, and finally with the Ilebo-Lubumbashi-Zambia border line. The line will also allow the junction with the Kolwezi-Lobito line crossing Angola to the Port of Lobito

(From December 2016 feasibility study)

title: Zuzu, Mkwese and Same Solar Plants, Tanzania
body:
Tanzania is actively pursuing solar energy projects to enhance its power supply and meet the energy demands of its population. The Tanzania Electric Supply Company (TANESCO) has identified three key sites for solar power development:

  • Zuzu in Dodoma: A proposed 60 MW solar power plant.
  • Mkwese in Manyoni, Singida: A planned 199 MW solar power plant.
  • Same in Kilimanjaro: A targeted 50 MW solar power plant.

The International Solar Alliance (ISA), based in India, has expressed interest in investing in these projects and is conducting preliminary feasibility studies at the identified sites.

These efforts reflect Tanzania's commitment to sustainable energy development and its goal to provide electricity to 8.3 million people by 2030.

title: Alexandria Metro, Egypt
body:
Alexandria Metro Line shall extend from Abou-Qier (East) to K.P. 21 Matrouh Road (West) with a length of 43 km. 

Phase 1
It shall extend from Abou-Qier Railway Station to Misr Station with a total length of about 21.5 km. The said Phase shall include 18 Stations , 9 of them at-grade, 6 over track and 3 on viaduct, with a maintenance workshop and rolling stock depot with a total length of about 21.5 km.

Phase 2
It shall extend from Misr Station to Al-Max Station with a total length of about 8 km, the said Phase shall include 6 underground stations.

Phase 3
It shall extend from Al-Max Station to K.P. 21 Matrouh Road (at the west) with a total length of about 13.5 km including 500m located for the inspection area, the said phase shall include 9 stations, 3 of them on viaduct and 6 stations shall be under-ground stations.

Source: National Authority for Tunnels

title: Kinshasa-Brazzaville Bridge, RoC and DRC
body:
Overall Scope: Build a road-rail bridge linking the Democratic Republic of Congo’s (DRC) capital Kinshasa with the Republic of Congo’s (RoC) capital Brazzaville

Specific Scope: 

  • Build a 1.575 km-long toll bridge over the Congo River, located 65 km from Brazzaville on the Maloukou Trechot site and 87 km from Kinshasa on the Malukuin site
  • The bridge is planned to include 10 structural bays, two road lanes, a single railway track, sidewalks and border checkpoints
  • The total width of the road, including sidewalks, will be 16.24 metres
  • Access roads of 3.2 km and 6.8 km will be constructed on the river's right bank (RoC) and left bank (DRC) respectively

Connecting Routes:

  • RoC: Construct the 26km Yie-Maloukou Trechot road and upgrade the 23km road linking Yie to the Special Economic Zone of Maloukou Trechot
  • DRC: Build the 27km Maluku-RN1 Junction road and the 40km Greater Kinshasa bypass road
  • Project Value:
  • More than 5 million passengers and 3 million tonnes of freight are expected to cross the road-rail bridge each year

     
  • The road-rail bridge will be connected to the Kinshasa-Ilebo railway, which is planned for extension
  • The bridge is part of the Central African section of the Tripoli-Windhoek-Cape Town trade corridor (Trans-African Highway 3) between Libya, Namibia and South Africa
  • Its construction will facilitate the connection of the capitals of Chad, Cameroon, Gabon, RoC and DRC
  • Ultimately, the bridge is expected to complete the trade corridor connecting the continent’s Atlantic Ocean coast on the west to the Indian Ocean coast on the east.

title: Kenitra-Marrakech High-Speed Rail, Morocco
body:
The project involves the development of a 492 km high-speed rail line connecting Kenitra to Marrakech, executed in three phases:

  • Phase 1: 150 km from Kenitra to Ain Sebaa.
  • Phase 2: 130 km from Ain Sebaa to Nouaceur, including a 60 km section of track expansion in a highly urbanized area with dense rail traffic.
  • Phase 3: 212 km from Nouaceur to Marrakech.

Ain Sebaa-Nouaceur section will feature a bypass around the Casablanca hub, with quadrupling of tracks to accommodate heavy urban rail traffic.

Kenitra-Marrakech High-Speed Line is a pivotal infrastructure project aimed at extending Morocco's high-speed rail network from Kenitra to Marrakech. This strategic extension of the existing LGV Nord line (connecting Tangier to Kenitra) is designed to enhance regional connectivity and improve transportation efficiency.

The scope of the project is divided into the following key sections:

Lot No. 3:

  • Extensive earthworks for track foundations.
  • Construction of standard engineering structures to ensure safe and efficient rail operations.
  • Building of 5 bridges to maintain continuity across varying terrains.

North Lot:

  • Design and construction of high-speed railway tracks.
  • Installation of catenaries for electric train operations.
  • Development of substations for power supply and network stability.

Lot No. 2: 

  • Execution of superstructure works to enhance track stability and safety.
  • Civil engineering on tracks currently in operation, minimizing disruption to existing services.

title: Genser Energy Hybrid Gas Power Plant, Liberia
body:
• Install a 270 MW hybrid natural gas and thermal power plant in phases in Buchanan, Grand Bassa County
  • The project’s first phase will be implemented within 18 months, producing approximately 120 MW
  • The second phase, which will incorporate a combined steam cycle for enhanced efficiency and greater power output, will bring total capacity to 270 MW within an additional 12 months
  • The facility will feature cryogenic fuel storage technology and advanced gas turbines, delivering low-emission, cost-effective and stable power generation
  • The plant will leverage Transco CLSG’s interconnection network and provide dedicated power for large industrial consumers such as mining companies, factories and commercial hubs
  • The facility is set to reduce Liberia’s dependence on seasonal hydropower and electricity imports, ensuring greater energy independence

title: Richards Bay LNG and Liquid Bulk Terminal, South Africa
body:
The development of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and Liquid Bulk Terminals at the Port of Richards Bay in South Africa is a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at bolstering the country's energy security and diversifying its fuel sources.

LNG Terminal:

The LNG terminal project is spearheaded by Zululand Energy Terminal, which has secured rights to the designated land for constructing the import facility. 

Technical scope includes:

  • Construction of new berths, including Berth 207, to accommodate LNG carriers. 
  • Installation of LNG storage tanks designed to safely handle and store liquefied natural gas.
  • Deployment of systems to convert LNG back into its gaseous state for distribution.
  • Establishment of connections to existing pipeline networks, facilitating efficient gas transport to regions such as Durban. 

Liquid Bulk Terminal:

The Liquid Bulk Terminal focuses on handling various liquid commodities, including green fuels, chemicals, and petroleum products. 

Technical scope includes:

  • Construction of dedicated berths and storage facilities tailored for liquid bulk goods.
  • Implementation of pipelines to enable seamless transfer between vessels and onshore storage.
  • Incorporation of systems to manage spills, emissions, and other environmental considerations.

title: Southern Ethiopia-Somalia Power Interconnector
body:
• Build a 780 km 400 kV electricity interconnection line running between Negele and Dolo Ado in southern Ethiopia to Somalia's capital city Mogadishu
  • The project includes work on substations at Negele, Dolo Ado and Mogadishu

 

The project's objectives include linking power generation facilities located in Ethiopia to the main load centres located in Somaliland as well as facilitating the integration of non-dispatchable renewable energy generation

The interconnection is expected to allow the Horn of Africa region to take advantage of Ethiopia’s and Kenya’s surplus of renewable energy and arbitrage against the high cost of thermal generation. Ethiopia’s export revenues are currently priced at US$0.07/kWh compared to US$1/kWh in Somalia
meta_description: Build a 780 km 400 kV electricity interconnection line running between Negele and Dolo Ado in southern Ethiopia to Somalia's capital city MogadishuThe project includes work on substations at Negele
migration_status: Dolo Ado and Mogadishu The project's objectives include linking power generation facilities located in Ethiopia to the main load centres located in Somaliland as well as facilitating the integration of non-dispatchable renewable energy generation

title: Northern Ethiopia-Somalia Power Interconnector
body:
• The scope includes building a 550 km 400 kV transmission line connecting Jigiga in Ethiopia to Hargeisa in Somalia and on to the Berbera port in Somalia
  • Work on the line covers building the 330 km Debre Zeit-Hurso, 140 km Jigjiga-Hargeisa and 80 km Hargeisa-Berbera connections 
  • The line begins at Bishoftu in Ethiopia’s Oromia region and runs through Hurso in the Oromia region, connecting to a substation in Jigjiga in the Somali Regional State and on to Tog Wajaale at the border between Ethiopia and Somaliland. From this point, the line traverses Hargeisa from Wajaale in Somaliland and terminates in Berbera, a port city in Somaliland
  • The line's route will follow a linear transmission corridor following existing road infrastructure where possible
  • The project includes building substations at Jigiga, Hargeisa and Berbera
  • Potential beneficiaries of the line are estimated at 3 million people 
  • The project is planned to contribute to improved electricity access in Somalia's northern regions
  • The project is expected to support the development of the Berbera port 

 

The interconnection is expected to allow the Horn of Africa region to take advantage of Ethiopia’s and Kenya’s surplus of renewable energy and arbitrage against the high cost of thermal generation. Ethiopia’s export revenues are currently priced at US$0.07/kWh compared to US$1/kWh in Somalia

title: King City, Ghana
body:
King City is a large-scale, mixed-use development project located in the Western Region of Ghana, specifically near Takoradi. The project is designed to accommodate the region's rapid urbanization, driven by the burgeoning mining and energy sectors.

Project Overview:

  • Approximately 10 km from Takoradi Harbour.
  • Encompasses 2,400 acres (approximately 9.7 square kilometers). 
  • The project is planned to be developed over a 10-year period, to accommodate about 90,000 residents upon completion. 

Key Components:

  • Approximately 24,000 dwelling units are planned to provide housing for about 90,000 residents. 
  • The development includes 1.5 million square meters of floor space dedicated to retail, office, industrial, and commercial activities. 
  • Over 30% of the land area is allocated for green spaces.

Infrastructure and Amenities:

  • The project includes comprehensive plans for roads, water supply, and other essential infrastructure to support the growing community.

title: Pearl Marina, Uganda
body:
The Pearl Marina Project is a large-scale mixed-use waterfront development spanning over 389 acres along the shores of Lake Victoria in Garuga, Entebbe, Uganda. Developed by Pearl Marina Estates, a subsidiary of Centum Real Estate, the project is being executed in multiple phases.

Completed Phases:

  • Mirabella Villas (Phase 1): This phase includes 22 high-end villas, each featuring four self-contained bedrooms, a maid's room, and modern amenities. 
  • La Perla Bungalows: Comprising three-bedroom bungalows with a maid's room, this phase offers residents access to landscaped gardens, swimming pools, a clubhouse, a sandy beach, and a lakeside boardwalk. Phase One of this development has been completed.

Ongoing and Planned Phases:

  • Riviera Residences: This phase includes the construction of modern townhouses. Current construction activities encompass roadworks, roofing, tiling, and installation of door frames and windows. 
  • Mirabella Residences (Phase 2): This phase involves the development of additional villas, each featuring four self-contained bedrooms, a maid's room, and modern amenities.

title: Bakassi Deep Seaport, Nigeria
body:
• Develop a port with a draft of 20 metres across a perimeter area of 36,000 hectares in Idua Inwang village, in the Esighi community of the Bakassi local government area
  • The port is aimed to become the eastern maritime gateway of Nigeria, enhancing the adjacent planned free trade zone and Bakassi Industrial City
  • The seaport is planned to have capacities for container-handling, storage and import-export facilities to facilitate the trade of petroleum products, vehicles, food, agricultural products and natural resources
  • The port is planned to provide a supply route base for the regional oil and gas sector as well as become a logistics base and regional trading hub for West Africa

title: Uganda-Tanzania Power Interconnection Line (UTIP)
body:
• Construct a 605 km 400 kV double-circuit transmission line to interconnect the Ugandan and Tanzanian national grids along with associated 4400 kV substations
  • Specifically, approximately 80 km of line and associated 400 kV substations will be built at Masaka and Mutukula in Uganda, and about 525 km of line and associated substations at Kyaka, Nyakanazi and Mabuki in Tanzania
  • The line will allow further trade with other countries in the Eastern (EAPP) and Southern African (SAPP) power pools 
  • UTIP will also support Uganda’s readiness to operate an interconnected system in compliance
    with the EAPP interconnection code

title: LMI Holdings 1GW Solar PV Farm Phase 1, Ghana
body:
• Develop a 200 MW PV plant for Solar for Industries, a subsidiary of LMI Holdings, at the 2,000-acre Dawa special industrial zone
  • The plant will have ground-mounted solar panels fitted on single-axis trackers 
  • The project will be executed over 3-5 years in three phases
  • The plant is expected to power over 100 industrial facilities and businesses and reduce carbon emissions by about 120,000 metric tonnes annually
  • Enclave Power Company Ltd (EPCL), a wholly owned subsidiary of LMI Holdings, will offtake the produced power within the estate and distribute it to tenants within the industrial parks
  • Power transmission from Dawa to the Tema industrial zone will be done through the existing Gridco grid lines (the state-owned grid) also used by other operators
  • The project is part of a 1 GW solar farm planned to be developed by 2032

title: Tepi-Bor Power Interconnector, Ethiopia and South Sudan
body:
• Construct a 500 kV transmission line from Ethiopia's Dedesa substation to Tepi, extending 704 km to the South Sudan border to Bor and on to Juba
  • Line's route will follow the western Ethiopian highlands through Tepi, crossing into South Sudan via the Boma National Park corridor
  • Line will have a transfer capacity of 1,000 MW
  • Three main substations are planned to be built
  • Potential beneficiaries estimated at 8.5 million people

 

Project is:

  • Aligned with COMESA Infrastructure Development Strategy
  • Key component of Eastern Africa Power Pool (EAPP) Master Plan 2024-35
  • Supports African Union (AU) Agenda 2063 infrastructure goals
  • Priority project under PIDA PAP 2 (2021-30)

title: PET Recycling Plants, Ghana and Nigeria
body:
• Establish polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plants in Ghana and Nigeria to produce 15,000 tonnes a year of recycled PET (rPET) resins that will substitute virgin PET resins used to make food-grade and beverage packaging containers
  • The plants will be built at the Poly Tanks Ghana and Sonnex Packaging Nigeria developments
  • 90 % of the raw materials will be sourced from local small businesses involved in plastic collection
  • Combined, the plants are expected to create more than 4,000 direct and indirect jobs across the value chain and approximately US$21 million in annual savings from imports for each country

 

The Polytanks rPET plant in Ghana is currently under construction within the Tema Free Zone Enclave in Accra on 3.7 hectares of land

The Sonnex rPET plant in Nigeria is in the final phase of construction within the Ikorodu Industrial Estate on 5 hectares of land. 

 

Austria's Starlinger is providing the extrusion and pelletising equipment 

Norway's Tomra is providing the sorting equipment 

(Source: Petnology)

The stadium's capacity will increase from 35,000 to 55,800 spectators. 

A new roof will be built over the auditorium.

 An additional building will also be constructed just in front of the western stand.

The reconstruction is to be carried out in two phases. 

  • Phase 1:  To be completed in 2025
  • Pase 2: To be completed in 2028

title: Cairo Metro Line 1 Upgrade, Egypt
body:
Line 1 stretches across 44 km, connecting 35 stations and transporting more than 1.5 million people per day. The project will enhance the line’s efficiency and increase capacity while improving levels of safety and performance.

Source: Orascom

Colas Rail will work with Orascom to modernise the electric power supply, catenary and electromechanical systems in stations and tunnels and on the rail track. Hitachi Rail, for its part, will modernise the signalling, control and telecommunications infrastructures.

This work will be an impressive technical feat, as it will be carried out during the day while maintaining commercial operations on the line.

Source: Colas Rail

title: Port Victoria Rehabilitation and Extension, Seychelles
body:
The project consists of the rehabilitation and expansion of the commercial port within Port Victoria. 

The works will include detailed design and construction of a new quay (310m) offset from the existing quay, demolition as necessary of the existing quay, extension of the port yard area and dredging.

(Source: European Investment Bank)

title: Cairo Metro Line 4 Phase 1, Egypt
body:
Line 4 project foresees the development of a 42-kilometers line and 35 stations, in two development phases.

The first phase is expected to deliver 19 kilometres, 16 stations, a depot, an Operations Control Centre.

The phase 2 of Cairo Metro Line 4 will come in a later stage, with additional 23.5 km, 19 stations, and 92 trains.

Source: Thales

Cairo Metro Line ‎‏4‏‎ is the base for linking ‎‏6‏‎ ‎October City and New Cairo with the Metro ‎network. It provides ‎transportation service for the high density population areas in El ‎Haram – Faysal – ‎El Omraniya – Giza - Nasr City – Al Azhar University ‎‎– New Cairo. It is expected to transport ‎‏2‏‎ million ‎passengers ‎daily. In addition to these, the transport service will integrate ‎with the Monorail of ‎‏6‏‎ ‎October City.‎

Cairo Metro Line ‎‏4‏‎ – Phase ‎‏1‏‎: It includes the civil works for the western part of Metro Line ‎‏4‏‎ – Phase ‎‏1‏‎ ‎‎(Hadayek El Ashgar – Amr ibn El Aas). It extends from El Mesaha to Hadayek El Ashgar with a length of 13.70. 

Source: The Arab Contractors

Cairo Metro Line 4 includes a 12 Metro Stations starting from Hadaek AL Ashgar on 6th October City till El Mesaha Station at Al Haram Street with total length 13.70 km.

Source: Hassan Allam Construction

The project comprises the construction of depot and workshop area for Phase 1 of Greater Cairo Metro Line 4, with a total length of 18.8 km. The line runs from Hadayek Al-Ashgar station to El-Malek El-Saleh station and consists of a total of 16 stations, where traction power is provided through the 3rd rail system (750 VDC). The depot has an approximate area of 317,515 m2 and is located 1.2 km east of Hadayek Al-Ashgar station with double access tracks. It is planned to have stabling and train inspection capacity for a fleet of 23 eight-car trains (Phase 1) and overhaul capacity for rolling stock (92 eight-car trains) of the whole line at the year 2050.

The project also includes the construction of 5 types of separate generator buildings in each station, High Voltage Station HVS (220 kV) with a total BUA of 8,650 m2, and Operation Control Center (OCC) with a total BUA of 9,500 m2.

The HVS encompasses transformers for converting high voltage (220 kV) to medium voltage (20 kV) and controlling the facilities of medium voltage transmission to the line.

The OCC building is located approximately 500 m south of El-Nasr Station, where it is inteded to accommodate Operation Control Center, SCADA facilities, and Power Control Point. Additionally, the space and facilities of the OCC building are to be designed for phases 1 and 2.

Source: Engineering Consultants Group (ECG)

title: TotalEnergies 120 MW Solar Plants, Uganda
body:
TotalEnergies is planning six 20 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) ground-mounted solar plants in:

  • Bukedea
  • Iganga
  • Kapeeka
  • Kumi
  • Paliisa
  • Tororo

Project Scope:

  • Installation of photovoltaic panels across designated sites in Iganga and Tororo districts.
  • Conversion of DC power to AC power for grid integration.
  • Facilities for voltage transformation and power distribution to the national grid.
  • Infrastructure to connect the solar plants to the existing grid network.

Implementation Structure:

  • Phase 1: Site preparation, including land clearing and installation of infrastructure.
  • Phase 2: Procurement and installation of photovoltaic panels, inverters, and electrical components.
  • Phase 3: Testing, commissioning, and integration into the national grid.
  • Phase 4: Operations and maintenance for a minimum of two years post-commissioning, with the possibility of extension up to 20 years.

title: Lake Victoria Marina, Kenya
body:
The Lake Victoria Marina Project is a major mixed-use development along the shores of Lake Victoria in Kisumu, Kenya, designed to transform the area into a prime commercial, residential, and tourism hub. The first phase of the project, valued at USD 309 million, involves the development of critical infrastructure, including:

  • A state-of-the-art marina capable of accommodating yachts and boats.
  • Residential complexes that include luxury villas, apartments, and townhouses, designed with sustainable materials and modern amenities.
  • Recreational facilities such as sports complexes, parks, and lakeside promenades, aimed at enhancing community well-being.
  • Educational institutions including schools and colleges, to serve the growing population of the area.
  • Healthcare facilities that will provide modern medical care for residents and visitors.
  • Retail and commercial spaces to create a vibrant business environment.


Additionally, the project is designed with sustainability in mind, incorporating green technologies, energy-efficient systems, and nature-based solutions to preserve the local environment.

title: Kigali Waste Treatment Plant, Rwanda
body: The project involves the construction of a centralized sewage sludge treatment facility in Kigali's Kicukiro district, specifically in the Kabuga area. Designed to process 500 cubic meters of fecal sludge daily, the plant will employ nature-based and energy-efficient treatment processes. The treated sludge is intended for use as fertilizer in agriculture.

title: Staoueli University Hospital, Algeria
body:
Also known as Staoueli CHU Hospital, is a low-rise building (12 floors) with a total built-up area of approximately 200,000 square meters. The structure includes multiple specialized hospital wings designed to provide a wide range of healthcare services.

Scope of Work and Capacities

  • 700 beds across various specialized units.
  • Multiple consultation rooms across different medical specialties.
  • Surgery rooms for various medical and surgical procedures.
  • Dedicated facilities for emergency medical care, including intensive care units (ICUs).
  • Specialized blocks for cardio-thoracic, oncology, dental, plastic surgery, pediatrics, and more.
  • 150 rooms for healthcare professionals and staff.

Technology of Key Components

  • The hospital will be equipped with advanced diagnostic and therapeutic medical technology, including MRI, CT scans, and medical imaging equipment.
  • The operating theaters will feature the latest surgical instruments and technologies.
  • The building is designed to incorporate green building technologies with sustainable energy-efficient systems.

title: African Medical Centre of Excellence, Nigeria
body:
The African Medical Centre of Excellence (AMCE) is a 500-bed secondary and tertiary healthcare institution, offering a wide range of services and specializations. The master plan conceived for a 170-bed specialist hospital at first phase, and at the final phase, a 500-bed hospital with multi-specialties and supplementary components such as a pharmaceuticals section, retails outlets and mall, academic and research centres, and hospitality and residential units.

The master plan for project site covering 51,200 m2, including all the necessary facilities, MEP services, and parking spaces.

Source: Dar Al Handasah

The facility is built in four phases. The first phase, a 170-bed specialist hospital, with plans to scale up to 500 beds by the third phase. Total floorspace 32,280m². 

Source: WSP

title: H2 Notos, Tunisia
body:
H2 Notos aims to produce green hydrogen using electrolysers powered by large onshore wind and solar projects and supplied with desalinated sea water. The project aims to produce 200,000 tons of green hydrogen annually during its initial phase, with the potential to scale up production to one million tons per year in South Tunisia. 

The project will have access to the European market through the “SoutH2 Corridor”, a hydrogen pipeline project connecting North Africa to Italy, Austria, and Germany, which is expected to be commissioned around 2030. 

Source: TotalEnergies

The project is developed by TE H2, a joint venture between TotalEnergies and EREN Groupe, together with Verbund. The project is also known as TE H2 Green Hydrogen Project in Tunisia.

title: Lagos Quality Bus Corridors Phase 1, Nigeria
body:
Phase 1 will see the development of three quality bus corridor (QBC) routes

  • QBC 1a (Yaba-Lawanson-Ijesha-Cele) 8.7km
  • QBC 1b (Ketu- Alapere- Akanimodo) 4.7km 
  • QBC 2 (Abule Egba-Iju Ishaga) 8.76km
  • QBC 3 (Iyana-Iba- Igando) 13km

The project includes the construction of laybys, bus stops, and signalised junctions, as well as the upgrade of 91 bus stops along the corridors.

QBC 1 will feature four new terminals at Cele, Lawanson, Ojuelegba and Alapere, in addition to upgrades at the existing BRT terminals in Ketu and Mile 12. 

QBC 2 will benefit from a new integrated terminal connected to the Iju rail station and the new Yamaha depot. 

QBC 3 will see new terminals at Iyana-Iba and an upgrade to the Ikotun terminal.

 

The project aim is to build the road infrastructure necessary for high-performance bus services on priority corridors connected to the public transport networks of light rail transit (LRT) and bus rapid transit (BRT).

title: Angola-DRC-Zambia Power Interconnection Line
body:
• Build, own, operate and transfer a high-voltage electricity interconnector linking Angola to the Copperbelt region in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Zambia
  • The line will integrate the Central Africa Power Pool (PEAC) with the Southern Africa Power Pool (SAPP)
  • The first phase will enable the export of 300 MW to Matadi in the DRC in the north and 1,200 MW to the east to Luau (Moxico) in Angola, and the Kalumbila and Kolwezi regions in Zambia

title: Hyport Gargoub, Egypt
body:
HYPORT green hydrogen production plant will be located within the industrial zone of the Port of Gargoub, which is the country’s newest commercial port and industrial zone that is situated on Egypt’s Mediterranean coast. The wind and solar renewable power generation infrastructure will be located 70 km southwest of Gargoub and it will be connected to the production facility via a dedicated high-voltage power line. HYPORT Gargoub is a three-phase project, with the first phase targeting an annual green ammonia production of approximately 320,000 tonnes.

Source: DEME

body:
Inga-Cabinda-Pointe Noire-Brazzaville-Kinshasa-Inga Interconnection Line (Boucle de l'Amitie Energetique)

Overall scope: Build a 1,037 km 220 kV and 400 kV transmission line running between Angola, the Republic of Congo and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)

The sections include the:

  • 557 km Inga-Moanda-Boma-Cabinda-Pointe Noire section line, including a 250 km 400 kV evacuation line from Soyo in Angola through Noqui-Matadi-Inga, which will evacuate the 750 MW Soyo thermal plant and electrify communities within 20 km of the line

title: Algiers-Agadez Railway and Agadez Dry Port, Niger and Algeria
body:
• Build a railway linking In Guezzam in southern Algeria on the border with Niger to Agadez in central Niger
  • Build a dry port at Agadez

 

Agadez, which is positioned along a route connecting Niger to the maritime ports of Benin, Togo, Ghana, and Nigeria is planned to become a logistics hub, facilitating the import and export of goods. 

The dry port is expected to coordinate logistics operations including storage, consolidation, containerisation, customs clearance and quality control, and streamlining shipments via Algerian port platforms.

Once operational, the dry port will reduce delivery times for imports and exports by serving as a storage and redistribution centre, promoting cross-border trade with neighbouring countries such as Algeria, Libya and Chad.

For its part, Algeria is working on the construction of a railway running from In Guezzam onwards to Algiers, its capital city.

 

(Sources: Niger Press Agency (ANP), Ecofin Agency, Echos du Niger and ANESRIF)

title: Jorf Lasfar Gas to Power Project, Morocco
body:
Sub-component 1 – LNG terminal

A maritime jetty

  • Located north of the port of Jorf Lasfar
  • Reception and unloading of LNG tankers
  • Estimated cost: USD 600 million
  • Estimated construction duration: 36 months

An onshore LNG regasification unit

  • Located north of the port of Jorf Lasfar
  • Total capacity of 5 billion Nm3
  • Estimated cost: USD 800 million
  • Estimated construction duration: 48 months

LNG storage tanks

  • Estimated cost: USD 400 million

Sub-component 2 - gas pipelines

  • 400 km high pressure transportation pipelines
  • Connect the LNG terminal to the Maghreb-Europe pipeline
  • Deliver natural gas to proposed CCGTs (as detailed in sub-components 3 and 4 below)
  • Estimated cost: USD 600 million
  • Estimated construction duration: 36 months

Sub-components 3 and 4 - new CCGTs

  • CCGT of Jorf Lasfar (1,200 MW)
  • CCGT of Dhar Doum (1,200 MW) located 120 km south of Tanger
  • Estimated cost: USD 2.2 billion
  • Estimated construction duration: 36 months

Ancillary Infrastructures

  • The construction of distribution lines for the evacuation of the produced electricity are not in the scope of the development of the Gas to Power Project.
  • ONEE will carry out the construction of distribution lines, but no further details or timeline have been disclosed by ONEE yet.
  • No other ancillary infrastructure or incentive has been disclosed by ONEE at this stage.

 

Source: White & Case

title: Yakaar-Teranga LNG, Senegal
body:
Yakaar-Teranga is one of the world’s largest gas discoveries in recent years and holds around 25 trillion cubic feet (Tcf) of advantaged gas in place, with negligible carbon dioxide content and minimal impurities, reducing the need for processing ahead of transportation/liquefaction.

The development concept is an offshore development producing approximately 550 million standard cubic feet of gas per day with domestic gas transported via pipeline to shore and export volumes liquified on a floating LNG vessel.

Source: Cosmos Energy Ltd

title: ENI Floating LNG, Congo
body:
The project is expected to reach an overall liquefied natural gas (LNG) production capacity of 3 million tons per year (approximately 4.5 billion cubic meters/year).

Congo LNG will exploit the huge gas resources of Marine XII, fulfilling the country’s power generation needs while also fuelling LNG exports, supplying new volumes of gas to international markets focusing on Europe.

The project, made though an accelerated development schedule and a zero-flaring approach, will see the installation of two floating natural gas liquefaction plants (FLNG) at the Nenè and Litchendjili fields – already in production – and at the fields yet to be developed.

The second FLNG plant will become operative in 2025 with a capacity of 2.4 MTPA.

Source: ENI

body:
1.2 million tonnes per annum Floating Liquefied Natural Gas FLNG facility would have a capacity to process 176 million standard cubic feet per day of natural gas and condensate with natural gas feedstock from Oil Mining Lease 104. The facility would be fully equipped with Turret and Mooring System, Gas pre-treatment modules, LNG production modules, living quarters, self-contained power generation and utilities as well as capacities for LNG storage and offloading.

Source: UTM Offshore

title: Ace Floating LNG, Nigeria
body:
Also known as Transoceanic Floating LNG.

The project, strategically located offshore Pennington and proximal to OML 289 (a block we operate on behalf of Cleanwaters), will have a capacity of 3 million tons per annum (MTPA). It is designed to supply 3 MTPA of LNG to the international market, 150,000 metric tons per year (MT/yr) of LPG to the domestic market, 25,000 barrels of oil per day (bopd) of condensates, and 75,000 MT/yr of propane. 

The feedstock for the project will be sourced from multiple fields located within a minimum of 4 blocks in the swamp and shallow water regions close to OML 109.

As part of the phased development plan, the project will deploy a floating power barge concept, starting with a Phase 1 Power capacity of 250 MW. This initiative is expected to support the development of over 1 GW of power, contributing significantly to the country's energy needs.

Source: Transoceanic Gas and Power

title: Rovuma LNG, Mozambique
body:
Liquefied natural gas from offshore Mozambique

The Rovuma LNG project involves the marketing of gas in the form of liquefied natural gas (LNG) by bringing into production a series of large fields discovered in the Rovuma Basin, offshore Mozambique. The first phase of the project concerns three fields in the Mamba complex and will be complemented by the construction of two onshore liquefaction trains, each of which will produce 7.6 million tonnes of LNG per year. 

 

The initiatives in support of local communities

In addition to producing LNG for international markets, Rovuma LNG will supply Mozambique with up to 17,000 tonnes of LPG per year, improving access to energy for local communities. 

 

Highlights

  • 15 mln ton/y expected LNG production
  • 17 kton/y expected LNG production
  • 2,400 bln m³ confirmed gas resources in place

Source: ENI

title: Ayago Hydropower Plant, Uganda
body:
Build the 840 MW Ayago run-of-river hydropower plant on the Victoria Nile River in Uganda's Murchison Falls National Park district

The work includes constructing:

  • A 24-metre-high concrete gravity dam
  • A 7.2km long tail race tunnel
  • 6 intakes on left bank of river feeding 6 6.6-metre circular-shaped pressure shafts
  • Underground powerhouse housing 6 units of 113.33 MW and 3 nos. of 13 (W) x 15 (H) m D-shaped

The project would utilise a head of 80 metres and a design discharge of 938 cubic metres per second for generation of 840 MW

title: Tah-7 Resilient Road Corridor, Guinea Bissau
body:
Rehabilitation and climate change resilience enhancement of the N2 highway between Safim and Mpack (115 km), corresponding to a section of the Dakar-Lagos Trans-African Highway corridor No.7 (TAH-7). 

The project includes widening the existing road to accommodate hard shoulders, as well as the rehabilitation of 2 major and 5 minor bridges. 

(Source: European Investment Bank)

title: Clean Coastal Towns, Angola
body:
The construction of sanitation infrastructure across nine coastal towns (Benguela, Baía Farta, Lobito, Soyo, N’Zeto, Ambritz, Porto Amboim, Moçâmedes and Tombwa). 

The project includes:

  • onsite sanitation (latrines and septic tanks)
  • sewers, pumping stations
  • faecal sludge transfer
  • wastewater treatment plants. 

The project will consist of the following three components: 

(i) development of sanitation infrastructure

(ii) capacity building and institutional strengthening

 (iii) project management.

title: Renewable Energy Support, Botswana
body:
The project is divided into 2 projects as follows:

  • Component  1: Operationalization  of  policy  and regulatory  framework  for  Integrated Resource Plan (IRP)  implementation. Key  activities will  include:

      - Review of  the  current sector policy,  legal and  regulatory framework;

      - Identify the role of each sector stakeholder and their mandate related to IRP;

       - Develop and propose any recommendations for improvement.

  • Component 2: Development of regulatory instruments and technical studies to support Independent  Power  Producer facilitation and roll out. This component seeks to develop the necessary regulatory tools, instruments and studies to support the facilitation of private investments into the sector, through Independent  Power  Producers.

(Source: African Development Bank Group)

title: Tunisia-Italy Electricity Interconnection (ELMED), Tunisia and Italy
body:
Transmission line:

  • Build a 220 km 500 kV monopolar power line running from the substation at Partanna (Sicily) to the substation at Mlaabi on the Tunisian peninsula of Capo Bon
  • From the landing point on the Sicilian coast, the underground cable will run for 18 km to the Partanna converter station. From the landing point on the Tunisian coast, the underground cable will run 6 km to the new converter station in Mlaabi. The undersea cable will cross the Strait of Sicily for about 200 km between the two landing sites
  • The line will have a capacity of 600 MW and a maximum depth of approximately 800 metres along the Strait of Sicily
  • Build a 113-120 km double-circuit 400 kV link starting at the new converter station at Mlaabi and connecting to Tunisia's bulk transmission system, ending at a new 400 kV substation at Mornaguia
     

Substations:

  • Build the Partanna converter station in Italy, which will have a capacity of 600 MW and will convert DC to AC
  • Build the Mlaabi (Menzel Temime) converter station in Tunisia, which will have a capacity of 600 MW

migration_status: success

title: Morocco-UK Power Project
body:
The Xlinks Morocco-UK Power Project will be a new electricity generation facility entirely powered by solar and wind energy combined with a battery storage facility. Located in Morocco’s renewable energy rich region of Guelmim Oued Noun, it will cover an approximate area of 1,500km2 and will be connected exclusively to Great Britain via 3,800km HVDC sub-sea cables.

This “first of a kind” project will generate 10.5GW of zero carbon electricity from the sun and wind to deliver 3.6GW of reliable energy for an average of 20+ hours a day. This is enough to provide low-cost, clean power to over 7 million British homes by 2030. Once complete, the project will be capable of supplying 8 percent of Great Britain’s electricity needs.

Alongside the consistent output from its solar panels and wind turbines, an onsite 20GWh/5GW battery facility provide sufficient storage to reliably deliver each and every day, a dedicated, near-constant source of flexible and predictable clean energy for Britain, designed to complement the renewable energy already generated across the UK.

Four cables, each 3,800km long form the twin 1.8GW HVDC subsea cable systems that will follow the shallow water route from the Moroccan site to a grid location in Great Britain, passing Spain, Portugal, and France.

Generation

The Morocco-UK Power Project will be powered by a wind and solar farm, approximately 1,500km2 in size, within Morocco’s Guelmim Oued Noun region. The wind farm will utilise the reliable Trade Winds in the region, which are driven by the temperature differential between the Atlantic Ocean and African continent. The windspeed at the generation site increases throughout the late afternoon and evening, ensuring power can be delivered to Britain during times of peak demand.

The solar photovoltaic (PV) farm will cover approximately 200km2 and track the sun from east to west throughout the day. This will not only maximise the output of the solar farm, but it will also increase the output early in the morning and late in the afternoon, providing the most consistent generation profile to Britain. Although the project will benefit from the most advanced solar panel designs, they will work in the same way as the ones installed on people’s houses, throughout the UK, and existing generation sites within Morocco. However, the increased solar resource means that the same PV panels generate approximately three times more power in Morocco than they would in the UK. Importantly, the solar panels will generate as much as five times more power from January to March than those in the UK, which will help to keep the lights on and homes warm in Britain throughout the coldest winter days.

Storage

The project will benefit from a 20GWh/5GW battery facility, which will provide confidence that the power generated can be stored and delivered to Britain at the times when it is most needed. This will primarily be provided by Lithium-ion batteries like those used in electric cars, home battery systems and utility scale storage projects throughout the world.

These batteries will also allow Xlinks to install more solar PV systems and wind generation, which will maximise the use of the subsea transmission system. Delivering an average of 20+ hours a day at full power reduces the cost of sending per unit of electricity delivered to Britain. It also provides National Grid with the confidence that the project will be powering Britain even at times of low wind and low solar output across Northern Europe.

HVDC System

To allow for electricity transfer, Xlinks is also installing a transmission system from the generation site in Morocco to Britain, most of it across the ocean. The power generated will be transmitted directly to Britain without connection to the Moroccan, Spanish, Portuguese, or French transmission networks. This provides confidence that no matter what is happening on any electricity networks, Britain will have exclusive access to reliable power from the Moroccan wind and solar resources.

The transmission system will use High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) cables to send the power from Morocco to Britain. HVDC technology is now well tried and tested as reliable and more cost competitive for a large volume of electron transfer across longer distances, than the High Voltage Alternating Current (HVAC) technology typically used for transmission systems within countries.

Converter stations will be used to change the HVAC power at the generation site in Morocco to HVDC, which is then sent through the subsea cable with very low losses before another converter station in Britain changes the HVDC power back to HVAC, ready to be injected into the British transmission network. While the Xlinks Morocco-UK Power Project subsea cable is significantly longer than existing interconnectors, the HVDC technology is the same proven technology used for connecting Britain and other European countries, or the technology proposed for the interconnector between Morocco and Portugal.

Xlinks

title: Desert to Power initiative
body:
Also known as Desert to Power G5 Sahel Facility. 

OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE

To create the world’s largest solar energy generation zone by harnessing the solar potential of the Sahel countries.

10 gigawatts (GW) of solar generation capacity via public, private, on-grid and off-grid projects by 2030.

5 PRIORITY AREAS OF INTERVENTION

  • Expanding grid-connected solar power generation capacity
  • Strengthening and expanding national and regional grids
  • Deploying decentralised energy solutions
  • Improving the financial and operational capacity of the power utilities
  • Strengthening the enabling environment for increased private-sector investments

title: Five Mini LNG Plants in Ajaokuta, Nigeria
body:
NNPC Prime LNG Plant

  • Overview: A small-scale LNG (SSLNG) project designed to process gas from upstream producers received via the Nigeria Gas Infrastructure Company (NGIC) pipeline system in Ajaokuta
  • Location: 33 hectares in Ajaokuta 
  • Capacity: Phase 1 – 25 million standard cubic feet a day (mmscfd)  
  • Expected Completion: H2 2025
  • Ownership: NNPC Prime LNG, a special-purpose vehicle (SPV) owned by NNPC Trading (90%), a wholly owned subsidiary of Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), and Silver Peaks (10%)

NGML/Gasnexus LNG Plant

  • Overview: An SSLNG project that will liquefy natural gas from the Oben-Ajaokuta pipeline, which will be transported via trucks fuelled by compressed natural gas (CNG) with cryogenic tanks and regasified for industrial and commercial customers in northern Nigeria
  • Capacity: Phase 1 – 7.5 mmscfd; further expansion to 20 mmscfd  
  • Expected Completion: H2 2026
  • Ownership:  NNPC Gas Marketing Limited (NGML) and Gasnexus, a subsidiary of the local Axxela Limited

Bua LNG Plant

  • Overview: The plant will liquefy natural gas from the Oben-Ajaokuta pipeline, which will be transported via CNG-fuelled trucks with cryogenic tanks and regasified at Bua Group's Sokoto cement facility
  • Capacity: 45 mmscfd 
  • Expected Completion: Q4 2025
  • Ownership: Bua Industries and NGML

Highland LNG Plant

  • Overview: An SSLNG facility designed to serve industrial and commercial customers not connected to Nigeria’s pipeline network. The plant will facilitate LNG to CNG conversion to promote gas-powered transportation under the Presidential CNG Initiative (Pi-CNG)
  • Capacity: Phase 1 – 10 mmscfd; further expansion to 35 mmscfd
  • Expected Completion: Q4 2026
  • Ownership: SPV backed by Nigerian energy sector investors

LNG Arete Plant 

  • Overview: A mini-LNG facility that will deliver turnkey gas solutions, equipment and infrastructure to the industrial, commercial, power generation and automobile sectors in northern Nigeria
  • Capacity: Phase 1 – 7 mmscfd
  • Ownership: LNG Arete

(Sources: NNPC, News Agency of Nigeria and Association of Local Distributors of Gas, Nigeria)
specifications: ["97 million standard cubic feet a day"]
meta_description: NNPC Prime LNG Plant
migration_status: success

title: Horn of Africa Isiolo Mandera Corridor: El Wak Rhamu Road Upgrade, Kenya
body:
The Project road, El Wak –Rhamu Road (142 km long), is part of the 740 km Isiolo-Wajir-Mandera  road  corridor located in the  North-Eastern region of  Kenya.

The project includes the following components:  

Road Civil Works:

The construction of a single carriageway road 7.0m wide with 2.0m shoulders on each side to bitumen standard. The Civil works will also include the construction of town loop roads, access roads as well as upgrading/rehabilitation of socio-economic infrastructures. The Civil works will be undertaken in two lots as follows:

  • Lot 1: El Wak to Gari (74 km)
  • Lot 2: Gari to Rhamu (68 km)  

Project Implementation, monitoring and evaluation

  • Construction supervision services for Lot 1 and Lot 2 of the Civil Works; 
  • Baseline survey and monitoring of environmental, climate change and socio-economic impacts;  
  • Awareness and sensitization campaigns on HIV/AIDS, Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs), Gender, Reproductive Health, and COVID-19; 
  • Project technical audit; 
  • Management of social risks associated with Civil Works and Community outreach activities; 
  • Consultancy services for Security liaison officer;
  • Feasibility, ESIA, RAP, and Detailed Engineering Design studies of two (2) road projects. 

Facilitation Of Regional Integration, Trade And Transport

  • a Trade and Transport Facilitation Study;
  • Strengthening of Rapid Response Unit at El Wak town.   

Enhancement of Road Safety

  •  Road Safety Audit and Road Safety Awareness and Sensitization Campaigns;
  • Enhancement of National Transport Safety Authority (NTSA) Motor Vehicle Inspection Centre at Garissa;
  • Supporting GoK’s Motorcycle “bodaboda” Safety Initiatives by training motorcycle trainers.   

Capacity Building And Institutional Strengthening: 

  • Skills development of Unemployed Youth in the Project area; 
  • Capacity Building of Project Implementation and supervisory staff; 
  • Enhancement of Road Traffic Data Management System;
  • Assessment of participation of domestic civil engineers in the implementation of transport projects.

title: Makelele Gas-To-Power Plant, DRC
body:
Build the 60MW Makelele biogas project in Lake Kivu in eastern DRC. 

The work involves developing a gas-to-electricity system connecting consumers in Goma and the North and South Kivu provinces via trading hubs.

Lake Kivu’s biogas potential is estimated at approximately 700 MW of electricity over a period of 50 years.

title: 1,800 MWh Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), Zimbabwe
body:
ZETDC is embarking on a project to install 1,800 MWh of battery energy storage systems (BESS) at four of its bulk supply points on an EPC basis. 

The scope involves the design, engineering, supply, packing and forwarding, transportation, unloading, installation and commissioning of grid-connected BESS within 10 months from the contract
commencement date.

The lots are as follows:


Connecting to Dema 330/132 kV substation (Lot 1)

  • Installation of 50 x 5 MVA power electronics inverter stations or equivalent capped at 200MW
  • Installation of a 600MWh BESS
  • Installation of two 132/33kV, 120MVA transformers and bay equipment
  • Substation ancillary services, protection equipment, metering equipment, power network control and telecommunication systems (including RTUs for remote monitoring and control from the National Control Centre)

 


Connecting to Warren 330/132 kV substation (Lot 2)

  • Installation of 50 x 5 MVA power electronics inverter stations or equivalent capped at 200 MW
  • Installation of a 600 MWh BESS
  • Installation of two 132/33 kV, 120 MVA transformers and bay equipment
  • Substation ancillary services, protection equipment, metering equipment, power network control and telecommunication systems (including RTUs for remote monitoring and control from the National Control Centre)

 

Connecting to Chertsey 330/132 kV substation (Lot 3)

  • Installation of 25 x 5 MVA power electronics inverter stations or equivalent capped at 100 MW
  • Installation of a 300 MWh BESS
  • Installation of a 132/33 kV, 120 MVA transformer and bay equipment
  • Substation ancillary services, protection equipment, metering equipment, power network control and telecommunication systems (including RTUs for remote monitoring and control from the National Control Centre)

 

Connecting to Tokwe 330/132 kV substation (Lot 4)

  • Installation of 25 x 5 MVA power electronics inverter stations or equivalent capped at 100 MW
  • Installation of a 300 MWh BESS
  • Installation of a 132/33 kV, 120 MVA transformer and bay equipment
  • Substation ancillary services, protection equipment, metering equipment, power network control and telecommunication systems (including RTUs for remote monitoring and control from the National Control Centre)

 

The tender document can be found here.

title: Maritime Corridor Development and Regional Trade Facilitation Project, Comoros
body:
The project will develop and upgrade the port infrastructure across the three Comorian islands: Grande Comore, Mohéli, and Anjouan.

It is divided into four components as follows:

Component  1:  Developing  and  improving  port  infrastructure  resilience:

  • Extension of the Port of Moroni including: (i) construction of  a  new  240m wharf to extend the existing wharf;  (ii)  construction  of  a  bypass  for  lorries;  (iii) construction  of  a  platform  and  fencing  for  the  container offloading area;  (iv)  works  control  and supervision;  (v)  training  courses  for  10  young  engineers,  50%  of  whom  are  women;  and  (vi) implementation of the ESMP and RAP
  • Extension of the Port of Boingoma, including (i)  the construction of a 136 m wharf to extend the current wharf to accommodate ferries and fishing boats in the protected area of the port and  (ii)  the construction of a  136  m wharf for commercial cargo vessels; (iii) works control and supervision; and (iv) implementation of the ESMP.

Component 2: Facilitating regional trade

Component 3: Women’s economic empowerment

Component 4: Institutional support, capacity building, and project management

title: Ogidigben Gas Revolution Industrial Park, Nigeria
body:
Build a 2,700-hectare gas-centric industrial park in phases in Ogidigben, located in Nigeria's Delta state

The park will host:

  • Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) processing plant
  • Oil refinery
  • Tank farm
  • Methanol plant
  • Deep-sea port
  • Light industrial areas
  • Power and water treatment plants
  • Fertiliser production facility 
  • Petrochemicals production facility
  • Aluminium smelters
  • Residential area
  • Commercial area
  • Helipad/heliport

(Source: Alpha Group UAE)

The first phase includes the preparation of a dedicated plot of about 150 hectares to support the establishment of power, water treatment and wastewater treatment plants, a lay-down area, a pioneer camp site and a construction jetty, which will evolve into a port.

(Source: CDR International)

title: Dedougou 18 MW Solar Plant, Burkina Faso
body:
The project involves the development, construction, operation, and maintenance of an 18 MWp solar farm at Souri near Dedougou, Burkina Faso.

The electricity output will be sold to Société Nationale d’Electricite du Burkina Faso (“SONABEL”), the state-owned utility under a 25-year Power Purchase Agreement. A Public Private Partnership agreement has also been signed with the Government of Burkina Faso for a tenor of 25 years.

(Source: World Bank Group)

title: Common User Infrastructure for Central Green Hydrogen Valley, Namibia
body:
Build common user infrastructure to facilitate shared infrastructure usage among the various projects under development in Namibia's Central Valley, namely the Erongo, Khomas and Otjozonjupa regions. 

The infrastructure is planned to include:

  • Green hydrogen and ammonia pipelines
  • Water transport and distribution pipelines
  • Transmission and distribution lines
  • Desalination plants
  • Access roads
  • Rail infrastructure
  • Port infrastructure
  • Storage infrastructure

The projects under development in the Central Valley include the HyIron Oshivela green iron scheme, which could require a dedicated railway siding for the iron ore inputs and export of the direct reduced iron (DRI) pellets.

Other schemes in progress are Cleanergy Solutions' green hydrogen and ammonia plant, the  Daures green hydrogen village, HDF Energy's hydrogen power plant, and Zhero/Envision's green ammonia gigawatt-scale project.

title: Guercif Nador Highway, Morocco
body:
Project Summary 

Guercif–Nador Highway project entails the construction of a new 105-kilometer, 2x2-lane highway designed to improve regional connectivity between the inland provinces and the Port of Nador West Med, linking it to Morocco’s national highway network. The new corridor will enhance logistics, trade, and mobility across Guercif, Driouch, and Nador provinces.

Scope of Work

The highway will be developed in three phases:

  • Section 1: Guercif to Saka — 36.5 km
  • Section 2: Saka to Driouch — 40.5 km
  • Section 3: Driouch to Nador — 27 km

Key infrastructure components include:

  • 15 bridges
  • 114 culverts
  • 53 upgrades, including:
    • A junction at Saka
    • A service area
    • An intersection with the RN2 national road

title: Road Network Rehabilitation Programme (PRRR) Phase IV, Comoros
body:
The Project consists of 3 components as follows:

Road Works:

  • rehabilitation of the Bahani-GTE-Itsikoudi section (20 KM) on the RN4;
  • rehabilitation of the Itsikoudt-Chezani section (20 KM) on the RN3;
  • control and supervision of the works;
  • awareness-raising among the populations of the project's area of ​​influence on environmental protection, road safety, the fight against STIs-AIDS, family planning, and gender-based violence (GBV);
  •  implementation of the ESMP;
  • compensation for people affected by the Project. 

Facilities - Related developments:

  • rehabilitation of the Reading and Cultural Activities Center of the town of MBENI and of Itsandzeni (for young people); 
  • construction of a center for the collection and sale of agricultural products from the village of BAHANI (the Habowo site);
  • supply and installation of equipment for women's associations involved in the activities of collecting and selling agricultural products in the village of BAHANI (Habowo site); 
  • support for the employability of young graduates from the ZIP by integrating sixteen (16) young engineers/senior technicians, 50% of whom are women, who have recently graduated from school, into the company awarded the road works contract and into the design office responsible for monitoring and supervising the said works;
  •  construction of a block of 3 kiosks of 16 m2 each, dedicated to the association of young people from the Lac Sale locality, involved in tourist activities (tourist guides, sales of local products/water/juice for travelers as well as the provision of solar equipment for lighting and preservation of products for sale). 

Institutional support and management of the Project 

  • It aims to ensure good monitoring of the execution of components A and B and includes: Monitoring-evaluation of the socio-economic impacts of the Project and technical audit

title: HDF Green Hydrogen Project, South Africa
body:
Also known as Renewstable Mpumalanga project. 

HDF Energy is strategically expanding into Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, to contribute to resolving the shortage of electricity-generation capacity. Mpumalanga, known for its rich coal reserves, produces approximately 80% of the country's coal. Notably, 11 out of Eskom's 13 coal-fired power stations are located in Mpumalanga, constituting 70% of Eskom's generation capacity. This unique combination of grid connectivity and high solar irradiance makes Mpumalanga an ideal region for intervention. In April 2022, Eskom initiated a request for proposal (RFP), launching a rigorous selection process for leasing 6184 hectares of land for 25 to 30 years. HDF Energy secured 1782 hectares to develop green hydrogen baseload power plants in Mpumalanga. These projects have the potential to become the largest green hydrogen power plants in the country, strategically located in six different locations within Tutuka and Majuba.

  • Type of project: 6 multi-MW hydrogen power plants
  • Status: under development
  • Solar PV: 1,500 MWp
  • Storage capacity: 3,500 MWh
  • Power generation: 1,9 TWh/year
  • Hydrogen production: 18,000 tons H2/year
  • Power supply: for 1.4 million inhabitants

HDF

title: Kingfisher Field Development, Uganda
body:
Located in the Southeast of Lake Albert, Kingfisher Development Area (KFDA) is one of Uganda’s key oil and gas projects. The name is derived from a fish-eating bird-Kingfisher- common there. It is in Buhuka “flat”, Kyangwaali in Kikuube district.   

UNOC, as the Government nominee, holds 15% participating interest in the project. Our partners are CNOOC Uganda Limited (operator) and TotalEnergies EP Uganda holding 28.33% and 56.67% respectively.   

KFDA covers the Kingfisher field located in Kikuube with plans for future tie-in of Mputa-Nzizi-Waraga fields in Kaiso-Tonya, Hoima District.

The project will produce 40,000 barrels of crude oil per day during peak production. KFDA key infrastructure comprises: 

  • Development of a Central Processing Facility (CPF) with a capacity of 40,000 barrels of oil per day.
  • Thirty-one (31) wells (11 injectors and 20 producers) to be drilled on four (4) well pads.
  • Nineteen (19) kilometres of flowlines to connect the fields to the CPF.
  • A forty-six (46) kilometer 12-inch feeder pipeline from the CPF in Buhuka to the export hub and Refinery in Kabaale, Hoima District.
  • A Lake Water Abstraction station.
  • Supporting infrastructure such as temporary and permanent camps, a materials yard, a jetty, and several access roads, among others.

The Front-End Engineering and Design (FEED) for the Project was completed in February 2018. The Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) was completed, and certificate issued by the National Environment Management Authority in February 2020. 

(Source: Uganda National Oil Company)

title: Mozambique South Africa Gas Pipeline
body:
Also known as African Renaissance Pipeline. The proposed 2,600 km gas pipeline, starting from the Rovuma Basin in northern Mozambique and extending to Springs in Gauteng, South Africa (2,175 kilometres in Mozambique and 425 kilometres in South Africa). The pipeline is designed to transport 18 billion cubic meters of gas annually, equivalent to 13.2 million tons of LNG.

Project Overview: 2,600-kilometre gas pipeline from Rovuma Basin in northern Mozambique to Springs, Gauteng, South Africa. 

Capacity: 18 billion cubic meters of gas annually (equivalent to 13.2 million tons of LNG.

Geographical Distribution:

  • 2,175 kilometres of the pipeline will be located in Mozambique. 
  • 425 kilometres will be located in South Africa.

title: Trans-Sahara Gas Pipeline
body:
The project is also known as Nigeria-Algeria Gas Pipeline. 

A 48 and 56-inch gas pipeline stretching:

  • 1,037 km in Nigeria to the Niger border. This segment is also known as Trans-Nigeria Gas Pipeline (TNGP)
  • 841 km in Niger to Algeria border
  • 2,303 km across Algeria
  • 220 km from Algeria to Spain

The pipeline will have an estimated annual capacity of 30 billion cubic litres of natural gas. 

The project will start in the Warri region in Nigeria and run north through Niger to Hassi R’Mel in Algeria. There it will connect with the existing Trans-Mediterranean, Maghreb-Europe, Medgaz and Galsi pipelines. 

The pipeline will be built through a partnership between the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) and Algeria’s Sonatrach, together holding 90% of the shares, and the Niger National Oil Company holding 10%. 

The pipeline will ensure closer co-operation and integration between neighbouring countries, and will ultimately allow for the diversification and marketing of Nigeria’s natural gas export route. 

Source: African Union Development Agency

title: Nigeria Morocco Gas Pipeline
body:
(Also known as the African Atlantic Gas Pipeline (AAGP))

  • The proposed 48-inch, 5,300 km gas pipeline will run from Nigeria to Dhakla (Morocco), with an additional 1,700 km section running from Dhakla to northern Morocco, with a total capacity of 30 billion cubic metres (bcm) a year, equivalent to approximately 2.9 billion standard cubic feet of gas a day
  • The pipeline will traverse multiple countries, including Benin, Togo, Ghana, Côte d'Ivoire, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Senegal, and Mauritania, before terminating in Morocco, with a spur connection to Spain. The proposed pipeline is an extension to the 678 km West African Gas Pipeline
  • The pipeline will supply energy to around 400 million people in 13 countries
  • The Moroccan government launched a call for tenders in April 2024 to develop the national natural gas infrastructure, which will connect the port of Nador to Kenitra and Mohammedia, extending to Dakhla, with the aim of linking up with the African Atlantic Gas Pipeline; the capex is estimated at US$6 billion
  • The African Atlantic Gas Pipeline project is a name resulting from the merging of the West African Gas Pipeline Extension Project (WAGPEP) and the Nigeria-Morocco Gas Pipeline (NMGP) project into a single estimated 7,000 km gas pipeline project. It will traverse up to 13 coastal countries, with spur lines connecting the three landlocked countries of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger. The NMGP was launched in 2016 by former Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari and Morocco’s King Mohammed VI
