title: Petroleum Hub Development, Ghana
body:
Build the Petroleum Hub across 20,000 acres in the Jomoro Municipality of the Western Nzema Traditional Council in Ghana's Western Region over a period of 15 years. 
Phase 1 will cover 6,590.8 acres  

Overall Scope of Main Works 
(to be built under build-own-operate deals)

  • Three refineries with a total of 900,000 barrels a day (bpd) minimum will be built, each of them will have a capacity of 300,000 bpd, but can be expanded to 500,000 bpd by 2030-35. One refinery will be built in each phase.
    The Petroleum Hub's minimum capacity is 900,000 bpd, which can be expanded to 1.5 million bpd.
    Crude will be sourced from Ghana or other regions. 
     
  • There will be five multi-purpose petrochemical plants with a 90,000-bpd capacity to produce fertilisers, lubricants and cosmetics. Three of these plants will be fed with gas and two with crude oil.
    The feedstock will come from byproducts of the refineries. One petrochemical plant will be built in phase 1, two in phase 2 and two more in phase 3.
     
  • The Petroleum Hub will have interconnected tank farms with 10 million cubic metres of storage capacity built across three phases – 3 million cubic metres in phase 1, additional 4 million cubic metres in phase 2 and 3 million cubic metres in the final phase.
     
  • The hub will have two or more jetties with multiple berths and at least four discharge/loading points. The hub should have the ability to handle vessels of all sizes. 
    One jetty and port infrastructure will be constructed in phase 1, another jetty with multiple berths will be built in phase 2 and yet another in phase 3 along with the development of social amenities. 
     

Overall Ancillary Works 
(to be executed through partnerships between government and private sector)

Transportation
• Road network
• Rail network
• Airfield

Utilities
• Water treatment facilities
• Power infrastructure (renewable and gas-powered power plants)
• Waste treatment facilities
• Solid logistics
• Commercial services
• Security
• Emergency response centre

Settlement
• Residential area
• Commercial area
• Recreational area

Other Services
• State-of-the-art laboratory for petroleum products
• Fabrication workshops
• Metering and calibration services
• Inspection services
• Equipment supply
• Logistics services

 

Key Infrastructure Under Phase 1

• Oil refinery – 300,000 bpd capacity
• Storage tanks – 1,000,000 cubic metre capacity
• Petrochemical plants (diammonium phosphate (DAP), urea and ammonia) – 1 million tonnes a year capacity each
• Jetty and port infrastructure

Ancillary Infrastructure Under Phase 1
• Utility facilities (heat, water, desalination, waste, power, etc)
• Solid logistics area
• Access roads and basic transportation infrastructure
• Residential, commercial and other facilities

Social Amenities Under Phase 1
• Educational facilities
• Health facilities
• Security and emergency installations

title: Takoradi Refinery, Ghana
body:
60,000 barrels per stream days (bpsd) (scalable to 120,000 bpsd) export refinery and related infrastructure in Takoradi. The refinery is expected to be a dual train refinery with each train producing 30,000 bpsd totaling 60,000 bpsd, with Jubilee crude being the primary feedstock to maximize the production of gasoline and diesel. Other products will include LPG, Kerosene, Industrial (Marine) Diesel and Fuel Oil. The refinery will also be able to process Bonny Light crude as an alternative fuel source. Takoradi Refinery Company

Takoradi Refinery is one of three refineries to be built in Ghana Petroleum Hub. 

Ghana Petroleum Hub also includes an oil terminal and two petrochemical projects.

title: Nyanza Titanium Dioxide Pigment Plant, South Africa
body:
Construct an 80,000 tonne per annum titanium dioxide (TiO2) pigment plant located within Zone 1F of the Richard’s Bay Industrial Development Zone (RBIDZ) in Alton, Richards
Bay. The plant will have an expected life of 60 years and will beneficiate ilmenite and titanium slags to produce TiO2 pigment. 

Ancillary process units included in the scope of the project: 

  • Scrubbing of digestion and calciner off-gas
  • Recovery of titanyl sulfate solution from digester solid residues and neutralisation of the digester solid residues
  • Re-concentration of strong waste acid for recycle to the main process
  • Neutralisation of remaining waste acid
  • Dewatering of gypsum
  • Preparation of the surface treatment and calciner additioning chemicals
  • Buffer storage facilities in the main TiO2 plant for copperas and ammonium aluminium sulfate and handling facilities for loading and dispatch of these

Other process units included in the scope of the project: 

  • A 2,000 tonne-a-day sulfur-burning sulfuric acid plant (also supplying steam to the main TiO2 plant)
  • A water demineralisation plant
  • A compressed air plant for plant air and instrument air
  • A vacuum generation plant
  • A lime slaking plant
  • Water cooling plant(s)
  • Steam boiler(s)

Supporting facilities:

  • A service road
  • A services area
  • A pump station to pump potable water to the Nyanza Technical Services Centre (TSC) from the storage tanks
  • An air-to-water plant located in the services area. Space will be set aside for future installation of additional gable structures for air-to-water generators 
  • A stormwater culvert spanned by a bridge along the site’s western side to give personnel access from the TSC
  • Parking

title: Abu Rawash Wastewater Treatment Plant Phase IV, Egypt
body:
The project is also know as Sustainable Development of Abu Rawash Wastewater Treatment Plant - Phase IV, and Abu Rawash Wastewater Treatment Plant Phase 4. 

Abu Rawash Water Treatment Plant is Egypt's second-largest wastewater treatment plant. The capacity of the treatment plant will be increased by 400,000 m³ per day (from 1.6 million to 2 million m³ per day).

This project is divided into three components as follows:

  • Wastewater treatment plant extension (€ 136.27 M)
  • An enabling environment for maximizing project performance (€ 0.36)
  • Project Management, Engineering Services, and Environmental and Social Safeguards (€ 4.41)

Source: African Development Bank

title: Kigali Urban Transport Improvement (KUTI), Rwanda
body:
The project includes:

  • Improvement/upgrading of selected junctions   such   as   Chez   Lando,   Gishushu,  Gisozi/Kinamba,  Nyabugogo,  Rwandex,  Sonatubes  and  Kibagabaga
  • Improvement  of public   transport services
  • Provision  of  non-motorized  transport (NMT) facilities in  urban areas
  • Multimodal transport system under urban transport plan. 

The key components and main activities of the KUTI project involve improvements of  7  key  Junctions in the  City  of  Kigali  (CoK)  comprising  the  following 

  • For Chez  Lando Junction- construction of a  740m   long underpass   (UP)   tunnel grade separation, signalization, and geometric Improvement for KN5 Rd.
  • For Gishushu Junction-construction of 500m long flyover (FO) bridge (including an approach section) for grade separation and geometric Improvement for KN5 Rd.
  • For Sonatubes  Junction-construction of  620m  long underpass   (UP)  tunnel as a grade separation, signalization and Geometric Improvement for KN3 Rd.
  • For Rwandex Junction-(i) construction of a new 4-lane bypass for throughway traffic of KN3 Rd, at northern Gikondo wetland and (ii) construction of two ramp bridges (Bridge-1=112m, Bridge-2=592m) separating the upper and lower lines in order to minimize the impact on the Gikondo wetland development area. 
  • For Kibagabaga Junction-widening KG11 Av into a 4-lane road and improvements shall also be made to the geometry of the right-turn lane from KG 11 Av to KG 19 Av.
  • For Gisozi Junction-(i) a plan to improve the traffic capacity on the main road of KN8 Av, (ii) construction of 540mlong flyover (FO) bridge. 
  • For Nyabugogo  Junction-(i)  Construction of a new 2-lane  flyover for throughway traffic of  NR1 Rd, (ii) Construction of a new 2-lane flyover for throughway traffic of KN7 Rd, (iii) Construction of 400m new road section which will constitute Nyabugogo Bypass, and junction  Improvements associated with the above works.

title: Karthala Geothermal Project, Comoros
body:
The project aims to explore the geothermal potential of the Karthala area, estimated at 45 MW, with the government looking to exploit the resource for baseload electricity generation. The project will be located across an area of 1,148 square kilometres on the country’s main Grande Comore Island (Ngazidja). It is divided into four components as follows:

  • Component 1: Execution of exploratory drilling
  • Component 2: Construction of related infrastructure
  • Component 3: Institutional support and project management
  • Component 4: Implementation of environmental and social measures

title: Central Africa Regional Waterways, Central African Republic and Congo
body:
The project comprises of five components:

The first component, waterways, ports, and road infrastructure improvement consist of following sub-components: 

(i) Congo-Ubangi waterways improvement investments

(ii) Congo-Ubangi ports infrastructure improvement investments

(iii) key road infrastructure investment and asset preservation in CAR

 (iv) digital connectivity along the road in CAR. 

The second component, support for waterway and road sectors governance and trade facilitation consists of following sub-components: 

(i) technical assistance (TA) on trade facilitation for enhanced efficiency;

(ii) TA to economic interest group for common waterways maintenance (GIE-SCEVN) for improved waterways maintenance capacity;

(iii) TA to International Commission of the Congo-Ubangi-Sangha Basin (CICOS) for improved water resources and waterways management;

(iv) TA for enhanced climate resilience, navigability, road and river transport safety, port and waterway security, and road and port asset management. 

The third component, socially-inclusive investments and capacity building for riparian communities consists of following sub-components: 

(i) community-level infrastructure works

(ii) capacity building for local traders. 

The fourth component, project management, implementation support, and institutional strengthening consists of following sub-components: 

(i) project management and operating costs

(ii) resettlement costs

(iii) institutional strengthening. 

The fifth component, contingent emergency response (CERC) can be activated in CAR and in ROC to provide support for an immediate response to an eligible crisis or emergency as needed.

(Source: World Bank)

title: Giseke Dam and Irrigation, Rwanda
body:
Scope: Construction and operation of a dam across the Giseke River in the Ndora sector of Gisagara district to create a reservoir and associated reticulation system for the supply and drainage of water for the development of irrigation-based agriculture along the river. 

The work will include building:

  • A dam with an estimated height of 28 metres and a crest length of 378 metres to serve a gross command area of 2,763 hectares 
  • Water catchment area for the reservoir is estimated to be 56.9 square km. The water reservoir volume is estimated at 6.6 million cubic metres, with 0.37 million cubic metres as dead storage
  • 58.4 km of conveyance canal and/or pipeline for delivery of irrigation water
  • Conveyance substructures including invested siphons to deliver canal water under natural channels and road crossings to carry canal water under roadways
  • Regulating structures for daily control of releases reservoir and regulating of the night storage reservoirs
  • Water level and flow measurement and adjustment structures
  • Protective structures including cross drainage, wasteways and spillways structures to protect
    the canals and reservoirs
  • Drainage network to collect storm water and excessive irrigation water from the command area
  • 85.2 km of access roads, culverts and bridges to aid in accessing the infrastructure and to facilitate transport. The roads will be 3.5 metres wide with a side inclination of 3% to evacuate the rainwater into adjacent drainage ditches

title: East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP), Tanzania and Uganda
body:
Pipeline:

  • Build a 1,443 km crude oil export pipeline that will transport crude oil from the Tilenga and Kingfisher oil fields in Uganda to the Chongoleani peninsula near the Tanga port in Tanzania 
  • The 24-inch insulated pipeline will be buried along its entire length, with the top of the pipe being 1 metre below the surface
  • The first 296 km of the pipeline will be located in Uganda and the remaining 1,147 km in Tanzania
  • The pipeline will have a peak capacity of 246,000 barrels a day 
  • The pipeline will have an electrical trace heating system and fibre-optic cable capacity, with high-voltage electrical cables and a fibre-optic cable to be laid and buried alongside the pipe

Above-Ground Facilities:

  • Construct six pumping stations – two in Uganda and four in Tanzania
  • Build two pressure reduction stations in Tanzania
  • Construct six mainline block valve stations (23 in Uganda)
  • Build 20 heating stations (five in Uganda)
  • Build a thermal insulation system (TIS) coating facility in Tanzania
  • Build a marine export storage terminal and load-out facility north of Tanga port over the Chongoleani peninsula. The terminal will consist of crude oil reception and storage, loading and metering facilities and a jetty extending into the Tanga bay to a water depth of 23 metres

Source: EACOP
meta_description: Pipeline:
migration_status: success

title: Tilenga Field Development, Uganda
body:
This project covers the Buliisa and Nwoya Districts in the North of Lake Albert and comprises 9 onshore oilfields:

  • 1 field in the Murchison Falls National Park (MFNP) – North of River Nile
  • 8 fields in the South of the Nile (outside the park)

The onshore drilling comprises 426 wells from 31 well pads, with 3 drilling rigs.

The project is projected to produce 190,000 bopd of oil at peak.

(Source: Petroleum Authority of Uganda)

title: Warri Refinery Rehabilitation, Nigeria
body: The Warri Refinery is the first Nigerian government wholly - owned refinery commissioned in 1978. It was built to process 100,000 barrels of crude oil per day but was later de - bottlenecked to process 125,000 barrels per day in 1987. It was essentially built to add value to some of the refinery by-products such as propylene rich stock and decant oil. This project is to refurbish the refinery to run at optimum. NNPC

title: ACWA Power Wind Farm in Gulf of Suez, Egypt
body:
• Design, construction, operation and maintenance of a greenfield 1.1 GW wind project along the Gulf of Suez, split in equal capacities across two phases and locations: west of Ras Ghareb and south of Ras Shukeir 
  • The wind farms will have a total of 138 220-metre tip height turbines. The capacity of each turbine will reach about 8 MW and a height of about 210 metres per turbine; the turbines will be supplied by China's Envision Group
  • Build an associated medium/high voltage step-up power substation
  • Construct cables connecting the turbines to the substation
  • Onsite building infrastructure including an administrative building (offices) and a warehouse for storage of equipment and machinery
  • Road access
  • Operate the plant under a 25-year take-or-pay  power purchase agreement (PPA)

title: Extension of Standard Gauge Railway (Naivasha-Malaba), Kenya
body:
Phase 2B (Naivasha-Kisumu):

  • Construction of 262 km standard-gauge railway (SGR) running from Naivasha through Narok, Bomet and Nyamira to Kisumu
  • Construction of 8 km branch line to Kisumu port on Lake Victoria
  • Construction of two multi-purpose berths and a work boat berth at Kisumu port

Phase 2C (Kisumu-Malaba):

Construct 107 km section of Kenya's Northern Corridor SGR running through the Kisumu, Kakamega, Vihiga, Siaya and Busia counties to Malaba on the border with Uganda. 

 

Kenya’s Northern Corridor SGR runs from the Port of Mombasa through Malaba, Nairobi, Naivasha and Kisumu to Malaba on the border with Uganda. The project has been divided into two phases. 

The completed phases are:

Phase 1 – It runs for 472 km between Mombasa and Nairobi and was completed by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) in 2017 at a cost of US$3.6 billion.

Phase 2A – It comprises the 120km Nairobi-Naivasha section, which was completed by China Communication Construction Company (CCCC) in 2019 at an estimated cost of US$1.5 billion.

title: Hydrogen Valley, South Africa
body:
Anglo American's Hydrogen Valley project in South Africa is a three large-scale integrated green hydrogen facilities and associated industries. 

AngloAmerican completed a feasibility study for the project in October 2021 in collaboration with South Africa's Department of Science and Innovation (DSI), South African National Development Institute (SANEDI), Bambili Energy, and ENGIE.  

The study identified three key locations:  

  • Durban, including the city and Richards Bay 
  • Johannesburg, extending to Rustenburg and Pretoria  
  • Limpopo Province, centered around the Mogalakwena PGM mine  

Nine pilot projects were proposed across these locations, encompassing industrial, transport, and construction applications.

title: Infinity-Conjuncta Green Hydrogen Project, Mauritania
body:
A consortium of Infinity Power Holding and Conjuncta GmbH join effort for the development of a green hydrogen facility in Mauritania capable of producing 8 million tons of green hydrogen annually, supported by a 10,000 MW electrolyser capacity.

The plant, which will be located near the Northeast of Nouakchott, can reach Electrolyser capacity of up to 10GW, making it capable of producing up to 8 million tons of Green Hydrogen or its equivalent in renewable fuels of non-biological origins. The green hydrogen, ammonia and/or other renewable fuels produced from the plant will be used for exports. The first phase of the plant of 400 MW is expected to be operational by 2028. The overall project will provide employment to approximately 3,000 workers during construction and to 1,000 workers when operational. Infinity Power Holding

  • Green Hydrogen 8 mpta
  • Electrolyser capacity 10,000 MW

title: Euthini-Chikwawa Corridor Road, Malawi
body:
• Upgrading to paved standard (asphalt concrete surfacing) the 67.86 km Euthini-Chikwawa Corridor road in northern Malawi
  • Upgrading to paved standard the 12.6 km route linking the corridor to the Malidade trading centre and a 1.2 km road connecting the corridor to the Mpherembe trading centre
  • Undertake periodic maintenance and improvements to 70 km of unpaved district and community access roads
  • The works on unpaved district and community access roads will include mainly reshaping to restore the road formation and side drainage. Culverts will be replaced where necessary and spot gravelling will be carried out on slopes and areas with weak soils. No new bridges or large culverts are envisaged on the unpaved link roads

title: Parliament Complex Reconstruction: Phase 2, South Africa
body: Ministry of Public Works & Infrastructure is set to reconstruct the Parliament Complex in South Africa. In the second phase, the primary rebuilding efforts will focus on the National Assembly and Old Assembly buildings, preserving their original spatial layout while rehabilitating, stabilizing, and reinstating structural systems to restore their former appearance. The interiors will be redesigned with a modern aesthetic. The Link Building, which sustained significant damage, will undergo restorative work to honor its heritage value. The new design will incorporate contemporary architectural techniques while respecting the building's historical significance and accommodating the needs of a diverse and democratic parliament.

title: Kisumu - Kakira Expressway: Section 4, Uganda
body: The East African Community is set to develop Section 4 of the Kisumu-Kakira Expressway in Uganda. This final section will cover 17 kilometers, connecting the Kakira-Malaba segment with the Kisian-Busia section in Kenya through the Busia One-Stop Border Post (OSBP). It is an integral part of the Mombasa-Nairobi-Kisumu-Busia-Kampala road network.

title: Parliament Complex Reconstruction: Phase 1, South Africa
body: The Ministry of Public Works & Infrastructure is set to undertake the reconstruction of the Parliament Complex in South Africa. The first phase will focus on clearing and removing the sections of the buildings that were damaged by fire. Special attention will be given to the Link building, which sustained severe damage and will undergo restorative measures due to its heritage significance. Initial efforts included limited debris clearance and stabilization in safe areas, as well as the installation of temporary roofs to shield the buildings from the elements. Additionally, assets were recovered and stored offsite for preservation.

title: N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR): Package 3, South Africa
body: The South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL) is set to undertake the construction of the N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR): Package 3 in the Eastern Cape of South Africa. This segment, extending from Bambisana to Lingeni, is a major infrastructure project designed to improve transportation and connectivity between these two towns. The Bambisana to Lingeni road project is anticipated to boost economic opportunities, provide better access to essential services, and enhance the overall quality of life for residents in the region.

title: N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR) : Package 2, South Africa
body: The South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL) is preparing to construct the N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR): Package 2 in the Eastern Cape of South Africa. This section will span from Ntafufu to Bambisana, running largely parallel to the existing R61, which will be retained as a local access road. Due to the challenging mountainous terrain, the new N2 road will feature an 80-100 km/h 4-lane design with a median barrier along its entire length.The Ntafufu to Bambisana road project is a key infrastructure development aimed at enhancing transportation and connectivity between these two regions.

title: N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR): Package 1, South Africa
body: The South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL) is set to develop the N2 Wild Coast Road (N2WCR): Package 1 in South Africa. This section, stretching 16.5 km from Ndwalane to the Ntafufu River, will feature a new 2-lane single carriageway highway. The road will include climbing lanes where necessary and will be designed for a minimum speed of 100 to 120 km/h. It will have a total width of approximately 12.4 meters, comprising two 3.7-meter lanes and two 2.5-meter paved shoulders, within an 80-meter road reserve.The Ndwalane to Ntafufu River road project is a significant local infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing transportation between Ndwalane and the Ntafufu River area.

title: Porcelain Tile Manufacturing Plant, Nigeria
body: Veenocks Limited plans to establish a porcelain tile manufacturing plant in Sagamu, Ogun State, Nigeria, with an annual production capacity of 6.6 million square meters for floor and wall tiles. During the pre-investment phase, a project preparation facility will be used to mitigate risks and accelerate the project’s development toward bankability. This early intervention aims to demonstrate Afreximbank’s strong commitment to the initiative. The project will leverage Nigeria’s underutilized natural resources by using clay to produce porcelain tiles for both domestic and international markets.

title: SunCentral Solar Firm Phase 1, South Africa
body: SolarAfrica Energy is set to launch its inaugural utility-scale SunCentral Solar Firm Phase 1 in the Northern Cape, South Africa. With a planned capacity of approximately 342 MW, SunCentral will revolutionize energy access by offering a one-to-many power model. This means that a broader range of South African businesses can benefit from more affordable and cleaner energy through wheeling. No longer limited to large-scale power users, this initiative promises to significantly boost economic growth in the commercial and industrial sectors. The electricity produced at SunCentral is entirely green and priced up to 50% lower than conventional utility power, allowing South African businesses to mitigate the impact of frequent electricity tariff increases while advancing their sustainability objectives.

title: Calabar - Obudu Railway Project, Nigeria
body: The Cross River State Government is preparing to advance the Calabar - Obudu railway project in Nigeria. This ambitious initiative involves constructing a 365-kilometer railway line that will link the southern and northern regions of the state. The new railway will enhance intra-state travel and function as a critical corridor for transporting goods and services across international borders. Cross River State borders Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon, and Sao Tome and Principe, and houses Nigeria’s largest export processing zone, the Calabar Free Trade Zone (CFTZ). The railway will feature main terminals in Calabar and Obudu, with additional sub-stations in Ugep, Ikom, and Ogoja, facilitating efficient movement throughout the region.

  • Training facilities with changing rooms

title: Abusera International Airport: Phase 2, Ethiopia
body: Ethiopian Airlines is advancing Phase 2 of the Abusera International Airport in Ethiopia. In the second phase, the airport terminal will be expanded to 1.1 million square meters to accommodate 110 million passengers annually, and two additional runways will be constructed. The new airport will be linked to Addis Ababa city via an express rail connection. A total of 35 square kilometers of land has been designated for the project. The Mega Airport City will feature the 1.1 million square meter terminal, passenger facilities, 126,190 square meters of airline support facilities, and over 100,000 square meters of cargo and airport support facilities, along with the necessary airfield and other critical infrastructure.

title: Jwaneng Solar PV Project, Botswana
body: Botswana Power Corporation (BPC) is set to develop the Jwaneng Solar PV Project in the southern town of Jwaneng, Botswana. This project will deliver 100 MW of solar photovoltaic power. It includes the construction of a 132 kV substation and associated transmission infrastructure to connect the plant to the national grid. The Jwaneng Solar PV Project is a ground-mounted solar installation and is one of two utility-scale, grid-connected PV projects being undertaken by independent power producers (IPPs) as part of Botswana’s updated Integrated Resource Plan, which aims to develop a total of 1,076 MW of clean energy projects.

title: Kinshasa Ring Roads Project, DRC
body: The Ministry of Infrastructure, Public Works & Reconstruction is set to develop the Kinshasa Ring Road in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). This 63-kilometer project aims to alleviate congestion in Kinshasa by linking its southeastern and southwestern regions. The four-lane, two-way route will begin at the Mbudi terminus, passing through Lutendele and Ngombi. It will intersect National Road 1 (RN1) at Mitendi and continue through Kimwenza and Lukaya Falls, reaching the N’djili brasserie before ending at the junction of N’djoku Avenue and Lumumba Boulevard. This ring road is part of a broader initiative to construct a peripheral road encircling Kinshasa to improve traffic flow towards N'djili International Airport.Client: Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Works.

title: Gabon Infrastructure Sector Support Project (PASIG): Phase 1, Gabon
body: The Ministry of Public Works is planning to develop the Ndende-Doussala Road Project in Gabon. This project involves constructing a 49-kilometer road section that will connect Ndende in the south to Doussala at the border with the Republic of Congo. The scope of work includes asphalting the road and the border bridge over the Ngongo River, along with a 2-kilometer connecting road. Additionally, the project will rehabilitate 15 kilometers of rural tracks and build two bus stations in Ndende and Owendo, a weighing station in Doussala, and a parking and rest area. The Ndende-Doussala road is part of the first phase of the Gabon Infrastructure Sector Support Project (PASIG).

title: Magwero Industrial Park, Malawi
body: ARISE Integrated Industrial Platforms (ARISE) will develop the Magwero Industrial Park in Malawi. The park will be established in phases across 417 hectares and will feature an industrial zone, logistics warehouses, residential areas, an internal container depot terminal, utilities infrastructure, and ready-to-use hangars for small and medium-sized enterprises. Designed to support sectors such as agriculture and manufacturing, the park aims to facilitate the processing of local raw materials into high-value finished products. It will include production units for glass, construction materials, LED lighting accessories, plywood, and paper.

title: Trans - Gabon Railway Modernization: Phase 2, Gabon
body:
The Government of Gabon, in collaboration with Société d’exploitation du Transgabonais (SETRAG), is advancing the Trans-Gabon Railway Modernization: Phase 2 project. This initiative aims to upgrade the 648-kilometer railway that connects Libreville, the capital on the Atlantic coast, with Franceville in the southeast of Gabon.

The modernization efforts will focus on the segments between Ndjolé and Alamba and between Mvengué and Franceville. Key improvements include the installation of new 60 kg/m rails to replace the old 50 kg/m rails and the substitution of wooden sleepers with durable two-block concrete sleepers. This upgrade is designed to enhance the railway's capacity and performance, supporting better connectivity across the country.

title: Moroni and Boingoma Port Development , Comoros
body:
The Government of Comoros is set to enhance the Moroni and Boingoma Ports with a major development project aimed at boosting both domestic and international connectivity. This initiative focuses on upgrading port infrastructure, fostering regional integration, and creating a supportive environment for developing value chains.

The expansion will involve constructing a new 240-meter quay at the Port of Moroni and a 136-meter quay at the Port of Boingoma. These upgrades are designed to accommodate ferries and fishing boats, thereby enhancing the Comoros’ agricultural and fisheries sectors. The project will also include the establishment of 10 fisheries product storage facilities, equipped with solar-powered cold rooms and refrigerated island transport solutions, to increase the ports' capacity and efficiency and address current and future demands.

title: Magufuli City, Tanzania
body:
The Tanzanian Government has unveiled plans for Magufuli City, an ambitious new development in the Ihumwa ward, spanning over 617 hectares. Named in honor of former President Magufuli, this administrative city is designed to be a beacon of Tanzania’s advancement and modernization. The city will be divided into several zones, featuring diplomatic offices, ministry buildings, national housing, and various social services.

Magufuli City is not just a construction project; it is a strategic initiative to enhance government efficiency and service delivery. It will boast state-of-the-art infrastructure, including green parks, schools, hospitals, and a dynamic business district, positioning itself as a model for sustainable urban living in Africa.

title: Ponta Techobanine Project, Mozambique
body:
The Governments of Mozambique, Botswana, and Zimbabwe are collaborating on the Ponta Techobanine project in Mozambique. This ambitious initiative aims to develop a deep-sea port at Ponta Techobanine and construct a new 1,700 km heavy-haul railway that will connect the three countries.

The project involves building a railway that runs from the Techobanine port through Bulawayo and extends across the border to Francistown in eastern Botswana. The Ponta Techobanine port complex is designed to handle up to 200 million tonnes of cargo annually, including general and bulk cargo, as well as passenger traffic.

The Ponta Techobanine project is expected to significantly reduce import and export costs for Mozambique, Botswana, and Zimbabwe, and benefit the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region as a whole. Additionally, it aims to stimulate the development of the region's mining, investment, and manufacturing sectors.

Project Overview

This multi-country infrastructure initiative aims to develop a new 1,100 km rail corridor linking Botswana's Selebi-Phikwe coal-rich region to a new deep-water port at Techobanine in Mozambique, traversing Zimbabwe. The objective is to establish an efficient, export-oriented logistics route for coal and other minerals, thereby enhancing regional trade and economic integration.

  • Project Title: Trans-Kalahari Rail and Techobanine Port Development Project, also known as Botswana–Zimbabwe–Mozambique Rail and Port Development Corridor, and Southern Africa Trans-Portlink Mozambique Zimbabwe Botswana Project.  
  • Length: Approximately 1,100 km
  • Countries Involved: Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique

Scope of Work

Railway Construction and Rehabilitation

  • Botswana Section:
    • Construction of a new rail line from Selebi-Phikwe to the Zimbabwean border near Bulawayo.
  • Zimbabwe Section:
    • Rehabilitation and upgrade of the existing rail segment from Bulawayo to Chicualacuala (at the Mozambique border).
  • Mozambique Section:
    • Construction of a new rail line from Chicualacuala to Techobanine on the Indian Ocean coast.

Port Infrastructure

  • Techobanine Deep-Water Port (Mozambique):
    • Development of a new seaport capable of handling bulk mineral exports.
    • Port infrastructure to include: berths for large cargo vessels, coal handling terminals, storage yards, and multimodal logistics integration facilities.

title: Bukavu - Goma Road Rehabilitation Phase 1: Lot 1, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)
body:
The Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Works will be undertaking the Bukavu – Goma Road Rehabilitation project in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Phase 1, Lot 1 of this project focuses on rehabilitating the Bukavu-Nyamukubi section includes the improvement of 24.3 kilometers of roads within the city of Bukavu and the construction of 17.7 kilometers of ramps.

The project's main goal is to enhance connectivity between the North and South Kivu Provinces and reduce poverty in the region. Specifically, it aims to upgrade the Bukavu-Goma highway transport network and improve living conditions for communities affected by the project.

title: Morupule Power Plant, Botswana
body:
Atlantic Energy Partners, in collaboration with Energy & Natural Resource Corporation, is developing the Morupule Coal Fired Power Plant in Central Botswana. This power plant is designed to generate 1,200 MW of electricity and will utilize a steam turbine configuration for baseload power generation.

The plant is equipped to operate on dual fuel, with bituminous coal as the primary fuel source. In the event of a shortage of bituminous coal, the plant can switch to diesel fuel oil. The coal required for the power plant will be sourced from the Morupule Coal Mine.

title: Luuq - Dollow - Beled Hawo Road Upgrade, Somalia
body: The Ministry of Public Works, Reconstruction and Housing (MPWRH) will upgrade the Luuq – Dollow – Beled Hawo Road in Somalia. This project involves transforming the 85-kilometer road from gravel to bitumen standard. The main goals of upgrading the Luuq – Dollow – Beled Hawo Road are to reduce travel time, stimulate economic growth, enhance interconnectivity, facilitate trade, and improve the road transport network between Somalia and Kenya. The studies aim to complete the necessary technical, economic, financial, environmental, and social preparations to ready the project for investment financing.

title: El Wak Rhamu Road Upgrading: Phase 2, Kenya
body:
The Kenya National Highway Authority will undertake the El Wak Rhamu Road Upgrading Phase 2 Project in Kenya. This project focuses on upgrading Lot 2: the 68 km section of the El Wak – Rhamu Road, which is part of the 740 km Isiolo-Wajir-Mandera corridor in the North-Eastern region of Kenya. This corridor is one of the four priority routes identified under the Horn of Africa Initiative, involving Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan, Djibouti, and Eritrea.

The project includes the construction of town loop roads, flood mitigation measures, a virtual axle load weighing station, and access roads. It aims to improve transportation, boost trade, reduce poverty, and enhance regional integration. Additionally, the development will strengthen security management in the area and contribute to a reduction in regional fragility.

title: Boke - Quebo Road Improvement Project Phase 1: Lot 2, Guinea
body: The Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Works will develop Phase 1, Lot 2 of the Boke - Quebo Road Improvement Project in Guinea. This phase involves constructing the road section from Dabiss in Guinea to the border with Guinea-Bissau, as well as building a 240-meter bridge over the Kogon River. The project aims to: (i) enhance service levels on the Boké-Québo road; (ii) alleviate obstacles to the movement of goods and people related to customs controls; and (iii) improve accessibility and living conditions for residents in the Project Direct Area of Influence (PDAI).

body: Bonang Power and Energy is set to develop the Murchison Falls – Bonang Hydro Power Project in Uganda. This significant venture is designed to harness the hydroelectric potential of the Nile River, with a planned capacity of 360 megawatts (MW). By leveraging the Nile’s flow, the project aims to offer a stable and renewable energy source, thereby enhancing the country's energy security and fostering economic growth.

title: Tabora - Kigoma Railway Line (SGR): Lot 6, Tanzania
body:
The Government of Tanzania and the Tanzania Railway Corporation are expanding the Standard Gauge Railway Tabora-Kigoma Line (SGR), specifically Lot 6. This project involves constructing a new electrified standard gauge track from Tabora to Kigoma, designed for mixed traffic use. The expansion covers 506 kilometers of railway line, including 411 kilometers of mainline and 95 kilometers of branch lines.

The project will include the construction of 10 passenger stations and two freight stations in Uvinza and Katosho. This new railway line in western Tanzania will connect to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Rwanda, and Uganda, forming a 2,561-kilometer rail corridor. It will also provide access to maritime transport through the Port of Dar es Salaam and the port city of Mwanza on Lake Victoria.

title: Tabora - Isaka Railway Line (SGR): Lot 4, Tanzania
body:
The Government of Tanzania and the Tanzania Railway Corporation are expanding the Standard Gauge Railway Tabora-Isaka Line (SGR), specifically Lot 4. This section, which spans 130 kilometers, is part of the Dar es Salaam-Mwanza rail corridor. The line will connect Tabora and Isaka, serving as a vital component of the country's infrastructure development.

The expansion includes a 130 km single track designed for mixed traffic, featuring 16 bridges, 8 overpasses, 8 underpasses, and 30 wildlife crossings. Additionally, the project will establish 3 stations, a workshop, a shunting yard, and the Institute of Railway Technology in Tabora. This development aims to enhance connectivity, improve transportation efficiency, and significantly boost regional trade and economic growth.

title: Lufubu 2 Hydro Power Project, Zambia
body: LPC Lufubu Power is developing the Lufubu 2 Hydro Power Project on the Lufubu River in Northern Zambia. This 88 MW hydro power project will feature a reservoir with a planned capacity of 86 million cubic meters. The project will have a gross head of 83 meters and a penstock length of 670 meters with a diameter of 4.2 meters.The Lufubu 2 Hydro Power Project will be implemented in two phases:Unit-I: This phase includes one Francis turbine with a nameplate capacity of 44 MW. The installed electric generator for Unit-I will have a nameplate capacity of 50 MVA. Unit-II (Expansion): This expansion phase also includes one Francis turbine with a nameplate capacity of 44 MW. The installed electric generator for Unit-II will similarly have a nameplate capacity of 50 MVA.

title: Lufubu 3 Hydro Power Project, Zambia
body: LPC Lufubu Power will develop the Lufubu 3 Hydro Power Project on the Lufubu River in Northern Zambia. This 106 MW hydroelectric project will feature a reservoir with a capacity of 400 million cubic meters, a gross head of 92 meters, and a penstock measuring 2,100 meters in length and 4.5 meters in diameter.The project will be the final facility in the Lufubu cascade. It will use a 40-meter high bituminous face rockfill dam to create the reservoir, which will have a total storage capacity of 400 million cubic meters. The dam will include a concrete spillway with radial gates, designed to handle a discharge of up to 5,170 cubic meters per second during a probable maximum flood (PMF).

title: Ngonye Falls Hydropower Project,  Zambia
body:
Eleqtra and Western Power are set to develop the Ngonye Falls Hydro Power Project on the Zambezi River in Western Zambia. This 180 MW run-of-river hydroelectric project will feature a gross head of 22.5 meters and is expected to generate an average of 830 GWh of electricity annually. This output will supply over 200,000 households and increase Zambia’s total generation capacity by approximately 8%. The project aims to enhance and stabilize the power network by reducing transmission flows and losses from the south to the west of the country and will support Zambia’s policy of exporting electricity to neighboring nations.

The facility will connect to the national grid via a 110 km, 330 kV transmission line (initially energized at 220 kV) to the Sesheke substation, which serves as a key interconnector to Namibia and the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP) network.

Key components of the project include:

  • A 3.5 km-long weir and barrage
  • A 2.9 km-long concrete-lined power canal
  • A powerhouse located 6.5 km downstream from Ngonye Falls
  • A 600 m-long forebay lake immediately upstream of the powerhouse
  • An outdoor switchyard situated southwest of the powerhouse
  • A 4.5 km 220 kV interconnection to a planned 220 kV line by the national utility ZESCO
  • Additional infrastructure such as access roads, bridges, operation-stage accommodation and facilities, and a visitor center.

title: Nyagisozi - Remera - Nshili Border Road Upgrade, Rwanda
body:
The Rwanda Transport Development Agency (RTDA) is set to upgrade the Nyagisozi - Remera - Nshili Border Road, spanning approximately 18 km. This project includes two main sections: Nyagisozi to Giswi Junction (10.74 km) and Gatunda to Remera to the Bitare/Nshili Border (7.26 km), along with related social infrastructure improvements.

The Nyagisozi - Remera - Nshili Border Road Upgrade is a key infrastructure initiative aimed at improving connectivity and facilitating cross-border trade and travel. The objective is to enhance the road infrastructure linking Nyagisozi, Remera, and Nshili, including the border area. This upgrade will improve transportation efficiency, support regional integration, and accommodate increased traffic by potentially involving paving, widening, and general enhancement of road conditions.

title: Rundu Water Treatment Plant Extension, Namibia
body:
The Ministry of Agriculture, Water, and Land Reform is undertaking the Rundu Water Treatment Plant Extension Project in Namibia, which includes several major developments:

  1. New Raw Water Abstraction Works: An intake system on the Kavango River will be established with an initial pumping capacity of 40,000 cubic meters per day, expandable to 80,000 cubic meters daily.

  2. New Water Purification Plant: A new plant will be constructed with a capacity of 36,000 cubic meters per day, expandable to 72,000 cubic meters per day.

  3. Additional Storage Reservoirs: New reservoirs will be added, providing a total storage volume of 35,500 cubic meters.

  4. New Pump Stations and Pipelines: New pump stations will be built, along with dedicated 50km pipelines connecting existing and new elevated reservoirs in Rundu and N’karapamwe.

  5. Expanded Service Area: The upgraded infrastructure will enhance water supply not only in Rundu but also to surrounding communities within a 100-kilometre radius. Extension pipelines will be constructed from N’karapamwe to Kayengona and Masivi, and from Rundu to Mupini and Sikondo, enabling these communities to benefit from the new water system.

body: The Ministry of Public Works will undertake the rehabilitation of the Mora-Tchakamari Road in Cameroon. This 22-kilometer segment marks the first phase of upgrading this essential route. The area is a significant trade hub connecting Chad and Nigeria. This project is part of the broader climate-resilient rehabilitation of the 205 km Mora-Dabanga-Kousseri (MDK) route, a crucial section of National Road 1 (RN1) linking northern Cameroon to the south.

title: Tchakamari - Kousseri Road Rehabilitation: Lot 4, Cameroon
body: The Ministry of Public Works will oversee the Tchakamari-Kousseri Road Rehabilitation Project: Lot 4 in Cameroon. This phase involves rehabilitating a 37-kilometer stretch of road from Tilde (PK166) to Kousseri - Customs (PK203) and constructing a 7.5 km bypass around Kousseri. The project aims to improve access to crucial infrastructure in the Far North region, which is the second most populous and one of the poorest regions in Cameroon. This area also functions as a vital trade hub connecting with Chad and Nigeria. The work is part of the larger climate-resilient rehabilitation effort for the 205 km Mora-Dabanga-Kousseri (MDK) route, a key segment of National Road 1 (RN1) that links northern Cameroon to the south.

title: Ruzizi IV Hydropower Plant
body: Électricité des Grands Lacs will develop the Ruzizi IV-Burundi Hydropower Project on the Ruzizi River in Burundi. This 287 MW run-of-river power plant will be the fourth in a series of hydropower stations on the Ruzizi River. It will provide electricity to millions of households, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises and industries across Burundi, the DRC, and Rwanda. The generated power will be evenly distributed among the three countries, significantly improving the living conditions and economic opportunities for the regional population.

body: China Gezhouba Group will develop the Congo Muhara Hydropower Station on the Luese River in Niari, Republic of the Congo. This 101 MW hydro power project will convert the kinetic energy of moving or falling water into electrical energy. The facility will house turbines and generators, where the electricity generation process will take place.

title: Gribo - Popoli Hydroelectric Plant, Côte d'Ivoire
body: Société d'Opération Ivoirienne d'Électricité and Sinohydro are set to develop the Gribo-Popoli Hydroelectric Plant in the Sassandra River basin in Bas-Sassandra, Côte d'Ivoire. The project will feature a hydro reservoir with a capacity of 82 million cubic meters and is designed to generate 554 GWh of electricity. With a total capacity of 112.9 MW, the Gribo - Popoli plant will be a significant addition to the region's power infrastructure.

title: Ngwempisi River Hydroelectric Plant, Eswatini
body: Swaziland Electricity is set to develop the Ngwempisi River Hydroelectric Plant in the Manzini region of Eswatini. This 120 MW hydro power project will be implemented in multiple phases. The primary goal of the plant is to generate renewable energy by harnessing the flow of the Ngwempisi River. The hydroelectric facility will convert the kinetic energy of flowing water into electrical power, offering a sustainable source of energy.

title: Ndjole River Port Construction, Gabon
body: The Government of Gabon is set to build the Ndjole River Port in Gabon. This new port will enhance regional transportation by facilitating the movement of food products and minerals from the hinterland to the port city of Port-Gentil in western Gabon via inland waterways. Additionally, a relay river port will be established at Port-Gentil as part of the development plan.

title: Oshakati Water Purification Plant Extension, Namibia
body:
NamPower is set to undertake the extension of the Oshakati Water Purification Plant in Namibia. This project aims to significantly boost the plant's water supply capacity, increasing its current production from 40,000 cubic meters per day to 90,000 cubic meters per day.

The extension will enhance the water supply to the Oshana, Oshikoto, and parts of Ohangwena regions. Upon completion, it will improve the reliability and accessibility of water for residents and businesses in Oshakati, addressing growing demand and supporting regional development.

title: Erongo Desalination Project, Namibia
body:
Location: Between Swakopmund and Henties Bay, west of Namibia

Project Scope & Components

Component 1: Desalination Plant (30 million cubic meters per year)

  • Construction of a state-of-the-art desalination facility to provide fresh water to coastal and inland regions

Component 2: Water Transmission System

  • Development of a pipeline network connecting the Namibian coast to central Namibia, particularly the Windhoek area
  • Supporting infrastructure, including:
    • Booster pump stations with reservoirs along the pipeline
    • Storage reservoirs in Swakopmund and Windhoek

Component 3: Power Supply Infrastructure

  • Development of energy infrastructure to power the desalination plant and water transmission system
  • 5 MW solar power plant to support sustainable energy supply

title: Danbushiya Junction - Danhonou Road Project, Nigeria
body: The Kaduna State Government is set to develop the Danbushiya Junction to Danhonou Road Project in Nigeria. This initiative involves constructing a 14.8 km ring road stretching from Danbushiya Junction to Danhonou, located in the Millennium City within the Chikun Local Government Area. title: Regional Hospital of Thies Expansion, Senegal
body: The Ministry of Health and Social Action (MSAS) in Senegal and the Regional Hospital of Thies are set to undertake the expansion of the Regional Hospital of Thies in Thies, Senegal. This project involves constructing a new specialized outpatient ward and an MRI facility, along with equipping these new sections to diagnose and treat non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes, cancer, and cardiovascular conditions. The expansion will enhance the hospital's capacity to serve patients and align with the Senegalese Government’s goal of achieving Universal Health Coverage (UHC).

title: Bobo - Dioulasso Cote d’Ivoire Border Road: Lot 2, Burkina Faso
body: The Government of Burkina Faso, through its Ministry of Infrastructure and the Permanent Secretariat of the Transport Sector Programme (SP-PST), is advancing the rehabilitation and enhancement of the Bobo-Dioulasso-Côte d’Ivoire Border Road. Development work is currently underway on the 42 km Banfora-Orodara section, which falls under Lot 2 of the project. This road serves as a vital corridor in southwestern Burkina Faso, facilitating the movement of people and goods between the Port of Abidjan in Côte d'Ivoire and the Hauts-Bassins and Cascades regions. It is essential for the transport of both agricultural and industrial products.

title: Konikablo Wind Farm, Ghana
body: Upwind Konikablo, NEK Umwelttechnik AG, and NEK Ghana will be developing the Konikablo Wind Farm in Ghana. This 250 MW onshore wind power project is set to generate 650,000 MWh of electricity annually, providing clean energy to power approximately 120,000 households. The project is projected to offset 220,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions each year and will feature turbines with 160-meter high towers.

title: Madavunu Wind Farm, Ghana
body: Upwind Madavunu Ltd will be developing the Madavunu Wind Farm in Greater Accra, Ghana. This 200 MW onshore wind power project will be implemented in a single phase. It is anticipated to produce 520,000 MWh of electricity annually, offsetting 230,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions. The wind farm will feature 60 turbines, each mounted on 140-meter high towers, and will be connected to the nearby 330 kV WAPP grid line. The project will cover an area of 42 square kilometers.

title: NDIC Lekki Training Office Building, Nigeria
body:
The Nigerian Deposit Insurance Corporation (NDIC) is developing the NDIC Lekki Training Office Building in Lagos, Nigeria. This versatile 12-floor facility will house offices, a training center, and residential apartments. At its core, the NDIC Academy will serve as a regional learning hub dedicated to deposit insurance systems and financial safety-net issues, featuring 9 floors, 6 classrooms, a library, a 300-person hall, and other advanced training amenities.

The building is being constructed on a 4,000 sqm plot and will include 51 residential suites, guest rooms, and additional support facilities. It will incorporate sustainable features such as partial solar power and wastewater recycling. To ensure security, the ground and first-floor doors and windows will be shatterproof to withstand potential explosions.

title: Elizabeth Grace Court III, Nigeria
body:
Godmade Homes Limited will develop Elizabeth Grace Court III in Nigeria, a prestigious residential high-rise featuring 8 floors of luxury living. This development includes ultra-luxurious 4-bedroom maisonettes with a maid’s room and two exclusive penthouses.

Elizabeth Grace Court III offers a refined living experience with modern amenities, including a fully equipped fitness center, a sparkling swimming pool, and beautifully landscaped gardens. Residents will enjoy secure parking, 24/7 security, and easy access to essential services and recreational facilities. The project aims to redefine upscale living in Nigeria with its combination of elegance, comfort, and convenience.

title: Konza Digital Media City (DMC), Kenya
body:
The Government of Kenya in collaboration with Ministry of ICT, Innovation and Youth Affairs  is set to develop the Konza Digital Media City (DMC) on a 160-acre site within Konza Technopolis. This initiative aims to establish a premier digital creative and innovation hub designed to position Kenya as a leading force in Africa's creative and content industries.

The Konza Digital Media City will feature state-of-the-art facilities and infrastructure to support a variety of digital media endeavors. It will house schools specializing in digital media and related technologies, digital media firms, and post-production studios focused on gaming, animation, and music.

The project, envisioned as the anchor tenant for phase two of Konza Technopolis, seeks to foster growth in the creative sector by offering an environment conducive to innovation and development. By leveraging the opportunities within the digital economy, the Konza Digital Media City aims to contribute significantly to Kenya’s economic development and strengthen its position in the global creative sector.

title: Twin Towers, Kenya
body: The Ministry for Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation of Tanzania, in collaboration with the National Social Security Fund (NSSF), will develop the Tanzania Towers in Nairobi, Kenya. These twin towers will each rise approximately 99 meters from ground level, comprising 22 floors, a podium, and two basement levels. The development will include 200 car parking spaces in the basements and an additional 25 ground-level parking spots.

title: Southern National Road RNT12A Rehabilitation: Lot 2, Madagascar
body: Madagascar’s Road Agency will develop Lot 2 of the Southern National Road RNT12A, focusing on the Masianaka-Vangaindrano section. This project is part of phase two of the broader Madagascar-Beira Corridor Development and Trade Facilitation Project (PACFC II). The RNT12A is a crucial road corridor for Madagascar’s Anosy and Atsimo Atsianana regions, linking southern coastal villages and serving as an export route for domestic products through the Port of Ehoala.

title: Sikuvyaye Hydro Power Project, Burundi
body: Tembo Power will develop the Sikuvyaye Hydro Power Project in Bururi Province, Burundi. The hydroelectric plant will have a capacity of 12.4 MW and will include a 12 km transmission line. This initiative aims to strengthen Burundi's energy infrastructure by leveraging the country's river systems to produce sustainable and reliable electricity. The Siku Hydro Power Project is designed to alleviate energy shortages, support economic growth, and enhance living conditions for local communities.

title: Bini a Warak Hydropower Plant, Cameroon
body:
Develop the 95 MW Bini a Warak hydropower and solar plant on the Bini and Warack rivers/basin in Adamawa

The project is expected to generate clean, stable and affordable power for Cameroon’s northern region, increasing its generation capacity by over 50%

Work on the hydro component includes:

  • Building a concrete gravity dam and embankment, with a height of 37 m and a crest of 1,179 m, dominating a reservoir of 771 million cubic metres
  • There will also be a 75 MW power station installed (three vertical Francis turbines of 25 MW each), a rated flow of 41.7 cubic metres per second (m3/s) and a power head of 206 m
  • The hydro scheme will generate 328.5 GWh of electricity
  • A 225 kV high-voltage electricity transmission line with a length of 70 km will be built connecting to the Mounguel substation
  • Construction will also take place on 19.9 km of permanent roads and 23.7 km of temporary roads in the project area, including two 40 m bridges and one 130 m bridge

 

Following an optimisation study undertaken in 2023, the approved project design now incorporates photovoltaic (PV) solar, complementing the power generation from hydropower and raising the project’s installed power generation capacity from up to 75 MW to up to 95 MW

Hydropower production will adapt to photovoltaic solar production levels, enabling a combined stable level of energy generation throughout the day

title: Jindal Mmamabula Energy Project, Botswana
body:
Jindal Mmamabula Energy Project (JMEP I&II)

Jindal’s Mmamabula Energy Project (“JMEP”), is a planned 600 megawatt (net) capacity power station and integrated coal mine project in Botswana that is intended to provide power to South Africa. This project remains the most advanced independent power producer (IPP) project that can meet the demand for new baseload capacity in South Africa in the medium term and long term under cross border arrangements.

Jindal Mmamabula Energy Project (JMEP I)

Jindal Mmamabula Energy Project (“JMEP I”) is a planned 300 megawatt power station and associated coal mine that is envisaged to be built at Jindal’s Mmamabula Coalfield.

The power is intended for sale to Botswana Power Corporation (“BPC”), Botswana’s national utility, as new baseload power generation is required to sustain the country’s growth.

The cost of the capital equipment and infrastructure for JMEP I is estimated at approximately US$ 1 Billion. The estimated construction time for the JMEP I is anticipated to be approximately 36 months from Financial close.

JMEP ESIA & BFS

  • ESIA for 4×171 MW (gross) Thermal Power Plant approved by DEA.
  • ESIA is been done by DigbyWells South Africa.
  • BFS is been completed by Mott McDonalds in 2017.
  • Water rights from Well fields received in range of 18.2 MCM.
  • ESIA for Wellfields approved by DEA.
  • Water Monitoring and Modelling completed by Well Field Consulting in 2017, revised and updated in 2021.

JMEP is being developed in accordance with the Equator Principles, a voluntary set of guidelines based on the International Finance Corporation’s (“IFC”) environmental and social standards. The IFC is the private sector arm of the World Bank Group and these standards are considered best practice for projects in developing countries. Project comply with all OECD guidelines for environment standards.

Source: Jindal Africa
editor_notes:
YG: New Lead Created

 

Source: https://www.power-technology.com/marketdata/power-plant-profile-botswana-coal-fired-power-plant-botswana/?utm_source=lgp5-power-asset-profiles&utm_medium=21-212856&utm_campaign=recommended-articles-pi&cf-view

title: Lowyaddo - Zeila Road: Lot 1, Somalia
body: Somaliland Roads Development Agency is set to develop the Lowyaddo - Zeila Road in Somalia, specifically upgrading the 30km single carriageway to bituminous standard. This road is part of phase one of a broader scheme aimed at enhancing connectivity between Somalia and Djibouti. Phase one encompasses upgrading the 256km Lowyaddo-Faddaha-Borama road in Somalia and the 15km Nagad-Loyada road in Djibouti. Additionally, it includes constructing a feeder road to a salt mine, installing three boreholes, rehabilitating a health center and a school, and improving a ring road for the Waheen market.

title: Kigoma Airport Upgrade, Tanzania
body: The Government of Tanzania and the Tanzania Airport Authority are set to upgrade Kigoma Airport in Kigoma-Ujiji Municipality. The project includes constructing a new passenger terminal, control tower, aircraft parking facilities, night lighting systems, and access roads. Additionally, the runway will be extended to 3,100 meters. The new passenger building will have a capacity to accommodate up to 129,000 passengers annually. This initiative aims to enhance the airport's infrastructure to better serve increased traveler demand. It involves renovating existing terminals, installing a new control tower, establishing a meteorological office, and expanding the parking area from 15,000 square meters to 30,000 square meters.

title: Anwiankwanta - Ahenema Kokoben Road Dualization, Ghana
body: The Ministry of Roads & Highways is set to dualize the Anwiankwanta - Ahenema Kokoben Road in Ghana, spanning 20 kilometers in the Ashanti region. This project aims to ease traffic congestion and enhance connectivity to towns like Ahenema Kokoben, Brofoyeduru, Kotwi, Trede, Adjamesu Dominase, Ofoase Kokoben, Anwiankwanta, Bekwai, and Obuasi. It will feature asphaltic concrete pavement, two grade-separated interchanges to alleviate congestion, and service lanes for safer access to adjacent properties and minor roads, ultimately reducing travel time and improving transportation efficiency.

title: MetroKin Rail Transit: Phase 1, Democratic Republic of Congo
body: MetroKin plans to develop the Kinshasa MetroKin Rail Transit: Phase 1 in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This initial phase focuses on constructing a 25 km rail line from Kinshasa’s central station to N’Djili International Airport. The project involves upgrading the existing railway, including rebuilding the current 1067-mm gauge route into a double-track 1435-mm gauge line. Additionally, eight new stations will be built, new signalling systems will be installed, and bridges along the route will be constructed or rehabilitated.

title: Cavalla River Border Bridge, Republic of Côte D'ivoire
body: The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) is set to construct the Cavalla River Border Bridge linking the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire and the Republic of Liberia at the Prollo border. The project includes a two-lane box girder balanced cantilever bridge spanning approximately 288 meters, accommodating both vehicular traffic and pedestrian walkways. Additionally, about 1 kilometer of approach roads will be built on both sides, along with measures to mitigate environmental impact. These developments form part of phase one of the Mano River Union Road Development and Transport Facilitation Programme (MRU/RDTFP).

title: Ethiopia - Sudan Railway, Ethiopia
body: The Ethiopian Railways Corporation is set to embark on the development of the Ethiopia-Sudan Railway within Ethiopia. This ambitious project entails the establishment of a 1512-kilometer standard gauge railway network linking Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia, to Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, with an additional stretch reaching Port Sudan on the Red Sea. The envisioned route spans from Addis Ababa to Awash, Kombolcha, Weldiya, Wereta, Gonder, Metema, Galabat, Gadarif, Kassala, Haiya, and finally, to the Port of Sudan.

title: Ethiopia Djibouti 2nd Power Interconnection Project (ETDJ2PIP)
body: Ethiopian Electric Power (EEP) is embarking on the development of the Ethiopia-Djibouti Second Power Interconnection Project: Phase 2, in Ethiopia. This project aims to establish a 230 kV transmission interconnection from Semera, Ethiopia to Nagad, Djibouti, which is deemed the most effective means to augment Djibouti's clean and cost-efficient power supply by over 30%. Furthermore, it will enable Ethiopia to enhance foreign exchange revenue from power trade while reducing Djibouti's reliance on fossil fuel-generated electricity. The project entails: (i) construction of a 230 kV double circuit Transmission Line spanning 292 km (102 km in Ethiopia and 190 km in Djibouti), with each circuit capable of transferring 160 MW; (ii) extension of the existing Semera 230 kV Substation in Ethiopia and the 230/63/20 kV substation at Nagad in Djibouti; (iii) reinforcement of the existing 230 kV transmission line between Kombolcha-Mile to Semera, spanning 170 km, alongside the construction of a new 230 kV substation at Mile and extensions of existing substations in Kombolocha and Semera, all in Ethiopia; and (iv) Last mile connections in Djibouti. The project has been divided into six lots to facilitate efficient execution.

title: Esan Garden City Estate, Nigeria
body: The Edo State Development and Property Corporation (ESDPC), in partnership with MaxImpact Global Ventures Limited, is set to embark on the development of the Esan Garden City Estate in Ekpoma, Nigeria. This initiative is designed to drive positive transformation in the lives and communities surrounding the Ekpoma/Irrua Axis of Edo State through real estate development. With the formalization of this agreement, both parties express their unwavering commitment to this noble endeavor. The government's vision includes the construction of 369 housing units in Ekpoma, with Esan Garden City tailored to meet the housing needs of civil servants and low-income earners. The estate will offer four housing types, including two and three-bedroom units.

title: Maputo Corridor
body: The Department of Transport (DoT) is undertaking the development of a business case for the Maputo Corridor in South Africa. This initiative aims to establish a seamless connection between Mozambique's Port of Maputo and the South African provinces of Gauteng, Limpopo, and Mpumalanga, as well as the broader Southern African Development Community (SADC) region. Central components of the corridor encompass South Africa's 570km N4 toll road, extending from Gauteng to Maputo in Mozambique, a railway network, the Lebombo/Ressano Garcia border post, and Maputo port.

title: Lamu Special Economic Zone (SEZ), Kenya
body: The LAPSSET Corridor Development Authority (LCDA) is establishing the Lamu Special Economic Zone (SEZ) along Kenya's Indian Ocean coast. This SEZ is a key component of the Lamu Port-South Sudan-Ethiopia Transport (LAPSSET) Corridor Programme, which aims to connect Kenya, Ethiopia and South Sudan through a network of ports, highways, railways, pipelines, airports and resort cities. Spanning approximately 5,200 acres in Lamu county, the Lamu SEZ will be designed to accommodate various land use developments, such as industrial, trade, commercial, office, and residential zones. The creation of masterplans and prototypes will adhere to a phased implementation framework.

title: The Dubai Investments Park (DIP), Angola
body: Dubai Investments has unveiled plans to construct a Dubai Investments Park (DIP) in Bengo province, Angola. Spanning 2,000 hectares, this innovative development will be a unique integrated hub encompassing residential, commercial, and industrial spaces, showcasing Dubai Investments' expertise in crafting successful mixed-use projects. Positioned along a stunning 3-kilometer coastline and featuring a 2-kilometer sandy beach, DIP Angola will offer a versatile canvas for master planning. With aspirations to become a tourism and industrial hub, the project will comprise 70,000 residential units, including villas and apartments, catering to 200,000 residents. Recreational amenities will include communal parks, cycle lanes, and an 18-hole, 100-hectare golf course. Additionally, plans entail the construction of a shopping mall and hospitals. This ambitious endeavor will be developed in phases, ensuring its successful realization.

title: National Route No.2 Faranah Bridge Reconstruction, Guinea
body: The Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Works in Guinea has unveiled its ambitious plans for the reconstruction of the Faranah Bridge along National Route No.2 in the Faranah region. The upcoming bridge will stretch 70 meters in length and span 17 meters in width, featuring two lanes, including a dedicated lane for motorcycles, and sidewalks on both sides. In addition, an access road measuring approximately 503 meters will seamlessly connect to both ends of the bridge. To facilitate this modernization effort, existing utilities such as electricity, water, and fiber optic internet cables will be relocated. This initiative aims to replace the current Faranah Bridge with a contemporary two-lane structure capable of accommodating heavy traffic in both directions, thereby enhancing road safety. Moreover, the project is poised to significantly improve transportation services, bolstering inter-regional connectivity and optimizing domestic logistics, particularly regarding agricultural goods and daily necessities. By enhancing the functionality of National Route No.2, a crucial international corridor, the project will expedite logistical operations not only within Guinea but also across neighboring countries, fostering greater economic integration and facilitating trade.

title: Pwalugu Multipurpose Dam, Ghana
body:
The Volta River Authority (VRA) is set to develop the Pwalugu Multipurpose Dam Project on the White Volta River in Ghana, approximately 16km east of the Pwalugu Bridge on the main Tamale-Bolgatanga road. The coordinated operation of the Pwalugu Dam with the Bagré Dam upstream on the White Volta River in Burkina Faso and with the Akosombo and Kpong dams downstream on the White Volta River is essential for river basin management. The dam will be a central roller compacted concrete combined and earth and rock fill dam on the banks. The key components of the project include:

  • A dam with an elevation of 165 meters near the Pwalugu Bridge on the White Volta River, featuring a maximum reservoir area of 350 square kilometers.
  • A powerhouse equipped with two turbines, providing an installed capacity of 60 MW and a firm continuous capacity of 16.5 MW
  • An irrigation scheme, which includes a 12-meter high weir and a comprehensive canal network (comprising main, primary, secondary, and tertiary canals) to irrigate around 25,000 hectares of land.

title: Steenbras Hydro Pumped Storage Scheme Upgrade, South Africa
body: The City of Cape Town will be upgrading  the Steenbras Hydro Pumped Storage scheme in Western Cape, Gordon's Bay, South Africa. The 180-megawatt Steenbras Hydro Pump Station consists of four turbines that are used to generate electricity. During peak electricity demand, it channels water from Upper Steenbras to Lower Steenbras through the turbine generator to create electricity.

title: Well City, Togo
body:
Derou & Partners is set to develop Wellcity, a mixed-use development in Lomé-Adétikopé, Togo. Wellcity will encompass 1,000 housing units, a hotel, an oil station, a retail mall, a school, a clinic, playgrounds, and gardens. It will also feature the first wedding-planning complex in the area, which includes 15 fully-furnished state-of-the-art villas and a 75-meter-long swimming pool.

Wellcity is divided into five clusters, providing a modern alternative to traditional industrial and business cities. This development focuses on well-being and ecological sustainability.

  • Cluster 01: Residential | Economy Villas | 200 duplex villas with 3, 4, and 5 rooms.
  • Cluster 02: 300 collective apartments (economy types with 3, 4, and 5 rooms).
  • Cluster 03: A 250-room MICE hotel and water park.
  • Cluster 04: Collective facilities, including a school complex, polyclinic, technoparc, and sports complex.
  • Cluster 05: Social Housing | Low scalable villas with 2, 3, 4, and 5 rooms, and a water park.

Wellcity aims to create a harmonious living environment that emphasizes well-being and ecological responsibility.

title: Gandon - Saint Louis Nord Road Section 2: Lot 4, Senegal
body: Senegal’s Agency for Works and Road Management (AGEROUTE) is leading the development of Section 2: Lot 4 of the Gandon - Saint Louis Nord Road in Senegal. This project entails constructing an 11-kilometer highway connecting Gandon and Saint-Louis in the northwest. It is part of the broader 200-kilometer Dakar-Tivaouane-Saint Louis highway project, aimed at enhancing access to Senegal’s northern regions and supporting the development of key sectors such as agriculture, hydrocarbons, tourism, and mining. Section two of the highway will include the construction of four interchanges and 81 crossings, comprising 68 underpasses and 13 overpasses.

title: Mandilas Tower, Nigeria
body: Mandilas Group Limited is embarking on the development of Mandilas Tower in Lagos, Nigeria. This residential complex boasts 58 units spread across 15 floors. Situated within the upscale neighborhood of Ikoyi, Mandilas Tower offers beautifully designed 2, 3, 4, and 5 bedroom apartments. Each home features elegant interiors, dual aspect views, and access to a private balcony. Residents will also enjoy access to amenities such as a state-of-the-art pool with a built-in bar, a high-specification fitness and wellness center, a private on-site cinema, a spa-quality massage room, meeting facilities, courtyard gardens, and two recreational areas.

title: Noqui River Terminal, Angola
body: The Minister of Transport in Angola is spearheading the Noqui Terminal Project, which involves dismantling the existing terminal and constructing a new container yard, bulk cargo yard, maintenance area, and management building. Covering an area of approximately 20,000 square meters, the project aims to enhance water transport connectivity in the north of Angola, facilitating interoperability between sea and river transport. The development includes a 200-meter-long pier with three ramps, two for passenger ships and one for cargo vessels. Approved as part of Angola's Transport Sector Development Plan, the project prioritizes expanding public transport and improving infrastructure to accommodate increased passengers and cargo transported by road, rail, sea, and air.

title: Bankenveld District City Development, South Africa
body: Calgro M3 and Eris Property Group are collaborating on the development of the Bankenveld District City in Gauteng, South Africa. Calgro M3 will oversee the residential components, while Eris will manage the commercial, retail, industrial, educational, and healthcare aspects. The project aims to create 20,000 to 30,000 housing units alongside significant commercial, retail, and industrial spaces. Spanning 300 hectares, the mixed-use precinct will encompass 500,000 square meters of warehouse and logistics, retail, and commercial developments. Approximately 34% of the land acquired will be allocated to infrastructure, including roads, stormwater management, and extensive recreational and green belt areas.

title: Airports Company South Africa Infrastructure Investment (ACSA), South Africa
body:
Airports Company South Africa (ACSA) is set to implement the ACSA Infrastructure Investment in South Africa, focusing on refurbishments and improvement. These upgrades aim to enhance infrastructure development across its airport network until 2029. Planned works include:

Dawid Stuurman International Airport:

  • Terminal expansion

George Airport:

  • Terminal expansion

Johannesburg Oliver R. Tambo International Airport:

  • Construction of passenger and cargo terminals
  • Addition of six bussing gates to Terminal A bus terminal
  • Expansion of retail, seating, and holding lounge areas

Cape Town International Airport:

  • Expansion of baggage claim area
  • Expansion of domestic departures lounge
  • Expansion of retail facilities
  • Addition of three aerobridges

Durban King Shaka International Airport:

  • Hotel development
  • Terminal expansion

King Phalo Airport:

  • Expansion of departure lounge
  • Expansion of retail options

The investment is designed to enhance asset availability, airport safety and passenger experience across ACSA's airports.

title: Thika Dam and Water Supply Infrastructure Project, Kenya
body: Thika Water and Sewerage Company (Thiwasco) is planning to upgrade and expand its infrastructure to increase water supply. This project will increase daily water production capacity from the current 40,000 cubic meters to 70,000 cubic meters. The project scope involves the construction of two 10m high water reservoirs on the Chania river and at the Thika 3A site, in Kiambu county in central Kenya. Additionally, it includes the replacement and rehabilitation of existing water distribution networks, refurbishment of the current water treatment plant, and provision of new last-mile water connections.

title: Antananarivo - Toamasina Road Project, Madagascar
body: The Autorite Routiere De Madagascar is initiating the Antananarivo - Toamasina Road Project in Madagascar, covering 250 kilometers. As Madagascar's inaugural toll highway, it promises to significantly slash the distance between Antananarivo and Toamasina by 110 kilometers, reducing travel time from nine hours to just three. This project will not only impact Madagascar but also benefit interconnected regions like Kenya and contribute to Africa's infrastructural goals, exemplifying collaborative innovation and determination in shaping the continent's future.

title: Berekum – Sampa Road Project, Ghana
body: The Ministry for Roads and Highways is undertaking the Berekum – Sampa Road Project in the Bono Region of Ghana. Stretching over 119 kilometers, this road will undergo construction to asphaltic finishing, with the inclusion of drainage structures and road signs. It serves as a vital link connecting Berekum to the border town of Sampa, passing through key cashew-growing towns such as Jinijini, Japekrom, Drobo, Dwenem, Seketia, and Sumwria Ahenkro.

title: Bank Of Ghana New Headquarters, Ghana
body: The Bank of Ghana is embarking on the development of its new headquarters in Accra, Ghana. The project comprises three main blocks: the Tower, Urban, and Amenities Blocks, along with basements, podium, and ancillary facilities. The development features a 20-storey Tower Block, an 8-storey Urban Block, and a 6-storey Amenities Block. Additionally, there will be upper and lower ground podiums, three levels of basement car parking areas, as well as ancillary facilities such as energy farms, treatment plants, and security gatehouses.
