title: Ofankor - Nsawam Road Rehabilitation, Ghana
body: The Ghana Highway Authority is undertaking the rehabilitation of the Ofankor - Nsawam Roads in Ghana, covering a distance of 33.4 kilometers. Progress includes the construction of an underpass footbridge at the Agya Appiah section and a footbridge at Fise, with other project components at varying stages of completion. The project involves expanding the road to eight lanes from Ofankor to Pokuase Interchange and ten lanes from Pokuase Interchange to the Nsawam Bypass.

title: Omi Eko Water Transport Project, Nigeria
body: Lagos State Waterways Authority (LASWA) and Lagos Metropolitan Area Transport Authority (LAMATA) are collaborating on the Omi Eko Water Transport Project in Lagos, Nigeria. This initiative aims to establish 15 ferry routes spanning the Lagos lagoon, covering approximately 140 km of inland waterway network. The project entails the enhancement of 25 ferry terminals and jetties, alongside the procurement of 75 electric-powered vessels. To facilitate the operation of these vessels, charging stations equipped with Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) supplied by solar PV panels will be installed at pontoons. Additionally, the grid and a backup generator fueled by Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) will support the charging infrastructure. Furthermore, the project encompasses the provision of equipment for routine maintenance, establishment of a control center to oversee the inland waterway network, and implementation of associated systems such as ticketing mechanisms.
specifications: ["15 Ferry Routes | 25 Ferry Terminals and Jetties"]

title: Bukasa Port Construction: Phase 1, Uganda
body: The Ministry of Works and Transport in Uganda is initiating Phase 1 of the Bukasa Port Development in Kampala, Uganda. This phase focuses on land reclamation for port construction, aiming for seamless integration with road, rail, and water transportation networks. Bukasa Port's strategic positioning, spanning 400 hectares, will facilitate efficient handling of international cargo and serve as a key gateway along the Central and Northern Corridors. Additionally, it will function as a vital logistical hub, driving down business costs, alleviating road maintenance burdens, and stimulating economic growth by promoting trade and job creation across the region.

title: New Materials Recovery Facility, South Africa
body:
The City of Cape Town and JG Afrika are collaborating on the construction of a new materials recovery facility (MRF) at Coastal Park landfill in Muizenberg, Cape Town, South Africa. Situated on a 65,000m² plot of land previously occupied by a 5m- to 6m-thick layer of municipal solid waste and a substantial stockpile of building rubble, the project necessitated innovative engineering solutions.

The MRF building will accommodate various mechanical separation equipment, including a bag splitter, magnetic separator, screens, conveyors, and baling facilities designed for processing recyclable materials. Additionally, the facility will house offices for city officials and the facility operator, alongside a training center dedicated to waste management education.

As part of the development, a nine-bay drop-off facility will be established to accept builders’ rubble, mixed waste, garden waste, and recyclables not processed by the MRF.

title: Bayside Canal Upgrade, South Africa
body: The City of Cape Town Water and Sanitation is undertaking the Bayside Canal Upgrade project, stretching from Blaauwberg Road to Rietvlei in Tableview, Western Cape, South Africa. This upgrade aims to achieve three key objectives: enhancing the capacity of the Bayside canal, implementing naturally-structured treatment facilities to enhance the quality of stormwater runoff entering Rietvlei, and ensuring future systematic maintenance accessibility. The project scope includes lining the canal's side slopes south of Blaauwberg Road, deploying floating litter booms for solid waste removal, constructing parallel primary sedimentation ponds, a secondary treatment channel, and reed bed ponds for additional water treatment. Additionally, the project involves building a bypass channel and laydown areas adjacent to the ponds and treatment channel to facilitate future maintenance efforts.

title: Mooi Plaats Solar Project, South Africa
body: Envusa Energy, a partnership between Anglo American and EDF Renewables, is advancing the development of the Mooi Plaats solar project situated on the border of the Northern and Eastern Cape provinces of South Africa. With a capacity of 240 MW, this project is a significant component of Envusa Energy’s mature pipeline of wind and solar projects in the country. The envisioned renewable energy ecosystem aims to furnish a blend of renewable energy, sourced both from Anglo American's sites in the Southern African region and from other locations, with energy transmitted via the national grid. As part of the Koruson 2 wind and solar projects, Mooi Plaats benefits from exceptional yield resources and a robust connection to the Eskom grid.

title: Special Economic Zone (SEZ) and Dry Port, Malawi
body: Government Of Malawi  in collaboration with Arise Integrated Industrial Platforms (ARISE IIP) is set to develop a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) and a Dry Port in the northern region of Lilongwe, Malawi. The SEZ will serve as a catalyst for attracting diverse investments across industrial and commercial sectors, while also providing logistical and inland container depot services to enterprises within Malawi. With a focus on promoting local processing of raw materials into high-value finished products, particularly in agriculture, the SEZ aims to bolster economic growth and foster value addition within the country.

title: Durban Port Road Rehabilitation, South Africa
body: Transnet National Ports Authority (TNPA) is embarking on the Port of Durban Road Rehabilitation Project in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. This initiative aligns with our commitment to provide robust port infrastructure, ensuring the efficient operation of the port as a vital economic gateway for South Africa. The refurbishment of port roads is poised to enhance operational efficiencies and facilitate smoother traffic flow in targeted areas. Priority will be given to Maydon Wharf, where 16 roads are slated for repair, followed by three roads in Island View and two in Bayhead. Alongside addressing structural defects, the project encompasses rectifying functional issues like surface drainage problems caused by damaged manholes and inlets due to heavy vehicle usage.

title: Lower Umkhomazi Bulk Water Supply Scheme: Phase 2, South Africa
body: Umgeni Waterworks is advancing with Phase 2 of the Lower Umkhomazi Bulk Water Supply Scheme in Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa. This phase of the project focuses on the potable water component and is divided into several packages, including the establishment of a 100Ml/day Water Treatment Works, a 3.5km gravity main pipeline to Quarry Reservoir, extension of Quarry Reservoir to a capacity of 30ML, and the construction of a Green Star Administration Building. These initiatives are integral parts of the broader Umkhomazi Water Project.

title: Lower Umkhomazi Bulk Water Supply Scheme: Phase 1, South Africa
body: Umgeni Waterworks is set to embark on the development of Phase 1 of the Lower Umkhomazi Bulk Water Supply Scheme in Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa. The project will be carried out in two distinct phases. Phase 1 will primarily focus on the raw water component, which will be divided into two separate systems: the Ngwadini system featuring off-channel storage, and the Goodenough System equipped with Abstraction Works and a raw water storage reservoir. This initiative forms an integral part of the broader Umkhomazi Water Project.

title: Blaise Diagne International Airport Expansion, Senegal
body:
Passenger Terminal

  • Expand Blaise Diagne International Airport (AIBD) by extending the passenger terminal, with the aim of boosting annual passenger capacity by 40%, increasing it from the current 3 million to over 5 million and then 10 million by 2035
  • The first phase of the passenger terminal extension project entails reconfiguring the terminal infrastructure to improve customer experience and support the expected growth in air traffic
  • The airport currently covers an area of 4,500 square metres

(Passenger terminal project brochure)

Cargo Terminal

  • Construct a new cargo terminal: The goal is to transform it into a regional freight hub, with a reception and storage capacity of 80,000 tonnes (import and export zones) by 2035, compared with 34,000 tonnes in 2022. This will address the problems relating to the storage and operation of the cargo village

Cargo Terminal Scope of Work:

  • Administrative quarters 
  • A loading and unloading dock
  • An import/export storage area
  • Cold-storage rooms
  • A cafeteria

(Cargo terminal project brochure)
meta_description: Passenger Terminal
migration_status: success

title: V&A Waterfront Expansion, South Africa
body:
The V&A Waterfront in Cape Town is embarking on an expansion, focusing on the adjacent Granger Bay precinct. 

Scope

  • The expansion will add up to 440,000 square meters of new development rights, two-thirds of which will be dedicated to Granger Bay.
  • The development will include mixed-use spaces: residential apartments, hotels, retail outlets, cultural facilities, and public amenities.
  • A significant portion of the project involves reclaiming land from the sea, continuing Cape Town’s tradition of coastal engineering seen in the original V&A Waterfront and Foreshore developments

title: Sherbro Island Eco City, Sierra Leone
body: Sherbro Alliance Partners (SAP) is embarking on the development of the Sherbro Island City project in Sierra Leone. Positioned on the expansive 600-square-kilometre Sherbro Island along the Atlantic Ocean coastline, this city is envisioned as a key economic center for West Africa. Under a public-private partnership with the government, it will be established as a semi-autonomous special economic zone (SEZ). The overarching goal is to craft a comprehensive, long-term vision for the island, serving as a blueprint for future investments and development. Immediate strategies will also be devised to address current needs effectively. A team of seasoned experts has been meticulously assembled to tackle various aspects crucial for a successful master plan. Their collaborative efforts from the onset aim to ensure that the plan is both grounded and visionary, capable of being implemented seamlessly.

title: Mesob Tower, Ethiopia
body: The Ethiopian Ministry of Culture and Tourism is embarking on the development of the Mesob Tower, an iconic landmark set to grace the skyline of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This visionary project envisions a striking 70-floor mixed-use development that pays homage to Ethiopian culture, with its design inspired by the traditional "Mesob" household utensil used for food storage. Spanning an impressive total land area of 50,000 square meters and towering 250 meters high, the Mesob Tower will not only serve as a symbol of national pride but also as a major tourist attraction. The development will feature a diverse array of facilities, including a hotel, shopping mall, cultural center representing all regions of Ethiopia, gym, gardens, athletic track, and golf club. Through its multifaceted offerings, the Mesob Tower aims to showcase the rich cultural heritage of Ethiopia while providing a modern and vibrant space for leisure, recreation, and hospitality.

title: Senoba - Ziguinchor - Mpack Road, Senegal
body: Ministry of Infrastructure & Land Transport in collaboration with Ageroute, is undertaking extensive rehabilitation works on the Senoba -Ziguinchor - Mpack Road in Senegal. This road segment forms part of the National Road 4 (RN4), spanning from Senoba on the northern border with The Gambia down to Mpack on the southern border with Guinea-Bissau. The rehabilitation project includes the construction of socio-economic infrastructure within the localities of Ziguinchor, Bignona, and Bounkling. This encompasses various amenities such as 10 classrooms, school canteens, four health centers, four training centers, seven markets, four motor parks, a heavy-duty vehicle parking area, six market gardening areas, and 1.5km of enclosures. Through these efforts, the aim is to enhance the overall infrastructure network, promote socio-economic development, and improve accessibility for communities along the Senoba - Ziguinchor- Mpack corridor in Senegal.

title: Sokoto - Badagry Expressway, Nigeria
body: The Federal Government, of Nigeria is spearheading the development of the Badagry-Sokoto Coastal Highway project in Nigeria. This ambitious initiative entails the construction of the 1,000km Sokoto-Badagry expressway, stretching from Sokoto in the northwest to the Badagry area of Lagos in the south. The primary aim of this project is to enhance transport connectivity between Kenya and South Sudan, thereby fostering regional integration and trade while contributing to the mitigation of fragility. By establishing a more efficient, safe, and effective cross-border transport system, the project seeks to address the specific objective of improving road transport along the Lesseru – Nadapal – Juba corridor (Kenya/South Sudan). Key objectives include reducing travel time, cutting travel costs, and enhancing road traffic safety along the project road sections. Through these efforts, the project aims to significantly enhance regional connectivity and promote socio-economic development across the affected regions.

title: Lesseru - Kitale and Morpus - Lokichar Road Upgrade: Phase I, Kenya
body: The Kenya Highways Authority (KENHA) is set to undertake the upgrade of vital sections along the Kenya to South Sudan road corridor, Lesseru - Kitale and Morpus - Lokichar Road Upgrade: Phase I, Kenya. This investment project, supported by GCA, will primarily focus on the Lesseru–Kitale (55km) and Morpus – Lokichar (138km) segments of the corridor. The overarching objective is to advance the social and economic development efforts of both countries while alleviating poverty. This will be achieved by establishing a more efficient and effective cross-border transport system, enhancing security measures, and fostering trade to deepen regional integration. Specifically, the project aims to: Improve connectivity along the Lesseru - Nadapal-Juba corridor, thus reducing travel time to northern parts of Kenya. Establish a vital link between landlocked South Sudan and seaports. Foster regional integration and cross-border trade, stimulating export-oriented agricultural development. Decrease travel costs and enhance road traffic safety along the project road. Provide a more efficient and effective transportation system, contributing to the improved economic and social empowerment of the population.

title: Kampala - Malaba Metre Gauge Railway Refurbishment, Uganda
body: The Uganda Railways Corporation (URC) is undertaking the development of the Kampala-Malaba Metre-Gauge Railway in Uganda. This project involves the rehabilitation of the existing 271 kilometers of the Meter-Gauge Railway, which includes the Kampala-Malaba and Port Bell-Kampala - Kyengera lines. These lines will be upgraded to connect Uganda, along the shores of Lake Victoria, with the Kenyan rail network at Malaba, situated at the Uganda-Kenya border. These enhancements will establish a direct link to the Port of Mombasa, bolstering transportation efficiency, facilitating trade, and enhancing cost-effectiveness in the region.

title: Magufuli Bridge, Tanzania
body: Tanzania National Roads Agency (TANROADS) is set to embark on the development of the Magufuli Bridge in Mwanza, Tanzania. The bridge work consists of a Dos bridge (520m) with a total length of 3.00 km (including the approach section) which will go over the outside of Lake Victoria. The road construction is composed of widening 1.66 km of the present road to two lanes to four road lanes and development of 1.16 km on the Kigongo side and 0.5 km at the Busisi side which tie in from the existing surfaced road to the Bridge.

title: Nimule Dry Port, South Sudan
body: The Ministry of Trade and Industry is set to spearhead the development of the Nimule Dry Port, located in South Sudan's Eastern Equatoria State near Uganda. This strategic project aims to establish an inland customs clearance hub equipped with state-of-the-art facilities, streamlining trade operations at the border and alleviating congestion of trucks and containers. Moreover, the Nimule Dry Port will serve as a pivotal depot and wholesale market for crucial commodities, further enhancing regional trade dynamics. By constructing this dry port, transportation expenses are projected to decrease, while trade facilitation in the area will significantly improve, fostering economic growth and development. The project will be constructed in two phases.

title: KD Towers, Nigeria
body: Darycet International Limited and Kaduna State Development And Property Company have announced their collaboration on the development of KD Towers in Lagos, Nigeria. KD Towers is set to be a sprawling mixed-use development comprising 82 units spread across four ten-story buildings. Each building will feature two flats on every floor. Block A will offer 20 units of three-bedroom apartments, while Block B will provide 18 units of three-bedroom apartments. Block C will have no three-bedroom units, and Block D will consist of 24 one-bedroom units and six office suites. Additionally, the ground and first floors of each block will host restaurant spaces and shops, enriching the community experience. With a prime location overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, KD Towers promises residents an unparalleled lifestyle within a two-acre grand development. World-class amenities will be provided, including two lifts in each tower, main and service staircases connecting to kitchen and service areas, and breathtaking views of the ocean.

title: Soyuz 1 Wind Energy Facility, South Africa
body: Emthanjeni Local Municipality, Pixley Ka Seme District Municipality and Soyuz 1 (Pty) Ltd proposes developing a 480 MW wind energy facility in the Northern Cape province of South Africa, approximately 22 km south of Britstown, within the Emthanjeni Local Municipality and Pixley ka Seme District Municipality. This project is part of a broader plan that includes five additional wind energy facilities—Soyuz 2 through Soyuz 6—across a 125,000-hectare area, all undergoing separate impact assessments in line with the 2014 Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations. The proposed facility will feature up to 75 turbines, along with internal cabling, substations, battery energy storage systems, batching plants, auxiliary buildings, and access roads, covering 150 hectares. The area includes 59 assessment units with conditions ranging from “Largely Natural” to “Poor,” providing various ecosystem services such as flood attenuation and biodiversity support. Two units are particularly crucial for biodiversity due to their location in the Graafwaterspruit Environmental Sensitive Area, with Ecological Importance and Sensitivity ratings spanning from low to high.

title: Malagarasi Hydropower Plant, Tanzania
body: Tanesco plans to construct a 44.8 MW hydropower plant in Kigoma, Tanzania. This facility, utilizing the Igamba Falls Stage III, will enhance the region’s energy reliability by providing renewable power to households, schools, clinics, and SMEs. As part of Tanzania’s Development Vision 2025 and Five-Year Development Plan, the project includes a 54-km, 132 kV transmission line to the national grid, expansion of the distribution network for rural electrification, and support for project management, contract administration, and resettlement of affected persons.

title: Chobe Zambezi Water Transfer Scheme, Botswana
body:
• The government of Botswana is looking to move ahead with the Chobe Zambezi water transfer scheme, with the aim of tapping into the water resources allocated to it from the Chobe-Zambezi River in the country's north
  • The project will transfer additional water from the Chobe and Zambezi rivers on the northern border of Botswana to the large demand centres in southeastern Botswana
  • The country’s Water Utilities Corporation (WUC) will be the principal offtaker and is planning to implement the project as a public-private partnership (PPP), using a design-build-finance-operate-transfer (DBFOT) contract
  • The proposed system will transfer 495 million cubic metres a year of water from the Chobe-Zambezi river through 1,500 km of pipeline, running from the collection point in the town of Kazungula in Zambia to Mmamashia in Botswana, with two spur lines towards Maun in the northwest and Orapa in the central district
  •  For more information contact: chobezambezi@kpmg.bw
specifications: ["110 mm to 355 mm diameter I 495 million cubic meter"]

title: Kumasi - Paga (Central Spine) Rail Project, Ghana
body: The Ministry of Railway Development is developing the Kumasi-Paga (Central Spine) Rail project in Ghana. Spanning a distance of 595 kilometers, this rail line will link Kumasi, located in the central region of Ghana, with Paga, situated in the northern region on the border with Burkina Faso. At the Kumasi Junction, the Central Line diverges into two branches: the Eastern Line and the Western Line. On completion, the Central Spine rail line will facilitate the movement of passengers and freight cargo from the southern to the northern parts of Ghana and beyond, extending into Burkina Faso and the Sahelian Region.

title: Farkwa Dam, Tanzania
body: United Republic of Tanzania has announced plans for the construction of the Farkwa Dam, strategically positioned downstream of the Bubu and Mkinki rivers' confluence in Mombose and Bubutole Villages of Farkwa Ward, Chemba District, Dodoma Region. Situated approximately 130 kilometers north of Dodoma on the route to Kondoa District, the dam comprises a 32-meter high composite roller compacted concrete (RCC) and earthfill Main Dam equipped with intake, outlet works, and spillway (FSL 1,110m), as well as a 15-meter high earthfill Saddle Dam. Additionally, the project includes the construction of associated site access roads spanning a total of 12 kilometers. The primary purpose of the dam is to provide water for domestic use, irrigation, and livestock activities.

title: Intermodal Rail and Development Plan (TIRP): Phase2, Tanzania
body: The Ministry of Works and Transport in Tanzania has unveiled plans for the Second Tanzania Intermodal and Rail Development Project (TIRP-II), set to span between Dar es Salaam and Isaka . As a pivotal phase of the Tanzania Intermodal Rail and Development Plan (TIRP), this initiative entails the refurbishment or rehabilitation of approximately 470 kilometers of railway track along with the implementation of climate resilience measures like flood control systems. Moreover, this project forms an integral component of Tanzania's broader investment strategy in rail infrastructure, which encompasses the construction of a Standard Gauge Railway linking the Port of Dar es Salaam to neighboring nations.

title: A-Grade Warehouse and Manufacturing Project, Kenya
body: Improvon Group and Actis have commenced the construction of an A-grade warehouse and manufacturing complex within the Nairobi Gate Industrial Park (NGIP), situated in Kiambu County. This purpose-built park aims to cater to Kenya's textile industry by offering state-of-the-art facilities and extensive networks across a 100,000 square meter plot of land. Positioned along the Eastern Bypass, the textile park project will feature three-phase power supply with the option for solar backup and robust safety services, leveraging NGIP's established reputation. Moreover, it is anticipated to provide advantages such as tax incentives and Zero-rated VAT within its Special Economic Zone (SEZ) designation.

The project scope encompasses seeks to link Mombasa Island and North Coast and will involve construction of a new 600 meter bridge and 400 meters of roads approaching the bridge. A consortium has been selected to implement the project under the PPP arrangement and will recover their investment by installing toll booths to collect charges from users.

title: Pakwach Bridge, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) has announced plans to replace the aging Pakwach Bridge on the Albert Nile in Pakwach district, Uganda with a new structure to tackle persistent flooding issues. The current bridge, constructed in the 1960s to connect the railway to the West Nile region, has developed significant cracks and frequently disrupts traffic on the Olwiyo-Pakwach road. Due to its deteriorating condition and the ongoing flooding challenges, the government has decided that a new bridge is necessary. This replacement aims to resolve the recurrent flooding problems and ensure smoother traffic flow. The new bridge will address both safety concerns and traffic disruptions caused by the old structure.

body: The Uganda National Roads Authority has outlined plans for the development of Lot 3 of the Gulu-Corner Kilak road project, spanning approximately 100 kilometers. This initiative involves upgrading the chosen route, exploring alternative routes and pavement options, enhancing road safety measures, conducting preliminary design work, establishing implementation plans and schedules, as well as conducting economic and financial analyses.

title: Kitgum - Kidepo Road, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) intends to enhance the Kitgum-Kidepo Road in Uganda. Spanning 115 kilometers in North Eastern Uganda, this road links the Kitgum and Kaabong districts. With rising traffic volumes between Kitgum and the Kidepo Valley National Park (KVNP), extending further to South Sudan, it has been deemed necessary to upgrade the existing first-class gravel road to better accommodate the increasing demand.

title: Chinhoyi University Of Technology Students Accommodation, Zimbabwe
body: The Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education, Innovation, Science and Technology Development has proposed the construction of a student accommodation complex at Chinhoyi University of Technology. This project involves the development of five new hostel blocks, including two three-storey buildings and three four-storey buildings, designed to provide a base capacity of 1,512 student beds. Additionally, the project scope includes the extension of existing services—such as water, sewer, roads, and electricity—to support these new facilities. The total area covered by the complex is 18,000 square meters.

title: Mazowe Shopping Mall, Zimbabwe
body: The Mazoe Rural District Council is constructing a Shopping Mall, Hotel, and Conference Facility in Mazowe, Mashonaland Central Province, Zimbabwe. This major development is designed to enhance the region's retail and commercial infrastructure, featuring shops with local and international brands, diverse dining options, and entertainment facilities such as cinemas and arcades. The mall will also provide essential amenities and plans to include a hotel and conference center to serve tourists and business travelers. This significant investment is expected to boost the local economy by creating jobs, supporting businesses, and contributing to community development, thereby improving the quality of life in Mazowe.

title: Mvurwi Housing, Zimbabwe
body: The Mvurwi Town Council plans to undertake the construction of low-cost housing and garden flats in Mvurwi, Zimbabwe. This project encompasses the development of affordable and practical single-family homes and multi-family units, designed to meet local needs and climate conditions. It includes site preparation, construction of the residential units with cost-effective materials, and the creation of garden flats featuring communal green spaces. The scope also covers the development of essential infrastructure such as access roads, water, and sewage systems, as well as community facilities like parks and playgrounds. Environmental considerations and sustainable practices will be integrated throughout the project to enhance the living environment. The initiative aims to provide quality, affordable housing and improve living conditions for residents in the region.

title: High Grand Falls Dam, Kenya
body: The National Irrigation Authority is undertaking the development of the High Grand Falls Dam in Kathwana, Kenya, situated in Tharaka-Nithi County. This ambitious project entails the construction of Africa’s second-largest freshwater dam. The High Grand Falls Dam is designed as a multipurpose structure and is set to be erected on a 165 square kilometer expanse of land spanning Kitui, Tharaka-Nithi, and Tana River counties. Once completed, the dam is projected to boast a water storage capacity exceeding 5,600 million cubic meters, facilitating irrigation efforts across 400,000 hectares of land in the region.

title: Integrated Transport Program: Phase I, Ethiopia
body: The Ethiopian Roads Authority is gearing up to enhance Phase I of the Ethiopia Integrated Transport Program, focusing on the Jimma–Chida & Sodo-Sawla road sections. This endeavor entails upgrading the existing 240-kilometer road segments to a high-standard asphalt concrete surface, featuring a 7-meter wide carriageway and sealed shoulders measuring 1.5 meters by 2. This upgrade will establish a direct link between the towns of Jimma and Sodo while also integrating Sawla into the primary trunk road network, facilitating access for local communities to Addis Ababa and other parts of the country. Moreover, the project encompasses capacity building in transport-related issues and climate change, alongside support for women's entrepreneurial development.

title: The Red Sands, South Africa
body: Globeleq plans to construct a battery energy storage system in the Northern Cape, South Africa. The project scope includes Red Sands, which will be Globeleq's first large-scale Battery Energy Storage Solutions (BESS) project in South Africa. Additionally, the Group owns and operates eight renewable plants (six solar PV, two wind) with a total generating capacity of 384 MW in South Africa. Furthermore, Globeleq owns a combined solar and BESS plant at Cuamba in Mozambique and is developing other BESS projects across the African continent.

title: Tzaneen Dam Rehabilitation, South Africa
body: The Department of Water and Sanitation plans to raise the wall of the Tzaneen Dam in Limpopo, South Africa. The project scope includes raising the dam wall by 3 meters in South Africa’s northernmost province of Limpopo. The Department of Water and Sanitation notes that the project, categorized as Category III dam classification, represents the highest hazard rating by the Dam Safety Office, considering the size and potential for loss of life in the unlikely event of a catastrophic dam failure.

title: Masaka - Mutukula Road Reconstruction, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is undertaking the reconstruction of the Masaka – Kyotera – Mutukula road project spanning 89.5 kilometers in Uganda. This initiative also involves the rehabilitation of the Nyendo – Villa Maria road covering 11 kilometers, as well as the upgrading of Access Roads spanning 7 kilometers to a paved standard. The reconstruction project entails a lane width of 3.5 meters, paved shoulders measuring 2.0 meters, parking lanes of 3.5 meters for heavy trucks, and paved walkways extending 2.5 meters. The road will extend from Masaka Broadway Road, passing through Kyotera, to Mutukula at the border point with Tanzania

title: National Route N1 Section 29 Musina Rehabilitation, South Africa
body: The South African National Roads Agency SOC Limited (SANRAL) is set to reconstruct a section of the N1 passing through the town of Musina in the Limpopo Province, South Africa. This stretch spans from Musina South (km 89.65) to Musina North (km 95.44), covering a total distance of 5.8 kilometers. The N1 segment between km 89.550 and km 95.440 can be classified as urban, with the area between km 89.550 and km 91.700 encompassing the Musina Central Business District (CBD), and the region between km 93.900 and 95.440 also classified as urban.

title: Polytechnic Project, Angola
body: The Ministry of Higher Education of Angola is set to embark on the development of the Polytechnic Project situated in the North Kuanza Province, Angola. This initiative encompasses the construction of 17 buildings, comprising teaching facilities, auditoriums, apartments, and accompanying infrastructure. Spanning across a vast land area of 360,000 square meters, the project will feature a total construction area of 29,000 square meters.

title: Grande Cote Water Desalination Facility, Senegal
body: The Ministry of Water and Sanitation, alongside the Senegalese Company of Water (Sones), is developing the Grande Cote Water Desalination Facility in Senegal. This project aims to establish a cutting-edge desalination plant in Dakar, Senegal, known as the Grande Cote Water Desalination Facility. Upon completion, the proposed facility will have an installed capacity to process 400,000 cubic meters per day of seawater. The project will be undertaken in two phases, with each phase achieving a capacity of 200,000 cubic meters of water per day upon completion.

title: Ummbila Emoyeni Electrical Grid Infrastructure, South Africa
body: Seriti Resources plans to construct Ummbila Emoyeni, a 900MW hybrid renewable energy facility. The project scope encompasses 750MW of wind energy, 150MW of solar PV, and 800MWh of battery storage. The project has been recognized as a Strategic Infrastructure Project and has received Environmental Authorization, paving the way for construction to begin.

title: KZN - Mozambique Border Barriers: Phase 3, South Africa
body:
The South African National Defence Force (SANDF) plans to construct a concrete barrier along the South Africa-Mozambique border. The project scope entails construction in three phases:

Phase 3: A 9 km barrier from the western boundary of Tembe Elephant Park towards the Pongolo River.

Phases 2 and 3 will commence following the completion of Phase 1. This initiative aims to enhance border security by curbing vehicle theft and the movement of illicit goods.

title: RIA Highway Construction & Expansion, Liberia
body: The Government of Liberia has plans to expand and reconstruct the Roberts International Airport (RIA) Highway in Monrovia, Liberia. This highway is a crucial artery connecting six out of Liberia's 15 counties. Upon completion, the expanded RIA highway will feature a four-lane road equipped with streetlights and traffic lights along its route and at intersections. Additionally, standardized culverts and drainage systems will be implemented.

title: Tanzania LNG, Tanzania
body:
Block 2 LNG production, expected to be 7.5 million tons per year (MTPA), will be exported to the international markets using dedicated LNG ships, which will constitute the main source of revenues.

A part of the gas arriving in Lindi will be allocated to the domestic market and in the future potentially exported to regional markets.

Key numbers of the Project:

  • More than 30 years of production
  • More than 20 TCF (trillion cubic feet) of gas in place
  • LNG production of 7.5 MTPA (Million Tons Per Annum)
  • Potential to produce 8TWh (terawatt hours) of yearly electricity from the 10% of gas allocated to the domestic market

Source: Equinor

title: G2, Nigeria
body: Cruxstone Development & Investment Limited is proud to announce the upcoming development of G2, a prestigious residential complex situated on Glover Road in Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria. G2 sets a new standard for ultra-luxury living, boasting a remarkable 17-floor architectural masterpiece. At G2, residents will experience the epitome of sophisticated urban living and exclusivity. With a selection of spacious luxury apartments, lavish duplexes, and presidential penthouses, G2 offers the highest class of residential accommodation. This exceptional project features meticulously designed 4, 5, and 6-bedroom maisonettes, each boasting high-quality finishes and attention to detail. Residents of G2 will enjoy a comfortable lifestyle, surrounded by modern leisure design facilities and amenities. Indulge in the lavish amenities offered by G2, designed to enhance every aspect of daily life. From premium facilities to unparalleled comfort, G2 promises a living experience that is truly worth savoring.

title: Nairobi Railway City, Kenya
body:
Nairobi Railway City project is a visionary 425-acre transit-oriented, mixed-use urban development initiative designed to transform central Nairobi into a modern, smart, and integrated commercial and cultural hub. The master plan integrates transport infrastructure with business, residential, cultural, and civic functions, fostering inclusive growth and urban renewal.

Key Development Zones and Scope:

Kenya Railway Zone (15 hectares)

  • Kenya Cultural Center
  • National Railway Museum
  • Historic Legacy and Heritage Area

R&D and Innovation Zone (4 hectares; FAR 400; 15 floors)

  • Knowledge industry cluster
  • Synergistic integration with Technical University of Kenya (TUK)

Street Commercial Zone (62 hectares; FAR 300; up to 10 floors)

  • Mixed-use commercial, residential, and office developments
  • 2.4 km shopping promenade – the longest in Eastern Africa

MICE Core (Meetings, Incentives, Conferences & Exhibitions) (44 hectares; FAR 600; up to 45 floors)

  • Convention centers
  • High-end hotels
  • Luxury residential and commercial facilities

International Office Zone (36 hectares; FAR 600; up to 25 floors)

  • Grade A office space
  • Regional and global business headquarters

Central Station & Multimodal Transport Hub (FAR 400; 15 floors)

  • Integrated railway, bus, and transit station
  • Mixed-use commercial spaces

EAST Core (New Wakulima Market Zone) (12 hectares; FAR 250; up to 8 floors)

  • Commercial spaces
  • Community services and local markets

Railway City Housing (51 hectares; FAR 250; 5–12 floors)

  • Total of 3,522 residential units
  • Includes 992 affordable housing units

Center Core (49 hectares; FAR 500; up to 20 floors)

  • Mixed-use developments
  • Offices, high-end residences, central green space, and park
  • Integrated transit station

High-Tech SME Zone (20 hectares; FAR 400; up to 10 floors)

  • Technology-driven industrial cluster
  • SME incubators and innovation spaces
  • Integrated green park and public realm

title: Abuja Gateway Airport, Nigeria
body: The Government of Nigeria has ambitious plans for the development of the Gateway Airport in Abuja, Nigeria. The project will encompass ceremonial reception halls, marketplaces, a gymnasium, and a children's zoo. The architecture aims to symbolize the country's diverse culture. This stunning solar-powered gateway will take the shape of the traditional Nigerian bow harp; its design will connect the new Abuja Airport to the central area on the opposite side of the freeway and will feature green roofs, a giant solar canopy, and bricks made from local laterite clay. The plan includes an amphitheater and public space with a photovoltaic canopy to provide power and shade for visitors from the sun. Nearby buildings will be adorned with green roofs, blending them into the surrounding greenery.

title: Orizon Tower, Angola
body: Investimo will be developing the Orizon Tower project in Luanda Bay, Angola. The Orizon Tower is a new multi-purpose development with a unique visual identity, comprising 26 floors. It includes three office floors, an amenities floor with a restaurant, swimming pool, outdoor terrace, spa, and gym, as well as 82 flats ranging from 2 to 5 bedrooms. The project will occupy a total area of around 39,000m² and provide 215 car parking spaces. title: Songo - Matambo Transmission Line Project, Southern Africa
body: Electricidade de Moçambique (EDM) is planning to construct a 118 km, 400 kV high-voltage single-circuit transmission line from Songo to Matambo to integrate the Mphanda Nkuwa hydropower plant. Steel mesh overhead towers will support a 2,300 MW energy transport capacity. The Songo substation will undergo expansion, including the addition of a new 600 MVA 220/220 kV phase shift transformer, a 3,200 MVA 220/400 (300) kV step-up transformer, and refurbishment of current transformers. This project aims to provide clean, reliable energy to the region's communities while enhancing grid reliability.
migration_status: success

title: Gogo Hydropower Redevelopment Project, Kenya
body: The Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen) plans to construct a hydropower redevelopment project in Migori County, Kenya. The project scope includes upgrading the current capacity from 2 MW to 8.6 MW, aiming to enhance the reliability of power supply and socio-economic activities in the Nyanza and Western Kenya regions. This project is part of KenGen's Least Cost Power Development Plan aimed at meeting the growing demand for electricity. Refurbishing the existing spillway and installing flashboards to increase the reservoir's level are key components of the project. This upgrade is expected to significantly improve the quality of life for people in the region.

title: Massey’s Children Hospital, Nigeria
body: The Lagos State Government Ministry of Works & Infrastructure has announced plans for the development of Massey's Children Hospital in Lagos, Nigeria. This healthcare initiative aims to revolutionize pediatric care in the region. The upcoming 5-floor facility, boasting 130 beds, will be a beacon of specialized medical attention for children. Set to become the largest children's hospital in Sub-Saharan Africa upon its completion, Massey's Children Hospital signifies a significant advancement from the aging Massey Street Children's Hospital, which has served for over six decades. With a focus on patient-centric care, the new hospital will cater to both inpatients and outpatients. Its mission extends beyond mere treatment; it aims to mitigate infant and maternal mortality rates, contributing to the overall improvement of healthcare in the region.

title: Quantum Luxury Towers, Nigeria
body: Quantum Properties Limited is set to develop the Quantum Luxury Towers in Ozumba Mbadiwe, Victoria Island, Lagos, Nigeria. Featuring 50 units, this residential development boasts a distinctive yet elegant design, characterized by its strong and simple form. The architectural detailing enhances the building's verticality, while the floor plan layouts emphasize functionality and axiality. The Quantum Luxury Towers offer breathtaking views spanning across the Lagos metropolis to the Nigerian coastline. Each apartment is meticulously designed with expansive glass panels to maximize natural light and showcase the stunning vistas. Functional recessed balconies add to the allure of this exceptional living space.

This residential project will soar over 26 floors and comprise 40 units .Metropolitan Towers are Lagos newest architectural icons. Sophisticated and elegant, the new Metropolitan Towers re-define urban luxury living within the city's most exclusive neighborhood. Looking at the vernacular architecture and patterns of Nigeria, the Tubali (Hausa) architectural queues were used to inform the overall massing and shape of the development. Symmetry and expressed vertical elements are abstracted from the traditional forms to create more of a sculptural design.

title: Beitbridge Airport, Zimbabwe
body: The Government of Zimbabwe is planning to build an airport in Beitbridge, Zimbabwe. The project includes upgrading the existing runway and constructing a new terminal building. Beitbridge, one of Africa's busiest border posts, currently relies on an aerodrome for light aircraft. The proposed modern airport will be situated around 20 kilometers outside the town, in the Makhavhane area. It aims to meet modernized border post standards and will include a new cargo terminal equipped with scanning technology for expedited goods inspection.

title: Zanzibar Energy Sector Transformation and Access, Tanzania
body:
Solar plant:

  • Construct an 18 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) plant across 41.4 hectares in the Makunduchi area
  • Plant is expected to be operated for a minimum of 30 years
  • Solar plant project will include associated works such as building a short interconnection line linking the plant to the grid

BESS:

  • Design, supply, install, test, commission and operate (initially) a 40 MWh battery energy storage system (BESS) in Mtoni
  • BESS to be located across 1.3 hectares in the Mtoni (Galagala) area of Unguja island

Transmission line:

  • Construction a 94 km 132 kV double-circuit transmission line running from Welezo through Ubago to Makunduchi and Matemwe
  • Line will evacuate power from the proposed PV plant and BESS
  • Build a 132kV switching substation at Welezo and two 132kV substations at Matemwe and Makunduchi
  • Design, supply and install a supervision, control and data acquisition (SCADA) system and an energy management system

title: Nakawuka-Mpigi Road, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is set to embark on the development of the Nakawuka-Mpigi Road in Uganda. This project comprises five segments totaling 72.5 kilometers, namely Kisubi – Nakawuka - Natete (27km), Nakawuka – Kasanje – Mpigi (22km), Nakawuka – Mawagulu- Nanziga – Maya (11km), Kasanje – Buwaya (9km), and the Entebbe – Nakiwogo Roads project. The aim of this road infrastructure initiative is to enhance traffic flow and connectivity within and around Wakiso, Kampala, and Mpigi Districts. It will facilitate easier access to major trunk roads such as the Kampala-Masaka and Entebbe-Kampala Highways, as well as the Buwaya and Nakiwogo landing sites.

title: Abuja-Kaduna-Zaria-Kano Road (AKR), Nigeria
body: The Ministry of Works and Housing, under the federal government of Nigeria, will undertake the reconstruction of the Abuja-Kaduna-Zaria-Kano Road (AKR). This vital roadway serves as a crucial link connecting various regions of Nigeria to the North, traversing through the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), Niger, Kaduna, and Kano States. The AKR spans a total length of 375.9 kilometers and is divided into three sections. Section I, stretching 165.5 kilometers, runs from Abuja to Kaduna. Section II covers a distance of 73.4 kilometers, connecting Kaduna to Zaria. Lastly, Section III spans 137 kilometers, linking Zaria to Kano.

title: Karpowership, South Africa
body:
The project involves the deployment of floating modular reciprocating gas engine power ships at three locations in South Africa under the Risk Mitigation Independent Power Producers Procurement Programme (RMIPPPP). Each power ship will be LNG-fueled and berthed at designated ports to provide a combined 1,220MW of electricity.

Project Scope:

  • Technology: Floating modular reciprocating gas engines
  • Fuel Source: Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG)
  • Total Capacity: 1,220MW
  • Implementation Sites & Capacities:
    • Saldanha, Western Cape – 320MW
    • Coega, Eastern Cape – 450MW
    • Richards Bay, KwaZulu-Natal – 450MW

Each location will host an LNG-fueled power ship, supplying power to the national grid to enhance energy security and support South Africa’s electricity needs

title: Desert to Power Initiative, Mauritania
body:
Build the 225 kV Mauritania-Mali power interconnection and and related solar power plants development project (PIEMM).

Components:

  • Construct the Yelimane (Mali)-Tintane-Kiffa (Mauritania) 225 kV double-circuit high-voltage line and three associated substations at Yelimane, Tintane and Kiffa
  • Construct the 225 kV Kayes-Yelimane double-circuit high-voltage line and extend the existing Kayes substation in Mali
  • Build the 225 kV Tintane-Aioun double-circuit high-voltage line and a new substation in Aioun (Mauritania)
  • Construct the 50 MW Kiffa solar power plant in Mauritania, with a storage capacity of 35 MW/70 MWh, and its connection to the 225 kV line

 

Overall, the PIEMM looks to construct a 1,373km 225kV double-circuit transmission network between the two countries with a transit capacity of 600MW, with 184km of the line located in Mali and 1,189km in Mauritania. 

In addition, eight transformer substations will be built and 100,000 new households (80,000 of them in Mauritania and 20,000 in Mali) are to be connected to the electricity network using smart prepayment meters in the localities crossed by the 225kV line.

title: Paarl Africa Underground Laboratory (PAUL), South Africa
body: The University of Stellenbosch plans to  construct an  Underground Laboratory at Du Toits Kloof mountains in the Western Cape in South Africa. The project scope encompasses The 10 000 m3 laboratory will be accessed through the existing Huguenot tunnel, 800 m underneath the surface,An engineering feasibility study will determine the viability of establishing the PAUL just off the tunnel as part of the South African National Roads Agency’s plans to upgrade the North Bore tunnel to decrease traffic volumes in the existing South Bore tunnel.

title: Sir Lowry’s Pass River Upgrade, South Africa
body:
The City of Cape Town's Water and Sanitation Department is planning a major upgrade for the Sir Lowry’s Pass River in Western Cape, South Africa, aimed at reducing flooding along its 12-kilometer course. The region's unique geography, characterized by mountainous terrain that causes intense, short-duration rainfall, makes the river highly susceptible to severe flooding.

The upgrade project includes several key measures:

  • Construction of berms along the riverbanks
  • Grade leveling to create a more uniform slope
  • Realignment of specific sections of the river

The project will be divided into three distinct sections based on the river's characteristics:

  • The upper section spans 1 kilometer and features steep slopes due to the surrounding mountains.
  • The middle section covers 8 kilometers, passing through hills, fynbos, vineyards, and Sir Lowry's Pass Village.
  • The lower section extends 3 kilometers, representing the river's base flow channel below the N2 highway before it enters False Bay.

title: Aman Green Hydrogen Project, Mauritania
body:
The Government of Mauritania and renewable energy developer CWP are collaborating on the Aman Project, a green hydrogen production facility located in the Dakhlet Nouadhibou and Inchiri regions of Mauritania. Spanning an area of 8,500 km2 across the country’s northern desert and coastal zones, the project integrates hybrid generators utilizing wind and solar power. With a combined capacity of 30 GW (18 GW from wind and 12 GW from solar), the facility is projected to generate 110 TWh of electricity annually. The initiative aims to produce approximately 1.7 million tons of green hydrogen and 10 million tons of green ammonia.

  • Solar Capacity 12,000 M W
  • Wind capacity 18,000 MW
  • Total Generation Capacity 100 TWh
  • Green Hydrogen 1.7 mtpa
  • Green Ammonia 10 mtpa
  • Water 50 million m3/y

title: Saldanha Green Hydrogen Project, South Africa
body:
The Phelan Green Energy plans to construct a Green Hydrogen Ammonia Plant in Saldanha, South Africa.. The project scope will use a mix of solar and wind power – which is expected to generate 2,5 GW – to create hydrogen as a fuel for a wide range of industrial applications. 
The project will use its own distribution grip to transfer energy from its renewable generating capacity to the hydrogen plant.

title: Geothermal Powered Data Centre, Kenya
body: EcoCloud and G42 are collaborating on the development of the cutting-edge Olkaria Geothermal-Powered Data Centre in Kenya. Initially, the facility is set to have a capacity of 100 MW, with plans for expansion up to 1 GW. Given the substantial electricity demands of data centers, particularly with the increasing reliance on power-intensive AI applications, the project aims to leverage Kenya's abundant geothermal resources. Through the establishment of the initial 100 MW facility, the project anticipates gradual scaling to meet rising demands over time. At its full potential, the center will play a pivotal role in reducing Kenya's reliance on fossil fuels, curbing carbon emissions, and fostering environmental preservation.

title: Ummbila Emoyeni Wind Energy Facility: Phase 1, South Africa
body:
Develop a 155 MW project located in Mpumalanga, South Africa. Anticipated to generate 500,000 MWh of electricity, this phase will feature 200-meter-high towers supporting up to 111 wind turbines with a maximum hub height of 200 meters. 

The tip height of the turbines is expected to reach up to 300 meters. The connection infrastructure will include 33kV cabling, laid underground where practical, linking the wind turbines to the onsite collector substations.

title: UNON Conference Facility Expansion, Kenya
body: The United Nations Office at Nairobi (UNON) is expanding its conference facilities in Kenya. The project aims to accommodate up to 9,000 delegates for formal meetings, a substantial increase from the current capacity of 2,000 persons. The expansion project includes the creation of twenty-four conference and meeting rooms of various sizes, a new visitors center, a delegates registration building, a media center, dining facilities, and multi-purpose exhibition buildings. Additionally, it involves the renovation of the existing 2,000-person capacity conference facility. The new facilities are designed to prioritize the health and safety of delegates, staff, and visitors, and will aim for net-zero energy consumption.

title: Wolf Wind Energy Facility, South Africa
body: Red Rocket is set to undertake the development of the Wolf Wind Energy Facility in Eastern Cape, South Africa. This initiative involves creating an inventive design for a sharply inclined concrete road leading to a location within the Klein Witerhoek mountain range. The project encompasses the establishment of 17 foundation bases to support wind turbine generators along a ridge. Specifically, it will feature the installation of five 6.2MW Vestas V162 turbines and twelve 4.5MW V163 models. The foundations for V162 turbines will have a diameter of 22.5 m, while those for V163 turbines will measure 21.2 m. The larger bases will necessitate over 650 cubic meters of concrete each, whereas the slightly smaller bases will utilize nearly 600 cubic meters.The construction process will entail more than 180,000 cubic meters of bulk earthworks for the base excavations and on-site roadways. This includes the development of a 15 km access road to connect with the wind turbines. Furthermore, around 100,000 cubic meters of rock will be blasted during the project's construction phase. Upon completion, the wind turbines are anticipated to contribute 84MW of energy to the country's grid.

title: Sechaba Energy Project, Botswana
body: Shumba Energy plans to develop the Sechaba Energy Project in Central Botswana, featuring a Baseload Steam Turbine power plant with a total capacity of 300 MW. Fuel for the plant will be sourced from the Sechaba Coal Mine. The project will include two coal-fired steam turbines, each with a 150 MW nameplate capacity. The power plant will utilize subcritical non-reheat steam turbine technology with dry air-cooled condensers. Sulphur oxide (SOx) emissions will be controlled through in situ capture using limestone dosing in the boiler furnace. Particulate matter will be managed with electrostatic precipitators, while nitrogen oxide emissions will be inherently controlled due to the low operating furnace temperatures of circulating fluidised bed boilers.

title: Sekelduin Substation, Namibia
body: The Namibia Power Corporation (NamPower) is gearing up to enhance its infrastructure with the construction of a substation in Swakopmund, Namibia. This comprehensive project involves the design, manufacturing, supply, and installation of specialized switchgear and substation protection systems, as well as automation systems for a new indoor 132/66/33kV substation. To ensure optimal functionality, eleven switchgear units will be provided, comprising six 132 kV units and five 66 kV units. Notably, the 33 kV switchgear for the new indoor substation will feature a four-panel switchboard of type GHA single busbar GIS switchgear, sourced from Schneider Electric, the international technology partner of ACTOM MV Switchgear. Through this initiative, NamPower aims to bolster its grid infrastructure, enhance reliability, and meet the growing demand for electricity in the Swakopmund region.

title: Springbok Solar Power Plant, South Africa
body: The SOLA Group plans to construct a Solar Power Plant at Free State Province, South Africa. The project scope encompasses to proceed with the establishment of a 150 MW photovoltaic solar facility alongside associated infrastructure on Farm Weltevrede No. 638, within the Theunissen Registration Division situated in the Matjhabeng Local Municipality, Free State Province. The proposed development site lies approximately 10 km north-northeast of Virginia and around 23 km north-northwest of Welkom. Spanning an estimated total development footprint of 350 hectares, the project aims to connect to the national grid via a power line linked to the existing Theseus MTS 400 132 22 kV Substation.

title: The Bellagio: Phase 1, Nigeria
body: Cavalli Business & Investment Group is set to develop The Bellagio Lagos, Nigeria, a striking 26-floor high-rise that serves as an architectural marvel, seamlessly blending space, comfort, functionality, and world-class amenities. The residences range from luxurious studios to one-, two, and three-bedroom en-suite apartments, as well as five-bedroom maisonettes. The Bellagio Lagos will feature a total of 136 exclusive residences, comprising 4 studio apartments, 52 one-bedroom units, 44 two-bedroom units, 32 three-bedroom apartments, and 4 five-bedroom maisonettes. The ground floor will host a lush lobby/reception area, a three-floor car-level parking facility, a recreational floor with a 5-star cafe and restaurant, a game area for playful activities, and modern spacious apartments spanning 21 floors. This development promises a sophisticated living experience with its carefully crafted design and upscale amenities. The project is divided into two phases, with the first phase, The Bellagio Lagos, featuring three towers of 10 floors each.

title: Tororo - Busia, Mayuge, Busia Towns Roads, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority is set to undertake the development of the Tororo-Busia Road, along with the improvement of Mayuge and Busia Town Roads in Uganda. The project encompasses the construction of the Busia-Tororo Road (25.0 km), the Busia border road (1.0 km), and the Mayuge and Busia town roads (18.0 km). Currently, the preferred route between Busia and Tororo is the 45-kilometer-long paved Busia – Busitema – Tororo route. However, the forthcoming Busia-Tororo Road, spanning approximately 25 kilometers, will serve as the shortest and most direct route between the two towns, reducing the overall travel distance by approximately 20 kilometers.

title: Umma Dam, Kenya
body: The National Water Collection and Storage Authority (NWHSA) of Kenya is undertaking the construction of the Umma Dam water supply irrigation project in Kitui County, located in the eastern region of Kenya. The primary construction aspect involves the erection of a 33-meter-high earth embankment dam, along with the establishment of a sewage treatment plant with a capacity to treat 500 cubic meters of sewage daily. This initiative aims to mitigate the risks associated with downstream flooding, enhance water quality for local residents, and serve as a vital measure in reducing the prevalence of waterborne diseases in the area.

title: Ummbila Emoyeni Solar PV Park, South Africa
body: Seriti Resources Holdings is set to undertake the development of the Ummbila Emoyeni Solar PV Park, a 150MW ground-mounted solar project located in Mpumalanga, South Africa. This solar power initiative will span 255.2 hectares and feature a total of 522,727 photovoltaic (PV) modules. These PV modules will range from 330Wp to 450Wp and will be mounted on either fixed tilt or single-axis tracker structures. The choice of mounting structure will be determined based on optimization, available technology, and cost considerations.

title: Design Data Centre Tier-IV, Angola
body: The Paratus Group is preparing to establish a state-of-the-art data center in Luanda, Angola, as part of its expansion strategy. This project involves constructing the company's third data center in the country, complementing its existing pair of Tier-III designed facilities. Covering an expansive area of 30,000 square meters, the new center is positioned to serve as a crucial hub for digital infrastructure in the region. With a capacity to accommodate over 2,000 servers, it offers ample space for data storage and processing requirements. Furthermore, with a robust information technology power capacity exceeding 10 MW, the facility is set to support high-performance computing and data-intensive operations, further solidifying Paratus Group's leadership in the Angolan data center market.

title: Luwero – Butalangu Road, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority is set to undertake the development of the Luwero – Butalangu Road in Uganda. This road, located in the Central Region, serves as a vital connection between Luweero, the political headquarters of Luweero District, and Butalangu, the political and administrative headquarters of Nakaseke District. Stretching approximately 29.7 kilometers, the road commences at Luweero, traverses through Kiwoko, and concludes at Butalangu.The primary objectives of the project are threefold:i) Enhancing access to goods and passenger transport services with the aim of reducing transportation costs along the entire route.ii) Improving access to social and economic development opportunities for communities situated along the road.iii) Ensuring that the upgrading works do not adversely impact the well-being of roadside communities, thereby emphasizing a commitment to their welfare.

title: Phezukomoya Wind Energy Facility, South Africa
body: The collaborative effort of EDF Renewables, H1 Holdings, and GIBB-Crede is set to bring to fruition a pioneering Wind Farm in Middelburg, South Africa. The project's focus centers on the development of three distinct wind farm projects, with Phezukomova boasting an impressive capacity of approximately 140 MW. Secured under Bid Window 5 of the Renewable Energy Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme, these projects represent a significant milestone in South Africa's renewable energy landscape. Each wind farm within the Koruson 1 initiative will comprise 26 wind turbines, distinguished by a hub height of 124 meters and an expansive blade length of 83 meters. This comprehensive approach underscores the commitment of the consortium to harnessing clean and sustainable energy sources to power the future of South Africa's energy sector.

title: Durban Container Terminal Pier 2, South Africa
body: The Transnet National Ports Authority (TNPA) and Transnet Port Terminals are planning to undertake a significant infrastructure project at the Port of Durban, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The focus of this project is the construction of the Durban Container Terminal (DCT): Pier 2 North Quay berth deepening. This initiative aims to bolster the operational efficiency of South Africa's largest container terminal, which presently handles a substantial portion of the Port of Durban's throughput and a significant proportion of the nation's overall port traffic. DCT Pier 2 currently has a container capacity of two million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs). However, to meet the growing demands of maritime trade, the terminal is targeted for capacity expansion to accommodate up to 2.8 million TEUs. This expansion strategy involves deepening the North Quay berth at Pier 2, a responsibility assigned to the Transnet National Ports Authority (TNPA). The TNPA is tasked with deepening the berth from its current depth of 12.8 meters to a depth of 16.5 meters. This enhancement will enable the terminal to accommodate larger vessels, with Berth 205 capable of hosting three 350-meter ships concurrently. These vessels are anticipated to handle average consignments of up to 12,000 TEUs per call, significantly boosting the terminal's throughput capacity. In the near future, TNPA is expected to issue a tender for the deepening project, signaling the commencement of the procurement process to engage contractors for the execution of this critical infrastructure development. This endeavor underscores the commitment of Transnet and South African authorities to invest in modernizing port infrastructure, ensuring the nation's continued competitiveness in global maritime trade and logistics.

title: Medium & Low Voltage Distribution Network Project: Lot 3, Madagascar
body: The Madagascar Hydroelectric Company is undertaking the construction of a Medium and Low Voltage Distribution Network project in Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar. This project involves the erection of medium and low voltage distribution grid overhead lines spanning approximately 424 kilometers. It encompasses various tasks such as civil engineering for pole and tower foundation construction, installation of conductors, fittings, insulators, and other necessary accessories. The aim of this initiative is to establish a reliable and efficient distribution network to facilitate the transmission of electricity across the region, thereby enhancing access to power for residents and businesses in Antananarivo.

title: Cotonou Port Reconstruction, Benin
body: The Port Authority of Cotonou is set to embark on a comprehensive reconstruction project for the Cotonou port in Benin. The project entails various aspects, including the reconstruction and deepening of the North dock spanning 1,391 meters, an extension of the North dock by 214 meters, and the construction of a roll-on roll-off (RoRo) ramp. Additionally, there will be a 154-meter extension of the South dock, widening of the harbour basin, deepening of the berths to 16 meters, and the implementation of maintenance dredging of the basins.As it stands, the current infrastructure of the Cotonou port comprises a 546-meter quay, a 31.2-hectare container park, and an impressive total container storage capacity approaching 20,000 TEU. The upcoming reconstruction aims to enhance the port's capabilities and overall efficiency, making it a more robust and advanced maritime facility.

title: Rietkloof Wind Farm, South Africa
body: G7 Renewable Energies is set to undertake the development of the Rietkloof Wind Farm in Western Cape, South Africa. he project consists of up to 58 wind turbines and electricity will be evacuated through the Bon Espirange substation which connects to the Komsberg Main Transmission Substation., boasting a total nameplate capacity of 140 MW. The Rietkloof Wind Farm is anticipated to generate nearly 590 GWh of electricity annually. This substantial energy output is expected to fulfill the power requirements of over 181,000 typical South African households, making a significant contribution to the country's renewable energy goals.

title: Majuba Rail Project, South Africa
body: Eskom is initiating a significant infrastructure project in Mpumalanga, South Africa, focusing on the construction of a railway line known as the Majuba rail project. This initiative, a vital component of the Eskom Road-to-Rail Initiative, aims to establish a railway connection between the Majuba power station and the primary coal railway hub in Ermelo, Mpumalanga. Spanning a distance of 68 kilometers, this corridor represents South Africa's first major greenfield freight-rail infrastructure project since 1986 and will be managed by the State-owned Transnet Freight Rail (TFR). The project involves constructing various key structures, including 96 culverts, nine cattle creeps, 32 agricultural underpasses and overpasses, 18 bridges, one service duct, and 40 cattle grids. Its primary objective is to enhance coal supply security by implementing efficient logistics solutions for multiple power stations, including Majuba, Tutuka, Camden, Grootvlei, Kendal, and Hendrina. With a projected coal throughput potential of 32 million tons annually, the railway will facilitate the transportation of coal by rail, contributing to reliable energy supply. Additionally, the terminal will be equipped with an upgraded coal tippler system to streamline coal unloading processes, further enhancing operational efficiency. This initiative underscores Eskom's commitment to optimizing operations and ensuring the reliability of energy supply through strategic infrastructure investments.

title: Rooiwal Waste Water Works Repair and Upgrade: Phase 1, South Africa
body: The Department of Water (DWS) is planning a Waste Water Works repair and upgrade in Tshwane, Gauteng, South Africa. This initiative encompasses Phase 1, which focuses on completing a repair project currently at 68% completion to enhance the quality of effluent from the facility. Phase 1A is considered urgent and will utilize a turnkey approach to ensure swift and efficient execution, including general building, mechanical, and electrical elements necessary for upgrading the plant's capacity and functionality. Subsequently, Phase 1B will adopt a conventional approach, which involves the construction of two primary sedimentation tanks, the refurbishment of the East flow balancing tank and pump station, and the upgrading of the anaerobic digesters at the Rooiwal West Works.

title: Belabo–Ngaoundere Railway Line Upgrade Project, Cameroon
body: Camrail has initiated plans for a comprehensive railway line upgrade in Cameroon. Focused on the Belabo–Ngaoundere line, which has lagged behind in modernization efforts since its establishment, this project entails enhancing 330 km of railway infrastructure. The primary objective is to improve freight and passenger connectivity to northern Cameroon, Chad, and the Central African Republic. Key components of the project include track upgrades, engineering enhancements, station facility improvements, and the implementation of advanced safety measures at rail crossings. Upon completion, the upgraded lines are poised to accommodate passenger trains operating at speeds of up to 90 km/h and freight trains at speeds of 70 km/h, signifying a significant leap forward in transportation efficiency and regional connectivity.

title: Ruhengeri Hospital Redevelopment, Rwanda
body: The Ministry of Health is set to undergo the redevelopment of Ruhengeri Referral Hospital in Musanze town, Rwanda. The renovation project is geared towards increasing the hospital's capacity from 320 beds to 550. The plan includes the replacement of all current buildings, excluding the laboratory. Furthermore, the initiative will bring in new services, incorporating intensive care and advanced diagnostic facilities like CT scanners, MRI, and electrocardiograms. The overarching objective is to reduce the need for patients to journey to the capital for medical treatment.

title: Mbeya University Main Campus, Tanzania
body: The Mbeya University of Science & Technology is planning the construction of its main campus in Mbeya, a city in southwestern Tanzania. The main construction elements will include an academic teaching building, a science and technology innovation center, and workshop facilities. This project, funded by the World Bank, represents the company's second successful bid in the Tanzanian market, following the construction project for the Aldi University main campus. Winning consecutive bids for two high-quality projects has significantly enhanced the company's influence and competitiveness in international engineering contracting. It has established a solid foundation for further expansion in the Tanzanian market and has earned the company a reputable standing.

title: Capanda Green Ammonia Plant, Angola
body: Minbos Resources is poised to embark on the construction of a groundbreaking Green Ammonia Plant in Angola. This ambitious project, centered around the Capanda region, has garnered global attention as a highly promising endeavor in the realm of green ammonia production. The project's cornerstone lies in its commitment to carbon neutrality, achieved through innovative design that eschews traditional carbon-based materials like natural gas. Instead, the plant will harness green hydrogen generated via water electrolysis and nitrogen extracted from the air using advanced air separation technology. This combination will enable the production of green ammonia, a vital component in various end products. Crucially, the project will tap into 200 MW of hydroelectric power sourced from the Capanda hydroelectric dam, solidifying its commitment to sustainable energy practices. Through strategic partnerships and forward-thinking approaches, Monbos Resources aims to set a new standard for eco-friendly industrial operations while contributing to Angola's renewable energy transition.

Known collectively as Koruson 1, each wind farm will feature 26 state-of-the-art wind turbines, boasting a towering hub height of 124 meters and expansive blade lengths of 83 meters. This monumental undertaking holds the promise of harnessing the abundant wind resources of Middelburg, driving South Africa towards a greener, more sustainable future.

title: Mbeya University Main Campus, Tanzania
body: The Mbeya University of Science & Technology is planning the construction of its main campus in Mbeya, a city in southwestern Tanzania. The main construction elements will include an academic teaching building, a science and technology innovation center, and workshop facilities. This project, funded by the World Bank, represents the company's second successful bid in the Tanzanian market, following the construction project for the Aldi University main campus. Winning consecutive bids for two high-quality projects has significantly enhanced the company's influence and competitiveness in international engineering contracting. It has established a solid foundation for further expansion in the Tanzanian market and has earned the company a reputable standing.

title: Capanda Green Ammonia Plant, Angola
body: Minbos Resources is poised to embark on the construction of a groundbreaking Green Ammonia Plant in Angola. This ambitious project, centered around the Capanda region, has garnered global attention as a highly promising endeavor in the realm of green ammonia production. The project's cornerstone lies in its commitment to carbon neutrality, achieved through innovative design that eschews traditional carbon-based materials like natural gas. Instead, the plant will harness green hydrogen generated via water electrolysis and nitrogen extracted from the air using advanced air separation technology. This combination will enable the production of green ammonia, a vital component in various end products. Crucially, the project will tap into 200 MW of hydroelectric power sourced from the Capanda hydroelectric dam, solidifying its commitment to sustainable energy practices. Through strategic partnerships and forward-thinking approaches, Monbos Resources aims to set a new standard for eco-friendly industrial operations while contributing to Angola's renewable energy transition.

Additionally, outdoor roads, parking lots, greening, fences, and other supporting facilities will be included. The project is located in the central area of Gaborone, the capital of Botswana, with a total construction area of 11,262 square meters. Winning the bid for this project will further consolidate the company's market share in Botswana's housing market and play a positive role in the development of subsequent projects

title: Mbuji Mayi & Mbanga Road Project, DRC
body: The Ministry of Infrastructure, Public Works & Reconstruction in the Democratic Republic of Congo is planning to construct the No. 2 National Road, Section Mbuji Mayi (PK 0+000) – Mbanga (PK 280+975), to a bituminous standard. The project is divided into two lots and involves constructing a two-way asphalt concrete road with two lanes spanning a length of 280 km. Key components include the construction of a reinforced concrete bridge, excavation of trenches for laying optical cables, installation of solar-powered street lights, rehabilitation of boreholes along the road, anti-erosion measures, drainage works, and more. Upon completion, the project will significantly enhance traffic connectivity between the central regions and the capital, Kinshasa, and will spur economic development in the local area.

title: Mmadinare Solar Complex, Botswana
body: Scatec, a prominent player in the renewable energy sector, is set to embark on a transformative venture in Botswana with the construction of the Mmadinare Solar Complex. Having achieved financial close for the initial 60 megawatts (MW), this milestone signals the company's readiness to kickstart construction on Botswana's first utility-scale solar project. A pivotal collaboration with the Botswana Power Corporation (BPC) resulted in the finalization of a binding 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA) in August 2022, laying the groundwork for the establishment of a 60 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) facility in the Mmadinare District. Building on this momentum, Scatec secured an additional 60 MW expansion to the project in the third quarter of 2023, effectively doubling the total capacity to 120 MW. This ambitious initiative underscores Scatec's commitment to advancing sustainable energy solutions and fostering economic development in Botswana.

title: HySHiFT Sustainable Aviation Fuel Project, South Africa
body: The HySHiFT Consortium is poised to pioneer a groundbreaking renewable hydrogen endeavor in Mpumalanga, South Africa. Positioned among nine esteemed green hydrogen initiatives listed with Infrastructure South Africa under the Infrastructure Development Act, this ambitious project, unveiled on December 6, 2022, signifies a significant leap forward in sustainable energy endeavors. At its core, the HySHiFT project aims to revolutionize aviation fuel production by introducing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), or e-kerosene, into the market. Anchored by a 200 MW electrolyzer complemented by 450 MW of renewable electricity infrastructure, the consortium plans to harness electrolysis to produce hydrogen and oxygen from water. The resultant green hydrogen will be seamlessly integrated into Sasol's existing Fischer Tropsch facilities, paving the way for the production of approximately 50,000 tons per day of power-to-liquid (PTL) kerosene. With the potential to fuel up to two daily flights between Germany and South Africa, this initiative promises to redefine the landscape of sustainable aviation and renewable energy on a global scale.
