title: Mulilo Total Hydra Storage Project, South Africa
body: TotalEnergies, Hydra Storage Holding, and Reatile Renewables are collaborating on the Mulilo Total Hydra storage project in Northern Cape, South Africa. This initiative involves building a significant hybrid renewables facility, including a 216 MW solar plant and a 500 MWh battery storage system. The purpose of this project is to manage the intermittency of solar power production. Specifically, it will provide 75 MW of reliable power to Eskom, the state-owned power utility, continuously. This project is part of the Risk Mitigation Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme initiated by the Department of Mineral Resources and Energy. Its goal is to enhance electricity generation capacity and address the country's electricity supply challenges.

title: JER Hydrogen Solar PV Project, Mozambique
body: Connect Plus Energy and Jearrard Energy Resources (JER) are joining forces to develop the JER Mozambique Hydrogen Solar-to-Hydrogen facility in Inhambane, Mozambique, with a colossal capacity of 12,000 megawatts (MW). This innovative project is designed to generate over 4,000 tonnes of hydrogen per day. The JER Mozambique Hydrogen Solar PV Project encompasses a vast ground-mounted solar installation spanning 10,000 hectares. The produced hydrogen will be transported via a 125-kilometer pipeline to a new port at Morrumbene for export. In addition to the facility, the project includes infrastructure such as a pipeline and a new port, contributing significantly to green energy production. The implementation of solar plants equipped with electrolysers will play a crucial role in meeting the growing demand for sustainable energy.

title: Nacala Cement Plant Expansion, Mozambique
body: Cimentos de Moçambique S.A. is planning the Nacala Cement Plant Expansion Project in Mozambique. The main works involve alterations and additions to the existing cement plant currently in operation, including partial demolition of concrete structures, construction of new facilities, and modifications to existing ancillary facilities. These efforts aim to expand the current cement production line to one capable of producing 3000 tons of clinker cement daily.

title: Steenbras Hydro Pump Station, South Africa
body: The City of Cape Town is constructing the Steenbras Hydro Pump Station (SHPS) in Cape Town, South Africa, as a critical infrastructure project. The SHPS will consist of four turbines with a combined capacity of 180 megawatts, serving as a hydroelectric power generation facility. The SHPS plays a crucial role in the city's electricity management strategy. During periods of high electricity demand, particularly during the day, the SHPS generates electricity by harnessing the potential energy of water. This process involves channeling water from the Upper Steenbras Dam to the Lower Steenbras Dam through its turbines. As the water flows through the turbines, its potential energy is converted into electrical energy, contributing to meeting the city's power requirements.

title: The Princess Mkabayi Mall, South Africa
body: Moolman Group, Twin City, JB Holdings, and Green Giraffe are collaborating on the development of Princess Mkabayi Mali in Vryheid, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. This expansive project features a single-level regional mall spanning 30,000m2, serving as a key component within a comprehensive mixed-use development. The larger vision for this project includes plans for an office park, a hotel and casino, as well as residential apartments. Positioned on a prime and easily accessible 23-hectare site, the development is poised to become the largest consolidated retail offering within a nearly 100-kilometer radius. The project's scope extends beyond retail, contributing to a broader mixed-use landscape in the region.

title: Kabuhanga - Muhato Road Upgrade Works, Rwanda
body: The Rwanda Transport Development Agency (RTDA) is planning to upgrade a network of roads spanning 81.7 kilometers across provinces and districts. These roads include the north-western lot located in Musanze, Rubavu, and Nyabihu districts, which are further divided into three sections: 1 Kabuhanga-Bugarama-Kiraro: This section measures 10.7 kilometers in length. 2 Kinigi-Kabuhanga: This section spans 48.4 kilometers. 3 Kabuhanga-Busasamana-Cyanzarwe-Muhato: This section covers a distance of 22.6 kilometers. Currently, the road running from Rubavu to Kabuhanga is in poor condition and requires rehabilitation. Despite the high agricultural production in this area, inadequate road networks hinder the transportation of produce to markets within the country and across borders. The planned road upgrades aim to address this issue and improve connectivity for the benefit of local communities and the economy.

title: Lotsane Solar Project, Botswana
body: Solarcentury Africa and ENRC have joined forces to co-develop the Lotsane Solar project in Botswana. Situated in Palapye, adjacent to the Morupule Coal Mine, the project has obtained its electricity generation license from the Botswana Energy Regulatory Authority (BERA) and has completed its grid impact assessment with the Botswana Power Corporation (BPC). This strategic partnership aims to construct a 100 MW solar project, marking a significant step towards advancing renewable energy infrastructure in Botswana. With these essential approvals secured, the project is poised to advance to the next phases of development, contributing to Botswana's sustainable energy goals and fostering environmental stewardship.

title: Nyacyonga - Mukoto Road, Rwanda
body: The Rwanda Transport Development Agency (RTDA) is planning to construct the Nyacyonga - Mukoto road, with funding support from the Rwandan government and the OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID). This 36-kilometer road will serve as a crucial link between two important paved roads connecting Kigali city to the Northern Province.Starting at the Kigali-Gatuna junction in Gasabo District, the road will extend to Rulindo District at the Kigali-Musanze road junction. The construction of this road is expected to have a significant impact by reducing traffic congestion, particularly along the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

title: Douala Water Distribution Network, Cameroon
body: The Cameroon Water Utilities Corporation (Camwater) is planning to execute the Douala Drinking Water Project in Cameroon. This project seeks to improve the supply of drinking water to Douala and its adjacent regions, by generating an extra 400,000 cubic meters of potable water daily and taking the city's overall treated water production capacity to 703,400 cubic meters per day. The scope of work includes new raw water pumping stations on the Wouri river, and extension of primary, secondary and tertiary networks. Storage facilities will also be upgrade and new connections to the water network will be provided.

title: Lafia Highway & Lagos Ibadan Road, Nigeria
body: The Federal Government of Nigeria is currently undertaking several road construction projects, including the Second Niger Bridge bypasses, Lafia highway, and the Lagos-Ibadan road. This particular project spans 260 kilometers, of which 229 kilometers have already been completed. However, some sections still require attention, prompting instructions for additional work, particularly in the first five kilometers. Previously, the journey from Abuja to Makurdi took approximately four and a half hours, but with the completion of this new road, the travel time is expected to reduce to three hours. This improvement in transportation infrastructure is anticipated to benefit businesses and facilitate better planning for travel along this route.The 260-kilometer project traverses through various regions, including the Federal Capital Territory, Nasarawa, Benue, and Enugu states.

title: Kenya-Tanzania Inter-connectivity Project, Kenya
body: The Tanzania Electricity Supply Company (Tanesco) is currently engaged in the construction of a significant energy infrastructure initiative known as the 2GW Kenya-Tanzania Inter-connectivity Project. This project involves the construction of a 400 kilovolt power line spanning approximately 510 kilometers, with 414 kilometers situated within Tanzania and the remaining 96 kilometers crossing into Kenya. The inter-connectivity project aims to enhance the transmission capacity between the two countries, facilitating the exchange of up to 2,000 megawatts of electric power. Located in the Lemugur area of the Arusha region, this initiative underscores Tanzania's commitment to expanding its energy infrastructure and fostering regional cooperation in the field of electricity supply.

title: Tema Motorway - Nsawam & Dzorwulu Roads: Phase 1, Ghana
body: The Ghana Highway Authority (G.H.A) is spearheading an ambitious project aimed at rehabilitating and expanding the Accra-Tema motorway, spanning 19.5 kilometers and featuring a minimum of 10 lanes. This comprehensive endeavor encompasses several key components, including the reconstruction of pivotal interchanges such as the Tetteh Quarshie, Teshie link, and Community 18-foot interchanges. Additionally, critical infrastructure enhancements like the Lashibi interchange, the establishment of eight toll booth plazas, and the construction of 10 new footbridges are integral parts of the plan. The overarching objective of this initiative is to significantly improve road traffic flow within the Tema and Lagos areas, thereby enhancing transportation infrastructure and connectivity throughout the region. Upon completion, this phase of the project will lead to the substantial improvement of 27.7 kilometers of road, marking a significant milestone in Ghana's efforts to bolster its transportation network and support economic growth.

title: Sasol and Air Liquide Renewable-Energy Project, South Africa
body: Sasol|Air Liquide is moving forward with plans to construct a large-scale renewable energy project in collaboration with Air Liquide, set to be located in Kouga municipality and Oyster Bay. The project's scope involves a joint effort between the two companies to procure 900 MW of renewable energy capacity from independent power producers (IPPs) by the year 2030. In the initial phase of procurement, Air Liquide will secure 400 MW, while Sasol will secure 200 MW. Each project within this initiative is required to have a generation capacity of at least 70 MW, ensuring that they collectively generate around 200 gigawatt-hours per year (GWh/y) of electricity. This ambitious endeavor signifies Sasol's commitment to sustainability and transitioning towards renewable energy sources.

title: Goromonzi Lithium Plant: Phase 2, Zimbabwe
body: The Government of Zimbabwe is currently undertaking the construction of a Lithium Plant in Goromonzi, Zimbabwe. This project represents a significant investment in the region's mineral resources and aims to capitalize on the country's abundant lithium deposits.In the second stage of the project, the plant is expected to have a daily processing capacity of about 1,500 tonnes of lithium. This increased capacity will enable the plant to meet growing demand for lithium, a critical component in the production of batteries for various applications, including electric vehicles and renewable energy storage systems.

title: Ekiti Knowledge Zone (EKZ), Nigeria
body: The Ekiti State Government is embarking on the development of the Ekiti Knowledge Zone Project (EKZ) in Nigeria, situated between Ago Araromi in Ado Local Government and Ijan Ekiti in Gbonyin Local Government. This transformative initiative involves the establishment of world-class infrastructure, including a 20-hectare green technology park, alongside essential amenities such as roads, electricity, water supply, and wastewater treatment facilities. Spanning 40 hectares, the EKZ aims to serve as a hub for digital entrepreneurship, attracting a diverse range of businesses including tech start-ups, business process outsourcing firms, fabrication and production companies, research institutes, and corporate back-office operations. To support budding entrepreneurs, an incubator program will offer pre-seed and seed funding through the Ekiti Innovation Fund. Additionally, the project will facilitate the formation of a special-purpose vehicle comprising anchor investors from the private sector, enabling multiple investors to pool financing and jointly manage the operations of the Zone.

title: 200 MW Wind Farm, Zimbabwe
body: Optate Africa intends to construct a 200MW wind power plant in close proximity to the town of Plumtree in the southwestern region of the country. This initiative marks a noteworthy stride in augmenting Zimbabwe's renewable energy capacity, aligning with objectives related to energy security and environmental sustainability. Despite economic challenges, such as elevated inflation, currently impeding progress, Zimbabwe's National Renewable Energy Policy has set a target to generate 1.1GW of renewable energy by 2025, constituting 16.5% of the overall capacity.

title: Dongo Kundu SEZ Berth Construction, Kenya
body: The Kenya Ports Authority (KPA) is set to undertake the development of the Dongo Kundu SEZ berth in Mombasa, Kenya, adopting a public-private partnership framework. This initiative is part of the broader objective to establish a free trade zone in the region. The first phase of the Dongo Kundu Berth will span 300 meters in length and have a depth of minus 15 meters.Situated on a vast 3,000-acre expanse, the Dongo Kundu SEZ is a multifaceted project encompassing diverse components such as a free port, industrial parks, free trade zones, logistics and warehousing facilities, energy project areas, as well as spaces dedicated to tourism and MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions). The comprehensive development plan underscores the ambition to create a dynamic economic hub, fostering trade, industry, and various other sectors. The incorporation of a public-private partnership model signifies a collaborative approach to realizing the potential of the Dongo Kundu SEZ for the benefit of both the public and private sectors.

title: Anglo American Platinum Amandelbul Solar Photovoltaic, South Africa
body: Anglo American Platinum is poised to spearhead a monumental transition towards renewable energy with its ambitious plan to construct a 125 MW solar photovoltaic initiative at the Amandelbult Complex. This initiative aligns with South Africa's broader push towards sustainability, as evidenced by the country's investment in three renewable energy projects. By embracing renewable energy solutions, South Africa underscores its dedication to creating a greener future and ensuring the well-being of future generations. The Anglo American Platinum project at Amandelbult Complex stands as a beacon of progress in this journey towards a more sustainable and environmentally conscious society.

title: GRA Regeneration Ogun, Nigeria
body: The Government of Ogun State is embarking on a significant endeavor to construct modern housing units in key cities such as Abeokuta, Ijebu-Ode, and Ota. This ambitious project spans over 100 hectares of land and aims to revitalize urban areas by replacing deteriorating structures with contemporary housing facilities. The initiative is part of a broader urban development plan aimed at enhancing the quality of life for residents while addressing housing challenges in the region. By introducing modern infrastructure and amenities, the government seeks to create sustainable communities that promote comfort, safety, and well-being for all residents.

title: New Mbamba Bay Port Upgrade, Tanzania
body: The Tanzania Port Authority (TPA) has commenced construction work on the Mbamba Bay Port, a significant project situated on Tanzania’s Lake Nyasa in the Ruvuma region. This development marks the beginning of an eagerly awaited initiative that is expected to bring numerous benefits to the local community. As the Mbamba Bay Port project progresses, residents of the Nyasa District, Ruvuma Region, and surrounding areas stand to gain employment opportunities, thereby enhancing livelihoods in the region. Furthermore, the port's completion is anticipated to stimulate an increase in cargo volume and passenger numbers, fostering economic growth and development in the area.

title: Crossroads-Kanengo Dual Carriageway, Malawi
body: Malawi's Ministry of Transport and Public Works is constructing the 10-kilometer Crossroads-Kanengo Dual Carriageway. This project aims to transform the existing road into a dual carriageway, enhancing transportation efficiency and safety. The dual carriageway will consist of two lanes, each spanning a width of 3.4 meters. In addition to the vehicular lanes, the project includes the incorporation of a dedicated cycle track, measuring 1.5 meters in width, to promote sustainable and alternative modes of transportation. Furthermore, a pedestrian track, also 1.5 meters wide, will be integrated, ensuring the safety and convenience of pedestrians along the route. This development aligns with the Ministry's commitment to modernizing and expanding the transportation network in Lilongwe, fostering better connectivity and accessibility.

title: Garden Walk Shopping Centre, South Africa
body: Moolman Group, in partnership with Neotrend and Dorpstraat, is undertaking the development of the Garden Walk Shopping Centre in the picturesque coastal town of Hartenbos, South Africa. Situated in the northern area of Hartenbos, the site benefits from a strategic location adjacent to the N2 highway, ensuring convenient access to nearby destinations such as George to the north and Mosselbay to the south via the R102 and Monte Christo Road. With approximately 20,000m² of retail space, the project promises to deliver a prominent and easily accessible shopping destination in the region.

title: Barra Do Dande Ocean Terminal (TOBD), Angola
body: The Sonangol plans to construct a Ocean Terminal at Luanda, in Angola. The project scope encompasses Barra do Dande Ocean Terminal is poised to become the largest storage terminal in Angola, spanning an area equivalent to 22 soccer fields. The project is underway to safeguard strategic reserves, comprising 580,000 m3 of liquid fuels such as gasoline and diesel oil, alongside 102,000 m3 of liquefied petroleum gas. This initiative is pivotal for bolstering the country's trade balance. Key components of the project entail the finalization of a refined-products storage park, the construction of a ship dock, and essential infrastructure enhancements aimed at expanding the country's capacity for importing, exporting, and storing petroleum products.

title: John Davies Town-Zwedru Road, Liberia
body: The Ministry of Public Works (Liberia) is set to undertake the development of the John Davies Town-Zwedru Road project in Liberia. Spanning a distance of 48.5 kilometers, this initiative is integral to the fourth phase of the Mano River Union Road Construction Facility, a multinational effort aimed at enhancing transportation infrastructure in both Liberia and Sierra Leone. The road project plays a crucial role within the Ganta-Harper Road corridor, contributing to regional connectivity and development.

title: National Highway (N1) Rehabilitation: Phase 1, Mozambique
body: Ministry of Public Works, Housing, and Water Resources (MOPHRH) of Mozambique is set to undertake the rehabilitation project for Phase 1 of the country's national highway N1. This initiative will encompass a total distance of 508 km, spanning across the following sections: Inchope - Gorongosa, Gorongosa - Caia, Chimuara - Nicoadala, and Metoro - Pemba. The project primarily involves addressing critical issues such as hole plugging and resealing on the identified stretches.

title: Polihali Dam and Transfer Tunnel
body: The Lesotho Highlands Development Authority (LHDA) is undertaking the ambitious construction of the Polihali Dam and the Polihali Transfer Tunnel in Mokhotlong. This project entails the creation of a 38-kilometer-long tunnel, with a nominal bore of five meters, connecting the Polihali reservoir to the Katse reservoir. Additionally, it involves the construction of intake works and gate shafts at the Polihali reservoir, outlet works and gate shafts at the existing Katse reservoir, and access adits to the waterway, along with associated construction infrastructure. As part of Phase II of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project, this initiative represents a significant investment in infrastructure to facilitate the transfer of water between the two reservoirs, laying the groundwork for the dam and tunnel construction to follow.

title: National Route 2 Section 7 Upgrade, South Africa

This initiative is situated in the Western Cape province within the district municipality of the Garden Route.

title: Umoyilanga Avondale Solar Project, South Africa
body: EDF Renewables and Perpetua Holdings are set to develop a groundbreaking Solar Park in Northern Cape, South Africa. The project will integrate 115 MW of solar PV capacity with 30 MW of battery storage. This innovative venture aims to combine solar energy and battery storage technologies, ensuring reliable and dispatchable power for the national electrical grid.

title: Koru - Soin Dam, Kenya
body: The Government of Kenya is planning to construct the Soin-Koru Dam near Muhoroni town, spanning the Nyando River. This multipurpose project is proposed to address flooding issues in the lower reaches of the Nyando River while offering various benefits to the region.The dam will have a dual purpose: to provide flood control and support agricultural activities. With a capacity to irrigate approximately 2,570 hectares of land, it will enhance agricultural productivity in the area, potentially boosting food security and economic growth. Additionally, the dam will generate 2.5 megawatts (MW) of hydroelectric power, contributing to the region's energy needs with clean and renewable energy. By harnessing the power of the Nyando River, the Soin-Koru Dam project aims to mitigate the adverse effects of flooding, promote sustainable agriculture, and address energy demands through environmentally friendly means. It represents a significant step toward integrated water resource management and sustainable development in the region.

title: Lynnwood Road Upgrade, South Africa
body: The City of Tshwane Roads and Transport is set to embark on the Lynnwood Road Widening Project in Mamelodi, stretching from January Masilela to Simon Vermooten Road. A significant aspect of this initiative is the development of a non-motorized transport access spanning a total of 12km. The key features of the project include the construction of two new 3.4 km x 3.5m wide median Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) lanes (one in each direction) dedicated to Line 2C on Lynnwood Road. Additionally, the project entails the establishment of new Non-Motorized Transport (NMT) pedestrian sidewalks and cycle paths, covering the segment between January Masilela and Simon Vermooten Road. Landscaping activities for median islands and adjacent road reserves are also part of the project. The comprehensive scope of work involves a diverse set of tasks, including site setup and preparation, clearing construction sites, implementing traffic management strategies, upgrading infrastructure, installing service ducts, performing excavation and earth-moving operations, enhancing drainage systems, constructing culverts, installing kerbs and asphalt pavement, placing guardrails and signage, as well as upgrading electrical systems.

title: Kenhardt 5 Solar PV Park, South Africa
body: The Kenhardt Solar PV 5 Project is underway to construct the Kenhardt 5 Solar PV Park, a significant 115MW solar PV power project located in the Northern Cape, South Africa. This ground-mounted solar project is poised to contribute substantially to the region's renewable energy capacity. Currently being developed and owned by the Kenhardt Solar PV 5 Project, the solar park is wholly owned by the project entity, reflecting a commitment to harnessing solar energy as a sustainable power source for the region. As construction progresses, the Kenhardt 5 Solar PV Park is expected to play a vital role in bolstering South Africa's renewable energy infrastructure and advancing its clean energy objectives.

body: National Housing and Construction Company Limited has planned the Bugolobi Apartments in Kampala, Uganda. The Project comprises of 100 units in two (2) blocks of ten (15) level apartments, with associated amenities such as access roads, driveways and parking areas on a 1.117-acre site. The housing estate will be a gated condominium community with the attendant infrastructure services-roads, water, drainage, electrical connections and sewage treatment – and will have a paved parking area.

title: Koysha Hydroelectric Power Project, Ethiopia
body: Ethiopian Electric Power (EEP) is poised to undertake the development of the Koysha hydroelectric project, situated in the southwest region of Ethiopia. Positioned as the fourth in a series of dams along the Omo River, this project is designed to have an installed capacity of 2,160 MW. It is expected to make a significant contribution to Ethiopia's energy production, complementing other major projects such as Gilgel Gibe I, Gilgel Gibe II, and the Gibe III hydroelectric project.

title: Rumphi - Nyika - Chitipa Road, Malawi
body: The Roads Authority Malawi (RA) has announced plans to construction of the the Rumphi - Nyika - Chitipa Road, spanning 241 km. This project will enhance two main roads: the M24 road from Rumphi District to Nyika and the M09 road from Nyika to Chitipa. Currently an earth road, it will be upgraded to a bitumen Class 1 standard. It will also ease transportation of people and agricultural and other goods in the area and also providing a link to access other markets in the North, Centre and South of Malawi. The road is close to the  boarder of the Eastern Province of Zambia and will open economic activities between the two countries.The project will ensure that the country develops beyond recognition. It will also facilitate the country’s economic development as well as improving transportation network in the area.The project once complete will transform the status of the people in Rumphi and Chitipa. It will also give people access to better markets for their products at the same time creating employment opportunities during the construction period.

title: Salvokop Precinct, South Africa
body:
Department of Public Works and Infrastructure (DPWI) is constructing the Salvokop government district in South Africa, located in Tshwane. Its is a groundbreaking project aiming to create a mixed-use precinct with government offices, businesses, schools, healthcare facilities, and residences. It's divided into three phases: Phase 1 focuses on infrastructure and PPP Head Office Buildings, Phase 2 on private sector business development, and Phase 3 on mixed-income housing. This project showcases DPWI's commitment to modern, integrated urban environments. Through phased development, it ensures efficiency and long-term sustainability, contributing to the region's socio-economic progress.

  • Total Area: 524,000 square metres
  • Development Type: Government offices, commercial and residential buildings
  • Phasing: 3 Phases
  • Delivery Model: Public-Private Partnership (PPP) and private sector participation

Project Description

This project involves the development of a large mixed-use government precinct that will house key South African government departments alongside commercial and residential components. Spread over 524,000 square metres, the development is intended to centralize public services, stimulate urban regeneration, and provide mixed-income housing in a single integrated environment.

The project is set to unfold in three phases, combining government-led development with private sector investment. The initial phase focuses on delivering four major government head office buildings, followed by private sector-led commercial development and a mixed-income residential component.

Government Headquarters

  • Department of Social Development (DSD)
    • Area: 30,361 m²
    • Parking: 867 bays
  • South African Social Security Agency (SASSA)
    • Area: 27,808 m²
    • Parking: 650 bays
  • National Development Agency (NDA)
    • Area: 2,087 m²
    • Parking: 75 bays
  • Department of Dwelling Affairs
  • Department of Correctional Companies and Constitutional Improvement
  • Department of Higher Education and Training

Scope of Work

  • Phase 1A & 1B:
    • Installation of bulk and internal infrastructure services (roads, water, electricity, ICT)
    • Construction of four PPP head office buildings for key government departments
  • Phase 2:
    • Development of business erven (plots) by the private sector for commercial use
    • Includes office spaces, retail, and support services
  • Phase 3:
    • Development of a mixed-income residential component
    • Housing aimed at accommodating a range of income levels
    • Associated social infrastructure and public spaces

title: Carnival City Lifestyle Estate Residential Development: Phase 1, South Africa
body: Livres and Sun International are in the process of planning the construction of the Carnival City Casino complex. This development will span over 50 hectares, offering secure mixed-use living. It is designed to accommodate over 3,000 new homes along with various recreational amenities, all interconnected by a network of green walking and cycling trails. The estate will include an office component, a private school, a park area, a 10,000 square meter neighborhood market, and a village-style retail center. East Village will be the first phase of the estate, offering 30 affordable residential units, with one- and two-bedroom apartment units – from 39 m2 to 72 m2 – in a series of three-storey apartment blocks.

body: SANY Southern Africa is set to establish its headquarters in Johannesburg, South Africa, featuring a comprehensive campus designed to accommodate SANY SA employees and facilitate three key operations: manufacturing, logistics, and training. Positioned as SANY's central hub in southern Africa, the state-of-the-art facility will encompass a 12,500 m2 floor area, incorporating a 9,500 m2 assembly plant and a 2,300 m2 administration building. title: Chiringa - Muloza Road Project, Malawi
body: Roads Authority Malawi (RA) is currently undertaking the construction of the Chiringa - Muloza road, a significant infrastructure initiative aimed at enhancing connectivity along vital trade routes. This road project begins at Chiringa and extends southward along the eastern base of the Mulanje Massif, closely following the established T415 road alignment. As the project advances, the road traverses several rivers and streams before reaching its endpoint at Muloza, near the Mozambique border post, where it intersects with the M2 road.

title: Clanwilliam Dam, South Africa
body: The Department of Water and Sanitation is set to undertake a significant infrastructure development project at Clanwilliam Dam in the Western Cape, South Africa. This venture represents one of the largest government investments in the region. The project entails raising the dam wall by 13 meters, a crucial step to enhance water capacity. The primary goals include supporting disadvantaged farmers, promoting food security, and generating decent employment opportunities through inclusive economic growth. Presently, the dam yields approximately 123 million cubic meters of water, with expectations that upon project completion, this capacity will increase to 343 million cubic meters.

title: Lobito Corridor
body:
Transport Ministry of Angola is poised to launch the Lobito Corridor Project with the goal of bolstering domestic and cross-border trade, and facilitating value chain development along the Lobito Corridor. This corridor encompasses a 1,340 km railway line traversing Angola from the Atlantic Ocean to the nation's borders with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Zambia. Moreover, the railway line extends an additional 400 km into the DRC, reaching the mining town of Kolwezi.

Also known as Lobito Atlantic Railway, and Lobito–Luau Railway Upgrade Project. 

Project Overview:

  • Length: Approximately 1,344 kilometers
  • Route: From Lobito Port on the Atlantic coast in Angola to Luau near the borders with DRC and Zambia.
  • Corridor Link: This line forms part of the Lobito Corridor, a key regional transport route linking central and southern Africa to international markets via Lobito Port.

Scope of Work:

  • Rehabilitation and modernization of existing railway infrastructure.
  • Track upgrades for improved safety, speed, and cargo handling.
  • Modernization of stations, bridges, and signaling systems.
  • Enhanced logistics and freight facilities to increase export and import efficiency.

title: Southern Electricity Grid Expansion, Ethopia
body:
Objective: Strengthen and expand the Southern Electric Grid to enhance electricity access, reliability, and capacity in Southern Ethiopia.

Scope of Work

Transmission Line Construction (Approx. 420 km total)

  • 230 kV Wolaita Sodo – Shigdan Line
  • 230 kV Shigdan – Arba Minch Line (93 km)
  • 132 kV Shigdan – Tirga Line
  • 132 kV Arba Minch 2 – Arba Minch 1 Line (10.6 km)

Substations

New Substation Construction

  • 230 kV Substations:
    • Shigdan
    • Arba Minch (Arba Minch 2)
  • 132 kV Substation:
    • Tirga

Substation Upgrades and Expansion

  • Wolaita Sodo 2 Substation
  • Arba Minch 1 Substation

title: Dar es Salaam Bus Rapid Transit Infrastructure: Phase 5, Tanzania
body: Tanzania National Roads Agency (TANROADS) is set to embark on the development of Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) infrastructure in Phase 5 within Dar es Salaam, known as the BRT Phase V project in Tanzania. This comprehensive initiative involves the creation of two trunk corridors, totaling 25.6 km in length, and includes the construction of Mandela and Mabagala roads (16.5 km) with 23 stations, as well as the construction of Tabata Kigogo road (9.9 km) with 13 stations. The project has dual objectives. Firstly, it aims to ensure inter-modality between the BRT and other modes of transport, achieved through the construction of 7 feeder stations and the commissioning of 6 feeder routes. Secondly, the project focuses on enhancing the Port Access Road with a 3 km extension, aligned with the BRT corridor on Mandela Road. The overall development will be divided into two lots to facilitate effective implementation.

Additionally, it includes the construction of associated border facilities to facilitate smoother transportation and trade activities at the border.

title: Katine - Ochero Road Upgrade, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is set to undertake the upgrading of the Katine-Ochero Road, spanning a length of 69.3 kilometers, inclusive of the construction of town roads in Kaberamaido and Kalaki towns, to bituminous standard. This road improvement initiative aims to connect the districts of Soroti and Kaberamaido and involves the construction of a 69.3km lane roadway, incorporating earthworks, pavement, and drainage works.The Katine-Ochero Road originates approximately 20 km north of Soroti town on the Soroti-Lira Road near Katine trading center. It concludes after 69.3 km in Ochero at the junction with the Dokolo/Lira Road. The current state of the road is classified as a Class C Gravel Road, spanning an altitude ranging between 1030m and 1090m above sea level. The road traverses the northern area of Kyoga Lake, intersecting the lake's catchment basins, with no major river crossings along its route.The pavement structure for the Katine-Ochero road includes a 27.5 cm or 17.5 cm gravel sub-base (for Subgrade 53 and 54, respectively), a 17.5 cm thick granular base course, and a 5 cm thick asphalt concrete. The planned upgrade aims to enhance the road to bituminous standards, facilitating improved connectivity and transportation between the specified districts.

title: Dar Es Salaam Bus Rapid Transit Infrastructure: Phase 4, Tanzania
body: Tanzania National Roads Agency (TANROADS) is set to initiate the construction of Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) infrastructure in Phase 4 within Dar es Salaam, known as the BRT Phase IV project. This project is designed to span from Kivukoni to Tegeta via the Bagamoyo Road in the city. Covering a distance of 30.1 kilometers, Phase Four extends from Kivukoni to Boko through Ali Hassan Mwinyi and Bagamoyo Road. Additionally, the project encompasses an extension to the Mwenge branch, connecting to Ubungo Simu 2000 via Sam Nujoma Road.

title: Vaccine Manufacturing Plant, Ethiopia
body: ShieldVax Enterprise is planning to stimulate local vaccine production for both domestic consumption and export within Ethiopia's Kilinto Industrial Park near Addis Ababa, with an investment exceeding 70 million U.S. dollars. Established by the Council of Ministers in July 2023, the project aims to bolster Ethiopia's health system and enhance local vaccine manufacturing capacity, a top priority in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. This initiative underscores Ethiopia's commitment to strengthening its healthcare infrastructure and achieving self-reliance in vaccine production.

body: Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) has outlined plans to improve rural transport connectivity in the districts of Hamurwa, Kerere, Kanungu, Buleme, Buhoma, Butogota, Hamayanja, Ifasha, and Ikumba. This initiative spans a total distance of 149.0 kilometers and is geared towards enhancing transportation access in these regions. Through the enhancement of road infrastructure, UNRA aims to streamline the movement of goods and people, fostering greater opportunities for internal and cross-border trade.

title: Magunje Cement Plant, Zimbabwe
body: Labenmon Investments and West International Holding have joined forces to embark on the construction of the Magunje cement plant in Mashonaland West. This envisioned industrial park will host a cutting-edge dry-process clinker cement production line boasting an annual capacity of 2.7 million tons, complemented by a 100 MW power generation unit. Additionally, the project includes a cement grinding station with an annual capacity of 900,000 tons. The development will unfold in two concurrent phases, with construction taking place simultaneously. The initiative also involves the establishment of a new building materials industrial park in Karoi, aligned with the overarching themes of 'intelligence, environmental protection, green, and technology.'

title: Shongweni Park Lifestyle Estate, South Africa
body: Baldwin Properties is set to develop the Shongweni Park Lifestyle Estate in South Africa, which will include 1,260 apartments spread across 20 phases. title: Clanwilliam Dam, South Africa
body: The Department of Water and Sanitation is set to undertake a significant infrastructure development project at Clanwilliam Dam in the Western Cape, South Africa. This venture represents one of the largest government investments in the region. The project entails raising the dam wall by 13 meters, a crucial step to enhance water capacity. The primary goals include supporting disadvantaged farmers, promoting food security, and generating decent employment opportunities through inclusive economic growth. Presently, the dam yields approximately 123 million cubic meters of water, with expectations that upon project completion, this capacity will increase to 343 million cubic meters.

title: Lobito Corridor
body:
Transport Ministry of Angola is poised to launch the Lobito Corridor Project with the goal of bolstering domestic and cross-border trade, and facilitating value chain development along the Lobito Corridor. This corridor encompasses a 1,340 km railway line traversing Angola from the Atlantic Ocean to the nation's borders with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Zambia. Moreover, the railway line extends an additional 400 km into the DRC, reaching the mining town of Kolwezi.

Also known as Lobito Atlantic Railway, and Lobito–Luau Railway Upgrade Project. 

Project Overview:

  • Length: Approximately 1,344 kilometers
  • Route: From Lobito Port on the Atlantic coast in Angola to Luau near the borders with DRC and Zambia.
  • Corridor Link: This line forms part of the Lobito Corridor, a key regional transport route linking central and southern Africa to international markets via Lobito Port.

Scope of Work:

  • Rehabilitation and modernization of existing railway infrastructure.
  • Track upgrades for improved safety, speed, and cargo handling.
  • Modernization of stations, bridges, and signaling systems.
  • Enhanced logistics and freight facilities to increase export and import efficiency.

title: Southern Electricity Grid Expansion, Ethopia
body:
Objective: Strengthen and expand the Southern Electric Grid to enhance electricity access, reliability, and capacity in Southern Ethiopia.

Scope of Work

Transmission Line Construction (Approx. 420 km total)

  • 230 kV Wolaita Sodo – Shigdan Line
  • 230 kV Shigdan – Arba Minch Line (93 km)
  • 132 kV Shigdan – Tirga Line
  • 132 kV Arba Minch 2 – Arba Minch 1 Line (10.6 km)

Substations

New Substation Construction

  • 230 kV Substations:
    • Shigdan
    • Arba Minch (Arba Minch 2)
  • 132 kV Substation:
    • Tirga

Substation Upgrades and Expansion

  • Wolaita Sodo 2 Substation
  • Arba Minch 1 Substation

title: Dar es Salaam Bus Rapid Transit Infrastructure: Phase 5, Tanzania
body: Tanzania National Roads Agency (TANROADS) is set to embark on the development of Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) infrastructure in Phase 5 within Dar es Salaam, known as the BRT Phase V project in Tanzania. This comprehensive initiative involves the creation of two trunk corridors, totaling 25.6 km in length, and includes the construction of Mandela and Mabagala roads (16.5 km) with 23 stations, as well as the construction of Tabata Kigogo road (9.9 km) with 13 stations. The project has dual objectives. Firstly, it aims to ensure inter-modality between the BRT and other modes of transport, achieved through the construction of 7 feeder stations and the commissioning of 6 feeder routes. Secondly, the project focuses on enhancing the Port Access Road with a 3 km extension, aligned with the BRT corridor on Mandela Road. The overall development will be divided into two lots to facilitate effective implementation.

title: Magunje Cement Plant, Zimbabwe
body: Labenmon Investments and West International Holding have joined forces to embark on the construction of the Magunje cement plant in Mashonaland West. This envisioned industrial park will host a cutting-edge dry-process clinker cement production line boasting an annual capacity of 2.7 million tons, complemented by a 100 MW power generation unit. Additionally, the project includes a cement grinding station with an annual capacity of 900,000 tons. The development will unfold in two concurrent phases, with construction taking place simultaneously. The initiative also involves the establishment of a new building materials industrial park in Karoi, aligned with the overarching themes of 'intelligence, environmental protection, green, and technology.'

title: Welisizwe Rural Bridges Project, South Africa
body: Department of Public Works and Infrastructure (DPWI) is planning the Welisizwe Bridges project, a government initiative aimed at addressing the backlog of bridge infrastructure in rural and disadvantaged communities. These bridges will enhance communities' access to health facilities, schools, and economic amenities, thereby improving overall accessibility and connectivity in these areas.

title: Nacala Road Corridor Development Project, Mozambique
body: The Nacala Corridor project aims to create a cost-effective route for imports and exports from Malawi, Zambia, and western Mozambique to the sea. The project consists of four phases, involving the construction or rehabilitation of over 900 km of roads in the three countries.Phase 1, approved in 2009, includes a 348 km road component in Mozambique and a 13 km bypass in Malawi. Phase 2 encompasses 360 km of roadworks in Zambia, from Laungwa to Mwami. Phase 3 involves 160 km of roadworks in Mozambique and 152 km in Malawi, along with the construction of two one-stop border posts.Phase 4 will focus on rehabilitating a 75 km road segment between Liwonde and Mangochi and establishing one-stop border posts at Chiponde and Mchinji along the Malawi–Mozambique and Malawi–Zambia borders, respectively. Once completed, the Nacala Corridor is expected to significantly improve transportation infrastructure and facilitate trade in the region.

title: First Electric Light Rail Transportation System, Ghana
body: The Ghanaian government plans to construct and launch its first electric rail system connecting Takoradi Port to Kumasi. This initiative aims to reduce traffic congestion in the region. The project involves implementing a tram system, also known as an electric rail system, which is a sophisticated mode of transportation commonly found in Europe. This modern transportation infrastructure is expected to enhance connectivity and efficiency in Ghana's transportation network, offering an alternative and sustainable means of travel between Takoradi Port and Kumasi.

title: Thwake Multipurpose Dam, Kenya
body:
The Thwake Multipurpose Dam is being planned by the Tanathi Water Services Board (TAWSB). This ambitious project involves harnessing the fluctuating flows of the Athi River and the seasonal water from the Thwake River. Phase one, covers 87m-high dam wall with 688 million cubic metres storage capacity, and preliminary works for the implementation of the subsequent three phases.

The second phase of Thwake Multi-Purpose Dam project will involve installation of a hydropower generation plant, while phase three comprises the installation of water supply, sanitation, and waste water infrastructure.

The fourth phase will involve the development of the irrigation component.

title: Trans - Sahara Highway Project: Phase 2, Mali
body: The Direction Nationale des Routes has proposed plans for the construction of the Bourem-Kidal Section, an integral part of Mali's segment of the Trans-Sahara Highway (TSH). This infrastructure holds significant importance across economic, social, political, and security dimensions for the continent. Phase 2 of the TSH Project focuses specifically on the Bourem-Kidal section, spanning 285.83km, with implementation anticipated to address critical issues such as peace, security, economic and social development, and regional stability. Malian authorities perceive the project as instrumental in promoting national unity, peace, and social cohesion. By improving access to the Kidal region, it aims to bolster the pacification process in Northern Mali and foster increased trade activities both within Mali and with Algeria. Additionally, the project serves as a strategic response to the imbalanced regional development criticized by armed movements in Northern Mali, crucial for enhancing national unity and reducing development inequalities across the Liptako-Gourma sub-region and beyond.

title: Ulesh Ikoyi Mixed-Use Development, Nigeria
body:
Misa Limited is developing a mixed-use project called Ulesh Ikoyi at 47a Glover Road, Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria. This 15-floor development features a versatile design with six floors dedicated to parking, seven floors for commercial use, and two floors for residential purposes. The project exemplifies a holistic approach to urban development, integrating parking convenience, commercial activities, and residential spaces within a single structure.

Upon completion, the development will have a gross built area of 21,335 square meters and offer a gross lettable area of 16,390 square meters. The commercial floors will encompass a total of 12,675 square meters, while the residential floors will cover 3,605 square meters.

title: Manzini Region Water and Sanitation Project: Lot 2, South Africa
body: The Eswatini Water Services Corporation is set to undertake the Manzini Region Water and Sanitation Project: Lot 2 in central Eswatini. This project involves constructing treated water gravity mains, including 12 kilometers of mains from the Logoba to Mphilo reservoirs, 3 kilometers of mains to the Manzini South area, and 4 kilometers of mains from the airport reservoir to the Nhlambeni network. Additionally, the project will include the construction of reinforced concrete storage reservoirs, with capacities of 9 million liters at Mphilo and 12 million liters at Logoba, as well as the development of a distribution extension system in Logoba and Mphilo. The primary goal of the Manzini Region Water and Sanitation Project is to expand water and sanitation services to currently unserved areas within the region, which is the most populated in the country. The project specifically targets four districts: Mtfongwaneni, Mafutseni, Manzini South, and Nhlambeni.

title: Water Treatment Plant and Drinkable Water Towers, Cote d’Ivoire
body:
The National Drinking Water Office (ONEP) of Ivory Coast is planning to construct two drinking water supply systems in Koumokro, Ivory Coast. These systems aim to enhance the drinking water supply for 100,000 people in the area.

The scope of the project involves building a 3,000 m³ groundwater tank to store water extracted from the water table. This water will then undergo purification at a potabilisation station before being conveyed to two 15-meter-high water towers. These towers, with a combined capacity of 100 m³, will ensure a continuous and reliable water supply to the population of Koumokro.

title: Yaoundé - Douala Expressway: Phase II, Cameroon
body:
The Cameroon Ministry of Public Works is commencing Phase 2 of the Yaoundé-Douala highway development project, focusing on the Bibodi-Douala route, which spans 135 kilometers. This significant initiative will be undertaken through a public-private partnership model, emphasizing collaborative efforts for infrastructure advancement. The project is divided into two main sections: Bidodi-Edéa (70 km) and Edéa-Douala (66 km).

Key features of the project include the integration of three slip roads: a side road to Edéa (12 km), a bypass to Edéa (10.5 km), and a side road to Dibamba Beach (7.6 km). Additionally, the project involves the construction of six interchanges and bridges over the Sanaga River (500 m) and the Dibamba River (250 m). These infrastructure enhancements are expected to significantly improve transportation infrastructure and connectivity within the region.

title: ZiZaBoNa Project, Namibia
body:
The Southern African Power Pool (SAPP) is planning the ZIZABONA transmission project, which entails the development, financing, construction, and operation of new transmission facilities in Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, and Namibia. The aim is to facilitate the establishment of a western transmission corridor in Southern Africa. The key components of the project include:

Component A: Hwange (Zimbabwe) to Mukuni (Zambia) 400 kV transmission line network (115 km) Component B: Victoria Falls (Zimbabwe) to Pandamatenga (Botswana) 400 kV transmission line network (59 km) Component C: Mukuni (Zambia) to Zambezi (Namibia) 400 kV transmission line network (231 km).

title: Mokolo and Crocodile River (West) Water Augmentation Project – Phase 2A, South Africa
body:
The Trans-Caledon Tunnel Authority (TCTA) is planning to undertake the Mokolo-Crocodile Rivers (West) Water Augmentation Project Phase-2A (MCWAP-2A), aimed at enhancing water supplies to the Lephalale municipality, Eskom's Matimba and Medupi power stations, and Exxaro's Grootegeluk mine, while also facilitating future economic development in the area. The project involves the construction of a 125 million cubic meters per year (m3/y) abstraction weir at the Crocodile River, pump stations, and a 160 km pipeline to transfer 75 m3/y of water from the Crocodile River near Thabazimbi to the Lephalale area. Additionally, a river management system, originally planned for a third phase, has been incorporated into Phase 2A. This initiative addresses the growing demand for water resources in the region and supports key industrial and municipal stakeholders.

Mokolo-Crocodile Rivers (West) Water Augmentation Project Phase-2A MCWAP-2A infrastructure is envisaged to comprise the components below:

  • The new Vlieëpoort Abstraction Works (Vlieëpoort Weir and associated water abstraction works) on the Crocodile River (West) at Vlieëpoort;
  • A low-lift pumping station and pipeline to convey water to the balancing dams and appropriate sediment disposal facilities;
  • A high-lift pumping station and rising main pipeline (approximately 29 km) to the break pressure reservoir located on the farm Leeuwbosch;
  • A gravity main pipeline (approximately 128 km) from the Leeuwbosch break pressure reservoir to terminal points close to Medupi Power Station and Steenbokpan, including an operational reservoir located on the farm Zoutpan south of Steenbokpan;
  • Infrastructure to enable off-takes at the Point/s of Supply.

The MCWAP-2A also includes a river abstraction and management system to control water abstractions and flows into the Crocodile River (West) between Hartbeespoort Dam and Vlieëpoort Abstraction Works, including the releases and spills from such works, the Moretele River from Klipvoor Dam to the confluence with Crocodile River (West) and the Elands River from Vaalkop Dam to the confluence with the Crocodile River (West).

Source: Trans-Caledon Tunnel Authority

title: Plaine Hollandaise Dam, Seychelles
body:
The Public Utilities Corporation, in collaboration with the European Investment Bank (EIB), plans to construct the Plaine Hollandaise Dam on Praslin Island, Seychelles. The project aims to enhance drinking water resources for Praslin, the second-largest island in the Seychelles archipelago, and improve the existing pipeline network.

Key project details include:

  • Dam: A 12-meter-high rockfill dam with upstream impermeabilization.
  • Reservoir.
  • Spillway: An ungated design.
  • Intake & Bottom Outlet: A steel pipe running through the dam.
  • Water Treatment Plant: To ensure potable water quality.
  • Pipelines: Connections to the existing water supply network.

title: The Yaoundé Transport Fluidity Project, Cameroon
body:
The Ministry of Transportation in Cameroon is leading the development of the Yaoundé Transport Fluidity Program, also known as Yaoundé Cœur de Ville. Through the implementation of various transportation solutions and infrastructure enhancements, the program seeks to improve mobility within Yaoundé, ultimately creating a more efficient and sustainable urban environment for residents and commuters. Specifically, the project will focus on redesigning and reconfiguring the three most congested intersections (Mvan, Elig-Effa, and Elig-Edzoa), as well as the Awae escalier, Emombo, and Sous-manguiers junctions.

Additionally, the project includes the demolition and reconstruction of the Mvan and Messa (Mokolo) bus stations, along with the reconstruction of two minibus and taxi terminals (Avenue Mvog-Fouda in Elig-Essono and Marcel Jezouin Street). Furthermore, rehabilitation work will be carried out on pedestrian hiking trails on Mount Messa and an access road.

title: Port Harcourt Ring Road, Nigeria
body: The Rivers State Government has planned to enhance transportation infrastructure for the city of Port Harcourt in Nigeria's South East through the Port Harcourt Ring Road project. This major infrastructure initiative involves the construction of a 50.15-kilometer dual carriageway. The road will connect Port Harcourt with Obio-Akpor, Etche, Eleme, and Ogu-Bolo, contributing significantly to improved connectivity and transportation within the region.

title: Praise Mall, Kenya
body:
Praise Mall Limited, as indicated in regulatory filings, plans to construct twin towers featuring a range of facilities. The scope of the work includes the construction of a thirty-story building with 2 lower ground levels, the construction of driveways, sidewalks, and parking bays, installation of development utilities (water, drainage, electricity, health, and safety systems, IT systems and security) and site landscaping/beautification.

The eventual Praise Mall will comprise Office spaces, Retail spaces, serviced apartments, hotels, a swimming pool, a gym, modern conference facilities, Church halls, a 200 capacity Parking space, and associated ancillary facilities.

title: Kasangati-Kitti Road, Uganda
body: Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) will be constructing the Kasangati-Kitti Road in Kasangati, Uganda. This road is a part of the outer ring road network to the north of Kampala City. The project entails upgrading the Kira-Kasangati-Matugga road together with the Najjera-Buwate spur and loop connection of the family access road from gravel to bituminous standard. It also involves the dueling of the two-kilometer road section from Kyaliwajjala to Kira from the current two lanes to four lanes with a median and provision of walkways and cycle lanes.

title: Koboko – Yumbe – Moyo Road Corridor Project, Uganda
body: Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) will be upgrading and widening the Koboko – Yumbe – Moyo road corridor (approximately 105km) to bituminous paved road standards. This road starts at Koboko near the Uganda-DRC international border and links Koboko and Yumbe districts with Moyo near the South Sudan Border. The Project Development objectives are to enhance road transport connectivity in selected refugee hosting districts of Uganda and to enhance the capacity of Uganda National Roads Authority to manage environmental, social, and road safety risks. Project components include road upgrading works, institutional strengthening for UNRA, road safety measures, and a contingent emergency response component.

title: La Digue School Reconstruction, Seychelles
body: The Ministry of Education in Seychelles is planning the comprehensive reconstruction of La Digue School in La Digue, Seychelles. This project includes the construction of new external facilities such as a multi-purpose playground for sports activities, an open-air amphitheater, bicycle parking areas, and upgraded sewage systems. The entire construction will be executed as a single project, rather than in phases, to accommodate the relocation and movement of students and staff on the site. The new school will be larger, providing additional space, particularly for technical rooms, and will include provisions for future expansions.

title: KwaMpumuza Skills Development Centre Project, South Africa
body: The Sector Education and Training Authority (SETA) is set to build the KwaMpumuza Skills Development Centre on a 27-hectare site. The facility will feature an administration block, a retail business hub, and fully equipped workshops for engineering and CETA-related trades, as well as an agricultural hub with training, warehousing, farming, agro-processing, and retail functions. Additional amenities will include lecture rooms, sick bays, a hospitality trades workshop, a multi-purpose hall, ablution facilities, and infrastructure for roads, parking, and landscaping. The centre aims to support sustainability through nearby amenities such as human settlements, a small dairy operation, and a shopping centre. SMMEs will benefit from an incubation programme, and the centre will also house farming and agro-processing operations. A multi-purpose centre is planned to generate income, with graduates from uMgungundlovu Technical Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College participating in staffing.

title: Free-Standing Elevated Traffic Circle, South Africa

The project scope includes the construction of a dedicated elevated traffic circle exclusively for the use of the MyCiTi bus fleet. title: Redstone (CSP) Project, South Africa
body: The ACWA Power SolarReserve Redstone Solar Thermal Power Plant plans to construct a solar project in the Northern Cape province, South Africa. The project scope includes the Redstone Concentrating Solar Power Plant (CSP) Project, which is designed to design, build, operate, and maintain a 100 MW capacity concentrated solar power plant. The project aims to close the energy supply gap, reduce dependence on coal, limit carbon emissions, create local jobs, and foster the development of a national solar energy industry.

title: Ronald Ngala Utalii College, Kenya
body:
The government of Kenya is constructing Ronald Ngala Utalii College. Situated in Vipingo, Kilifi County, this world-class institution will blend a traditional model of hospitality education with hands-on learning, exciting internships, insightful industry visits, and cutting-edge hospitality knowledge. The college will feature a dining hall, student class blocks, administration buildings, a social hall, and several student accommodation blocks to facilitate the admission of the first cohort of students.

Upon completion, Ronald Ngala Utalii College is projected to annually graduate approximately 3,000 on-campus students.

title: Lagos Bridge, Nigeria
body: The Lagos State government will be developing the Fourth Mainland Bridge, connecting Lagos Island via Langbasa (Lekki) and Baiyeku (Ikorodu) across the Lagos Lagoon to Itamaga in Ikorodu. The Fourth Mainland Bridge is a 38-kilometer-long project, consisting of a 2 x 4 lane carriageway cross-sectional road with permission for a BRT Lane and future road construction. It is anticipated to become the second longest bridge in Africa and will feature three toll plazas, nine interchanges, and a 4.5-kilometer Lagoon Bridge.

title: Nagad - Loyada / Lowyaddo - Borama Road Upgrade: Phase 1, Somalia
body:
The Somaliland Road Development Agency (SRDA) has launched a critical initiative to enhance the Nagad-Loyada/Lowyaddo-Borama Road Phase 1, linking Djibouti and Somalia. This includes upgrading the 30km single carriageway section from Lowyaddo to Zeila to a bituminous standard. This section is part of phase one of the broader Lowyaddo-Faddaha-Borama road upgrade project.

Phase one also encompasses the construction of a feeder road to a salt mine, installation of three boreholes, renovation of a health center and school, and rehabilitation of a ring road for Waheen market. On the Djibouti side, the Nagad-Loyada section will be upgraded from a national road to a regional road. Civil works involve raising the road level, enhancing drainage, and widening the carriageway to 7.5 meters.

title: Cross Border Roads Upgrading Project: Phase I, Rwanda
body: The Rwanda Transport Development Agency plans to upgrade access roads to cross-border areas between Rwanda and Burundi. The Cross Border Roads Upgrading Project including construction of a One Stop Border Post (OSBP) at Akanyaru Haut Border has been prioritised by the two countries as part of addressing the missing road links. Phase 1 will comprise: Upgrading from gravel to bitumen 69 km of roads in Rwanda (part of 213 km Cross Border Roads in Rwanda). The remaining sections of Cross Border roads in Rwanda (about 144 km) will be completed in Phase 2.

title: Lusaka City Water Supply Improvement Project, Zambia
body: Zambia Ministry of Water Development & Sanitation is embarking on the Lusaka City Water Supply Improvement Project in Lusaka, Zambia. The primary goal is to ensure fair and consistent water supply throughout Lusaka by enhancing water supply infrastructure and distribution networks. This initiative aims to elevate the living standards of citizens. The project encompasses the construction of various components, including intake facility works, raw water transmission pipelines, treated water booster pump stations at both the Water Treatment Plant and Chilanga, a 1200 mm treated water transmission pipeline from Kafue to Lusaka, establishment of a Water Treatment Plant, and expansion of the water distribution network in specific areas.

title: Nakasero - Northern Bypass VVIP Road, Uganda
body: Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) will be developing the  Northern Bypass in Nakasero, Uganda. The VVIP Express Route Project is located within Kampala District. The extent of the project is expected to stretch between Garden City, Nakasero and Kampala Northern Bypass. The VVIIP Express Route links the Kampala Northern Bypass with Nakasero through Bombo Road or Gayaza, Binaisa Road and Yusuf Lule Road. It is proposed that the VVIP express Route will provide linkage with Kampala Flyover Construction, major hotels and conference centres within Nakasero area.

title: Electricity Transmission and Distribution Infrastructure, Senegal
body: The Société Nationale d’Electricité du Sénégal is set to undertake the development of electricity transmission and distribution infrastructure in Senegal. This initiative entails the construction of 1,350 kilometers of high - voltage and very - high - voltage overhead and underground transmission lines, facilitating the connection of numerous households. Additionally, the project involves the construction of eight very - high - voltage transformer stations. Furthermore, enhancements to the grid management system will include the integration of an interface for remote operation management and the detection of faults in both overhead and underground power lines.

title: Tana River Hydroelectric Power Station, Kenya
body:
GBM Limited and the National Irrigation Authority are collaborating on an ambitious project to construct a hydroelectric power station across the Tana River in Kenya. The dam, when built, is expected to cover an area of more than 165 square kilometres, provide a volume of more than 5.6 billion cubic meters of water to irrigate 400,000 acres of land, the irrigation authority said.

This innovative initiative aims to harness the energy of the Kibuka Falls, providing a sustainable source of hydroelectric power. Once completed, the project will contribute significantly to the country's energy infrastructure, emphasizing the commitment to renewable energy solutions and the harnessing of natural resources for sustainable development

title: Busega - Mpigi Expressway, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is embarking on the development of the Busega - Mpigi Expressway in Kampala, Uganda. This significant infrastructure initiative aims to improve transportation connectivity and ease traffic congestion in the area. Stretching across 32 kilometers, the expressway begins at Busega and extends southwards, eventually connecting with the existing Masaka road at Lungala. From Lungala, it proceeds along Masaka road until reaching the junction of Mpigi Town. Additionally, it provides a link to Mityana Highway to the North via Bujjuuko.

title: Grand Inga, DRC
body:
The Grand Inga project is about 42 GW of hydropower capacity to be developed in 6 phases, and aims to connect 300 million people in Africa to electricity. 

In its lower course, the Congo River, 4,700 km long, is only navigable for 140 km, from the mouth to the port of Matadi. Upstream of this city, up to Kinshasa, the river is only a succession of rapids over a distance of 350 km. It is in the rapids area, less than 30 km upstream of the port city of Matadi, that is the extraordinary site of Inga, with a significant difference in height of 150 m, over 20 km. As the crow flies, Inga is located 256 km from Kinshasa. The Congo River, 2nd river in the world in terms of flow, after the Amazon, with an average flow of 40,000 m3/s, up to 60,000 m3/s. In the dry season, especially during low tide (July - August), its flow sometimes drops to 26,000 m3/s, on the other hand, in the rainy season, it can exceed 75,000 m3/s. 

This series of rapids makes the Inga site (which is called the Congo Energy Power Triangle, because of its right triangle shape) one of the most important reservoir of hydroelectric power concentrated in the same point.

It is through this site that the DRC wants to play its role as a catalyst for the industrialization of Africa. The Inga project is an integrative project, a project of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Congolese territory, but its field of action is regional and intercontinental. It thus offers opportunities for energy exports to the African continent, in particular to SAPP, WAPP and PEAC.

Inga 3 is the first phase (7,800 MW) of the Grand Inga project. 

INGA 3 LOWER FALL (BC)

The first phase of this development consists of the development of a power plant with an installed capacity of 4,800 MW called "Inga 3 Basse Chute.

  • No intervention on the riverbed. 
  • Construction of a water intake on the river. 
  • Construction of a dam on the Bundi River to reach a water retention level of 145 m. 
  • Installation of a hydroelectric power plant with bi-drop turbines. 
  • Installed power: 4,800 MW
  • Construction of energy evacuation lines to Kinshasa, to the former province of Katanga and the Republic of South Africa.

INGA 3 HIGH FALL (HC)

the second phase of this development called HIGH FALL, consists of raising the retention dam in order to produce an additional 3,000 MW and reach 7,800 MW.

  • Construction of a dam on the river. 
  • Transformation of the Bundi valley into a retention basin and flooding of the water intake on the river and the 12-kilometer-long supply channel, built for the need of Inga 3 BC. 
  • Raising the dam on the Bundi so that the water level increases from 145 m to 205 m. 
  • Recalibration of bichute turbines to produce an additional 3,000 MW. 
  • Installed power: 7,800 MW. 
  • Construction of energy evacuation lines.
meta_description: The Grand Inga project is about 42 GW of hydropower capacity to be developed in 6 phases
migration_status: and aims to connect 300 million people in Africa to electricity.

title: Calcined Clay Production Facility, Burkina Faso
body: Ciments de l'Afrique (CIMAF) is planning to construct a calcined clay production facility for its subsidiary OIP, CIMAF Bobo Dioulasso, in Burkina Faso. This initiative aims to decrease the dependency on clinker, a primary raw material for cement production, resulting in enhanced energy and fuel efficiency and a notable reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. CIMAF intends to utilize the calcined clay to manufacture limestone calcined clay cement (LC3), which is recognized for its high quality, low carbon footprint, and cost-effectiveness.

title: International Football Stadium, Rwanda
body:
Rwanda's Ministry of Sports plans to construct international football stadiums in the country. The project aims to have five such stadiums completed within the next five years. These stadiums will either be built or revamped in locations such as Kigali, Nyanza, and Muhanga District.

The Amahoro Stadium, which is currently being renovated, is expected to increase its capacity to 45,000 people. Kigali and Huye stadiums are also slated for renovation. Muhanga and Nyanza stadiums will be renovated, and studies have already been conducted.

The Government of Rwanda will provide the land for the new stadium to be built in Muhanga, with FIFA and CAF providing funding and construction works.

title: Palmeraie Bridge, Djibouti
body: Djibouti Road Agency will be constructing a bridge on the Palmeraie Road in Djibouti City.The objective of the Project is to improve transportation that stably functions even in the event of a flood and a large traffic volume by constructing a bridge across the Ambouli River and improving Palmeraie road in Djibouti City, thereby facilitating road traffic in the country. It will contribute to strengthening urban transport functions and facilitating logistics in the Horn of AfricaConstruction of a bridge (bridge length 113.5 m, width 26.8 m, 6 car lanes), river improvements (river channel excavation, revetment works [maintenance of right and left embankments]), road widening (455 m from east intersection to end of bridge attachment road [including a 113.5 m bridge section], 6 car lanes), intersection improvements (additional lanes, changes to traffic regulations)..

title: Hargeisa - Odweyne - Burao Road, Somalia
body: The Ministry of Transport & Road Development (MOTRD), working in conjunction with the Roads Development Agency (RDA), is set to undertake the development of the Hargeisa-Odweyne-Burao road in Somalia. This strategic infrastructure project spans approximately 183 kilometers and plays a crucial role as part of the IGAD Economic Transport corridors. Connecting the towns of Hargeisa and Burao in Somaliland, within the Berbera corridor, it serves as a pivotal link facilitating connectivity between Somalia and Ethiopia, as well as forming a part of the Djibouti-Mogadishu corridor.

title: Bayne’s Hydropower Project (HPP), Namibia
body: NamPower intends to upgrade the Baynes Hydropower Project to 878 MW from its initial 600 MW capacity. Positioned 45 km downstream from the Epupa Falls on the Cunene River, serving as the Angola-Namibia border, the project will comprise a main dam generating 878 MW through four units, capable of annually producing 1,724 GWh. Additionally, an 18 MW balancing dam situated approximately 12 km away will include three units, generating 98 GWh annually.

title: Gwagwalada Independent Power Plant, Nigeria
body:
The Nigerian National Petroleum Company Limited (NNPCL) is planning to construct an Independent Power Plant named the Gwagwalada Independent Power Plant in Abuja, Nigeria. This ambitious project, initiated by NNPCL, involves the establishment of a 1,350 MW combined cycle power plant, equipped with auxiliaries and a balance of plants.
 

The strategically chosen location for this groundbreaking power project is a vast 547-hectare expanse of land in Gwagwalada, marking a significant effort to enhance power generation infrastructure in the region. The project will be developed in three phases.

title: Gwayi - Shangani Cowdray Park Water Treatment Plant, Zimbabwe
body: The Zimbabwe National Water Authority (Zinwa) is set to construct the Gwayi-Shangani Cowdray Park Water Treatment Plant in Zimbabwe. With a capacity to process 80 megalitres (ML) of water daily, the plant aims to supply residents of Cowdray Park and other areas in Bulawayo. Water will be transported from Lake Gwayi-Shangani dam via a 245 km pipeline. This initiative marks a significant effort to meet water supply demands in the Bulawayo region, enhancing treatment and distribution services. The project's goal is to ensure that water sourced from the Gwayi-Shangani Dam and other outlets meets rigorous standards for safe drinking water, thereby improving reliability and quality across the city and its environs.

The new airport will cover a 45 sq km site, and will have the capacity to handle up to 1.75 million passengers annually, and will have a runway of just over 2km in length. title: Bergrivier Water Pipeline, South Africa
body: The Trans-Caledon Tunnel Authority (TCTA) will be developing the Berg River Voëlvlei Augmentation Scheme (BRVAS). The project comprises abstraction works on the Berg River, including a diversion weir, sediment traps, and a 5 MW pump station. Additionally, it involves the construction of a 6.3 km bulk water pipeline from the Berg River to Voëlvlei dam, appurtenant works such as a canoe-fishway chute, a saddle embankment for flood risk management, and an access road. The project also includes providing electricity supply and associated installations to energize the new pump station, as well as measures to mitigate the impact of the project on the environment.

title: Tana River Hydroelectric Power Station, Kenya
body:
GBM Limited and the National Irrigation Authority are collaborating on an ambitious project to construct a hydroelectric power station across the Tana River in Kenya. The dam, when built, is expected to cover an area of more than 165 square kilometres, provide a volume of more than 5.6 billion cubic meters of water to irrigate 400,000 acres of land, the irrigation authority said.

This innovative initiative aims to harness the energy of the Kibuka Falls, providing a sustainable source of hydroelectric power. Once completed, the project will contribute significantly to the country's energy infrastructure, emphasizing the commitment to renewable energy solutions and the harnessing of natural resources for sustainable development

title: Busega - Mpigi Expressway, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is embarking on the development of the Busega - Mpigi Expressway in Kampala, Uganda. This significant infrastructure initiative aims to improve transportation connectivity and ease traffic congestion in the area. Stretching across 32 kilometers, the expressway begins at Busega and extends southwards, eventually connecting with the existing Masaka road at Lungala.
