title: Grand Inga, DRC
body:
The Grand Inga project is about 42 GW of hydropower capacity to be developed in 6 phases, and aims to connect 300 million people in Africa to electricity. 

In its lower course, the Congo River, 4,700 km long, is only navigable for 140 km, from the mouth to the port of Matadi. Upstream of this city, up to Kinshasa, the river is only a succession of rapids over a distance of 350 km. It is in the rapids area, less than 30 km upstream of the port city of Matadi, that is the extraordinary site of Inga, with a significant difference in height of 150 m, over 20 km. As the crow flies, Inga is located 256 km from Kinshasa. The Congo River, 2nd river in the world in terms of flow, after the Amazon, with an average flow of 40,000 m3/s, up to 60,000 m3/s. In the dry season, especially during low tide (July - August), its flow sometimes drops to 26,000 m3/s, on the other hand, in the rainy season, it can exceed 75,000 m3/s. 

This series of rapids makes the Inga site (which is called the Congo Energy Power Triangle, because of its right triangle shape) one of the most important reservoir of hydroelectric power concentrated in the same point.

It is through this site that the DRC wants to play its role as a catalyst for the industrialization of Africa. The Inga project is an integrative project, a project of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Congolese territory, but its field of action is regional and intercontinental. It thus offers opportunities for energy exports to the African continent, in particular to SAPP, WAPP and PEAC.

Inga 3 is the first phase (7,800 MW) of the Grand Inga project. 

INGA 3 LOWER FALL (BC)

The first phase of this development consists of the development of a power plant with an installed capacity of 4,800 MW called "Inga 3 Basse Chute.

  • No intervention on the riverbed. 
  • Construction of a water intake on the river. 
  • Construction of a dam on the Bundi River to reach a water retention level of 145 m. 
  • Installation of a hydroelectric power plant with bi-drop turbines. 
  • Installed power: 4,800 MW
  • Construction of energy evacuation lines to Kinshasa, to the former province of Katanga and the Republic of South Africa.

INGA 3 HIGH FALL (HC)

the second phase of this development called HIGH FALL, consists of raising the retention dam in order to produce an additional 3,000 MW and reach 7,800 MW.

  • Construction of a dam on the river. 
  • Transformation of the Bundi valley into a retention basin and flooding of the water intake on the river and the 12-kilometer-long supply channel, built for the need of Inga 3 BC. 
  • Raising the dam on the Bundi so that the water level increases from 145 m to 205 m. 
  • Recalibration of bichute turbines to produce an additional 3,000 MW. 
  • Installed power: 7,800 MW. 
  • Construction of energy evacuation lines.
meta_description: The Grand Inga project is about 42 GW of hydropower capacity to be developed in 6 phases
migration_status: and aims to connect 300 million people in Africa to electricity.

title: Calcined Clay Production Facility, Burkina Faso
body: Ciments de l'Afrique (CIMAF) is planning to construct a calcined clay production facility for its subsidiary OIP, CIMAF Bobo Dioulasso, in Burkina Faso. This initiative aims to decrease the dependency on clinker, a primary raw material for cement production, resulting in enhanced energy and fuel efficiency and a notable reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. CIMAF intends to utilize the calcined clay to manufacture limestone calcined clay cement (LC3), which is recognized for its high quality, low carbon footprint, and cost-effectiveness.

title: International Football Stadium, Rwanda
body:
Rwanda's Ministry of Sports plans to construct international football stadiums in the country. The project aims to have five such stadiums completed within the next five years. These stadiums will either be built or revamped in locations such as Kigali, Nyanza, and Muhanga District.

The Amahoro Stadium, which is currently being renovated, is expected to increase its capacity to 45,000 people. Kigali and Huye stadiums are also slated for renovation. Muhanga and Nyanza stadiums will be renovated, and studies have already been conducted.

The Government of Rwanda will provide the land for the new stadium to be built in Muhanga, with FIFA and CAF providing funding and construction works.

title: Kira - Kasangati - Matugga Road Upgrade, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is set to develop the Kira-Kasangati-Matugga road project, which will cover a total of 23 kilometers. This includes the main 16-kilometer section, a 2-kilometer Kira-Kyaliwajjala link, a 5-kilometer Najjera-Buwate spur, and a connecting loop to Family Care Hospital Link. Key features of the project include junction improvements at Erisa, Mpererwe, Kitetika, and Gayaza, as well as infrastructure upgrades like on and off ramps, a half-diamond interchange, a pedestrian bridge, and signalized junctions at major intersections. Upon completion, the road will significantly enhance access to essential services, improve commuting, and facilitate business activities in the area.

title: Benue State Geographic Information Service Centre (BENGIS Centre), Nigeria
body: The Benue State Government plans to construct a Benue State Geographic Information Service Centre (BENGIS centre) at Makurdi Nigeria. GIS is one of the modern methods that is now being embraced and used in the computerisation of land records as well as enhancing the process of land registration in Nigeria.This underscores the reason why many state governments in Nigeria are beginning to adopt GIS in their land administration processes. With the success story of the Abuja Geographic Information System (AGIS), other states such as Lagos, Niger, Bauchi,  Cross River, Nasarawa, and now Benue, are establishing their respective GISs.

title: Economic Community of West African State (ECOWAS) Headquarters, Nigeria
body: The Economic Community of West African States plans to construct a Headquartres at Abuja, Nigeria. The China - aided construction of the permanent headquarters of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS headquarter) in Nigeria’s capital, Abuja. To consolidate the regional bloc’s operations in one complex, a departure from operating at three different locations in Abuja. The new headquarters project consists of a set of office buildings, comprising a central wing of ground floor plus 9 floors, framed by an east wing and a west wing (ground floor plus 7 floors) with a conference centre (ground floor plus 1 floor) and other buildings for maintenance, sports, care and bank.

title: Mwanza Bridge, Tanzania
body: Tanroads will be constructing the Kigongo–Busisi Bridge across the Gulf of Mwanza, a 30 - kilometer inlet on the lake's south shore between Kigongo and Busisi, to link Tanzania to Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Burundi by road. The project scope consists of two major components: bridge works and road works. The former involves constructing an extra - dosed bridge with a total length of 3 km (including the approach section), crossing a gulf on Lake Victoria. Road works entail widening 1.66 km of the existing road from 2 lanes to 4 lanes and constructing 1.16 km on the Kigongo side and 0.5 km on the Busisi side. The approach roads tie in with the existing surfaced road to the bridge

title: Ngalda - Mutai Road: Phase 2, Nigeria
body: The North-East Development Commission is undertaking the construction of the Ngalda-Mutai Road in Nigeria. This project involves building a 54km road linking Ngalda town in the Fika local government area. The road will connect various thriving agricultural communities across Fika and Gujba local governments in Yobe State, contributing significantly to their economic growth. The completion of this road will enhance accessibility, fostering smoother transportation of people, goods, and services, thereby stimulating development in the region.

title: Kibaha Industrial City, Tanzania
body: Elsewedy Electric is developing an Industrial City in Kibaha, Tanzania, spanning 2.6 million square meters to host 200 factories in key sectors like pharmaceuticals, building materials, food and beverages, and engineering. The city will also include residential areas and various amenities, located just 15 km from Kwala Dry Port and connected by the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR), reducing travel time to Dar es Salaam to 45 minutes. Additionally, the project features the El Sewedy Academy for Technical Education, focused on training the local workforce to international standards, enhancing transportation efficiency and fostering economic growth through its subsidiary, Elsewedy Industrial Development.

title: Kidunda Dam, Tanzania
body:
Also known as Kidunda Multi-Purpose Project. 

Main Features

  • Reservoir ( A = 78 km², V_live = 280 Mm³ )
  • Rockfill Dam with bituminous facing ( H = 21 m, L_crest = 860 m, V = 450’000 m³, A_grouting curtain = 24,000 m² )
  • Gated spillway ( L = 133 m, W = 117 m, No. 8 Gates, Q_design = 3,500 m³/s )
  • Intake tower ( H = 25 m, No. 4 Slide gate, HxW = 6×6 m )
  • Outlet works ( Type double barrel, L = 200 m, D = 6 m each )
  • Tailrace Canal ( L = 103 m, W = 30 m )
  • Outdoor Power House ( E = 60 GWh/y, IP = 20 MW, No. 2 Kaplan turbines )
  • Resettlement ( No. 5,000 People relocated, No. 2,000 Houses involved )

Source: Studio Pietrangeli

title: Win Farm Project, Tanzania
body: Aseel Oilfield Services Limited followed the signing, in July 2003, of a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between Aseel and the Zanzibar government for the implementation of a wind power project in the Isles. The site visit lays the groundwork for the development of the wind farm, which is expected to commence upon the signing of a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) between Aseel Oilfield Services and the Ministry of Water, Energy, and Minerals. The wind farm will have the capacity to produce from 20 MW to 200 MW of electricity, marking a significant leap forward in the goal of diversifying the energy mix and achieving a greener future.

title: Kibaha - Mlandizi - Chalinze - Morogoro Road, Tanzania
body: The Tanzania National Roads Agency - HQ - is moving forward with plans to construct a 205 km, 4-lane dual carriageway toll expressway from Kibaha to Morogoro, Tanzania. This expressway will have a design speed of 120 km/hr and will feature modern rest areas, international standard service levels, free interchanges, and an e-tolling system. Implemented under a PPP arrangement, the expressway will be built parallel to the existing Morogoro road, allowing continued access for non-toll users. The project also includes connections to Mlandizi, Kwala Dry Port, and Kinguruwila township, and it forms part of the TANZAM highway network.

title: Komenda Cargo Airport, Ghana
body:
The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) is planning the construction of a cargo airport in Komenda, Ghana. This ambitious project, spearheaded by the Ghanaian government, aims to enhance the country's logistics and trade infrastructure.

The cargo airport's comprehensive development plan includes the following features:

  • Fuel Farm: A dedicated area for fuel storage and distribution to support airport operations.
  • Airport City: An integrated urban development adjacent to the airport, providing commercial and residential spaces.
  • Fire Station: A facility to ensure safety and emergency response capabilities.
  • Cargo Yard and Warehouses: Extensive space for handling and storing cargo efficiently.
  • Rail Connection: A rail link on the landside to facilitate the easy movement of goods to and from the airport.

On the airside, the airport will be equipped with:

  • Navigational Aids: Systems to support the safe and efficient navigation of aircraft.
  • Passenger Terminal: A facility to handle passenger traffic, indicating potential future expansion beyond cargo services.
  • Parallel Taxiway: A taxiway running parallel to the runway to improve traffic flow and operational efficiency.

This project is expected to significantly boost Ghana's trade capabilities, enhancing its position as a key logistics hub in the region.

title: Kwa Jomvu - Mariakani Road, Kenya
body:
The Kenya National Highway Authority (KeNHA) is undertaking the development of the Kwa Jomvu - Mariakani Road in the coastal region, which is part of the Mombasa - Nairobi (A8) Highway. Starting at the Kwa Jomvu interchange and ending just after the Mariakani weighbridge, the project covers a distance of 30.4 kilometers and follows the alignment of the existing road through Miritini, Mazeras, and Mariakani.

The project involves upgrading the road from a 2 - way lane to a 4 - way lane dual carriageway with climbing lanes and service lanes in urban sections. Additionally, it includes improving grade intersections, constructing non - motorized facilities and pedestrian footbridges, enhancing urban drainage, and providing truck parking facilities and weighbridges for axle - load control.

title: Koboko - Yumbe - Moyo Road Corridor, Uganda
body:
The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is set to upgrade and widen the Koboko – Yumbe – Moyo road corridor, covering approximately 103 kilometers, to bituminous paved road standards. This roadway starts near the Uganda - DRC international border in Koboko, linking Koboko and Yumbe districts to Moyo near the South Sudan border.

The main objectives of the project are to enhance road transport connectivity in designated refugee hosting districts of Uganda and to strengthen UNRA's capacity to address environmental, social, and road safety challenges. The project includes key components such as road upgrading, institutional strengthening for UNRA, road safety initiatives, and a contingent emergency response component.

title: Kabale - Lake Bunyonyiand & Kisoro - Mgahinga Roads, Uganda
body:
The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is embarking on the development of the Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi and Kisoro - Mgahinga Roads in Uganda, covering a total distance of 34 kilometers. This project involves upgrading two key road links in South - western Uganda: the Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kabeho circuit and the Kisoro - Mgahinga Park Gates Road, aiming to elevate them to Class III Paved Road standards.

The proposed cross - section includes 3.00 - meter lanes and 1.5 - meter shoulders, with specific sections featuring walkways and dedicated cycle lanes. The project also prioritizes the enhancement of three main junctions to improve traffic flow and safety.

Beyond road development, the initiative includes broader infrastructure enhancements, such as the construction of four landing sites along Lake Bunyonyi, two roadside markets, and farm produce holding facilities. Additionally, the project involves providing two ferries equipped with search and rescue boats and navigational aids.

body: The Tanzania National Roads Agency (TANROADS) is advancing its plans to upgrade the Same-Kisiwani-Mkomazi Road to bitumen standard, with the total stretch covering approximately 100 km. The focus of this initiative, specifically Lot 1, involves the Same-Kisiwani-Mroyo section, which spans 56.83 km. This significant infrastructure project aims to enhance transportation efficiency and bolster economic activities in the region by improving the road's capacity, safety, and durability. The upgrade will extend from Same to Kisiwani, ultimately reaching Mkomazi, marking a crucial development for the area's connectivity and economic growth.

title: Kira - Kasangati - Matugga Road Upgrade, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is set to develop the Kira-Kasangati-Matugga road project, which will cover a total of 23 kilometers. This includes the main 16-kilometer section, a 2-kilometer Kira-Kyaliwajjala link, a 5-kilometer Najjera-Buwate spur, and a connecting loop to Family Care Hospital Link. Key features of the project include junction improvements at Erisa, Mpererwe, Kitetika, and Gayaza, as well as infrastructure upgrades like on and off ramps, a half-diamond interchange, a pedestrian bridge, and signalized junctions at major intersections. Upon completion, the road will significantly enhance access to essential services, improve commuting, and facilitate business activities in the area.

title: Benue State Geographic Information Service Centre (BENGIS Centre), Nigeria
body: The Benue State Government plans to construct a Benue State Geographic Information Service Centre (BENGIS centre) at Makurdi Nigeria. GIS is one of the modern methods that is now being embraced and used in the computerisation of land records as well as enhancing the process of land registration in Nigeria.This underscores the reason why many state governments in Nigeria are beginning to adopt GIS in their land administration processes. With the success story of the Abuja Geographic Information System (AGIS), other states such as Lagos, Niger, Bauchi,  Cross River, Nasarawa, and now Benue, are establishing their respective GISs.

body: The Economic Community of West African States plans to construct a Headquartres at Abuja, Nigeria. The China - aided construction of the permanent headquarters of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS headquarter) in Nigeria’s capital, Abuja. To consolidate the regional bloc’s operations in one complex, a departure from operating at three different locations in Abuja. title: Mwanza Bridge, Tanzania
body: Tanroads will be constructing the Kigongo–Busisi Bridge across the Gulf of Mwanza, a 30 - kilometer inlet on the lake's south shore between Kigongo and Busisi, to link Tanzania to Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Burundi by road. The project scope consists of two major components: bridge works and road works. The former involves constructing an extra - dosed bridge with a total length of 3 km (including the approach section), crossing a gulf on Lake Victoria. Road works entail widening 1.66 km of the existing road from 2 lanes to 4 lanes and constructing 1.16 km on the Kigongo side and 0.5 km on the Busisi side. The approach roads tie in with the existing surfaced road to the bridge

title: Kibaha Industrial City, Tanzania
body: Elsewedy Electric is developing an Industrial City in Kibaha, Tanzania, spanning 2.6 million square meters to host 200 factories in key sectors like pharmaceuticals, building materials, food and beverages, and engineering. The city will also include residential areas and various amenities, located just 15 km from Kwala Dry Port and connected by the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR), reducing travel time to Dar es Salaam to 45 minutes. Additionally, the project features the El Sewedy Academy for Technical Education, focused on training the local workforce to international standards, enhancing transportation efficiency and fostering economic growth through its subsidiary, Elsewedy Industrial Development.

body:
Also known as Kidunda Multi-Purpose Project. 

Main Features

title: Kampala City Roads Rehabilitation Project (KCRRP), Uganda
body:
The Smart City initiative in Kampala is built on three core pillars: technology, infrastructure, and people. As part of this vision, the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) is planning to refurbish 270 kilometers of city roads.

The primary objective of the project is to to enhance transport efficiency thereby enabling the City of Kampala to maximize agglomerative benefits of access and improved attractiveness resulting from reduced traffic congestion through upgrade and expansion of road network; and

To improve air quality in the city through implementation of Scheduled Eco - Bus transit Services and broadening travel choices for non - vehicular movements within Kampala by expanding networks of walkways and cycling tracks.

Project Overview

The project involves the comprehensive upgrading, reconstruction, dualling, and signalization of roads across multiple divisions within Kampala, Uganda. The works are divided into five distinct lots covering various areas including Lubaga, Makindye, Nakawa, Kawempe, and Central divisions.

Scope of Work by Lot

Lot 1: Lubaga and Makindye

  • Upgrade of 8.07 km of roads to paved standard
  • Reconstruction of 6.83 km of roads
  • Signalization of 7 junctions

Lot 2: Nakawa

  • Reconstruction and dualling of Port Bell and Spring Roads (total 10.01 km)
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 3: Makindye, Central, Kawempe, and Lubaga

  • Reconstruction of 18.84 km of roads
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 4: Kawempe, Lubaga, Makindye, and Central

  • Asphalting of 3.94 km
  • Reconstruction of 8.10 km
  • Dualling of 3.90 km
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 5: Lubaga

  • Upgrading of 9.54 km of roads
  • Reconstruction of 6.72 km
  • Signalization of 5 junctions
  • Channelization of drainage on 3.9 km section

title: Berg River Voëlvlei Dam Augmentation Scheme (BRVAS), South Africa
body:
The Trans - Caledon Tunnel Authority (TCTA) is set to develop the Berg River Voëlvlei Dam Augmentation Scheme (BRVAS). This project involves multiple components, including abstraction works on the Berg River, featuring a diversion weir, sediment traps, and a 5 MW pump station. Additionally, a 6.3 km bulk water pipeline will be constructed from the Berg River to Voëlvlei Dam.

Appurtenant works such as a canoe - fishway chute, a saddle embankment for flood risk management, an access road, and the installation of electricity supply and associated infrastructure to power the new pump station are also part of the project.

The Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kisoro - Mgahinga Road Project in South - western Uganda aims to upgrade two vital road links prioritized in the National Development Plan 2020/21 - 2024/25. These roads, the Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kabeho circuit and the Kisoro - Mgahinga Park Gates road, are crucial for tourism development and regional accessibility.
With the region's rich environment and wildlife as major tourist attractions, the project focuses on upgrading 34 kilometers of roads to bituminous standards. Additionally, it includes the construction of four landing sites on Lake Bunyonyi, two roadside markets, and farm produce holding facilities. The provision of two ferries and search and rescue boats will enhance water transportation options.

title: Fourth Mainland Bridge, Nigeria
body: The Lagos State Government is constructing the Fourth Mainland Bridge, a 38 km bridge in Nigeria. The bridge will connect Lagos Island via Langbasa (Lekki) and Baiyeku (Ikorodu) across the Lagos Lagoon to Itamaga in Ikorodu. The project scope includes three toll plazas, nine interchanges, and a 4.5 km lagoon bridge. The bridge structure will also feature a 2 x 4 lane carriageway cross-sectional road, with provisions for a BRT Lane and future road expansion. When completed, the Fourth Mainland Bridge will be the longest bridge in Africa, surpassing the 6th October Bridge (20.5 km) in Cairo, Egypt, and the Third Mainland Bridge (11.8 km) in Lagos.

title: New Kampala-Jinja Expressway, Uganda
body:
Build the new Kampala-Jinja Expressway (KJE), which is part of the Northern Corridor linking Kenya’s Port of Mombasa to the landlocked countries of Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) 

Work will be undertaken in phases over five years and involves building a toll expressway routed to the south of the existing Kampala–Jinja Highway, starting from Ntinda/Kyambogo, through Namagunga and Namataba to Jinja

The road will be built in three sections:

  • Section 1: Build the Kampala Southern Bypass, which is a 20 km dual-carriage urban expressway with four lanes forming a bypass to the south of Kampala City; design speed will be up to 100 km per hour. Over 12 km of road will traverse through swamps and be elevated on a viaduct. The route will allow connection to junctions through four interchanges and roads over bridges for links. It is expected partly to be fenced to allow limited access with lighting and provisions for toll plazas

     

  • Section 2: Build the 35 km first section of the Kampala-Jinja Expressway from Kampala to Namagunga as a dual-carriage urban expressway with six lanes; design speed will be up to 120 km per hour 

 

  • Section 3: Build the 41 km second section of the expressway from Namagunga to Njeru at the new Nile bridge as a dual-carriage urban expressway with four lanes; design speed will be up to 120 km per hour 
     

The overall scope includes building about 16 interchanges, 11 toll plazas, 12 km of service roads, 30 km of link roads, 5 km of viaducts, 18 pedestrian over-bridges/underpasses, 54 vehicular over-bridges/underpasses and one rest area in each direction of the expressway
 

All sections will be undertaken under the design, build, finance, operate, maintain and transfer (DBFOT) model for a 30-year concession term. The project is to be delivered as one holistic corridor project over a five-year construction period.

 

The proposed route corridor largely follows virgin terrain on the southern part of the existing Kampala-Jinja road through Munyonyo, Bunga, Mutungo, Butabika, Mbalala and Namagunga up to Njeru, where it links with the Source of the Nile Bridge. 

 

The project provides seamless connectivity between the Kampala Northern Bypass and the Kampala-Entebbe Expressway spur to Munyonyo through the Kampala Southern Bypass, which will provide a complete ring road around Kampala City. 

 

The project also links with 10 existing major roads along the corridor, including the Mukono-Katosi road, to enable connectivity with existing and future developments.

Additionally, it includes expanding and renovating the runway, constructing a new passenger terminal, taxiway, aircraft apron, access roads, car park, security fence, and installing a new navigation aid lighting system.

title: Kigongo–Busisi Bridge, Tanzania
body:
Tanroads is gearing up to construct the Kigongo - Busisi Bridge, which will stretch across a 30 - kilometer inlet in the Gulf of Mwanza on the southern shore of Lake Victoria, linking Kigongo and Busisi. This pivotal infrastructure endeavor aims to establish a vital road link between Tanzania and neighboring nations like Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Burundi.

The project comprises two key components: bridge works and road works. The bridge works entail constructing an extra - dosed bridge spanning a total length of 3 kilometers, including the approach section, across a gulf on Lake Victoria. Meanwhile, the road works component involves widening 1.66 kilometers of the existing road from 2 lanes to 4 lanes. Furthermore, 1.16 kilometers will be constructed on the Kigongo side and 0.5 kilometers on the Busisi side. The approach roads seamlessly integrate with the existing surfaced road leading to the bridge.

title: Lusaka - Ndola Dual Carriage Road, Zambia
body:
The Government of Zambia (GRZ) is embarking on the development of the Lusaka-Ndola Dual Carriageway, a crucial economic route in the nation. This initiative involves constructing a 327km dual-carriageway connecting Lusaka and Ndola. Additionally, it encompasses the rehabilitation of the 45km Luanshya - Fisenge -Masangano road, which has been neglected for years. The overarching goal is to bolster transportation infrastructure, foster economic development, and tackle longstanding road maintenance issues in Zambia.

Key Components

  • Construction of a 327 km New Carriageway between Lusaka and Ndola
  • Rehabilitation of the Existing 327 km Carriageway on the same route
  • Bypass Construction:
    • 20 km bypass in Kapiri Mposhi
    • 20 km bypass in Kabwe
  • Rehabilitation of a 45 km Road Section from Masangano to Luanshya (M006)
  • Construction of Toll Plazas for efficient revenue collection and road maintenance
  • Construction of Weighbridges to regulate axle loads and protect road infrastructure

title: Landmark Waterview Apartments, Nigeria
body:
Landmark Group is preparing to launch the Landmark Waterview Apartments, a residential project located along Water Corporation Road in Oniru, Lagos. This impressive structure will stand tall at 28 floors, covering a gross lettable area of 36,000 square meters and offering a total of 306 luxury apartments. The residential options will vary from studio apartments and 1–4 bedroom units to 3 & 5 bedroom penthouses.

Landmark Waterview Apartments is meticulously designed to serve as a centralized leisure hub, providing residents with access to a plethora of amenities including a gymnasium, swimming pool, children’s pool, clubhouse, games room, outdoor lounge, and children’s play area. This development aims to deliver a premium living experience in the vibrant city of Lagos.

title: Mtwara - Mbamba Bay Railway, Tanzania
body:
The Tanzania Railways Corporation (TRC) plans to develop the Mtwara - Mbamba Bay Railway, spanning 1,000 km from Mtwara port to Mbamba Bay port on Lake Nyasa, passing through Songea and Ludewa. This railway will link the Indian Ocean to Lake Nyasa and traverse mineral - rich regions, including areas abundant in iron ore and graphite. It will also have spurs connecting to Mozambique, Zambia, and Malawi.

The project aims to serve proposed coal and iron ore mines in Mchuchuma and Liganga, as well as support Dangote Cement Plc and Tancoal Energy Ltd. Its main objective is to promote sustainable transport along the Mtwara corridor, unlocking agricultural and mineral - rich areas in Southern Tanzania. The railway will be standard gauge (SRG) with 120 - pound rails and concrete sleepers, designed for passenger trains to travel at 160 km/hr and freight trains at 120 km/hr.

title: National Cathedral, Ghana
body:
The Ghana National Cathedral Board is undertaking the development of the National Cathedral of Ghana in Greater Accra. Spanning approximately 101,000 square meters of land, the colossal structure will have a building area of around 23,000 square meters, totaling a built area of 62,450 square meters.

The National Cathedral will feature a series of impressive chapels, a baptistery, a 2 - level 5000 - seat auditorium with a spacious central hall, a music and choir school, an art gallery, a shop, and multipurpose spaces. Additionally, it will house Africa’s first Bible Museum and Documentation Center, dedicated to Christianity and Ghana's nation - building efforts.

title: Kapchorwa - Suam Transport Highways, Uganda
body:
The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) plans for the 73km stretch of road connecting Kapchorwa, the district capital of Kapchorwa District to Suam, which lies on the Uganda - Kenya border.
The scope of works for the Kapchorwa – Suam road construction project includes the tarmacking of the entire gravel road starting at Kapchorwa, moving west to Kween, then towards Bukwo and ending at Suam which is on the border of Kenya and Uganda. It also includes the construction of 20km town roads, 10 - foot bridges, one border post, 11 high standard bridges, 23 box culverts and 191 pipe culverts.

title: Kigali Central Sewerage System, Rwanda
body: The Water and Sanitation Corporation of Rwanda (WASAC) is undertaking the Kigali Central Sewerage project to enhance sanitation services in central Kigali. This initiative involves constructing a comprehensive sewerage system and wastewater treatment plant. The primary goal is to connect residents to a networked sanitation service, thereby improving public health resilience and protecting the environment, including the Kigali water catchments, the Nyabarongo River, and downstream ecosystems such as Lake Victoria. The wastewater treatment plant is set to have a capacity of 12,000 cubic meters per day.

title: New Mapulaneng Hospital, South Africa
body: Eris Property Group is leading the development of the New Mapulaneng Hospital in Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga. This state-of-the-art regional hospital will include a wide array of facilities such as outpatient and casualty departments, emergency medical services, an isolation ward, a surgical orthopaedic ward, and residential buildings. The hospital is set to be a key component of the District Health System in South Africa, which integrates comprehensive primary health care services through community-based programs, mobile or fixed clinics, and community health centres, with district hospitals playing a crucial role in this framework.

title: Kasomeno Mwenda Toll Road Project (KMTR), Zambia
body:
Agence Congolaise des Grands Travaux are planning to construct the Kasomeno Mwenda Toll Road Project (KMTR), which aims to enhance transportation and connectivity in Congo and Zambia. Its key components include:

1. Modernizing, constructing, and expanding 184km of highway.
2. Building a 345m cable-stayed bridge over the Luapula river border.
3. Establishing one-stop border posts with warehousing and parking facilities.
4. Implementing a tolling system and related infrastructure, along with social infrastructure for community development.

This project will significantly reduce travel distance for commercial transporters from Haut-Katanga’s mining sector in the DRC to the Port of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, by approximately 500 km.

title: Julius Nyerere Hydropower Plant, Tanzania
body:
Construct the Julius Nyerere Hydropower Station (JNHS), also known as the Rufiji Hydroelectric Power Project (RHHP) or Stiegler's Gorge Dam, on the Rufiji River in eastern Tanzania

The plant is expected to have an installed capacity of 2,115 MW (equivalent to 2,836,000 horsepower) and generate 5,920 GWh of electricity annually

The main works include constructing:

  • A main roller compacted concrete dam, with a total length of 1,025 metres at crest level and 130 metres at dam level
  • Four saddle dams with lengths of 1.4 km, 7.9 km, 4.6 km and 2.6 km and a capacity to impound 33 billion cubic metres of water
  • A power station with nine turbines, each with a capacity of 235MW
  • A 400 kV substation, with transmission lines linking to the national grid

Other civil works include the construction of:

  • About 21 km of permanent access roads and 59 km of temporary access roads
  • Administrative and control buildings, workshops and stores
  • A 660-metre-long diversion tunnel and two coffer dams
  • A permanent concrete bridge over the Rufiji River
  • A residential housing complex

Lot 1 covers 48 kilometers from Kenol to Sagana, while Lot 2 covers the stretch from Sagana to Marua. title: Bugesera (Kigali) International Airport, Rwanda
body:
Aviation Travel and Logistics (ATL) is currently developing Bugesera (Kigali) International Airport in Rwanda, situated approximately 23 kilometers southeast of Kigali. Spanning 2,500 hectares, the airport is planned in two phases. Upon completion of phase one, it will accommodate 8.2 million passengers and handle 150,000 tonnes of cargo annually. After phase two is finalized, the airport's capacity will increase to 14 million passengers and 300,000 tonnes of cargo per year.

The airport development project is planned in five phases, gradually expanding passenger and cargo capacity.

Phase 1:

  • Construction of a passenger terminal with:
    • 22 check-in counters
    • 6 security checkpoints
    • 10 gates with 6 passenger boarding bridges
    • 10 immigration counters (arrivals) & 10 emigration counters (departures)
  • A presidential terminal with conference and lounge areas
  • An air traffic control tower
  • Cargo terminal and aircraft maintenance facility
  • Parking area and airport rescue & fire-fighting facilities
  • A 4.2 km-long runway, designed to accommodate large commercial aircraft

Phase 1 Capacity:

  • 1.7 million passengers annually
  • 13,803 tonnes of cargo annually

Phases 2–5: (Future Expansions)

Phase 2:

  • Expansion of passenger and cargo terminals
  • Capacity: 2.52 million passengers & 19,542 tonnes of cargo

Phase 3:

  • Additional terminal expansions
  • Hotel construction
  • Capacity: 3.42 million passengers & 27,626 tonnes of cargo

Phase 4:

  • Further expansion of passenger and cargo facilities
  • Capacity: 4.48 million passengers & 39,434 tonnes of cargo

Phase 5: Final expansion phase

  • Capacity: 5.72 million passengers & 56,416 tonnes of cargo

title: Mpakeni Dam, Eswatini
body:
The Eswatini Water and Agricultural Development Enterprise is set to undertake the development of the Mpakeni Embankment Dam Project in the Shiselweni Region of southern Eswatini. This construction project encompasses a 67-meter-high clay-core rockfill dam, a 35-meter-wide rectangular spillway, intake towers, outlet control rooms, and diversion culverts.

The primary purpose of the dam is to provide irrigation, with additional considerations for flood control, water supply, and aquaculture. Upon completion, the dam will boast a storage capacity of approximately 120 million cubic meters and will facilitate irrigation for about 4,000 hectares of land.

title: Maun Water Supply and Sanitation Project: Phase 3, Botswana
body:
The Ministry of Land Management, Water, and Sanitation Services intends to develop Maun Phase 3 Water Supply and Sanitation Project of the in Matshwane and Moeti wards by building wastewater treatment plants.

These plants will treat wastewater in the Maun area, rendering it suitable for agricultural, construction, and domestic use, except for consumption. Contract 3 will focus on constructing water treatment plants in Matshwane and Moeti wards, facilitating the treatment of wastewater from Maun for distribution to communities. The treated water will be utilized for agricultural, construction, and domestic purposes, excluding consumption.

title: Kigali Green Complex (KGC), Rwanda
body: Ultimate Developers Ltd (UDL) will be developing the Kigali Green Complex (KGC) in Kigali, Rwanda. The building will comprise 29 storeys and a total of six basements, totaling 35 floors in the complex, making it the tallest building in Rwanda. Kigali Green Complex shall cover a gross floor area of 82,971 square meters. Furthermore, the Kigali Green Complex will be established on a plot of land occupying an area of 7,600 square meters. The Kigali Green Complex upon completion will have a total of 140 service apartment rooms, conference rooms, offices, entertainment and exhibition areas, in addition to cinema rooms, markets, shops, bars, and restaurants, forex bureaus, natural areas, children areas, playgrounds, pharmacies, clinics, and others.

title: Zarema Mayday Irrigation Dam, Ethiopia
body: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia will develop the Zarema Mayday irrigation dam in Tigray, Ethiopia, covering nearly a tenth of the size of Lake Tana, the country's largest lake. The main elements of the project include a 145.00m high embankment dam with a crest length of 730m, a cofferdam integrated into the main structure, a diversion conduit (currently under construction), a side channel spillway, an intake structure, an approach channel, and a Middle Level Outlet measuring 6.0/8.0m in width, situated on the left abutment. Upon completion, the dam is expected to store 3.5 billion cubic meters of water and reach a height of 152 meters.

title: Maun Water Supply and Sanitation Project: Phase 4, Botswana
body:
The Ministry of Land Management, Water, and Sanitation Services is undertaking the Maun Phase 4 Water Supply and Sanitation Project, which focuses on enhancing water sources and bulk water supply to Sexaxa, Matsaudi, and Shorobe villages. This phase includes constructing and installing pipelines connecting from the water point in Maun to these villages, ensuring an ample water supply for residents.

Phase 4 is closely linked with Contract 2, which involves connecting boreholes, water treatment, and storage facilities to the infrastructure supplying water to the external villages, extending from Sexaxa to Shorobe. The overall impact of this project is expected to improve water quality, increase water supply, and enhance sanitation services in Maun and the surrounding villages.

title: Masindi - Hoima - Kabwoya Roadways, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority(UNRA) has planned for Phase IV of the Road Sector Support Project, focusing on rehabilitating the Kigumba - Masindi - Hoima - Kabwoya road, a critical 238-kilometer transportation artery in western Uganda. This initiative aims to significantly improve access to the Albertine Graben region, benefiting the oil sector's development and enhancing opportunities in agriculture and tourism. By linking key towns and trading centers, the project will also establish a strategic connection between the northern corridor (including southwestern Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, and eastern DRC) and the Kampala-Gulu-Juba corridor. Its broader objectives include enhancing access to markets, social services, healthcare, and employment prospects for residents throughout the road's influence area.

title: Ohangwena II Wellfield Water Supply Schemes (WSS), Namibia
body: Namibian Water Corporation Limited is embarking on the development of the Ohangwena II Wellfield Water Supply Schemes in Ohangwena. This comprehensive project involves enhancing water supply infrastructure, equipping boreholes, expanding a Reverse Osmosis (RO) Plant, constructing brine disposal ponds, replacing and installing new pipelines, separating bulk and rural water supply lines, building elevated reservoirs, and constructing concrete groundwater reservoirs. The primary objective of this project is to meet the water demand projected for 2037 and enhance water supply reliability for the Omafo - Eenhana and Omakango - Onambutu - Eenhana Schemes, including Eenhana Town.

title: Kampala City Roads Rehabilitation Project (KCRRP), Uganda
body:
The Smart City initiative in Kampala is built on three core pillars: technology, infrastructure, and people. As part of this vision, the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) is planning to refurbish 270 kilometers of city roads.

The primary objective of the project is to to enhance transport efficiency thereby enabling the City of Kampala to maximize agglomerative benefits of access and improved attractiveness resulting from reduced traffic congestion through upgrade and expansion of road network; and

To improve air quality in the city through implementation of Scheduled Eco - Bus transit Services and broadening travel choices for non - vehicular movements within Kampala by expanding networks of walkways and cycling tracks.

Project Overview

The project involves the comprehensive upgrading, reconstruction, dualling, and signalization of roads across multiple divisions within Kampala, Uganda. The works are divided into five distinct lots covering various areas including Lubaga, Makindye, Nakawa, Kawempe, and Central divisions.

Scope of Work by Lot

Lot 1: Lubaga and Makindye

  • Upgrade of 8.07 km of roads to paved standard
  • Reconstruction of 6.83 km of roads
  • Signalization of 7 junctions

Lot 2: Nakawa

  • Reconstruction and dualling of Port Bell and Spring Roads (total 10.01 km)
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 3: Makindye, Central, Kawempe, and Lubaga

  • Reconstruction of 18.84 km of roads
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 4: Kawempe, Lubaga, Makindye, and Central

  • Asphalting of 3.94 km
  • Reconstruction of 8.10 km
  • Dualling of 3.90 km
  • Signalization of 5 junctions

Lot 5: Lubaga

  • Upgrading of 9.54 km of roads
  • Reconstruction of 6.72 km
  • Signalization of 5 junctions
  • Channelization of drainage on 3.9 km section

title: Berg River Voëlvlei Dam Augmentation Scheme (BRVAS), South Africa
body:
The Trans - Caledon Tunnel Authority (TCTA) is set to develop the Berg River Voëlvlei Dam Augmentation Scheme (BRVAS). This project involves multiple components, including abstraction works on the Berg River, featuring a diversion weir, sediment traps, and a 5 MW pump station. Additionally, a 6.3 km bulk water pipeline will be constructed from the Berg River to Voëlvlei Dam.

Appurtenant works such as a canoe - fishway chute, a saddle embankment for flood risk management, an access road, and the installation of electricity supply and associated infrastructure to power the new pump station are also part of the project.

title: Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kisoro - Mgahinga Roads Upgrade, Uganda
body:
The Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kisoro - Mgahinga Road Project in South - western Uganda aims to upgrade two vital road links prioritized in the National Development Plan 2020/21 - 2024/25. These roads, the Kabale - Lake Bunyonyi - Kabeho circuit and the Kisoro - Mgahinga Park Gates road, are crucial for tourism development and regional accessibility.
With the region's rich environment and wildlife as major tourist attractions, the project focuses on upgrading 34 kilometers of roads to bituminous standards. Additionally, it includes the construction of four landing sites on Lake Bunyonyi, two roadside markets, and farm produce holding facilities. The provision of two ferries and search and rescue boats will enhance water transportation options.

title: Fourth Mainland Bridge, Nigeria
body: The Lagos State Government is constructing the Fourth Mainland Bridge, a 38 km bridge in Nigeria. The bridge will connect Lagos Island via Langbasa (Lekki) and Baiyeku (Ikorodu) across the Lagos Lagoon to Itamaga in Ikorodu. The project scope includes three toll plazas, nine interchanges, and a 4.5 km lagoon bridge. The bridge structure will also feature a 2 x 4 lane carriageway cross-sectional road, with provisions for a BRT Lane and future road expansion. When completed, the Fourth Mainland Bridge will be the longest bridge in Africa, surpassing the 6th October Bridge (20.5 km) in Cairo, Egypt, and the Third Mainland Bridge (11.8 km) in Lagos.

title: New Kampala-Jinja Expressway, Uganda
body:
Build the new Kampala-Jinja Expressway (KJE), which is part of the Northern Corridor linking Kenya’s Port of Mombasa to the landlocked countries of Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) 

Work will be undertaken in phases over five years and involves building a toll expressway routed to the south of the existing Kampala–Jinja Highway, starting from Ntinda/Kyambogo, through Namagunga and Namataba to Jinja

The road will be built in three sections:

  • Section 1: Build the Kampala Southern Bypass, which is a 20 km dual-carriage urban expressway with four lanes forming a bypass to the south of Kampala City; design speed will be up to 100 km per hour. Over 12 km of road will traverse through swamps and be elevated on a viaduct. The route will allow connection to junctions through four interchanges and roads over bridges for links. It is expected partly to be fenced to allow limited access with lighting and provisions for toll plazas

     

  • Section 2: Build the 35 km first section of the Kampala-Jinja Expressway from Kampala to Namagunga as a dual-carriage urban expressway with six lanes; design speed will be up to 120 km per hour 

 

  • Section 3: Build the 41 km second section of the expressway from Namagunga to Njeru at the new Nile bridge as a dual-carriage urban expressway with four lanes; design speed will be up to 120 km per hour 
     

The overall scope includes building about 16 interchanges, 11 toll plazas, 12 km of service roads, 30 km of link roads, 5 km of viaducts, 18 pedestrian over-bridges/underpasses, 54 vehicular over-bridges/underpasses and one rest area in each direction of the expressway
 

All sections will be undertaken under the design, build, finance, operate, maintain and transfer (DBFOT) model for a 30-year concession term. The project is to be delivered as one holistic corridor project over a five-year construction period.

 

The proposed route corridor largely follows virgin terrain on the southern part of the existing Kampala-Jinja road through Munyonyo, Bunga, Mutungo, Butabika, Mbalala and Namagunga up to Njeru, where it links with the Source of the Nile Bridge. 

 

The project provides seamless connectivity between the Kampala Northern Bypass and the Kampala-Entebbe Expressway spur to Munyonyo through the Kampala Southern Bypass, which will provide a complete ring road around Kampala City. 

 

The project also links with 10 existing major roads along the corridor, including the Mukono-Katosi road, to enable connectivity with existing and future developments.

body: Tanzania National Roads Agency (Tanroads) will upgrade Sumbawanga Airport in Tanzania's Sumbawanga. The project involves extending the current 1,516-meter-long, 30 - meter - wide gravel - level runway to 1,750 meters. Additionally, it includes expanding and renovating the runway, constructing a new passenger terminal, taxiway, aircraft apron, access roads, car park, security fence, and installing a new navigation aid lighting system.

title: Kigongo–Busisi Bridge, Tanzania
body:
Tanroads is gearing up to construct the Kigongo - Busisi Bridge, which will stretch across a 30 - kilometer inlet in the Gulf of Mwanza on the southern shore of Lake Victoria, linking Kigongo and Busisi. This pivotal infrastructure endeavor aims to establish a vital road link between Tanzania and neighboring nations like Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Burundi.

The project comprises two key components: bridge works and road works. The bridge works entail constructing an extra - dosed bridge spanning a total length of 3 kilometers, including the approach section, across a gulf on Lake Victoria. Meanwhile, the road works component involves widening 1.66 kilometers of the existing road from 2 lanes to 4 lanes. Furthermore, 1.16 kilometers will be constructed on the Kigongo side and 0.5 kilometers on the Busisi side. The approach roads seamlessly integrate with the existing surfaced road leading to the bridge.

title: Lusaka - Ndola Dual Carriage Road, Zambia
body:
The Government of Zambia (GRZ) is embarking on the development of the Lusaka-Ndola Dual Carriageway, a crucial economic route in the nation. This initiative involves constructing a 327km dual-carriageway connecting Lusaka and Ndola. Additionally, it encompasses the rehabilitation of the 45km Luanshya - Fisenge -Masangano road, which has been neglected for years. The overarching goal is to bolster transportation infrastructure, foster economic development, and tackle longstanding road maintenance issues in Zambia.

Key Components

  • Construction of a 327 km New Carriageway between Lusaka and Ndola
  • Rehabilitation of the Existing 327 km Carriageway on the same route
  • Bypass Construction:
    • 20 km bypass in Kapiri Mposhi
    • 20 km bypass in Kabwe
  • Rehabilitation of a 45 km Road Section from Masangano to Luanshya (M006)
  • Construction of Toll Plazas for efficient revenue collection and road maintenance
  • Construction of Weighbridges to regulate axle loads and protect road infrastructure

title: Landmark Waterview Apartments, Nigeria
body:
Landmark Group is preparing to launch the Landmark Waterview Apartments, a residential project located along Water Corporation Road in Oniru, Lagos. This impressive structure will stand tall at 28 floors, covering a gross lettable area of 36,000 square meters and offering a total of 306 luxury apartments. The residential options will vary from studio apartments and 1–4 bedroom units to 3 & 5 bedroom penthouses.

Landmark Waterview Apartments is meticulously designed to serve as a centralized leisure hub, providing residents with access to a plethora of amenities including a gymnasium, swimming pool, children’s pool, clubhouse, games room, outdoor lounge, and children’s play area. This development aims to deliver a premium living experience in the vibrant city of Lagos.

title: National Route 7 Section 3 Improvement, South Africa
body:
The South African National Roads Agency SOC Limited (SANRAL) will be Improving of National Route 7 Section 3 of 33.37 Km from Piketberg (km 31.53) to Piekenierskloof Pass (km 65.30). This project is in the province of the Western Cape in the district municipality of the West Coast and local municipality of Bergrivier.The proposed project mainly entails the provision of additional climbing / passing lanes and widening the road
and associated infrastructure in certain areas. The existing carriageway would be widened to the following cross-sections:1)Where no climbing lanes are provided: two 3.7 m-wide lanes and two 3.5 m-wide shoulders;2 )Where a climbing lane is provided on one side only: a 1.5 m-wide shoulder (1.0 m surfaced) with 3.5mwide slow lane and 3.7 m-wide fast lane. The side without the climbing lane would have a 3.7 m-widelane and a 3.5 m-wide shoulder (3.0 m surfaced); and In instances where climbing lanes are provided on both sides: each side would have a 1.5 m-wideshoulder (1.0 m surfaced) with a 3.5 m-wide slow lane and a 3.7 m-wide fast lane.

title: National Route N11 Section 9 Improvement, South Africa
body:
The Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) is undertaking the upgrading of the Tanzania-Zambia Railway which serves as a critical transportation link between the neighboring countries of Zambia and Tanzania. This cross-border railway spans a distance of 1160 kilometers connecting Kapiri-Mposhi in Zambia with the port of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania.

The upgrading project aims to enhance the efficiency capacity and reliability of the railway infrastructure to meet the growing demands of freight and passenger transportation between the two countries. This may involve various improvements such as track rehabilitation modernization of signaling and communication systems expansion of railway stations and terminals and upgrades to rolling stock and locomotives.

title: United Capital Fertilizer Plant: Phase 2, Zambia
body: United Capital Fertilizer Zambia Company Limited is preparing to embark on the construction of Phase 2 of its ultra-modern Urea fertilizer and Ammonia plant in Chilanga, Zambia. The facility is designed to boast a production capacity of 135,000 metric tonnes per annum for fertilizer and 80,000 metric tonnes per annum for ammonia bicarbonate. Notably, the plant will feature an advanced integrated cross-circuit production process aimed at eliminating emissions of smoke or gases. Instead, any smoke generated will be transformed into a valuable gas by-product, ensuring sustainability and fulfilling existing market demand for this resource.

title: Millennium Tower and Cultural Center, Nigeria
body: The Federal Government is currently in the planning phase for the Millennium Tower which is set to become a central element of the Nigeria National Complex in Abuja. Rising to an impressive height of 170 meters the Millennium Tower features three concrete cylinders that support a revolving Panoramic Restaurant and Belvedere located 110 meters above the ground. This iconic structure symbolizes unity and strength and is poised to become a prominent landmark in Abuja's skyline. With powerful laser spotlights illuminating it the tower will be visible from up to 50 kilometers away from the city center.

title: Purple Lekki, Nigeria
body: Purple Lekki is currently in the planning stages of an ambitious 8-floor development covering an estimated 12,000 square meters in gross leasable area. This dynamic project aims to provide a wide array of services including commercial retail hospitality and entertainment offerings. The ground floor of the development will feature an open-space retail section offering modular-sized spaces ranging from 3 square meters to 16 square meters as well as larger retail spaces ranging from 30 square meters to 50 square meters.

title: Mombasa Gateway Bridge, Kenya
body: The Kenya National Highways Authority (KeNHA) has announced the construction of the Mombasa Gateway Bridge in Kenya. This cable-stayed bridge will stretch approximately 4 kilometers in length, featuring a main span of 660 meters, which will make it the longest bridge in Africa. It will accommodate four regular traffic lanes and will rise to a height of 69 meters at its center to allow passage for seacraft beneath it. The bridge is designed with three spans supported by four piers on each side, forming a robust arch structure for enhanced strength and durability.

Covering an extensive area of 30000 square meters this initiative marks Ethiopia's entry into the global Bitcoin mining sector as a significant player. The establishment of this state-of-the-art data center is expected to bring substantial economic advantages to the country.

title: BUA Office Building, Nigeria
body: BUA Group is currently planning the development of a 10-floor office complex located on Churchgate Street adjacent to Churchgate 1 and 2 Towers. This property which had its structural framework completed but remained abandoned for several years is now under the ownership of BUA Group. The conglomerate has acquired the site with the aim of commencing remedial works including cladding to revitalize it into their new headquarters.

title: Riruta - Ngong' Commuter Railway Line, Kenya
body: The Kenya Railways Corporation is set to embark on the construction of the Riruta – Ngong commuter rail line with the aim of alleviating road congestion and reducing transportation costs in Nairobi. This new rail line will connect with the existing railway line in the residential suburb of Riruta and will extend over a distance of 12.5 kilometers through Karen and Bulbul to reach Ngong situated to the southwest of Nairobi.

title: N3 Ashburton Interchange, South Africa
body:
The South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL) is embarking on the development of the N3 Ashburton Interchange in KwaZulu-Natal. This ambitious project involves expanding the existing infrastructure from four to six and eight lanes on the Camperdown to Ashburton Interchanges respectively. The primary objective is to address chronic traffic congestion and enhance overall mobility safety and efficiency resulting in reduced travel times. Key components of the project include the reconstruction and upgrade of the existing N3 northbound and southbound carriageways from a two-lane configuration with climbing lanes to a four-lane configuration with climbing lanes. Additionally the project entails the demolition of the existing Ashburton bridge and the construction of a new bridge to accommodate the widened highway. Interchange improvements including enhancements to ramps and crossroads along with the construction of supporting structures are also part of the comprehensive plan.

Scope of Work

Main N3 Highway Expansion

  • Upgrade from 2 lanes + climbing lane to 4 lanes + climbing lanes in both directions.
  • Expansion from 4 to 6 or 8 lanes between Camperdown and Ashburton interchanges.
  • Addition of auxiliary lanes at on- and off-ramps.
  • Construction of median barriers throughout.

Interchange Reconstruction

  • Full rebuild of Ashburton Interchange, including all ramps to meet SANRAL’s geometric standards.
  • Cleland Overpass bridge to be demolished and not replaced.
  • Ashburton bridge to be demolished and rebuilt to fit the expanded highway.

Bridge & Road Infrastructure

  • All associated bridges to be lengthened to accommodate new lane configurations.
  • Significant shale-cutting, excavation, and blasting on both sides of the N3 to create space.

R103 Alternative Route (Approx. 7 km)

  • Upgrade and rehabilitation to be completed prior to N3 lane width reduction.
  • Pope Ellis Drive to CB Downes Drive section to be widened:
    • Cycle lane
    • Climbing lane (~3 km)
    • Expansion from 2 to 4 lanes (with sidewalks)
meta_description: The South African National Roads Agency Limited (SANRAL) is embarking on the development of the N3 Ashburton Interchange in KwaZulu-Natal. This ambitious project involves expanding the existing infrastructure from four to six and eight lanes on the Camperdown to Ashburton Interchanges respectively. The primary objective is to address chronic traffic congestion and enhance overall mobility safety and efficiency resulting in reduced travel times.
migration_status: success

title: Kranzberg - Tsumeb Railway Upgrade, Namibia
body: TransNamib Holdings Limited is preparing for a significant railway upgrade project in Tsumeb, Namibia. Recently assessed, the project focuses on enhancing the Kranzberg-Tsumeb railway, a crucial 400-mile corridor linking Namibia with Zambia, Angola, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). This vital transportation route connects the port of Walvis Bay to northern Namibia, facilitating trade for major industries like Ohorongo Cement and Dundee Precious Metals (Copper). Annually, 330,000 tonnes of sulphuric acid, a by-product of copper extraction, is transported from northern Namibia's Uranium mines back to Walvis Bay via this railway. Originally converted from a 600 mm to a 1067 mm gauge in the 1960s, the line was constructed to branch line standards, featuring 30Kg/m jointed flat bottom rails on steel sleepers with through T-Bolt fastening systems and minimal ballast. Rails ranging from 12m (40ft) to 36m (120ft) are joined by fishplates to accommodate expansion and contraction.

title: N2/N3 EB Cloete Interchange Improvement, South Africa
body:
The South African National Roads Agency SOC Limited (SANRAL) is undertaking the N2/N3 EB Cloete Interchange Improvements Project in KwaZulu-Natal. This extensive project involves upgrading both the N2 and N3 highways.

The N2 upgrade will span a 55km stretch from Lovu River on the South Coast to Umdloti on the North Coast while the N3 upgrade will focus on an 80km section from Durban to Pietermaritzburg. These upgrades will include widening the carriageways of both highways to accommodate four or five lanes in each direction.

title: Windhoek Solar Farm, Namibia
body:
Witputz Energy (Pty) Ltd. is poised to undertake the construction of a 100 MW solar farm in Windhoek. The project aims to be connected to one of NamPower’s major substations facilitating accessibility of the generated electricity to industrial energy users including mining companies regional electricity distributors and NamPower.

Furthermore a portion of the power generated at the solar plant is planned to be exported to the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP). This initiative underscores efforts to expand renewable energy sources and contribute to regional electricity supply.

title: Marsabit Wind Power Plant, Kenya
body: The Kenya Electricity Generating Company Plc (KenGen) is embarking on the construction of a Wind Power Plant in Marsabit Kenya. This ambitious project known as the Marsabit Wind Power Plant is set to become the second-largest wind power plant in Kenya boasting a capacity of 200 Megawatts. It forms a crucial part of KenGen's commitment to fully green the national grid by the year 2030. The first phase will generate 200 Megawatts and the power generation is set to increase into other three phases of the wind power project. This project represents a significant step towards Kenya's renewable energy goals and underscores KenGen's dedication to sustainable energy production.

title: National Route 2 (N2) Section 7 Kraaibosch - Touw River Upgrade, South Africa
body: The South African National Roads Agency Ltd (SANRAL) is set to enhance National Route 2 (N2) Section 7 commencing from Kraaibosch (Km 28.60) just east of George and extending to Touw River (Km 36.80). The stretch covers a distance of 8 kilometers in the Western Cape province within the Garden Route District Municipality. The project scope entails reparation of pavement failures and various intersections construction of new accesses frontage roads bus stops and widening of the N2 in certain locations slope stabilization works and installation of streetlights.

title: Menengai II Geothermal Power Station, Kenya
body: Globeleq, an independent power producer headquartered in London, United Kingdom, is developing the Menengai II Geothermal Power Station, a 35 MW (47,000 hp) facility currently under construction in Kenya. The project, located in Nakuru County, is a collaborative effort between Globeleq and Kenya’s state-owned Geothermal Development Co. (GDC). Both entities are preparing to launch construction of the geothermal power station.

title: Wits Brian & Dorothy Zylstra Sports Complex, South Africa
body:
The Zylstra family in partnership with the Skye Foundation is poised to embark on an ambitious project to construct a Sports Complex in Johannesburg South Africa. The proposed Brian and Dorothy Zylstra Sports Complex will serve as a comprehensive facility dedicated to training research and clinical practice in sports. The project encompasses three main components:

Zylstra Sport and Health Building: This facility will house state-of-the-art training facilities research labs and sports science amenities providing athletes with the resources they need to excel in their respective disciplines.

Zylstra Aquatics and Rowing Centre: The complex will include an aquatic centre and rowing facilities catering to athletes involved in water sports and rowing disciplines.

Zylstra Residence: An accommodation facility will be provided for 44 elite athletes ensuring they have comfortable lodging while pursuing their athletic endeavors.

This integrated sports complex aims to elevate the standard of sports training and research in the region fostering excellence and innovation in the field of athletics.

title: Kenya Off-Grid Solar Access Project (KOSAP), Kenya
body:
The Kenya Off-Grid Solar Access Project (KOSAP) represents a key initiative of the Ministry of Energy backed by funding from the World Bank. Its primary objective is to extend electricity and clean cooking solutions to remote low-density and traditionally underserved areas of Kenya. As part of the government's commitment to achieving universal access to electricity by 2022 and advancing Vision 2030 KOSAP plays a crucial role in driving growth and development in the country.

Under Component 2 of the project Results-based Financing (RBF) and Debt Facilities have been established to incentivize private sector companies to operate and distribute solar and clean cooking solutions in targeted areas. The goal is to provide 250000 stand-alone solar home systems and higher-tier clean cooking solutions to 150000 households. SNV Netherlands Development Organisation in collaboration with SunFunder Inc. serves as the Facilities Managers for these initiatives.

In addition to Component 2 KOSAP comprises three other components:
1.Mini-grids for Community Facilities Enterprises and Households (Component 1)
2.Stand-alone Solar Systems and Solar Water Pumps for Community Facilities (Component 3)
3.Implementation Support and Capacity Building (Component 4)

Kenya Power and Lighting Co. (KPLC) and the Rural Electrification and Renewable Energy Corporation (REREC) are responsible for implementing Components 1 and 3 respectively. Meanwhile the Ministry of Energy oversees the implementation of KOSAP as a whole and is specifically responsible for Component 4 in addition to being the implementing agency for the RBF and Debt Facilities under Component 2.
meta_description: The Kenya Off-Grid Solar Access Project (KOSAP) represents a key initiative of the Ministry of Energy backed by funding from the World Bank. Its primary objective is to extend electricity and clean cooking solutions to remote low-density and traditionally underserved areas of Kenya. As part of the government's commitment to achieving universal access to electricity by 2022 and advancing Vision 2030 KOSAP plays a crucial role in driving growth and development in the country.

title: Kusile Coal - Fired Power Project, South Africa
body: Eskom Holdings SOC plans to construct the Kusile power station in Mpumalanga, South Africa. Designed with six 800MW generating units, Kusile will be one of the largest coal-fired power plants globally, boasting a total capacity of 4.8GW. It will also be the first South African coal plant to use advanced wet FGD (Flue Gas Desulfurization) technology.

title: Zambezia Bridge, Mozambique
body: The Mozambique government has unveiled plans to build a new 1.7-kilometer bridge over the Licungo River in Zambezia province to replace the current crossing, which has been in use since the 1940s. The new bridge will be positioned 5000 meters downstream and will be connected to the N1 highway by 16 kilometers of new access roads. This project aims to modernize the region's infrastructure, improve transportation links, and create a bypass to divert traffic from the city of Mocuba.

title: Tete Solar Power Plant, Mozambique
body:
Ncondezi Energy is moving forward with plans to construct a Solar Power Plant in Tete Mozambique. The energy producer recently obtained the Right to Land Use Planning (DUAT) from the Mozambican government. The approval grants Ncondezi permission to develop its project on a 950-hectare site located in the province of Tete situated in western Mozambique. The 300 MW project will be built in two stages. For the first 100 MW phase the company will use existing infrastructure. It is planning new infrastructure for the remaining 200 MW.
According to the company the site allocated by the Mozambican government has the capacity to accommodate a 500 MW solar plant. This development marks a significant milestone in the advancement of renewable energy infrastructure in Mozambique and underscores Ncondezi's commitment to sustainable energy solutions.

  • Football and basketball courts
  • An 80-room boutique hotel
  • Retail spaces (including sustainable shops made from repurposed shipping containers)
  • Co-working spaces
  • A podcasting hub and studio

title: Adenta - Dodowa Road, Ghana
body: The Ministry of Roads and Highways in Ghana is undertaking the development of the Adenta-Dodowa road, a major project spanning 22 kilometers that will include interchanges and flyovers at key intersections to enhance connectivity and ease commuting for residents and motorists. The Adentan-Dodowa road, a crucial link in the Greater Accra Region, has faced several delays and complications, attributed by the Minister to issues with the previous contractor and new developments along the corridor. Despite these setbacks, the government is committed to ensuring the project's timely completion to improve transportation and stimulate economic growth in the area.

title: Ashaiman - Akosombo Road, Ghana
body:
The Ministry of Roads & Highways is embarking on a major transportation infrastructure upgrade, focusing on the 64km Ashaiman to Akosombo Junction Road Project as part of the Eastern Corridor Road upgrading (Lot 1). This initiative includes constructing a dual carriageway from the Ashaiman Roundabout to Akosombo Junction, along with a flyover at the Ashaiman Roundabout, an interchange at Asutsuare Junction, eleven pedestrian footbridges, three river bridges, and ancillary works like drainage structures and walkways. The project aims to modernize the road network, improve traffic flow, enhance connectivity, and ensure safer travel conditions for motorists and pedestrians alike.

Ashaiman - Akosombo Road Dualization Project (64 km), also known as Ashaiman Roundabout - Akosombo Junction Road Project. 

  • Ashaiman to Sebrepor Section
    • Two-lane dual carriageway

title: Western Railway Line, Ghana
body: The Government of Ghana has announced plans to develop the Western Railway Line, which will span a total of 299 kilometers. This railway line will stretch from the Ghanaian city of Kumasi to the port of Takoradi in the Ashanti Region. This vital railway facilitates the movement of goods and passengers, supporting the transport of minerals from mining regions and aiding agricultural distribution. Ongoing efforts to modernize and upgrade the infrastructure aim to enhance efficiency and service quality.

title: Vodacom Mpumalanga Network Expansion, South Africa
body: Vodacom is making major moves to improve connectivity in South Africa’s Mpumalanga province. The telecoms giant recently announced plans to invest over R450 million in the region this financial year, aiming to deliver “best-in-class coverage and customer service. The investment will boost Vodacom’s 3G and 4G population coverage to 99.62% and 99.14% respectively. The company has also increased its 5G sites to 109, reaching 29.81% of Mpumalanga’s population. As a result, 13% of data traffic is now carried over 5G, allowing customers to benefit from next-generation speeds.

title: Zim Cyber City, Zimbabwe
body:
Zimbabwe Global Investments (ZGI), operates under the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) program. planning to construct a smart city named Zim Cyber City marks the inaugural venture of Mulk International Real Estate in Zimbabwe.

Zim Cyber City is a state-of-the-art mixed-use development project. Sprawled across a 2.5 million square foot space, it is currently under construction in Mount Hampden, New Harare. Mount Hampden’s master plan includes the newly completed Parliament building, all ministry buildings, as well as high-end residential and commercial buildings.

The master plan of the project includes 250 townhouses, more than 80 luxury villas, a number of apartment blocks, hi-tech office facilities, a high-end retail arcade, a 15-storeyed commercial tower, and landscaped gardens – all within a high-security gated community with a health club, community center, and other facilities.

title: Vungu Multi-Purpose Dam, Zimbabwe
body:
The Zimbabwe National Water Authority is currently planning the construction of the Vungu Dam Water Treatment and Irrigation project in the Midlands Silobela district. This comprehensive project aims to address water needs for both consumption and irrigation while also accommodating a fisheries project. Additionally the project includes the installation of a mini hydro plant to generate electricity.

The scope of the project encompasses the construction of the dam which will span 2.6 kilometers in length and stand at a height of 30 meters. Furthermore a spillway measuring 120 meters will be constructed as part of the project. Once completed the dam will have a capacity to irrigate over 1200 hectares of land utilizing water from a reservoir with a capacity of 118 million cubic meters. This project is poised to significantly enhance water resources and agricultural productivity in the region upon its completion.

title: Msenge Emoyeni Wind Farm, South Africa
body: Msenge Emoyeni (RF) (Pty) Ltd is undertaking the establishment of a 72 MW wind turbine farm in Bedford. This pioneering project involves the construction of South Africa's first utility-scale private wind farm located near Bedford in the Eastern Cape. The energy generated will originate from the Msenge wind farm situated approximately 200 km north of Gqeberha in the Eastern Cape region. The Msenge Emoyeni wind farm represents a significant milestone as the first grid-connected private wind farm in South Africa. Upon completion it will comprise 16 Goldwind 4.5MW turbines.

title: West African Power Pool Côte d'Ivoire-Liberia Interconnection, Cote d’Ivoire
body:
The West African Power Pool (WAPP) is embarking on a significant project to construct 650 kilometers of 225 kV transmission lines.

These lines will serve to connect the cities of San Pedro in Côte d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast) with Buchanan and Greenville in Liberia. Additionally the transmission lines will facilitate the connection to the future 220 MW hydroelectric project located on the Cavally River bridging the energy networks between the two countries.

title: Sports Center of Excellence, Tanzania
body:

Lot 1: This includes the construction of a student hostel cafeteria classrooms an indoor sports building external works and playing grounds.

title: Stellantis Automotive Manufacturing Facility, South Africa
body: Stellantis is gearing up to establish a cutting-edge vehicle manufacturing facility in Coega, South Africa. Scheduled to kick off production in early 2026, the facility's first offering will be a one-ton bakkie, anticipated to yield up to 50,000 units annually for both local and international markets. However, due to space limitations and the capacity of the paint plant, the facility's maximum output is capped at 90,000 units per year.

title: Trans-Volta Logistics Project, Ghana
body: The Trans-Volta Logistics Project is a multimodal corridor being developed by LMI Holdings to transport containers and bulk cargo from the Port of Tema to Ouagadougou via Lake Volta. The Project will involve the construction of 2 new ports on the Lake at Mpakadan Akwamu-Korankye in the Eastern Region (Southern arm) and Debre in the Savannah Region (Northern arm). The project also encompasses the development of an industrial park at Debre.

title: Stoni Athi Waterfront City Residential Development, Kenya
body: Kenya's National Housing Corporation and Epco Builders have joined forces in a joint venture to develop the Stoni Athi Waterfront City in Mavoko, Machakos, Kenya. This expansive project spans 150 acres and encompasses a diverse range of amenities and housing options. It includes 5,000 affordable housing units priced between Ksh1 million and Ksh3 million each, catering to lower-income households, as well as 5,500 units targeting middle and upper-income brackets, ranging from Ksh2 million to Ksh8 million per unit. The development is designed as a mixed-use community, featuring residential, commercial, recreational, educational, and healthcare facilities to meet the needs of its residents.

title: Trans - Zambezi Railway Extension, Namibia
body: Namibia's Ministry of Works and Transport will be developing the Trans- Zambezi Railway Extension from Grootfontein - Rundu - Katima Mulilo via Rundu.The proposed Grootfontein-Rundu-Katima Mulilo line will run for 772km and will feature 35 stations, although it will be predominantly used for freight. The stations are intended to facilitate the bypassing of trains on the single line track. It will be a Cape gauge (1,067mm) railway to ensure compatibility with other lines in the region, but the study suggested that the substructure of bridges be built to standard gauge specifications to future proof the railway. The freight trains will run at 80km/h.

title: Upgrade of Kitai – Lituhi Road: Lot 1, Tanzania
body:
Tanroads is actively advancing plans for the upgrading of the Kitai – Lituhi Road spanning a total of 84.5 kilometers to Bitumen Standard. Lot 1 specifically addresses the Amanimakoro – Ruanda Section covering 35 kilometers.

This project road serves as a crucial link connecting the coal dry port in Amani Mokoro Village to the coal mining center at Ruanda Village. The comprehensive initiative encompasses the construction of four bridges along with several box culverts and pipe culverts to enhance the overall infrastructure and connectivity.
