title: Tunduma - Vwawa Water Supply Project, Tanzania
body:
The Ministry of Water is formulating plans for the Design and Build of the Tunduma-Vwawa Water Supply Project through Engineering Procurement Construction and Financing (EPC+F). The project entails the following components:

a. Design and construction of a Raw Water Intake at Momba River to cater to the water demand of Tunduma and Vwawa Mlowo Towns until 2045. The intake is designed to have a capacity of 97441 m³/day.

b. Development of a Raw Water Pumping Station Water Treatment Plant with a capacity of 94518 m³/day and two Treated/Clear Water Reservoirs each with a capacity of 1000 m³.

c. Installation of seven storage tanks with varying capacities ranging from 1000 m³/day to 30000 m³/day.

d. Establishment of four Booster Pumping Stations to convey water from the intake to the storage tanks.

e. Implementation of Raw water transmission through 118.597 km of steel pipes varying in diameter from DN500 PN16 up to DN1200 PN40 connecting the intake to Tunduma and Vwawa.

This comprehensive project aims to improve water supply infrastructure ensuring sustainable and efficient access to water for the specified towns until the year 2045.

title: Takoradi Floating Dock Ship Repair Facility, Ghana
body: Prime Meridian Docks AssetCo Ltd (PMD) is planning to build a modern floating dock ship repair facility in Ghana’s western Takoradi port. The scope of the Project consists of (i) the construction of a 200-meter jetty adjacent to the floating dock pocket, (ii) dredging of 300,000 cubic meters of rock from the seabed within the port basin, (iii) procuring and installing a 13,500-ton lift capacity floating dock, and (iv) setting-up an integrated workshop comprising main offices (management, client, engineering, logistics, accounts administration and IT offices), a main warehouse, steel and pipe fabrication workshop, mechanical and electrical workshop, blasting and painting, and an equipment maintenance shop. The facility targets various types of vessels: container vessels, bulk carriers, tankers, drilling rigs, as well as offshore support vessels. The repair and maintenance scope includes dockage, hull part, engine works, electrical, and general and auxiliary services.

title: Talanta Sports Complex, Kenya
body:
The Kenyan government is constructing the Talanta Sports Complex for the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) 2027

The 60,000 seater stadium facility will be located at the Jamhuri grounds in Nairobi 

The stadium will have a total built-up area of 94,150 square metres and outdoor training facilities, including a standard athletics track, football field and shared rugby pitch

It will be 54 metres high at its highest point and will have parking for 3,000 vehicles

title: Uvinza-Musongati Standard-Gauge Railway, Tanzania and Burundi
body:
Build a 282 km electrified standard gauge railway (SGR) line from Uvinza in Tanzania (off the Tabora-Kigoma SGR line) across the international border along the Malagarasi river to Musongati. The implementation period is 72 months, including a 12-month waiting period 

About 240 km will be main line and 42 km will be bypass line

  • Lot 1 consists of a 180 km stretch of railway in Tanzania from Uvinza to the Malagarasi border, including an 800-metre bridge across the river, earthworks, bridges, culverts, viaducts, ballasting and laying of tracks, installation of telecommunication systems, construction of stations, electrification and environmental and social actions, according to specifications
  • Lot 2 consists of the 102 km Burundi section from the Malagarasi border to the Musongati mine  fields, where there will be significant freight sidings and where the control station of the Burundi SGR, including a marshalling yard, will be built, including rehabilitation of Rutana hospital 

According to the Tanzania Railways Corporation, work includes building a bridge connecting Tanzania and Burundi designed to carry rail and road traffic, 1 km long, with about seven stations and one freight terminal in the Musongati area. 

Project Scope

  • Mainline Length: 282 km
  • Siding/Passing Loops: 85 km
  • Electrified Standard Gauge Railway (SGR)

Lot Breakdown

  • Lot 1 (Tanzania Section): Uvinza to Malagarasi (156 km)
  • Lot 2 (Burundi Section): Malagarasi to Musongati–Gitega (126 km)
    • Package A: Malagarasi to Musongati (80 km)
    • Package B: Musongati to Gitega (46 km)

title: Amahoro National Stadium Upgrade, Rwanda
body: The Government of Rwandan is upgrading the Amahoro National Stadium in Kigali. The project will expand the stadium's capacity from 25,000 seats to a FIFA-standard 45,000-seat arena and the roof will cover all the stands. The stadium will retain the athletics track and oval shape. The upgrade transformation will also include a hybrid grass pitch, spacious VIP skyboxes, commercial premises and comprehensive accessibility improvements.

title: Seriti Greens Wind Farm, South Africa
body:
The Seriti Reseources plans to construct the phase 1 of the Wind Farm at Mpumalanga. The project scope encompasses construction of the 155 MW which is the phase one of the 900 MW Mpumalanga wind farm South Africa’s largest of its kind is about to start in the heart of the country’s coal industry.
The first phase of a larger ~900MW renewable energy cluster called Ummbila Emoyeni located between Bethal and Morgenzon in Mpumalanga. Ummbila Emoyeni is a combination of 750 MW wind energy facilities and 150 MW solar PV plants. The entire project has been designated as a Strategic Integrated Project by the Department of Public Works and Infrastructure.

title: Shauri Moyo Estate Nairobi, Kenya
body:
Kenya's State Department for Housing and Urban Development is developing the Shauri Moyo Estate in Nairobi. The project will be constructed on a 15.7-acre piece of land and will include the following residential units: 348 studio units, 696 one-bedroom units, 1,740 two-bedroom units, and 1,044 three-bedroom units. Additionally, the project will feature 728 commercial units.

Social infrastructure will be a key component of the development, including a social hall, upgrading of the nearby school with an additional 16 classrooms, a commercial center, playgrounds, and parking spaces to accommodate 1,672 vehicles. Landscaping plans involve the planting of 200 trees to enhance the environment of the estate.

title: Singrobo - Ahouaty Hydropower Plant, Cote D'Ivoire
body: Ivoire Hydro Energy is spearheading the development of the Singrobo - Ahouaty Hydropower Plant in Cote D'Ivoire. This initiative encompasses the establishment, operation, and transfer of a hydroelectric facility on the Bandama River, complemented by a 3.5-kilometer transmission line and substation for efficient power distribution. Located approximately 150 kilometers north of Abidjan, the plant holds the potential to provide electricity to around 100,000 households, while concurrently mitigating Côte d’Ivoire’s carbon footprint by reducing CO2 emissions by an estimated 109,000 tons annually.

title: Lugu Dam Embankment Reconstruction, Nigeria
body: The Ministry of Environment in Sokoto State, Nigeria, is rehabilitating the collapsed Lugu Dam embankment in Wurno local government area of Sokoto state. The project scope includes rehabilitating the dam embankment, reconstructing service and auxiliary spillways, providing an emergency spillway for enhanced safety, installing collector or trunk drains at the base of the dam and establishing drain inlet structures. On completion, the project will restore approx. 19 million cubic metres of water in the Lugu Dam and rehabilitate 1,300 hectares of irrigable land.

title: Lichtenburg 1 PV Solar Facility, South Africa
body: African Rainbow Minerals (ARM) has unveiled plans to erect the Lichtenburg 1 PV solar facility in Lichtenburg, South Africa, marking a notable stride in renewable energy development. This initiative entails the establishment of a solar facility within the North West province, facilitated by successful negotiations with local commercial banks and partners by the Independent Power Producer (IPP). With secured funding, the construction of a 132MWp solar project is set to commence, promising a substantial contribution to the region's renewable energy infrastructure and sustainable energy objectives. The solar PV plant will feature 201,252 bifacial solar modules mounted on single-axis trackers, spanning 105 hectares and generating 295,347 MWh of energy annually—enough to supply electricity to over 40,000 households. Moreover, the project is expected to mitigate over 209,589 tons of carbon dioxide emissions annually, further cementing its environmental significance.

title: Muvumba Multipurpose Dam and Hydropower Plant, Rwanda
body:
The Rwanda Water Resources Board (RWB) is undertaking the development of the Muvumba Multipurpose Dam in Rwanda. Located on the Muvumba River, which flows through northeastern Rwanda and southwestern Uganda, this dam is situated in the upper headwaters of the River Nile. Apart from flood control, it will also serve the needs of livestock watering. The dam will reach a height of 39 meters and have a storage capacity of 55 million cubic meters. It is designed to fulfill various purposes such as domestic water supply and irrigation across a net command area of 9,640 hectares, encompassing Tabagwe, Gatunda, Karama, Rukomo, Nyagatare, Rwempasha, Musheri, and Rwimiyaga sectors.

The initiative spearheaded by Ruzigana includes extensive landscape restoration efforts. These include the creation of 352 hectares of radical terraces and 2,340 hectares of progressive terraces. Additionally, 239 hectares will be designated for afforestation, while 1,537 hectares will be dedicated to agroforestry. A hydropower station with a capacity of 1 MW (500 KW x 2) is expected to generate 6.94 GWh annually.

title: Ohangwena II Wellfield Water Supply Schemes (WSS), Namibia
body: The Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Land Reform, in collaboration with NamWater, has launched the Ohangwena II Well Field Water Supply Schemes project at Eenhana in the Ohangwena region. This initiative, part of the Namibia Water Sector Support Program, will develop the Ohangwena Aquifer as a secondary bulk water source for the central northern area. The project aims to improve water infrastructure and ensure sustainable, high-quality water access for Eenhana and surrounding communities amid rising demand due to population growth and industrialization. Key elements include enhancing infrastructure, equipping boreholes, expanding a Reverse Osmosis Plant, constructing reservoirs, and updating pipelines to meet water needs projected for 2037.

title: Okavango Bridge, Botswana
body:
The Ministry of Transport and Communications plans to construct a bridge in Botswana. The project scope entails the construction of the Okavango Bridge, which will connect villages on the east side of the river with the rest of the country. The bridge will span from the Mohembo East (Kauxwi) ferry landing site to the Mohembo West (Shakawe) ferry landing site.

A unique feature of the bridge is its 54-meter-high pylons, designed to resemble elephant tusks. With a length of 1,161 meters, it will be the longest bridge in Botswana. The bridge will feature two lanes, and two pedestrian walkways, and will measure 12.5 meters in width. It is the first bridge to be constructed over the Okavango River, which is part of the Okavango Delta, the 1000th World Heritage site.

title: Rehabilitation of Lubumbashi to Lobito, Angola
body: The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has announced a collaborative project aimed at rehabilitating the railway line that connects the Congolese mining regions to the Atlantic Ocean. This ambitious undertaking involves the modernization and rehabilitation of the 1700-kilometer railway line stretching from Lubumbashi in the DRC to Lobito in Angola.The primary goal of this project is to facilitate the efficient transportation of key resources such as copper cobalt and other commodities from the DRC to global markets. By enhancing the transportation infrastructure the project aims to bolster trade and stimulate economic development in both countries.

title: Mwache Multipurpose Dam, Kenya
body: Ministry of Water & Sanitation and Irrigation (Kenya) is developing the Mwache Dam project as part of the second phase of the Water Security and Climate Resilience programme which focuses on Mombasa and Kwale counties. The multi-purpose dam will be an 87.5-meter-tall concrete gravity dyke impounding 230 million liters of water each day. The dam will be built on the Mwache River in the village of Fulugani. The structure will cover an area of 250000 hectares with an 87.5 m high concrete gravity dam. The dam lake that will be formed is expected to hold 118 million m3 of water. The dammed water will irrigate 2600 hectares of land in Kwale County.

title: Nachtigal Hydro Power Project, Cameroon
body:
The Nachtigal Hydro Power Company (NHPC) is undertaking the development of the Nachtigal Hydro Power Project, located on the Sanaga River near Nachtigal Falls, approximately 65km from Yaoundé, the capital city of Cameroon. The Nachtigal hydro power plant is a 420MW run-of-river project, with a planned hydro reservoir capacity of 27.8 million cubic meters and a gross head of 50 meters. This project is expected to generate 2,900 GWh of electricity annually.The Nachtigal hydropower plant will feature two roller-compacted concrete dams on the Sanaga River, each approximately 2km in length and 15m in height. The reservoir will cover a surface area of 4.21 km² and have a storage capacity of 27.8 million cubic meters.

The Nachtigal Hydro Power Project is funded through a combination of equity and debt financing. The equity contributions come from several stakeholders, including EDF International, IFC, the Republic of Cameroon, Africa50, and STOA. The debt financing is provided by a consortium of major development financing institutions and local commercial banks, including the African Development Bank, IFC, FMO, AFD, Proparco, Africa Finance Corporation, and others.

title: Paardevlei Solar PV Plant, South Africa
body: The city of Cape Town is currently planning a ground-mounted solar photovoltaic (PV) and battery storage project at Paardevlei, situated near Somerset West, South Africa. This initiative entails the development of a 60 MW power plant dedicated to generating renewable energy. Anticipated to produce up to 60 MW, the project aims to mitigate the impact of Eskom's load-shedding by supplying sufficient electricity to counteract one complete stage of power reduction. Strategically positioned on a 400-hectare city-owned site, this project plays a crucial role in bolstering local energy resilience and reducing reliance on conventional energy sources, thereby advancing sustainable energy objectives in the region.

title: Narok Milk Processing Plant, Kenya
body: The government, through the newly established Kenya Cooperative Creameries (KCC), is poised to construct a milk processing plant in Narok County to enhance milk productivity and increase farmers' incomes. By developing these facilities, KCC aims to eliminate the practice of hawking milk, where farmers currently sell a litre for as low as KSh 30, and establish a standard buying price of no less than KSh 50. The initiative targets a significant increase in national milk production, with a goal to raise output from 1.5 million liters to 4.5 million liters by empowering farmers to boost their production. The project is expected to create 200 direct jobs and another 1,000 indirect jobs, which will contribute to reducing unemployment rates in the county, with most of these positions being filled by local residents.

title: Pan-African Memorial Park Development, Zimbabwe
body:
The African Liberation Museum plans to construct a Pan-African Memorial Park development. Zimbabwe recently provided Namibia with a one-acre parcel of land in Liberation City Harare’s Pan-African Memorial Park and the Museum of African Liberation Project for the construction of an outdoor monument honoring Namibia’s liberation from South Africa’s apartheid regime.
The Pan-African Memorial Park will encompass a Museum of African Liberation that will Showcase the history of liberation struggles across the continent through exhibits artifacts and educational programs. A Monument of the African Liberation a yet-to-be-designed iconic structure symbolizing the continent's fight for freedom an amphitheater that will Host cultural events conferences and other gatherings. A Research Center dedicated to studying African history and promoting pan-Africanism. Memorial Wall: Honoring fallen heroes of liberation movements and finally the Theme Park and botanical garden that would offer recreational activities and educational experiences and even highlight the diverse flora of Africa.
meta_description: The African Liberation Museum plans to construct a Pan-African Memorial Park development. Zimbabwe recently provided Namibia with a one-acre parcel of land in Liberation City Harare’s Pan-African Memorial Park and the Museum of African Liberation Project for the construction of an outdoor monument honoring Namibia’s liberation from South Africa’s apartheid regime.
migration_status: success

title: KZN - Mozambique Border Barriers: Phase 1, South Africa
body:
The South African National Defence Force (SANDF) plans to construct a border wall between South Africa and Mozambique. The project scope encompasses the construction of a concrete wall along the border of South Africa and Mozambique. This decision was made recently by the KwaZulu-Natal Provincial Government as part of its measures to stop vehicle theft and the movement of illicit goods.

The concrete wall, also referred to as New Jersey Barriers, will run for a stretch of eight kilometers, starting from the boundary of the iSimangaliso Wetlands Park and extending to the western boundary of Tembe Elephant Park.

body: The Department of Mineral Resources and Energy is poised to advance the development of 2,500 megawatts (MW) of nuclear capacity in South Africa, aiming to enhance national security and energy sovereignty. The initiative stands at a pivotal moment, ready to contribute significantly to the country's energy demands and climate objectives. As the South African government progresses with this development, successful collaboration with international partners and a thorough assessment of economic and environmental factors will be crucial to unlocking the full potential of nuclear energy in the region.

title: Maai Mahiu - Suswa Reconstruction of Transport Road, Kenya
body: The Kenya National Highways Authority (KeNHA) is set to redesign and reconstruct the 41 km Maai Mahiu-Suswa road a crucial route to Western Kenya and the Maasai Mara Reserve. Recurrent disruptions particularly during the rainy season and geological faults in the Rift Valley area have prompted this initiative. The project involves expanding the road to accommodate larger vehicles and traffic volumes utilizing advanced technologies such as bridges and concrete slabs to address unstable surfaces. An interchange near Naivasha ICD and Industrial park will enhance traffic flow and safety featuring pedestrian walkways.

title: Kenhardt Projects South Africa
body:
The Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE) plans to construct three Kenhardt projects in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa under the Risk Mitigation Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme (RMIPPPP).

Once operational the project will have a total solar capacity of 540 MW and battery storage capacity of 225MW/1140MWh and provide 150 MW of dispatchable power under a 20-year Power Purchase Agreement to the Kenhardt region – in a country that is currently suffering from power shortages.

title: Kenya-Ethiopia Rail, Ethiopia/Kenya
body:
The LAPSSET Corridor Development Authority will be developing the Kenya-Ethiopia High-Speed Electric Railway line from its Indian Ocean port of Lamu to Ethiopia and then later extend to South Sudan. The standard gauge railway will cover a distance of 3,000 kilometers, and will link the brand-new port to Isiolo. The rail line will later branch into three routes to Addis Ababa, Juba and also the city of Nairobi.

Route Segments

  • Lamu to Isiolo (Kenya) 533 km
  • Nairobi to Isiolo (Kenya) ~270 km
  • Isiolo (Kenya) to Juba (South Sudan) ~1,200 km
  • Isiolo (Kenya) to Addis Ababa (Ethiopia) ~1,250 km

title: Koru - Soin Multi - Purpose Dam, Kenya
body: Kenya's National Water Harvesting and Storage Authority is developing the Koru-Soin multipurpose dam located about 5 km upstream of Muhoroni town and across the Nyando River that forms the boundary between Kericho and Kisumu Counties. The proposed project will reduce the flooding problem on the lower reaches of River Nyando. It will also supply 72000m3/day of water for domestic use provide irrigation for 2570 Hectares of land and generate 2.5MW of hydropower. The dam is proposed to be a zoned rock-fill dam with an impermeable clay core. It will have the water storage capacity of 93.7 million cubic meters.

title: Marula Green Power Plant, South Africa
body:
The Palabora Mining Company plans to construct a Marula Green Power plant at Phalaborwa. The project scope encompasses to establish a 132 MWp Marula Green Power plant and battery energy storage system. The storage system will have the capacity to store 310 MWh of electricity in light of a clean affordable and reliable electricity supply.
Mzansi Energy will design finance install operate and maintain the plant for 12 years. The plant will be based within the municipal jurisdiction of Ba-Phalaborwa Limpopo just outside Namakgale township and will be approximately 20km from the mine.

title: Kribi Port Container Terminal: Phase 2, Cameroon
body: The Autonomous Port of Kribi (PAK) in Cameroon is set to undertake Phase 2 of the Kribi Port Container Terminal project. The primary objective is to enhance the port's capabilities in accommodating larger vessels and increasing cargo throughput. This phase involves the construction of a 715-meter long quay and the establishment of two new container berths designed to handle vessels of up to 11,000 TEU (Twenty-foot Equivalent Unit) capacity. Additionally, it includes the development of 32 hectares of additional open space, which will significantly expand operational capacity to process 1.3 million TEUs. The project also focuses on upgrading infrastructure and equipment to align with the latest international standards, thereby improving overall efficiency and service quality at the port.

title: Malawi - Mozambique Power Transmission Line, Mozambique
body: The Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi (ESCOM) and Electricidade de Moçambique are collaborating on the Malawi-Mozambique Power Transmission Interconnection Project. This project involves constructing a 218-kilometre, 400-kilovolt transmission line from Matambo in Mozambique to the Phombeya Power Sub-station in Balaka District, Malawi. The new high-voltage line will enable Malawi to import up to 120 megawatts of power from Mozambique, significantly enhancing its local electricity supply.

title: Kampala Outer Ring Road, Uganda
body: Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) planning to construct Kampala Outer Beltway, also known as the Kampala Outer Ring Road in Uganda. The project which is estimated to cover a distance of about 100 Kilometers is set to change the face of Uganda’s capital. The proposed route would begin on the Kampala-Jinja Expressway near Seeta in Mukono Town, some 16 kilometers east of Kampala. Running from Bukeerere in Mukono District to Nsangi on the Kampalab - Mpigi Expressway, it would then extend west through Namugongo, Kira, Kasangati, Matugga, Wakiso, and Buloba.

title: Lanet Military Strip Phase 1, Kenya
body: Kenya Airports Authority is converting the Lanet military airstrip into a civilian airport. Phase one of the project involves construction of a 1.7km runway; construction of taxiways and terminals; a military lounge; air rescue centre; fence; and military and civilian gate. The runway strip will be 150 metres wide with four taxiways and a military apron that will be able to accommodate larger and heavier commercial aircrafts such as Beechcraft 1900.

title: Kampala - Bombo Expressway, Uganda
body: The Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) is in the planning stages for the construction of the Kampala-Bombo Expressway in Uganda. This proposed four-lane, dual-carriage highway will span approximately 32 kilometers, connecting Kampala to Bombo in Luwero district. Commencing from Wandegeya, it will traverse through Bwaise, Kawempe, Matugga, and culminate at Bombo. The primary goals of this project are to enhance capacity along this vital section of the Northern Corridor and to mitigate transport time and costs by upgrading road infrastructure.

title: Pomona City, Zimbabwe
body:
Also known as Project Title: Pomona Smart City. WestProp Holdings Limited (WHL) is developing Pomona city in Zimbabwe's Harare region. The project is a residential and commercial estate, and is situated on 273-hactares of land.

  • Location: Harare, Zimbabwe
  • Project Type: Mixed-use development (residential and commercial)
  • Phases: 3 (Current: Phase 1 under development)

Scope of Work – Phase 1

  • Total Residential Units in Phase 1: 745 stands
    • Phase 1A: 140 residential stands
    • Phase 1B and 1C: 595 residential stands
  • Plot Sizes: Each residential unit is planned on plots ranging from 500 m² to 1,000 m²

Additional Notes:

  • The project is a planned mixed residential and commercial estate, with commercial and public amenities to be defined in future phases.
  • The current scope covers infrastructure servicing, such as internal roads, drainage, water supply, and electricity connections, to accommodate the first 745 housing plots.
  • Subsequent phases are expected to expand the residential offering and introduce commercial, retail, and institutional components.

title: Kenhardt Projects South Africa
body:
The Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE) plans to construct three Kenhardt projects in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa under the Risk Mitigation Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme (RMIPPPP).

Once operational the project will have a total solar capacity of 540 MW and battery storage capacity of 225MW/1140MWh and provide 150 MW of dispatchable power under a 20-year Power Purchase Agreement to the Kenhardt region – in a country that is currently suffering from power shortages.

title: Kenya-Ethiopia Rail, Ethiopia/Kenya
body:
The LAPSSET Corridor Development Authority will be developing the Kenya-Ethiopia High-Speed Electric Railway line from its Indian Ocean port of Lamu to Ethiopia and then later extend to South Sudan. The standard gauge railway will cover a distance of 3,000 kilometers, and will link the brand-new port to Isiolo. The rail line will later branch into three routes to Addis Ababa, Juba and also the city of Nairobi.

Route Segments

  • Lamu to Isiolo (Kenya) 533 km
  • Nairobi to Isiolo (Kenya) ~270 km
  • Isiolo (Kenya) to Juba (South Sudan) ~1,200 km
  • Isiolo (Kenya) to Addis Ababa (Ethiopia) ~1,250 km

title: Hive Green Ammonia Plant, South Africa
body:
Also known as Coega Green Ammonia project. 

Overview

A large-scale green ammonia facility designed to support clean energy transition through renewable hydrogen and ammonia production.

Key Components

  • Electrolysis Capacity: 1,200 MW (for hydrogen production via water electrolysis)
  • Renewable Energy Feed:
    • Solar PV: 1,445 MW
    • Onshore Wind: 2,205 MW
    • Total Renewable Input: 3,650 MW
  • Green Ammonia Output: Approx. 950,000 tonnes per year

Process Flow

  • Seawater Desalination → Clean water for electrolysis
  • Electrolysis Unit → Produces hydrogen
  • Air Separation Unit (ASU) → Extracts nitrogen
  • Ammonia Synthesis → Combines hydrogen + nitrogen
  • Output → Green ammonia for domestic use/export
specifications: ["1.445 GW solar","2.205 GW wind","950,000 TPA green ammonia"]

title: Kenya-Tanzania Highway: Phase 1, Kenya
body: The Kenya National Highways Authority (KeNHA) is preparing to launch a significant 454 km highway project aimed at connecting Kenya and Tanzania. The project will be implemented in phases, with phase one covering 54 km in Kenya and 120 km in Tanzania. In Kenya, the highway will start at the proposed New Mtwapa Bridge near Mtwapa town and will extend northward through Mtwapa, Majengo, Kanamai, Kwa Kadzengo, Kijipwa, Shariani, Takaungu, and Mavueni, concluding in Kilifi. In Tanzania, the route will proceed from Mkange, passing through Tungumaa, and ending at Pangani.

title: Abuja Mass Transit Railway, Nigeria
body: The Abuja rail mass transit project is being developed by the Federal Capital Development Authority (FCDA). The rail line is planned to cover a total distance of 290 km and be developed in six phases or lots. The 42.5 km Lot 1 which has been completed has two lines and 12 stations connecting the Abuja City Centre with the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport. Lot 2 connects from Gwagwa through the metro station to Nyanya/Karu. The Blue Line (Lot 3) is expected to pass through Idu to Kubwa with stations in Idu Gwagwa Deidei Kagini and Gbazango. Lot 4 is from Kuje to Karshi with the remaining legs of the transit-way line 2. Lot 5 is expected to be from Kubwa via Bwari to Suleja and Lot 6 from the airport via Kuje and Gwagwalada to Dobi.

title: Giyani Bulk Water Pipeline, South Africa
body:
The Department of Water and Sanitation (DWS) plans to develop Bulk Water Project to ensure water delivery to 55 villages in Giyani. The project is being developed in various phases:

1. Nandoni Water Service Scheme: The dam will be upgraded from 60 Ml/d to 120 Ml/d to feed the bulk water pipeline projects to extend the supply from Nandoni water treatment works to Malamulele Vuwani Elim Makhado and the Sinthumule Kutama areas.
2. Nandoni to Nsami: This involves expanding the existing raw water pump station Nandoni to cater for the Nsami/Giyani pipeline (40 km) and utilising the existing new infrastructure to support the Mavambe bulk main pipe which includes modifying the existing Mavambe pump station at Nandoni
3. Giyani Water Treatment Works: Phase 1 of the project entails refurbishment of the existing 30 Ml/d. Phase 2 of the project involes upgrade of the water treatment work from 30 MI/d to 40 MI/d.
4. Giyani Water Service Project: Revitalisation of 154 boreholes and the installation of package plants.
5. Reticulation to 55 villages in Giyani

body: The Zimbabwe National Water Authority (ZINWA) is undertaking the development of the Dande Dam situated in Guruve, Zimbabwe. With a substantial capacity of 160 million cubic meters, the dam aims to support extensive agricultural irrigation, covering a minimum of 4,000 hectares of land. Moreover, the dam's irrigation capabilities extend even further, reaching up to 4,500 hectares of land, promising significant agricultural benefits for the area.

title: Batoka Gorge Hydro Electricity Scheme, Zimbabwe
body: Zambezi River Authority is developing the Batoka Gorge Hydro Electricity Scheme (BHES) a 2.4GW hydroelectric project located across the boundary between Zambia and Zimbabwe on the Zambezi River approximately 54km downstream of the Victoria Waterfall .The project scope encompasses a run-of-the-river hydroelectric facility comprising a 181m-high and 720m-long roller compacted concrete (RCC) gravity arch dam and two 1200MW surface power plants on the north and south banks of the Zambezi River. Each power plant will be equipped with six 200MW hydro turbines.The reservoir will have a catchment area of 508000km² and four intakes which will take the water through 4.2km of tunnels to both the power plants to generate electricity.The project aims to have a crest overflow type spillway with 12 radial gates. Each radial gate will measure 13m-high and 14m-wide. The design capacity of the spillway will be 20000m³/s.

title: Unzovu Estate, Botswana
body:
The Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC) is undertaking the construction of the UNZOVU Estate (Kazungula Housing Project) in Botswana. This project, located in the tourism and trade gateway village of Kazungula, includes a total of 212 housing units. The development has been divided into four packages:

Package 1: Consists of 60 housing units, comprising 26 low-income houses, 33 medium-income houses, and 1 high-income house.

Package 2: Includes 51 units, all designated as low-income houses.

Package 3: Involves 36 units of two to three-bedroom flats.

Package 4: Comprises 65 housing units.

These packages reflect the diversified approach of the project, catering to different income brackets and housing needs within the Kazungula area. As part of the infrastructure for the development, the Corporation will also undertake construction of internal roads, storm water drainage and water reticulation.

title: Boegoebaai Green Hydrogen Programme, South Africa
body:
Sasol plans to develop the Boegoebaai Green Hydrogen Programme within the Namakwa Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in the Northern Cape, South Africa. This large-scale initiative aims to establish a global hub for green hydrogen and its derivatives. Designated as a Strategic Integrated Project (SIP) under the South African National Development Plan, Boegoebaai already hosts an established hydrogen production plant. The expanded development is expected to include an additional 60,000 hectares adjacent to the existing plant.

Sasol’s plans include:

  • Constructing 10 GW of electrolyser capacity at the Boegoebaai SEZ.
  • Developing 240,000 hectares for renewable energy generation infrastructure.
  • Partnering with the private sector to build a green hydrogen pipeline system connecting projects across the province to the SEZ.
  • Collaborating with State-owned freight and logistics group Transnet to deploy dedicated rail infrastructure, linking green hydrogen producers to the SEZ and other ports in the country by 2030.

This comprehensive plan is set to significantly enhance South Africa's green hydrogen production capabilities, positioning the country as a leader in the global green hydrogen economy.

title: Doornhoek PV Project, South Africa
body:
• AMEA Power has been awarded a 120 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) project near Klerksdorp in South Africa's North West Province as part of the Sixth Bid Submission Phase of the Renewable Energy Independent Power Producer Procurement (REIPPP) Programme
  • The Doornhoek PV Project will sell electricity to the state utility, Eskom, under a 20-year Power Purchase Agreement
  • It is expected to power 97,000 households annually and have a future life of 30 years
  • The project owners are AMEA Power: 51%; Local Community Trust: 2.5%; and a consortium wholly owned by African women, formed by Ziyanda Energy and Dzimuzwo Consulting: 46.5% (WindWorks Holdings (Pty): 64.52%; and K2022301132 (South Africa) (Pty) Ltd: 35.48%

 

Transmission Network Connection:

The Facility will connect to the existing Eskom network at the Klerksdorp North 132/11kV Substation and the Brakspruit 132/22kV Substation line by establishing a 132kV Switching Station on the Property. The Project Company has applied for grid connection under the Eskom selfbuild Programme, as such the Project Company will construct the grid connection works and transfer the assets over to Eskom at COD

The Self-build Works are:
• Establish 132kV switching station with two 132kV feeder bays for one incomer and one outgoing
• Cut in the 132kV line and create a Loop-In Loop-Out (LILO) between the Brakspruit and Klerksdorp North substations
• Build 100m of 132kV Kingbird overhead line from the existing 132kV line to LILO on the 132kV Switching Station
• Install metering at the 132kV Switching Station
• Shift the normal open point from Klerksdorp North 132/11kV substation to the new 132kV Switching Station

Planned voltage connection level: 132 kV
Planned connection point: new 132kV Doornhoek PV Switching Station, between Klerksdorp north 132/11kV and Brakspruit 132/22kV substation line

title: 48 Glover Mixed-Use Development, Nigeria
body: Orangeline Design & Development Company is developing a mixed-use project at 48 Glover Road in the upscale area of Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria. Covering a land area of 4,999 square meters, this development will feature a blend of residential and commercial spaces, including apartments, maisonettes, and penthouses. The architecture of the project will showcase Orangeline's contemporary design and high-end finishes, creating an appealing environment for both investors and homeowners. This development is part of a larger trend of increased construction activity on Glover Road, driven by spillover demand from nearby prime commercial areas like Alfred Rewane Road.

title: Oji River Industrial Park, Nigeria
body: The Enugu State Government is set to embark on the construction of an Industrial Park in Oji River, Nigeria. Situated in Ugwuoba, near Nnamdi Azikiwe University in Awka, Anambra State, this trade hub is poised to revolutionize the economic terrain. The multi-billion dollar endeavor, beyond its role as a prominent trade complex, will encompass housing estates, recreational facilities, educational institutions, hospitals, and more, leveraging the benefits of its significant economy of scale.

title: Angola Rural Solar Energy Project MCA
body:
The project is part of Angola Solar Mini-Grids & Water Infrastructure Project, also known as Angola's Rural Solar Energy and Water Supply Project.

Angola’s Ministry of Energy and Water has proposed the construction of 48 hybrid PV systems across multiple provinces including Moxico, Lunda Norte, Lunda Sul, Bie, and Malanje. These mini-grid systems are set to have a combined capacity of 296 MW of solar energy supported by energy storage in lithium-ion batteries totaling 719 MWh.

Furthermore, approximately 200,000 households across 60 communities throughout the country are expected to benefit from this initiative. This project represents a significant step towards expanding access to reliable and sustainable energy sources thereby improving the livelihoods and socio-economic development of communities across Angola.
meta_description: The project is part of Angola Solar Mini-Grids & Water Infrastructure Project
migration_status: also known as Angola's Rural Solar Energy and Water Supply Project.

title: Bulawayo - Old Gwanda Road, Zimbabwe
body: The Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure Development, Zimbabwe is preparing to construct a 120km roadway that will connect Bulawayo to Old Gwanda. This infrastructure initiative aims to bring significant benefits to the residents of Matabeleland South province, including job creation, opportunities for domestic tourism, and enhanced business prospects. The project also includes the construction of a substantial bridge over the Mtshabezi River near Gwanda, along with necessary supporting infrastructure.

title: Exapansion of Kribi Container Terminal Cameroon
body: The Autonomous Port of Kribi (PAK) is expanding the port container terminal at the Kribi seaport. The project will increase the will increase the terminal’s container handling capacity from 9000 TEU to 22000 TEU. The project scope includes increasing the surface area of the terminal from 14 to 33 hectares doubling the number of yard gantries from 10 to 20 increasing the number of reefer berths from 192 to 37 and tripling the number of quayside gantries from two to seven.

title: Abidjan Bus Rapid Transit (BRT), Cote d’Ivoire
body: The Urban Mobility Authority in Greater Abidjan (Amuga) is developing a bus line with a very high level of service (Bus Rapid Transit) to connect the outlying communities of Yopougon and Cocody to the Adjamé/Plateau activity centre of the city. With a dedicated corridor along the entire route the service will carry approximately 300000 passengers per day with frequencies exceeding one bus per minute at peak times. Electric buses are being considered in order to limit the air and noise pollution of the service.

title: Bute Multi-Purpose Dam, Kenya
body: Kenya's Ministry of Water & Sanitation and Irrigation is developing the Bute multifunctional dam located in the Lagabro River Basin 7 kilometers north of Bute in Wajir County Kenya. The construction works include an asphalt core rockfill dam with a water storage capacity of 6.69 million cubic meters and a crest height of 25 meters the total filling amount is 750800 cubic meters; the 565-meter-long concrete-lined diversion tunnel has a diameter of 9.7 meters×8.45 meters; the spillway with a total axis length of 524 meters.

title: Abidjan Metro, Côte d'Ivoire
body: The Government of Ivory Coast has announced plans for Abidjan Metro a 37.5 kilometre long elevated rapid transit network to address traffic congestion in the Ivorian economic capital of Abidjan. It will pass through 18 stations linking seven municipalities in Abidjan district. The overground metro will include the construction of 24 bridges eight underpasses a viaduct over the Ebrié lagoon and 34 footbridges for pedestrians. The Abidjan metro will be able to carry more than 500000 passengers a day. The project is expected to generate 2000 jobs.

title: Cape Winelands Airport Expansion, South Africa
body: The Cape Winelands Airport Authority plans to expand its airport in Durbanville, Cape Town. The project scope includes the construction of a boutique terminal building, cargo facilities, and fuel storage buildings on both sides of the realigned 3.5-kilometer-long runway. The expansion will feature open spaces with amenities such as a plaza, hotel, conference center, wine-tasting experiences, an outdoor amphitheater for events hosting up to 5000 people, and an aviation museum.

title: Abuja Mass Transit Railway, Nigeria
body: The Abuja rail mass transit project is being developed by the Federal Capital Development Authority (FCDA). The rail line is planned to cover a total distance of 290 km and be developed in six phases or lots. The 42.5 km Lot 1 which has been completed has two lines and 12 stations connecting the Abuja City Centre with the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport. Lot 2 connects from Gwagwa through the metro station to Nyanya/Karu. The Blue Line (Lot 3) is expected to pass through Idu to Kubwa with stations in Idu Gwagwa Deidei Kagini and Gbazango. Lot 4 is from Kuje to Karshi with the remaining legs of the transit-way line 2. Lot 5 is expected to be from Kubwa via Bwari to Suleja and Lot 6 from the airport via Kuje and Gwagwalada to Dobi.

title: Giyani Bulk Water Pipeline, South Africa
body:
The Department of Water and Sanitation (DWS) plans to develop Bulk Water Project to ensure water delivery to 55 villages in Giyani. The project is being developed in various phases:

1. Nandoni Water Service Scheme: The dam will be upgraded from 60 Ml/d to 120 Ml/d to feed the bulk water pipeline projects to extend the supply from Nandoni water treatment works to Malamulele Vuwani Elim Makhado and the Sinthumule Kutama areas.
2. Nandoni to Nsami: This involves expanding the existing raw water pump station Nandoni to cater for the Nsami/Giyani pipeline (40 km) and utilising the existing new infrastructure to support the Mavambe bulk main pipe which includes modifying the existing Mavambe pump station at Nandoni
3. Giyani Water Treatment Works: Phase 1 of the project entails refurbishment of the existing 30 Ml/d. Phase 2 of the project involes upgrade of the water treatment work from 30 MI/d to 40 MI/d.
4. Giyani Water Service Project: Revitalisation of 154 boreholes and the installation of package plants.
5. Reticulation to 55 villages in Giyani

title: African Court, Tanzania
body: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation has unveiled proposals for the construction of the African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights in Arusha city. This initiative, to be executed by CRJE, will span 24 hectares of land allocated by Tanzania in Laki Laki, situated on the outskirts of Arusha.It will be near the UN Mechanism for International Tribunals (formerly the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda). The African Court is currently a tenant in the Tanzania National Parks main office building.

title: African Liberation Museum, Zimbabwe
body: The Government of Zimbabwe in collabration with The Institute of African Knowledge (INSTAK) and National Social Security Authority (NSSA)  has announced plans to construct the African Liberation Museum within its borders. A critical initial step towards realizing this priority project involved securing support from the host country. Subsequently, efforts focused on identifying and allocating a suitable 100-hectare plot of land for the museum site.

title: N3 Route Construction and Upgrades, South Africa
body:
The South African National Roads Agency SOC Limited (SANRAL) plans to undertake major construction and upgrades on the N3 route between the Westville viaduct and the Paradise Valley interchange.

The project includes the addition of one and two lanes to create a varying four- to six-lane dual carriageway, plus auxiliary lanes where required. Further upgrades will also be made to Eden Road, the Paradise Valley interchange, including the M13 Provincial Route, and the Westville interchange, including Spine Road.

The project will also involve major bridge construction works, including the widening of the Westville and Paradise Valley viaducts, which are between 25 m to 30 m in height above both valleys.

title: Godegode Bridge and its Approach Roads Tanzania
body:
The Tanzania National Roads Agency is actively advancing plans for the construction of the Godegode Bridge spanning 154 meters and its associated approach roads covering 6.0 kilometers along the Mpwapwa - Makutano Junction - Pwaga Junction - Lumuma Road.

This infrastructure project is designed to alleviate traffic congestion and enhance connectivity in the specified region contributing to improved transportation and accessibility.
